Title: The Rise of the "Woke" Mob: A Threat to Free Speech and Academic Freedom

The recent trend of "woke" activism has led to a surge in mob mentality, where individuals are being targeted and ostracized for holding differing opinions. The latest examples include the cases of University of Chicago professor Harold Uhlig and author J.K. Rowling, who have both faced backlash for expressing views deemed unacceptable by the "woke" crowd.

Uhlig, a professor and head of the Journal of Political Economy, was placed on leave after tweeting that the Black Lives Matter movement "torpedoed itself" with its support of defunding the police. Hundreds of people signed a petition demanding his resignation, with prominent economists like Janet Yellen and Paul Krugman joining the chorus. However, Uhlig's comments were not intended to belittle the concerns of those less fortunate, as claimed by some.

Similarly, Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, faced backlash for expressing her concerns about the growing number of young women transitioning. She was accused of being "transphobic" and "hate-mongering," with some staff at her publisher refusing to work on her next book. However, Rowling stood her ground, stating that it's not hate to speak the truth and mocking a charity that used the phrase "people who menstruate" instead of women.

The "woke" mob has also targeted others, including David Shor, an analyst at Democratic polling firm Civis Analytics, who was fired after tweeting that race riots reduced Democratic vote share. His bosses took action despite his issuing a groveling apology.

Robby Soave, senior editor at magazine, notes that there is a cruel streak in activism that says, "If you disagree with me, you have no right to speak." He believes that people are afraid to challenge the "woke" crowd, and it only takes one employee at one company to say, "Here's the law that protects my rights to feel safe and comfortable in this workplace. If you're not making me feel safe and comfortable, I'm going to get you in trouble."

The University of Chicago stood up to the mob, reinstating Uhlig after a 10-day investigation found no basis for taking away his job. Rowling's publisher also defended her, stating that freedom of speech is the cornerstone of publishing.

The rise of the "woke" mob is a threat to free speech and academic freedom. It's essential to challenge these individuals and stand up for those who are being targeted. As Soave notes, "The solution is to challenge these people. We just have to speak up."

Title: Turkey's Shoot-Down of Russian Fighter Jet Highlights Challenges in Building Anti-IS Coalition

The recent shoot-down of a Russian fighter jet by Turkey, which strayed into its airspace from Syria, has underscored the difficulties in building a broad international coalition to destroy the self-proclaimed Islamic State (IS). Despite President Obama's announcement of a coalition of over 50 countries to "degrade and ultimately destroy" IS, also known as ISIS, more than a year ago, there is still no effective alliance of major powers.

French President François Hollande, who will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday, has made building a coalition his goal in the wake of the Paris attacks. However, the same challenges remain: major players deeply mistrust one another's intentions and visions for a post-Islamic State Syria.

Turkey and Russia exemplify the complex and often contradictory motives that Hollande will try to manage. Turkey's anti-IS coalition supposedly shares similar aims with Russia, including the removal of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad as a key step toward reducing IS's allure for Syrian Sunnis. However, it took months of sustained diplomatic effort for the United States to bring Turkey on board, and even now, the differences between the US and Turkey remain pronounced.

The US has sent special operations forces to the region to help Syrian and Iraqi Kurds, who have been effective fighters against IS. However, Turkey has a large Kurdish population and worries that empowering Kurds anywhere in the region might create trouble at home. Turkey has been "friendlier towards ISIS than Russia" because of Turkey's satisfaction with the setbacks that IS has dealt Syria's Kurdish rebels.

Many countries in the region find ISIS useful to have around and are in no rush to get rid of it, as it is virulently anti-Shiite and acts as a counterbalance to Iran and the Shiite parties in the region. Russia says it entered the Syrian conflict to defeat Syria's "terrorists," but analysts say its airstrikes in Syria have focused on Assad's opponents, with only about a quarter targeting IS.

The recent incident has made it even harder for Hollande to get Turkey and Russia on the same page for destroying IS, a priority for neither. Russia has canceled Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's visit to Turkey and warned that the perpetrators of the "crime" will face "serious consequences." NATO has called an emergency meeting of alliance ambassadors, and the incident is the first shoot-down of a Russian aircraft by a NATO country since the 1950s.

Russia insists the fighter jet did not stray outside Syria, while Turkish officials said the jet was warned 10 times to turn back from its trajectory into Turkish airspace. The incident has further illustrated the difficulty of building a united anti-IS coalition that includes Russia.

**Pence's Speech at Patrick Henry College Met with Protests and Low Attendance**

Indiana Governor Mike Pence, the running mate of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, delivered a stump speech at Patrick Henry College in Purcellville, Virginia, on Saturday. However, the event was met with protests and low attendance, illustrating the challenges Trump faces in appealing to evangelical Christians, particularly younger ones.

The college, known for its conservative leanings, has a history of anti-Trump sentiment, with an estimated 75% of students opposing the Republican nominee. Students protested outside the event, while those inside stood in silent protest until they were ejected mid-speech.

Pence's speech was marked by awkward moments, as he seemed to downplay Trump's controversial views and policies. He spoke about free trade, as if Trump had not run a campaign slamming international trade, and criticized Hillary Clinton's plan to tax the rich, as if the Republican nominee had not taken aim at Wall Street.

The event was also marred by poor attendance, with the room being only half-full. This was a stark contrast to Marco Rubio's visit to the college during the Republican primaries, which drew a large crowd.

The protests outside the college were peaceful, with students holding signs reading "PHC is Not Trump Country," "Immigrants Make America Great," and "For Christ and Liberty, Not Bigotry And Idiocy." Some locals passed by, honking in support, while one driver flipped off the protesters and yelled "TRUMP!"

The event highlights the challenges Trump faces in appealing to evangelical Christians, particularly younger ones, who are turned off by his tone, campaign ideas, and personal history.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Apologizes to Native Americans Over Past Claim of Tribal Heritage

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren offered a public apology to Native Americans on Monday, addressing the controversy surrounding her past claim of tribal heritage. Warren, a Massachusetts senator, spoke at the Frank LaMere Native American Presidential Forum in Sioux City, Iowa, where she acknowledged her mistakes and expressed regret for any harm caused.

Warren's remarks were an attempt to move past the fallout from her past claims of tribal ancestry, which sparked criticism and ridicule from President Donald Trump. The issue nearly derailed her campaign in the early days, with Trump derisively referring to her as "Pocahontas." Warren's campaign website had previously featured a video and materials about her DNA analysis, which showed evidence of a tribal ancestor as far back as 10 generations, but the Cherokee Nation and other Native Americans rebuked her for attributing tribal membership to genetics.

Warren's apology was well-received by attendees at the Native American forum, with some expressing appreciation for her willingness to acknowledge her mistakes and move forward. Manny Iron Hawk, a 62-year-old resident of the Cheyenne River Sioux reservation in South Dakota, said Warren "did excellent" in her appearance and has done a good job of addressing her past mistakes.

However, not all attendees were satisfied with Warren's apology. Snuffy Main, a 64-year-old member of the Gros Ventre Tribe of Montana, said he doesn't think Warren needs to continue apologizing for claiming Native American heritage. "I don't understand why she is constantly apologetic for making a mistake," he said.

Warren's appearance at the Native American forum was part of her efforts to prove to voters that the controversy won't doom her in a general election matchup against Trump. She also fielded questions about her proposals, including a legislative change for a Supreme Court ruling that impedes tribal governments' ability to prosecute crimes committed on tribal lands by those who don't belong to a tribe.

Warren's campaign has been gaining momentum, and she drew her largest crowd yet – 12,000 people – to an outdoor rally at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota, later on Monday.

Title: FBI Under Fire for Failure to Act on Tip About Florida School Shooting Suspect

The FBI is facing intense scrutiny over its failure to act on a tip received in January about Nikolas Cruz, the 19-year-old suspect in the Florida school shooting that left 17 people dead. The agency's director, Christopher Wray, has apologized for the "failures" and promised to investigate the circumstances surrounding the incident.

The tip, received on January 5, warned of Cruz's gun ownership, desire to kill people, erratic behavior, and disturbing social media posts, as well as the potential for him to conduct a school shooting. However, the FBI has admitted that protocols were not followed, and the information was not properly assessed as a potential threat to life.

The FBI's failure to act on the tip has sparked outrage, with Florida Governor Rick Scott calling for Director Wray to resign. Attorney General Jeff Sessions has also announced a review into how the FBI handles indications of potential violence.

The incident has also raised questions about how local police responded to concerns about Cruz. Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel said his office received 20 "calls for service" about Cruz, but did not provide further details.

The FBI has been criticized in the past for failing to prevent other attacks, including the 2009 Fort Hood shooting, the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, and the 2016 Orlando nightclub shooting. The agency receives thousands of tips daily, with about 100 considered "actionable."

The investigation into the Florida school shooting is ongoing, and Cruz has been charged with 17 counts of murder. The incident has sparked renewed debates about gun control and school safety.

Title: Christine Blasey Ford Testifies Before Senate Committee, Eliciting Widespread Support and Criticism

Article:

Christine Blasey Ford, a 51-year-old psychology professor from California, testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 27, 2018, detailing her allegation that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers. Ford's testimony was met with a mix of reactions, with many praising her as a brave and credible witness, while others questioned her credibility and accused her of orchestrating a partisan attack against Kavanaugh.

Ford's testimony began with her stating she was "terrified," and she appeared nervous and emotional throughout her account. However, she remained firm and dignified, detailing the alleged assault and its lasting impact on her life. Her testimony was widely praised by many, including prominent conservatives, who acknowledged her credibility and bravery.

The #MeToo movement, which has been associated with high-profile men accused of misconduct, saw Ford emerge as a compelling figure, with many American women identifying with her story. Thousands of conservatives took to social media to accuse Ford of lying, but many Republicans, including some prominent figures, praised her testimony.

The Republican Party posted online videos of women supporting Kavanaugh throughout Ford's testimony, while a GoFundMe page to support Ford and pay for her security and legal expenses quickly raised over $412,000. The Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network (RAINN) reported a 147% increase in calls to its support hotline after the hearing.

An analysis by the Ipsos polling firm found that positive sentiment towards Ford increased each time she spoke, with people responding strongly to her testimony. While some Republicans questioned Ford's credibility, many others, including some conservative strategists and commentators, praised her as a credible and brave witness.

The testimony sparked a national conversation about sexual assault, trauma, and the #MeToo movement, with many Americans weighing in on social media and in public forums. The outcome of the hearing and the subsequent confirmation of Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court remain uncertain, but Christine Blasey Ford's testimony has undoubtedly had a lasting impact on the national conversation.

Title: The Paradox of American Prosperity and Social Isolation

The United States is experiencing a paradox: despite its economic prosperity, social anxiety and unhappiness are on the rise. According to the Sustainable Development Solutions Network, a United Nations initiative, social support networks in the US have weakened over time. This decline is reflected in various statistics, including a decrease in marriage rates, a shrinking average household size, and an increase in loneliness.

The article highlights the decline of social connections and community, citing a decrease in church attendance, a decline in the number of people knowing their neighbors, and a decrease in everyday charity and philanthropy. The author notes that this trend is not limited to the general population, but also affects the elite, who may have the means to navigate a world without strong social connections but still value their social status.

The article suggests that this decline in social connections is a key factor in the current state of American politics, with both the left and right emphasizing shared burdens and duties to one another. The author notes that politicians will need to address this issue, as it is one of the few areas where Americans can collectively discuss the quality of their social relations and sense of morality.

The article concludes that the decline of the social treasury is not easily addressed by political policy, but politicians will need to learn to address the issue of social isolation and loneliness in order to understand the quiet desperation that many Americans feel despite their economic prosperity.

**Trump's Words Continue to Cause Trouble**

The past six days since the firing of James Comey have brought new reasons to question the words from the White House press office and the Vice President of the United States. The president's words have been causing trouble in virtually every aspect of his job, with his attacks on major institutions of government taking a toll on his credibility and that of the White House.

The Trump administration is set to argue before a federal appeals court on Monday to reverse a judge's March order that blocked the president's revised travel ban. The administration contends that the ban is a vital component of a strategy to prevent potential terrorists from entering the country.

Meanwhile, associates of fired FBI Director James Comey believe that the former director's first comments on his termination would likely come in an open session before Congress. Comey declined an invitation to speak to a closed session of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday and was replaced on a panel testifying before that committee last Thursday by his temporary replacement, Acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe.

The Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chair, Mark Warner, expressed his desire to have Comey testify in a public hearing, stating that he believes Comey deserves his chance to lay out the facts about his firing. Nikki Haley, the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, defended President Trump's firing of Comey, stating that the president is the CEO of the country and can hire and fire anyone he wants.

Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper believes that Russia likely sees Comey's firing as "another victory on the scoreboard for them." The U.S. believes that North Korea launched a KN-17 medium-range missile on Saturday, marking the first successful test of the missile.

The article also mentions recent news and analysis from ABC News, including a warning from former White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus to senior staff to stop trying to secretly slip news articles to President Trump, and a warning from law enforcement officials that the worst of the global cyberattack may be yet to come.

Title: Representative Ocasio-Cortez Discusses Congressional Pay Raises and Lobbying

Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) recently discussed the possibility of a $4,500 pay raise for members of Congress, which she characterized as a cost-of-living adjustment. According to Fox News, this would be the first such adjustment in nine years. Democrats in vulnerable states are reportedly concerned about the optics of the raise during the next election.

In an interview with Fox News, Ocasio-Cortez acknowledged that efforts to hike Congressional pay may not be popular, but emphasized that it is essential to address the issue. She stated that the pressure to turn to lobbying firms and cash in on member service after leaving office is a result of the lack of cost-of-living adjustments.

Ocasio-Cortez argued that voting against pay increases may look good in the short term, but it only increases the pressure on members to exploit loopholes and legal loopholes to enrich themselves. She emphasized that members of Congress, like retail workers, should receive cost-of-living increases to accommodate for changes in the economy.

The representative concluded that while the optics of voting against pay increases may be appealing, it is essential to be transparent about the issue and address the substance. She advocated for a $15 minimum wage pegged to inflation, ensuring that every American worker receives a cost-of-living increase.

Title: Bernie Sanders Condemns Sandra Bland's Arrest as "Police Abuse," Calls for "Real Police Reform"

Bernie Sanders, an independent senator from Vermont and presidential candidate, has released a statement condemning the arrest and subsequent death of Sandra Bland, a 28-year-old African American woman, as "police abuse." This makes him the only presidential candidate to publicly address the case so far.

Bland's arrest and death in a Texas jail cell on July 13 have sparked a national outcry. Initially, authorities ruled her death a suicide, but witness cell phone footage later revealed that she was yelling during the arrest that the officer had slammed her head on the ground. The officer had stopped Bland for a minor traffic infraction, failing to signal a turn, and later threatened to "light her up" with a taser if she didn't stop smoking a cigarette and exit the vehicle.

Sanders added a passage to his stump speech in Houston on Sunday, referencing Bland's death, which drew the longest and loudest applause from the crowd. He stated, "It is unacceptable that police officers beat up people or kill people. If they do that, they have got to be held accountable."

The dashcam video of the arrest, released last night, shows the officer pulling Bland over, opening her driver-side door, and threatening to use his taser. Sanders quickly released a statement condemning the arrest, saying, "This video shows totally outrageous police behavior. No one should be yanked from her car, thrown to the ground, assaulted, and arrested for a minor traffic stop. The result is that three days later she is dead in her jail cell. This video highlights once again why we need real police reform. People should not die for a minor traffic infraction. This type of police abuse has become an all-too-common occurrence for people of color and it must stop."

Two Texas state lawmakers have already called Bland's arrest unlawful, but neither Senator Ted Cruz nor former Governor Rick Perry, both Texans running for president, have commented on the case. Activists have utilized the #SayHerName hashtag on social media to garner attention to the Bland case.

Title: The Need for a Long-Term Strategy in Syria

The ongoing conflict in Syria has been a complex and challenging issue for the international community, with the United States being a key player in the crisis. The author of this article, Michael O'Hanlon, argues that the U.S. needs a long-term strategy to address the situation, rather than just reacting to immediate crises.

The author acknowledges that President Barack Obama has been slow to provide meaningful support to the Syrian opposition, allowing President Bashar Assad to remain in power and extremist groups to rise to prominence. However, O'Hanlon also understands the White House's reluctance to engage in the conflict, given the risks and complexities involved.

The article highlights the importance of re-establishing deterrence against the use of chemical weapons, as well as the need to protect minority groups in Syria. O'Hanlon suggests that a comprehensive strategy is necessary to achieve a political settlement among the belligerents, which may require the deployment of U.S. troops to help implement any peace deal.

The author also emphasizes the need for an integrated strategy that takes into account the broader regional implications of the conflict, including the potential for instability in Lebanon, Israel, and Jordan. He notes that any military action taken by the U.S. must be part of a larger plan to address the root causes of the conflict and promote a lasting peace.

In conclusion, the article argues that the U.S. needs a long-term strategy to address the complex issues in Syria, rather than just reacting to immediate crises. This strategy must take into account the regional implications of the conflict and prioritize the protection of minority groups.

Title: Supreme Court Weighs Constitutionality of DOMA, Banning Same-Sex Couples from Federal Benefits

The United States Supreme Court heard oral arguments on Wednesday regarding the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), a 1996 law that prohibits same-sex married couples from receiving a wide range of federal benefits. A majority of justices expressed doubts about the law's constitutionality, with Justice Anthony Kennedy potentially siding with the four liberal justices who are expected to vote to overturn it.

Justice Kennedy's concerns focused on the traditional right of states to define marriage, rather than the fairness question for gays. This difference could result in a decision that wipes DOMA from the books and provides federal benefits to same-sex married couples, but stops short of declaring that all government distinctions based on sexual orientation be subject to "heightened scrutiny" by the courts.

The sole lawyer arguing for the constitutionality of the law, Paul Clement, was retained by Republican leaders in the House after President Barack Obama decided in 2011 that the Justice Department would no longer defend the statute. Clement argued that Congress's key interest in passing the law was preserving the uniform treatment of couples in various states at a time when there were indications that some states might allow same-sex marriages. Nine states now do.

Justice Elena Kagan questioned Clement's argument, saying that Congress was not preserving tradition but departing from it when it jumped into the marriage issue. She also read aloud from the House Judiciary Committee report on DOMA, which described the statute as a way to resist the immorality of homosexuality. The report stated that Congress decided to reflect an honor of collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality.

The court's decision is expected to have significant implications for same-sex couples who are seeking federal benefits and recognition of their marriages.

Title: Navy SEAL's Court-Martial Highlights Challenges in Prosecuting War Crimes

The court-martial of Special Operations Chief Edward Gallagher, a decorated sniper and medic, has shed light on the challenges faced by military courts in prosecuting alleged war crimes committed by elite special forces. Gallagher is accused of fatally stabbing a wounded Islamic State captive and shooting civilians in Iraq in 2017. A jury of mostly combat Marines will decide his fate, charged with murder, attempted murder, and conduct prejudicial to good order and discipline.

The case has sparked a fierce debate within the Navy SEAL community about brotherhood, morality, and loyalty. The trial has also highlighted the struggles of military courts in prosecuting alleged war crimes, with the lead prosecutor being removed after allegedly tracking the defense team's emails to find a news leak, and the lead investigator acknowledging mistakes.

The trial has revealed the complexities of the case, with nearly a dozen SEALs testifying over the past two weeks. Most were granted immunity to protect them from being prosecuted for acts they described on the stand. Seven SEALs said Gallagher unexpectedly stabbed the prisoner on May 3, 2017, moments after he and the other medics treated the 17-year-old boy. Two SEALs testified they saw Gallagher plunge his knife into his neck, including Special Operator Corey Scott, who stunned the court when he said he was the one who ultimately killed the teen by plugging his breathing tube with his thumb as an act of mercy.

The Navy is considering perjury charges against Scott. An Iraqi general who handed the wounded prisoner to the SEALs testified that Gallagher did not stab the boy. And Marine Staff Sgt. Giorgio Kirylo said after the militant died that he moved the body to take a "cool guy trophy" photo with it and saw no stab wounds on his neck.

Gallagher's lawyers say the WhatsApp group chat, known as "The Sewing Circle," was used to orchestrate a smear campaign to bring down their demanding platoon chief. A SEAL troop commander told the court that the allegations, which he took no action on for months, were suspect because they came about as Gallagher was being considered for a Silver Star and a promotion. Platoon members testified that the team was fractured, and the running joke was that if something was missing from a care package, Eddie took it.

The trial has also highlighted the challenges faced by special forces as the United States increasingly relies on such troops, which make up only 2% of the military yet carry out most of its battles around the globe. A number of special forces members are on trial this year, including a U.S. Navy SEAL who last month pleaded guilty to hazing and assault charges for his role in the 2017 strangulation of a U.S. Army Green Beret in Africa.

The case has prompted a review by the Navy's top commanders into the behavior of the special warfare teams. Closing arguments are expected Monday, and a jury of five Marines and two sailors, one a SEAL, will weigh whether Gallagher went off the rails and fatally stabbed the war prisoner as a kind of trophy kill, or if the boy died from wounds sustained in an airstrike and Gallagher is being falsely accused by junior SEALs trying to permanently oust a platoon chief they hate.

Title: FBI Director Comey's Handling of Anti-Trump Dossier Raises Questions

The FBI Director James Comey's handling of an anti-Trump dossier compiled by a former British intelligence officer, Christopher Steele, has raised questions about the bureau's relationship with Steele and his company, Orbis, and its potential ties to Washington, D.C.-based Fusion GPS. The dossier, which contains salacious allegations about then-candidate Donald Trump, was included in the final intelligence community report on Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.

According to sources, Comey considered the dossier so important that he insisted it be included in the report. The FBI and Office of the Director of National Intelligence declined to comment on the classified document.

The dossier was part of the evidence used to obtain a FISA warrant for Carter Page, a peripheral figure in the Trump campaign. Page denied the dossier's central allegations that he was the Trump campaign's point person for Moscow. The dossier also contained allegations about Trump's campaign.

During a Senate hearing, Comey was questioned about the bureau's relationship with Steele and Fusion GPS. Comey said he knew the name of the former British officer who wrote the dossier, but declined to comment on whether Fusion GPS is part of the Russian intelligence apparatus. When asked if he agreed that it would be interfering in the election if Fusion were involved in preparing the anti-Trump dossier, Comey replied, "I don't want to say."

The hearing also raised questions about the FBI's relationship with Fusion GPS and its founder, Glenn Simpson, who is a former Wall Street Journal reporter. A letter of complaint was filed with the Justice Department alleging that Fusion GPS violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act by acting as an unregistered agent for Russian interests. Fusion GPS denied the allegations, stating that it complied with the law and was not required to register under FARA.

The FBI's handling of the dossier has also raised concerns about the bureau's reliance on unverified information. Senator Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., questioned the FBI's use of the dossier as a basis for its investigation, citing the fact that the author of the dossier admitted that it contains unverified claims.

The controversy surrounding the dossier and Fusion GPS has sparked a heated debate about the FBI's handling of the investigation and the potential political motivations behind it.

Title: Trump Administration's Handling of Dreamers Sparks Confusion and Criticism

The Trump administration's handling of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, also known as Dreamers, has been marked by contradictory statements and a lack of clear direction. Despite previous claims that he wants to protect the program, President Trump has sent mixed signals, leaving many wondering what his administration's true intentions are.

In February, Trump described Dreamers as "absolutely incredible kids" who deserve to be treated "with heart." However, in September, he ordered an end to the program unless Congress found a permanent fix by March 5. Two weeks ago, he promised to deliver a "bill of love," but two days later, he rejected a bipartisan deal aimed at achieving that goal. On Friday, Trump reportedly agreed to a deal with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer that would have protected Dreamers and increased border security, but he later reversed course at the urging of anti-immigrant hawks in his administration.

The president's lack of clear convictions and ignorance of basic policy matters have led to a shutdown, with Senate Minority Leader Schumer describing dealing with the president as "like negotiating with Jell-O." A Republican strategist noted that Trump's lack of clear principles and ignorance of policy matters "emboldens all parties to take positions that they won't compromise."

In contrast, former President Barack Obama's administration took a clear stance on the Affordable Care Act, refusing to negotiate on its defunding and ultimately prevailing. In contrast, Trump's administration appears to be driven by a desire to promote his own brand and score "wins," regardless of the consequences. The lack of clear direction and principles has made it difficult to negotiate with the administration, leaving many wondering what its true intentions are.

Title: The New York Times Editorial Calls for Renaming Military Bases After "American Heroes, Not Racist Traitors"

The New York Times published an editorial over the weekend, titled "Why Does the U.S. Military Celebrate White Supremacy?", which argues that the U.S. military celebrates white supremacy and calls for renaming military bases after "American heroes, not racist traitors". The editorial cites specific examples, such as Fort Benning, Georgia, which honors Henry Lewis Benning, a Confederate general who believed African-Americans were not fully human and could not be trusted with full citizenship. The editorial also references John Brown Gordon, a Confederate general and leader of the Georgia Ku Klux Klan, whose base is named after him.

In response, Pentagon spokesman Jonathan Rath Hoffman tweeted that the New York Times has more than a million possible stories of American patriots who have given their lives for the country, but instead chooses to focus on a few examples of Confederate generals. He also stated that the Department of Defense is the most diverse meritocracy in the country and has many stories of valor still waiting to be told.

The New York Times editorial board argues that the federal government has embraced white supremacist ideals by naming military bases after Confederate generals, and that these names represent not only oppression during the Civil War but also state-sponsored bigotry after it. The editorial concludes that it is long past time for these bases to be renamed.

The article does not provide any information on the current status of the renaming process or any potential plans to rename the military bases.

Title: Bloomberg Storms Super Tuesday States, Pledging to 'Get It Done'

Mike Bloomberg has embarked on a whirlwind tour of Super Tuesday states, seeking to capitalize on his growing momentum in the Democratic presidential race. The billionaire former New York City mayor has been gaining traction in recent weeks, as front-runner Joe Biden has struggled with disappointing finishes in the first two contests.

Bloomberg's campaign has been focused on promoting his message of experience and effectiveness, with a slogan that reads "Mike will get it done." He has been holding a series of rallies and events across the country, including stops in Tennessee, North Carolina, and Texas.

The candidate has been emphasizing his ability to bring people together and get things done, citing his experience as mayor of New York City. He has also been highlighting his plan to address issues such as climate change, gun violence, and economic inequality.

Bloomberg has been avoiding direct attacks on his Democratic opponents, instead focusing on his own qualifications and vision for the country. However, he has been taking aim at President Trump, saying that he is the only one who can defeat him.

The candidate has been using social media to engage with voters and respond to criticism, including a recent exchange with Trump on Twitter. He has also been using his rallies to respond to Trump's latest insults, saying that the president is afraid of him.

Despite some criticism of his wealth and the fact that he entered the race relatively late, Bloomberg has been gaining support from some voters. Retiree Michael Day, who attended a rally in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, said that he is willing to give Bloomberg a chance because he believes that someone with his resources is needed to take on Trump.

However, not all voters are sold on Bloomberg. Briana Brady, 20, who attended a rally in Chattanooga, Tennessee, said that she is still undecided and is considering supporting Elizabeth Warren. The Bloomberg campaign has also faced criticism over some of his past comments and actions, including his support for the stop-and-frisk policy and his comments on redlining.

Despite these challenges, Bloomberg's campaign is expected to continue to be a major player in the Democratic primary, and voters will get to assess his strength on Super Tuesday.

Title: The Odds Are Against Convicting Officer Wilson: A Look at the History of Police Shooting Investigations

The recent shooting of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson has sparked widespread debate and outrage, with many calling for justice to be served. However, the history of criminal investigations into police shootings suggests that convicting an officer of wrongdoing is extremely unlikely. According to William Yeomans, a former attorney and senior official in the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, the odds are stacked against Officer Wilson being convicted.

Yeomans notes that police officers are often given a significant amount of leeway to perform their duties, which can lead to a lack of accountability when they use deadly force. This is due in part to the public's trust and dependence on police officers to protect them, as well as the recognition that officers must be given some flexibility to perform their dangerous jobs.

The backgrounds of the participants in a police shooting also play a significant role in the investigation and subsequent trial. Officers are often entitled to use reasonable force in situations where they are confronted with individuals suspected of criminal wrongdoing. This can lead to a tendency to give the benefit of the doubt to the officer, making it even more challenging to secure a conviction.

The release of a video showing Michael Brown allegedly stealing cigars from a convenience store was seen as an attempt to reinforce this dynamic, and the conflicting statements from witnesses have made it difficult to determine what exactly happened during the confrontation. The difficulty in obtaining accurate eyewitness testimony is a common challenge in police shooting investigations, as the events often occur in sudden and chaotic circumstances, making it difficult for witnesses to recall the details accurately.

The use of video evidence can be crucial in these cases, as seen in the prosecution of officers who beat Rodney King in Los Angeles in 1991. The availability of video footage helped to secure a federal conviction, and there are renewed calls for officers to be required to record their confrontations to protect themselves from false allegations and to preserve the record in cases that raise legitimate concerns.

In conclusion, while the investigation into the shooting of Michael Brown is ongoing, the history of police shooting investigations suggests that convicting an officer of wrongdoing is extremely unlikely. The complex legal and cultural factors at play make it challenging to secure a conviction, and the odds are stacked against Officer Wilson being held accountable for his actions.

Title: US Senate Sets Ground Rules for Trump's Impeachment Trial

The US Senate has adopted ground rules for President Donald Trump's impeachment trial, following nearly 13 hours of debate on the first day. The trial will resume on Wednesday with arguments by the prosecution, followed by the defense and questions.

The rules, approved by the Republican-led Senate, allow each side to present their case in opening arguments over three days, with up to 24 hours to be used. Senators are barred from live tweeting and speaking to those sitting near them while the case is being heard, and no outside reading materials are allowed to be brought in.

The trial is the third in US history, with Trump facing charges of abuse of power and obstructing the congressional impeachment inquiry. He has denied wrongdoing and accused Democrats of trying to unseat him for political reasons.

The president is attending the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he again dismissed the accusations against him as "a total hoax." On the question of whether new witnesses would be called to the trial, he said he would leave that to senators to decide, but the White House has actively worked to block the appearance of certain officials.

Democrats have made it clear they wish to hear testimony from former National Security Adviser John Bolton, who has said he would comply with any subpoena. The Trump administration has claimed that evidence from Bolton would pose a national security threat, a claim dismissed by Democrats as a smokescreen.

Senators have taken oaths to act as impartial jurors in the trial, presided over by US Chief Justice John Roberts. House Democrats, known as "impeachment managers," act as the prosecution, while Trump's legal team acts as the defense.

The trial is expected to continue for several more days, with senators having 16 hours to ask questions after opening arguments. The key issue of new witnesses and evidence will be revisited after that.

Title: Trump Campaign Faces Internal Fractures and Challenges in Winning Over Evangelicals

The Trump campaign is facing internal divisions and struggles to unite its staff, according to Dr. Gerson Moreno-Riano, a professor at Regent University. The campaign's firing of its campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, on Monday is seen as a symptom of these internal issues. Moreno-Riano believes that the campaign is trying to cater to multiple constituencies, including evangelicals, but has been unable to do so successfully.

The professor emphasized that the key to Trump's success lies in his ability to bring his message under control and highlight the core concerns of GOP constituencies, including evangelicals. He noted that Trump's direct and strong-minded nature may be a challenge for him to demonstrate the necessary discipline to achieve this goal.

The upcoming meeting between Trump and hundreds of evangelical leaders in New York City is seen as a crucial test for the candidate. Moreno-Riano listed abortion, religious liberty, and the Supreme Court as key issues that Trump must address to gain the trust of evangelicals. He believes that Trump must demonstrate a deep understanding of the evangelical mindset and bring unity to the table.

Since the 1950s, evangelicals have struggled to rally around a single candidate, and Moreno-Riano believes that this is a significant burden for Trump to overcome. The professor concludes that it will be a difficult challenge for Trump to unite evangelicals around a common denominator, but it is a crucial test for the candidate to prove his commitment to their values.

Title: Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval Declines Supreme Court Nomination

Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval announced on Thursday that he has declined a possible nomination for the United States Supreme Court. In a statement, Sandoval expressed his gratitude for being considered for the position, but ultimately decided not to pursue it. He notified the White House and Senators Reid and Heller of his decision.

The White House declined to comment on whether Sandoval was ever seriously considered for the nomination. Nevada's senior Senator, Harry Reid, had previously recommended Sandoval for the position, which was leaked to the public on Wednesday.

Sandoval's nomination was seen as unlikely, with some viewing it as a way to pressure Republicans into considering a nominee from their own party. As a moderate Republican, Sandoval has taken stances on issues such as gay marriage and abortion that differ from those of some of his fellow Republicans.

Despite his decision to decline the nomination, Sandoval's name may still be brought up in the future, according to Professor Richardson of the University of Nevada, Reno. Sandoval's Republican colleague, Senator Dean Heller, expressed support for his decision and hopes that the next president will consider him in the future.

It is worth noting that Sandoval's background and qualifications are different from those of most Supreme Court justices. He earned his law degree from Ohio State University Moritz College of Law in 1989, whereas most justices have attended prestigious law schools such as Harvard, Yale, or Columbia.

Title: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham Embraces Immigration Reform, Avoiding Primary Challenge

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina, has taken a bold stance on immigration reform, advocating for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants. This move may seem counterintuitive, given the party's traditionally tough stance on border security and immigration. However, Graham believes the political landscape has shifted since his previous attempts at reform in 2007, and he is willing to take the risk.

Graham's decision to support immigration reform is a departure from his party's stance, which has been criticized for being too restrictive. In 2007, he was booed at town halls and censured by county parties for his support of the Kennedy-McCain immigration reform bill. However, since the November election, Graham believes the dynamic has changed, and he is now convinced that people in the Republican Party are beginning to understand the politics of immigration.

Graham's stance is not without support within the Republican Party. Senator Marco Rubio, a fellow member of the Gang of Eight, provides cover on his right flank, and some Republicans are rethinking the party's opposition to comprehensive overhaul. Randy Page, chairman of the GOP committee in South Carolina's 2nd Congressional District, believes that the party's message on immigration has been misaligned with the Hispanic community's values.

The 2012 electoral thumping the GOP took, partly due to Mitt Romney's 27% showing with Hispanics, has prompted many Republicans to reassess their stance on immigration. Graham believes that people want the borders secured and the issue resolved, and he thinks he is in a good position to go back home and tell people that now is the time to get it done.

While some may be surprised by Graham's stance, it is clear that he is willing to take a risk to push for reform. The question remains whether his fellow Republicans will follow his lead and whether the party's stance on immigration will continue to evolve.

Title: Gunman Attacks Annapolis Capital Gazette, Killing Five and Wounding Two

A gunman stormed into the offices of the Annapolis Capital Gazette on Thursday, killing five people and wounding two others. The attack was described as a "targeted attack" by police, who said the gunman had sent threats to the newspaper on social media and entered the building looking for specific people.

The victims included five Capital Gazette employees: Wendi Winters, special publications editor; Rob Hiaasen, editor and Sunday columnist; John McNamara, writer; Gerald Fischman, editorial page editor; and Rebecca Smith, sales assistant.

The suspect, identified as Jarrod W. Ramos, a 38-year-old Laurel resident, was taken into custody without exchanging fire with police. Authorities said it took only about a minute to respond to the shooting and clear the building, evacuating about 170 people.

The Capital Gazette's staff took to Twitter to share details of the assault, describing the gunman as shooting through the glass doors to the office, then opening fire on employees. "There is nothing more terrifying than hearing multiple people get shot while you're under your desk and then hear the gunman reload," tweeted reporter Phil Davis.

The 30,000-circulation daily newspaper has offices in a building on the outskirts of downtown Annapolis, which shares the building with other professional offices. People in those offices described a harrowing ordeal, with one worker saying, "It's terrifying. You never think you'll wake up one day and see the police with big guns yelling and screaming to get your hands up."

The shooting has left the community in shock, with many expressing their condolences and support for the victims and their families. The White House also offered its condolences, with First Lady Melania Trump tweeting, "My heart is heavy today as I think of the lives lost and the families affected by the senseless act of violence in Annapolis."

The shooting has also sparked concerns about the safety of journalists and the media, with many expressing their solidarity with the Capital Gazette and its staff. The New York Police Department also confirmed it dispatched officers to media outlets in that city as a precaution.

The investigation is ongoing, with police still trying to determine the motive behind the attack.

Title: Stormy Daniels Escalates Legal Fight with President Trump, Adds Michael Cohen as Defendant

Article:

Adult film actress Stormy Daniels has amended her lawsuit against President Trump, adding his lawyer Michael Cohen as a defendant. The move comes a day after Daniels' widely viewed 60 Minutes interview, in which she provided salacious details about an alleged sexual encounter with Trump and claimed she was physically threatened to keep quiet about the affair.

In her new filing, Daniels argues that a $130,000 payment made to her days before the 2016 presidential election was an illegal campaign contribution. The payment was arranged by Cohen, who claimed he used his own money to "facilitate" the payoff and said Trump was not aware of his actions at the time.

Cohen's statement, which implied that Daniels was lying about the affair, is at the center of Daniels' defamation claim. She alleges that the statement exposed her to "hatred, contempt, ridicule, and shame."

The White House has denied breaking any campaign-finance laws in the payment to Daniels and has cast doubt on her claim that she was physically threatened to keep quiet about the alleged tryst. White House spokesman Raj Shah said the president does not believe Daniels' claims are accurate and that there is no evidence to support her allegations.

The legal saga has taken a new turn, with Daniels' attorney Michael Avenatti waging an aggressive public-relations campaign to invalidate a confidentiality agreement with Trump's lawyer. Cohen's lawyer has sent a cease-and-desist letter to Avenatti, demanding that Daniels retract "false and defamatory" claims she made to 60 Minutes.

In the CBS interview, Daniels said she agreed to keep silent about the alleged 2006 sexual relationship with Trump in exchange for the $130,000 payment arranged by Cohen because she feared for her safety. She claimed that her fears were rooted in a 2011 encounter with an unidentified man who threatened her in a Las Vegas parking lot after she first tried to sell her story to a tabloid magazine and told her to "Leave Trump alone."

The White House has denied any wrongdoing in connection with election laws, and Trump himself has been uncharacteristically silent about the matter. Watchdog groups have filed complaints arguing that the $130,000 payment to Daniels likely violated campaign-finance laws that limit the size and source of donations to federal candidates.

Title: US Government Explores Alternatives to China-Based Supply Chain Amid Pandemic

The Trump administration is accelerating efforts to reduce the United States' reliance on China-based supply chains, according to a report on Monday. The move is a response to the economic damage and death toll caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has highlighted the country's dependence on China for critical goods such as generic drugs, medical equipment, and food supplies.

The initiative is an extension of President Trump's pledge to bring manufacturing jobs back to the US. Keith Krach, Undersecretary for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment at the State Department, stated that the government is "turbocharging" its efforts to reduce reliance on China. Krach emphasized the need to identify critical areas and bottlenecks in the supply chain and to make goods outside of China.

The report suggests that several government agencies, including the Commerce and State departments, are examining ways to move the supply chain and manufacturing from China using tax incentives and other measures. The government is also considering designating certain manufacturing work as "essential" and making those goods outside of China.

The White House's policy on China has been a subject of debate, with some officials pushing for a more aggressive approach and others advocating for a more collaborative approach. The current situation has given "hard-liners" new ammunition, according to an official.

The pandemic has highlighted the risks associated with relying on China for critical goods, and the administration is considering imposing new tariffs on Chinese goods and slapping sanctions on Chinese officials or companies. The administration is also exploring closer ties with Taiwan, which China considers a rogue province.

The pandemic has also shed light on the critical role China plays in the global supply chain for generic drugs, medical equipment, and food supplies. However, many US companies have invested heavily in China and rely on its massive consumer market.

Diversification and redundancy in supply chains may make sense, according to Doug Barry, spokesman for the U.S.-China Business Council. However, he noted that companies are not rushing to leave China. John Murphy, senior vice president for international policy at the US Chamber of Commerce, emphasized that building new manufacturing facilities in the US could take up to eight years.

The administration is working with other countries, including Australia, India, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, and Vietnam, to restructure supply chains and prevent similar crises in the future. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that the administration is working to "move the global economy forward" and to "prevent something like this from ever happening again."

Title: Fact-Checking the "Apology Tour" Claim: A Look at Obama's Foreign Policy Speeches

The debate between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney has sparked a heated discussion about Obama's foreign policy, with Romney accusing the President of going on an "apology tour" during his first foreign trips as President. Columnist Charles Krauthammer argued that Romney's charge was devastating, but fact-checkers and journalists quickly dismissed the claim, citing that Obama never used the word "apology" in his speeches.

However, a closer examination of Obama's speeches during his first foreign trips reveals a different story. According to the Heritage Foundation, Obama did acknowledge past U.S. foreign policy mistakes, using phrases such as "at times we sought to dictate our terms" and "we have not pursued and sustained engagement with our neighbors." These statements can be seen as a form of apology or regret for past actions.

ABC and CNN, among other mainstream outlets, have disputed Romney's claim, stating that Obama did not apologize for America's actions. However, a closer look at Obama's speeches shows that he did acknowledge past mistakes and criticized past U.S. foreign policy, which can be seen as a form of apology.

The Heritage Foundation's "Top 10 Apologies" list, compiled by Nile Gardiner and Morgan Lorraine Roach, provides several examples of Obama's criticism of past U.S. foreign policy. These instances include his regret over the use of enhanced interrogation techniques, his criticism of the war on terror, and his apology for the Guantanamo Bay detention center.

In conclusion, while Obama did not use the exact word "apology" in his speeches, his words and actions can be seen as a form of apology or regret for past U.S. foreign policy mistakes. The debate surrounding this issue highlights the importance of nuanced language and the need for a closer examination of the facts.

Title: Ebola Nurse Kaci Hickox Refuses to Comply with Mandatory Quarantine, Citing Civil Rights Concerns

Article:

Ebola nurse Kaci Hickox, 33, has refused to comply with a mandatory 21-day quarantine ordered by Maine officials, citing concerns over her civil rights. Hickox, who was treating Ebola patients in Sierra Leone for Doctors Without Borders, returned to the United States on Friday and was initially quarantined in an outdoor tent at Newark Liberty International Airport. After testing negative for the virus twice, she was released and returned home to Maine on Monday.

Maine officials have said they will seek a court order to enforce the quarantine if Hickox does not comply voluntarily. However, legal experts say it is unclear whether such an order would be approved by a judge. "The state has the burden of proving that she is infected, or at least was credibly exposed to infection, and also that by her own behavior she is likely to infect others if not confined," said public health lawyer Wendy Mariner.

Hickox has stated that she is not infected and plans to take precautions to avoid exposing anyone to her bodily fluids. "You could hug me, you could shake my hand, and I would not give you Ebola," she said outside her Fort Kent home.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) does not consider health workers who treated Ebola patients in West Africa to be at "high risk" for catching Ebola if they were wearing protective gear, according to new guidelines announced this week. The CDC recommends that these workers undergo monitoring and take precautions, but does not require home quarantines.

Hickox's decision to refuse the quarantine has sparked debate over the balance between public health concerns and individual rights. Maine Governor Paul LePage has expressed concern for Hickox's safety and the health of the community, stating that the state is exploring all options to protect the health and well-being of healthcare workers, the Fort Kent community, and all of Maine.

Title: North Korea Cuts Military Hotlines with South Korea, Escalates Rhetoric and Threats

North Korea has severed its last military hotlines with South Korea and intensified its rhetoric, sparking concerns in the region. Thousands of North Koreans rallied in central Pyongyang, chanting "Death to the U.S. imperialists" and calling for "scores to be settled" with the U.S. The country also released a video showing an invasion of Seoul, depicting North Korean forces crossing the border to destroy American bases in South Korea.

Pyongyang also cancelled the armistice agreement that ended the Korean War, but experts are skeptical about the country's threats to attack American bases in Guam, Hawaii, and the U.S. mainland. "I do not think they are capable of launching this type of attack against the United States," said Kim Heung-kyu, a professor at Sungshin Women's University in Seoul and an adviser to South Korea's last president, Lee Myung-bak.

Instead, experts anticipate provocations against South Korea, including cyberattacks and targeting of military areas or scientific facilities. South Korea's new president, Park Geun-hye, has continued to pursue a "trustpolitik" policy, re-establishing trust while taking a tough line with the North. Pyongyang is trying to pressure her to soften her policies, while gaining direct talks from Washington.

The severing of communication links between the two countries has raised concerns about the potential for miscalculation. "Both countries are essentially on a kind of war footing," said John Delury of Yonsei University in Seoul. "In the South, certainly there's expectation that some provocation could be coming soon, and there's no one on the end of the [hotline] to answer, to clarify." South Koreans are "finger-on-the-trigger ready to do something," making it a dangerous situation.

North Korea's actions have also antagonized China, its traditional ally, with its recent rocket launch and third nuclear test. Beijing's position is now much tougher, and China is on board for stiffer U.N. sanctions against its old ally. However, Beijing's prime concern remains stability, and it is unlikely to abandon Pyongyang at the moment.

The escalating threats and massive rallies leave Pyongyang with little room to maneuver. One thing is clear: the new young leader, Kim Jong Un, has learned from his father's playbook and may yet be more unpredictable.

Title: Iowa Caucuses: Ted Cruz Wins Republican Contest, Democrats Clinton and Sanders Remain Tied

The Iowa caucuses, the first nominating contests in the 2016 White House race, have concluded, with Republican Senator Ted Cruz emerging victorious in the Republican contest and Democrats Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders remaining in a dead heat. Cruz won with 28 percent of the vote, followed by businessman Donald Trump with 24 percent, and Senator Marco Rubio with 23 percent.

In the Democratic contest, Clinton and Sanders both received roughly 50 percent of the vote, with 95 percent of precincts reporting. Sanders declared the results a tie. Former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley suspended his campaign, finishing with less than one percent.

Cruz's win and Rubio's strong showing could dent the momentum for Trump, whose candidacy has been marked by controversies and has alarmed the Republican establishment. Cruz thanked God and said the results showed that the nominee would not be chosen by the media, the Washington establishment, or lobbyists.

Trump congratulated Cruz and said he still expects to win the Republican nomination. Clinton congratulated Sanders and did not declare victory in her remarks. Sanders said he and Clinton are in a "virtual tie" and expressed gratitude for the support of Iowa voters.

The results could shift momentum in both races. Clinton hopes for a strong finish against Sanders to vanquish his insurgent candidacy, while Rubio's third-place finish established him as the Republican mainstream alternative to Trump and Cruz. The Iowa caucuses have given extra weight to the candidates' campaigns, which can translate into momentum for winning candidates.

The 2016 election is shaping up to be the year of angry voters, with disgruntled Americans worrying about issues such as immigration, terrorism, income inequality, and healthcare, fueling the campaigns of Trump, Sanders, and Cruz. Market reaction in Asia to the results was muted, with U.S. stock futures down around half a percent.

Title: Federal Government Misses Opportunity to Profit from Strategic Petroleum Reserve

The Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) has 78.5 million barrels of spare capacity, which could have been used to buy crude oil at a discounted price and sold at a higher price in the future, generating a profit for taxpayers. However, the federal government did not take advantage of this opportunity, and instead, the SPR will likely be used to store oil for oil companies, resulting in a profit for them instead.

The SPR had the potential to buy 78.5 million barrels of crude oil at a price of $18.27 per barrel and sell it in December at a price of $33.82 per barrel, resulting in a profit of $15.55 per barrel. This would have generated a profit of $1.22 billion for the government. However, the SPR was not used for this purpose, and instead, the government will likely use its spare capacity to store oil for oil companies, which will result in a profit for them.

The SPR has the authority to store oil for producers, and it is likely that the Trump administration will use its spare capacity to do so. The Energy Department declined to comment on the storage fee and the duration of the storage, but it is likely that the companies will deposit oil and then retrieve most of it, resulting in a tidy profit.

The article argues that the government should have used the SPR to make a profit, which would have benefited taxpayers. Instead, the profit will likely go to oil companies. The article concludes that even a small profit of $860 million is better than nothing, and it is essential to deal with the problem to ensure that taxpayers benefit from the SPR.

Title: Heavy Fighting Erupts Along Iraq-Syria Border as Kurdish Forces Battle Islamic State

Heavy fighting has been reported along the border crossing between Iraq and Syria, as Kurdish forces clashed with Islamic State (IS) militants. Iraqi Kurdish troops have reportedly recaptured the town of Rabia, but suffered heavy casualties, including the loss of a senior commander. Meanwhile, IS fighters have been trying to dislodge Syrian Kurdish forces on the other side of the border.

The fighting comes amid ongoing air strikes by a US-led coalition on IS targets in both Syria and Iraq. According to Kurdish sources, British Tornado jets carried out strikes on Tuesday, helping the Kurds retake an "important border crossing" at Rabia. In Syria, US warplanes conducted 11 air strikes over the past two days, targeting IS positions near Deir al-Zour, Sinjar, Mazra al-Duwud, and Aleppo, destroying several armed vehicles, artillery pieces, and a tank.

In Iraq, 11 US raids on Tuesday destroyed IS armored and transport vehicles and a checkpoint. At least 20 people were killed in bomb attacks on Shia areas of the Iraqi capital Baghdad, with similar attacks reported in the holy Shia city of Karbala.

The UN humanitarian chief, Valerie Amos, warned that 11 million people inside Syria need urgent aid, and without extra funding, the World Food Programme will be forced to end its operations completely within two months.

In a separate development, Turkish tanks have taken up positions along the border near the Syrian town of Kobane after several shells hit Turkish territory during clashes between IS and Kurdish fighters. The Turkish government has asked parliament to authorize military action against IS in Iraq and Syria, and MPs are expected to discuss the issue on Thursday.

Senior Iraqi Kurdish officials said their Peshmerga special forces had made good initial progress during their dawn offensive in Rabia, with the town firmly in Kurdish hands by nightfall. However, IS militants continued to hold out in one building. Rabia lies about 100km northwest of Mosul, the biggest city controlled by IS.

The Iraqi Kurdish forces also took heavy casualties, including the loss of a senior commander, when three suicide car bombers blew themselves up among the Kurdish troops. The bombers are believed to have traveled from IS-controlled areas further east.

Control of the Rabia crossing and cutting IS supply lines are seen as important steps towards an eventual move to regain the town of Sinjar and its nearby mountain. Militants overran that area in August, forcing tens of thousands of civilians from the minority Yazidi community to flee for their lives. The other side of the border is controlled by Syrian Kurdish fighters, who themselves have been coming under attacks from IS. More than 30 Syrian Kurdish fighters are reported to have been killed as the jihadists took over several villages south of the border crossing. However, the crossing itself is said to be still under Kurdish control.

Title: Sanders to Meet with Supporters Amid Frustration Over Primary Process

The Democratic National Convention is just around the corner, and Senator Bernie Sanders is set to meet with his supporters on Monday. The meeting comes as Sanders' backers have expressed frustration over the nominating procedures, party platform, and party leadership. Some have even threatened to protest or take action on the convention floor.

Despite this, Sanders has taken a positive approach, emphasizing the importance of party unity and defeating Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump. In recent interviews, he has expressed his support for Hillary Clinton, the Democratic nominee.

"I'm proud that, in the Democratic platform that was passed a few weeks ago, we are making some real progress," Sanders said on CNN Sunday. "My focus right now is defeating Trump, electing Clinton, electing progressive candidates around this country, and focusing on the issues that matter the most to working families."

The publication of thousands of hacked emails last week, which suggested the Democratic National Committee (DNC) favored Clinton during the primary season, has not helped to promote party unity. Many Sanders fans believe the emails prove their concerns about party officials preferring Clinton were correct.

Despite this, Sanders has made it clear that his focus is on defeating Trump and electing progressive candidates. He has also won major concessions on the party platform, including a $15 federal minimum wage, abolishing the death penalty, and breaking up large Wall Street banks.

The DNC's decision to create a "unity commission" to review changes to the nominating process, including limiting the role of superdelegates, has also been seen as a positive step. Sanders supporters who sought to pass amendments to abolish or curtail superdelegates have opted against pursuing convention floor fights on the issue.

While some Sanders delegates are still unhappy with the party's handling of the primary process, others are looking forward to the convention and the opportunity to support Sanders' vision. "We're not here to disrupt for the purpose of disruption," said delegate Courtney Rowe, 34, from Cedar Rapids, Iowa. "We want to hear from Sanders and see what he has to say."

The Democratic National Convention is set to begin on July 25 in Philadelphia.

Title: Republicans' Healthcare Plan: A Deeper Dive into the Consequences

The debate surrounding the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has been ongoing for over three years, with Republicans repeatedly voting to repeal the law without presenting a viable alternative. Despite the troubled rollout of the ACA, Republicans have failed to agree on a replacement plan, which has damaged their credibility as healthcare reform critics. However, a closer examination of their proposed plans reveals that they would have more significant consequences for the healthcare system than the ACA.

According to Jonathan Cohn, a healthcare expert, almost all GOP plans would disrupt the insurance market more dramatically than the ACA. These plans would kick millions of people off Medicaid and inflict adverse selection on the employer-sponsored insurance market, leading to more cancellation notices and "rate shock" than the current situation.

The National Review's Ramesh Ponnuru suggests a slow and steady disruption, while other conservative policy wonks propose replacing all insurance with subsidized catastrophic coverage and tax-preferred health savings accounts. This would mean that nearly all insurance plans would be eliminated, including those with private insurance and Medicaid.

Additionally, many Republicans support eliminating traditional Medicare for future retirees and replacing it with a plan that resembles the ACA. While this plan would be marketed as preserving the promise made to current retirees, it would be massively disruptive and unsustainable in the long run.

The article concludes that Republicans are using the "if you like your plan you can keep it" pitch as a way to criticize the ACA, while their own plans would have more significant consequences for the healthcare system. The author suggests that if a consensus GOP plan existed, it would be difficult to square the outpouring of sympathy for young policyholders with the radical intent of their own vision.

Title: Republicans Poised to Maintain House Majority in 2014 Mid-Term Elections

The upcoming mid-term elections in 2014 are expected to see Republicans maintain their majority in the House of Representatives, according to current arithmetic. The current makeup of the House stands at 233 Republicans, 200 Democrats, and two vacancies. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has identified 17 Republican-held seats as targets, which would require Democratic victories in all of these districts to recapture the majority. However, this strategy depends on Democrats winning all targeted seats and Republicans not picking up any.

The Democratic strategy focuses on the 17 districts carried by President Barack Obama in 2012, where voters also sent a Republican to the House. These districts include narrow 2012 winners such as Reps. Mike Coffman of Colorado, Lee Terry of Nebraska, and Mike Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania. However, Republicans will likely target the nine districts that went for Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential election but sent a Democrat to the House.

One of the most vulnerable Democratic-held districts is Florida's 18th District, where Rep. Patrick Murphy won by less than 2,000 votes. Four Republicans have already filed to run against Murphy, with Carl Domino, a former assistant state house GOP leader, investments adviser, and U.S. Navy veteran, considered the early favorite.

There are 14 open seats without incumbents, with five Democratic-held seats and nine Republican-held seats. The West Virginia seat being vacated by Rep. Shelley Moore Capito, who is running for the Senate, could go Democratic, while the Iowa seat being given up by Rep. Bruce Braley for a Senate run could go the other way. While much can change between now and November 2014, the current prediction is that the House will remain Republican.

Title: Grass-Roots Activists Push for Obama to Act on Immigration Reform

The debate surrounding immigration reform has sparked a rift within the progressive community, with some groups demanding that President Barack Obama take action to stop deportations, while others believe that administrative advocacy is not the most effective approach. The National Day Laborer Organizing Network (NDLON) has been at the forefront of the push, with its director, Pablo Alvarado, arrested outside the White House in protest of deportation policy.

According to Chris Newman, the legal director of the National Day Laborer Organizing Network, some groups have become too close to the White House and have lost their objectivity. "There is no doubt that some groups have at times seen administrative advocacy as being in tension with the legislative campaign, an idea we strongly reject," he said.

However, other progressive groups, such as the Center for American Progress and the National Council of La Raza, are not demanding that Obama stop deportations, citing the need for a comprehensive legislative solution. "It's access misinterpreted as influence," said an official from one of these groups, who wished to remain anonymous. "We operate on the fundamental rule that if they're upset, we're making progress. It is how this White House operates."

Representative Luis Gutierrez (D-Ill.) believes that the push to stop deportations is so broad that no Washington organization can stop it. "It's becoming something that you can't control," he said. "People have tried to control it. This administration has put inordinate pressure on people not to criticize the president on his immigration policy and not to talk about prosecutorial discretion."

The White House has maintained that Obama does not have the authority to act unilaterally on deportations without Congress. However, some activists believe that the president has the power to use prosecutorial discretion to stop deportations. Obama has urged listeners to call Republicans in Congress and demand they move on immigration reform, stating that the main thing people can do right now is put pressure on Republicans who have refused to act.

The debate highlights the complexities of the immigration issue and the differing opinions within the progressive community. While some groups believe that administrative advocacy is the most effective approach, others believe that legislative action is the only way to achieve meaningful reform.

Title: Debunking the Myth: The True Story of Aunt Jemima and the Racist Origins of the Brand

The recent social media posts claiming that Nancy Green, a former slave, created the Aunt Jemima brand and became a millionaire philanthropist have gone viral. However, a closer examination of the actual history reveals that these claims are largely inaccurate.

The Aunt Jemima brand was actually created by Chris Rutt and Charles Underwood, who named their pancake flour after a minstrel show song titled "Old Aunt Jemima." Nancy Green was hired to portray the image of a "mammy," a racist stereotype of an amiable, older, overweight African American woman who served in a domestic role to whites. The logo has undergone six changes over the years to move away from this stereotype.

According to Patricia Turner, a professor in UCLA's Department of African American Studies, there is no record of what Nancy Green was paid or what her relationship with the brand was like. While it is possible that she was paid well enough to support her church and activities, it is highly unlikely that she was a millionaire philanthropist.

The actual history of Nancy Green and other African Americans in similar roles during that time period is difficult to uncover due to spotty record-keeping. However, what is known suggests that her relationship with the Aunt Jemima brand was not the equal, beneficial partnership that these social media posts make it out to be.

In conclusion, the social media posts downplaying the racist nature of the Aunt Jemima brand rely on factually incorrect information and fabrications for which there is no record. The true story of Aunt Jemima is one of a brand created by white businessmen and perpetuating harmful stereotypes, rather than a story of empowerment and success for African Americans.

Title: Media Criticism and Accountability: A Call to Transparency

The article is a scathing critique of the media's handling of the Trump administration, specifically the use of anonymous sources and the perpetuation of a narrative that portrays the president as incompetent and malicious. The author argues that the media's reliance on anonymous sources creates an atmosphere of national anxiety and hysteria, and that the lack of transparency and accountability undermines the public's trust in the press.

The article highlights several instances where the media has been accused of spreading misinformation or presenting conflicting information, citing examples such as the botched special-forces raid in Yemen and the disputed transcript of Trump's call with the Mexican president. The author also questions the motivations of the media, suggesting that some may be using their platforms to advance their own careers or political agendas rather than serving the public interest.

The article concludes by calling on the media to adopt a more transparent and accountable approach, urging journalists to go on the record and provide credible sources to support their claims. The author argues that if the media truly believes the president is a menace, they should be willing to risk their careers to expose the truth and serve the public interest.

Title: House Approves Bipartisan Border Funding Bill, Sending it to President Trump's Desk

The House of Representatives has approved a $4.6 billion border funding bill, sending it to President Trump's desk for his expected signature. The bill, which was passed with bipartisan support, provides funding to address the humanitarian crisis at the southern border and ease a cash crunch at federal agencies that care for migrants.

The bill was sent to the House floor after Speaker Nancy Pelosi backed down from a push to include restrictions on immigration enforcement, which could have scuttled the measure. The Senate had previously approved the bill with an 84-8 vote, and the House's decision to pass it without restrictions came after intense pressure from Republicans and moderates.
