The bill aims to provide funding to address the humanitarian crisis at the border, which has seen a surge in migrants arriving at the border in recent months. The bill includes measures to ensure the health and safety of those in custody, limit the amount of time unaccompanied minors can spend at an influx shelter to 90 days, and reduce funding for ICE by $81 million.

However, liberal members of the House had sought to include additional measures, such as ensuring the health and safety of those in custody, limiting the amount of time unaccompanied minors can spend at an influx shelter to 90 days, and reducing funding for ICE by $81 million. These measures were rejected by Republicans, who argued that they would hinder efforts to address the humanitarian crisis.

The decision to pass the bill without restrictions has sparked controversy among liberal members of the House, with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) declaring "Hell no" to voting on the Senate bill. Other liberal members, such as Rep. Jim McGovern (D-Mass.), have accused Republicans of engaging in "antics" and prioritizing grandstanding over providing aid to migrants.

The bill's passage comes as pressure mounts on lawmakers to address the humanitarian crisis at the border. Reports of poor and unsanitary conditions at detention centers have sparked outrage, and the publication of an image of a migrant and his daughter found drowned in the Rio Grande has fueled the debate nationally.

The White House has threatened to veto the House version of the bill, which included restrictions on immigration enforcement. However, the Senate's bipartisan bill has been praised by both sides, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) urging the House to pass the bill and send it to the president's desk.

Title: Trump Campaign Highlights Economic Progress as Democrats Face 2020 Challenges

The Trump campaign is emphasizing the president's accomplishments and the benefits Americans have seen since his election in 2016. As the Iowa Caucuses approach in less than 12 weeks, the Democratic Party is facing concerns about their ability to beat Trump in the 2020 election. The Republican National Committee (RNC) has released new data showing that voters in key battleground states, including New Hampshire, Michigan, and Pennsylvania, believe they are better off financially today than they were three years ago.

According to the RNC's data, voters in Michigan are 17 percent more likely to believe they are better off financially today than they were three years ago. In New Hampshire, voters are 33 percent more likely to feel the same way, while in Pennsylvania, they are 20 percent more likely. The data also shows that working moms in these states are more likely to feel their financial situation has improved since Trump took office.

The RNC invested over $350 million in data tracking key issues in every state, allowing their data and analytics team to closely monitor electorates and the issues that are important to them. According to Bill Skelly, CEO of Causeway Solutions, the RNC's data is "unmatched" and provides Republicans with a valuable asset that their Democratic counterparts are "rightly jealous of." The data is provided to campaigns at the federal, state, and local levels free of charge, with the only request being that Republicans keep the data up-to-date when they knock on doors and phone bank.

The Trump campaign is highlighting these statistics as evidence that Americans are benefiting from the president's policies, including tax cuts and the confirmation of 99 judges. Trump Victory spokesperson Rick Gorka stated, "Democrats know they can't beat President Donald Trump at the ballot box in 2020. The American people are better off today than they were three years ago, and a socialist nominee would only destroy the economic progress enjoyed by tens of millions."

Title: Trump's Strong Historical Arguments for Reelection

The article discusses President Donald Trump's potential advantages in the 2020 presidential election. As an incumbent, Trump has historically had a strong track record of winning reelection, with 14 out of 19 incumbent presidents since 1900 winning their bids for a second term. Additionally, Trump's approval ratings have been steadily increasing since the impeachment proceedings against him began in September 2019, with his Gallup approval rating now at 49%, his highest since his inauguration.

The article also highlights Trump's strong economic record, with low inflation, low interest rates, positive economic growth, near-record low unemployment, rising workers' wages, and record gas and oil production. This has contributed to his high approval rating among the public, with 63% of Americans approving of his economic performance, the highest rating for any president in the last 20 years.

Furthermore, Trump's opponents, such as Senator Bernie Sanders, have been criticized for their radical agendas, which may turn off a majority of the public. Sanders' socialist policies and redistribution schemes have been met with skepticism, and his opponents, such as former front-runner Joe Biden, have been hurt by revelations about their personal scandals.

The article concludes that Trump's greatest advantage in 2020 may be his most likely opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders, and that the election appears to be Trump's to lose.

Title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Right-Wing Media, But Some See Biased Approach

Article:

In her book "What Happened," Hillary Clinton has sparked controversy by labeling the right-wing media as a "war on truth." However, some critics argue that her approach is one-sided and fails to acknowledge the media's role in perpetuating polarization.

Clinton's criticism of the right-wing media is not new, as she has long been vocal about her disdain for outlets like Fox News. In her book, she specifically targets Fox, calling it a "dedicated propaganda channel" and lumping it together with other conservative outlets. However, some have pointed out that this criticism is overly broad and fails to distinguish between the news division and opinion-based programming.

Clinton also takes aim at individual journalists, such as Matt Lauer, whom she accuses of being tougher on her than Trump during a Commander-in-Chief forum. However, others have argued that Lauer's questions were fair and that Clinton's defensiveness is misplaced.

Clinton's criticism of the media is not limited to right-wing outlets. She also takes aim at the New York Times, which she accuses of perpetuating a narrative that she has a "penchant for secrecy" due to her use of personal email. However, many would argue that this is a valid criticism, and Clinton's attempts to downplay the issue come across as defensive.

The polarization of the media landscape is a complex issue, and Clinton's book does not provide a nuanced view of the topic. While it is true that some conservatives have been critical of the media, it is also true that liberal pundits and organizations have been quick to attack Trump as a racist, sexist liar and question his mental stability.

Ultimately, Clinton's criticism of the media is seen by some as a way to deflect attention from her own mistakes and failures during the 2016 election. Her book has been met with skepticism by many, who see her approach as overly defensive and lacking in self-awareness.

Title: Threatening Letter to President Obama Intercepted, Similar to Those Sent to Mayor Bloomberg and Gun-Control Group

The Secret Service has confirmed that a threatening letter addressed to President Obama was intercepted this week, similar to the ricin-tainted letters sent to New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and his gun-control group, Mayors Against Illegal Guns. The letter was discovered on Wednesday and has been turned over to the FBI Joint Terrorism Task Force for testing and investigation.

According to the Secret Service, all presidential mail is examined at an off-site facility, and the Obama letter was not opened before it was shipped out for testing. Federal officials close to the investigation said the letter appeared to have the same postmark and handwriting as the ones sent to Bloomberg and Mayors Against Illegal Guns.

The letters, postmarked May 20 in Shreveport, Louisiana, were opened in New York on Friday at the city's mail facility in Manhattan and in Washington on Sunday at an office of Mayors Against Illegal Guns. The New York Police Department has confirmed that the letters contain threatening language related to gun-owner rights.

The FBI has also announced that another letter with ricin was mailed to Obama from Spokane, Washington, and was intercepted on May 22. Authorities have arrested a man in connection with that letter.

The letters to Bloomberg and his group included threatening language, with one letter stating, "You will have to kill me and my family before you get my guns. Anyone wants to come to my house will get shot in the face. The right to bear arms is my constitutional God-given right and I will exercise that right till the day I die." Bloomberg has stated that the letters refer to the group's anti-gun efforts, but they will not be deterred from their work.

The letters addressed to Bloomberg and Mark Glaze, director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, both tested positive for ricin, and more testing is scheduled. Three New York officers involved in the case experienced mild diarrhea, a minor symptom of ricin exposure, while Glaze showed no symptoms after opening the letter.

The investigation is ongoing, with the FBI and Joint Terrorism Task Force working to determine who sent the letters and where the ricin came from.

Title: Trump Criticizes Senator Who Revealed Gorsuch's Criticism of Remarks on Judges

Article:

President Donald Trump launched a verbal attack on Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal, who revealed that Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch expressed criticism of Trump's recent attacks on judges. During a private meeting, Gorsuch reportedly told Blumenthal that Trump's comments were "demoralizing" and "disheartening." A member of the Supreme Court nomination team also confirmed the remarks to NPR.

Gorsuch's team later disputed the characterization of the comments, stating that they were "mischaracterized." Trump also took aim at Blumenthal, accusing him of exaggerating his military service. In 2010, Blumenthal was criticized for falsely claiming he served in Vietnam, when in fact he received several deferments and served in the Marine reserves.

The controversy surrounding Blumenthal's military record dates back to his 2010 Senate campaign. The New York Times uncovered that Blumenthal said at a 2008 event honoring veterans and service members, "We have learned something important since the days that I served in Vietnam." However, Blumenthal later apologized and said he meant to say, "I served during Vietnam."

Trump's attacks on the judiciary are highly unusual for a sitting president. Gorsuch has been a federal judge since 2006 and has been meeting with senators in preparation for his confirmation hearings. Republican Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska revealed even stronger comments by Gorsuch, stating that he "got pretty passionate" and said, "Any attack on any of — I think his word to me was — 'brothers or sisters of the robe is an attack on all judges.'"

The White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, defended Trump's attacks on the judiciary, stating that Gorsuch was not specifically talking about Trump's tweet about the "so-called" Judge Robart. However, it is unclear why the Supreme Court nominee would bring up criticism of judges unless to talk about the president's recent statements that did just that. The statements also contradict Sasse's account of their talk.

**French Police Officer Dies After Offering Himself as Hostage in Supermarket Attack**

A French police officer, Col. Arnaud Beltrame, died on Friday after offering himself as a hostage to an Islamic extremist gunman in a supermarket in the south of France. The attack has left four people dead, including the gunman, and 15 others injured.

Beltrame, a decorated officer with over 15 years of service, was among the first responders to the attack. He had organized a training session in December for hostage situations, where he armed his officers with paintball guns to simulate real-life conditions.

When the gunman, identified as Morocco-born Redouane Lakdim, took hostages at the Super U supermarket, Beltrame gave up his own weapon and volunteered himself as a hostage. Unbeknownst to the gunman, Beltrame left his cellphone on, allowing police outside to hear what was happening inside the store. Police stormed the building when they heard gunshots, and Beltrame was fatally wounded.

The attack began when Lakdim hijacked a car near Carcassonne, killing one person and wounding another. He then fired at police officers, hitting one in the shoulder, and went to the Super U supermarket, where he killed two people and took an unknown number of hostages.

French President Emmanuel Macron paid tribute to Beltrame, calling him a "hero" who gave his life to end the deadly plan of a jihadi terrorist. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities focusing on how Lakdim obtained his weapon and became radicalized.

The attack is the latest in a series of extremist attacks in France, which has been on high alert since a series of attacks in 2015 and 2016 that killed over 200 people.

Title: House Republicans Request Documents from IRS Official's Personal Email Account

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has requested documents and communications from Lois Lerner, a former IRS official at the center of an investigation into the agency's targeting of Tea Party groups, related to her personal email account. The request comes after it was discovered that Lerner allegedly used her personal email account, labeled "Lois Home," for official business.

According to a letter sent by Committee Chairman Darrell Issa, the request is aimed at understanding the extent to which Lerner may have used her personal email account for official purposes. Issa expressed concerns that such activity could violate federal records requirements, create difficulties in filing Freedom of Information Act requests, and frustrate congressional oversight obligations.

The IRS acknowledged earlier this year that it had targeted Tea Party groups and other conservative organizations between 2010 and 2012, delaying their applications for nonprofit status. Lerner, the former director of the IRS's Exempt Organizations unit, invoked her Fifth Amendment rights in May when called to testify on the issue and has since been on paid leave.

The House oversight committee has given Lerner until August 27 to comply with the request, which also covers any other non-official account that references Lerner's official IRS duties. A committee spokesman told FoxNews.com that documents could be subpoenaed, but declined to say whether investigators would take such action. An IRS spokesman stated that agency officials are awaiting receipt of the letter and will review it.

The targeting of Tea Party groups sparked public outrage and several other probes, including one by the FBI. The House oversight committee has also complained that acting IRS Commissioner Danny Wurfel has failed to comply promptly with requests to supply documents related to the investigation.

Title: Polls Show Tight Race, Romney Edges Ahead in Some Surveys

The 2012 presidential election is entering its final stretch, with polls showing a close race between incumbent President Barack Obama and challenger Mitt Romney. Three recent polls have released their results, with some indicating a slight edge for Romney.

Rasmussen's daily tracker has Romney leading Obama 49-47, while the Obama campaign has been stuck in the 46-47 range for days. In the 11 swing states, Romney leads Obama 50-46, with 2% of voters supporting other candidates and 2% undecided.

The Washington Post/ABC News poll shows Romney leading Obama by a single point, 49-48. However, the poll's internals suggest a more significant lead for Romney, with the Republican candidate winning independents by 15 points and neutralizing the gender gap.

The Politico/GWU Battleground poll has Obama inching back ahead by a single point, 49-48, but the internals tell a different story. Romney leads among independents by double digits, 50-40, and has a 13-point intensity advantage among his supporters.

The Battleground poll's "vote election model" projects Romney winning the election 52-47, with Romney also leading among middle-class voters, 52-45. The poll's methodology takes into account voter intensity, age, and education, as well as voters who are certain in their vote.

Gallup's daily tracker shows a five-point Romney lead, 51-46. Rasmussen's daily tracker has Republicans edging Democrats by 2.6 points, with a partisan breakdown of 34% Democrats, 37% Republicans, and 29% independents.

The polls highlight the tight race and the challenges both campaigns face in the final week before the election.

Title: FEMA and HHS Emphasize Global Pandemic Efforts, State-Managed Response, and Supply Chain Challenges

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) are working together to address the global pandemic, emphasizing the need for a locally-executed, state-managed, and federally-supported response. According to FEMA, the demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) and other supplies continues to outstrip supply globally, not just in the United States.

Despite the administration's claims of a successful testing ramp-up, public health experts agree that the U.S. is still not testing enough people to accurately track the virus's spread. The nation's testing figures have increased over the past month, but officials acknowledge that the U.S. is still not testing enough to have an accurate picture of the virus's spread.

FEMA and HHS are working to ensure federal contracting efforts do not compete with states' abilities to acquire PPE and other supplies. The administration has touted the nation's testing ramp-up, stating that the U.S. is conducting more tests than any other country in the world. However, officials have cautioned that states trying to test scores of patients are hampered by equipment and gear shortages.

The article highlights the challenges faced by states in securing testing supplies and PPE, with officials stating that funding and staff are not the main limiting factors, but rather the ability to secure these supplies. The article also notes that the administration has only just begun to shift its efforts from scrambling to import supplies to trying to boost domestic production of key materials like protective equipment.

The article also touches on the concerns of health officials regarding the potential for new coronavirus outbreaks as states begin to lift their distancing restrictions. Officials on a May 1 call expressed concerns about the likelihood of new hot spots in prisons, meat processing plants, and other high-risk facilities. The article notes that at least two states, South Carolina and Georgia, were planning to reopen despite logging zero consecutive days of decreasing cases, and that new Covid-19 cases were up 65% and deaths were up nearly 103% over a two-week period in Georgia.

The article concludes by highlighting the ongoing efforts of health officials to monitor for outbreaks and the potential for new waves of coronavirus cases to threaten the nation's health system. Officials emphasized the need for continuous monitoring and the potential for reinitiating mitigation measures if needed.

Title: Ottawa Shooting: What We Know and Don't Know

A day after a gunman killed an army reservist in Ottawa, many questions remain. The attack on Wednesday, which killed Nathan Cirillo, was the latest in a series of troubling incidents in the nation. On Monday, a man Canadian authorities said was "radicalized" hit a soldier with a car in Quebec, killing him. Passports for the men in both attacks had been confiscated before the attacks, with no immediate indication that the incidents were related.

The gunman, identified as Michael Joseph Hall, who changed his name to Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, was born in Canada in 1982. Authorities said he converted to Islam, but there is no indication so far that he was part of the militant group ISIS. The motive behind the attack is still unknown, and it may never be fully known.

Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson said the gunman was acting alone, and a U.S. law enforcement official told CNN that a connection to terrorism has not been ruled out. Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper stated that the events are a grim reminder that Canada is not immune to the types of terrorist attacks seen elsewhere in the world.

Nathan Cirillo, the Canadian army reservist who was killed, was described as a strong and smiling individual who loved snuggling with his dog, enjoying music, and joking with friends. He was part of the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, a reserve unit of the Canadian army.

Kevin Vickers, sergeant-at-arms of Canada's House of Commons, is credited with bringing down the gunman. Details on how he stopped the gunman are still unclear, with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police stating that more information will be provided in a news conference.

The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear whether the gunman had any ties to any group or groups. The U.S. heightened security at the Ottawa embassy and another consulate in the country after jihadist chatter indicated an attack could be in the works, according to officials.

Title: Ohio Senate Candidates Brown and Mandel Engage in Heated Campaign Trail

Article:

Ohio is a crucial battleground state in the upcoming presidential election, and the state's Senate seat is also up for grabs. Incumbent Democrat Sherrod Brown is facing a challenge from Republican challenger Josh Mandel, who is highlighting Brown's support for the Affordable Care Act (ACA). The two candidates have been crisscrossing the state, touting their respective platforms and criticizing each other's records.

Brown, who is seeking re-election, visited the West Side Market in Cleveland, where he touted a federal grant that helps vendors accept food stamps. However, the conversation quickly turned to his campaign and Mandel's name was not mentioned. Brown emphasized his focus on job creation, saying he wakes up every day thinking about how to create jobs, whereas Mandel is focused on running for office.

Brown is one of 60 senators who voted for the ACA, and he is pleased that most of it was upheld by the Supreme Court. However, he demurred when asked if he would campaign on the law, saying he believes there are many good things in it and will continue to support it. Some voters, however, want him to discuss the law more, citing its unpopularity.

Mandel, a 34-year-old former Marine intelligence officer and Tea Party favorite, is a fast-rising star in the Republican Party. He is highlighting Brown's vote for the ACA, saying it is a government takeover of healthcare. However, the independent fact-checking group Politifact has labeled this claim as false.

The two candidates have also clashed on campaign spending, with Mandel saying he is the underdog when it comes to fundraising. However, records show that outside groups backing Mandel have spent nearly five times more than groups backing Brown. The Brown campaign has received support from labor unions and other groups, while Mandel has received support from business groups opposed to his union-friendly voting record.

Recent polls show Brown ahead of Mandel by single digits, but the gap is narrowing as outside money continues to pour in. The two candidates will continue to crisscross the state, touting their respective platforms and criticizing each other's records.

Title: Mueller Investigation May Target Trump or Family Members in 2019

The special counsel investigation into Russian meddling and possible collusion with the Trump campaign is expected to advance significantly in 2019, potentially targeting President Donald Trump or his family members. After two years of the Trump presidency, the national mood is tense, and the country is bracing for a potentially tumultuous year.

The investigation, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, has been notoriously leak-proof, with Mueller's team not releasing any private information. However, legal experts and observers believe that Mueller may present evidence of alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, as well as obstruction of justice by the president.

One possible scenario is that Mueller may target Trump himself, his son Donald Trump Jr., or his son-in-law Jared Kushner, who are all legally exposed to charges of making false statements to investigators or Congress. The investigation may also focus on the June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower and the February 2017 meeting between Trump and former FBI Director James Comey, where Comey said Trump encouraged him to drop an investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn.

Other potential areas of focus include the hush payments made to adult film star Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal, as well as new details about projects or prospective projects advanced by Trump and his family in Moscow or the Middle East. The investigation may also explore the nature of the Trump campaign's relationships with foreign backers during the 2016 election.

While it is impossible to predict the exact direction of the investigation, legal experts agree that Mueller's investigation is likely to have significant consequences for the Trump administration. As University of Michigan law professor Barb McQuade noted, "People tend to lie under a situation as serious as that only if they believe that the truth would be worse. And so if they're lying about the Trump Tower Moscow, what truth about that is worse?"

Title: Arkansas Oil Spill Raises Concerns About Keystone XL Pipeline

The recent oil spill in Arkansas, caused by ExxonMobil's Pegasus pipeline, has sparked concerns among environmental activists and others about the proposed Keystone XL pipeline. The spill, which has forced the evacuation of over 20 families in the small town of Mayflower, has raised questions about the safety of large-scale pipeline projects.

The incident comes at a critical moment for the Keystone XL pipeline, which has been delayed for years and is currently under review by the Obama administration. The project enjoys bipartisan support in Congress and is backed by a strong majority of American people, according to a recent survey.

However, critics of the pipeline are using the Arkansas spill as an example of what can go wrong with large-scale pipeline projects. They argue that the spill is a reminder that oil companies cannot be trusted to transport toxic tar sands crude through American backyards.

"This latest toxic mess is just another reminder that oil companies can not be trusted to transport toxic tar sands crude through Americans' backyards," said Michael Brune, executive director of the Sierra Club. "It's not a matter of if spills will occur on dangerous pipelines like the Keystone XL, but rather, when."

Some environmental groups are also arguing that the thick Canadian oil sands could pose unique dangers to pipelines due to faster corrosion and other factors. The exact cause of the spill is still unclear and is under investigation.

The Arkansas spill is the latest in a series of incidents raised by Keystone critics to demonstrate holes in both pipeline safety and other dangers associated with crude oil transport. They are also pointing to last week's rupture of a Chevron Corp. pipeline in Utah and the derailment of a southbound train carrying Canadian oil sands through Minnesota.

Meanwhile, even before the Arkansas incident, President Obama was set to hear from the environmental movement. Liberal activist group Credo, the Sierra Club, and others have organized a protest in front of a Democratic Party fundraiser in San Francisco, an event the president is scheduled to attend. Credo has also promised to mobilize more than 50,000 activists to engage in "civil disobedience" in front of government office buildings, outside banks financing the project, and at other locations if Mr. Obama greenlights Keystone.

Support for the pipeline had been increasing both in Congress and among voters, though it remains to be seen whether that support erodes because of what's happened in Arkansas. A recent survey found that 58 percent of likely U.S. voters support building the pipeline, while just 26 percent are opposed to it.

Title: Benghazi Committee Requests Transcribed Interview with Hillary Clinton on Email Practices

The Benghazi investigative committee has formally requested a transcribed interview with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to clarify her decision-making regarding her email practices during her tenure. The request comes as the State Department begins to release some of Clinton's emails, which she had previously withheld for years.

Chairman Trey Gowdy, a South Carolina Republican, emphasized that Clinton's "unique arrangement with herself" needs to be explained, as she claimed complete control over government business email. The committee is seeking to understand why Clinton refused a government-issued account and set up her own server, why she kept the emails herself instead of turning them over to the State Department, and how she decided which emails to delete and which to turn over.

The committee has also requested that Clinton turn over her server to a neutral third party, which her team has rejected, citing compliance with the law. Clinton's spokesman, Nick Merrill, stated that she is willing to appear at a public hearing, but did not address the request for a transcribed interview.

The White House has declined to comment on the matter, stating that it is up to Clinton, who is no longer part of the Obama administration. The State Department has begun releasing some of Clinton's emails, with the process expected to take several months. The department has also rejected a request from Judicial Watch, a conservative legal group, to expedite the release of the emails.

The controversy surrounding Clinton's email practices has sparked questions about her decision-making and potential motivations. The release of some emails has already revealed inconsistencies with her previous claims, including the use of an iPad in addition to her mobile phone for sending emails. The committee's investigation is ongoing, with the goal of shedding light on Clinton's email practices and their implications.

Title: Snowden's Path to Justice: A Complicated and Uncharted Journey

The National Security Agency contractor, Edward Snowden, who admitted to leaking classified information, faces a complex and uncertain path to justice. Snowden, 29, is currently staying at a hotel in Hong Kong and hopes to win asylum in a country like Iceland. However, his situation is unique and lacks precedent, making it difficult to predict the outcome.

Legal experts expect that the charges Snowden would face would carry maximum penalties of 10 years apiece, but he would not be subject to the same penalties as Bradley Manning, who is facing life imprisonment for providing classified information to WikiLeaks. Snowden's case is different because he did not sell the secrets or give them to a foreign power, unlike Robert Hanssen and Aldrich Ames, who were caught spying.

The Justice Department can charge Snowden, but to go beyond that, he would need to be brought back to U.S. soil. The extradition treaty between the United States and Hong Kong contains an exception for political crimes, which Snowden's admitted acts would almost certainly fall under. However, Hong Kong could decide to expel him without turning him over to American authorities.

The situation is further complicated by Hong Kong's reversion to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, making it unclear which government would decide Snowden's status. The questions are even more complicated given the recent summit between President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping aimed at improving relations between the two countries. If the United States seeks to extradite Snowden, it could have major diplomatic consequences, and remanding him to the United States might serve as an act of good faith for the Chinese, but they would likely have high demands for what they would want in return.

The United States does not have a separate extradition treaty with China, making it unclear which government would take the lead in deciding Snowden's fate. "There has to be a political decision on the part of the extraditing country that that sort of act is in its political interest," said Ryan Scoville, an expert in international law at Marquette University Law School.

If Snowden can get himself to a Hong Kong consulate of a nation that will welcome him, he could stay there indefinitely without being captured by U.S. or Chinese officials. Julian Assange of WikiLeaks has gone this route in London, staying in Ecuador's embassy for nearly a year to avoid extradition to Sweden on sexual assault charges. While it is unlikely that another country would shelter Snowden and bear the political costs of harboring such a high-profile American wanted by the U.S. government, the possibility remains.

In conclusion, Snowden's path to justice is complex and uncharted, with many factors at play. His situation is unique, and the outcome is uncertain, making it difficult to predict what the future holds for the former National Security Agency contractor.

Title: Polls Indicate Hillary Clinton's Lead Over Trump Widening, Democrats Poised for Victory

The latest polls suggest a significant lead for Hillary Clinton in the presidential race, with an average margin of 6.6 points over Donald Trump, according to FiveThirtyEight's model. The ABC tracking poll, designated as A+, shows Clinton with a 12-point lead over Trump, a larger margin than in most other polls. This trend is reflected in the averages across the board, with Clinton's percentage up by a comfortable margin.

The FiveThirtyEight model gives Clinton an 85% probability of winning, while The New York Times Upshot estimates a 92% probability. The Upshot also provides side-by-side comparisons of all predictions, with all models showing Clinton with an 85% or higher chance of winning.

In terms of down-ballot races, the Democrats are looking strong, with a decent possibility of winning the Senate if they retain the White House. However, this outcome is not assured, and some analysts are predicting ticket splitting, where voters support Clinton but also vote for a Republican incumbent senator.

The House of Representatives is a different story, with the GOP's gerrymandering efforts making it difficult for Democrats to win a majority. However, the possibility of a Democratic win is not entirely ruled out, with some polls showing Clinton ahead by 5% or more. The magic number for House Democrats is a Clinton win by 8%, which is currently within reach.

The shift in the polls is attributed to several factors, including Trump's controversial behavior, particularly his 3 a.m. tweets about the former Miss Universe and the allegations of groping and assaulting women. Additionally, the right-wing media and Trump's campaign spread rumors about Clinton having brain damage or Parkinson's disease, which were barely covered in the mainstream media but had an impact on public perception.

The debates have also played a significant role in the shift, with Clinton's strong performance and Trump's inability to behave with discipline. The debates allowed voters to see what Clinton is made of, and it was clear that one of them was a president – and it wasn't Trump.

Title: The Perception of a "Gang of Thieves" in the US Government

The article discusses the perception that the US government is a "gang of thieves" due to a series of incidents involving the destruction of evidence and the lack of accountability. The author cites examples such as the CIA's destruction of a classified report on torture, the IRS's destruction of hard drives containing incriminating evidence, and Hillary Clinton's deletion of emails from her private server.

The author argues that these incidents raise questions about the government's commitment to transparency and accountability. They suggest that the government's actions are motivated by a desire to protect the guilty and avoid accountability, rather than a genuine attempt to follow the law.

The article also touches on the concept of "high-trust societies" and how the erosion of trust in the government can have negative consequences. The author quotes Gonzalo Lira, who warns that when law-abiding citizens see that those in power are not following the rules, they may decide that it is acceptable to do the same.

The article concludes by asking what the future holds for American society if these trends continue and what can be done to ensure that the government remains accountable to the people.

Title: Rep. Paul Ryan Visits Alma Mater, Hopes to Energize Young Voters

Article:

Representative Paul Ryan, the newly chosen vice presidential running mate for Republican Mitt Romney, visited his alma mater, Miami University of Ohio, on Wednesday. Ryan graduated from the university in 1992 with degrees in economics and political science. His selection as the GOP ticket's running mate has thrilled Rob Harrelson, a member of the school's College Republicans, who believes Ryan's youth, energy, and ideas about the economy will appeal to younger voters.

At 42, Ryan is the nation's first vice presidential candidate from Generation X. Harrelson, 21, thinks Ryan's budget proposal will resonate with college students, citing its focus on cutting government regulation and red tape, which he believes will help the economy. If true, this could be good news for Republicans, who struggled to win over young voters in the 2008 election, with only a third of voters under 30 supporting Sen. John McCain.

However, not all students at Miami University are familiar with Ryan or his budget plan. Many said they were either uninterested in the race or planning to check in on it later. According to census data, the youth turnout hit its third-highest rate ever in 2008, but many expect that number to drop in 2012.

Patrick Haney, a professor of political science at Miami University, is skeptical that Ryan's selection will make a significant difference in the youth vote. He believes it may be more about energizing the Republican base than bringing out young voters. Haney notes that young voters typically do not focus on the lower half of the ticket and that Ryan's stances on social issues like abortion and gay marriage may not align with typical college students.

Overall, while Ryan's visit to his alma mater may generate some excitement among college students, it remains to be seen whether his selection will have a significant impact on the youth vote in the upcoming election.

Title: FBI Officials' Anti-Trump Text Messages Raise Questions About "Secret Society" Within Department

The FBI officials involved in the investigation of Hillary Clinton's email scandal and the Russia probe, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, exchanged over 50,000 text messages, including references to a "secret society" within the Department of Justice and the FBI. The messages, which were revealed by lawmakers with knowledge of the matter, have raised questions about the objectivity of the FBI's investigations during the 2016 presidential election.

According to Rep. Trey Gowdy, the "secret society" reference was made the day after President Trump's election victory. Gowdy stated that the exchange between Strzok and Page mentioned the possibility of a "first meeting" of the "secret society." Gowdy expressed his desire to know more about the context behind the term, as it could potentially undermine the FBI's objectivity in investigating Trump.

The revelation is not the first time the messages have raised concerns about the FBI's actions during the election. In a previously released message, Strzok appeared to make a reference to an "insurance policy" against a Trump win. The message was interpreted as a plan to investigate Trump's campaign, which could have been seen as biased.

The FBI has acknowledged that it failed to preserve five months of texts between Strzok and Page, which spanned the presidential transition and the launch of the Russia probe. The agency has promised to investigate the missing messages and provide an update to Congress if they are recovered.

The controversy has sparked a new wave of scrutiny, with Attorney General Jeff Sessions urging FBI Director Christopher Wray to fire Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, who is at the center of the controversy. The White House Counsel has reportedly told Sessions that firing McCabe would be a mistake and could lead to another media firestorm.

President Trump has described the missing messages as "one of the biggest stories in a long time." The investigation is ongoing, and the FBI is working to recover the missing messages and provide an explanation for their absence.

Title: Senator Ted Cruz Correctly States Decline in Gun Prosecutions Under President Obama

Article:

Senator Ted Cruz recently stated on "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno" that under President Obama, prosecution of gun crimes was 30% lower than under President George W. Bush. Politifact, a left-leaning fact-checking website, disputed this claim, citing a cherry-picked comparison between the highest number of prosecutions under Bush (11,015 in 2004) and the lowest number under Obama (7,774 in 2012). However, Cruz's statement is accurate when considering any year from 2002 to 2008, which would show more prosecutions under Bush.

Cruz's spokesman, Catherine Frazier, emphasized that the senator believes the focus should be on prosecuting violent criminals, not restricting Second Amendment rights. The Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse from Syracuse University tracks prosecutions with a lead charge of firearms-related offenses, which shows that the most common prosecution is for felons possessing firearms. In 2012, 5,487 felons were charged with possession, but it is unclear how many were prosecuted.

Politifact criticized the Syracuse data and instead used Justice Department figures, which show a higher number of gun charges in 2004 (12,962) compared to 2012 (11,728). However, these figures are irrelevant to the debate on gun control, as new laws aim to reduce access to firearms, not overall violence.

Senator Cruz co-sponsored the Grassley-Cruz amendment, which focused on prosecuting existing laws on background checks instead of expanding the system. The critical issue is that the bad guys are not getting caught when attempting to illegally buy guns. According to the most recent data from 2010, 94% of denials for gun purchases through the FBI's National Instant Background Checks System were not investigated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF). Only 62 charges were referred to prosecutors, and only 13 led to guilty pleas.

In conclusion, Senator Ted Cruz correctly stated that prosecution of gun crimes has not been a priority for the Obama administration, which is supported by the statistics.

Title: Debunking Five Common Myths About the House Freedom Caucus

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of approximately 40 conservative Republican lawmakers, has been a target of misinformation and mischaracterization in the media. This article aims to set the record straight by addressing five common myths about the HFC.

Myth 1: The House Freedom Caucus Is Trying to Shut Down the Government

The HFC is not seeking to shut down the government, but rather wants to return to regular order and have a real conversation about spending. The Constitution intended for Congress to enact 12 appropriations bills over the course of the year, allowing for debate and ensuring wise and responsible spending. The HFC wants to restore this process, rather than being forced to vote on omnibus bills without adequate time for review.

Myth 2: The House Freedom Caucus Is Shut Out of the Lawmaking Process

The HFC has been punished by their party's leadership for dissent against House Speaker John Boehner, rather than being shut out. They want to keep promises made to their constituents and avoid supporting bills that would make them hypocrites in the eyes of their voters.

Myth 3: The House Freedom Caucus Is Only Interested in Attacking Obama

The HFC's differences with President Obama are not personal, but rather a desire to negotiate with him. The president has been unwilling to come to the table and discuss his agenda, and the HFC wants to force him to engage in a real conversation. The HFC is not interested in attacking Obama, but rather in finding common ground and working together.

Myth 4: The House Freedom Caucus Is Bad for the Party

The HFC's vigorous disagreement with party leadership is not chaos, but rather a healthy debate that ensures the truth emerges. The Founding Fathers wanted politicians to engage in debate and present a range of opinions, not just a watered-down party line. The HFC wants to follow up rhetoric with actual action.

Myth 5: The House Freedom Caucus Is a Bunch of Right-Wing Marxists

This myth is simply false. The HFC stands in direct opposition to the policies of Marx, and wants to combat the $18 trillion debt, economic stagnation, an entitlement system that is going bankrupt, and a government that encroaches on personal liberty. These are all things the GOP claims to stand for, but the HFC wants to follow up rhetoric with actual action.

Title: Judge Orders Trump Administration to Pay for Reuniting Separated Immigrant Families

A U.S. judge in California has ordered the Trump administration to pay for the costs of reuniting immigrant parents with their children, who were separated from them by officials at the U.S.-Mexican border. The decision comes as the government works to reunite around 2,000 children with their parents, who were detained and separated as part of the administration's "zero tolerance" approach to deter illegal immigration.

U.S. District Judge Dana Sabraw, who ordered the reunifications by July 26, stated that it does not make sense for parents who have been separated to pay for anything. The government missed a deadline this week for getting the youngest of the children back with their parents.

The Trump administration adopted the family separation policy as part of its effort to discourage illegal immigration, but Trump bowed to intense political pressure and abandoned the policy on June 20. A lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), which has sued the administration over the family separations, said that immigrant parents had been told by immigration officials they had to pay for their travel. One parent was initially asked to pay $1,900 to be reunited with a child, according to ACLU court papers.

The Trump administration's lawyer, Sarah Fabian, called the judge's order on paying for the reunifications "a huge ask on HHS," referring to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Fabian said that those decisions were handled at the field level and that HHS had limited resources.

The judge also agreed to impose timelines on the government for reporting details about its reunification efforts. The administration has said its initial reunifications were slowed by the need for DNA testing and criminal background checks on parents, and to determine their fitness to care for their children.

In a filing with the court, HHS official Chris Meekins said the administration had streamlined its vetting procedures to comply with a July 10 court order, but that the swifter process could put children at risk. Adults are no longer being DNA tested to verify parentage, and background checks are not being performed on adults who will be living with the children. Meekins said that while the abbreviated vetting speeds up the reunification process, it also "materially increases the risk of harm to children" and could result in children being placed in abusive environments or with adults who are not their parents.

The government said it intends to identify between six and eight locations where all reunifications will take place. The government's filing did not specify whether it intends to release families after reunification, deport them, or keep them together in detention.

Title: Decline in Support for Controversial Speech Among College-Aged Americans Over the Past Four Decades

The General Social Survey has been tracking American attitudes towards the right to give a racist speech in one's community since the 1970s. John Sides, writing for The Washington Post, analyzed the data and divided the respondents into four groups: Americans aged 18-25 with and without a college education, and older Americans with and without a college education. The results show a striking trend.

The percentage of college-age individuals supporting the right to give a racist speech has decreased significantly over the past four decades. However, the decline is not unique to this age group, as the non-college-educated population has also seen a decrease in support. The data reveals that the biggest drop occurred in the late 1980s, with a slight decline in the 1990s and a more significant decline in the 21st century.

This finding challenges the common perception that the 1990s were the era of political correctness, as many people assume that the decade saw a surge in pro-censorship sentiments. However, the data suggests that the 1990s were actually a time of backlash against political correctness, with more people resisting the trend.

The analysis also examines the percentage of Americans who support the right to give a speech by communists. While the decline in support among college-educated individuals is not as severe, there is still a noticeable drop, followed by a flattening in the 1990s and a resurgence in the post-9/11 era.

The data shows that the trend of declining support for controversial speech does not apply to older Americans, particularly those without a college education, who have actually become more tolerant over time. The article also notes that the decline in collegiate civil libertarianism resumed in the 21st century, with one possible factor being that the further one gets into the century, the fewer people who remember the 1980s and the backlash against political correctness.

Title: Presidential Candidates Refuse to Concede, Prepare for Conventions Despite Recent Losses

Article:

Despite significant losses in the New York primaries, both Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz have vowed to continue their campaigns, refusing to concede defeat. On the Republican side, Cruz has no realistic path to overtake Donald Trump, while Sanders would need to win 73% of the remaining delegates and uncommitted superdelegates to catch up with Hillary Clinton.

Clinton, on the other hand, could lose every remaining primary and still clinch the nomination. She has already begun positioning herself as the all-but-certain nominee, while her campaign aide stated that Sanders has no mathematical chance of a comeback.

Cruz and Sanders are recalibrating their approach and rhetoric, focusing on the delegate-selection process and courting "unbound" delegates to strengthen their positions going into the Cleveland convention. Cruz aims to have delegate allies in place from across the country who would peel off from Trump and support him after the first round of voting.

Meanwhile, Trump is focusing on racking up delegates in the coming weeks to reach the 1,237 threshold and rule out the possibility of a contested convention. According to an internal memo, Trump projects he will get over 1,400 delegates on the first round of balloting to secure the nomination.

On the Democratic side, Sanders is pursuing a tricky strategy, relying on the prospect of winning over superdelegates, the party insiders and officials free to support whomever they want. However, Clinton holds an overwhelming lead among them and is well-positioned to reach the 2,383 total delegates needed by the end of primaries in June.

Despite the odds, Sanders has given mixed signals on the heels of his New York loss, taking a day off from the campaign trail and saying he will reassess his strategy after the next week's primaries. However, he continues to claim he can still win and plans to return to the campaign trail in Pennsylvania on Thursday.

Title: Egyptian Court Orders Release of Former President Hosni Mubarak from Jail

Egyptian judicial officials have ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak from jail, a decision that could plunge the country into further turmoil. Mubarak, who ruled Egypt for three decades before being ousted in a popular revolution, is expected to be freed within the next 48 hours after a prosecutor cleared him of a corruption charge.

The move comes as Egypt is gripped by new protests following the ouster of Mubarak's successor, Mohammad Morsi, and amid fears of violent reprisals from the Muslim Brotherhood. The Brotherhood's supporters have clashed with security forces and torched dozens of Coptic churches, resulting in the deaths of as many as 1,000 Egyptians, including 70 soldiers and police officers.

Mubarak, who is on retrial for the killings of hundreds of protesters during the 2011 uprising that led to his ouster, will still face trial for the same charges, but cannot be held in custody beyond a two-year limit. He has been in detention since April 2011 and is being held at Tora prison on the southern outskirts of Cairo.

The judicial authorities ordered Mubarak's release in one of the remaining corruption cases against him, which alleged he and his two sons embezzled funds for presidential palaces. According to his lawyer, Fareed El-Deeb, the only legal grounds for Mubarak's detention rest on one other corruption case, which is slated to be cleared up this week.

The decision has sparked concerns about the potential for further violence, as the Muslim Brotherhood has accused the government of killing its supporters. The government has denied these allegations, saying that the detainees suffocated in the back of a prison van after tear gas was used on them as they rioted.

The international community is closely monitoring the situation, with the EU planning to meet on Wednesday to discuss the crisis. The U.S. has urged calm, but has not explicitly taken sides.

Title: Portfolio Manager Sees Similarities Between Current Market Frenzy and 2008 Financial Crisis

As the global financial markets continue to rally, Pilar Gomez-Bravo, a portfolio manager at MFS Investment Management, is sounding the alarm. With over a decade of experience in the industry, including a stint at Lehman Brothers, Gomez-Bravo has seen her fair share of market cycles. She believes that the current frenzy for risk is reminiscent of the speculative mania that preceded the 2008 financial crisis.

Gomez-Bravo is taking a contrarian approach, selling junk bonds and reducing her exposure to high-yield debt. She believes that the debt rally is on its last legs, with the potential to trap funds with billions of dollars invested in levered and often illiquid assets. According to Gomez-Bravo, the average U.S. high-yield bond spreads have fallen below 375 basis points, a level that has historically signified negative excess returns in a year's time.

As the director of fixed income for Europe, Gomez-Bravo oversees $4.5 billion in fixed-income assets. She has cut her high-yield exposure to 10% from as high as 30% in 2016, citing concerns about the opacity and leverage of junk issuers. Over a third of private high-yield companies in Europe restrict access to financial data, making it difficult for investors to make informed decisions.

Gomez-Bravo is not alone in her concerns. Bob Michele, a renowned credit bull at JPMorgan Asset Management, turned bear last month when average U.S. high-yield bond spreads fell below 375 basis points.

Despite her concerns, Gomez-Bravo is not leaving the party just yet. She is selling into a rising market and taking more political risk by adding to investments in peripheral governments like Greece and Italy. "There's more risk than reward right now," she said. "There are real end-of-cycle fears about what performs."

Gomez-Bravo's experience at Lehman Brothers during the 2008 financial crisis has given her a unique perspective on the current market. She was a portfolio manager at Lehman's investment arm when the company went bust, and she had previously worked as a senior credit analyst on Lehman's sellside. She left Lehman in 2006, citing frustration with unchecked animal spirits.

In May 2007, Gomez-Bravo became cautious on U.S. risk and issued warnings on corporate health, echoing her concerns today. "Everything was bid indiscriminately," she recalls. "I knew things were heating up; there were telltale signs. It's always difficult to leave money on the table, but as a result we avoided the blow-ups."

Title: Wisconsin to Hold In-Person Voting Despite Pandemic Concerns

Wisconsin is set to hold its presidential primary on Tuesday, despite concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The state's Republican-controlled legislature declined to take up an effort to delay the election, as proposed by Democratic Governor Tony Evers, to make it an all-mail election and extend the deadline for returning ballots until late May.

According to Reid Magney, public information officer for the Wisconsin Election Commission, the election will proceed as planned, with in-person voting available. The legislature, which has the authority to delay the election, did not take action on Evers' proposal. However, legislators could still reconsider in the coming days.

The decision has sparked controversy, with Evers criticizing the legislature for playing politics with public safety and ignoring the urgency of the public health crisis. "It's wrong. No one should have to choose between their health and their right to vote," Evers said in a statement.

Residents in the state are under orders to stay at home and public gatherings are banned due to the pandemic. Fears about infection have led to a shortage of poll workers and an explosion in requests for absentee ballots. Officials have warned of potential chaos if the voting goes ahead.

The pandemic has disrupted the Democratic race to pick a challenger to run against Republican President Donald Trump in the November 3 election, forcing more than a dozen states to delay or adjust their primaries to limit the health risks. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has said it is possible to conduct Wisconsin's in-person vote safely, while rival Bernie Sanders has called for the primary to be postponed.

Title: Amazon Faces Criticism Over Labor Conditions, Launches Hotline for Reporting Workplace Issues

Amazon, the e-commerce giant, has faced numerous criticisms over its labor conditions, with a recent partnership between the Free and Fair Markets Initiative and former Amazon workers launching a hotline for reporting unsafe working conditions. The hotline aims to provide a safe and confidential platform for workers to report concerns about their working environment.

The Free and Fair Markets Initiative, a nonprofit watchdog, has been scrutinizing Amazon's practices, particularly as the company plans new expansions without addressing workplace conditions. Amazon has been listed on the National Council for Occupational Safety and Health's "Dirty Dozen" list for two years, highlighting its failure to address worker complaints about stress, overwork, and other conditions that can lead to illness, injuries, and fatalities.

According to the Daily Beast, emergency responders have responded to Amazon warehouses at least 189 times between 2013 and 2018 for suicide attempts, suicidal thoughts, and other mental-health episodes. The hotline provides workers with instructions and resources for filing complaints with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) online, in person, or over the phone.

A former Amazon worker from the Hebron, Kentucky warehouse, who wished to remain anonymous due to a non-disclosure agreement, shared their concerns about the working conditions, stating that burnout rates are high and that people need to be aware of what's happening inside the warehouses. The worker emphasized that a single hotline is not enough to address the scale of the issue.

Amazon responded to the criticism, stating that it works hard to provide a safe and quality work environment for its associates, who are encouraged to provide feedback through public and private channels. The company also highlighted its industry-leading minimum wage of $15 and comprehensive benefits starting on day one.

The hotline aims to provide a platform for workers to report concerns about their working environment, and it is available for workers to use.

Title: Oregon Republicans Eye Senate Seat in Bid to Gain Control

Article:

The Republican Party is looking to make a push in the upcoming election to gain control of the U.S. Senate, and one state they are targeting is Oregon. The Beaver State has not elected a Republican to the Senate since 2002, but some believe incumbent Senator Jeff Merkley is vulnerable due to his strong support for ObamaCare, which had a disastrous rollout in the state.

Two candidates, Dr. Monica Wehby and Jason Conger, are vying for the Republican nomination in the primary election on Tuesday. Wehby, a pediatric neurosurgeon with 30 years of experience, is a strong critic of ObamaCare and has received endorsements from influential Republicans like Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, and Dr. Ben Carson. She has also received a significant boost from the New Republican super PAC, which has funded a $400,000 advertising campaign highlighting her credentials and opposition to ObamaCare.

Conger, a two-term representative in the Oregon State House and a practicing lawyer, has a more humble background. He grew up in a trailer park and was homeless for stretches, but went on to graduate from Harvard Law School. He has received endorsements from social conservatives and has been endorsed by former presidential candidate Rick Santorum.

While Wehby has raised significantly more money than Conger, he has received support from Republican lawmakers in Oregon and has a strong stance on social issues like the Second Amendment, pro-life issues, and opposition to gay marriage. Wehby, who is personally pro-life but would not work to take away abortion rights for other women, believes the GOP can grow by becoming more libertarian on social issues.

The Republicans have been on a losing streak in Oregon since Merkley defeated Gordon Smith in 2002. Mike Riley, a political consultant, notes that gender politics play a significant role in the state, with Republican men having a hard time attracting votes among Democrats and independent women.

However, Conger believes that moving to the center is not the answer and that Republicans should instead focus on offering an alternative to voters that is more attractive, credible, and speaks to issues that they care about.

Wehby may face some baggage in the general election if she wins the primary, as recent stories have raised questions about her relationship with a Republican donor who runs a large Oregon lumber company. The Oregon Democratic Party has filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission alleging coordination between the donor and Wehby's campaign, which would be a violation of campaign finance laws. Wehby has denied any coordination, and Politico has reported that the donor accused Wehby of stalking him and harassing his employees during their breakup in 2013.

Title: New Center Report Proposes Comprehensive Immigration Reform, but Timing Remains a Key Issue

The New Center, a think tank founded by William Galston and Bill Kristol, has released its debut report, proposing a comprehensive immigration reform plan. The plan aims to address the complex issue of immigration, which has been a contentious topic in the United States. The report suggests a merit-based system for legal immigration, prioritizing factors such as education, work experience, job offers, and English skills. However, the plan's approach to illegal immigration has raised concerns.

The proposal would offer legal status and permanent residency to individuals who have resided in the United States continuously since 2011, have paid application fees and back taxes, and have clean criminal records. "Dreamers" who arrived as minors and have not committed felonies would receive green cards immediately. The plan would also increase border security with a mix of fencing and advanced technologies, implement a new system for tracking people on temporary visas, and mandate the use of E-Verify, a system for employers to check job applicants' legal status.

However, the timing of the plan's implementation is a major sticking point. Conservatives have long insisted on "enforcement first," requiring the government to demonstrate control of the border, catch and deport those who overstay their visas, and punish employers who hire illegal immigrants before legalizing the remaining illegal population. The New Center plan does not delay amnesty, and it specifies that E-Verify implementation will occur only after everyone has had a chance to apply for legal status. This has raised concerns that conservatives will lose leverage to insist on vigorous enforcement measures.

The report highlights the difficulty in finding a compromise on this issue, as both sides have valid concerns. While the plan's legal immigration reforms are laudable, the approach to illegal immigration is vulnerable to conservative critiques. The timing of the plan's implementation will be crucial, and it remains to be seen whether a plan like this will become law, likely over the objections of the other side.

Title: Roy Moore Announces Bid for Alabama Senate Seat, Defying Republican Wishes

Article:

Former Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy Moore has announced his bid for the U.S. Senate, defying the wishes of many Republicans, including President Trump. Moore's previous campaign was marred by allegations of initiating unwanted sexual contact with teenage girls when he was in his 30s, which he denied as "fake news." Despite this, he still has a passionate base of support among conservative evangelical Christians.

Moore's new campaign faces significant challenges, as he would need to win a majority of the primary vote or face a runoff election. While he may struggle to win the majority support necessary to advance to the general election, his opponents may have weaknesses that he can exploit. A crowded primary field could also benefit Moore, as it may fragment the vote and make it easier for him to advance to a runoff.

Moore's opponents include Rep. Bradley Byrne and former Auburn University football coach Tommy Tuberville, who have both released internal polls showing Moore's net favorability among Republicans to be worse than their own. Alabama Secretary of State John Merrill is also gearing up to run, and former Attorney General Jeff Sessions may join the race.

If Moore makes it to a runoff, he would face an uphill battle to win the GOP nomination. However, some of his opponents have potential weaknesses, such as Tuberville's recent voting record in Florida, which could be used as a "carpetbagger" attack. Byrne, the establishment favorite, has had difficulty in past primary battles and was critical of Trump in the 2016 cycle.

Moore's path to victory is uncertain, but he does have a chance to make it to a primary runoff and potentially face off against incumbent Sen. Doug Jones. National Republicans may have an "Anyone But Moore" attitude, but Moore's 2017 campaign showed that a Trump endorsement couldn't stop him.

Title: Quad Copter Crashes on White House Grounds, Secret Service Reports

The Secret Service has identified a device found on the White House grounds as a quad copter, which crashed after its operator lost control. According to the agency, the individual who was operating the device reported the incident and has been cooperative. The Secret Service stated that the incident appears to be related to the recreational use of the device.

The agency reported that an on-duty Secret Service officer saw and heard the 2-foot-wide commercial quad copter fly low onto the grounds of the executive mansion at around 3:08 a.m. ET, crashing on the southeast side. The agency immediately alerted and locked down the complex until the device was examined and cleared.

The White House initially stated that the device posed no threat to the first family, as President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama were in India, while their daughters, Sasha and Malia, stayed behind in Washington with their grandmother, Marian Robinson.

The Secret Service is investigating the incident, which comes after a series of security lapses at the White House, including a previous incident in which a knife-wielding man scaled the White House fence and made it inside the executive mansion's main level. The incident led to the resignation of the Secret Service's then-director, Julia Pierson. In December, a panel appointed by the Department of Homeland Security recommended changes at the Secret Service, citing a lack of leadership.

Title: Appeals Court Rules Trump's Accountants Must Turn Over Tax Records

The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that President Trump's accounting firm, Mazars USA, must turn over his personal and business tax returns starting from 2011 to Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. The decision upholds a U.S. District Court order from last month requiring the accounting firm to provide the records.

The ruling comes as part of an investigation into whether two women who claimed to have had affairs with Trump were paid for their silence before the 2016 election. The Manhattan District Attorney's office is seeking the records as part of its investigation into whether any New York state laws were broken when Trump's then-attorney, Michael Cohen, arranged payments to adult film actress Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal.

Trump's attorneys plan to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court, with Jay Sekulow, one of Trump's outside attorneys, stating that the decision "will be taken to the Supreme Court." The issue at hand goes to the heart of the Republic, and the constitutional issues are significant, Sekulow added.

The appeals court did not rule on the merits of Trump's claim that as president, he is immune from criminal investigation. Instead, the court focused on the fact that the subpoena is directed at Trump's accountants, not the president himself, and compliance does not require the president to do anything at all, according to Judge Robert Katzman's written opinion.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen whether the Supreme Court will ultimately intervene.

Title: Trump Signs Bill to Address Backlog of Untested Rape Kits, Providing Funding for DNA Testing and Forensic Services

The President Donald Trump signed the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act of 2019 on Monday, aiming to eliminate the backlog of untested rape kits across the United States. The legislation provides funding from the Department of Justice to help local governments process and test the kits, which currently number over 100,000, according to ABC News.

The bill will allocate $151 million to the Debbie Smith DNA Backlog Grant Program, $12.5 million for DNA training and education programs, and $30 million for the Sexual Assault Forensic Exam Grant Program. The funding will support the testing and analysis of DNA evidence, which is crucial in identifying criminals and bringing them to justice.

The legislation has bipartisan support and has been reauthorized several times since its original passage in 2004. The bill is named after Debbie Smith, a victim of sexual assault whose evidence was not tested until five years after the attack. Since 2005, the program has led to over 40% of DNA matches, highlighting the importance of addressing the backlog.

Advocates emphasize the urgency of addressing the backlog, as the statute of limitations in some jurisdictions can make it difficult to prosecute cases. The reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act was caught in the middle of the debate this year, but the bill's passage is a step forward in combating sexual violence and bringing justice to victims.

Title: Democrats Divided Over Funding Bill as Trump Suspends Raids

The Democratic Party is facing internal divisions over a funding bill aimed at addressing the humanitarian crisis at the US-Mexico border. The bill, which Speaker Nancy Pelosi described as reflecting "our values," is intended to provide emergency aid to vulnerable children and families. However, dozens of House Democrats are expressing concerns that the legislation does not set high enough standards for migrant shelters and does not do enough to block funds from going towards enforcement.

The controversy arose after President Trump announced on Sunday that he was suspending immigration raids for two weeks to allow for a bipartisan compromise on changing asylum laws and closing "loopholes." The decision came after Pelosi telephoned Trump to request a delay. Pelosi praised the postponement and called for passage of the emergency aid package, stating that it protects families and does not fund the administration's "failed mass detention policy."

However, many House Democrats are skeptical of the bill's effectiveness. Representative Pramila Jayapal, co-chairwoman of the Progressive Caucus, argued that the legislation lacks "sticks" to ensure the Trump administration spends the money as intended. Jayapal also expressed concerns that the administration's "lawless" behavior towards immigrants makes it unlikely that they will abide by any restrictions or standards included in the bill.

The debate highlights the ongoing divisions within the Democratic Party over how to address the humanitarian crisis at the border. While some Democrats see the bill as a necessary step to provide aid to vulnerable populations, others believe it does not go far enough to address the root causes of the crisis. The controversy is likely to continue as lawmakers work to find a solution.

Title: Reality Winner, 25, Indicted for Allegedly Stealing Classified Documents from NSA

Reality Winner, a 25-year-old woman, has been indicted for allegedly stealing classified documents from the National Security Agency (NSA) and leaking them to The Intercept. According to the federal complaint, Winner stole the documents on May 9, four days after they were published by the NSA, and sent them to the news outlet through ground mail. The documents revealed that Russian agents attempted to hack into U.S. voting systems prior to the November election.

Winner's social media footprint suggests she is a supporter of progressive causes, including Bernie Sanders, Bill Maher, and Michael Moore. She also appears to be a supporter of the Women's March and the Islamic Society of North America, a Muslim civil rights group. Additionally, she has been critical of President Trump, using the hashtag "NeverMyPresident" and "Resist" in a Facebook post about his stance on the Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) protests.

Winner was employed by Pluribus International, a defense contractor that works with the NSA, and was arrested at her home in Augusta, Georgia. The FBI interviewed Winner, who admitted to stealing the documents and providing them to The Intercept. The news outlet published an article based on the stolen materials, which revealed the Russian hacking attempts.

Winner's online presence is limited, but her Facebook page shows she is a political activist. She posted a photo outside the Atlanta offices of Georgia Sen. David Perdue, stating she had a 30-minute private meeting with his state policy director to discuss her concerns about climate change and the state's dependency on fossil fuels. She also drew parallels between President Trump's statements and those of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, claiming ignorance of human rights violations.

A spokeswoman for Sen. Perdue released a statement calling the allegations against Winner "very serious" and expressing trust in the Justice Department to handle the matter appropriately. Winner's most recent Facebook post was on Friday, the day before she was interviewed by the FBI.

Title: House Votes to Hold Lois Lerner in Contempt of Congress

The House of Representatives voted on June 18, 2013, to hold Lois Lerner, the former head of the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) tax-exempt division, in contempt of Congress. The vote was largely along party lines, with 231 Republicans voting in favor and 187 Democrats voting against. Six Democrats joined Republicans in supporting the contempt charge.

The decision was a result of Lerner's refusal to answer questions from House Republicans regarding the IRS's targeting of conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status. Lerner's lawyer, William Taylor, stated that the decision was "unfortunate" and that it prioritized politics over Lerner's constitutional rights.

The contempt citation now goes to the Justice Department, where it will be reviewed by the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia. If tried and found guilty, Lerner could face up to a year in prison or a fine of up to $100,000, according to a Congressional Research Service report.

The House also voted to call on Attorney General Eric Holder to appoint a special counsel to investigate the matter. The contempt charge allows the House to arrest Lerner and hold her in a Capitol jail cell until she complies with the subpoena or until the end of the 113th Congress.

Lerner's actions, which involved targeting conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status, have been the subject of controversy since May 2013. The Treasury inspector general for tax administration attributed the unfair practice to gross mismanagement, rather than political bias. However, House Republicans have accused Lerner of using her position for political mischief.

The contempt citation is not the end of the IRS scandal, with nearly a half-dozen congressional investigations expected to wrap up in the coming months. However, it may be the last time Republicans have a chance to hear from Lerner, as criminal contempt would not require her to testify.

Title: House Democrats Make Pitch to Donors to Keep Engaged for Hillary Clinton's Potential 2016 Run

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and the House Majority PAC are urging donors to stay engaged and continue supporting House campaigns, citing the potential benefits of having a Democratic majority in the House if Hillary Clinton wins the presidency in 2016. The message is that a Democratic House would provide a stronger foundation for Clinton's presidency, allowing her to pass legislation and implement her policy agenda.

The pitch is not just about holding on for 2016, but about preparing for the days following the inauguration and the potential impact a Democratic House could have on Clinton's presidency.
