The House Majority PAC has been making this argument to major donors, emphasizing the importance of keeping the flame alive and not taking the GOP's hold on the majority for granted.

The National Republican Congressional Committee has also been making a similar case, urging their own donors not to take the GOP's majority for granted and to focus on winning as many seats as possible to build a firewall against Clinton in 2016.

The only White House official to have appeared at a House Majority PAC event is John Podesta, who is expected to have a top position in Clinton's presumptive campaign. Podesta met with a small group of labor leaders to try to keep their checks coming in for the fall.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and House Majority PAC are emphasizing the importance of staying engaged and competitive in the 2014 elections, even if the outcome of the presidential election is uncertain. The pitch is not about winning a majority in 2014, but about setting the stage for a strong Democratic House in 2016.

A senior Democrat said that the party could mount a strong case in 2016 without Clinton, but it would not be nearly as effective. The party is banking on Clinton's popularity and fundraising prowess to make the case for staying engaged and competitive in the 2014 elections.

Title: The Weight of Whiteness: A Call to Acknowledge the Struggle of Black Lives

The article discusses the concept of "whiteness" and its implications on the lives of black people. The author argues that whiteness is not just a lack of melanin, but a privilege that allows individuals to view black life from a distance, without intimacy or understanding. This privilege is not limited to any particular class, but is a widespread phenomenon that perpetuates harmful stereotypes and biases.

The author highlights the ways in which these biases are passed down through generations, often informally, and are reinforced by societal norms and institutions. The article also touches on the idea that many people are resistant to learning about the struggles and hardships faced by black people, and instead prefer to maintain their own beliefs and biases.

The author also references the recent events in Dallas, Texas, and the ongoing struggles faced by black people in their daily lives. They argue that the fear and terror experienced by black people is a result of systemic racism and the constant threat of violence and death at the hands of law enforcement.

The article concludes by urging individuals to put down their "binoculars" and see the world from a different perspective, acknowledging the struggles and hardships faced by black people and working towards a more equitable society.

Title: Beto O'Rourke's Authenticity May Be His Secret to Uniting the Obama Coalition

Article:

In a crowded Democratic primary field, Beto O'Rourke's authenticity may be his key to success. Unlike some of his opponents, O'Rourke's personality is unfiltered, and he is unafraid to take far-left positions in a red state. This authenticity has the potential to unite the Obama coalition, a feat that has eluded many other candidates.

O'Rourke's ability to connect with people is a major asset. Unlike Donald Trump, who has a reputation for being unpolished and unfiltered, O'Rourke's authenticity is a refreshing change. His willingness to be himself, without the aid of focus groups or poll-tested answers, has helped him build a strong connection with voters.

While some may view O'Rourke's lack of polish as a liability, it is an asset in the eyes of many voters. His ability to unite the Obama coalition, which includes minority voters, white liberals, and young people, is a significant advantage in the Democratic primary.

In contrast, other candidates, such as Kirsten Gillibrand and Joe Biden, will have to reckon with their more moderate pasts and long histories in Congress. Kamala Harris has struggled to come across as authentic, often appearing uneasy committing to a policy.

O'Rourke's biggest challenge is making the case for why he should be the nominee. However, if he can strike the right balance between his authenticity and his political ability, he may have a strong chance of defeating the deepest Democratic primary field in a generation and facing off against President Trump in the fall.

Title: Former Staffer Files Criminal Complaint Against Joe Biden Over 1993 Alleged Sexual Assault

A former staffer for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has filed a formal criminal complaint against her former boss with the Washington, D.C. police. Tara Reade, who previously accused Biden of sexually assaulting her in 1993 while she was employed as one of his Senate staffers, alleges that the former vice president and senator assaulted her in a Senate corridor, shoving his hand under her skirt and penetrating her with his fingers.

According to Reade, the alleged incident occurred in 1993, and the statute of limitations for the alleged assault has passed. However, Reade has spoken publicly about her allegations, stating that she was alone with Biden in a Senate corridor when he allegedly assaulted her. She described the incident as "the strangest thing" and recalled that Biden's hands were on her and underneath her clothes, and he penetrated her with his fingers while kissing her.

Biden's campaign has vehemently denied the allegations, with deputy campaign manager Kate Bedingfield stating that the accusations are false and that women have a right to tell their story, but reporters have an obligation to rigorously vet those claims.

It is worth noting that the alleged incident occurred over 25 years ago, and the statute of limitations has passed, making it unlikely that criminal charges will be filed. However, the allegations have sparked renewed attention on the #MeToo movement and the importance of believing and supporting survivors of sexual assault.

Title: Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush Endorses Texas Senator Ted Cruz in Presidential Bid

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who suspended his presidential bid in February after several primary losses, has endorsed Texas Senator Ted Cruz. This move is striking, given the Bush family's past criticism of Cruz. However, Bush and Cruz share similar stances on issues such as immigration and Common Core education standards, and Bush believes Cruz is a "consistent, principled conservative who has demonstrated the ability to appeal to voters."

The most likely reason for Bush's endorsement is that he believes Cruz is the only candidate with a prayer of beating front-runner Donald Trump. Given the delegate math, Kasich's path to overtaking Trump is steep. According to the Associated Press, Trump leads with 739 delegates, followed by Cruz with 465, and Kasich with 143. A candidate needs 1,237 delegates to win the nomination outright at the convention.

Cruz has the best chance of beating Trump one-on-one and keeping Trump from hitting the threshold, according to polls. Bush's endorsement is the latest sign that the so-called Republican establishment is coalescing around Cruz's campaign. If Trump and Cruz do not reach the necessary delegate threshold, the two candidates will head into a contested convention where delegates will be freed up to vote with their conscience.

Title: Trump's Lawyers Seek $20 Million in Damages from Stormy Daniels, Claiming Breach of Non-Disclosure Agreement

Article:

Lawyers representing US President Donald Trump have filed a motion seeking $20 million in damages from adult film actress Stormy Daniels, also known as Stephanie Clifford. The legal action claims that Daniels breached a non-disclosure agreement signed in 2016, allegedly at least 20 times. The agreement was reportedly signed before the 2016 presidential election, and Daniels claims she had an affair with Trump that began in 2006 and lasted several months.

The non-disclosure agreement was allegedly paid for by Trump's personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, who paid Daniels $130,000 in 2016. Cohen has stated that neither Trump nor his company was a party to the transaction. The agreement was intended to keep Daniels silent about her alleged relationship with Trump.

Daniels has filed a lawsuit to void the non-disclosure agreement, claiming it is invalid since Trump did not sign it. Her lawyer, Michael Avenatti, has described the filing by Trump's lawyers as "unprecedented" and "yet another bullying tactic" against her. The filing also seeks a change of venue from state to federal court.

The case has been ongoing for some time, with Daniels first making claims of a sexual relationship with Trump in a 2011 interview with InTouch magazine. The story gained renewed attention earlier this year when reports emerged about the payment made to Daniels in the run-up to the 2016 election.

Trump's lawyers have obtained a restraining order against Daniels, seeking to prevent her from sharing "confidential information" about their alleged relationship. Daniels has recorded an interview with the CBS network's 60 Minutes program to air later this month about her fight to void the agreement. A CrowdJustice campaign to raise funds for her legal fees has already raised almost $200,000.

Title: Advocacy Groups Sue Georgia Over "Exact Match" Voter Registration Requirement

A coalition of advocacy groups, the Campaign Legal Center and Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, has filed a lawsuit against the state of Georgia, arguing that its "exact match" voter registration requirement violates several federal laws and the state's own constitution. The requirement, which was reinstated in 2017 after being temporarily suspended, checks voter registration applications against state databases for exact matches on name, date of birth, and Social Security number. The plaintiffs claim that this process disproportionately affects the voting rights of African-American, Latino, and Asian-American citizens.

The lawsuit, filed in a federal district court on Thursday, alleges that the "exact match" requirement violates the Voting Rights Act, the National Voter Registration Act, and the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs argue that the practice has already resulted in the suspension of over 53,000 voter registrations, with nearly 70% of those affected being African-Americans.

Georgia's Secretary of State, Brian Kemp, who is currently running for governor, has defended the practice, stating that those affected can still vote in the upcoming election. However, the Abrams campaign has called for Kemp to resign, citing a lack of confidence in his ability to impartially oversee the election.

The controversy surrounding the "exact match" requirement has sparked a national debate, with some arguing that it is necessary to prevent voter fraud and others claiming it disproportionately affects certain communities. The lawsuit is ongoing, and a decision is expected in the coming months.

Title: Obama's Handling of Syria Crisis Highlights Weaknesses in Institutions and Leadership

Article:

The ongoing Syria crisis has been a challenging moment in presidential history, with President Barack Obama's handling of the situation sparking debate and criticism. The crisis has highlighted the weaknesses of multiple institutions and leaders in American life, including the president and congressional leaders of both parties.

The fact that the president and congressional leaders are in agreement on a matter of national security, yet the country remains divided, is a historic event. The Syria episode has revealed the weakness of institutions and leaders, with the president's unsteady handling of the crisis causing his enemies to cackle and supporters to cringe.

The article highlights the decline of party discipline, citing the example of the Syria resolution, which has faced uncertain prospects for passage despite being supported by House Speaker John Boehner, House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid. The article notes that party leaders have emphasized their lack of leverage in pressing for passage of the White House-backed resolution.

The article also touches on the changing media landscape, noting that the president's power to command attention has waned. Historically, presidents have relied heavily on their ability to make everyone stop and pay attention, but this power has diminished with the rise of alternative news sources and entertainment options. The article quotes presidential historian Martha Kumar, who notes that Ronald Reagan gave 34 Oval Office addresses in his presidency, while George H.W. Bush gave 12 in his single term.

The article concludes by noting that Obama's speech on Tuesday night may not command universal interest or attention from the American people, as many will be distracted by other news and entertainment options.

Title: Federal Government Works to Implement Same-Sex Marriage Benefits

The United States government has been working to implement the benefits for same-sex married couples, following the Supreme Court's decision to strike down a law defining marriage as between a man and a woman. The effort, led by the Department of Justice, aims to ensure that thousands of same-sex married couples receive the federal benefits they are entitled to.

According to Attorney General Eric Holder, the task is a civil rights matter, akin to the struggle for equal treatment faced by African-Americans in the 1950s and 1960s. The Justice Department has reviewed over 1,000 rules and laws to ensure that same-sex couples receive the same benefits as opposite-sex couples.

Some benefits have already been extended, including health and life insurance coverage for federal employees in same-sex marriages, review of immigration petitions for same-sex couples, and the ability for same-sex couples to file taxes jointly. However, there are still challenges to overcome, particularly in areas where same-sex marriage is not recognized by the state.

The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Social Security Administration are among the agencies still working to implement the benefits, with some legal issues still unresolved. The Supreme Court's decision did not create a universal right to marry, leaving unclear what happens to same-sex couples who live in states that do not recognize their marriages.

Advocates are still waiting for answers on Social Security and the VA, and Congress may need to weigh in to change the language in those laws. Some states have also pushed back against the federal government's efforts, requiring same-sex couples to travel long distances to enroll in federal benefit programs.

Despite the challenges, Justice Department officials believe the American people have assimilated the decision and are comfortable with the progress made. Attorney General Holder hopes that elected representatives will reflect the magnanimity of the American people and work towards a more inclusive society.

Title: Analysis Reveals Hillary Clinton's Performance in 2016 Presidential Election

The 2016 presidential election saw Donald Trump win the White House, with Democrats attributing their loss to Hillary Clinton and her campaign. A closer examination of the results, however, suggests that Clinton underperformed in key states, even as she overperformed in others.

According to Inside Elections' "Vote Above Replacement" (VAR) metric, Clinton overperformed a typical Democrat in 19 states, while Trump overperformed a typical Republican in 15 states. VAR measures the strength of a political candidate relative to a typical candidate from the same party by comparing the percentage of the candidate's vote to the party's Baseline.

Clinton overperformed in four of the 10 closest states in 2016, while Trump overperformed in three. However, her negative VAR in the four closest states – Michigan, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin – was enough to leave her short of the presidency. She also underperformed in Minnesota and nearly lost that state.

On the other hand, Clinton's overperformance in California, Illinois, and Massachusetts is evidence that Democrats are "wasting" votes by running up the score in Democratic states and not changing the math of the Electoral College. David Wasserman of the Cook Political Report has noted how Trump could lose the popular vote by 5 million votes and still win the presidency.

The analysis also highlights some positive news for Democrats. Clinton overperformed in the perennial battleground state of Florida, former battleground state of Nevada, and the emerging battleground of Maine. The best news for Democrats might be in growing states where Clinton overperformed and Trump underperformed, such as Texas and Georgia.

Overall, the VAR analysis provides a nuanced view of the 2016 presidential election, highlighting both Clinton's strengths and weaknesses.

Title: Democrats to Make Noise During Republican National Convention

The Democratic Party is planning to break with tradition and make a strong presence during the Republican National Convention, which is set to take place in Tampa, Florida, next week. Vice President Joe Biden will visit the city, accompanied by Hollywood actress and Obama for America co-chairwoman Eva Longoria, who is also expected to speak at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, North Carolina, the following week.

President Barack Obama will hold campaign stops in the battleground states of Ohio, Colorado, and Virginia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while First Lady Michelle Obama is scheduled to appear on "The Late Show with David Letterman" on Wednesday. This move marks a concerted effort by the Democratic Party to ensure its message is not drowned out by the Republican convention.

According to Christopher Arterton, former dean of the George Washington University's Graduate School of Political Management, "decorum has broken down" and it is now accepted practice for parties to make news during each other's conventions. Arterton notes that Obama's presidency makes whatever he says newsworthy, making it easier for the Democratic Party to "intrude" on the Republican convention.

The Obama campaign will hold events in Ames, Iowa, and Fort Collins, Colorado, on Tuesday, followed by a rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Wednesday. The Democratic Party's decision to make a strong presence during the Republican convention is a departure from the traditional practice of presidential candidates keeping a low profile during their opponents' conventions.

Romney campaign officials have announced that their candidate will hold events in Charlotte during the week of the Democratic convention, although details have not been released. Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki described the president, first lady, and Biden's visit to Tampa as "going to the belly of the beast," stating that they will be "laying out the choice the American people are facing in November, cutting through some of the political chatter." Romney senior adviser Kevin Madden characterized Biden's trip as an attempt to distract from Democrats' economic record and draw a contrast between the parties' visions for the country.

**Harvey's Impact: Climate Change Debate Erupts Amid Devastating Storm**

The recent Category 4 Hurricane Harvey has sparked a heated debate about the role of climate change in the devastating storm's impact. While some experts argue that climate change worsened the storm's effects, others dispute this claim, citing natural factors and historical data.

The storm, which made landfall in Texas on August 25, brought catastrophic flooding and record-breaking rainfall to the Houston area. Climate activists and scientists have linked the storm to climate change, citing rising sea levels and surface temperatures that create more moisture in the atmosphere. Michael E. Mann, a Penn State professor of atmospheric science, stated that "climate change made Hurricane Harvey more deadly."

However, other experts disagree. Judith Curry, a climatologist and recently retired Georgia Tech professor, pointed out that Harvey tied for 14th among strongest U.S. hurricanes since 1851, and that natural factors, such as wind patterns and atmospheric conditions, play a significant role in storm intensity.

Roger Pielke Jr., a professor at the University of Colorado Center for Science & Technology Policy Research, noted that there were 14 U.S. landfalls of Category 4 or greater hurricanes from 1926 to 1969, but only four from 1970 to 2017, despite rising greenhouse gas emissions. He argued that the politicized debate over climate change distracts from the immediate need for disaster response and recovery efforts.

The National Weather Service reported that Harvey produced more than 50 inches of rain in Cedar Bayou, Texas, surpassing the measured single-storm rainfall record for the continental United States. However, Roy W. Spencer, a principal research scientist at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, disputed the idea that climate change played a significant role in the storm's intensity and duration, citing natural factors such as wind patterns and atmospheric conditions.

The debate highlights the ongoing scientific discussion about the role of climate change in extreme weather events. While some experts believe that climate change worsens the impact of storms, others argue that natural factors play a more significant role. As the world continues to grapple with the effects of climate change, this debate will likely continue to unfold.

Title: Retailers and Politicians Respond to Confederate Flag Controversy

Article:

In the wake of a mass shooting at a historically black church in Charleston, South Carolina, which killed nine people, Governor Nikki Haley called on the state legislature to remove the Confederate battle flag from the state Capitol grounds. The move comes as retailers and politicians weigh in on the controversy surrounding the flag, which has become a symbol of the slave-holding South.

Retailers Walmart, Amazon, Sears, and eBay have announced they will no longer sell Confederate flag merchandise. The decision is the latest indication that the flag has become increasingly divisive and controversial in the aftermath of the shooting.

Politicians and pundits have also weighed in on the issue. Fox News host Kimberly Guilfoyle questioned whether the American flag would be next to be removed, while Rush Limbaugh claimed that the removal of the Confederate flag is part of a larger effort to "destroy the South as a political force." Bill Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, accused liberals of "expunging history in a frenzy of self-righteousness."

Fox News host Bill O'Reilly argued that the Confederate flag "represents bravery" in the Civil War, while Todd Starnes, a Fox News Radio host, framed the removal of the flag as "a full-fledged cultural cleansing of the Southern states."

The debate surrounding the Confederate flag has sparked a national conversation about the role of symbols and their impact on American society. As the discussion continues, it remains to be seen how the controversy will unfold and what the long-term implications will be for the flag and its symbolism.

Title: Trump Administration Signals Flexibility on Border Wall Funding in DACA Legislation

The Trump administration is willing to consider legislation addressing protections for children brought to the United States illegally, known as Dreamers, without including funding for a border wall with Mexico, according to a senior aide. White House legislative director Marc Short stated that the administration will outline its priorities for a fix for the Deferred Action on Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in the next couple of weeks.

While President Trump remains committed to his campaign promise to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, he is not insisting on including funding for the wall in a potential DACA package. Short emphasized that the administration wants to avoid binding itself to a specific construct that could make reaching a conclusion on DACA impossible.

This development signals a potential shift in the administration's stance, as it seeks to engage Democrats and Republicans in finding a solution. The move is seen as a positive development by Democrats, who have insisted that border funding should not be part of any legislation and would likely have the votes to block such a provision.

Senator Dick Durbin, a senior Democrat, welcomed the administration's comments, stating that it clears away a major stumbling block to legislation helping DACA recipients. Democrats are willing to work with the White House and congressional Republicans on other border security measures as part of the legislation.

However, Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, criticized the potential shift on DACA, saying the administration is forfeiting leverage it needs to tighten border enforcement. Krikorian believes the administration is seeking an "escape hatch" on the controversial DACA program.

The Trump administration's decision to end the Obama-era program protecting Dreamers has put the onus on Congress to address the nearly 800,000 Dreamers facing uncertainty about their status in the United States.

Title: Conservative Candidates Face Intense Media Scrutiny as Election Approaches

The article discusses the increasing media attention and criticism aimed at conservative and libertarian politicians, particularly Kentucky Senator Rand Paul. The author notes that the liberal media and the Democratic National Committee are targeting several top GOP candidates, including Paul. The article highlights Paul's stance on Syria, where he advocated for a non-interventionist approach, which the author believes prevented the US from supporting ISIS.

The article also touches on the shift in the foreign policy establishment's stance on ISIS, with many now advocating for its destruction. The author suggests that the media attacks on conservative candidates are a sign of fear and a desperate attempt to discredit them before the November midterm elections and the 2016 presidential election.

The article presents a neutral and factual account of the situation, without taking a political stance or expressing personal opinions. It provides context and background information on the issues at hand, allowing readers to form their own opinions and make informed decisions.

Title: Obama's Foreign Policy: A Story of Disengagement and Consequences

The article discusses the Obama administration's foreign policy, specifically its approach to international relations and the consequences of its decisions. The author, Darrell Issa, a member of the House Foreign Relations Committee, argues that President Obama's policies have led to a power vacuum, which has been filled by various bad actors.

The article highlights several examples of the Obama administration's disengagement from the world, including the cancellation of the missile defense system in Eastern Europe and the abandonment of the Iraqi military. The author claims that these decisions have created a power vacuum, which has been exploited by Russia, Iran, and other countries.

The article also criticizes the Obama administration's deal with Iran, which the author believes will empower the country's nuclear program and provide it with access to conventional arms and ballistic missile technology. The author argues that the deal will not address the Iranian regime's support for terrorism and will only delay the problem's ultimate resolution.

The article concludes by stating that the Obama administration's foreign policy has been marked by disengagement and a lack of resolve, which has allowed Russia and other countries to fill the power vacuum. The author believes that this approach will have negative consequences for the United States and its allies.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of the Obama administration's foreign policy and its consequences, highlighting the author's concerns about the impact of the administration's decisions on the world and the United States.

Title: Majority of Americans Fail US Citizenship Test, Study Reveals

A recent study by the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation has found that a majority of Americans would fail a test based on questions from the U.S. citizenship test. The survey, conducted from November 14, 2018, to January 3, 2019, among 41,000 adults, revealed that only 40% of Americans would pass the test. The results are concerning, as the test is designed to assess knowledge of American history and civics.

The study showed that majorities failed in 49 out of 50 states, with the lone exception being Vermont. Women and those under the age of 45 performed particularly poorly, with 68% and 73% failing the test, respectively. Senior citizens, on the other hand, performed better, with 27% earning an A or B grade.

The study also found that there is no significant difference between self-identified liberals and conservatives in terms of their performance on the test. The results suggest that the lack of knowledge about American history and government is not limited to one political ideology.

The study's findings have sparked a debate about the state of education in the United States. Some have suggested that requiring high school students to pass a standardized civics test could help improve their understanding of American government and history. Indiana lawmakers have proposed a bill that would require high school students to pass a civics test by graduation, starting with the 2020-2021 academic year.

The test itself is based on questions from the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services' citizenship exam, which is designed to assess knowledge of American history and civics. The test covers topics such as the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and the branches of government.

The study's results have been met with concern and criticism from some, who argue that the lack of knowledge about American history and government is a result of a broader issue with the education system. Others have suggested that the test is too difficult or that it is not a reliable measure of civic knowledge.

Overall, the study's findings highlight the need for a renewed focus on American history and civics education in the United States.

Title: Trump Criticizes Schiff, Calls for Investigation into Biden and Son

Article:

President Donald Trump has criticized Democratic Representative Adam Schiff, accusing him of making up a fake statement about a phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Trump made the comments during a press conference in the Oval Office, where he also expressed his frustration with Schiff's handling of the situation.

Schiff had previously presented a summary of the call to the House Intelligence Committee, which Trump claimed was inaccurate. Trump stated that Schiff "made up what I said" and that the congressman "actually took words and made it up." The president also called for Schiff to be investigated for "fraud" and "treason."

Rudy Giuliani, Trump's personal attorney, echoed the president's sentiments, stating that Schiff "didn't embellish" but instead "lied" about the memo summarizing the Zelensky call. Eric Trump, the president's son, also weighed in, calling Schiff a "total disgrace" and advocating for term limits.

In addition to his criticism of Schiff, Trump also sought to cast doubt on the accuracy of a whistleblower complaint that detailed his call with Zelensky and alleged efforts by White House officials to "lock down" records of the conversation. The president claimed that the whistleblower knew "almost nothing" and that the complaint was "a fraud."

The whistleblower complaint, filed by an anonymous intelligence officer, alleged that Trump had pressured Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son. The complaint was deemed credible and "urgent" by the intelligence community's inspector general.

Trump also referenced a report by the conservative publication The Federalist, which stated that the U.S. intelligence community had eliminated the first-hand knowledge requirement from its whistleblower complaint form between May 2018 and August 2019. The president tweeted, "WHO CHANGED THE LONG STANDING WHISTLEBLOWER RULES JUST BEFORE SUBMITTAL OF THE FAKE WHISTLEBLOWER REPORT?"

The whistleblower complaint's description of the call between Trump and Zelensky is largely similar to the readout the White House produced last Wednesday. Joseph Maguire, the acting Director of National Intelligence, testified before Schiff's Intelligence committee last Thursday that "the whistleblower's complaint is in alignment with what was released yesterday by the president."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Highlights Benefits of GOP Tax Reform Bill

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is promoting the benefits of the GOP tax reform bill, highlighting its positive impact on "main street" operations across the country. The bill, passed in December, is projected to result in a deficit of $804 billion in 2018 and $1 trillion in 2020, according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO). The national debt is expected to reach $33 trillion in ten years, up from $21 trillion last month.

Senator Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., has called for the repeal of the bill, citing concerns over the growing deficit and debt. However, the data suggests that nearly all middle-income earners will receive a tax break under the bill. The CBO projects that the budget deficit will rise to $804 billion in 2018 before hitting the $1 trillion mark in 2020, two years earlier than anticipated.

The article also mentions that Republicans are running ads online, including on Facebook, highlighting the day-to-day impact of their tax cuts and warning about Democrats' desire to turn back the clock with tax increases. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is promoting elements of the law that are helping "main street" operations across the country, with examples of which have proliferated in recent months, from coast to coast.

In other Senate news, Rick Scott has officially jumped into the Florida Senate race against Bill Nelson. The current, razor-thin GOP upper chamber majority continues to confirm President Trump's judicial appointments at an aggressive clip, with Claria Horn Boom and Rebecca Jennings being the latest confirmations.

Title: Midterm Elections: A Review of the Current System and Potential Changes

The upcoming midterm elections in the United States are expected to see around 90 million Americans casting their ballots, a significant number, but still less than 40% of the electorate. This election is likely to further exacerbate partisan divisions and gridlock, making governance more challenging. The candidates, advocacy groups, and super PACs have spent over $1 billion to air over 2 million ads to influence the election.

Historically, midterm elections were meant to provide accountability to the people, with the Constitution establishing a system where at least one body of Congress would be closely tied to the people. However, with Americans' confidence in their government at an all-time low, the two-year House terms no longer make sense. In fact, few offices at any level of government have two-year terms, and with modern technologies like Twitter, video cameras, and 24-hour cable news, voters can hold their elected officials accountable without the need for an election every two years.

The two-year cycle is not only unnecessary but also harmful to American politics. The main impact of midterm elections in the modern era has been to weaken the president, the only government official elected by the entire nation. Since the end of World War II, the president's party has on average lost 25 seats in the House and about 4 in the Senate as a result of the midterms. This is a bipartisan phenomenon, with Democratic and Republican presidents experiencing similar losses.

Title: Romney Seeks to Shake Up Obama in Upcoming Debate

The presidential campaigns are downplaying expectations ahead of the first debate on Wednesday, with Team Obama emphasizing Mitt Romney's preparation time and Team Romney highlighting the president's reputation as a gifted speaker. However, both sides may be underestimating the potential impact of the debate on the election.

Romney's team is hoping for a game-changer, with The Week magazine giving him a 60% chance of delivering a surprising performance. Some Republicans believe he will focus on "fact-checking" the president, using statistics to weigh him down on issues like unemployment and the national debt. Romney's recent gaffes have made it easy to forget that he was an effective speaker during the 2012 Republican primaries, where debates played a crucial role.

While a strong performance by Romney is no guarantee of a poll boost, several factors need to come together for it to have a significant impact. Undecided voters need to tune in, the press needs to agree that Romney won, and his team needs to effectively communicate his performance to the public.

In 1984, Walter Mondale won his first debate against Ronald Reagan, but it barely shifted the polls, and Reagan rebounded with a strong performance in their rematch. However, this election is different, with voters focusing on culture, morals, personality, and trust. Romney's chance to redefine his national image and showcase himself as a compelling politician and normal human being makes this debate crucial.

If Romney can shake up Obama, it could have a bigger effect than if the president prevails. Polling shows the president is expected to best Romney by a 25-point margin, making a Romney victory a bigger shock to the electorate. Seeing the Democratic Cicero shaken by the Republican challenger could cause the public to rethink their perception of both men, as happened in 1980 when Reagan's debate performance shifted public sentiment.

To win, Romney should focus on articulating a positive vision and sticking to the facts, rather than going on the attack or trying to be humorous, as suggested by some. The debate's outcome is uncertain, but one thing is clear: both sides are underestimating the potential impact of this election's first debate.

Title: US Congresswomen Protest Against Outdated Dress Code, Calling for Change

A group of around 25 women in the US Congress have staged a protest, dubbed "Sleeveless Friday," against the Capitol building's dress code, which prohibits women from showing their arms in certain areas. The protest comes after several female reporters and staff members were told their outfits violated the rules, preventing them from entering the lobby area where they meet with politicians.

The dress code, which also applies to men, requires them to wear suit jackets and ties to enter the same areas. The policing of the rules is left to the chamber's security team, under the guidance of the House speaker.

The controversy has sparked a debate about the need to modernize the dress code, with some arguing that it is outdated and restrictive. House Speaker Paul Ryan acknowledged the issue, saying that the code had not been devised under his term and agreed it needs to be updated. He emphasized that members should wear "appropriate business attire."

The protest is not the first time the dress code has been challenged. In June, House of Commons Speaker John Bercow in the UK relaxed the rules, allowing a member of parliament to ask a question without wearing a tie. The rise of more casual media and tech companies has also raised questions about what constitutes "business attire" in 2017.

The protest has sparked a wider conversation about the need for change, with some arguing that the dress code is a relic of a bygone era and that it is time for the US Congress to adapt to the changing times.

Title: Senate's Second Chance to Confront Trump's Obstruction and Executive Privilege

The Democratic leaders' decision to send articles of impeachment to the Senate without countering President Trump's interference with House proceedings has been criticized as an opportunity lost. However, there is a second chance for the Senate to confront the president's obstruction and executive privilege claims, with the added benefit of bipartisan support for any subpoenas issued. It is crucial to push back on the president's dangerous expansion of executive privilege, regardless of the outcome of the impeachment process.

The president's assertion of executive privilege to prevent witnesses from testifying or withhold incriminating documents or evidence is a gross abuse of the concept. The Senate must be prepared to go to the mat to enforce any subpoenas it issues, or the impeachment process will weaken congressional authority and establish the president's entitlement to use the privilege of his office to immunize himself from scrutiny.

The enforcement of subpoenas in an impeachment trial is complex. The Senate Impeachment Rules provide that the Senate has the power to compel the attendance of witnesses and enforce obedience to its orders. However, the sergeant-at-arms does not have a jail or a full police force at his disposal, and Congress has not used its enforcement powers since 1934. This leaves open the possibility that the Senate will turn to the courts to enforce subpoenas, potentially leading to a pitched battle between Congress's power and executive branch claims of executive authority.

In such a scenario, the case could land in the Supreme Court, with Chief Justice John Roberts presiding over the trial. If Justice Roberts were to recuse himself, the country might face the specter of a Supreme Court deadlocked on the critical question of whether a sitting president undergoing an impeachment trial has the right to assert executive privilege to block witnesses at his own trial.

Title: 9/11 Responders and Survivors Eligible for Cancer Compensation

The World Trade Center Health Program has expanded its coverage to include 14 categories of cancer, including lung, breast, colon, and other common types, as well as childhood cancers. The decision, made by Dr. John Howard, the program's administrator, is a significant shift from previous assurances by the federal government that there was no link between 9/11 and cancer.

The decision was met with relief from some survivors, like Ernest K. Matthews, who developed lung cancer after being exposed to toxic substances while cleaning elevators at the Merrill Lynch building near Ground Zero. Matthews, 62, said it was a "good day" for those who suffered and lost their lives during the cleanup efforts.

The decision was based on a New York Fire Department study published in the British medical journal The Lancet, which showed that firefighters exposed to Ground Zero toxic substances had a 20% higher rate of cancer than those who were not exposed. Dr. Howard also relied on recommendations from a scientific and technical advisory committee, which concluded that 14 broad categories of cancer, encompassing 50 specific types, should be deemed related to the 9/11 attacks.

The expanded coverage applies to people who lived, worked, or attended school in Lower Manhattan between September 11, 2001, and May 30, 2002. Survivors of patients who have died, as well as those caught in the dust cloud downtown on the day of the attack, may also apply. The amount of compensation will depend on the severity of the illness and duration of exposure, as proven by records like employment or housing documents.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has consistently deferred to scientific rulings on health hazards at Ground Zero, said the decision was an "important step." The advisory committee considered but rejected adding all cancers to the list, citing concerns about the scientific evidence and the potential for false positives.

Epidemiologists have expressed mixed opinions on the decision, with some saying it was motivated by societal concerns and others noting that the scientific evidence is currently weak. Dr. Alfred I. Neugut, an oncologist and professor of epidemiology, said the decision was "difficult" and "primarily motivated by concern for a sympathetic population."

Title: Candidates Face Challenges in Michigan Primary

The upcoming primary election in Michigan is expected to be a crucial test for both Senator Ted Cruz and Governor John Kasich, as they vie for the second spot behind front-runner Donald Trump. While Cruz has benefited from Marco Rubio's weak performance in Kentucky and Louisiana, it remains unclear whether he can replicate this success in Michigan, a traditionally blue state with a relatively small evangelical voter base. Cruz has struggled in such states in the past.

On the other hand, Kasich, a moderate governor from a neighboring state, has been gaining ground and is now in a tight race with Cruz for second place. A strong showing in Michigan could set him up for a strong performance in his home state of Ohio next week.

Michigan is considered a strong state for Senator Bernie Sanders, who has been focusing on economic issues and appealing to white, working-class voters. The state's demographics align with Sanders' message, with a predominantly white population and a significant presence of college towns like Ann Arbor and East Lansing. However, the burden is high for Sanders, as he needs to make up for losses in the early primary season with stronger showings going forward. The polls suggest Hillary Clinton is on track for a decisive victory, so Sanders needs a surprise win to prove he still has a path to the nomination.

Title: Trump Campaign Launches Multimillion-Dollar Ad Blitz to Support Republicans in Midterm Elections

The Trump campaign is planning a significant advertising push in the final two weeks before the midterm elections, as part of a multimillion-dollar effort to help Republicans maintain control of Congress. The campaign has committed $6 million to a TV and digital ad buy, set to launch on October 29 and run through Election Day. Additionally, the campaign will send $3 million to the Republican National Committee (RNC) to support GOP candidates.

The Trump campaign has also announced plans to host at least 10 more "Make America Great Again" rallies in support of Republicans before the election. The rallies serve a dual purpose, boosting GOP candidates while keeping Trump's base energized ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

The Trump campaign has already amassed a significant war chest, raising around $100 million to date. The campaign will draw down some of this funding to support Republican candidates in the midterms.

According to the latest polling, Republicans are seen as holding the edge in the race for control of the Senate, while Democrats remain favored in the race for the House. However, the Democratic advantage in the House is narrowing.

The Trump campaign's efforts are part of a larger push by the RNC, which has raised a record $269.9 million in a non-presidential election year. The RNC has also received a significant influx of small-dollar donations, with 40% of the total coming from individual donors. In comparison, the Democratic National Committee has raised $136 million so far this cycle.

The RNC will receive an additional $3 million from the Trump campaign, which will be used to support GOP candidates. The campaign has also made direct contributions to 107 House and Senate campaigns, totaling $214,000 in August.

Both parties are urging voters not to sit out the election, with the Trump campaign emphasizing the importance of keeping control of Congress. The Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez has also emphasized the significance of the election, tweeting, "This is the most important election of our lifetime."

Title: Democratic Senators Defend Planned Parenthood Affiliates' Access to PPP Loans, Accuse SBA of "Scoring Political Points"

Article:

A group of 41 Democratic senators and one independent senator have written a letter to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Small Business Administration (SBA) Administrator Jovita Carranza, expressing their concerns that the SBA is unfairly targeting Planned Parenthood affiliates by seeking to reclaim Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans granted to the organization during the coronavirus pandemic. The senators argue that the SBA's actions are an "ideologically-driven" attempt to "score political points" by attacking nonprofit healthcare providers.

According to the letter, the SBA has notified at least three Planned Parenthood affiliates that they should return their PPP loans, with it unclear if other clinics have been contacted. The SBA declined to comment on individual borrowers, while the Treasury Department did not respond to questions from ABC News.

Planned Parenthood maintains that its affiliates rightfully qualified for the PPP funding, citing the eligibility rules established by the CARES Act and the SBA. The organization argues that its affiliates are independent, standalone entities with their own governing boards, and therefore qualify for the program.

The SBA's rules for determining eligibility for the PPP have been a source of confusion since their implementation, with Republicans arguing that Planned Parenthood Federation of America's organizational control over its affiliates means it should be considered a single entity with too many employees to qualify for the lending program. However, Planned Parenthood disputes this claim, stating that its affiliates are separate entities that lawfully qualify for the program.

The controversy surrounding the PPP loans has sparked a heated debate, with Senate Republicans urging the Department of Justice to investigate reports that Planned Parenthood affiliates received around $80 million from the program. The SBA's actions have been criticized by Democrats, who argue that the agency is unfairly targeting Planned Parenthood and other nonprofit healthcare providers.

Title: Representative Louie Gohmert Discusses Gun Control and Second Amendment Rights

Article:

Representative Louie Gohmert recently appeared on Fox News Sunday with Chris Wallace to discuss the Second Amendment and gun control in the wake of the Connecticut massacre. The segment began with footage of Eric Holder's call to discuss the freedom and rights Americans have, and how they can be used responsibly. Gohmert responded by referencing the Fast and Furious scandal, stating that the Department of Justice's actions led to the death of over 200 Mexicans and that there should be national outrage.

Gohmert also brought up the Aurora movie theater massacre, arguing that more people carrying weapons could have prevented a similar situation. When asked if it's desirable to have armed individuals in movie theaters, shopping malls, and schools, Gohmert responded that every mass killing of more than three people in recent history has occurred in a place where guns were prohibited, except for one. He emphasized the importance of having an open dialogue about the situation and highlighted the heroic stories of individuals who have used firearms to defend themselves.

The media then asked why people need semi-automatic weapons, which Gohmert attributed to the founding principle that a free people should be an armed people, as stated by George Washington. He emphasized that allowing citizens to carry concealed weapons has led to a decrease in crime rates and used Washington, D.C. as an example, stating that it should be the safest place in America, but it is not.

Title: Federal Government Plans to Share Medical Records with 35 Agencies Raises Concerns Over Privacy and Control

The Health and Human Services Department has announced a plan to share medical records with over 35 federal agencies, citing the goal of improving healthcare efficiency. However, critics argue that this move will compromise patient privacy and control over their medical information.

The plan, outlined in the Federal Health IT Strategic Plan 2015-2020, aims to advance the collection, sharing, and use of electronic health information to improve healthcare, individual and community health, and research. The plan involves collecting medical records through electronic health records, sharing patient information with the community, and using the data to advance health and well-being.

The plan has raised concerns among privacy advocates and individuals who value their personal freedom. The plan's scope is vast, with 35 federal agencies participating, including the Department of Defense, NASA, the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Agriculture, and the Department of Labor, among others.

Critics argue that this plan is a step towards a single-payer healthcare infrastructure, which could lead to government control over healthcare delivery. They also point out that the plan poses significant security risks, given the history of federal government computer system breaches, including those at the White House, State Department, and Obamacare.

The public has until February 6 to provide input on the plan, and critics are urging individuals to take a stand against this perceived violation of privacy and expansion of government control.

Title: Pelosi Refuses to Rule Out Indicting Trump While in Office

Article:

House Speaker designate Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California, has refused to rule out the possibility of indicting President Donald Trump while he is still in office. During an interview with NBC's Savannah Guthrie on "Today," Pelosi seemed to suggest that the Department of Justice's guidelines, which suggest a sitting president cannot be indicted, could be ignored in certain circumstances.

Pelosi stated, "I do not think that that is conclusive. No, I do not." When asked directly if Mueller can indict a sitting president, she replied, "Let's just see what Mueller does. Let's spend our time on getting results for the American people."

The relevant Justice Department guidance, drafted in 2000 by the Office of Legal Counsel, states that the indictment or criminal prosecution of a sitting president would unconstitutionally undermine the capacity of the executive branch to perform its constitutionally assigned functions. However, Pelosi pointed out that there is no existing legislation prohibiting the indictment of a sitting president.

"It's not the law," Pelosi said. "Everything indicates that a president can be indicted after he is no longer president of the United States." Guthrie asked, "A president who's in office? Could Robert Mueller come back and say I am seeking an indictment?" Pelosi responded, "I think that's an open discussion. I think that's an open discussion in terms of the law."

Pelosi, who served as the first female Speaker of the House from 2007 to 2011, is expected to reclaim the gavel in a Thursday afternoon leadership vote. She has attempted to avoid the question of Trump's impeachment in the weeks leading up to the leadership vote but has pledged to thoroughly investigate the president using Congressional subpoena power.

Title: House Republicans to Meet to Discuss Immigration Reform on July 10

Article:

House Republicans are set to meet on July 10 to discuss immigration reform, a topic that has been a contentious issue in the party. The meeting comes after lawmakers returned from their week-long break in their districts, where they heard from constituents about the Senate-passed bill. While some Republicans are expected to feel pressure to move quickly on the issue, others are skeptical that any immigration bill can garner the support of 218 Republicans.

Speaker John Boehner and his leadership team are aware of the political pressure building around the issue but do not see it as time-sensitive. They are willing to let the process stretch until the end of the year, according to sources. Key lawmakers have been meeting with rank-and-file Republicans, but have had difficulty reading the "coalitions" of support and opposition for various proposals.

The meeting on July 10 will be broken down into a three-step process. GOP leadership is expected to give a presentation urging lawmakers to speak their minds and develop a policy. Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte and Homeland Security Committee Chairman Mike McCaul will explain what House committees have already passed and options going forward.

Leadership needs to determine where lawmakers stand on four main areas: the future flow of immigrants into the U.S., a possible pathway to citizenship, government benefits, and border security. The meeting will likely decide whether to tie these items together in one bill or put them on the floor separately, which could allow members to say they supported a package with items they both liked and disliked.

The outcome of the meeting will be decided in a somewhat stealthy manner, with many details still to be determined.

Title: Hillary Clinton Returns to the White House for Lunch with President Barack Obama

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton made a return visit to the White House on Monday, meeting with President Barack Obama for lunch. The meeting was described as a social occasion, with Deputy Press Secretary Josh Earnest stating that the main topic of conversation was likely to be their friendship, rather than any specific policy issues.

Clinton's visit was not a formal meeting, but rather an opportunity for the two to catch up and discuss various topics. The menu for the lunch included grilled chicken, pasta jambalaya, and salad. Current Secretary of State John Kerry was also spotted arriving at the White House around the same time as Clinton, but it is unclear whether he joined the meeting.

The White House is preparing for Middle East peace negotiations, which may have been discussed during the lunch. Earnest noted that while the purpose of the meeting was social, it is unlikely that the topic did not come up.

Clinton's visit was arranged after Obama and Clinton met at the George W. Bush Presidential Center dedication ceremony in April. The two have maintained a strong working relationship since Clinton's departure from the State Department earlier this year. Clinton has been busy delivering speeches and launching her post-government initiatives, including an initiative through the Clinton Foundation dedicated to early childhood development and a book deal for a diplomacy-centered memoir to be released in 2014.

Title: Biden's Unconventional Approach to LGBTQ Issues at Democratic Town Hall

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden recently participated in a Democratic presidential town hall focused on LGBTQ issues, where he took an unconventional approach to showcasing his support for the community. Biden started by warning that all the candidates support LGBTQ rights, with any differences being in their "degree of emotional concern." He then proceeded to demonstrate his own emotional concern by flirting with multiple men, joking about coming out as gay, and even mimicking a kiss with CNN anchor Anderson Cooper.

Biden's actions were met with a mix of laughter and discomfort from the audience, with some finding his attempts to prove his allyship to be awkward and strained. The former vice president also made some humorous remarks, including joking that gay couples are more likely to stay together longer than heterosexual couples and referencing the progress made in public discourse around LGBTQ issues over the past 15-20 years.

Despite the unconventional approach, Biden's message of acceptance and normalization of being queer resonated with the audience. He emphasized that being LGBTQ is "normal" and "not strange," and noted the significant progress made in recent decades. The event concluded with Biden's segment ending on a passionate note, with Cooper remarking that they would "leave it there" after a fitting last note from the candidate.

Title: Mortgage Industry Faces Uncertainty Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

The mortgage industry is facing unprecedented challenges due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, with estimates suggesting that between 25% to 50% of borrowers may be unable to make their mortgage payments. This has sparked concerns about the ability of mortgage servicers, particularly non-bank servicers, to remain solvent. The Conference of State Bank Supervisors warned Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in a March 25 letter that the industry's ability to withstand the crisis is uncertain.

State regulators are concerned because non-bank servicers are the primary regulators of the industry. According to Jay Bray, CEO of Mr. Cooper, if 25% of borrowers fail to make their payments, the industry would need $40 billion to cover three months of payments. Depending on the duration of the crisis, demands on servicers could exceed $75 billion and climb above $100 billion.

The potential consequences of widespread mortgage defaults are severe. "The system breaks down" if mortgage companies fail across the board, said Andrew Jakabovics, vice president for policy development at Enterprise Community Partners, an affordable housing nonprofit. This could have serious ramifications for the availability and price of mortgage credit.

The Federal Housing Finance Agency Director Mark Calabria has expressed confidence that large banks will continue to extend credit to mortgage servicers for the time being. However, he acknowledged that a bigger solution may be needed if the crisis extends beyond two months.

Some mortgage companies may not survive the crisis, depending on the share of loans in their portfolios located in areas heavily affected by the virus. "Some servicers will need the liquidity sooner than others, so we're hoping that the facility will be set up immediately," said Broeksmit.

Industry experts believe that credit lines from banks will not be enough to keep the system afloat. "The mortgage market is one of the many complexly interconnected pieces of our financial system, so those assurances are really important, but I think the role of the government in being a reliable and available source of credit for the mortgage market and mortgage servicers during a crisis is even more important," said Margaret Liu, CSBS senior vice president and deputy general counsel.

In the meantime, the industry is hoping that individual cash relief in the Senate bill will lead to fewer people needing to request forbearance on their payments. "We're hoping that the take-up rate won't be too high and that the duration is not extended, but we have to prepare for both," said Broeksmit.

Title: House Democrats Move Closer to Suing for Access to Unredacted Mueller Report

Article:

The U.S. congressional Democrats have taken a step closer to suing the Trump administration in federal court for access to the unredacted Mueller report on Russian election meddling and its underlying evidence. The move is part of their ongoing efforts to investigate President Donald Trump and his presidency.

The House Judiciary Committee has introduced a resolution that authorizes the committee to seek a court order to enforce its subpoenas against U.S. Attorney General William Barr and former White House Counsel Don McGahn. Both Barr and McGahn have refused to cooperate with the committee's requests for the unredacted report and related documents.

The resolution, which is expected to be considered by the House of Representatives on Tuesday, replaces an earlier plan to hold Barr and McGahn in contempt of Congress. The measure also sets out terms for possible court action by other House committees investigating the president and authorizes the Judiciary Committee to petition a federal judge for access to Mueller's grand jury evidence.

The House Ways and Means Committee is also poised to file a federal lawsuit to enforce subpoenas of Trump's individual and business tax returns. Congressional committees already have the authority to seek court remedies, but the Democratic-controlled House is seeking to reaffirm its authority to enforce subpoenas against the White House's efforts to stymie investigations by six separate House committees.

The move follows through on House Democrats' plans to go to court in their quest for an unredacted copy of Mueller's report. Democrats are confident of swift court victories after decisive court rulings against Trump's efforts to block subpoenas of his financial records issued by three other House panels.

The Justice Department has not commented on the resolution. The House Judiciary panel voted on May 8 to cite Barr for contempt of Congress, and the House Oversight Committee is also weighing contempt citations against Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross for failing to comply with subpoenas in its probe of their handling of the U.S. Census.

Title: White House Launches "Made in America" Messaging Campaign to Refocus President Trump's Public Agenda

The White House is set to launch a three-week "Made in America" messaging campaign on Monday, aimed at refocusing President Trump's public agenda. The campaign will emphasize key tenets of Trump's agenda, including American-made products, American jobs, and the "American Dream." The initiative is expected to serve as preparation for the Senate's push to rewrite the U.S. tax code.

The first week of the campaign will highlight American-made products, with President Trump touring products displayed at the White House and on the South Lawn, and speaking to the media about his administration's support of manufacturing companies in America. The following week, "American Heroes Week," will focus on American jobs, and the third week will be dedicated to the "American Dream."

The White House has not announced a week dedicated to healthcare, despite the ongoing efforts to pass a Republican alternative to ObamaCare through the Senate. According to a White House official, "every day and every week is a healthcare week" for the administration, as it has devoted significant resources to the issue since taking office.

The campaign comes as White House aides are reportedly struggling to determine which of the president's policy priorities to focus on. Former Speaker Newt Gingrich, a political adviser to Trump, told the Wall Street Journal that the White House communications team is "still learning" how to wield its political influence and was unclear in stating its goals for the healthcare debate.

The "Made in America" campaign follows the White House initiative to promote "theme weeks" on policy areas, such as "infrastructure week" in June, during which the president tweeted about once a day on infrastructure issues. Subsequent theme weeks focused on energy and technology.

Title: June Jobs Report: Economy Adds 80,000 Jobs, But Growth Remains Slow

The United States added 80,000 jobs in June, a modest increase of 3,000 jobs compared to the previous month, according to the Labor Department's latest report. While the unemployment rate remains at 8.2%, some experts believe that what matters more than month-to-month job growth is a candidate's long-term plan for economic recovery.

In Ohio, a swing state with an unemployment rate of 7.3% in May, the question of what's next is crucial. Just before the job growth numbers were released, President Barack Obama spoke with diners who worked at Goodyear Tire & Rubber and toured the Summer Garden Food Manufacturing plant, which makes pasta sauce. Later, he addressed the tepid job growth in a speech to a gathering of a few hundred at an elementary school gym in Poland, Ohio.

Obama highlighted the economy's slow but steady recovery under his watch, including businesses creating 4.4 million new jobs over the past 28 months, including 500,000 new manufacturing jobs, and a government program to shore up the ailing U.S. auto industry. He acknowledged that "it is still tough out there."

Meanwhile, Republican challenger Mitt Romney called the jobs figures "another kick in the gut to middle-class families." Romney's economic recovery plan includes reducing the corporate income tax rate and curbing some regulatory policies he says have driven up energy costs, among other measures to help whittle down the unemployment rate.

Economist Ken Rogoff, a professor at Harvard University and former International Monetary Fund chief economist, believes that what's more important than month-to-month jobs numbers is a candidate's long-term plan for recovery. "What are the job numbers going to look like the next four years? And I think that's what the debate has to be around," Rogoff said.

The June jobs figures may make news now, but presidential candidates and voters will be more closely watching a critical jobs report due just days before the November 6 general election. If there's an uptick in jobs creation just before the election, Obama is in good stead. But a downtick could bode well for Romney, said Tom Smith, an assistant professor at Emory University's Goizueta Business School.

For those affected by the economic downturn, like Deanna Hubbard, who serves up steaming plates of scrambled eggs and bacon at Ann's Place in Akron, Ohio, the question of what's next is a daily reality. "The economy is doing bad. Right now, we've been blessed, but the economy has taken a toll on us with the food prices and delivery prices and people losing their homes," Hubbard said.

Title: Social Media Reacts to State of the Union Address: Memes, Tie Talk, and More

The State of the Union address delivered by US President Donald Trump to Congress sparked a range of reactions on social media, with many people discussing the event on Twitter. While political analysis and debate dominated the conversation, some lighter topics also gained attention. One of the most popular memes to emerge was a photo of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi applauding after Trump called for compromise in politics, highlighting the ongoing political rivalry between the two leaders.

Another notable trend was the widespread use of the color white by women on both sides of the aisle to celebrate the centenary of women's right to vote in the US. This move highlighted the significant increase in female representation among Democratic lawmakers, who sat stony-faced as Trump claimed that women had benefited greatly from the thriving economy. After Trump stated that women filled 58% of the newly created jobs last year, female representatives enthusiastically cheered and clapped for each other, a moment that was not lost on many Twitter users.

The irony of Trump's comments on female employment being associated with the electoral success of Democratic congresswomen was not lost on many. While some suggested that Trump did not intend for his comments to be linked to the Democratic lawmakers' success, the president did go on to praise the influx of female lawmakers.

The evening also saw some lighter moments, including the appearance of 11-year-old Joshua Trump, who was invited by the president and First Lady Melania. The boy, who has been bullied at school due to sharing the same name as the president, dozed off during the speech, earning him some fans on Twitter. His parents had pulled him out of school after his classmates called him an "idiot" and "stupid" for sharing the same name as the president.

The State of the Union address is an opportunity for the president to inform the nation of their goals for the year ahead. However, some were distracted by less weighty issues, such as the position of Trump's tie, with many taking to social media to point out that it was off-center. During the almost 90-minute address, many social media users were also preoccupied with trying to guess what Pelosi was reading.

After Trump finished his address, Stacey Abrams delivered the Democratic response, speaking about immigration, voting rights, healthcare, and the economy. However, Twitter users were more focused on the visual aspects of the address, with many wondering if Abrams was appearing in front of a green screen. The camera panned out after she finished speaking, revealing that a green screen was not used.

Title: Democrats Face Uphill Battle in Seven Key Senate Races

As the 2014 midterm elections approach, Democrats are bracing for a tough fight to maintain control of the Senate. With four weeks to go, the terrain and current momentum seem to be against them. A recent CNN/ORC poll suggests a Republican lead over a Democratic incumbent in Alaska, adding to Democratic concerns.

Some Democratic operatives are privately admitting that it's going to be a difficult task to keep control of the Senate. The economy, despite showing signs of improvement, is not translating to increased voter enthusiasm, and wages are stagnant. Additionally, many Democrats defending their seats in GOP-leaning states were swept into office in 2008, when President Obama's popularity boosted Democratic candidates in red states.

The GOP needs to win at least six seats to take control of the Senate, and Republicans are well-positioned to do so. Three incumbent Democrats have announced their retirement, making Montana, West Virginia, and South Dakota easy GOP pickups. The remaining seven competitive Senate races are in solid red states Alaska, Arkansas, and Louisiana, as well as blue-ish Colorado, Iowa, New Hampshire, and purple-ish North Carolina.

Democrats are cautiously optimistic about their chances in two of these races, Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Sen. Kay Hagan (D-NC). Hagan's current polling numbers show her trailing her GOP opponent Thom Tillis by 4 percentage points.

While each race is unique, the general trend suggests that Democrats are facing an uphill battle. Midterm elections tend to be more challenging for the party in power, and opposition to Washington appears to be a motivating factor for many voters. With Democrats in tight races but under 50% right now, it's difficult to imagine all of them breaking in favor of the party that holds the White House.

Title: Massachusetts Legislature's Mixed Views on Mitt Romney's Tenure as Governor

During his tenure as governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney worked with a predominantly Democratic legislature to tackle the state's problems. While Romney often highlights this collaboration as a key aspect of his governorship, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have mixed opinions about his leadership style.

Some Democrats praise Romney for his willingness to work with them to pass health care reform, which is considered his signature achievement. However, others criticize him for being distant and elitist, citing his decision to block off one State House elevator specifically for his office and install security ropes outside.

Robert Hedlund, the second-ranking Republican in the state Senate, noted that Romney's corporate background at Bain Capital influenced his approach to governance, which sometimes alienated Democrats. Hedlund said Romney was "all business" and focused on policy, which came back to bite him.

Romney's willingness to work with Democrats was evident in his ability to pass health care reform, a feat that earned him high marks from Mike Widmer, a government watchdog with the nonpartisan Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation. However, Romney's job creation efforts were not as successful, partly due to his CEO-style approach.

State lawmakers, including Democrats and Republicans, recalled that Romney was focused on national politics towards the end of his term, which may have contributed to his distant demeanor. His successor, Governor Deval Patrick, noted that he made changes to the governor's office, including reopening the executive elevator to the public.

While some lawmakers, like Democratic Rep. Jim Vallee, praised Romney's leadership, others, like Rep. Frank Smizik, described him as "elitist" and "distant." Overall, Romney's tenure as governor of Massachusetts was marked by a mix of cooperation and controversy, with lawmakers on both sides of the aisle having different opinions about his leadership style.

Title: Hundreds Gather at Washington National Cathedral for National Vigil for All Victims of Gun Violence

Hundreds of people gathered at the Washington National Cathedral on Thursday for the Newtown Foundation's National Vigil for All Victims of Gun Violence. The event aimed to honor the lives lost to gun violence and advocate for stricter gun control legislation. Neil Heslin, whose 6-year-old son Jesse was among the 20 students and six adults killed in the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, attended the vigil to find solace and pay tribute to his son.

The event featured a series of multi-faith leaders praying for an end to violence, with Rev. Mel Kawakami of the Newtown United Methodist Church saying, "We gather to say 'No more.'" Dr. Rajwant Singh, chairman of the Sikh Council on Religion and Education, emphasized the need for action, stating, "Only then can we call this nation a perfect union."

Relatives of those killed in various mass shootings, including the Empire State building and Aurora, Colorado, theater massacres, shared their stories and expressed their pain. Anthony Hardmon, 15, whose 19-year-old sister Ashley was shot and killed five months ago, offered words of support to those affected by gun violence, saying, "You're not alone."

Some speakers urged elected leaders to take action on stricter gun control legislation, with Rev. Gary Hall, the dean of the National Cathedral, calling on leaders to "find the moral courage and political will to lead us all to a new, safer era in American history."

Outside the cathedral, a group of women wore sashes made from yellow and black tape, reading "Stop Gun Violence," as a symbol of their advocacy for stricter gun laws. Babe Healy King, who organized the group, said the Newtown massacre was a "tipping point" for her and her friends to raise awareness about ongoing gun violence and push for change.

The event was sponsored by the Newtown Foundation and the National Cathedral, and aimed to bring attention to the devastating impact of gun violence on individuals and communities across the United States.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Wins Primary Election in Wisconsin

Article:

House Speaker Paul Ryan has won his primary election in Wisconsin, defeating businessman Paul Nehlen by a significant margin. Ryan, who has been in office since 1998, had largely ignored his opponent and was expected to win easily. Despite Trump's initial support for Nehlen, Ryan's popularity in his southeastern Wisconsin district and his massive fundraising advantage ultimately gave him the edge he needed to secure the win.

Ryan's campaign focused on his well-established reputation and connections to the district, where he was born and raised. He emphasized his experience and leadership skills, which have served him well as House Speaker. Nehlen, on the other hand, ran to Ryan's right, accusing him of betraying Trump and supporting a "globalist agenda" of disastrous trade deals and porous borders.

The primary election was not without controversy, as Trump initially praised Nehlen and then later endorsed Ryan. Nehlen's campaign gained momentum, but ultimately, Ryan's popularity and name recognition proved too much for him to overcome.

In other primary elections in Wisconsin, Republican Mike Gallagher won the primary in the northeastern part of the state, defeating two opponents. Gallagher, a former Marine and national security adviser for Governor Scott Walker's presidential campaign, will face Democrat Tom Nelson in the general election.
