The primary elections in Wisconsin were seen as a test of Trump's influence on the Republican Party, but Ryan's win suggests that Trump's endorsement may not be as powerful as some had thought. Ryan will face Democrat Ryan Solen, an Iraq war veteran, in the November general election.

Title: Trump Announces "Dishonest & Corrupt Media Awards" Amidst Feud with Steve Bannon and Criticism Over Nuclear Button Remark

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced plans to award "Dishonest & Corrupt Media Awards" on Monday at 5:00 pm, citing "Bad Reporting in various categories from the Fake News Media." The move comes amidst his ongoing feud with former advisor Steve Bannon and criticism over his recent comments about having a bigger nuclear button than North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

The awards are likely to target news outlets that have been critical of the Trump administration, including CNN and The New York Times. It is unclear whether the recognized stories will be deemed "fake" or simply unfavorable to the White House. The recipients may not wear the award as a badge of honor, as some have had to retract admitted false stories.

Late-night host Stephen Colbert has taken a humorous approach, buying a Times Square billboard with a "For Your Consideration" message, listing reasons why he should be honored, including "Outstanding Achievement In Parroting George Soros' Talking Points" and "Least Breitbartian." Trevor Noah's "The Daily Show" also has a similar graphic on its Twitter feed.

The move is seen as a publicity stunt aimed at exciting Trump's base, which already distrusts the press and enjoys the president's media-bashing. Trump views his presidency as an hour-by-hour exercise in programming, driving coverage to new topics when he wants to change the story line. The media dishonesty awards will likely generate significant coverage, but may not win him any new supporters.

Title: Attorney General William Barr Expresses Concerns Over Tech Companies' Content Censorship

Attorney General William Barr has expressed concerns over the growing trend of technology companies, including Google and Twitter, attempting to censor content that does not align with their views. In an exclusive interview with Maria Bartiromo on "Sunday Morning Futures," Barr stated that there is something "very disturbing" about the recent incidents, where tech companies have punished conservative news sites for their coverage of the protests following the death of George Floyd.

Barr specifically mentioned the cases of The Federalist and ZeroHedge, which were banned from Google Ads for allegedly pushing unsubstantiated claims about the Black Lives Matter movement. Google later disputed the claims, stating that The Federalist was never demonetized and that they worked with the site to address issues with its comments section.

Barr also referenced Sen. Tom Cotton's (R-Ark.) claim that Twitter tried to permanently lock down his account if he refused to censor his tweets on the topic of riots and looting. Barr noted that tech companies have gone from marketing themselves as open to all comers to becoming more selective and censoring different viewpoints.

The Attorney General emphasized that the concentration of power among a few large tech companies poses a fundamental problem for the sharing of information and viewpoints in society. He stated that this concentration of power allows companies to quickly galvanize people's views and push the public in a particular direction.

Barr suggested that one way to address this issue is through antitrust laws and challenging companies that engage in monopolistic practices. The Department of Justice is pushing Congress to pass new legislation that would hold tech companies accountable for what is posted on their platforms.

The proposed legislation would require online platforms to better police their sites for illicit and harmful material and take a more objective approach in deciding what content to remove. The DOJ is seeking to roll back the legal protections that tech companies have enjoyed under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996.

Barr explained that the problems with Section 230 arose when tech companies started taking down viewpoints and becoming selective in their content moderation. He noted that what the DOJ is stressing is that tech companies can take down content that is unlawful or does not accord with their terms of service, but they must make their terms clear and provide a process for users to dispute removals.

Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) has introduced legislation that would give Americans the ability to sue major tech companies like Facebook, Google, and Twitter if they engage in selective censorship of political speech.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Scrutiny in Second Debate

The second Democratic primary debate saw Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey receive praise for his performance, while Senator Kamala Harris struggled to regain momentum. Former Vice President Joe Biden was deemed "perfectly adequate" by some, but still faced criticism for his handling of healthcare questions.

Booker was commended for his optimistic demeanor and powerful speeches on criminal justice reform and immigration. He also made a notable point about Biden's attempts to take credit for former President Barack Obama's accomplishments while distancing himself from the Obama legacy when it's more convenient.

Harris, on the other hand, faced criticism for her unclear answers on healthcare questions, particularly regarding private plans under Medicare-for-all. Her campaign's new proposal aimed to address these doubts, but some argue it didn't provide sufficient clarity.

Biden was seen as "perfectly adequate" by some, but struggled to find the right words at times and seemed over-rehearsed. He did, however, show more energy and preparation compared to his first debate performance.

The debate also touched on the topic of climate change, with Booker emphasizing the need for more ambitious action to meet the US's climate goals. He argued that simply rejoining the Paris climate agreement is not enough.

The article also noted that both Harris and Booker need Biden to stumble, but for now, that's not happening. The candidates' differing views on healthcare reform were also highlighted, with Harris advocating for a more comprehensive overhaul and Biden seeking to build on the current system.

Overall, the debate saw a mix of praise and criticism for the candidates, with Booker and Harris facing scrutiny for their performances and Biden receiving a more lukewarm reception.

Title: China Plans to Send Nuclear-Armed Submarines to Pacific Ocean Amid Territorial Disputes

The Chinese military is reportedly planning to send submarines armed with nuclear weapons to patrol the Pacific Ocean, according to sources cited by The Guardian. The move is seen as a response to territorial disputes over islands in the region. While the timing of the maiden patrol has not been determined, Chinese officials have emphasized that such an action is inevitable.

This development comes on the heels of US President Barack Obama's decision to lift a decades-long arms embargo against Vietnam. Chinese officials publicly praised the move, but an opinion piece in a state-run newspaper warned that any attempt to enlist Vietnam in an effort to contain China could further complicate the situation in the South China Sea and risk turning the region into a tinderbox of conflicts.

US Secretary of State John Kerry responded by cautioning China against unilaterally engaging in reclamation activities and militarization of islands in the South China Sea. The Pentagon has reported that China has reclaimed over 3,200 acres of land in the South China Sea and is developing and building military installations on man-made islands.

The US and Vietnam have strengthened their relationship in recent years, amid growing Vietnamese concern over Chinese moves to assert its maritime claims. The two countries have clashed in the past over their conflicting claims in the South China Sea, with tensions rearing again in 2014 when China parked an oil rig off Vietnam's central coast, sparking confrontations at sea and deadly anti-China riots in Vietnam.

Last week, the Pentagon reported that two Chinese fighter jets flew within about 50 feet of a US Navy reconnaissance plane, which was deemed an "unsafe intercept." China responded by demanding that the US end surveillance patrols around the South China Sea, claiming that such missions "seriously endanger Chinese maritime security." Earlier this month, a US Navy destroyer sailed within 12 miles of China's Fiery Cross reef, an artificial island made after months of dredging operations. It was the third time the Navy has sailed a warship close to a contested Chinese island in what the Pentagon calls "freedom of navigation" operations.

**Trump's Escalating Battle with Justice Department Raises Constitutional Concerns**

In a move that has sparked concerns about the limits of presidential power, President Donald Trump has ordered an inquiry into claims that the FBI infiltrated his 2016 presidential campaign. The request was made to the Justice Department's inspector general, Christopher Wray, and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, during an Oval Office meeting.

The inquiry is a response to conservative media reports claiming that the FBI inserted a "spy" into Trump's campaign. However, the FBI has not confirmed this claim, and experts say it is unlikely that the agency would engage in such a move.

The move has raised concerns about Trump's willingness to challenge the boundaries of executive power and potentially undermine the independence of the Justice Department and the judiciary. Michael Hayden, a former CIA and NSA director, described the situation as "a little scary" and warned that Trump's actions could erode confidence in the independence of the judiciary.

The situation has also sparked concerns about Trump's use of his power to launch investigations into his political enemies. Trump has been accused of using his office to attack his political opponents, including former President Barack Obama and senior intelligence chiefs.

The controversy has also led to a campaign by Trump and his allies to discredit the special counsel investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Trump has sent out a campaign email calling on supporters to sign a petition to investigate whether Obama's FBI and Department of Justice infiltrated or surveilled his campaign.

Democrats have blasted the move as a symptom of a President raging out of control and disregarding the rule of law. Even some of Trump's allies on Capitol Hill have expressed discomfort with his latest actions.

The situation highlights the extraordinary times in Trump's Washington, where a President has turned on his own Justice Department and is urging his loyal followers to do the same. The outcome of this showdown remains uncertain, but it is clear that the nation is facing a constitutional crisis.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Defends Family Separation Policy with Biblical Reference

Attorney General Jeff Sessions sparked a heated debate on immigration and the meaning of a Bible passage while speaking in Fort Wayne, Indiana, on Thursday. Sessions cited Romans 13 to defend the Trump administration's policy of separating parents from their children at the border, which has been widely denounced by religious leaders and immigration advocates.

The policy aims to crack down on potential child trafficking or abuse and discourage parents from bringing their children on the often-dangerous border crossing. However, critics argue that the policy is inhumane and goes against Christian values.

Sessions, a Sunday school teacher at a United Methodist Church in Alabama, said, "I would cite you to the apostle Paul and his clear and wise command in Romans 13 to obey the laws of the government because God has ordained them for the purpose of order."

The first three verses of Romans 13 in the Common English Bible read: "Every person should place themselves under the authority of the government. There isn't any authority unless it comes from God, and the authorities that are there have been put in place by God. So anyone who opposes the authority is standing against what God has established. People who take this kind of stand will get punished."

However, some who share Sessions' faith disagree with his interpretation of the passage. Mike Mather, the senior pastor at Broadway UMC in Indianapolis, said, "It was terrible. If you read the first 11 chapters of Romans, you get a pretty good idea of what the context of that community was. If you read (Chapter) 12, you see love is supposed to be the guiding force... (Sessions) didn't read on very far."

Romans 12 includes the line, "Contribute to the needs of God's people, and welcome strangers into your home." Those verses, Mather said, seem to run contrary to the policy Sessions was defending.

The policy has been criticized by religious leaders from various denominations, including the United Methodist Church, Islamic Society of North America, Union for Reform Judaism, and Mennonite Church. A joint statement released by these organizations criticized the policy, saying it is "contrary to the values of compassion, empathy, and love that are at the heart of our faith."

The Rev. Rob Saler, executive director for the Center for Pastoral Excellence at Indianapolis' Christian Theological Seminary, said Romans 13 has a history of being used incorrectly to justify government decisions or edicts. He noted that it was used by Lutherans in Nazi Germany to support Adolf Hitler and by defenders of slavery in the 1840s and 1850s.

Saler emphasized that it's important to consider the context in which Paul wrote Romans. At that time, Christians were being executed by the Roman Empire, and Paul was writing about living a gentler life full of charity. "It's flat-out irresponsible (for Sessions) to use it without attention to the broader context," Saler said. "It's basically practical advice: While you're doing this, sure, go ahead and pay your taxes, give the government its due. But taken as a whole, Romans stands as a counter to unjust government and unjust rule."

Title: Biden's Campaign Strategy Echoes Jeb Bush's 2016 Approach

Article:

A comparison between Joe Biden's 2020 presidential campaign and Jeb Bush's 2016 bid reveals striking similarities. Both candidates were closely associated with their party's last president, and both led in early polls. However, their performances in debates and primary elections differed significantly.

Like Biden, Bush struggled in debates and performed poorly in Iowa and New Hampshire. He ultimately lost to Donald Trump in South Carolina by 25 points and dropped out of the race. Biden, on the other hand, beat Bernie Sanders by 29 points in South Carolina and went on to win in several other states.

Both Bush and Biden employed a strategy of emphasizing their connection to their party's previous president. Bush, the son of former President George H.W. Bush, made himself the defender of the "old guard" in South Carolina, drawing a contrast between Trump's nativism and his brother's more welcoming message. He also defended his brother's response to the 9/11 attacks, accusing Trump of "lying" about the presence of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

Similarly, Biden made his relationship with former President Barack Obama the centerpiece of his South Carolina campaign. His surrogates reprised Obama's campaign chant, "Fired up, ready to go," and Biden himself referred endlessly to the "Obama-Biden" administration in speeches. He also used Obama as a battering ram against his opponents, accusing Bernie Sanders of trying to "destroy Obama's legacy" and considering challenging Obama in a primary in 2012.

While both Bush and Biden employed a strategy of emphasizing their connection to their party's previous president, the results were vastly different. Bush's campaign ultimately failed, while Biden's campaign gained momentum and went on to win several states.

Title: White House and House Republicans Remain Divided on Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

The White House and House Republicans have failed to reach an agreement on the fiscal cliff, with the main point of contention being the tax rates on the wealthy. Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner stated that tax rates will have to increase, citing the need for responsible governance. However, House Speaker John Boehner expressed skepticism, calling the president's plan "flabbergasting" and stating that the president's idea of negotiation is "roll over and do what I ask."

The president's plan proposes increasing tax rates on income above $250,000 a year to 39.6 percent, generating an additional $1.6 trillion in revenue over the next 10 years. In exchange, the president suggests cutting Medicare and other programs by $600 billion. House Republicans have not publicly specified what they would cut, but have expressed dissatisfaction with the proposal.

Geithner emphasized that the ball is now in the Republicans' court, and the White House is willing to wait for them to come forward with their proposals. The president is also pushing for additional stimulus spending, totaling $200 billion, for unemployment benefits, training, and infrastructure projects. Boehner dismissed this proposal, stating that it would be more than the spending cuts the president was willing to consider.

The fiscal cliff, a combination of automatic tax increases and spending cuts, is set to take effect on January 1 if a deficit-cutting deal is not reached. The tax increases would cost the average family between $2,000 and $2,400 per year, and economists predict that the combination of tax increases and spending cuts would likely put the country back into recession.

Title: Joe Biden Recalls Being Arrested for Following Women into Dormitory in 2008

Article: In a recently unearthed clip from 2008, Joe Biden, then the Democratic presidential nominee and running mate of Barack Obama, shared a story about being arrested for following a group of young women into their dormitories. The incident occurred on October 15, 2008, during a football game between his university and Ohio University.

According to the clip, Biden joked about the incident, saying he was attending a game between his university and Ohio University, and he mistakenly followed the women into an all-female dormitory. He claimed an officer stopped him, noting that men were not allowed inside, and Biden joked that it was only a temporary detention.

In a separate report by CBS News, Biden recalled the incident, saying he was attending a game between his university and Ohio University, and he mistakenly followed the women into an all-female dormitory. He said he met the women, who were Ohio University students, and they invited him to join them, but he ended up getting arrested because men were not allowed in women's dormitories.

Biden recalled that he never breached the first floor and that it was only a temporary detention. He also mentioned that he was over 60 at the time and didn't want to admit it on national television.

The incident was documented on a CNN Political Ticker blog and was nearly identical to the remarks from the CBS News report.

Title: Attorney General Nominee Loretta Lynch Discusses Immigration and Law Enforcement

In a recent exchange with U.S. Senator Jeff Sessions, Attorney General nominee Loretta Lynch addressed the topic of immigration and law enforcement. Senator Sessions asked Lynch about the rights of lawful immigrants and citizens versus those who entered the country illegally. Lynch emphasized that everyone in the country, regardless of their immigration status, has the right to participate in the workforce.

Senator Sessions pressed Lynch on the issue, asking who has the most rights: lawful American immigrants or citizens versus those who entered the country illegally. Lynch responded that the benefits of citizenship confer greater rights on citizens than those who are not. She emphasized that lawful immigrants have the right to work and participate in the economy, but those who entered the country illegally do not have the same rights.

In a separate portion of the exchange, Lynch discussed the importance of building trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. She noted that many community residents feel disconnected from government and may view law enforcement as an extension of that disconnection. Lynch emphasized the importance of listening to community concerns and working together to create a safe and free society.

The exchange between Senator Sessions and Attorney General nominee Loretta Lynch highlights the complexities and challenges surrounding immigration and law enforcement in the United States.

Title: ACLU's Deleted Tweet on Catcalling Raises Concerns about Prioritization of Free Speech

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) recently sparked controversy when it seemingly called for a ban on catcalling, a form of street harassment typically directed at women. The tweet was quickly deleted, but not before a screenshot was obtained. The idea of a U.S. ban on catcalling, defined as street harassment of women, often of a sexual nature, would likely violate the First Amendment unless it was narrowly tailored to prohibit only severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive conduct or threatening behavior.

The ACLU's stance on catcalling is a complex issue. While many anti-catcalling groups understand that criminalizing such behavior would undermine important goals like criminal justice reform, as it would disproportionately affect marginalized communities, the ACLU's tweet seemed to suggest otherwise. The organization's deletion of the tweet and the fact that it was posted in the first place have raised concerns about the ACLU's commitment to free speech.

The article notes that a single tweet does not necessarily indicate a broad shift in the ACLU's thinking, but it is still surprising that someone who is unclear about the organization's stance on free speech would be in charge of its Twitter feed. The article also references concerns raised by former ACLU board member Wendy Kaminer and former president Nadine Strossen about the organization's commitment to free speech.

The article concludes that the deleted tweet raises concerns that free speech is becoming a secondary concern for the ACLU, with generic lefty social justice goals taking precedence. The notion that the organization would strongly oppose catcalling legislation is no longer obvious to those who work there, as they view the ACLU as a progressive organization rather than a civil liberties organization.

Title: California Democratic Party Refuses to Endorse Senator Dianne Feinstein for Fifth Term

Article:

Senator Dianne Feinstein, a self-proclaimed centrist Democrat, has faced a significant setback as the California Democratic Party refused to endorse her for a fifth term in the U.S. Senate. At the party's annual convention in late February, Feinstein received only 37% of delegates' votes, falling short of the 60% needed for an endorsement. This marks a significant departure from her reliably left-of-center voting record, which has earned her an 8 out of 100 on the American Conservative Union's congressional rankings.

Feinstein's lifetime rating is 9.15, indicating a consistent voting record that leans left. In contrast, left-leaning Americans for Democratic Action gives her an 85 rating, with scores ranging from 75 to 100 in recent years. Despite her reliably left-wing voting record, Feinstein's popularity among California Democrats has waned, with some attributing this to the party's shift to the left.

State Senator Kevin de León, who nearly won the endorsement, has taken a harder line against the Trump administration and promoted himself as a young leader with more energy to fight the battles the party is picking in 2018. De León's popularity at the convention was driven by his reputation as a steamrolling union organizer and his promise to stir up Trump's Washington more than Feinstein has.

The article highlights California's pressing issues, including public-employee pensions, taxation, and the state's struggling economy. The state's quality of life has been ranked the worst in the nation, with a high poverty rate and a failing public school system. The article concludes that if the state Democratic Party's shunning of Feinstein is any indication of how voters will mark their state and local ballots this year and in coming elections, these problems will only grow worse.

Title: Democratic National Committee Establishes Cybersecurity Advisory Board in Response to Hack Attack

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has formed a cybersecurity advisory board in the wake of a hack attack that resulted in thousands of internal party emails being leaked online. The decision was announced by interim chairwoman Donna Brazile, a political analyst from Louisiana, in a memo outlining the board's purpose and composition.

The four-member board, comprising Rand Beers, former acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security; Nicole Wong, a former technology lawyer for Google and Twitter; Aneesh Copra, co-founder of Hunch Analytics; and Michael Sussmann, a former Justice Department cybercrime prosecutor, will work closely with Brazile and the entire DNC to ensure the party's cybersecurity capabilities are best-in-class.

The decision to form the board is a direct response to what Brazile described as an "illegal cyber attack by state-sponsored Russian hackers." Federal investigators believe the DNC was one of several entities associated with the Democratic Party to be successfully targeted by hackers widely assumed to be agents of the Russian government.

The hack attack resulted in the release of thousands of internal emails, including correspondence that led to the ousting of former DNC chief Debbie Wasserman Schultz. The leaked emails also included credit-card data and other sensitive information concerning DNC staffers and their contacts.

The new board will work to prevent future attacks and strengthen the DNC's cybersecurity capabilities. Those affected by the data breach will receive offers of assistance to help mitigate any threats to their financial security. Details concerning the breach and other pertinent information for victims will soon be available.

In a statement, Brazile emphasized the importance of taking cybersecurity and privacy seriously and expressed her commitment to preventing similar incidents in the future. The DNC's decision to establish the cybersecurity advisory board is a step towards achieving this goal.

Title: Trump and Health Advisers Disagree on Timing of Social Distancing Easing

The Trump administration is facing internal disagreement on when and how to ease social distancing measures, with President Donald Trump advocating for a more aggressive approach and his top health advisers cautioning against a hasty reopening of the economy.

Trump has stated that he will base his decision on when to adjust federal social distancing guidelines and reopen businesses on "a lot of facts and a lot of instincts." However, Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and Dr. Stephen Hahn, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, have emphasized that their recommendations will be based solely on constantly changing data.

Fauci warned that it is not a simple matter of flipping a switch and returning to normal, as the decision will depend on various factors, including the nature of the outbreak and the threat of future outbreaks. He also cautioned against setting a specific date for reopening the economy, stating that it is too early to predict when the worst of the pandemic will pass.

Hahn also declined to set a specific date for reopening the economy, stating that it is too early to determine whether May 1 is a suitable target. He emphasized the importance of a data-driven approach and the need to take things day by day.

The disagreement between Trump and his health advisers highlights the challenges of navigating the pandemic and the need for a balanced approach. While Trump's instincts may be driven by a desire to get the economy back on track, his health officials are urging caution and a focus on data-driven decision-making.

Title: Senate Republicans Estimate Billions in Costs for Legalizing Illegal Immigrants

Article:

Senate Republicans on the Budget Committee have estimated that legalizing illegal immigrants could cost taxpayers billions of dollars in 2022, primarily due to increased Medicaid and ObamaCare benefits. According to the committee's Republican staff, the estimated cost could total up to $40 billion. This estimate includes payments from Medicaid and subsidies from the federal health care law, which are just a fraction of the federal government benefits available to green-card holders or U.S. citizens.

However, Senator Marco Rubio's office disputed the numbers, stating that it is too early to provide cost estimates since there is no legislative proposal yet. Rubio's office emphasized that he is concerned about the potential fiscal impact of the bill and will request an in-depth budget analysis.

Rubio has been a key member of the "Gang of Eight" drafting a proposal and has stressed that he would ensure there are limits on benefits being applied to these individuals. He stated that the first phase for them would be to get a non-immigrant visa, not a green card, and they would not qualify for federal benefits under that. However, their eligibility would change once they obtain a green card.

The office of Alabama Senator Jeff Sessions, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, expressed concern that the current plan does not apply the law meant to prevent immigrants from becoming a "public charge" to those already in the country before they are granted legal status. The Department of Homeland Security reported that the "public charge" standard is not aggressively enforced, with only one case found in most of fiscal 2012 where the claim was leveled at an immigrant, and the charge was later withdrawn.

It is worth noting that a bill has not yet been introduced, and Senators are working out the details in hopes of bringing it before Congress in the coming weeks.

Title: Hillary Clinton Shifts Left on Key Issues, Aims to Attract Young and Diverse Voters

Hillary Clinton, the former Secretary of State, has taken a more liberal stance on several issues, including gay marriage, immigration, and economic inequality, in an effort to appeal to the young and diverse coalition that propelled President Barack Obama to victory in 2008 and 2012. According to The Washington Post, Clinton's campaign has analyzed social and demographic trends, concluding that this approach will not harm her among moderate and independent voters in the general election.

Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, emphasized that her approach is not about measuring herself against an ideological scale, but rather about addressing the problems facing American families and people. Her aides believe that issues like paid family leave, a higher minimum wage, and more affordable college will resonate with the public, while her hawkish foreign policy views will not be a major concern.

By taking liberal positions on issues like climate change, abortion rights, and economic inequality, Clinton's advisers hope to avoid a serious challenge from the left while still finding support among general election voters. However, conservative America Rising PAC director Colin Reed predicts that this positioning will backfire, as it reinforces Clinton's worst attributes as a candidate and hurts her image among voters of all stripes.

Political strategists believe that it is unlikely for Clinton to recreate the coalition that Obama won, particularly among non-white voters. Nevertheless, they predict that her positions will draw strong support. The strategic advantage the Democrats have is that the distance between their base and the middle is shorter than for Republicans, according to Neera Tanden, president of the liberal Center for American Progress and a longtime Clinton confidant.

Clinton has not yet taken positions on the Keystone XL pipeline or Obama's free trade deal, but her advisers predict that her silence on these issues will not damage her standing.

Title: Congressional Democrats Argue for Nationwide Subsidies in Affordable Care Act

The congressional Democrats who drafted the Affordable Care Act (ACA) have filed a brief with the Supreme Court, arguing that they intended for consumers in all states to be eligible for subsidies. The brief disputes the opponents' claim that the law only allows subsidies to be paid in states that set up their own exchanges, not in those that use the federal exchange.

The Democratic lawmakers, led by Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, contend that excluding some states would defy the purpose of the ACA, which is to make health insurance affordable for all Americans. They argue that the law's language, which states that subsidies will be paid to those in exchanges "established by the state," does not draw a distinction between state-run and federal exchanges.

The case, known as King v. Burwell, has significant implications for the ACA, as it could create a hole in the law's economic assumptions. House Republicans have warned the Health and Human Services Department to prepare for the possibility of a ruling against the law.

The dispute centers on the language in the law, which states that subsidies will be paid to those in exchanges "established by the state." Opponents argue that this means the federal exchange, which covers two-thirds of states that refused to set up their own exchanges, are not eligible. However, the Democratic lawmakers who drafted the law argue that this interpretation is "so weak" and that the law grants subsidies to "applicable taxpayers" and defines them by income, not by geography.

The lawmakers' brief was filed by the Constitutional Accountability Center and disputes the opponents' claim that the subsidies were created as an incentive to get states to set up exchanges. Former Senator Ben Nelson, a key vote in the passage of the ACA, has written a letter stating that he always believed tax credits should be available in all 50 states, regardless of who built the exchange, and that the final law reflects this belief.

The case highlights the complexities of the ACA's drafting process, which was rushed and involved the use of budget gimmicks to pass the bill. The outcome of the case could have significant implications for the future of the ACA and the millions of Americans who rely on it for healthcare.

Title: Five Senators' Decisions on Kavanaugh Nomination Likely to Determine Confirmation

Article: The confirmation of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's nomination is likely to pass, as five senators considered swing votes have made their decisions public. Republican Senators Jeff Flake, Susan Collins, and Joe Manchin, as well as Democratic Senator Heidi Heitkamp, have announced their support for Kavanaugh, while Senator Lisa Murkowski is expected to oppose him. The senators' decisions are crucial, as the Republican majority in the Senate is razor-thin, with 51-49 votes.

Senator Susan Collins announced her support for Kavanaugh in a floor speech on Friday, stating that she believes the FBI report on sexual misconduct allegations against him is thorough but does not contain new corroborative information. Collins had previously expressed confidence in the report and had not yet finished reviewing the materials.

Senator Jeff Flake also announced his support for Kavanaugh, saying he intends to vote in favor unless something changes before the floor vote. He echoed Collins' sentiments about the FBI report, stating that it was thorough but did not contain new information.

Senator Lisa Murkowski voted against limiting debate on the nomination and advancing Kavanaugh to a floor vote, which is likely indicative of her ultimate decision. She stated that she believes Brett Kavanaugh is a good man but may not be the right man for the court at this time. Murkowski had previously been reviewing the FBI report and had not yet made a decision.

Senator Heidi Heitkamp announced her opposition to Kavanaugh, while Senator Joe Manchin is expected to support him. The decisions of these five senators will likely determine the outcome of Kavanaugh's nomination.

Title: House Republicans Question Authority of Obama Administration to Delay Health Care Law Provision

Article:

House Republicans are scrutinizing the decision by the Obama administration to delay a key part of the health care overhaul, questioning whether the administration has the authority to ignore the law without Congressional approval. The administration announced the delay last week, citing concerns from businesses about the complexity of the reporting requirements.

According to a Treasury official, the delay is an exercise of the administrative authority under the IRS code, with the department having "longstanding" authority to grant transition relief when implementing new legislation like the health care law. However, Republicans are challenging the move, citing concerns about the administration's authority to pick and choose which parts of the law to follow.

Representatives Phil Roe and Kevin Brady have expressed concerns about the delay, with Roe stating that he has asked the Congressional Research Service to investigate the issue. Brady has scheduled a hearing for July 10 to examine the administration's authority to change the law. Representative Darrell Issa has described the move as "another in a string of extra-legal actions taken" by the Obama administration.

The delay in question is the requirement for large employers to offer access to health insurance, which was originally set to take effect in 2014. The administration has stated that the delay is intended to simplify the rules and give businesses more time to comply. However, Republicans are questioning why the individual mandate, which requires individuals to buy health insurance, was not also delayed.

The controversy surrounding the delay is just one of several issues that Republicans have raised about the health care law. They are concerned that the administration may delay or change other provisions in the run-up to the January 1 launch of many of the law's major provisions.

Title: Navy Yard Rampage Highlights the Sterility of Gun Control Debate

The recent Navy Yard shooting has sparked a renewed debate on gun control, but the incident highlights the futility of the current discussion. The media and some columnists have focused on the wrong aspects of the tragedy, perpetuating misconceptions and misinformation.

According to law enforcement, Aaron Alexis used a shotgun in his rampage, not an AR-15, as initially reported. This mistake has led to a flurry of incorrect information and sensationalized headlines. The incident demonstrates the sterility of the gun control debate, as no amount of legislation or ban on specific weapons would have prevented the tragedy.

The article argues that the focus on gun control is misguided and that the real issue is mental illness. The author suggests that the authorities failed to intervene when Aaron Alexis called the Rhode Island police a month prior, indicating he was suffering from paranoid delusions and needed help. The author believes that it is crucial to address mental illness and make it easier to compel treatment for those suffering from it.

The article also criticizes the media for spreading misinformation and perpetuating misconceptions about gun control. The author argues that the Daily News' headline "Same gun, different slay" was incorrect and that the focus on gun control is a distraction from the real issue.

In conclusion, the Navy Yard rampage highlights the need for a more nuanced discussion on mental illness and the importance of addressing the root causes of violence, rather than focusing solely on gun control.

Title: White House in Political Bind Over Syria as Politicians Press for Military Action

The White House is facing pressure from both sides of the political aisle to take direct action against Syrian President Bashar Assad after reports emerged that he has used chemical weapons against rebels in the country's civil war. President Barack Obama had previously warned that the use of such weapons would be a "red line" and a "game changer," but the administration is now seeking to establish all the facts before deciding how to proceed.

According to a letter to Congress, U.S. intelligence officials believe with varying degrees of confidence that Assad has used the nerve agent sarin, based on physiological samples. However, the administration has not placed the U.S. on the brink of military action, instead calling for a comprehensive United Nations investigation and the need to establish all the facts before deciding how to respond.

A White House official emphasized the need for a strong, firm, and evidentiary basis to inform the way the U.S. consults its friends and allies, citing the need to avoid a repeat of the run-up to the invasion of Iraq. The official stressed that the "red line" threshold demands certainty, and that the U.S. must present information that is airtight and presented in a public and credible fashion.

Skeptics in Washington, however, are worried that not acting or acting too slowly might not only embarrass the U.S. if it backs away from its earlier rhetoric, but also lead to more atrocities by Assad. House Speaker John Boehner expressed concern that if the U.S. does not take action, it will embolden the Syrian regime.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called for immediate action to prevent further use of chemical weapons, stating that the "red line" had clearly been crossed and that action must be taken to prevent larger-scale use. House Armed Services Committee Chairman Buck McKeon questioned the utility of red lines if they lack clearly delineated boundaries and meaningful consequences, and asked why Obama had given warnings to Syria if the U.S. is not prepared to enforce them.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel stated that he would be prepared to give Obama military options at such time as the president requires them, but emphasized the obligation for the U.S. to investigate the situation with key partners and allies.

Title: Senators Introduce Bipartisan Legislation to Improve Wireless Networks in Rural Areas

Article:

A pair of senators, Cory Gardner (R-Colo.) and Maggie Hassan (D-N.H.), have introduced bipartisan legislation aimed at improving wireless networks in underserved rural areas of America. The "Advancing Innovation and Reinvigorating Widespread Access to Viable Electromagnetic Spectrum" (AIRWAVES) bill proposes opening up spectrum space for commercial licensed and unlicensed use, with the goal of driving down wireless costs and increasing accessibility.

Gardner and Hassan believe this will bring increased broadband access to rural areas, whose connectivity coverage rates and speed lag severely compared to urban areas. The legislation aims to avoid a spectrum crunch, pave the way for 5G service, and provide critical resources to rural America to continue rural buildout in unserved and underserved areas throughout Colorado and the country.

Some technology trade associations praised the introduction of the new bill, arguing it is needed to help rural communities. The Information Technology Industry Council's (ITI) Vice President of Government Affairs, Vince Jesaitis, applauded the bill, saying it would help the rollout of 5G high-speed wireless. Kelly Cole, Senior Vice President for Government Affairs at CTIA, a trade association representing wireless companies, echoed this sentiment, stating that the legislation provides a much-needed long-term plan to unlock valuable licensed spectrum.

However, some observers have expressed concerns about the bill's approach. Michael Calabrese, director of New America's Wireless Future Program, praised the bill's ambition but criticized its focus on a one-time auction of spectrum, arguing that this would not be as effective as opening up additional underutilized bands of spectrum.

The push to bridge the connectivity gap between rural and urban areas has become a growing priority in Washington, with lawmakers and government officials recognizing the importance of improving broadband access in rural areas. Senators Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) and Shelley Moore Capito (R-W.Va.) have advocated for deploying better broadband in rural portions of their states, and Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai has pushed for solutions that would make it easier for broadband companies to increase access to internet in rural areas.

Title: US Accuses Iran of Attacking Oil Tankers in Gulf of Oman

The United States has accused Iran of being responsible for an attack on two oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman, with President Donald Trump stating, "Iran did it." The president pointed to a video released by the U.S. military, which shows Iran's Revolutionary Guard removing an unexploded limpet mine from one of the oil tankers. Iran has denied any involvement, accusing the U.S. of waging an "Iranophobic campaign" against it.

The suspected attacks occurred on Thursday, with the Front Altair and the Japanese-owned Kokuka Courageous being targeted near the Strait of Hormuz. The U.S. Navy rushed to assist the stricken vessels, with the USS Bainbridge being sent to the scene. The ships' operators have not provided an explanation for the damage, but the U.S. military has released footage and still photographs showing the limpet mine on the Kokuka Courageous.

Iran has denied any involvement, with a statement from its mission to the United Nations saying that the U.S. economic war and terrorism against the Iranian people are the main sources of insecurity and instability in the region. The U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has stated that the U.S. assessment of Iran's involvement is based on intelligence, expertise, and recent incidents in the region.

The incident has raised concerns about the potential for further escalation in the region, with tensions already high between the U.S. and Iran. The U.S. has accused Iran of using limpet mines in previous attacks, including one in May targeting four oil tankers off the Emirati port of Fujairah.

Title: Obama and Boehner Reiterate Opposing Views on Tax Reform

The White House and the Republican-led House of Representatives have reiterated their opposing views on tax reform, with President Barack Obama advocating for higher taxes on the wealthy and House Speaker John Boehner pushing for tax code reform and lower tax rates.

In his weekly address, President Obama emphasized the need for a balanced approach to address the country's fiscal challenges, stating that higher taxes on those making over $250,000 are necessary to reduce the deficit and invest in education, job training, and manufacturing. He also highlighted the results of the recent election, claiming that the American people sent a message that they want action, not politics as usual.

On the other hand, Speaker Boehner argued that tax increases would send the economy back into a double-dip recession and instead called for tax reform that closes special interest loopholes and lowers tax rates. He emphasized the need for the country to work together to address its economic challenges and restore its future.

The two sides are at odds over the Bush tax cuts, with the White House supporting an extension for income under $250,000 and higher rates for income above that level, while Republicans want to extend the cuts across the board. The debate is centered around the "fiscal cliff" facing the U.S. economy, which includes the scheduled expiration of the Bush tax cuts and the potential for automatic spending cuts and tax hikes.

Title: Former Rep. Tulsi Gabbard Drops Defamation Suit Against Hillary Clinton

Article:

Former Democratic presidential hopeful Tulsi Gabbard has dropped her defamation lawsuit against former Secretary of State and presidential nominee Hillary Clinton. The lawsuit was filed in January, seeking at least $50 million in damages for remarks Clinton made during an October 2019 podcast interview. Clinton had stated that Gabbard was a "favorite" of Moscow and was being "groomed" by the Kremlin, implying that she was a "Russian asset."

According to Reuters, Gabbard and her campaign filed a notice of dismissal, stating that they "remain certain of the action's legal merit" but wanted to focus on the current coronavirus pandemic and "defeating Donald Trump in 2020" rather than pursuing the lawsuit.

The lawsuit claimed that Clinton's comments were made with "malicious intent" and had harmed Gabbard's reputation. The suit also alleged that Clinton's statements were made in an attempt to derail Gabbard's presidential campaign.

During the podcast interview, Clinton stated that Moscow was "grooming" a Democratic candidate to run as a third-party candidate, and that Gabbard was the "favorite" of the Russians. She also mentioned that the attempt to get a Democrat to run third-party would happen only if the Russians did not use 2016 Green Party candidate Jill Stein to accomplish the same thing.

Gabbard's campaign stated that Clinton's comments were made with "personal animus" and "political enmity," and that they were intended to harm Gabbard's reputation and derail her presidential campaign. The campaign also claimed that Clinton's statements were made during a critical presidential election, and that American democracy had suffered as a result.

The exact reasons for Gabbard's decision to drop the lawsuit are unclear, as the article does not provide further information on the matter.

Title: Planned Parenthood's Controversial Practices Under Scrutiny

Planned Parenthood, the nation's largest abortion provider, has been under investigation by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) for double billing Medicaid. The organization has also been paid over $650,000 as official "Obamacare Navigators" to promote the Affordable Care Act, which could generate hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue for the organization. This raises concerns about the organization's motives and the potential conflict of interest.

The organization's sex education programs, which are funded by taxpayers, have been criticized for promoting promiscuity and normalizing inappropriate relationships and abortion. The programs are taught in some school districts, starting as early as age two, and promote the use of condoms and hormonal birth control. However, Consumer Reports has rated Planned Parenthood's condoms as the lowest quality, and the World Health Organization has labeled hormonal contraception as a Type 1 Carcinogen, the same category as cigarettes and asbestos.

The organization's business model relies heavily on abortion, with 92% of their pregnancy services being abortions. Former employees have admitted that the organization's "options counseling" is designed to get women to have abortions, rather than providing actual counseling. The organization's annual report shows that they perform 145 abortions for every one adoption referral, suggesting that adoption and parenting are not viable options for the organization.

Planned Parenthood's financial incentives are also under scrutiny, with the organization receiving over $542 million in taxpayer funds annually and boasting a profit of over $100 million. The organization's motives for promoting Obamacare are clear: the more women enrolled, the more revenue they can generate.

The controversy surrounding Planned Parenthood has sparked concerns among students and parents, with some calling for transparency and accountability. The organization's practices have been exposed by Students for Life of America, which has taken its Planned Parenthood Project to over 40 schools in 20 states. The organization aims to educate students about Planned Parenthood's true intentions and the potential risks associated with their sex education programs and contraception methods.

Title: Republicans Suffer from "Pauline Kaelism": A Media Cocoon and Alternate Reality

The Republican Party is facing a generational battle, with younger operatives and ideologues calling for a break from what they see as a self-defeating and intellectually suffocating media cocoon. The party's electoral defeat in the recent presidential election has led to a re-examination of the GOP's media habits and the role they play in shaping the party's views.

A group of Republicans under 50 believes that the party's problem is not just the country's changing demographics or voter turnout, but rather a self-selected media universe that reinforces their own views and creates an alternate reality. This phenomenon is reminiscent of the concept of "Pauline Kaelism," coined by the late film critic Pauline Kael, who famously said that she knew only one person who voted for Richard Nixon in the 1972 election.

Young Republicans are concerned that they are trapped in a hermetically sealed bubble, where only their own views are reinforced and an alternate reality is reflected. They point to the rise of Rasmussen polls, the Benghazi controversy, and the influence of Fox News, talk radio, and the Drudge Report as evidence of this bubble.

Technology has also played a role in creating this cocoon. Facebook, Twitter, and email in-boxes have given consumers the power to curate their own news feeds, allowing them to largely shut out dissenting voices. This has led to a phenomenon where people are more empowered than ever to access a wide range of viewpoints, but also more likely to only see information that confirms their existing beliefs.

The result is a party that is increasingly insular and disconnected from the broader American public. As one Republican strategist noted, "The right is suffering from an era of on-demand reality."

Title: U.S. Airlifts $400 Million in Cash to Iran, Denies Ransom Payment

The Obama administration secretly airlifted $400 million in cash to Iran in January, settling a decades-old legal dispute over a failed arms deal, according to The Wall Street Journal. The payment was the first installment of a $1.7 billion settlement reached with Iran to resolve a 37-year-old dispute over a failed arms deal signed just before the fall of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi in 1979.

The money was flown into Iran on an unmarked cargo plane, with wooden pallets stacked with euros, Swiss francs, and other currency. The payment was not a ransom for the release of four American prisoners, according to White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest, who denied the claims, saying it would violate U.S. policy.

The prisoners, including two Iranian-Americans arrested by Iranian security services during Obama's first term, were released in January. The initial idea was to swap the Americans for Iranians held in U.S. jails, but the plans shifted in December as discussions dovetailed with the arbitration in The Hague over the old arms deal.

In January, President Obama referred to the resolution of the arms dispute, without disclosing the $400 million cash payment, saying that "with the nuclear deal done, prisoners released, the time was right to resolve this dispute as well."

White House spokesman Josh Earnest defended the deal, saying it's "Iranian money" and noting that the money had been paid into a U.S. account in 1979 as part of a deal to buy military equipment that never took place because of the overthrow of the shah. Earnest also said the bulk of the money "has been going to shoring up their economic weakness, and that's exactly what we predicted," while acknowledging that "it's possible that some of the money" has been used by Iran to support Hezbollah and the regime of President Bashar Assad in Syria.

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump criticized the deal on Twitter, saying "Our incompetent Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, was the one who started talks to give $400 million in cash to Iran. Scandal!" Sen. Tom Cotton, a Republican from Arkansas and a strong opponent of the Iran nuclear deal, accused Obama of paying "a $1.7 billion ransom to the ayatollahs for U.S. hostages."

Title: Biden Prepares for High-Stakes Debate Against Ryan

Article:

Vice President Joe Biden is gearing up for a crucial debate against Representative Paul Ryan, Mitt Romney's running mate, on Thursday night. The stakes are high, as Biden's performance in the debate could help turn the tide in the presidential election. Biden has been preparing extensively, scrutinizing videos of Ryan's speeches and interviews, and holding mock debates against Representative Chris Van Hollen and David Axelrod, a senior adviser in the Obama campaign.

Ryan, relatively untested in debates, has been preparing as well, spending days at a resort in the Blue Ridge Mountains with former Solicitor General Ted Olson playing the role of Biden. Biden, a seasoned debate veteran, has been careful not to get too rough with Ryan, who is 27 years younger than him. However, after Obama's lackluster performance in the first debate, Biden is expected to come out swinging.

The debate is likely to focus on issues such as taxes and Medicare. Biden will likely try to force Ryan to defend Romney's proposals on these topics and tie him to Ryan's Medicare plan, which includes caps on future spending and a plan to partially privatize it. Ryan has been critical of the Obama administration's handling of Medicare, accusing them of siphoning off hundreds of billions of dollars from the program to pay for the 2010 health care overhaul.

Polls have given Obama the edge on handling Medicare, with a recent CNN survey showing him leading Romney-Ryan 53% to 44%. Biden has been vocal about his opposition to Ryan's Medicare plan, calling it "voucher-care" and accusing the Romney-Ryan ticket of turning Medicare into a "piggy bank" for Obamacare. Ryan has defended his plan, saying it is necessary to protect the Medicare guarantee for current seniors and future generations.

The debate is expected to be a high-stakes showdown between two seasoned politicians, with Biden looking to regain momentum for the Obama campaign and Ryan seeking to capitalize on his opponent's perceived weaknesses.

Title: Iowa Caucuses: Lessons Learned for Hillary Clinton

The Iowa caucuses have once again proven to be a crucial test for Democratic presidential hopefuls, with Hillary Clinton underperforming for the second time in eight years. Despite her efforts, Clinton's campaign appears to be losing momentum, with Bernie Sanders emerging as a strong contender.

The Iowa caucuses are often seen as a barometer of momentum and expectations, rather than a true reflection of the broader American electorate. Nevertheless, the results have significant implications for the Democratic primary race. Sanders' strong showing has erased any remaining doubts about his viability, and he has defined the contours of the primary race more effectively than Clinton.

Clinton's speech highlighted her focus on domestic issues, echoing Sanders' own platform. However, her failure to address international concerns, such as ISIS, has raised questions about her ability to adapt to the changing political landscape.

The campaign is far from over, with New Hampshire and subsequent primaries in Nevada and South Carolina still to come. While Sanders has a commanding lead in New Hampshire, Clinton is expected to perform better in the later contests. The outcome is uncertain, but one thing is clear: the primary race will take much longer than initially anticipated.

The reasons behind Clinton's struggles are complex and multifaceted. Some attribute her underperformance to her inability to connect with voters, while others point to the broader shift in the Democratic Party towards more progressive policies. The truth likely lies somewhere in between. The Democratic Party's shift to the left is not solely due to Sanders' influence, but rather the result of various social movements, including Occupy Wall Street, Black Lives Matter, women's rights activists, climate change activists, immigrants' rights activists, and LGBT activists. These movements have pushed the boundaries of discourse and forced the political process to adapt.

As the campaign continues, it remains to be seen how Clinton will respond to her struggles and whether Sanders can maintain his momentum. One thing is certain, however: the 2016 presidential election will be a long and unpredictable ride.

Title: Study Finds Conservatives and Liberals Equally Unlikely to Trust Science When It Goes Against Their Beliefs

A recent study published in The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, conducted by researchers Erik Nesbit, R. Kelly Garrett, and Kathryn Cooper from Ohio State University, has found that both conservatives and liberals are equally likely to distrust scientific findings when they contradict their political beliefs. The study, titled "The Partisan Brain: How Dissonant Science Messages Lead Conservatives and Liberals to (Dis)Trust Science," examined the reactions of 1,518 adults to scientific messages that conflicted with their political leanings.

The researchers divided the participants into three groups: one group of conservatives was presented with scientific research on climate change and evolution that clashed with their political beliefs, while a second group of liberals was shown similar research on fracking and nuclear power that went against their political views. A third group was presented with more neutral scientific information. The results showed that both conservatives and liberals were less likely to trust the scientific results when they conflicted with their own ideology.

The study's findings challenge previous research that suggested conservatives are less capable of rationally processing scientific evidence due to psychological deficiencies. The study's authors noted that their findings link to the larger debate about political polarization of science and its implications for science communicators. The study's results suggest that both conservatives and liberals are equally likely to distrust science when it goes against their beliefs, highlighting the need for effective communication strategies to address the growing polarization of public attitudes towards the scientific community.

Title: Obama Calls for Action on Gun Control, Avoids Specifics

The President Barack Obama's call to action at a vigil for the victims of the Newtown massacre has sparked hope among anti-gun advocates that progress may be made on gun control, despite the President avoiding specifics. The White House has not provided a specific agenda, with Press Secretary Jay Carney stating that the administration does not have a specific plan to announce.

However, ideas are already circulating, including proposals from Senators Mark Warner and Joe Manchin, both of whom have top National Rifle Association ratings and have expressed openness to new gun restrictions. Senator Dianne Feinstein, one of the principal authors of the expired 1994 assault weapons ban, has announced plans to introduce an updated bill in the next Senate session.

The President has expressed support for an assault weapons ban, but has not expended political capital to support it. Senator Feinstein hopes to change this and has placed a call to the President to discuss the issue. Speaker John Boehner expressed sympathy for the Newtown victims and said the House is ready to assist the community, but did not mention any legislative action.

Representative Peter King, a supporter of an assault weapons ban, is skeptical about any significant changes. "I hope I'm wrong, but I'm just being realistic," he said. "Maybe this is the incident that is going to drive common-sense regulation forward, but we've seen so much in recent years and none of them have done anything."

The President himself acknowledged that individual government actions would be limited and would not necessarily stop future gun attacks. "No single law, no set of laws, can eliminate evil from the world or prevent every senseless act of violence in our society," he said.

The Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence is in regular contact with the White House and is encouraged by the President's message. However, the organization believes that legislation is necessary to make a significant impact and that executive action alone is insufficient.

Title: CNN Poll Reveals Divided Public Opinion on Healthcare for Illegal Immigrants and Private Insurance Coverage

A recent CNN poll has shed light on the public's stance on healthcare for illegal immigrants and private insurance coverage. The survey found that 58% of Americans oppose giving government-backed healthcare to illegal immigrants, while 38% support it. This is in contrast to the views of the 10 Democratic presidential candidates who participated in the second debate, all of whom raised their hands in support of providing healthcare to illegal immigrants.

The poll also asked about eliminating private insurance coverage and replacing it with a national government-run program. According to the results, only 21% of respondents support completely replacing private health insurance with a national program. Most of those who support a single-payer system want to allow private coverage to continue.

The poll's findings are reflected in the views of some Democratic presidential candidates, including Bernie Sanders, Kamala Harris, and Elizabeth Warren, who support eliminating private insurance coverage and replacing it with a government-run system. However, even among Democratic voters, a large majority are opposed to this proposal.

The CNN poll highlights the significant divide between the public's views on healthcare and the views of many Democratic presidential candidates. The survey's results suggest that the public is not in favor of providing healthcare to illegal immigrants or eliminating private insurance coverage, which could have significant implications for the upcoming presidential election.

Title: Obama Calls for Replacing Automatic Budget Cuts with Smaller Cuts and Tax Increases

The White House has renewed the debate over spending cuts, with President Obama calling for replacing the automatic $85 billion budget cuts with a mix of smaller cuts and tax increases. The proposal is a rehash of previous suggestions made by the president, which include ending tax breaks and lowering projected increases in healthcare spending. However, the White House has yet to provide a full list of deductions it wants Congress to target.

The president's call comes as the country approaches the next round of budget cuts, set to take effect in March. The cuts, known as the sequester, were first proposed by the White House in 2011 as a way to pressure Congress into coming up with their own spending cut plan to reduce the deficit over the next decade. However, partisan gridlock has stalled efforts to find an alternative, and the cuts are now set to take effect.

The Pentagon has grown increasingly pessimistic about the chances of avoiding the cuts, and the branches of the military have outlined what programs and sections would be hit hardest. Washington think tanks and policy centers have warned repeatedly of the havoc that the cuts could wreak on the economy, estimating that 1 million jobs could be lost this year and next as a direct result of the spending cuts.

House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell have rejected the president's proposal, citing the need for spending cuts and reforms to reduce the deficit. Boehner stated that the president's proposal would lead to more tax hikes, while McConnell criticized the president for failing to submit a budget by the statutory deadline this year.

The debate over the sequester has been ongoing for years, with both sides refusing to budge. The country is bracing for the impact of the cuts, which could have serious repercussions for the economy and the military.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Criticizes Government Spending, Calls for Pentagon Audit

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) has spoken out against what he considers "runaway government spending" and "wasteful spending" in a recent radio interview with John Catsimatidis on New York radio station AM 970. Paul, known for his fiscal conservatism, accused lawmakers of kicking the can down the road on budget issues by repeatedly passing continuing resolutions to keep the government running.

During the interview, Paul highlighted specific examples of what he considers wasteful spending, such as the $700,000 spent last year to study what Neil Armstrong said when he landed on the moon. He criticized the government for spending money on trivial matters, saying, "That's the kind of stuff your government is spending money on."

Paul also expressed his desire for the Defense Department to be audited, stating, "Before we give them more money, make them account for the money they're already spending." This is not the first time Paul has spoken out against government spending, as he has previously criticized his own party for embracing high spending under President Trump.

Paul's comments come after he forced a brief government shutdown early Friday morning by delaying a vote on a sweeping spending bill with a lengthy speech on the Senate floor. The bill, which included increases in both domestic and military spending, eventually passed hours later and was signed by Trump, ending the shutdown.

Title: Trump's Nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court: A Normal Move in a Polarized Political Landscape

The nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court by President Trump has sparked intense reactions from both sides of the political spectrum. While some have hailed the move as a normal and expected choice, others have deemed it a threat to democracy itself. The article argues that the liberal response to the nomination has been excessive and alarmist, treating every action and statement by the Trump administration as abnormal and unprecedented.

The article notes that the Trump administration has indeed taken many actions that diverge from traditional norms, but it also highlights the tendency of critics to treat everything as abnormal. The author urges critics to separate out the normal, abnormal, and truly alarming words and deeds.

The liberal response to the nomination has been characterized by dire warnings of the end of democracy, with some even suggesting that the appointment of Kavanaugh will lead to the end of the planet. The article argues that this reaction is not justified, as Kavanaugh's views are not extreme and he is a mainstream conservative.

The article also raises concerns about the long-term implications of the liberal response. If Democrats continue to treat every Republican idea and goal as a threat to democracy, it could lead to a crisis of American democracy. The author suggests that this would signal the end of normal politics in America and constitute a genuine crisis.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced view of the nomination, acknowledging the legitimate concerns about the Trump administration's actions while also cautioning against the dangers of hyperbole and alarmism.

Title: Florida's Felons Regain Right to Vote, Expanding Eligible Voter Pool

Florida has become a more unpredictable battleground state after nearly two-thirds of its residents approved Amendment 4, granting approximately 1.4 million convicted felons who have completed their sentences the right to vote. The measure excludes those convicted of murder and sex crimes. This expansion of eligible voters, roughly 1.4 million people, is significant, as elections in the state are often decided by fewer than 100,000 votes.

The exact impact of this new pool of eligible voters on the political landscape remains uncertain, according to experts and activists. Democratic candidates in the 2018 midterm elections overwhelmingly endorsed Amendment 4, making it a key part of their campaigns. Republicans, including Senator Rick Scott, largely opposed it.

The potential for change in Florida is theoretically enormous, according to Republican strategist Mac Stipanovich. "We're a state where statewide elections, where millions of votes are cast, are decided by a few thousand votes." Indeed, both former Democratic Senator Bill Nelson and Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum fell short in their races by less than 33,000 votes.

However, the implementation of this new right remains to be seen. Governor Ron DeSantis has stated that an implementing bill may be necessary by the Legislature to make the process clear. "There's going to need to be guidance for that. It's not delaying it. The people spoke on it. It's going to be implemented, but I think it needs to be implemented the way people intended, and I don't think that they wanted to see any sex offenders fall through the cracks," he told reporters.

Title: Presidential Candidates Focus on South Carolina Ahead of Upcoming Primaries

The Republican and Democratic presidential candidates are currently focused on South Carolina, with the Republican primary set to take place on February 20 and the Democratic primary on February 27. According to recent polls, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are the clear frontrunners, but the other candidates are vying for second place.

Trump has a solid lead, with a Real Clear Politics average of recent polls showing him at 36% support, compared to around 20% for his nearest competitor, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. Trump is looking to build on his momentum from his New Hampshire win, stating, "If we win here after winning so big in New Hampshire, we will make America great again."

Cruz believes he is the main challenger to Trump, saying, "One of the most important conclusions coming out of these first two states is that the candidate who can beat Donald Trump is me." Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush are currently in third and fourth place, respectively.

On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders crushed Clinton in New Hampshire, but she leads him in South Carolina, with 62% compared to his 32%. Clinton has acknowledged that she must figure out how to reach young voters, especially women, after Sanders pulled in more than 80% of women voters under 30 in New Hampshire. Sanders has also invested heavily in Nevada, which holds its Democratic caucus on February 20.

The Congressional Black Caucus PAC has endorsed Clinton, and both she and Sanders are vying for the minority vote. While the polls suggest Clinton and Trump will likely win in South Carolina, the other candidates are fighting to catch up, with more than 20 states set to vote in March.

Title: Bernie Sanders Regains Momentum in Democratic Primary, Narrowing Gap with Biden

Article:

Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator, has made significant strides in the Democratic primary, narrowing the gap with front-runner Joe Biden. Just two months ago, Sanders trailed Warren in the polls after recovering from a heart attack, but he has since regained lost ground, demonstrating the resilience of his left-wing campaign.

According to the RealClearPolitics polling average, Sanders is now averaging 19.3% in national polls, eight points behind Biden and four points ahead of Warren. Sanders' campaign has been gaining momentum, with some experts predicting he could win the nomination the second time around.

Sanders has been criticized for performing better in early-voting states like Iowa and New Hampshire, which are predominantly white, before losing to Hillary Clinton in more diverse states like Nevada and South Carolina. This time around, Sanders has made significant efforts to reach out to voters of color, specifically Latinos, who are crucial in states like California, where they make up about 40% of the population.

Polls show Sanders is the top choice among Latino voters, and he held a Spanish-language town hall in Las Vegas, alongside Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. This outreach could prove critical in states like California, which awards nearly 500 delegates, about 10 times as many as the first caucus state of Iowa.

However, Sanders' greatest asset – a core of solid support – is also shared by Biden. The Democratic presidential primary has proven surprisingly stable so far, with Biden continuing to lead even as candidates previously considered potential frontrunners, such as Kamala Harris and Beto O'Rourke, have exited the race.

Like Sanders, Biden has a solid base of supporters who have not abandoned him despite negative coverage in recent months. The Vermont senator would need the dynamics of the primary to shift in some significant way to pull ahead of the former vice-president.

While some centrist Democrats remain unconvinced Sanders can form a winning Democratic coalition, his 2016 campaign proved that he thrives on low expectations. Many Washington insiders scoffed at Sanders' first White House bid, until he fought Clinton to a draw in Iowa and scored a decisive victory in New Hampshire. Today, Sanders is offering the same message: "Don't underestimate me."

Title: Biden Campaign Reports Higher Percentage of People of Color Among Senior Staff Compared to Trump Campaign

The presidential campaigns of Joe Biden and Donald Trump have released data on the diversity of their staffs, with the Biden campaign reporting a higher percentage of people of color among its senior staff. According to the Biden campaign, 35% of its full-time staff and 36% of its senior staff are people of color. In comparison, the Trump campaign reported that 25% of its senior staff are people of color.

The Biden campaign also reported that 53% of its full-time staff and 58% of its senior staff identify as female. The Trump campaign reported similar numbers, with 52% of its full-time staff and 56% of its senior staff identifying as female.

The data was released by the Biden campaign after being pressed about the information during a town hall focused on issues affecting Asian American and Pacific Islander communities. Biden reportedly said, "We'll release the diversity data today when we get off this call. We'll call you, and the fact of the matter is we have a very diverse staff. And we have a diverse staff that goes across the board, in high-level and senior positions."

The Trump campaign did not release information on the percentage of people of color on its full-time staff.

Title: Trump's Immigration Policy Still Unclear, Campaign Manager Says

The Trump campaign's stance on immigration remains unclear, with his campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, stating that it is "to be determined" whether the Republican presidential nominee will continue to support the deportation of millions of undocumented immigrants living in the US. Trump himself insisted that he is not flip-flopping on the issue, saying he wants to come up with a "fair but firm" process.

Conway's comments came after reports emerged that Trump discussed a "humane and efficient" way to work with undocumented immigrants in the country currently, which was characterized by BuzzFeed as a way to legalize some and let them stay.
