This would be a significant departure from Trump's previous hardline stance on immigration, which focused on removing people in the country illegally.

However, Conway disputed that Trump presented a reversal of his position in the meeting, saying that what he said varied little from what he has said publicly. She emphasized that Trump wants to enforce the law, be respectful of those Americans looking for jobs, and be fair and humane to those who live among us.

The Democratic presidential nominee, Hillary Clinton, released a statement scoffing at Trump's potential change of heart on deportation, saying his immigration plan remains the same: to tear apart families and deport 16 million people from the United States.

Jose Fuentes, a Trump supporter and former attorney general of Puerto Rico, was at the roundtable with Trump on Saturday and said he did not walk away with the interpretation that Trump was open to legalization for some undocumented immigrants. Fuentes said Trump used the language of wanting to handle the issue in a "fair," "humane," and "legal" way, but did not automatically mean he would allow some to stay or have legal status.

The article also touched on other topics, including Trump's refusal to release his tax returns, which are under audit, and Conway's comments on Hillary Clinton's leadership and ability to stand up to enemies in the world.

Title: Tea Party Members Claim IRS Targeting and Other Government Actions Confirm Their Fears of Government Overreach

The Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) targeting of some political groups, combined with recent revelations about the Justice Department's seizure of Associated Press phone records and the Benghazi attack, have led tea party members to claim that their fears of government overreach are being confirmed. At a rally on Capitol Hill, Representative Michele Bachmann (R-Minn.) stated that these events demonstrate a pattern of political misdeeds by the federal government, specifically citing the president's health care law as a measure with potential political implications.

Bachmann questioned whether the IRS's actions could be used to deny healthcare based on political beliefs or religious beliefs, and whether this could happen under the new entitlement program of Obamacare. She also expressed concerns about the potential for political gamesmanship and political targeting.

Tea party groups have long been skeptical of the president's health care law and government overreach into citizens' personal lives. The recent events have only strengthened their concerns, with Senator Mike Lee (R-Utah) stating that the events of the last few days confirm their worst fears about the government targeting and spying on citizens.

At least one lawmaker, Bachmann, even floated the idea of impeachment, comparing the IRS scandal to Watergate. Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.) called for accountability, stating that someone needs to be held responsible and prosecuted for the actions taken by the IRS.

The resignation of the acting IRS commissioner, Steven Miller, has been seen as a step in the right direction, but tea party members believe that more needs to be done to address the issue. Bachmann described the resignation as a "canard" meant to distract from the real problem, and Senator Paul emphasized the need to find out who was responsible for the policy and hold them accountable.

Title: Secretary Kerry's Case for War in Syria Falls Short

Article: Secretary of State John Kerry recently appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to make his case for military intervention in Syria. However, his argument was met with skepticism, as the administration still cannot clearly justify the war and the American public remains hesitant to support it.

Kerry's presentation was marred by a lack of clear national security connections between the United States and Syria, and the supposed justification for intervention to stop the use of chemical weapons did not provide a clear explanation of how military action would deter their use. The administration's failure to demonstrate a clear national interest in the conflict has left many questions unanswered.

The article highlights the elephant in the room that Kerry and other politicians supporting the war refuse to discuss: the potential benefits to al-Qaeda-affiliated rebel groups in Syria. The author notes that President George W. Bush's 2001 statement, "We will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those who harbor them," raises concerns about the potential consequences of supporting these groups.

The article concludes that the administration has failed to provide a clear explanation of what benefits the war would bring to the United States, citing the words of President Dwight Eisenhower, who believed that every major problem should be tested by asking, "Is it good for America?" The author argues that, by this measure, war with Syria is not good for America, and that the administration's failure to explain the benefits of the war has left many questions unanswered.

Title: The Real Cost of the U.S. Government's $16 Trillion Debt: A Growing Concern

The U.S. government's nearly $16 trillion debt is a growing concern, according to a recent report by Deloitte, one of the world's largest accounting firms. The report highlights the significant impact of interest payments on the national debt, which is expected to total $4.2 trillion over the next decade. This amount is equivalent to paying tuition for every science/math/engineering college degree in the country, offsetting 80% of global warming pollution in the atmosphere, or providing tax cuts.

The report notes that interest payments on the national debt could quickly spiral out of control if investors become less willing to lend more money. According to Deloitte's lead author, Bill Eggers, if interest rates increase by just 3% over the next decade, the additional cost to the Treasury would equal the peak combined cost of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Not all economists agree with the implications of the study. Robert Stonebraker, an economics professor at Winthrop University, argues that a significant portion of the interest payments will go back to Americans, as major holders of government bonds are agencies and individuals within the U.S. However, Eggers notes that a significant portion of the interest payments do go overseas, with foreigners owning some $5 trillion in U.S. government bonds, $1 trillion of which is owned by China.

Stonebraker believes that the debt crisis is being overhyped and that the economy will recover, reducing the need for debt. He argues that deficit spending is necessary during economic slowdowns to stimulate the economy and get people back to work. Other analysts, however, believe that the deficit should be brought under control quickly, citing European countries that are cutting budgets as an example.

The Deloitte report highlights the importance of addressing the U.S. government's debt, which is expected to continue growing unless action is taken. While opinions may vary among economists, the report underscores the need for a comprehensive plan to address the debt and ensure the country's financial stability.

Title: House Republicans Propose Six-Week Debt Ceiling Increase, White House Open to Deal

The House Republicans have proposed a six-week increase to the nation's debt ceiling in exchange for the White House agreeing to discuss a broader set of fiscal issues. The proposal was made during a meeting between President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner and other GOP leaders at the White House. The meeting lasted over an hour, with the White House stating that "no specific determination was made" and that the two sides will continue to discuss the issue.

The proposal would raise the debt ceiling from its current $16.7 trillion to a temporary limit, allowing the government to continue borrowing and avoiding default. However, Senate Democrats remain skeptical, with Majority Leader Harry Reid stating that he is unsure what to expect from the House GOP.

The debt ceiling increase proposal sent the stock market soaring, as business leaders are keenly watching the negotiations. Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew warned that the government will run out of borrowing room on October 17 and will have to resort to paying out of cash on hand, potentially leading to missed payments to Social Security recipients and veterans.

The debt negotiations have overshadowed the ongoing government shutdown, which began on October 1 when Congress and President Obama were unable to agree on how to fund the government in fiscal year 2014. The House has passed several piecemeal bills to restore government operations, while the Senate has not held a floor vote on any of the proposals.

The White House has signaled its willingness to relent on some national park closures, allowing states to use their own money to fund operations at some sites. However, it remains unclear whether the GOP is focused solely on a debt deal or will accept adding a shutdown deal into the mix.

Title: The Left's Accusations of Racism: A Critical Examination

The left has long accused the right of being racist, with prominent figures on the left making bold statements about the Republican Party and its members. However, a closer examination of conservative policies and their implications reveals a more nuanced picture.

The article highlights the longstanding conservative opposition to Affirmative Action, which was first implemented during the administration of Republican President Richard Nixon. The policy aimed to address historical discrimination by lowering standards for black students, but conservatives argue that this is no longer necessary, as blacks have repeatedly proven they can compete with anyone without such benefits. Studies suggest that Affirmative Action actually hurts more blacks than it helps, as it sets them up for failure by admitting them to schools for which they are not prepared.

The article also examines the issue of voter ID, with conservatives advocating for its implementation to ensure election integrity. Critics argue that this is a ruse to prevent blacks and other minorities from voting, as many of them may not have the necessary identification. However, this claim is condescending and ignores the fact that ID requirements are necessary for various everyday activities.

Finally, the article discusses school choice initiatives, which conservatives support to give all parents, not just wealthy ones, the ability to decide where their children attend school. The left opposes these reforms, seemingly not trusting minority parents to make informed decisions about their children's education.

The article concludes by asking the question: Who is really obsessed with race? The left or the right? And whose policies really hurt blacks?

Title: Trump and Pence Vow to Continue Campaign Despite Republican Calls for Withdrawal

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and his running mate Mike Pence have indicated that they will continue their election campaign despite growing calls from prominent Republicans for Trump to withdraw from the race. The calls for Trump to step down come after a 2005 audio tape surfaced, in which Trump made lewd comments about women.

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Trump stated that there was "zero chance" he would drop out of the race. He also expressed confidence in his campaign's support, citing Hillary Clinton as a "horribly flawed candidate." Trump later appeared outside his Trump Tower headquarters, where he high-fived supporters and reiterated his commitment to the campaign.

Pence, who has described himself as a "Christian, a conservative, and a Republican, in that order," told a Rhode Island fundraiser that he was committed to Trump and the campaign. While he did not directly address the controversy, he reassured attendees that the campaign would "get through this" and remain on a path to victory.

Despite the controversy, Trump's campaign adviser told Fox News that Pence is "solid" behind the nominee. However, Pence himself stated that he was "offended" by Trump's comments and could not defend them. He also cancelled a planned appearance with House Speaker Paul Ryan in Wisconsin, citing the circumstances surrounding the tape.

Several Republicans have publicly withdrawn their support for Trump, including Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte, and Arizona Sen. John McCain. McCain, who is facing a challenge in November, stated that Trump's behavior made it "impossible to continue to offer even conditional support for his candidacy."

The Republican National Committee is considering how to move forward, with one possibility being to redirect its political operation away from Trump and toward helping vulnerable Senate and House candidates. Election law experts suggest it would be logistically impossible to replace Trump on the ballot altogether, with early voting underway in some states and overseas ballots already distributed.

Ryan fundraising chief Spencer Zwick has received calls from donors who want to help fund a new candidate to replace Trump, and a write-in or "sticker campaign" relying on social media could potentially make it harder for Trump to win.

Title: Protections for Federal Workers May Delay Termination Process for IRS Employees Involved in Targeting Scandal

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is facing scrutiny over its handling of tax-exempt organizations, with lawmakers calling for heads to roll. However, it appears that no one has been formally reprimanded, and a union spokesperson said no employees have been called to help. Most employees involved in the targeting program are protected by federal worker protections, which could prolong the termination process.

The incoming acting IRS Commissioner, Daniel Werfel, may try to clean house, but he would need to be prepared for a lengthy appeals process. Under federal rules, a fired government worker has the right to appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board, which can challenge the decision and ask to be reinstated. The board is set up so fired employees get two chances to prove they should stay, with the first stop being the regional level, which would be in Chicago for the Cincinnati-based IRS employees in question. The initial appeals take an average of 93 days to process, and if the regional board rules against the IRS employees, they could appeal to the national board in Washington, D.C., which takes an average of another 245 days.

The IRS employees would not collect a paycheck during the appeals process and would only receive back pay if they are ultimately reinstated. Max Stier, who heads the Partnership for Public Service, a nonprofit that recommends ways to improve the federal workforce, says it's "not impossible" to get rid of federal workers. In 2012, 8,755 federal workers were fired, and others likely resigned to avoid the ax.

There is also the option of getting the IRS employees out of the way more quickly by putting them on administrative leave. However, IRS workers could always fight back if they've had positive performance reviews until now, and the board has been known to mitigate penalties if an employee is a first-time rule violator.

Title: U.S. Lawmakers Divided on Fate of $1.5 Billion in Aid to Egypt

The United States is facing a dilemma over its $1.5 billion in foreign aid to Egypt, with lawmakers divided on whether to suspend funding following the country's military coup. Republican Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee believes that funding should continue, while Democratic Senator Jack Reed of Rhode Island is not eager to cut off aid. However, Republican Senator John McCain of Arizona and Representative Mike Rogers of Florida are advocating for the suspension of aid until specific conditions are met, including the establishment of elections and a free press.

Senator McCain, appearing on CBS' "Face the Nation," described the military's action as a coup, stating that it was the second time in two-and-a-half years that the military has intervened. He believes that aid should be suspended until a new constitution and free and fair elections are held. However, he acknowledged that aid cannot be pulled back because it is "in the pipeline."

Representative Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, emphasized the importance of ensuring a stable Egypt, but believes that the United States should not ignore the law requiring aid to be suspended in cases of a military coup. He suggested making an exemption to the current rule, but only if the president comes to Congress and explains the reasoning behind the decision.

Senator Robert Menendez, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, emphasized the need for a swift transition to a civilian government, with all parties participating, and new elections for the next president and a new constitution. He believes that the $1.4 billion in aid is intended to protect domestic interests while helping Egypt along a path to democracy.

The debate highlights the complexities of U.S. foreign policy and the challenges of navigating the nuances of international relations. While some lawmakers believe that suspending aid could accelerate the transition to democracy, others argue that it could undermine the stability of the region. The situation remains uncertain, with the U.S. government yet to declare whether the military's ouster of President Mohamed Morsi constitutes a military coup.

Title: Federal Investigators Release Preliminary Report on Amtrak Derailment, Find No Anomalies with Braking System or Track

A preliminary report released by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has shed some light on the May 12 Amtrak derailment that killed eight passengers and injured 200 others. The report found no anomalies with the braking system of the train or the signals and track at the site of the incident.

According to the report, the train was traveling at 106 mph before the emergency brake system engaged, and data from the train's event recorder indicated that the engineer activated the emergency brakes seconds before the derailment. The train, Amtrak 188, was traveling from Washington, D.C. to New York City when it derailed at 9:21 p.m. north of Philadelphia.

The NTSB is investigating whether the engineer was distracted or fatigued at the time of the accident, examining the engineer's cell phone and cell phone records to determine if any calls, texts, or messages were sent while operating the train. Although records indicate that calls and texts were made, investigators have not yet determined if any phone activity occurred during the time the train was being operated.

The NTSB is also investigating whether vandals threw rocks or other objects at passing trains around the time of the derailment, as the locomotive windshield has impact damage. However, investigators have not determined whether the damage was caused by a thrown object or the crash.

The Amtrak 188 locomotive has been estimated to have suffered $9.2 million in damages. The NTSB and FBI found no evidence of damage caused by a gun.

The incident has raised concerns about the safety of rail travel, particularly in the Northeast Corridor, where Amtrak has committed to installing an automatic braking system by December 31. However, a section of the track operated by Metro-North will not meet the deadline. Industry groups have warned that they will miss the deadline for having the system on an estimated 60,000 miles of track carrying passengers or toxic chemicals.

The Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) counted about 300 people injured and 10 killed in train accidents each year from 2003 to 2012, without counting highway-grade crossings or trespassers walking along tracks.

Title: Lyft Condemns Trump's Travel Ban, Pledges $1 Million to ACLU, Despite Investor Peter Thiel's Support for the Policy

Article:

Ride-hailing service Lyft has been praised by customers for its stance against President Trump's travel ban and its pledge to donate $1 million to the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) over the next four years. However, this move has raised questions about the company's relationship with one of its investors, Peter Thiel, who is a top tech advocate and adviser to the Trump administration.

Thiel, the billionaire investor and PayPal co-founder, has defended the travel ban, stating that it does not impose a religious test. However, Lyft's CEO Adrian Durbin emphasized that the company does not agree with Thiel's stance on the issue. "We don't always agree with our investors and aren't afraid to say so," Durbin said.

Lyft is not the only tech company to take a stance against Trump's travel ban while still having an investor who supports the policy. Airbnb and Stripe have also spoken out against the ban, but both companies have investors who back Trump. Airbnb's CEO Brian Chesky slammed the ban as "not right" and announced his company would provide free housing to refugees and anyone not allowed in the U.S. Stripe's CEO Patrick Collison said he would match $50,000 in donations to the ACLU.

Other tech companies, such as Facebook and Y Combinator, have also faced criticism for not distancing themselves from Thiel, who is a long-time investor in both companies. Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg framed the issue as allowing for diversity in all things, including politics. "We can't create a culture that says it cares about diversity and then excludes almost half the country because they back a political candidate," Zuckerberg wrote.

Y Combinator's president Sam Altman also weighed in on the issue, stating that he does not believe that deciding to get rid of all founders/employees who voted for someone is much better than a Muslim ban.

Title: Clashes Erupt Along Israel-Gaza Border as Hamas Stages Violent Riots

Article:

Violent clashes erupted along the Israel-Gaza border on Monday, as Hamas staged protests against the official opening of the U.S. embassy in Jerusalem. The Hamas-run health ministry in Gaza reported 43 Palestinians killed and hundreds more wounded, although the casualty numbers could not be immediately verified. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) stated that 50,000 Gazans participated in the clashes, with some attempting to breach the border fence and others hurling rocks at soldiers.

The IDF reported that three Gazans were shot while trying to plant explosive devices at the border fence, while others were killed attempting to open fire on Israeli soldiers. Protesters set tires on fire, sending thick plumes of black smoke into the air at several spots along the border, and incendiary kites were flown towards Israel, sparking a fire in a field outside Kibbutz Mefalsim.

The Facebook page for the Gaza riots instructed followers on how to breach the border fence and attempt to infiltrate Israeli communities, some of which are located about 1.2 miles from the Gaza border. The official Facebook page of the riots in Gaza published photos directing rioters to breach the fence and infiltrate nearby Israeli communities.

The Shin Bet Security Services revealed that Iran is funding some of Hamas' Gaza border chaos, with the agency stating that Hamas is encouraging and sending protesters to the border fence to carry out violent acts and damage security infrastructure. The Shin Bet also warned that Hamas is instructing its own members to stay away from the border until civilians breach the barrier.

The IDF warned in a video that Hamas is planning to "massacre" Israelis if its terrorists infiltrate the Israeli border. The army dropped leaflets over Gaza warning residents against approaching the border, attempting to sabotage it, or carrying out terror attacks.

Israeli Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman warned Gazans against participating in Hamas' riots, stating, "I suggest to the residents of Gaza: Do not be blinded by [Hamas leader Yahya] Sinwar, who sends your children to sacrifice their lives without hope. We will protect our citizens by all means necessary and will not allow the fence to be breached."

The article also analyzed some of the reasons Hamas may have organized the mass protests, including the Islamist terrorist group's desire to channel Gazans' anger towards Israel, the economic crisis in Gaza, and the potential for international attention and pressure on Egypt to ease the blockade.

Title: Trump Announces Delay of Tulsa Rally to Avoid Conflict with Juneteenth Holiday

Article:

President Donald Trump announced that he would be delaying his previously scheduled rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on June 19th, citing concerns from African American friends and supporters who suggested moving the event to avoid conflicting with the Juneteenth holiday. Trump stated that the date was not chosen deliberately, but dismissed concerns about the timing, calling his rallies "celebrations."

During an interview with Fox News, Trump also claimed that he has done more for the black community than any other president, and jokingly mentioned Abraham Lincoln, saying "it's always questionable." The timing and location of the rally drew criticism from African American leaders and Democrats, who argued that it sent the wrong message, particularly in the wake of recent protests sparked by the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody.

Tulsa was the site of a 1921 massacre in which a white mob killed dozens of black people and destroyed black-owned businesses. Rep. Val Demings (D-Fla.) and Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.), both African American lawmakers, criticized the decision, with Demings stating that the president's speech would be a message to every Black American: "more of the same." Harris tweeted that the event was "throwing a welcome home party to white supremacists."

Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt (R) commended Trump's decision to delay the rally, stating that it was done out of respect for the significance of June 19th. However, Oklahoma state Rep. Ajay Pittman (D) argued that the decision was made due to backlash and not an attempt to respect the holiday.

The rally, which was initially scheduled to take place in March but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic, is still expected to go ahead, with Tulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum (D) stating that the city will protect the free and peaceful exchange of ideas during the event.

Title: Brexit Politics: A Complex and Contentious Process

The latest developments in the Brexit process have led to a stalemate, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowing to use every means at his disposal to frustrate the new bill, including attempts to filibuster its progress in the unelected upper house. This move has sparked concerns about the prime minister's willingness to engage in a "scorched earth" policy, effectively going to war with Parliament.

The Brexit process has been marked by institutional affairs, with parliamentary procedure and court battles dominating the headlines. The arcane language of parliamentary procedure has been parsed by constitutional experts, leaving many members of the public bewildered. According to research by the Hansard Society, civic trust is at an all-time low, with only a third of people trusting politicians to act in the public interest and nearly half feeling they have no influence on decision-making.

The withdrawal from the European Union was always expected to be a complex technical matter, but the real cause of the conflict lies in domestic politics. Prime Minister Theresa May's handling of Brexit was marked by her autocratic instincts and refusal to engage in parliamentary consultation. Her successor, Boris Johnson, has taken a similar approach, leading to a series of procedural conflicts and legal battles.

The prominence of these conflicts has transferred the political questions driving the Brexit debate into arguments about legal permissibility. Questions about the kind of state Britain wants to be, its relationships with its constituent nations, its attitudes towards migrants, and its economic integration with other European states have been folded into and sometimes lost in conflicts over parliamentary rights and legal obligations.

The intensity of these conflicts has led to unusual alliances and unexpected protests, with usually pacific sections of society becoming ardent protesters. The tabloid press has branded High Court judges "enemies of the people," highlighting the deep divisions and mistrust that have developed during the Brexit process.

Title: Tea Party Movement Sees Resurgence in Favorability and Fundraising Following IRS Targeting Scandal

The Tea Party movement is experiencing a resurgence in popularity and fundraising following the revelation that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) targeted conservative groups and organizations for political reasons. A recent poll by Rasmussen Reports shows that 44% of likely U.S. voters now have a favorable opinion of the Tea Party, a 14-point increase from January and just 7 points below the record high of 51% in April 2009.

The poll also found that the percentage of voters with an unfavorable opinion of the movement decreased by 5 points, to 44%. The survey of 1,100 likely voters had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

The Tea Party Express, a California-based group, reported a spike in interest and contributions since the news of the IRS targeting broke earlier this month. Sal Russo, co-founder of the group, told Fox News that Tea Party members feel vindicated and energized by the scandal.

The movement, which started in 2009 as a reaction to the federal government's multibillion-dollar bank bailouts during the recession, played a significant role in the 2010 midterm elections by backing conservative candidates who helped Republicans take control of the House. However, critics argued that the movement had become less relevant during the 2012 election cycle.

The IRS targeting scandal has sparked anger and disappointment among Americans, but it has also given Tea Party members a sense of vindication. Russo stated that Tea Party members knew that government spending was out of control and that their political opponents would stop at nothing to achieve their goals.

The Rasmussen Reports poll also found that Tea Party support among Republicans surged from 61% to 80% following the scandal. This could have implications for the internal struggles within the Republican Party, particularly between the conservative caucus and the more moderate chamber leadership.

Company President Scott Rasmussen believes that the IRS targeting has the potential to thrust the Tea Party into the 2014 elections and could have a bigger impact on Democrats. He noted that the scandal cuts to the heart of President Obama's agenda, which is faith in government, and that his health-care plan is tied to the IRS. The question remains whether the Democrats' brand will remain tainted by the scandal.

Russo is optimistic about the Tea Party's prospects in the 2014 elections, saying he is working on potential races. However, he is uncertain about how long the scandal will remain in voters' consciousness.

Title: House Republicans Reject Senate's Comprehensive Immigration Reform Bill, Opt for Targeted Approach

The debate on immigration reform has shifted to the House of Representatives, where Republicans have rejected the comprehensive approach taken by the Senate and instead are pushing for a package of targeted bills. The Senate's "Gang of Eight" members, including Senator Charles Schumer, are not giving up hope that House Speaker John A. Boehner and other Republican leaders will eventually come around to supporting a broader package that includes a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants and enhanced border security.

Senator Schumer believes that the House will pass the Senate bill by the end of the year, despite current opposition from House Republicans. However, House Speaker Boehner and other Republicans have rejected the Senate's bill, citing concerns that it grants legal status to 11 million people before securing the U.S.-Mexico border.

House Republicans, such as Representative Trey Gowdy, have dismissed Senator Schumer's comments and emphasized that they will take their own approach on immigration reform. Representative Bob Goodlatte, a Virginia Republican, expressed concerns that the Senate bill does not prioritize border security and that the government failed to live up to its obligations in the past.

The House Hispanic Caucus Immigration Task Force Chairman, Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, criticized House Republicans for abandoning the bipartisan work accomplished in the Senate and warned that their approach will lead to no progress. Senator John McCain, a key supporter of the comprehensive package, acknowledged the difficult task facing House Speaker Boehner but expressed hope that the House will eventually come around to supporting the Senate's bill.

The debate is ongoing, with President Obama setting a timetable for the House to pass an immigration reform bill by the end of July. The outcome remains uncertain, as House Republicans continue to push for a targeted approach, while Senate Democrats and some Republicans advocate for a comprehensive solution.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Send Strong Signals of Anti-Establishment Sentiment

The Iowa caucuses, the first major test of the 2016 presidential election, have sent a clear message of discontent with the current political establishment. According to CNN senior political analyst David Gergen, the top four vote getters on the Republican side, Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, and Ben Carson, ran anti-establishment campaigns, capturing around 60% of the total vote. On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders won nearly half the total votes by campaigning for a revolution.

Voters on both sides are expressing frustration with the current economic order, with many seeking change and a break from the status quo. While it is possible that each party may ultimately choose a more moderate candidate, the Iowa caucuses have significant implications for the election.

For the Democratic Party, Sanders' strength will likely draw Hillary Clinton further to the left on issues, and she will need to find a way to close the enthusiasm gap with Sanders. On the Republican side, the establishment will be terrified of a Cruz candidacy, but they cannot ignore the strength of the far-right candidates.

The Iowa caucuses have also opened the door to a new, more extreme American politics. Much of the anger and frustration among voters stems from the sluggish growth of the economy over the past 10 years, and unfortunately, most economists do not expect this to change regardless of who is elected in November.

While the Iowa caucas results may not be representative of the entire American electorate, they can still have significant implications for the election. The caucuses saw a small fraction of the Iowa electorate, with Cruz winning with around 50,000 votes, or about 2% of the state's registered voters. However, big changes in America often come from small towns and hamlets, and the Iowa caucuses may be a harbinger of things to come.

Title: Washington Leaders Seek Deal Amid Emotional Aftermath of Connecticut Shooting

Article:

In the wake of the devastating shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut, Washington leaders are seeking a deal to avoid a fiscal crisis. Despite past partisan divisions, the tragedy has brought a sense of urgency and cooperation to the negotiations. President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner met at the White House on Monday, and a potential deal has begun to take shape.

The shooting has had a profound impact on the political landscape, with many lawmakers acknowledging that the tragedy has brought a sense of perspective and a need for cooperation. "It takes the fire out of the belly of partisans, just kind of puts everything in perspective and makes people question, well, everything," said John Feehery, a former adviser to three House Republican leaders.

The real test for any deal will be whether it can be approved by enough lawmakers in both parties. However, the shooting has given party leaders a little more room to maneuver, as the American people are focused on the tragedy and less concerned with political gamesmanship.

The negotiations have been ongoing since the election, with President Obama and Speaker Boehner meeting alone for only the second time since November. Reports suggest that Boehner has come closer to the president's position, offering to support raising the tax rate on high incomes and including an increase in the nation's debt limit in exchange for more long-term reductions in entitlement programs.

While some experts believe that the shooting may not have a significant impact on the fiscal negotiations, others see it as a turning point. "Psychologically, this puts them in kind of a depressed mood, and so it's not so much that they're reacting to what the people think, but that they're reacting to their own personal experiences," said John Feehery.

The shooting has also brought attention to the issue of gun control, which is a sensitive topic for many lawmakers. "I'm trying to be nonpartisan with this, but honestly, I think the Republicans have a big challenge," said Tad Devine, a longtime Democratic strategist. "They're not only in the position of defending tax breaks for rich people, but one issue that they don't even want to talk about — gun control — is now front and center."

Despite the challenges, both sides are aware of the need to avoid a fiscal crisis and are working towards a deal. The shooting has brought a sense of urgency and cooperation to the negotiations, and many lawmakers are hopeful that a deal can be reached before the year-end deadline.

Title: Senate Democrats' Concerns about Amy Coney Barrett's Catholic Views Spark Controversy

Article:

The nomination of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court has sparked controversy among Senate Democrats, who are concerned about her Catholic views. Specifically, they are worried that she may be influenced by her faith to make decisions that align with her beliefs, rather than the law. However, a closer examination of Barrett's views on the death penalty reveals a more nuanced picture.

Barrett has expressed opposition to the death penalty, a stance that aligns with many Democrats. However, her views on the issue are not necessarily tied to her Catholic faith, as some have suggested. In fact, she has written an article expressing her opposition to the death penalty, citing moral and philosophical concerns.

The controversy surrounding Barrett's nomination highlights the complex and often confusing nature of Catholic doctrine on the death penalty. The Catholic Church has historically taken a nuanced stance on the issue, with some popes and bishops expressing opposition to the death penalty, while others have supported it.

The article notes that the current Pope's views on the death penalty are not binding or infallible, and that the Church's opposition to it is not a traditional teaching. The author argues that the Church's current stance on the death penalty is more a reflection of modern liberal values than traditional Catholic doctrine.

The article also highlights the irony of Democrats opposing Barrett's nomination due to her Catholic views, while simultaneously advocating for the appointment of judges who share their own views on the death penalty. The author suggests that the Democrats' opposition to Barrett's nomination is driven by their own biases and a desire to maintain a liberal agenda.

Overall, the controversy surrounding Amy Coney Barrett's nomination highlights the complex and often confusing nature of Catholic doctrine on the death penalty. While some may view her views as a threat to the separation of church and state, others see her as a champion of moral and philosophical principles. Ultimately, the debate surrounding her nomination will continue to be a topic of discussion and debate in the coming weeks and months.

Title: The Misuse of Language: A Barrier to Clarity on Enhanced Interrogation Techniques

The debate surrounding enhanced interrogation techniques has been plagued by a crucial error: the misuse of the term "torture." This linguistic confusion has hindered progress and clarity on the issue, as opponents of these techniques have affixed the term to American practices to discredit them. Even defenders of these procedures have allowed themselves to be drawn into absurd debates, "defending torture."

The term "torture" has a negative connotation, implying a sinister motivation. However, the CIA's enhanced interrogation techniques were employed in carefully screened cases to secure information vital to defeating jihadists and saving lives. These practices, such as sleep deprivation, cramped confinement, and waterboarding, were used to extract information from high-value detainees.

The author argues that these techniques are not torture if they are employed with noble intentions, clear definitions, and close supervision. Waterboarding, in particular, is an ill fit for the "torture" designation, as it is not torture if done to one's own people. The author cites the experiences of special forces veterans who have undergone waterboarding as part of their training.

The article also references Rep. Sam Johnson, a retired congressman who was brutally tortured by the North Vietnamese, but does not equate their actions with those of American intelligence officers. CIA Director Gina Haspel's testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee highlighted the need to clarify the language surrounding these techniques.

The author concludes that the left has successfully hijacked the language to further their political agenda, using terms like "reproductive freedom" and "investment" to describe abortion and confiscatory taxation, respectively. The author urges the public to resist this linguistic manipulation and instead engage in honest discussions about the pros and cons of enhanced interrogation techniques.

Title: Former President Clinton Makes Strong Case for Obama's Re-Election

Former President Bill Clinton delivered a strong defense of President Barack Obama's presidency at the Democratic National Convention, highlighting the progress made in the economy and rebuking Republican criticisms. Clinton's speech was designed to appeal to undecided voters in battleground states like Ohio and Michigan, emphasizing the importance of a functioning government and the need for compromise.

Clinton's speech focused on the economy, acknowledging the challenges Obama inherited and the progress made since then. He emphasized that while the economy is not yet fully recovered, it is better than when Obama took office. He also criticized Republican policies, specifically those of Vice Presidential nominee Paul Ryan, and used humor and sarcasm to make his points.

Clinton's speech was not just a defense of Obama's presidency, but also an attempt to build a bridge to reluctant voters who are concerned about the economy. He emphasized the importance of a functioning government and leaders who can work together to advance the public interest. He also highlighted Obama's commitment to constructive work and derided the "overt hatred" of the president by some on the right.

The speech was well-received by the crowd in the arena, and it remains to be seen how it will be received by voters at home. However, Obama's nomination was secured with the votes of Ohio delegates in the early hours of Thursday morning.

Title: Racial Identity Politics and the Legacy of the First Mulatto Presidency

The article discusses the racial identity politics of Barack Obama, the first mulatto president of the United States. The author, a freelance opinion writer, argues that Obama's presidency has not brought about the transcendence of race consciousness, as initially hoped, but instead has led to increased racial tensions and strife.

The article highlights the recent incidents of rioting and police brutality, as well as the rise of the Black Lives Matter movement, which the author believes is focused exclusively on black-on-black violence and ignores the skyrocketing murder rate in black communities. The author also notes that two black males, radicalized online by militant Afrocentrism, targeted and murdered eight police officers in Dallas and Baton Rouge.

The article also references a New York Times/CBS News poll, which found that 69% of Americans believe race relations are generally bad, the highest level of discontent since the 1992 Los Angeles riots. The author argues that Obama, as a half-white, half-black president, should have used his platform to promote unity and transcendence of race consciousness, but instead has focused on racial identity politics.

The article also references the work of sociologist Everett Stonequist, who theorized that the mulatto's emergence as a race leader is often driven by a disparity between their aspirations and their status. The author suggests that Obama's adoption of an exclusive black identity may have been a calculated decision to address this disparity.

The article concludes by referencing the work of mixed-race poet and novelist Jean Toomer, who believed that mixed-race individuals could be the turning point for the return of mankind to a unified human race. The author notes that black-white multiracial Americans largely fall into two camps, one embracing Toomer's worldview and the other viewing their European ancestry and colonialist history as evil incarnate.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced and thought-provoking exploration of racial identity politics and the legacy of the first mulatto presidency.

Title: Democrats Prepare for Convention, Trump Heads West, and Superdelegate Saga Continues

The Democratic National Convention is just around the corner, and party insiders are bracing for potential tensions between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. While the relationship between the two candidates is unlikely to devolve into the same level of animosity as the Trump-Cruz rivalry, some Sanders supporters are still frustrated with Clinton's vice presidential pick and the Democratic National Committee's handling of the primary process.

One of the key issues on the agenda is the role of superdelegates, who have historically played a significant role in the convention process. Sanders has been pushing for reforms to limit their influence, but the party establishment is resistant to change. The proposed rules committee has recommended keeping superdelegates, but with some restrictions, which may not satisfy Sanders' supporters.

Meanwhile, the Democratic Party is searching for its next rising star, with some hoping to find a new face to carry the torch in future elections. The list of prospects is not as long as it was during the Obama era, but some lesser-known Democrats may be looking to make a name for themselves this week.

Donald Trump, on the other hand, is heading west, looking to make inroads in the crucial swing state of Colorado. Recent polls have shown Hillary Clinton with a steady lead, but Trump's presence in the state could still sway some voters. The addition of Mike Pence as his running mate may help him with social conservatives, but could also hurt him with key swing voters.

As the convention approaches, party insiders are bracing for a potentially contentious few days, with some Sanders supporters looking to make their voices heard and the party establishment fighting to maintain its influence.

Title: The Flynn Affair: A Cautionary Tale of the Dangers of Unaccountable Intelligence Leaks

The sudden resignation of Michael Flynn as national security adviser has sparked a heated debate about the role of the intelligence community and the accountability of government officials. While some have hailed the leaks that led to Flynn's downfall as a necessary check on the Trump administration, others have raised concerns about the erosion of democratic institutions and the dangers of unaccountable intelligence agencies.

The controversy surrounding Flynn's resignation is a complex one, with both sides presenting valid points. On one hand, Flynn's actions as national security adviser have been widely criticized, and his resignation was likely the right decision. On the other hand, the leaks that led to his downfall raise serious questions about the role of the intelligence community and the accountability of government officials.

The article argues that the leaks were not a legitimate means of holding Flynn accountable, but rather an attempt by unelected intelligence agents to manipulate public opinion and achieve a desired political outcome. The author notes that the leaks were not a one-time event, but rather part of a larger pattern of illegal leaks coming out of Washington.

The article also highlights the importance of congressional oversight and accountability in a democratic system. The author argues that elected members of Congress have a responsibility to conduct public investigations of alleged wrongdoing by public officials, rather than relying on anonymous leaks from the intelligence community.

The article concludes by warning that the erosion of democratic institutions and the rise of unaccountable intelligence agencies pose a significant threat to American democracy. The author argues that the American people must hold their elected representatives accountable and demand action to protect the integrity of the democratic process.

Title: US Job Growth Slows Down in May, Adding 69,000 Jobs

The United States added 69,000 jobs in May, a significant slowdown from previous months, according to a report from the Labor Department. This disappointing news sent the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting nearly 275 points. The report shows that hiring ground to a halt across various industries, with the unemployment rate rising to 8.2 percent.

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, attributes the slow job growth to fear and uncertainty among businesses. "Businesspeople are just very nervous. They've been through a lot. If anything goes off-script, they pull back. They stop hiring," he said.

The 69,000 jobs added in May represent the slowest pace of hiring in a year. Meanwhile, hundreds of thousands of new jobseekers entered the workforce, pushing the unemployment rate up. President Obama emphasized that the country is still adding jobs, but not quickly enough. "We knew there would be ups and downs along the way," he said. "But we also knew if we were willing to act wisely and boldly, and if we were acting together as Americans...and never quit, then we wouldn't just come back. We'd come back stronger than ever."

Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney seized on the report as evidence of Obama's handling of the economy, stating that the president has had three and a half years to turn the economy around. "Their policies have not worked, and in many respects their policies have made it harder for the economy to recover," he said.

Obama supporters argue that the struggling job market is less an indictment of the president's policies than the failure of Congress to pass his proposed legislation. Jared Bernstein, former chief economist for Vice President Joe Biden, notes that the president has been unable to get much through Congress in the last year and a half, since Republicans took control of the House. "The president has been pushing for policies which – if they were in place – the job market wouldn't be doing as badly as it is," he said.

The report comes at a bad time for Obama, as these months tend to shape voters' opinions about the economy as they prepare for the November election. Obama's re-election campaign has been busy criticizing Romney's record on job creation during his time as governor of Massachusetts. However, Nathan Gonzales, deputy editor of The Rothenberg Political Report, notes that history suggests it's Obama who will be held accountable for the economy if things don't improve between now and November. "Voters just want to feel like the country and the economy are headed in the right direction," he said. "And I don't know if enough voters believe that right now to help the president win a second term."

Title: Bronx Apartment Fire Kills 12, Including Four Children, in Deadliest Blaze in 25 Years

A devastating fire in the Bronx borough of New York City has claimed the lives of 12 people, including four children, making it the deadliest blaze in the city in at least 25 years. The fire occurred on Prospect Avenue, near Fordham University and the Bronx Zoo, and is still under investigation.

The victims include a one-year-old child, according to New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. The cause of the fire is not yet clear, but officials said it started on the first floor and quickly spread to the other floors of the five-story building.

More than 160 firefighters responded to the blaze, and television footage showed them carrying people to safety from fire escapes. Residents who managed to escape huddled outside in the bitterly cold conditions, with temperatures dropping to around -10C (13F). The Red Cross provided blankets to those on the street, as some residents fled the building without shoes or coats.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and Fire Commissioner Daniel Nigro described the fire as a "tragedy" and "historic in its magnitude." The fire service rescued at least 12 people from the building, but many more were injured.

Witnesses described the scene as chaotic, with people using fire escapes to escape the burning building. Luz Hernandez, who lives on the fourth floor, said her apartment filled with thick smoke, and she escaped with her husband and two sons as the smoke continued to rise.

The building, which contains more than 20 flats, was built over 100 years ago. The Associated Press reported that the fire is the deadliest in New York City since 87 people died in a social club fire in the Bronx in 1990. This is the second major fire in New York City in recent weeks, following a fire that killed a mother and her three children in Brooklyn earlier this month.

Title: Attorney General Barr Expresses Frustration Over Inadequate Answers on Trump-Russia Probe Origins

Attorney General William Barr has expressed frustration over the lack of clear answers regarding the origins of the Trump-Russia investigation. In an interview with Fox News, Barr stated that he has been trying to get answers to his questions, but many of the explanations he has received have been inadequate. He also noted that some of the explanations he has received do not "hang together," leaving him with more questions than when he first started.

Barr's comments come as the investigation into the origins of the Trump-Russia probe continues to unfold. The investigation, led by U.S. Attorney John Durham, is examining the role of government officials in the investigation and whether they abused their power.

The latest revelations involve former FBI Director James Comey, former Director of Intelligence James Clapper, and former CIA Director John Brennan, who reportedly used the unverified Steele dossier, paid for by the Democrats and the Hillary Clinton campaign, to discredit President-elect Donald Trump. The dossier contained salacious and unverified claims about Trump's alleged ties to Russia.

The investigation has also raised questions about who directed former FBI Director James Comey to brief President-elect Trump on the most salacious aspect of the dossier, the prostitutes in Moscow, in early January 2016. Comey has stated that his mission was to inform Trump about that slice of the dossier, but it is unclear who directed that mission.

The investigation has also raised questions about who leaked the information to the media, which ran with the story. Comey has stated that he did not explain to Trump that the dossier was opposition research and that he does not know who leaked it to the press. He also stated that he did not try to find out who leaked it.

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what further revelations will come to light.

Title: Lawmakers Question IRS's Ability to Administer Obamacare

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is facing scrutiny over its ability to administer the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as lawmakers from both sides of the aisle express concerns about the agency's capacity to handle the complex process. The IRS is responsible for enforcing the individual mandate, which requires Americans to hold health insurance unless they have a specific exemption, and for reconciling subsidy payments with actual income.

According to IRS Commissioner John Koskinen, the agency will handle the workload without additional funding, but some lawmakers are skeptical about the agency's ability to do so. House Republicans have questioned the IRS's fairness in enforcing the individual mandate, citing the agency's past targeting of political groups and the loss of Lois Lerner's emails, which could be relevant to the investigation.

Koskinen emphasized that the IRS's auditing system prevents any one employee from singling out a specific taxpayer, but some lawmakers remain unconvinced. The commissioner also acknowledged that the agency will need additional funding to build systems to administer its share of Obamacare, but Congress has not provided the necessary funds.

The debate highlights the challenges the IRS faces in implementing the ACA, particularly in reconciling subsidy payments with actual income. Many Americans will need to certify their insurance status when filing their taxes next year, and those who received tax credits to help pay for insurance will need to reconcile their subsidy payments with their actual income. The IRS is also responsible for enforcing the individual mandate, which requires Americans to hold health insurance unless they have a specific exemption.

The controversy surrounding the IRS's ability to administer Obamacare has sparked concerns about the agency's capacity to handle the complex process, and lawmakers from both sides of the aisle are weighing in on the issue.

Title: Ray Rice's Wife Defends Him, Criticizes Media Over Handling of Domestic Violence Incident

Ray Rice's wife, Janay Rice, has spoken out in defense of her husband, the former Baltimore Ravens running back, and criticized the media for its handling of their domestic violence incident. In an Instagram post, Janay Rice expressed her feelings of pain and sadness, stating that the media's coverage of the incident has caused her family immense suffering.

The incident in question involves a video that surfaced on Monday, showing Ray Rice punching Janay, then his fiancée, and knocking her out in an elevator of a New Jersey casino in February. The video, which went viral, led to Rice being released by the Ravens and suspended indefinitely by the NFL. Earlier, Rice was suspended for two games and fined $500,000 after an earlier video showed him dragging an unconscious Janay from the elevator.

Janay Rice accused the media of using the incident to "gain ratings" and "embarrass" her and her family. She wrote on Instagram, "No one knows the pain that the media & unwanted options (sic) from the public has (sic) caused my family... To make us relive a moment in our lives that we regret every day is a horrible thing."

NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell admitted that the league did not have the full video until Monday, when it was released by TMZ. Goodell also acknowledged that the league's initial handling of the incident was not sufficient, stating that he "didn't get it right." The NFL has since strengthened its sanctions for players who commit domestic violence.

The incident has also received attention from the White House, with President Barack Obama stating that he believes domestic violence is "contemptible and unacceptable in a civilized society." New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft praised Goodell's handling of the situation, stating that anyone who saw the video would be "outraged and really disgusted."

Title: Pro-Life Movement Makes Progress, Despite Setbacks, in the United States

The anniversary of the landmark Roe v. Wade decision has sparked a renewed debate on abortion in the United States. For many Americans, abortion has had a profound impact, leaving scars and breaking families. As science advances, the understanding of the developing fetus has become clearer, revealing the presence of small fingers, toes, a beating heart, and a functioning nervous system.

In 2014, the American people elected a new Senate majority, with a strong pro-life stance. The same year, undercover videos exposed Planned Parenthood's alleged trafficking of body parts from aborted babies, sparking widespread outrage. The videos led to a bill to redirect taxpayer funding from Planned Parenthood to community health centers, which fell short of the required 60 votes in the Senate.

Although the bill was unsuccessful, it marked a significant shift in the pro-life movement, with a 13-vote swing in favor of protecting all life since 2011. The movement has continued to gain momentum, with a recent Gallup poll showing 55% of Americans wanting all or most abortions made illegal.

The pro-life community has made significant progress, with technological advancements revealing the humanity of the unborn. Despite setbacks, including the president's veto of a bill to defund Planned Parenthood, the movement remains hopeful. The annual March for Life in Washington, D.C. will take place on Friday, with millions of Americans standing up for the vulnerable.

Senators James Lankford and Ben Sasse, both pro-life advocates, have been at the forefront of the movement, working to protect the lives of the unborn. Their efforts have been met with resistance, but they remain committed to their cause. As the president said in his State of the Union address, "Our collective futures depend on your willingness to uphold your duties as a citizen... to speak out... to stand up for others, especially the weak, especially the vulnerable, knowing that each of us is only here because somebody, somewhere, stood up for us."

Title: The Resistance Must Change Its Approach to Reach Trump Supporters

The article discusses the importance of understanding and respecting the perspectives of Donald Trump supporters, rather than simply condemning them. The author, a proud member of The Resistance, shares a personal experience of having a conversation with a friend who voted for Trump, which led them to realize that many Trump supporters are not necessarily bigots or racists, but rather individuals who are afraid of losing their sense of American identity and values. The author argues that progressives must stop being intolerant and condescending, and instead, try to understand where Trump supporters are coming from and why they voted the way they did.

The article highlights that many Trump supporters see progressivism and concepts like political correctness and intersectionalism as an attack on their deeply held feelings of what America "is." They are afraid of losing their (white and Christian) America in the tidal wave of cultural shifts that have occurred over recent decades. The author suggests that calling them names or labeling them as bigots will not change their minds, but rather, it is essential to respectfully suggest that the causes they fight for align with their deeply held patriotism and love for America.

The article concludes that the only way The Resistance can succeed is by fundamentally changing its tactics and realizing that the way into these hearts is to respectfully suggest that the causes they fight for align with their deeply held patriotism and love for America. The author emphasizes the importance of putting oneself in others' shoes and being willing to listen and teach, rather than getting offended or condescending.

**The Congressional Budget Office's Role: Separating Fact from Fiction**

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) is a non-partisan organization responsible for providing objective and accurate estimates of the budgetary implications of various legislative proposals. In recent years, the CBO has been under scrutiny due to its predictions about the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The White House has claimed that the CBO was "way, way off" in its predictions, but a closer examination reveals that the CBO was actually quite accurate in its overall assessment of the law's impact.

According to the CBO's 2012 projections, the number of people under the age of 65 without insurance would decline to 11% by 2016. The actual figure, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), was 10.3% in 2016. While the CBO did overestimate the number of people who would receive government-subsidized coverage through the new insurance exchanges, it underestimated the number who would gain coverage through Medicaid expansion.

The CBO's predictions were closer to the mark than those of the Obama administration and other prominent forecasters, according to an analysis by the nonpartisan Commonwealth Fund. The CBO's forecast of the ACA's effects was "reasonably accurate" compared to actual results in 2014, according to Sherry Glied, a New York University professor.

The CBO's 2012 projections also showed that millions of people would gain coverage, and millions did. The actual number of nonelderly people without insurance declined by 20.3 million since 2010, according to the CDC. The CBO predicted that 89% of the nonelderly would be covered by 2016, which was close to the actual figure of 89.7%.

In conclusion, the CBO's role is to provide objective and accurate estimates of the budgetary implications of legislative proposals. While the CBO may have made some errors in its predictions, it was closer to the mark than the White House and other forecasters. The CBO's work is essential in helping policymakers make informed decisions about healthcare policy.

Title: EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's Behavior Raises Questions About Power and Corruption

Article:

EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's recent actions have sparked concerns about the potential for corruption and abuse of power. Pruitt, who has been praised for his efforts to reduce regulations and promote conservative policies, has also been accused of using his position for personal gain. This raises questions about the relationship between power and corruption, and whether individuals with significant authority are more likely to abuse it.

Pruitt's behavior has been criticized for being petty and self-serving, with allegations of using his security detail to fetch him special items, such as hand lotion, and attempting to secure a discount on a used mattress. He has also been accused of trying to secure jobs for his wife and exceeding the budget for interior decorating.

This behavior is not unique to Pruitt, as other high-ranking officials, such as Ben Carson, have also been accused of abusing their authority for personal gain. Carson, the housing and urban development secretary, has been criticized for treating his cabinet appointment as a kind of ducal fiefdom, rewarding his family with business opportunities but also blaming his wife when he got caught exceeding the budget for interior decorating.

The article notes that there are perks to working in government, but these perks are inherent to the job, not the individual holding it. The article also highlights the importance of accountability and transparency in government, and the need for officials to prioritize the public interest over personal gain.

It is worth noting that Pruitt's actions have been criticized by both sides of the political aisle, and that his behavior has sparked concerns about the potential for corruption and abuse of power.

Title: States with High Debt and Pension Payments Struggles: A Growing Concern

The article highlights the financial struggles of several heavily Democratic states, including New Jersey, New York, Illinois, and California, which are facing significant debt and pension payment issues. According to former Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels, these states are approaching a "day of reckoning" and may force taxpayers to bail them out.

Connecticut, often considered the richest state per capita, has accumulated a debt of over $53 billion, with taxpayers potentially being forced to cover the shortfall. Illinois, New Jersey, New York, and California are struggling to make pension payments to retired government workers, with Illinois' vendors waiting months to be paid due to the state's $30 billion debt. New York's debt stands at over $356 billion, New Jersey's at over $104 billion, and California's at over $428 billion.

While the heavily Democratic legislature in Trenton, New Jersey, had to scale back Governor Phil Murphy's tax increase agenda, it is unclear whether this will be enough to address the fiscal woes of these states. The article suggests that decades of irresponsible spending have led to this crisis, and it remains to be seen whether these states will find a rational solution to their financial struggles.

Title: Obama's "Fix" for Insurance Cancellations Creates Confusion for State Regulators and Companies

The recent announcement by President Obama to allow insurance companies to sell policies that do not meet the Affordable Care Act's minimum standards has created confusion and raised concerns among state insurance regulators and companies. The National Association of Insurance Commissioners stated that it is unclear how the proposed changes can be practically implemented, and many state insurance commissioners are struggling to figure out how to implement the administration's sudden change.

The change was intended to address the concerns of millions of Americans who have lost their current insurance plans due to not meeting the minimum standards under the law. However, the move has caused chaos for insurance companies and state commissioners, as it upends the financial balance the industry was trying to strike, likely resulting in higher premiums for others.

Premiums have already been set for next year based on an assumption of when consumers will be transitioning to the new marketplace. If fewer younger and healthier people choose to purchase coverage in the exchange, premiums will increase and there will be fewer choices for consumers, according to America's Health Insurance Plans' President and CEO Karen Ignagni.

Some states, such as Washington and Oklahoma, have already expressed skepticism about the proposal, with Oklahoma Insurance Commissioner John D. Doak calling it "just passing the buck." Insurance commissioners are struggling to figure out how to implement the change, with some states already having sent out cancellation notices and set rates and plans for 2014.

The president's plan has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle, with Republicans accusing him of making the announcement to shift the burden and blame to insurance companies and state commissioners. The GOP-backed bill would allow people to extend their plans for another year and opt-in to new plans, but Obama has threatened to veto the bill.

Wendell Potter, a former executive at Cigna, believes that some insurance companies might take up the president's offer to make money off policy holders. He stated that the main reason the administration is doing this is because the federal exchanges are not working, and eventually, people will start to find out that there are better policies.

Title: Texas Senate Candidates Cruz and O'Rourke Engage in Second Debate, Focus on Domestic Issues

The second debate between Senator Ted Cruz and challenger Beto O'Rourke, held in San Antonio, Texas, focused on domestic issues, with both candidates refraining from personal attacks and delving into the details of their policy proposals. The debate offered a contrast to the common criticism that American campaigns spend too little time on the issues, with both candidates discussing their stances on taxes, climate change, immigration, judicial philosophy, and healthcare.

Senator Cruz, the Republican incumbent, emphasized his commitment to cutting taxes and maintaining the current economic boom, while O'Rourke portrayed himself as a moderate Democrat who wants to provide universal healthcare and work with anyone in Congress, regardless of party affiliation. The candidates sparred on various issues, with Cruz highlighting O'Rourke's support for impeaching President Trump and O'Rourke criticizing Cruz's record on judges and gun rights.

The debate also touched on the topic of the deficit, with Cruz defending his vote for tax breaks in 2017 and O'Rourke criticizing the move. The confirmation of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh was also discussed, with Cruz proudly stating his role in getting him on the Supreme Court and O'Rourke expressing his opposition to the appointment.

Despite being down in the polls, O'Rourke's campaign has seen a surge in fundraising, with a record-breaking quarter of $38.1 million. Cruz, on the other hand, has maintained a strong lead in the RealClearPolitics average of major polls, with a 7-point advantage. The race has drawn intense national interest, with Democrats hoping to retake Congress.

Title: National Security Concerns Emerge in Wake of Boston Marathon Bombing

The recent Boston Marathon bombing has raised concerns about the national security implications of the US immigration and visa system. The incident has sparked a renewed debate about the need for stronger national security protections in any comprehensive immigration reform. The tragedy has also highlighted the importance of scrutinizing individuals from high-risk areas, such as the Chechen Republic in Russia, before they enter the country.

The Boston bombing has exposed weaknesses in the US immigration and visa system, which allowed two individuals to allegedly commit acts of terrorism. The incident has raised questions about the effectiveness of current safeguards and whether they could have prevented the tragedy. The US immigration and visa system should provide more scrutiny to individuals from high-risk areas, as was the case with the 9/11 attacks.

The current system has been criticized for not adequately detecting extremist behavior in individuals who have already entered the country. The FBI had interviewed one of the deceased Boston attack suspects at the request of a foreign government two years ago, but there was no follow-up to the interview. This raises questions about whether there were any red flags that were missed and whether further investigation could have prevented the tragedy.

The incident has also highlighted the need for stronger national security protections in the immigration and visa system. The National Security Registration System, created in 2002, was suspended in 2011, but its basic premise – that extra screening is necessary for immigrants from high-risk nations – needs to be revisited and reinstated. Any comprehensive immigration reform must address these national security concerns and provide stronger protections against terrorism.

The incident has also raised questions about the refugee program, with two Iraqi citizens being sentenced to long prison terms for participating in terrorism and providing material support to terrorists while living in the United States. The current immigration reform must address how this could have happened and provide stronger safeguards for refugees from high-risk nations.

In addition, the incident has highlighted the need for a thorough examination of student visas and the possibility of suspending visas from high-risk areas pending an investigation into the national security implications of this program. Any new legislation must address the visa entry and exit programs, as well as refugee programs that have proven problematic.

Senator Rand Paul, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and Homeland Security committees, has emphasized the need for Congress to ensure that the federal government is doing everything it can to prevent any would-be terrorists from using a flawed immigration system against the US. The Boston Marathon bombing has highlighted the importance of national security concerns in the comprehensive immigration reform debate.

Title: Florida State University Shooting Leaves Three Students Wounded, Suspect Dead

A shooting occurred at Florida State University's Strozier Library early Thursday morning, leaving three students wounded and the suspect dead. According to a law enforcement official, the gunman, identified as Myron May, was an alumnus of the university and a lawyer who had graduated from Florida State before attending Texas Tech University's law school.

May had been staying at a guest house in a rural area, courtesy of David Taunton, who knew him through his sons who ran track together in high school. Taunton described May as a "good kid" and said he had confided in him about something that raised concern, but declined to elaborate on their last conversation.

The shooting occurred around 12:30 a.m. when the suspect walked into the library and opened fire. Students reported hearing several gunshots in a row, and some took refuge in a private study room rented by a fraternity. The suspect was confronted by campus police outside the building and was ordered to drop his weapon, but he disregarded the order and fired a shot at the officers. Police returned fire and fatally hit the man.

The three victims were located around the library, with one student in critical condition, another stable, and one treated at the scene and released. The Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare reported that the condition of the patients had not changed as of 10:30 a.m. Thursday.

University officials assured that the shooting was an isolated incident and there is no further threat on campus. Classes were canceled, but the campus remained open. A nursing supervisor at Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare confirmed that the hospital was treating two people for gunshot wounds early Thursday.

The incident sent shockwaves through the campus, with students and parents receiving alerts and updates on social media. One parent, David Sillick, received a text message from his daughter during the shooting, saying "There's a man with a gun in the library. I love you." He later received a call from his daughter, saying police were at the scene and clearing out the floors, and she was fine.

The investigation is ongoing, and detectives were seen inspecting the body of the alleged gunman, who was lying face down at the top of an access ramp just outside the library. Florida State President John Thrasher issued a statement expressing sadness and concern for the injured students and the university community.

Title: Republicans and Democrats Mark 50th Anniversary of March on Washington with Separate Events

The 50th anniversary of the historic March on Washington, celebrated in the nation's capital this week, is being marked with separate events by Republicans and Democrats as a sharp partisan divide persists on issues of race in America. The anniversary commemorates the 1963 event that drew hundreds of thousands of Americans to the National Mall in Washington, where Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his iconic "I Have a Dream" speech.

A new national poll indicates a left-right divide over whether King's dream has been reached.
