According to the Pew Research Center survey, 49% of Americans say that "a lot more" needs to be done to achieve King's dream, while 16% say little or nothing needs to be accomplished. The poll also shows that Democrats and Republicans do not see eye-to-eye on the question, with 35% of Republicans surveyed saying "a lot more" needs to be done, compared to 63% of Democrats.

Louisiana's Republican Governor Bobby Jindal wrote in Politico that while progress has been made on racial equality since King's speech, there is still a sense of dividedness among Americans. He suggested that Americans should focus on their shared identity as "Americans" rather than emphasizing their ethnic or racial heritage.

Separate events are being held by Republicans and Democrats to mark the anniversary. A Saturday rally, organized by the Rev. Al Sharpton's National Action Network, featured speeches from Rep. Nancy Pelosi, Rep. John Lewis, and other Democratic leaders. On Wednesday, President Barack Obama will deliver remarks at a rally on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, where King delivered his famous speech 50 years ago. Former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter will also attend and address the crowd.

The Republican National Committee is hosting a luncheon on Monday to commemorate the anniversary, featuring party chairman Reince Priebus and prominent African-American Republicans, including T.W. Shannon and former Rep. Allen West. The event aimed to recognize the progress made since King's speech and the importance of racial equality.

The events highlight the ongoing partisan divide on issues related to race, including voting rights and minority unemployment. While some Republicans are marking the anniversary, others are choosing not to participate, citing the ongoing work to be done to achieve King's dream.

Title: A Century of Meetings: U.S. Presidents and the Pope

The meeting between Pope Francis and President Obama at the White House marks a century-long tradition of private, often personal, and always significant encounters between U.S. presidents and the head of the Roman Catholic Church. The first such meeting took place in 1919, when President Woodrow Wilson visited Pope Benedict XV at the Vatican. The meeting was part of Wilson's tour of Europe, which included the Paris Peace Conference, and was seen as a way to discuss the recovery efforts following World War I.

The growing Catholic population in the U.S. was also a factor in Wilson's decision to visit the Vatican, as Catholics were becoming a significant force within the Democratic Party. However, the meeting was not without its awkward moments, as Wilson declined to be blessed by the pope, citing his Presbyterian faith.

The 40-year gap between Wilson's visit and the next presidential visit to the Vatican, by Dwight D. Eisenhower, was due in part to the Great Depression and World War II. However, anti-Catholic bias in the U.S. also played a role, as seen in the 1960 presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy, who had to address concerns about his Catholic faith and its potential influence on his presidency.

Kennedy, the only Catholic president in U.S. history, traveled to Rome and Vatican City as president, meeting with Pope John XXIII in 1963. The meeting was a significant moment for American Catholics, who saw it as a reaffirmation of their faith and pride in their country.

Since then, every U.S. president has met with the pope, with notable meetings between Lyndon B. Johnson and Pope Paul VI in 1965, Jimmy Carter and Pope John Paul II in 1979, and Ronald Reagan and Pope John Paul II in 1987. The meetings have often been marked by significant discussions on issues such as communism, the Cold War, and international relations.

In 2004, Pope John Paul II met with President George W. Bush, who was criticized for the U.S. war in Iraq. The pope condemned the war and referred to recent revelations of prisoner abuse at Abu Ghraib prison. Despite the criticism, Bush spoke warmly about the pope, describing him as an "awesome" individual.

The relationship between popes and presidents is seen as important by both sides, with each meeting offering a unique opportunity for dialogue and understanding. The meeting between Pope Francis and President Obama is the latest in a long line of significant encounters between U.S. leaders and the head of the Roman Catholic Church.

Title: The Hidden Government Program Behind American Healthcare

The recent Economist/YouGov poll highlights the complexity of healthcare politics in the United States, revealing why it is challenging for both left-wing and right-wing ideas to gain traction with the American public. The poll shows that many Americans are unaware of the government's role in providing healthcare assistance, which is often hidden from view.

The majority of Americans with health insurance receive government help to afford it, whether through Medicare for the elderly, Medicaid for the disabled and poor, or the tax subsidy for employer-provided health insurance for full-time workers. Some individuals may not know what Medicare is or mistakenly believe they have "paid for" their benefits with earlier taxes.

The tax subsidy for employer-provided health insurance is a significant government program that benefits millions of Americans. When employers pay employees' salaries, they do not pay income taxes on the portion used for health insurance. This makes it efficient for employers to offer health insurance as a benefit. The regulations require employers to offer insurance to all new hires, regardless of health history, and to treat all employees equally.

This system works well for employees of large companies, which can pool their risk to provide affordable insurance. However, it does not work as well for the self-employed, small businesses, contractors, part-time workers, or those who get laid off or are entrepreneurs, as they cannot spread the cost of caring for an individual sick person across a large group of mostly healthy people.

Policy experts agree that it is unfair to provide this subsidy to employees of large companies while others go unsubsidized and uncovered. The Affordable Care Act aimed to address this unfairness by creating a parallel system of subsidies for those without job-based care and reducing the tax subsidy for the most expensive job-based plans.

Conservative plans, such as those proposed by John McCain and currently being pushed by Richard Burr, Orrin Hatch, and Fred Upton, aim to level the playing field by eliminating or curtailing the subsidy for job-based plans. However, this subsidy is often seen as the "original sin" of American healthcare policy by conservative health wonk Avik Roy. The public's lack of awareness about this subsidy contributes to the difficulty in finding common ground on healthcare policy, making it challenging for both liberals and conservatives to agree on a solution.

Title: Rep. Devin Nunes Expresses Concerns Over Tech Oligarchs' Alleged Bias Against Conservatives

Rep. Devin Nunes, the ranking member of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, has expressed concerns over the alleged bias against conservatives by tech giants like Twitter, Facebook, and Google. In an exclusive interview on SiriusXM Patriot Channel 125, Nunes stated that he is "very concerned" about the rising threat of tech oligarchs censoring conservatives in an effort to stymie free speech and push a leftist agenda.

Nunes, who is currently suing Twitter in Virginia, claimed that the company has been the "worst" and that tech companies have gotten away with bias against conservatives for years due to a special "carveout" in federal law. He argued that tech companies have warped their products into pushing a certain ideology rather than being open platforms.

Nunes also stated that the solution to this problem would be "easiest" if tech companies went back to being open platforms on their own, but he does not have any confidence they will do so. He suggested that the easiest way to solve the issue is for tech companies to get out of the content development business and focus on policing their platforms for breaking federal or state laws.

Nunes also expressed skepticism about the Democrats' claims of regulating or holding tech companies accountable, calling it a "fake threat" meant to intimidate them into becoming subservient to the left's agenda. He believes that Democrats are trying to silence conservative voices and ensure that only left-leaning news sources are prioritized.

Given the current Democratic majority in the House of Representatives, Nunes stated that there is "nothing" that Congress can do to combat the tech giants until after the 2020 election. As a result, he is suing Twitter in a Virginia state court, seeking to hold the company accountable and put himself forward to do so, given that he has been the victim of smears, lies, fake accounts, and inaccurate attacks.

Nunes emphasized that the court system is the only way to solve this problem, and he believes that winning a defamation case would set the tech giants back. He also expressed hope that someone will develop a better search engine to counterbalance the dominance of Google.

Title: The New York Times Criticized for Using Partisan Smears to Undermine Hillary Clinton's Record on Women's Rights

The New York Times recently published an article that cast Hillary Clinton as "vulnerable" on the subject of gender, relying heavily on Republican criticisms to undermine her career-long advocacy for women's rights. The article focused on the Clinton Foundation's acceptance of donations from Middle Eastern countries known for gender discrimination, citing Republican attacks and criticisms from the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), the Republican National Committee (RNC), and a former White House ethics lawyer.

The article claimed that these donations present a "difficult appearance problem" for Clinton, who is running as a champion of women's aspirations to equality. However, the Times' own report undermines this suggestion, highlighting Clinton's long history of advocating for women's rights and leadership. The article noted that during her time as secretary of state, Clinton emphasized the importance of empowering women and girls, and that previous donations to the foundation have not stopped her from criticizing countries that discriminate against women.

The article also failed to mention that Clinton has consistently spoken out against countries that violate women's rights, including Saudi Arabia, despite receiving donations from those countries. The Times' own reporting contradicts the notion that Clinton's record on women's rights is questionable, and instead highlights her commitment to advancing women's empowerment and equality.

Title: Immigration Reform Stalemate: Enforcement Concerns and Discrepancies in Obama Administration's Claims

The debate over immigration reform in the United States has reached a stalemate, with the Senate passing a bill deemed unacceptable by the House due to concerns over amnesty, new immigration, and enforcement. The Republican majority in the House wants to tackle the issue piece by piece, starting with shoring up enforcement and border security.

According to metrics kept by the Department of Homeland Security, House Republicans have a legitimate point. Border Patrol Chief Michael Fisher recently disclosed that agents arrested 420,000 illegal border crossers in 2013, marking the second straight year of increases. This admission has upset Obama administration officials, who had not yet decided how to explain the contradiction between their claims that illegal immigration is a thing of the past and the actual numbers.

Enforcement in the interior has fallen off alarmingly in the last several years. Leaked internal statistics show that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents are arresting many fewer illegal aliens inside the country, and removals from the interior have declined more than 35% since 2009. Arrests declined in every part of the country, with the biggest drops in Georgia and the Carolinas, where 62% fewer illegal aliens were picked up.

Experts agree that the size of the illegal population has not budged much in several years, remaining around 11.5 million. However, it includes nearly 900,000 people who have been ordered removed at least once but refuse to leave because no one makes them.

The Obama administration's claims of "record" deportations and "smarter" enforcement have been called into question. Internal documents made public as part of a lawsuit by ICE officers against their own agency confirm that ICE has been padding its deportation numbers by taking credit for removing tens of thousands of illegal border crossers who were arrested by Border Patrol. These cases represented about half of all deportations in the "record" counts of the last two years.

This practice has allowed the administration to cover up plummeting interior arrests and give the false impression that they are vigorously enforcing immigration laws. In 2013, ICE agents encountered more than 700,000 aliens who could have been removed, but took action against fewer than 200,000, meaning that ICE is now releasing more illegal aliens, including criminal aliens, than it is arresting.

The administration's policies, known as "prosecutorial discretion," have created so many exceptions to the law that criminal removals have dropped too. In North Carolina alone, authorities have lost track of more than 3,000 illegal alien ex-cons that ICE failed to remove. Inevitably, they will find new victims.

The Obama administration's deliberate suppression of immigration enforcement has understandably chilled enthusiasm among House Republicans for a massive comprehensive bill. Instead, lawmakers should pass targeted measures to boost interior enforcement and restore credibility to the laws we have.

Title: Romney's Paradox: A Complex Figure in a Polarized Election

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate who lost the 2012 election to President Barack Obama, has been a paradox throughout his political career. On the surface, he appears to be a polished, technocratic politician with a moderate background in Massachusetts. However, his shift to the right during the election campaign has left many questioning his true political leanings.

Romney's journey began as a moderate Republican in Massachusetts, where he was known for his bipartisan approach. However, during the election campaign, he shifted his stance to the right, adopting a more conservative platform. This move was likely an attempt to appeal to the Republican base, which is predominantly conservative.

The Republican Party's dilemma lies in its own lack of ideological clarity. The party has a large base of conservative voters who are passionate about economic and social conservatism, but it also needs to appeal to moderates and independents who prefer more practical politics. Romney's challenge was to take the tea party agenda and rebrand it to appeal to both the right and the center. Unfortunately, he failed to achieve this goal.

Romney's campaign was marked by his business experience, which was seen as a major asset during the recession. His polished, gentle style was a contrast to Obama's flashy rhetoric, and his family was seen as wholesome and relatable. However, his speeches were often flat and lacked the passion and energy of his opponents.

Despite his flaws, Romney's performance in the first debate was impressive, and he regained control of the narrative. His ability to appeal to both the center and the right was a major factor in the election, but ultimately, the contradictions within both Romney and his party proved too great to overcome.

The outcome of the election was a victory for the incumbent, Obama, who won the support of the ambivalent American public. Romney's future plans are unclear, but it is possible that he may return to his church and dedicate himself to charity work.

Title: Turkey's Proposed Constitutional Amendments: A Shift Towards More Inclusive Politics?

Article:

As Turkey approaches its referendum on proposed constitutional amendments on April 16, both President and Prime Minister are intensifying their campaigns to persuade voters to support the changes. One of the key claims made by the "yes" camp is that the new system will force political parties to become more inclusive and appealing to a broader segment of the population. Under the current system, parties can form governments with as little as 20-30% of the public's support, but the proposed changes would require a presidential candidate to receive more than 50% of the votes, making it necessary for parties to reach out to a wider audience.

Experts argue that this change will alter Turkey's political culture, which has long been accustomed to short-lived coalition governments. According to İsmail Çağlar, director of public and media researches at the Foundation for Political, Economic and Social Research (SETA), the new system will force parties to form coalitions with other parties during elections to become more inclusive and appealing to a larger voter base.

The supporters of the proposed changes argue that Turkey has suffered from short-lived governments, with an average lifespan of about a year-and-a-half. The changes aim to abolish the prime minister's post and replace it with a stronger system, expected to produce stability and a more effective system of governance in the long term.

Prime Minister Binali Yıldırım emphasized that the proposed changes are not only beneficial for the AK Party but for all parties that aim to work and serve the people. He stated that the new system will pave the way for anyone who wants to work and struggle to win people's hearts, but will close the door to divisive, regional, or ethnicity-based parties.

Academic Yaşar Hacısalihoğlu from Yeni Yüzyıl University believes that the changes will lead to a more embracing political atmosphere, which will eliminate political polarization. He added that the new system will make representation more fair and equitable, addressing the needs of Turkey's socio-political dynamics emerging from its political diversity.

A recent survey by pollsters ANAR put the "yes" votes at 52%, while Konsensus put it at 51.2%. The number of undecided voters has fallen to 8%, leading to a 2 percentage point boost for the "yes" campaign since the beginning of March.

President Erdoğan emphasized that the new system will allow people to elect their governments without intermediaries, stating that April 16 will be a nightmare for those who want to form a government but serve only themselves instead of the people.

Title: Trump's Budget Director Pushes for Sanctuary Cities Restrictions in Spending Bill, Complicating Government Funding Talks

The Trump administration is urging congressional Republicans to include language restricting federal funding grants for cities that do not enforce federal immigration policies in a must-pass spending bill, according to officials from both parties. This move is complicating efforts to avoid a government shutdown at the end of the month.

Mick Mulvaney, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, is pushing lawmakers to include this language in the spending bill, which would aim to bring the House Freedom Caucus on board with a government funding bill. However, this effort is threatening to disrupt bipartisan negotiations on funding the government.

Democrats are already calling the request for border wall money a "poison pill" that would shut down the government, and an attempt to block liberal cities from receiving federal funds if they ignore immigration guidance would similarly cause Democrats to flee. The budget bill will need Democratic votes to pass, at least eight in the Senate and possibly in the House as well.

Senior Republicans and members of the Appropriations Committee are trying to keep Mulvaney's proposal out of the bill, fearing that Senate Democrats will filibuster any bill with this language and put Washington on a path toward a shutdown. In the House, a GOP leadership source said the sanctuary cities restriction would repel Democrats and force Speaker Paul Ryan to rely on House Freedom Caucus members to pass a funding bill.

The talks between congressional leaders are already delicate, with Trump wanting $1.4 billion for a border wall and security in the spending bill, but Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) saying his caucus won't support it. The Democratic leader reiterated his caucus's stance during a conference call with reporters on Tuesday.

Congress returns in two weeks and will have just five days to avert a shutdown before funding expires on April 28. The nation's decentralized process for grant-giving makes it difficult to say how much money would be at stake if Mulvaney's sanctuary cities proposal were adopted.

Title: Charges Dropped Against Man Accused of Sending Ricin-Laced Letters to Officials

A Mississippi man, Paul Kevin Curtis, has been cleared of charges after being accused of sending ricin-laced letters to President Barack Obama, Senator Roger Wicker, and Judge Sadie Holland. Curtis was arrested on April 17 and charged with sending a threat to the president after the letters triggered security scares around Washington.

According to Curtis, he is "overwhelmed" and "extremely happy to be vindicated" after being cleared of the charges. Authorities are now investigating whether someone may have tried to frame him, with a law enforcement source stating that new information has become available.

Curtis's attorney, Christi McCoy, believes that someone familiar with Curtis used his personal information to frame him. McCoy stated that Curtis was "absolutely horrified" by the situation and that it is "horrific" that someone could be framed so easily.

The letters, which were sent to the officials with a Memphis, Tennessee, postmark and no return address, contained the phrase "I am KC and I approve this message," which Curtis uses on social media. The FBI had initially identified the substance in the letters as ricin, a toxin derived from castor beans with no known antidote. However, no illnesses were reported as a result of exposure to the toxin.

The charges against Curtis were dropped due to new information becoming available, according to U.S. Attorney Felicia Adams. Curtis has been released from custody and is now able to see his children again.

Title: Trump's Actions Undermine Constitutional Principles

The article discusses the concerns of conservatives who initially supported Donald Trump's presidency, citing his promise to appoint justices who would strictly adhere to the Constitution. However, Trump's actions have raised questions about his commitment to the nation's founding document. The article highlights several instances where Trump has disregarded constitutional principles, including his criticism of the press, his threat to punish NBC News, and his stance on libel laws.

The article also notes that Trump has held up the late Justice Antonin Scalia as his model, who believed in a "dead Constitution" that does not evolve over time. However, Trump's actions suggest that he has a different understanding of the Constitution, as he has shown disregard for the First Amendment and the freedom of the press.

The article concludes that Trump's empty threat to punish NBC News for allegedly inaccurate reporting is a betrayal of the principles of press freedom, which extends to broadcast news media. It also notes that Trump's stance on libel laws is at odds with the Supreme Court's decision in 1964, which protects citizens from being punished for inadvertent misstatements.

The article also highlights Trump's other actions that undermine constitutional principles, including his travel ban targeting Muslims, his rejection of a Justice Department report on police brutality, and his support for police brutality. The article concludes that Trump's supporters who feared a liberal Supreme Court would damage constitutional rights have instead gotten a president who prefers to damage them immediately.

Title: Israel's Airstrike in Syria Sparks Concerns Over Regional Tensions

Article:

Former New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson and former Senator Jim DeMint, both appearing on ABC's "This Week," expressed concerns over the recent Israeli airstrike in Syria, which targeted a shipment of missiles from Iran to Hezbollah. Richardson described the situation as "very, very tense" and predicted that the US president may opt for a limited military option in the coming days.

DeMint, a conservative, criticized the president's handling of the Syrian conflict, stating that the administration's indecisiveness has destabilized the region and brought Israel into the conflict. He referenced the president's earlier statement about a "red line" regarding the use of chemical weapons, which has become a sticking point for the White House.

Richardson noted that increasing signs of British and French support for the Syrian rebels could pave the way for some kind of American intervention. However, DeMint emphasized that the focus should be on Iran and its potential weapons distribution to Israel's enemies, rather than the Syrian conflict itself.

The Israeli airstrike, which occurred early Sunday, is seen as a signal to Iran, Hezbollah, and possibly the US that the situation in the region is escalating. The strike targeted a shipment of missiles from Iran to Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group, and reports suggest that forces loyal to Syrian President Bashar Assad are using chemical weapons on their own people.

Title: Romney's CEO Core: A Businessman's Approach to Politics

Article:

Mitt Romney's political opponents have labeled him a "man without a core" and a "flip-flopper" due to his shifting positions on various issues. However, Dean Obeidallah argues that Romney's core is not that of a politician, but rather that of a CEO. As a businessman, Romney's success is measured by the bottom line, not by how many principles he sticks to.

According to Obeidallah, a CEO is not bound by ideology, but by the ability to sell a product. If a product is not selling, a CEO will modify it to appeal to customers. Romney, as a businessman, has taken a similar approach to politics. He has tweaked his views to appeal to different audiences, rather than sticking to a rigid ideology.

Romney's views on issues such as abortion and gun control have changed over time, but this does not necessarily mean he is a flip-flopper. Rather, he has modified his "product line" to appeal to different customers. For example, during his 1994 Senate campaign, Romney was pro-choice, but during his 2012 presidential campaign, he shifted to support the reversal of Roe v. Wade.

Romney's ability to adapt his views to appeal to different audiences is a testament to his business acumen. As a CEO, he knows that the customer is always right, and he is willing to modify his product to meet their demands. This approach may be seen as pragmatic by some, but it also raises questions about the sincerity of his political views.

Ultimately, whether or not Romney's CEO core is a positive or negative trait depends on one's perspective. Some may see it as a refreshing change from the typical politician, while others may view it as a lack of conviction. Regardless, Romney's approach to politics is a unique blend of business acumen and political savvy.

Title: Ferguson Businesses Suffer Financial Blow Amid Ongoing Unrest

Ferguson, Missouri - The ongoing protests and civil unrest in Ferguson have taken a significant toll on the city's small businesses. In the 10 days since Michael Brown's shooting, store owners have reported a major financial blow due to looting, vandalism, and property damage. Many businesses have been forced to board up their storefronts, with some even being burned down.

Looters and vandals have smashed windows, spray-painted graffiti, stolen property, and damaged businesses. Some stores have reopened with plywood covering their broken windows, with signs reading "Open for Business" and "Black Owned" in an attempt to deter looters. However, many customers are too afraid to venture into the area, causing a significant decline in business.

Small business owners are struggling to cope with the financial losses, with some reporting a 70% decline in customers. Sonny Dayan, owner of a cell phone store, expressed concerns about the uncertainty and unpredictability of the situation. "You just don't know what to expect. Is there going to be another break-in? Is there going to be another one?" he said.

A medical facility owner, who wished to remain anonymous, shared similar concerns about the financial impact of the unrest. "Our patients are canceling left and right because they don't want to come on our street," she said. "It's affecting our bottom line for the past week. We're going on the eighth day now."

Business owners are also worried about the potential for insurance companies to deny claims due to the "social unrest" clause in their policies. "I have the best insurance, but I heard rumors they may try to play the social unrest card and say that I'm not covered," said Dayan.

The medical facility owner echoed these concerns, stating that several businesses have checked their insurance policies and found that they are not covered for damages related to riots. "So it's not enough that we've suffered for nine days and lost about 70 percent of our business and can't pay our rent and can't get anybody here to help us. So what else can we observe here as small business owners?" she asked.

The ongoing unrest in Ferguson has left many small business owners feeling frustrated and uncertain about their future.

Title: White House Confirms President Trump Has No Intention to Fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller

The White House has reiterated that President Trump has no intention to fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller, according to a statement released by Trump's attorney, Ty Cobb, on Sunday. This confirmation comes amid ongoing speculation and questions from the media about the possibility of Trump firing Mueller.

In a series of tweets, Trump expressed his frustration with the ongoing investigation, stating that the Mueller probe was based on fraudulent activities and a "Fake Dossier" paid for by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton. Trump also questioned the integrity of former FBI Director James Comey and FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe.

Trump's personal lawyer, Joseph Dowd, issued a statement calling for an end to the investigation, citing the "brilliant and courageous example" of the FBI Office of Professional Responsibility and Attorney General Jeff Sessions. However, Rep. Trey Gowdy, chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, criticized Dowd's statement, saying it "does the president a disservice."

Several lawmakers from both sides of the political aisle have also warned Trump against firing Mueller, with Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) stating that it would be the "beginning of the end of his presidency."

Title: New York City's Contact Tracing Force Not Asking About Protest Attendance

New York City's contact-tracing force is not actively asking individuals who test positive for COVID-19 if they recently attended a Black Lives Matter demonstration, according to a city spokesperson. Avery Cohen, a spokesperson for Mayor Bill de Blasio, confirmed that tracers are not proactively asking about protest attendance, but individuals who test positive are free to volunteer this information if they choose to do so.

The city's contact tracing program, which aims to hire 1,000 tracers, is designed to ask those who test positive for COVID-19 to recall their contacts and individuals they may have exposed, as well as anyone who has been within six feet of the infected person for at least 10 minutes. The goal is to identify and isolate individuals who may have been exposed to the virus.

New York City officials have taken a cautious approach regarding the potential impact of mass protests on the spread of COVID-19. Mark Levine, head of the city council's health committee, has emphasized that if there is a spike in coronavirus cases in the next two weeks, it should not be attributed to protesters. Mayor de Blasio, whose daughter was arrested during a Manhattan protest over the death of George Floyd, has faced criticism for allowing protests to proceed while restricting religious services. However, he has pushed back against claims of hypocrisy, stating that the situation is not comparable to the understandable concerns of store owners and religious individuals who want to resume their activities.

Title: Republican Attempts to Insert Abortion Restrictions into Coronavirus Relief Bill Cause Controversy

Article:

A potential deal on a coronavirus rescue package, which includes paid sick leave and free virus testing, hit a roadblock as Republican attempts to insert anti-choice restrictions into the House's relief bill sparked controversy. The proposed legislation would have effectively overturned the Hyde Amendment, a decades-old provision that blocks federal funds from going to abortion services, affecting millions of low-income Americans on Medicaid.

Conservative media reported that some top Republicans believed a stipulation in the House bill requiring the government to reimburse private laboratories doing coronavirus testing could establish a government funding stream not subject to the restrictions. In response, anti-choice lawmakers insisted on including language in the legislation that would reaffirm the principles of the amendment.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell accused House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of turning the legislation into an "ideological wish list" instead of focusing on immediate relief to affected individuals, families, and businesses. However, it is often Republicans who use unrelated legislation as a vehicle for their anti-abortion agenda.

This is not the first time Republicans have used legislation tied to public health emergencies to push for anti-abortion measures. During the Zika virus outbreak in 2016, anti-choice lawmakers added a caveat blocking Planned Parenthood health care providers from accessing emergency funds. Similarly, they tried to wedge anti-abortion provisions into Trump's 2017 tax plan, which included fetal personhood language and defined "unborn child" as any "child in utero."

Abortion restrictions have been a sticking point in spending bills, with both parties using them to push for policies they are having trouble advancing by other means. In 2018, the White House pushed Republicans in Congress to slip measures that threatened to cut federal funding to Planned Parenthood into a bill to prevent the third government shutdown of the year.

In contrast, the current coronavirus rescue package focuses on providing unemployment benefits and free testing to prevent the further spread of the virus and ensure low-wage workers can afford necessities like food, rent, and healthcare. These measures have no direct connection to abortion and are urgent health matters that require swift action from elected officials.

Title: Virginia Republican Nominee Accuses Civil Rights Establishment of Selling Out Christian Values

Article:

E.W. Jackson, a black minister and activist, has been nominated as the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor of Virginia. In a four-minute video posted on YouTube, Jackson accused the "civil rights establishment" of selling out their Christian values by supporting Democratic policy positions on gay marriage and abortion. He also compared Planned Parenthood to the Ku Klux Klan, stating that the organization has been more lethal to black lives than the KKK ever was.

In the video, Jackson claimed that the Democratic Party has created an alliance between certain civil rights leaders and Planned Parenthood, which has resulted in the deaths of millions of unborn black babies. He also described abortion as an "idolatrous offering to the god of'sexual license'." The website of his advocacy group, Staying True to America's National Destiny, further elaborates on this point, comparing abortion to the ancient pagan practice of offering children as sacrifices to ensure good fortune.

The emergence of Jackson as a prominent figure in the Republican Party may have implications beyond the lieutenant governor's race. Republican gubernatorial candidate Ken Cuccinelli has focused his campaign on jobs and economic concerns, while Democrats have criticized him for his conservative stance on abortion and gay rights. The selection of Jackson as the GOP candidate may keep social issues in the forefront of the 2013 debate.

The comments about Planned Parenthood are particularly incendiary, as the organization recently ran web ads against Cuccinelli and the Democratic Party of Virginia produced robo-calls accusing him of pursuing an "ideological tea party agenda that bans abortion." A Jackson adviser did not respond to requests for comment, while Republican Party of Virginia spokesman Garren Shipley defended the candidate as a person of faith and predicted that the 2013 elections would focus on economic issues rather than social policy.

Title: Brett Kavanaugh Accuser Julie Swetnick Describes Him as "Mean Drunk" Who Pushed Girls Against Walls

Article:

Julie Swetnick, the third woman to accuse Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct during his teenage years, described him as a "mean drunk" who pushed girls against walls during her first televised interview. In an interview with NBC News' Kate Snow, Swetnick also called Kavanaugh a "liar" for dismissing her allegations against him.

Swetnick's allegations were made in a sworn statement signed under penalty of perjury and released through her attorney, Michael Avenatti. In her statement, she alleged that Kavanaugh preyed on young women, but she did not accuse him of assaulting her. During the interview, Swetnick did not provide any new information that corroborated her allegations, but she did describe Kavanaugh's behavior as "aggressive" and "sloppy drunk."

Swetnick also strayed from her sworn statement during the interview, admitting she did not know if Kavanaugh and his friend Mark Judge would "spike" the punch at house parties in the early 1980s to cause girls to lose their inhibitions and their ability to say "no." She described seeing Kavanaugh push girls against walls and try to get too physically close to them.

Kavanaugh has denied Swetnick's allegations, calling them "ridiculous" and "from the Twilight Zone." During his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, he denied the allegations made by Christine Blasey Ford, Deborah Ramirez, and Swetnick.

NBC News was unable to confirm Swetnick's allegations, as four people she named as attending the parties did not respond or recall the events. Swetnick's attorney, Michael Avenatti, claimed to have multiple witnesses who could corroborate her story, but did not provide any additional information.

The FBI is currently investigating Kavanaugh's background, and President Donald Trump has expressed support for his Supreme Court pick. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has announced that the full Senate will vote on Kavanaugh's nomination this week.

Title: Senate Begins Debate on Immigration Reform Bill, With Amendments Piling Up

The Senate has officially brought the immigration reform bill to the floor, marking the first time since 2007 that the full issue has been debated in Congress. The bill, worked out by the bipartisan "Gang of Eight" senators, offers illegal immigrants quick legalization, but withholds the full path to citizenship until the government spends more money on border security, creates a new verification system to check workers, and begins to track entries and exits at airports and seaports.

Lawmakers have filed 44 amendments to the 1,075-page bill, including potential "poison pills" to grant immigration benefits to American citizens' gay partners and to make illegal immigrants wait until the borders are deemed secure before they can get any legal status. Other contentious proposals include setting the level for guest-workers who would be allowed into the country to compete for jobs, and whether to make English the official language of the U.S.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has warned that he will allow some latitude for amendments but will have little patience for those trying to undercut the bill rather than working sincerely to improve it. Reid's heavy hand in controlling amendments helped derail a 2007 immigration bill.

Sen. Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican and part of the Gang of Eight, said the legislation needs stiffer border security, better checks of visitors entering and leaving the country, and more stringent English-language requirements. Rubio introduced an amendment to strike the option for immigrants to enroll in English classes, saying it is a loophole.

Other amendments include Sen. James M. Inhofe's proposal to let businesses declare English-only policies in their workplaces and another to make English the official language of the U.S. Designating the official language polls exceptionally well with voters, but proved to be contentious when Congress debated immigration reform in 2006 and 2007.

The 82-15 vote to head off a filibuster marked an auspicious start for this year's debate. In a similar vote in 2007, supporters got just 69 votes. The difference this year is that far more Republicans are eager to at least hold the debate, with many feeling that their political futures depend on finding a way to reach out to Hispanic voters who view the immigration issue as a litmus test.

The focus will now be on about 20 Republicans who voted to begin the debate but who are likely to want to see major changes before they support the final product. Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky said the legislation has "serious flaws" and will need more assurances on border security and taxpayer benefits for newly legalized illegal immigrants.

Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, Vermont Democrat, introduced an amendment to grant immigration benefits to partners in states that perform same-sex marriages, saying it is the right thing to do. Leahy made a similar move in the Senate Judiciary Committee last month but withdrew the amendment at the last moment.

Title: Democrats' Memo on Trump-Russia Dossier Omissions Raises Questions

The House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence has released a memo claiming to refute the allegations of FBI and Justice Department abuse in obtaining a spy warrant on former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page in 2016. However, the Democratic memo has been criticized for omitting several key points, which were highlighted by the Republican memo.

The Democratic memo failed to address the testimony of former FBI Deputy Director Andy McCabe, who stated that the FISA warrant would not have been sought without the infamous Trump-Russia dossier. McCabe's testimony was a crucial point in the Republican memo. While Democratic California Rep. Eric Swalwell claimed that Republicans had mischaracterized McCabe's testimony, the Democrats did not directly refute this claim in their own memo.

The Republican rebuttal to the Democratic memo pointed out several omissions, including the fact that the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton campaign paid for the Steele dossier, which formed a significant portion of the Carter Page FISA application. The memo also failed to acknowledge that this information was not provided to the FISA Court.

The Republican rebuttal also highlighted the omission of the fact that the FBI failed to inform the Court that Steele provided information to Yahoo News, which was part of the FISA application. Michael Isikoff, the author of the Yahoo News article, has publicly confirmed that Steele was a source for the article about Page.

Additionally, the Republican memo claimed that the Democratic memo paints an incomplete picture of Page's past activities and omits the fact that a Russian intelligence officer called Page "an idiot" in a secretly-taped statement reproduced in a 2015 federal court filing.

The controversy surrounding the FISA warrant and the Trump-Russia dossier continues to raise questions about the handling of intelligence and the accuracy of the information presented to the FISA Court.

Title: Gas Prices Continue to Fall, Reaching Below $1.42 in Some Areas

Gas prices in the United States have been steadily decreasing, with some stations already selling regular gasoline for less than $1.42 per gallon. According to AAA and GasBuddy, two organizations that track gasoline prices, it's not uncommon for prices to drop below $2 in most areas. As oil prices continue to fall and refinery capacity remains strong, some experts predict that gas prices could reach $1 per gallon in some areas, a level not seen since 1999.

The entire states of Alabama, Arkansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, and South Carolina have average gas prices at or below $1.75 per gallon. The four main factors driving gasoline prices are oil prices, proximity to refineries, refinery capacity, and state taxes and levies.

Oil prices have dropped below $33 per barrel and continue to decline, with the recent decision by Saudi Arabia to maintain its oil exports high dissolving the OPEC cartel. This has led to an oversupply of crude oil, which is expected to continue. Additionally, slowing national economies in large countries like China will lower demand, as China has surpassed the United States as the world's largest oil importer.

The cost of producing oil from shale deposits, particularly in the United States, is often higher than the current market price, leading some producers to continue pumping, while others go bankrupt. Several states have large refineries or are close to those that do, with some refineries in the Gulf of Mexico, such as those owned by Exxon Mobil Corp., processing hundreds of thousands of barrels per day. Proximity to refineries is a factor in gasoline prices, as refineries running at or near capacity produce gasoline instead of other petroleum products.

Finally, gas taxes in some states are below the national average of $0.4869 per gallon, according to the American Petroleum Institute. States like South Carolina, Missouri, and Oklahoma have gas taxes below $0.40 per gallon, which compounds the effect of falling oil prices.

As the odds of gas prices reaching $1 per gallon in some areas continue to grow, particularly in areas where prices are already close to $1.40, it's clear that the current trend is likely to continue.

Title: President Obama Naturalizes 25 Active-Duty Service Members, Highlights Immigration Reform

President Barack Obama celebrated the Fourth of July by naturalizing 25 active-duty service members, using the occasion to emphasize his recent executive order to spare hundreds of thousands from deportation and urge lawmakers to pass a comprehensive immigration overhaul. The ceremony took place in the East Room of the White House, where Homeland Security Secretary Janet A. Napolitano swore in the new citizens.

In his remarks, Obama congratulated the individuals and their families, highlighting the importance of immigration and the country's history as a nation of immigrants. He stressed that America is a country bound together by its ideas and values, rather than ethnicity or bloodlines. The President also praised the group of service members for choosing to serve the country "that was not yet fully their own" during a time of war.

Obama called on Congress to pass the Dream Act, which would grant citizenship to certain illegal immigrants who arrived in the US as children and remain in good moral standing. He also emphasized the need for a comprehensive overhaul of the nation's immigration laws. The President's remarks came after he bypassed Congress in mid-June and issued a directive allowing potentially over 800,000 young people to remain in the US without the risk of deportation.

The move was seen as a politically charged decision, as Obama faces a tough re-election fight against likely Republican nominee Mitt Romney. Romney has said he would veto the Dream Act and favors a path to citizenship only for illegal immigrant young adults who join the military. Hours after Obama's announcement, Romney stated that the move could make it harder to find a long-term fix to the immigration issue.

The article also mentions that Obama and the first family planned to spend the afternoon and evening with military families at a USO concert on the White House's South Lawn, featuring country music star Brad Paisley and the Marine Corps Band. The President will also embark on a two-day "Betting on America" tour, while Romney will spend the week with his family at their lakeside home in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire.

Title: Fed's Potential Winding Down of Asset Purchases Raises Concerns for Economic Recovery

The recent jobs report showing a gain of 195,000 jobs in June has sparked concerns about the Federal Reserve's potential winding down of its asset purchases, which could have significant implications for the economic recovery. The report, released by the Labor Department, indicates that the economy is moving ahead at a modest pace, but some experts warn that the Fed's actions could have far-reaching consequences.

The Fed's asset purchases, which have been in place since 2008, have helped boost the economy by keeping interest rates low and encouraging borrowing and spending. However, if the Fed starts winding down these purchases as early as September, it could lead to higher interest rates and potentially tip the economy back into recession.

Economists are divided on the issue, with some arguing that the economy is strong enough to withstand the Fed's actions and others warning that it could be a major mistake. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which is the benchmark for home loans and credit cards, has already spiked over 2.7 percent, indicating investor concerns about the potential impact of the Fed's actions.

The Fed's actions have become increasingly important in recent years, as the traditional drivers of economic growth, such as business investment and higher wages, have been absent. The jobs report showed wages rising 10 cents to $24.01, with hourly earnings up 2.2 percent over the year, which is not likely to survive higher interest rates.

The jobs being created are also not the kind that tend to drive a robust economy, with the leisure, hospitality, and retail industries adding 112,000 jobs in June, while professional and business services added just 53,000. The average workweek was unchanged at 34.5 hours, suggesting employers do not see much need to boost production.

The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 7.6 percent, and the number of workers who want full-time jobs but were only employed part-time surged by 322,000 to 8.2 million, which some attribute to employers declining to hire workers full-time in order to avoid the mandate to provide coverage under President Barack Obama's health reform law.

The Fed's potential winding down of its asset purchases will be closely watched in the coming months, as it could have significant implications for the economy and the 2014 midterms and 2016 general election.

Title: Wisconsin's Public Employee Union Law: A Decade of Decline and Stagnant Wages

The passage of Wisconsin's public employee union law in 2011, which restricted collective bargaining rights and limited union membership, has had a profound impact on the state's labor landscape. The law, championed by Governor Scott Walker, aimed to weaken the electoral muscle of the main opposition to his conservative agenda. However, the unintended consequence has been a decline in public employee union membership and stagnant wages for middle-class workers.

According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, union membership in Wisconsin has fallen to 11.7%, down from 16% 10 years ago. The Wisconsin affiliate of the National Education Association has seen a 33% decline, while the American Federation of Teachers has dropped by 50%. The state employees union has seen a 70% decline.

The decline in union membership has led to a decrease in public employee numbers, with the ratio of public employees to total population at its lowest level in at least two decades. The Wisconsin Budget Project found that the ratio of public employees to total population is at its lowest level in at least two decades.

The decline in union membership has also led to a decrease in wages for middle-class workers. According to the Census Bureau's American Community Survey, median household income in Wisconsin is $51,467 a year, nearly $800 below the national average. The Bureau of Economic Analysis puts Wisconsin in the middle of the pack on earnings growth, despite a fairly tight labor market with a headline unemployment rate of 5.2%.

The decline in wages has been particularly pronounced for public employees, who lost the equivalent of 8-10% in take-home pay due to increased contributions to healthcare and pension benefits. The meager earnings growth that has come to Wisconsin has mostly gone to the top 1% of earners, according to a Wisconsin Budget Project report.

The trends mirror those in the country at large, where labor has similarly stumbled. Real hourly wages fell for almost everyone nationwide in 2014, except for the low-wage sector, bolstered by minimum wage increases at the state and local level. Wisconsin has not joined that movement, with its minimum wage still consistent with the federal floor, at $7.25 an hour.

The decline in union membership and stagnant wages has real consequences for middle-class workers. The erosion of collective bargaining is the single largest factor suppressing wage growth for middle-wage workers over the last few decades, according to Larry Mishel, a labor economist. The decline in union membership has also led to a decrease in public employee numbers, with the ratio of public employees to total population at its lowest level in at least two decades.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of worker voices in wage growth. The decline in union membership has taken away the voice of public employees, and effectively the entire Wisconsin labor movement, which finds itself crippled. The article warns that if Governor Walker's anti-union policies are adopted nationwide, it could have devastating consequences for middle-class wages.

Title: Trump's Language and Leadership: A Case Study in Ineffectiveness

The recent events in Syria have highlighted the consequences of President Trump's unconventional communication style and its impact on international diplomacy. Trump has consistently dismissed criticism of his language as "tone-policing" and has described his approach as "MODERN DAY PRESIDENTIAL." However, his blunt style has been met with skepticism and disregard by world leaders, including Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.

The recent invasion of northern Syria by Turkey, despite warnings from the United States, serves as a stark example of the ineffectiveness of Trump's language. Erdoğan reportedly snickered and dismissed a strongly worded letter from the President, demonstrating a lack of respect for American leadership. The situation has resulted in the withdrawal of American troops, the bombing of U.S. munitions dumps, and reports of atrocities in the fighting.

The visit of Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to Ankara is an attempt to revive old-fashioned diplomacy and negotiate a cease-fire. However, Erdoğan's recent statement that "we will never declare a cease-fire" suggests that the situation may be too far gone. The failure of the diplomatic efforts would demonstrate the ineffectiveness of Trump's personal approach, while a successful outcome would be a rare instance of his unconventional style yielding positive results.

In the meantime, Trump's comments about the situation have been met with skepticism. His statement that "they've got a lot of sand over there, so there's a lot of sand that they can play with" has been seen as flippant and unhelpful. It is unclear what world leaders can expect from a president who does not seem to take his words seriously.

Title: Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith Apologizes for Comments on Public Hanging

Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith, a Republican candidate running for re-election in the U.S. Senate, apologized for her comments about attending a public hanging, which were captured in a video posted online. The video shows Hyde-Smith saying, "If he invited me to a public hanging, I'd be on the front row" during a November 2 event alongside cattle rancher Colin Hutchinson, a supporter of the senator.

Hyde-Smith made the comment in response to Hutchinson praising her, and the supporters around them laughed. The exchange was tweeted by Lamar White Jr. and quickly went viral. When asked about the comment during a debate on Tuesday night, Hyde-Smith apologized, stating that there was "no ill will, no intent whatsoever" behind her statement.

Hyde-Smith also mentioned that she is close to Hutchinson, whose parents died of cancer when he was in high school. She also recalled using another phrase that day, saying she would fight a circle saw for Hutchinson. However, she clarified that she would not actually participate in such an activity.

After apologizing, Hyde-Smith accused the Espy campaign of using her comments for "political gain." Espy, the Democratic candidate running against Hyde-Smith, responded by saying that the comments came directly from Hyde-Smith's mouth and that the video went viral "around the world" within three minutes.

Title: Family Rift: Woman Considers Cutting In-Laws Out of Her Children's Lives Due to Political Differences

A recent op-ed published by a Huffington Post contributor, Hannah Selinger, has sparked a heated debate about the impact of political differences on family relationships. Selinger, who is considering removing her children's grandparents from their lives, argues that the grandparents' conservative views and support for President Donald Trump are damaging to her children's well-being.

Selinger's article, "It Might Be Time to Cut My Right-Wing, Trump-Loving In-Laws Out of My Kids' Lives," highlights several instances where she feels her in-laws' behavior and beliefs have been hurtful and intolerant. She claims they have made offensive comments, such as her father-in-law's reaction to a same-sex kiss on TV and his criticism of a movie featuring an impoverished black drug dealer. Selinger also notes that her in-laws have expressed problematic views on abortion and have shown no concern for the treatment of migrant children at the US-Mexico border.

Selinger believes that her children's exposure to these beliefs and behaviors could have a negative impact on their development and well-being. She argues that it is her responsibility as a parent to protect her children from harm and ensure they grow up with a strong sense of empathy and understanding.

Selinger's husband is reportedly more hesitant to cut his parents out of their lives, citing a sense of disappointment and frustration with his mother's inability to understand and accept their values. The couple is currently putting off making a decision about the fate of their family relationships, but Selinger is adamant that she will do what is best for her children.

The article has sparked a lively discussion about the challenges of navigating political differences within families and the importance of protecting children from harm. While Selinger's decision is not an easy one, she believes it is necessary to ensure her children grow up in a safe and supportive environment.

Title: Trump's First Year: A Mixed Bag of Progress and Concerns

The first year of Donald Trump's presidency has been marked by a mix of progress and concerns. While some of his policies have been successful, such as the defeat of the ISIS caliphate and the passage of a tax reform bill, others have been controversial, like his travel ban and response to the Charlottesville violence. Trump's associates, including Steve Bannon and Michael Flynn, have also been involved in scandals and have been forced to leave their positions.

Despite these concerns, many conservatives have been pleased with Trump's presidency, citing his commitment to conservative values and his willingness to challenge the status quo. However, others have been disappointed by his lack of experience and his tendency to make impulsive decisions.

As the midterm elections approach, Trump's character and policies will continue to be scrutinized. While some of his policies have been successful, his character and associates have been a source of concern.

Title: Barclays Agrees to Pay $450 Million to Settle Rate-Manipulation Claims, Amid Controversy Over Political Donations

Article:

Barclays, a British bank, has agreed to pay $450 million to settle accusations that it attempted to manipulate interest rates to benefit its financial performance. The settlement comes as the bank's executives are facing scrutiny over their political donations, particularly to Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney.

Eleven members of Parliament recently signed a resolution calling on Barclays executives to cease fundraising for political candidates and focus on rebuilding consumer confidence in the banking system. The resolution was sparked by the bank's role in the interest rate manipulation scandal, which has led to the resignation of its CEO, Bob Diamond.

Romney's campaign has received significant donations from Barclays employees, with $234,650 contributed through the end of May. However, the Obama campaign has also received donations from Barclays employees, with $34,800 contributed to date. The Obama campaign has a policy prohibiting registered lobbyists from bundling donations for his campaign.

The controversy surrounding Barclays' political donations has raised questions about the potential influence of big banks on the political process. The bank's executives have been accused of using their connections to raise funds for Romney's campaign, which has led to concerns about the potential for conflicts of interest.

Despite the controversy, Romney's campaign has taken precautions to ensure that donors are U.S. citizens, with an invitation to one of the London fund-raisers reminding guests that they "must provide a copy of U.S. passport." However, the timing of the controversy may still detract from Romney's trip to London, where he will attend the opening ceremonies of the 2012 Olympics.

The controversy has also raised questions about the role of big banks in the political process, with some critics arguing that their influence can be used to shape policy and undermine regulation. The Dodd-Frank Act, which was passed in response to the 2008 financial crisis, has been a target of criticism from Romney, who has argued that it is too burdensome and ineffective.

In a statement, a Romney campaign spokesperson declined to comment on the controversy. The Obama campaign also declined to comment.

Title: Funeral Procession for Iranian General Qassem Soleimani Marred by Deadly Crush, Injuries

A funeral procession for Iranian General Qassem Soleimani, the head of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps-Quds Force, turned deadly on Tuesday, with reports indicating that up to 40 people were killed and hundreds injured. The incident occurred in Soleimani's hometown of Kerman, according to an emergency services official quoted by Iran's semiofficial Fars news agency.

Soleimani was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Americans, and the U.S. State Department confirmed that he was coordinating attacks on U.S. personnel. The State Department stated that Soleimani had been traveling in the Middle East, coordinating imminent large-scale attacks against U.S. diplomats and service members, which were deemed highly credible and supported by intelligence.

The Defense Department also released a statement, saying that Soleimani was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region. The statement added that Soleimani and his Quds Force were responsible for the deaths of hundreds of American and coalition service members and the wounding of thousands more.

In response to Soleimani's death, President Trump tweeted that the general had killed or wounded thousands of Americans over an extended period and was plotting to kill many more. Trump also stated that Soleimani was both hated and feared within Iran and should have been taken out many years ago.

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei openly cried during Soleimani's funeral, uttering an emotional prayer. The funeral procession showcased the depth of the bond between Khamenei and Soleimani and could impact how Khamenei responds to the United States.

The incident highlights the complex and sensitive situation between the U.S. and Iran, with both sides exchanging accusations and threats. The U.S. has stated that the strike that killed Soleimani was aimed at deterring future Iranian attack plans, while Iran has vowed to take revenge.

Title: Former National Security Advisor Flynn Reportedly Prepared to Testify Against Trump and Transition Officials

Former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn has reportedly agreed to cooperate with special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. According to ABC News, Flynn has promised full cooperation and is prepared to testify against President Donald Trump, members of the Trump family, and others in the White House. Flynn is expected to testify that President Trump, as a president-elect, directed him to make contact with Russian officials, contradicting Trump's previous denials.

Flynn pleaded guilty in federal court on Friday to making false statements to the FBI, a felony, as part of an agreement with the special counsel's office. The guilty plea and agreement to cooperate with the investigation are reportedly the result of mounting legal bills and intense pressure from prosecutors.

According to Flynn's Statement of Offense, Trump transition officials directed him to reach out to Russian officials and officials from other countries during the presidential transition. Flynn stated that his guilty plea and agreement to cooperate with the special counsel's office were made in the best interests of his family and the country.

ABC News reported that Flynn made the decision to cooperate with Mueller only in the past 24 hours, and is said to be distraught about the decision, but feels he is doing the right thing for his country.

Title: The Politicization of Judicial Nominations: A Legacy of Division

Article:

The death of Justice Antonin Scalia has sparked a renewed focus on the politicization of judicial nominations, a trend that has overshadowed his own legacy. Scalia, the longest-serving justice in the Supreme Court's history, was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1986. At the time, the process of judicial confirmations was vastly different from today. Presidents were granted significant deference on appointments, and Senate rejection of Supreme Court nominees was rare.

Scalia's own confirmation was a testament to this era of comity. He won a 98-0 vote in the Senate, becoming the first Italian-American to sit on the Supreme Court. However, this was the last gasp of comity in judicial nominations. The appointment of Robert Bork in 1987 marked a turning point, as Democrats rallied against him due to his role in the "Saturday Night Massacre" and his views on privacy. Bork's nomination ultimately failed, and he resigned from the DC Circuit in protest.

The politicization of judicial nominations has continued to escalate since then. Democrats attempted to humiliate Clarence Thomas, but failed to defeat his nomination. Republicans delayed or blocked Bill Clinton's judicial appointments, and Democrats responded with delays during the Bush years. The trend has continued, with both parties using judicial nominations as a political tool.

The death of Justice Scalia has highlighted the breakdown of the legal and political process. Republicans have adopted Chuck Schumer's 2007 stance, refusing to consider any Supreme Court nominations during President Obama's term. Democrats, meanwhile, have forgotten that the Senate has no obligation to approve nominees and that it was Democrats who were largely responsible for dispensing with deference to elected presidents in judicial appointments.

Several stopgap solutions have been proposed to address the impasse, including a recess appointment of a retired Supreme Court justice or an open seat that would allow for compromise. However, these solutions are unlikely to work in a system where both sides lack a basic understanding of constitutional prerogatives.

Scalia's legacy is complex and multifaceted, and his impact on American jurisprudence may take several more decades to be fully appreciated. However, his death has highlighted the need for a return to a more civil and respectful process of judicial nominations.

Title: Elizabeth Warren's Campaign Receives Support from Dark Money Group in Florida

Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign received a significant boost in Florida after a dark money group, New Florida Majority, disbursed $101,345 to support her candidacy. The nonprofit, which does not disclose its donors, spent the funds on canvassing and advertisements to promote Warren's campaign. This development marks a reversal of Warren's stance on dark money, as her campaign had previously asked a dark money group to halt its support for her in Iowa.

New Florida Majority, a progressive social justice nonprofit, endorsed Warren late last year, stating its readiness to mobilize constituents in support of her plans for "big structural change." The group's executive director, Andrea Mercado, emphasized the importance of defeating Trump and his agenda, saying, "The stakes are too high for millions of Floridians in 2020. We're prepared to support whoever the candidate is to defeat Trump and his agenda of inequality and division."

New Florida Majority has a history of political activism, having played a key role in the 2018 elections. The group was part of the Win Justice campaign, a coalition of liberal groups that focused on battleground states like Florida, Michigan, and Nevada. The campaign was initially bankrolled by a $3 million check from liberal billionaire George Soros and received additional funding from other liberal donors, including billionaire megadonor Donald Sussman, director Steven Spielberg, and his wife Kate Capshaw.

New Florida Majority's goal is to register 100,000 new voters for the 2020 elections. Last week, the group held a joint press conference with the Florida Democratic Party and two other activist organizations, boasting that the groups have registered tens of thousands of Floridians as Democrats. The Florida primary is scheduled for March 17.

Title: Senator Tom Coburn's 2013 Wastebook Highlights Federal Government Waste

Senator Tom Coburn's annual Wastebook report has shed light on extravagant federal government spending in 2013, sparking concerns about inefficiencies and waste. The report highlights several instances of unnecessary expenditures, including the Department of Defense's decision to leave 2,000 Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) vehicles behind in Afghanistan to be destroyed, rather than delivering them to other bases. Each MRAP cost $500,000 to build.

The report also criticizes the Department of Defense's purchase of 21 C-27 transport planes, which were authorized by Congress despite testimony from a former Air Force chief of staff stating that the planes were not needed and the C-130 could do the job better. The planes were eventually mothballed in the desert without ever flying a single operational mission.

Other examples of waste highlighted in the report include the State Department spending $630,000 to attract followers to its Facebook and Twitter accounts, NASA spending $3 million to study how Congress works, and the National Endowment for the Humanities spending nearly $1 million over three years to explore the origins of popular romance in multi-media. Additionally, the report notes that taxpayers have spent $319 million to build the Healthcare.gov website, with estimates projecting that more than twice that amount will be spent on publicity and marketing.

Senator Coburn attributes the lack of progress in reducing federal spending to Congress's inability to work together and prioritize the country's needs over individual interests. He specifically criticized Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid for not adhering to regular order and bringing appropriations bills to the floor, contributing to Congress's lax oversight of federal government spending in 2013.

Title: Catholics Struggle to Reconcile Church Teachings with Political Polarization

The article discusses the challenges faced by American Catholics in reconciling their religious beliefs with the political polarization in the United States. A recent conference at the University of Notre Dame brought together an ideologically diverse group of Catholic leaders to discuss the impact of polarization on Catholic life. The conference aimed to change the tone of political engagement by priests, laypeople, and the hierarchy.

The article highlights the unique position of Catholics, who are more likely to identify with both major parties due to the church's broad political views. Conservative evangelicals tend to align with the Republican Party, while mainline Protestant denominations align with the Democratic Party. Moderate evangelicals, black Protestants, and Eastern Orthodox traditions cut across the two major parties.

The article quotes Robert McElroy, the newly installed Catholic bishop of San Diego, who warned against the ways both parties can be hostile to human dignity and the common good. The author notes that parties pose a paradox for Christian citizens, as they provide a platform for different policy goals, but can also lead to abandoning religious principles for party loyalty.

The article concludes that American Catholics are uneasy with the current state of polarization, as neither party offers a platform that aligns with Catholic values. The author suggests that Catholics should fight for space in both parties for Catholic social teaching, which offers a comprehensive and authentic "Christian" ethic. The article concludes by noting that polarization challenges Catholics more acutely than many other religious adherents, and they should seek ways to promote fuller expressions of their church's humane teachings in both parties.

Title: Supreme Court's Health Care Ruling Sparks Political Debate Over Tax Angle

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has sparked a heated political debate, with Republicans seizing on the ruling's tax implications and Democrats emphasizing the law's benefits for Americans. The court's decision, led by Chief Justice John Roberts, ruled that the individual mandate, a key provision of the ACA, is a tax, which Congress has the authority to impose.

Republican leaders, including House Speaker John Boehner, quickly criticized the ruling, calling it a "tax" and vowing to repeal the law or any part of it. They argue that the decision gives Congress the power to tax Americans for anything, including broccoli consumption, as an example. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor announced that the House would vote to repeal the law again after its summer recess.

Democrats, on the other hand, emphasized the law's benefits, particularly for those with pre-existing conditions who will now be able to get coverage. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi downplayed the debate over the tax angle, calling it "Washington talk," and emphasized the law's benefits for American families.

The ruling has given Republicans new ammunition to attack the ACA, which they had previously criticized as an overreach of government power. The decision has also reignited the debate over taxes, with Republicans arguing that the law is a tax increase and Democrats emphasizing its benefits.

The Supreme Court's decision has set the stage for a contentious political battle in the run-up to the November elections, with both parties using the ruling to advance their own agendas.

Title: Face Masks: Should You Wear One During the COVID-19 Pandemic?

The use of face masks has become a common practice in many Asian countries to protect against COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. In Europe and the United States, the adoption of masks is less widespread, but many people are asking whether they should wear them during the pandemic.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), healthy individuals only need to wear a mask if they are caring for someone with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 infection, or if they are coughing or sneezing themselves, or suspect they might have the virus.

Masks work by capturing droplets that are dispersed in coughs, sneezes, and breath, which are the main transmission route of the new coronavirus. There are two main types of masks: surgical masks, which are strips of fabric worn across the nose and mouth, and closer-fitting ones, sometimes called respirators.

Close-fitting masks, such as N95 ones, can offer good, but not total protection against infectious droplets, while the next rank up, N99-rated masks, can provide better protection, but some find them difficult to breathe through. The "N" rating relates to the percentage of particles of at least 0.3 microns in diameter that the mask is designed to block: N95 masks stop 95%, and N99 masks stop 99%.

Some masks have a valve in the front to help prevent moisture in exhaled breath from condensing on the inside, making the mask wet and more liable to virus penetration. Masks are only effective if you combine wearing them with frequent handwashing and ensure you don't touch your face.

Anyone using a mask should make sure their hands are thoroughly cleaned with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer before putting it on. The mask should cover your mouth and nose, and there should be no gaps between your face and the mask. When the mask becomes damp, replace it with a new one. Do not reuse single-use masks.

According to Stephen Griffin, an associate professor at Leeds University's Institute of Medical Research, "Wearing a mask can also reduce the propensity for people to touch their faces, which happens many more times a day than we all realize and is a major source of infection without proper hand hygiene."

Title: US Leads International Effort Against Islamic State with 85% of Air Strikes

The United States is responsible for approximately 85% of the international air strikes against the Islamic State (IS) in Iraq and Syria, according to the latest Pentagon report. The report, obtained by FoxNews.com, reveals that US fighter planes and drones have conducted 819 strikes, compared to 157 from the 10 other participating countries.

The international coalition, launched by President Obama in August, has seen the US joined by Australia, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom.
