Canada was the last to join, on October 7, and the last to launch a strike. France was the first Western country to launch an air strike, destroying an IS depot on September 17.

The US-led coalition has committed at least 30 fighter jets and four support aircraft to the mission, which has targeted IS military equipment, including vehicles and depots. One mission last month targeted a captured oil refinery, according to a top Australian military official.

However, US military officials have not released specific information about the accuracy of the strikes, which has been questioned. The US Central Command did not respond to requests for information about strike accuracy and why the US flies the majority of the sorties.

Pilots have expressed concerns about killing civilians, which has limited their targets and forced them to attack only at night. The elusive and unconventional nature of IS also presents a challenge. Dakota Wood, a defense expert at the Heritage Foundation and retired Marine Corps special operations officer, noted that the decisions about which countries will fly which missions involve logistical and political factors.

The other countries participating in the coalition could have joined under limited rules of engagement, like Germany did in the war in Afghanistan. Alternatively, Central Command may be marshaling the majority of sorties to US pilots. Oklahoma Sen. James Inhofe, the top Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, expressed concern about the challenges of targeting IS, stating, "We need more targeting capability."

The combined 10 other countries have flown fewer attack missions, which is not surprising given the US has the world's biggest and most powerful military, with approximately 4,800 attack and fighter planes among more than 13,600 aircraft. The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that US-led coalition warplanes carried out as many as 30 airstrikes overnight against IS militants in and around the group's de facto capital of Raqqa, in northeastern Syria, bringing the total to roughly 1,000.

Title: White House Prepares for Obamacare Push as Enrollment Period Approaches

The White House is gearing up for a coordinated effort to promote the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, as the six-month enrollment period approaches. According to senior administration officials, President Barack Obama, First Lady Michelle Obama, Vice President Joe Biden, and Jill Biden will be deployed to sell the healthcare law in a more coordinated manner than ever before.

The increased engagement comes as the ACA enters its prime time, with the unpopular law facing criticism and skepticism from many Americans. However, the White House views this as an opportunity for Obama to prove his critics wrong and turn around public opinion. The president has already begun to emphasize the importance of the law, tweeting about it with Katy Perry and devoting a weekly address to the topic.

The White House is mapping out a strategy to track the turnout for the exchanges in key states and send the Obamas and Bidens into weak markets to boost numbers. The administration is also courting leaders of the African-American community, which has the highest uninsured rate of any demographic, and has already begun to engage with faith-based leaders.

The increased involvement comes as the ACA's enrollment period approaches, with the first day to sign up for health care on October 1st. While the White House is not likely to mark this as an arbitrary benchmark, government funding runs dry on this day, raising the possibility of congressional gridlock and a potential shutdown. Despite this, the White House wants to keep Obama's schedule open and is reluctant to over-hype the first day.

In recent months, Obama has focused more on the law in public and behind closed doors, with health policy aides packing the Roosevelt Room at the White House every month to discuss the latest on Obamacare implementation. The administration is aware that glitches and problems are likely to arise, but is preparing for a coordinated push with events by advocacy groups and tweets from celebrities.

Title: Labor Unions Face Uncertain Future Amidst Weakened Private-Sector and Anti-Union Efforts

The labor movement in the United States is facing significant challenges, with private-sector unions severely weakened by factory shutdowns and corporate resistance to unionization. As a result, government employee unions have become the most powerful part of the labor movement. This has led anti-union billionaires and foundations to finance efforts to undermine government worker unions, including the Janus litigation, which aims to reduce union membership and dues.

The recent appointment of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court does not bode well for workers and unions. In a 2014 opinion, Kavanaugh dissented in a 2-to-1 case, suggesting that the Labor Department should not regulate the safety of SeaWorld trainers, comparing them to sports figures who accept the risk of injury in hazardous businesses. This opinion echoes 19th-century court rulings that factory workers assumed the risk of injuries from machinery.

Despite these challenges, labor unions may receive a boost from President Trump's efforts to increase coal, steel, and aluminum production, as well as his push to renegotiate NAFTA to spur domestic auto production. These moves could bring back tens of thousands of mining and manufacturing jobs, potentially lifting union membership. However, experts estimate that more than a million workers will quit their unions over the next few years as a result of the Janus ruling.

On a positive note, a recent Gallup poll found that public approval for unions has reached its highest level in 15 years. Unions have scored significant victories, particularly among white-collar workers, with adjunct professors and journalists unionizing at various universities and publications. There have also been gains among nurses, bus drivers, and service-sector workers in Silicon Valley.

The labor movement in the United States is already weaker than in any other major industrialized nation, with just one in 10 American workers belonging to a union, down from more than one in three in the 1950s. In the face of decades of employer resistance and the Trump administration's hostility, unions are not making the gains they need to reverse their decline. If America's unions don't rebound, it will likely mean even more income inequality, wage stagnation, and control of the levers of power by corporations and wealthy donors.

Title: The Illusion of Healthcare Policy: A Tale of Partisan Folly

The healthcare policy debate in the United States has been marked by partisan posturing and dishonesty, with both parties guilty of perpetuating falsehoods and refusing to accept reality. The article argues that the problem is not the existence of partisanship, but rather the dishonesty and refusal to accept reality that comes with it.

The article highlights the example of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, which was passed with promises that were later proven to be false. The article notes that the Republican pledge to repeal the ACA was often a sales pitch that expired after the election, and that the actual repeal bills debated in Congress did not repeal the law, but rather kept most of its regulations intact.

The article also criticizes the Democratic Party for its own dishonesty, pointing out that the ACA was passed with promises that were later proven to be false, such as the claim that people could keep their plans and doctors. The article argues that both parties are guilty of using lies and rhetoric to further their own interests, rather than engaging in honest and constructive policy debates.

The article concludes that the polarized and tribal climate in Washington is frustrating because it is a battle of liars trying to protect past lies and make new ones seem plausible. The article does not advocate for a return to bipartisanship, but rather argues that honest partisanship is not the problem, but rather the dishonesty and refusal to accept reality that comes with it.

Title: Majority of Democratic Voters Believe Hillary Clinton Should Continue Running for President Despite Email Controversy

A recent poll conducted by Rasmussen found that a strong majority of Democratic voters believe Hillary Clinton should continue running for president even if she is charged with a felony in connection with her private email use while serving as Secretary of State. The poll, which surveyed 1,000 likely voters, found that 71% of Democratic voters believe she should keep running, compared to 30% of Republicans and 46% of unaffiliated voters.

The poll also found that 50% of those polled overall believe Clinton should continue her presidential bid. The FBI investigation into her email practices is still ongoing, and Democratic primary rival Bernie Sanders has avoided commenting specifically on the probe.

Clinton's campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, expressed doubt about whether she could continue running if an indictment were to come down. "That would be difficult to continue running a race," Weaver said.

The email scandal could still be problematic for Clinton's general election hopes, with 40% of all voters saying they are less likely to vote for her because of it. However, 48% of voters said it would have no impact on their vote.

The poll also found that 65% of voters consider it likely that Clinton broke the law with her email use, with 47% saying it's very likely.

Title: U.S. Government Expands Use of DNA Tests to Reunify Separated Parents and Children

The U.S. government has expanded its use of DNA tests to establish paternity in immigration matters, as part of its efforts to quickly reunify parents and children who were separated after crossing the border illegally from Mexico. The government claims that DNA testing is a faster means of confirming parentage than relying on assembling documents such as birth certificates.

According to a declaration filed with the U.S. District Court in San Diego, the government is using DNA testing to verify family ties between parents and children. The testing involves taking swabs from the cheeks of children and adults and sending them to a third-party laboratory for analysis. The process takes about a week, although it can take longer to complete verification.

The government is using DNA testing as part of its efforts to reunify parents and children who were separated after crossing the border illegally. The testing is seen as a faster and more efficient way to confirm parentage, as opposed to relying on assembling documents such as birth certificates.

The use of DNA testing in immigration cases is not new, but it has become more widespread in recent years. The government has used DNA testing to verify family ties between parents and children, as well as to identify the biological parents of unaccompanied minors.

In a declaration filed with the U.S. District Court in San Diego, U.S. Health and Human Services official Jonathan White described the testing as a "faster but costlier method for confirming parentage than collecting and assessing documentation and anecdotal information." The testing is just one part of the reunification process, which also involves assessing parental fitness and potential child endangerment.

The government has not disclosed the cost of the DNA testing, but lab companies such as DNA Diagnostics and LabCorp have said that their tests to identify relatives can cost in the "hundreds of dollars." The testing is seen as a necessary step in the reunification process, as it helps to ensure that children are reunited with their biological parents and not with individuals who may pose a risk to their well-being.

Title: Campaign 2012 Reaches Record Degree of Triviality, Strategists and Observers Agree

The 2012 presidential campaign has unfolded as a "grinding, joyless slog" in the eyes of veteran strategists and observers, falling short of the larger-than-life personalities and debates of the 2008 campaign. The race has been marked by a focus on trivialities, with both the Obama and Romney campaigns engaging in a daily trench warfare on Twitter and in television ads.

Strategists and operatives acknowledge that the campaign has been a disappointment, with neither candidate outlining a detailed agenda for their second term. Instead, they have chosen to focus on tactics and daily skirmishes, rather than engaging in a serious discussion about the issues. The Obama campaign has spoken in broad strokes about his accomplishments, but has not yet outlined a detailed agenda for a second term. Romney has openly declared that he will not detail his policy proposals, such as slashing the size of government, so as to avoid giving his opponents ammunition.

The campaign has been defined by a focus on trivialities, with both sides engaging in antics that satisfy their partisans but do not focus the national dialogue. The chair of the Democratic Party has labeled Romney a "job cremator," while the Romney campaign has driven its campaign bus in circles around an Obama event, honking the horn in a stunt reminiscent of a third-tier frat house.

Some strategists and observers believe that the campaigns are stuck in a defensive crouch, unwilling to engage in a serious discussion about the issues. "Who's going to say, in the middle of an election year, we're going to come up with a new system and here's how we're going to play, and everyone's going to come along?" said Todd Purdum, the Vanity Fair editor and former New York Times White House reporter.

The expanding and hyperactive press corps does not help matters, with reporters focusing on who said what in the last five minutes and who said what in response to that. The tenor of the race could change after Labor Day, but for now, the campaign remains a "total crock" that neither side wants to abandon.

Title: Vice President Biden Advocates for Amnesty, Discusses Deportation Review

Vice President Joe Biden recently spoke at a Miami Dade college, where he discussed his stance on immigration reform and amnesty for illegal immigrants. According to reports, Biden stated that he believes illegal immigrants are already American citizens, and he advocated for amnesty for all illegal immigrants. When an audience member shouted "Stop deportations!", Biden replied that he would consider it, but asked to finish his speech.

The Obama administration has faced pressure from pro-amnesty advocates to stop deportations and grant more amnesty. In response, the administration has announced an administrative review of deportation laws, which has been met with criticism from some lawmakers. Twenty-two senators wrote a letter to President Obama, denouncing his actions as a threat to the constitutional system and the rule of law.

Biden also praised Florida for becoming the 20th state to grant in-state tuition to illegal immigrants, which could cost taxpayers up to $50 million. In 2012, Biden publicly expressed his support for gay marriage before President Obama had made his stance clear, which reportedly led to Obama freezing Biden out.

It is worth noting that the Obama administration has not officially announced plans to stop deportations, and the exact details of the administrative review of deportation laws are still unclear.

Title: Trump's Associates Admit to Controversial Actions, but Claim They Were Justified

The recent impeachment of President Donald Trump has sparked a flurry of admissions from his associates about their involvement in the scandal. Rudy Giuliani, Trump's personal lawyer, has publicly confessed to pushing for the firing of former US Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch because she was seen as an obstacle to Ukraine announcing investigations that would help Trump's political interests.

Giuliani's admission is part of a larger pattern of Trump and his associates acknowledging their involvement in the scandal, but downplaying its significance. White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney has admitted to a "quid pro quo" involving military aid, while US Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland has confirmed that Trump refused to give Zelensky a White House meeting until Ukraine announced the investigations Trump wanted.

Trump himself has also made several admissions, including urging China to investigate the Bidens and claiming that he was concerned about corruption in Ukraine. However, his claims of corruption are based on a conspiracy theory that has been widely debunked by intelligence agencies and experts.

Giuliani's recent trip to Ukraine has provided new details on his smear campaign against Yovanovitch, which he claims was necessary to remove her because she was obstructing justice and enabling Ukrainian collusion. However, he has offered no credible evidence to support these claims.

The Republican-run Senate will now have to decide whether to agree with Trump and his associates that their actions were justified.

Title: Trump Urges Republicans to "Get Over" Criticism of Judge's Mexican Heritage

Article:

Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has responded to criticism from some Republicans over his recent comments about Judge Gonzalo Curiel, who is overseeing a case against Trump University. Trump stated that he does not care about the judge's heritage and wants a fair trial. In an interview on Fox News' "Hannity" program, Trump said, "I don't care where the judge comes from or where judges come from - I just want to get a fair shake."

Trump has previously stated that Judge Curiel has a conflict of interest due to his Mexican heritage and Trump's plan to build a wall along the US-Mexico border. Many Republicans, including former presidential candidates Jeb Bush and John Kasich, have criticized Trump's remarks. Trump responded by saying that some Republicans are "angry" and "can't get over it," urging them to move on.

Senator Mark Kirk, who is facing a tough re-election fight in Illinois, has announced that he will not support Trump due to the comments about Judge Curiel and other attacks. Trump had previously issued a statement saying his comments were "misconstrued as a categorical attack against people of Mexican heritage." He stated that he does not believe heritage makes someone incapable of being impartial, but feels justified in questioning the fairness of the trial based on the rulings he has received in the Trump University case.

Title: Kellyanne Conway Accused of Violating Federal Law, Advocating for Specific Senate Candidates

The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) has announced that Kellyanne Conway, senior counselor to the President, has twice violated the Hatch Act, a federal law prohibiting government employees from engaging in political activities. The OSC stated that Conway's actions occurred during two television interviews in November and December, where she advocated against one Senate candidate and gave an implied endorsement of another.

According to the OSC, Conway's statements during the interviews mixed official government business with political views about candidates in the Alabama special election for U.S. Senate. The agency has referred its report to President Trump, but the White House has disputed the finding, making it unlikely Conway will face serious discipline.

The OSC's report details how Conway was briefed on the Hatch Act at least five separate times and received training on the law's requirements. The agency claims Conway never followed through on her commitment to comply with the law.

The Hatch Act, enacted in 1939, aims to ensure federal programs are administered in a nonpartisan fashion, protect federal employees from political coercion, and advance employees based on merit, not political affiliation. The law has a few exceptions, including the President, Vice President, and some other federal employees.

This is not the first time Conway has been accused of violating federal ethics rules. In 2017, she was found to have violated federal ethics rules during an appearance on "Fox and Friends" when she urged viewers to purchase items from Ivanka Trump's clothing line.

The White House has disputed the OSC's findings, stating that Conway did not advocate for or against the election of any particular candidate, but rather expressed the President's position on having people in the House and Senate who support his agenda. However, the OSC's report suggests otherwise.

The incident has sparked controversy, with Rep. Elijah Cummings, the top Democrat on the House Oversight Committee, calling for the President to take disciplinary action against Conway.

Title: U.S. Senator John McCain Condemns Trump Administration's Family Separation Policy

The Trump administration's practice of separating families at the U.S.-Mexico border has sparked a national outcry, with U.S. Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona, condemning the policy in a sharp statement. McCain's statement reflects a break within Republican ranks on the controversial policy, which has resulted in an estimated 2,000 children being separated from their families.

Three of Arizona's five GOP House members have avoided public comments on the "zero tolerance" crackdown, while all four of the state's U.S. House Democrats have pilloried the practice in recent days. U.S. Senator Jeff Flake, also from Arizona, hinted at his dismay in questions about the policy he put to Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen.

McCain's statement read: "The administration's current family separation policy is an affront to the decency of the American people, and contrary to principles and values upon which our nation was founded. The administration has the power to rescind this policy. It should do so now."

The family separations have sparked a national outcry and emerged as a searing test of how far Americans are willing to go in their efforts to enforce immigration and border control. The White House has offered conflicting accounts of the policy and the reasons behind it, with officials alternately blaming Democrats for it, denying there is a separation policy, or suggesting the policy is intended as a deterrent to reduce illegal immigration.

Congressional Republicans have done what they often do in other high-profile controversies involving President Donald Trump: they have waited. U.S. Rep. Martha McSally, a Republican whose Tucson-based district includes part of the border with Mexico, issued a statement that suggests she does not like the separation tactics, but does not find fault with the Trump administration.

U.S. Rep. Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat, condemned the policy, saying, "The administration's choice to separate families at the border is wrong – they should stop immediately. I'm ready to work with anyone to fix our broken immigration system, secure our border, & protect our communities."

U.S. Rep. Paul Gosar, a Republican, pointed the blame at former President Barack Obama, saying, "The Obama Admin's lack of enforcement of our immigration laws is responsible for this crisis. The (Justice Department's) zero-tolerance policy returns to the rule of law & ensures families are no longer lured to our borders with false promises. Elections matter."

McCain and Flake are Republicans who have cast themselves as the conscience of their party as their congressional careers wind down. McCain is battling an aggressive form of brain cancer, while Flake is not seeking re-election this year.

Title: Federal Judge Allows Lawsuit Against Trump to Proceed, Alleging Violation of Emoluments Clause

A federal judge has ruled that a lawsuit against President Donald Trump can proceed, alleging that he is violating the Constitution's emoluments clause by doing business with foreign governments. Judge Peter J. Messitte's decision will allow the attorneys general of Maryland and the District of Columbia to proceed with their case, which claims that Trump has accepted benefits from foreign governments without permission.

The plaintiffs are seeking to grill Trump Organization employees and search company records to determine which foreign countries have spent money at Trump's hotel in Washington. The Justice Department and Trump's attorneys have not commented on the matter.

The Constitution's emoluments clause prohibits federal officials from accepting gifts or payments from foreign governments. The clause was included to prevent US ambassadors from being influenced by European powers. However, the modern meaning of the clause has not been settled, as most presidents have not run or taken part in running their businesses while in office.

Trump has maintained ownership of his business empire, including over 10 hotels and golf clubs around the world. Although he has said he gave up day-to-day management of his businesses, he still owns them and can withdraw money from them at any time. Several foreign governments have spent money at Trump's hotel, including Kuwait, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Romania.

The plaintiffs may also seek access to Trump's tax returns, which he has refused to reveal, fueling speculation that the president has something to hide. The case is ongoing, and Trump's team may appeal the decision and ask the judge to delay granting the attorneys general access to Trump Organization employees and records until the appeal is decided.

Title: University of Illinois Student Dies After Being Strangled and Sexually Assaulted in Parking Garage

A 19-year-old University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) student, Ruth George, was found dead in a parking garage on the university campus after being strangled and sexually assaulted. According to prosecutors, George was walking to her car in the garage early Saturday morning when a man, later identified as 26-year-old Donald Thurman, began following and catcalling her. When she ignored him, Thurman allegedly got angry and followed George to her car, putting her in a chokehold and throwing her into the backseat.

Thurman then allegedly sexually assaulted George while she was unconscious. Her sisters and UIC police found her body in the car, and she was pronounced dead at the scene. A medical examiner confirmed that George died from strangulation.

Thurman was arrested on Sunday and charged with first-degree murder and aggravated sexual assault. He was released from prison in December after serving two years of a six-year sentence for armed robbery. A judge ordered Thurman to be held without bail.

During a court hearing, prosecutors described the chilling circumstances of George's death. Thurman allegedly saw George walking to the parking garage at around 1:25 a.m. and thought she was "pretty." He tried to talk to her, but she ignored him and continued walking to her car. Thurman then allegedly put her in a chokehold, dragged her from the ground, and threw her into the backseat. George was unconscious when Thurman sexually assaulted her.

Surveillance camera footage showed Thurman following George into the parking garage and running away 35 minutes later. Authorities recovered a condom and semen in the car. Thurman admitted to choking George, throwing her in the car, and sexually assaulting her while she was unconscious, but denied having sexual intercourse with her.

The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward.

Title: Republican National Convention Kicks Off with Busy Day Ahead

The Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida, is set to begin in earnest this afternoon, with a packed schedule of events and speakers. The convention was delayed due to Hurricane Isaac, but it's now ready to get underway.

The day's highlights include the roll call, where delegates will officially nominate Mitt Romney as the party's presidential candidate and Paul Ryan as his running mate. The roll call is expected to wrap up by 6:40 p.m. ET.

Other notable speakers include Rick Santorum, who will address the delegates at 7 p.m. ET, and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who will speak at 8 p.m. ET. Former Representative Artur Davis will also take the stage at 9 p.m. ET, and Ann Romney, Mitt Romney's wife, will speak at 10 p.m. ET.

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie will deliver the keynote address at 11 p.m. ET, a must-see for political junkies. The convention is expected to adjourn at 11 p.m. ET, or possibly later if things run behind schedule.

Title: Abortion Debate Rises to Prominence, Impacting Midterm Elections

The debate over the Supreme Court's potential nomination to overturn the Roe v. Wade decision has reached a level of prominence not seen in years, creating an unpredictable and potentially volatile environment for incumbents in the midterm elections. The issue has the potential to mobilize both Democratic and Republican voters, with each side confident that their base will be energized by the fight.

Democrats believe that the prospect of a nominee who could overturn Roe v. Wade will bring an army of Democrats to the polls, particularly in suburban House districts, where female voters are expected to be motivated by the issue. Republican pollsters, on the other hand, are confident that the issue will energize their own base, particularly among non-college-educated white males and evangelicals.

The battle over the Supreme Court nomination could have significant implications for the midterm elections. While House members will not vote on the nomination, the fight could drive up Democratic turnout in districts won by Hillary Clinton in 2016. Conversely, Republicans believe that a conservative nominee winning confirmation could help them keep their Senate majority.

The Cook Political Report identifies several Republican-held seats that are vulnerable in blue-state districts won by Clinton in 2016. In the Senate, Democrats are defending seats in Indiana, West Virginia, North Dakota, and Missouri, which could be at risk due to the abortion debate. Senators Joe Donnelly and Joe Manchin, who are up for reelection in these states, are seen as being particularly vulnerable.

The Pew Research Center's 2014 poll found that only 35% of West Virginia adults support legalizing abortion in all or most cases, while 51% believe it should be illegal. In Indiana, 43% support legalizing abortion, while 51% believe it should be illegal.

The debate over abortion rights could play out differently in different states. In Montana, more than 50% of voters favor abortion rights, which could help Democratic incumbent Jon Tester. In Arizona, 49% of voters support legalizing abortion, according to the Pew poll.

The issue of abortion rights could also impact the presidential election, with some pollsters predicting that it could help swing independent male voters to Democratic candidates in Western states like Montana, Nevada, and Arizona.

Title: Miller's Confirmation Hearing Highlights Tensions Over Inspector General's Independence

Article:

The confirmation hearing of Brian Miller, President Trump's nominee for the new inspector general, focused on his ability to operate independently and resist political pressure. Miller's sworn assertion suggests he will uphold the language in the $2 trillion CARES Act, which requires the inspector general to report to Congress if impeded in his investigative work. This stance differs from Trump's signing statement, which stated that the inspector general cannot report to Congress without "presidential supervision."

During the hearing, Miller emphasized his commitment to independence, stating that he would inform Congress immediately if any agency asked him to withhold information and would consider any effort to distribute massive sums of taxpayer money to states based on "political gain" a violation. Miller also sidestepped questions about his role in Trump's dismissal of intelligence community watchdog Michael Atkinson and Glenn Fine, who was initially picked to oversee the government's coronavirus response.

Miller's nomination has sparked concerns among Senate Democrats, who worry that his current role as a White House lawyer may compromise his independence. Miller, however, vowed to resist any pressure from the president or other administration officials seeking to undermine his independence, citing his track record of battling with officials from the George W. Bush administration as a federal watchdog.

The hearing also touched on Miller's potential role in investigating potential abuses, with Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) pressing him to make commitments on what might constitute potential abuses worthy of investigation. Miller agreed that a bailed-out corporation that lays off employees or companies that lobby the White House and Congress before receiving funds could be investigated.

Miller's confirmation is likely to be approved in the Republican-controlled Senate, as he would oversee a $500-billion fund managed by the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve meant to shore up companies and industries ravaged by the coronavirus crisis.

Title: Obama Reassures Greece on NATO's Importance Amid Uncertainty

Article:

U.S. President Barack Obama has begun his final foreign trip as president with a visit to Greece, where he sought to reassure the country about the United States' commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) alliance. Obama met with Greek President Prokopis Pavlopoulos and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, discussing the importance of a strong NATO and the need for economic cooperation.

Obama emphasized that a strong NATO is of "utmost importance" and would provide "significant continuity" despite the transition in the U.S. government. Pavlopoulos thanked Obama for U.S. support during Greece's economic crisis and expressed confidence that the next U.S. administration will continue on the same path.

The visit comes amid concerns in Europe about the future of the NATO alliance following the election of Donald Trump as the next U.S. president. Trump's campaign rhetoric has suggested the U.S. might pull out of the alliance if other countries do not contribute more.

Obama also met with Tsipras, pledging to continue supporting Greece as it struggles with economic woes and a massive influx of refugees. He emphasized the need for debt relief and other accommodative strategies to help the country recover.

The U.S. president's visit has been met with tight security measures, with over 5,000 police deployed in Athens and a ban on public gatherings and demonstrations in certain areas. Left-wing and anarchist groups have planned protest demonstrations, while an armed anarchist group has called for "attacks and clashes" to disrupt the visit.

Obama's trip will continue with a visit to the Acropolis and a major speech on democracy and globalization before he travels to Berlin and then Peru for an Asian economic summit.

Title: The Complexities of Gender-Affirmative Care for Youth: A Delicate Balance of Risks and Benefits

The decision to initiate estrogen or testosterone treatment for gender dysphoric youth is a serious and complex one, involving a delicate balance of risks and benefits. Medical guidelines recommend that these treatments generally not be provided until age 16, or at the earliest, 14, due to the potential for irreversible cosmetic changes, such as body fat redistribution and voice changes. However, existing data suggests that access to estrogen or testosterone is associated with improved mental health for these youth.

Recent studies have highlighted concerns about the potential for youth to "de-transition" due to societal pressure or regret the physical changes resulting from treatment. However, medical professionals who care for these patients emphasize that it is far more likely that a young transgender person will have regrets when physicians refuse to provide the medical care to pause the puberty that is actively distressing them.

The potential benefits of providing gender-affirmative care typically outweigh the minor risks associated with treatment. These medications are administered only after thoughtful conversations between the patient, family, and physician, with medical interventions not started without all three being on board and understanding the risks and benefits. Legislation that puts these decisions in the hands of the government instead of families and physicians is seen as dangerous.

Conservatives often use phrases like "sex change surgery" to scare the general public, but current medical guidelines emphasize that genital surgeries for transgender patients are never offered before adulthood. The only surgeries sometimes considered before adulthood are the removal of breast tissue, which requires careful evaluation before proceeding. Furthermore, youth who require this surgery are generally those who were unable to obtain puberty blockers, developed significant breast tissue, and had strong negative emotional reactions to their chest. Easier access to puberty blockers could eliminate the need for this kind of surgery.

State legislators are urged to educate themselves about the medical care of gender-diverse youth and consult with physicians, professional medical societies, and researchers in the field. Most importantly, they should listen to the voices of transgender youth themselves, who should have the opportunity to be heard by those who would make decisions about their bodies. The medical profession has made it clear that legislation that restricts access to gender-affirmative care is dangerous and should not become law.

Title: US Officials Believe Intelligence Supports Strike Against Syria, But Details Remain Classified

The United States has gathered intelligence that suggests the Syrian government was behind the recent chemical weapons attack, but officials have not directly linked Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to the incident. Despite this, the administration believes it has both the evidence and legal justification to launch a military strike against Syria to deter the use of such weapons again.

A key piece of intelligence is an intercepted telephone call between Syrian military officials, which suggests that the attack was more devastating than intended. One official described the conversation as "a small operation that got out of control." However, Republican lawmakers have disputed this assessment, saying that the White House believes Syria intended to inflict widespread damage.

The administration has briefed several lawmakers on the intelligence, including Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, Director of National Intelligence James R. Clapper Jr., and National Security Adviser Susan E. Rice. The briefing was unclassified, meaning lawmakers were given limited details about the intelligence.

Some lawmakers have expressed frustration that the White House did not consult with Congress before planning the strike. Representative Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said that "when we take what is a very difficult decision, you have to have buy-in by members and buy-in by the public."

Title: President Trump Leaves Mitt Romney Off List of Senators Invited to Coronavirus Task Force

The White House has released a list of senators invited to participate in the "Opening Up America Again Congressional Group," a task force focused on reopening the economy during the coronavirus pandemic. The list does not include Utah Senator Mitt Romney, a Republican who has been a vocal critic of President Donald Trump.

According to an official, President Trump reviewed the list of invited lawmakers before it was released on Thursday. A spokesperson for Senator Romney confirmed that he was not asked to participate in the task force.

Senator Romney and President Trump have a history of disagreements, dating back to the 2016 presidential election. When Trump became the Republican primary frontrunner, Romney delivered a speech urging Americans to vote tactically to prevent Trump from winning the nomination. The two briefly put aside their differences when Trump considered Romney for a cabinet position after his election, and subsequently supported Romney's bid for the Senate in 2018.

However, their relationship deteriorated again when Romney continued to criticize Trump in the press and was the only Republican senator to vote to impeach the president on abuse of power earlier this year. Trump has publicly labeled Romney a "Democrat secret asset," a "failed presidential candidate," a "Republican in name only," and "one of the dumbest and worst candidates in the history of Republican politics."

Title: Michigan Legislature to Vote on Abortion Coverage Ban

The Michigan Republican-controlled Legislature is set to vote on a measure that would ban abortion coverage from all health insurance plans, requiring women to purchase a separate policy to cover the procedure. The proposal, certified by the state election board, was introduced by the anti-choice group Right to Life of Michigan through a rarely used initiative petition, which can become law without executive action by the governor.

The ban contains no exceptions for pregnancies resulting from rape or incest. Reproductive health advocates have criticized the proposal, calling it an attempt to force women to purchase "rape insurance." Meghan Groen, director of government relations for Planned Parenthood Advocates of Michigan, stated that the proposal would not allow women to purchase a rider for abortion coverage once they are pregnant.

Jessica Tramontana, communications director for Progress Michigan, described the proposal as "unconscionable" and accused Right to Life of launching a campaign against women's rights by finding a loophole in the law and skirting a signature from the governor. She also emphasized that the measure is deceptive, as Michigan and federal law prevent taxpayer dollars from funding abortion care.

A majority of Michigan voters appear to oppose the measure, and identical proposals have been vetoed twice by Republican governors. However, advocates say the state Legislature has taken an extreme rightward turn and may push the measure through despite the lack of support.

Title: Obama Calls for Transformation on Gun Violence After Navy Yard Shooting

President Barack Obama delivered a speech at the Marine Barracks in Washington, D.C., on Sunday, honoring the 12 people killed in the recent shooting at the Navy Yard. The president emphasized that the country cannot accept the senseless violence that occurred and urged for a transformation on gun violence in the United States.

Obama acknowledged that the country has seen mass shootings before, including those in Fort Hood, Texas; Tucson, Arizona; Aurora, Colorado; and Newtown, Connecticut. He expressed his concern that the country is becoming desensitized to gun violence and that it is not acceptable to accept it as the "new normal."

The president also highlighted the lives of the 12 victims, sharing stories of their love, family, and work. He emphasized that the country needs to change its approach to gun violence, citing examples of other countries that have successfully reduced gun violence by restricting access to guns.

Obama's speech was reminiscent of his previous remarks at memorial services for mass shootings, and he acknowledged that the country has been hesitant to take action on gun laws. However, he emphasized that change will come because it is what the American people desire.

The event was attended by representatives from the military, including Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel, Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus, and Vice Adm. William Hilarides, who honored the fallen by noting that they died in the line of duty, just like those killed in battle.

The speech was also attended by Washington, D.C., Mayor Vincent Gray, who joined Obama in calling for tighter gun laws in response to the shooting.

Title: Clinton's Favorability Ratings Plummet in Swing States, IG Referrals to DOJ Raise Questions

Article:

A recent poll conducted by Quinnipiac University and a subsequent survey by NBC/WSJ have revealed a significant decline in Hillary Clinton's favorability ratings among voters in key swing states. In Iowa and New Hampshire, her ratings are approximately 20 points underwater, with 37% of voters viewing her favorably and 56% unfavorably.

The news comes as two Inspectors General have referred the matter of Clinton's improper email usage to the Department of Justice (DOJ) for investigation. The referral involves the FBI's counterintelligence division and has been described as "incredibly significant" by Meet the Press host Chuck Todd.

Clinton's campaign has responded to the news by downplaying the significance of the referral and emphasizing that it is unclear whether the investigation will focus on her personally. However, critics argue that Clinton is responsible for her email usage and that her actions have led to a "classified'spillage' problem."

A Twitter thread by Gabriel Malor highlights the severity of the issue, noting that any government employee with a 10% "spillage" rate would be fired and investigated. The thread also points out that Clinton's email situation was referred to the FBI's counterintelligence division and that she sent classified materials.

The article also mentions Hillary's recent comments on the matter, in which she referred to her opponents as "all guys" and then corrected herself to include one woman, Carly Fiorina. The comment was seen as an attempt to deflect attention from the email scandal and play the woman card.

Overall, the recent developments have raised questions about Clinton's trustworthiness and her ability to manage classified information.

Title: Tillerson and Rubio Clash Over Russia Policy in Senate Confirmation Hearing

Article:

Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson faced a series of tough questions from Senator Marco Rubio during his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The exchanges were marked by tension and disagreement, particularly on issues related to Russia.

Rubio pressed Tillerson to label Russian President Vladimir Putin as a "war criminal," but Tillerson refused, instead opting for a more nuanced approach. "I find it discouraging your ability to cite that, which I think is globally accepted," Rubio said. Tillerson responded by stating that he is "clear-eyed and realistic about dealing with cultures."

The hearing also touched on Russia's actions in Ukraine, with Tillerson stating that Russia has no legal claim to Crimea and that the Obama administration should have provided Ukraine with more support in defending its borders. Tillerson also called Russia an "unfriendly adversary" and stated that it poses a danger to the United States.

In addition to Russia, Tillerson addressed other topics, including China's construction of man-made islands in the South China Sea, radical Islam, and the situation in Syria. He emphasized the need for the United States to focus on defeating ISIS before discussing who should lead the country.

Tillerson also faced questions about his business ties to Russia during his time as CEO of ExxonMobil. He stated that he would not "tell the boss how to communicate with the American people," referring to President-elect Donald Trump's frequent use of Twitter.

The hearing was marked by moments of levity, including a exchange between Tillerson and Senator Tim Kaine about ExxonMobil's climate change policies. Kaine asked Tillerson if he lacked the knowledge to answer his question or was refusing to answer it, to which Tillerson responded that Kaine would need to ask current executives.

The audience at the hearing was filled with protesters, including Code Pink activists dressed as the Statue of Liberty and a man dressed in a suit made of money. One protester was ejected after screaming "I reject you!" at Tillerson.

Title: Sanders and Trump Discuss Possibility of Debate Ahead of California Primary

The possibility of a debate between Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders and Republican presumptive nominee Donald Trump has gained momentum, with Sanders expressing his willingness to engage in a one-on-one discussion with Trump. The idea was first floated on ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live! on Wednesday, when Trump joked about the potential debate and suggested that any proceeds from the event go to charity.

Sanders told Kimmel that he believes a debate between the two candidates would be "very interesting" and allow the public to see the different visions they have for the country. Trump, on the other hand, expressed his enthusiasm for the idea, saying he would "love to debate Bernie" and suggesting that the event could raise millions of dollars for charity.

The Sanders campaign has been pushing for a debate with Trump, particularly ahead of the California primary on June 7. Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, told CNN that the campaign hopes Trump will "not chicken out" and follow through on his commitment to debate.

Trump's team has been in talks with several networks about hosting the debate, with the real estate mogul suggesting that it should be held in a "big arena" and that he would be willing to donate a portion of the proceeds to charity.

The debate would be a significant event, as it would pit the two candidates with vastly different visions for the country against each other. Sanders has been critical of Trump's policies and has accused him of being a "dream" opponent. Trump, on the other hand, has dismissed the idea of debating Sanders, saying that his system is "rigged" and that he will likely lose.

The debate would also provide an opportunity for the public to see the two candidates engage in a more personal and direct manner, which could be a departure from the more formal and structured debates typically seen during election season.

Title: Prosecutors Describe Paul Manafort's Crimes as "Brazen" and "Bold" in Sentencing Memo

Article:

Prosecutors for special counsel Robert Mueller have submitted a sentencing memo to Judge Amy Berman Jackson, detailing the crimes committed by Paul Manafort, President Trump's former campaign chairman. According to the memo, Manafort "brazenly" and "boldly" violated the law, committing a multitude of crimes, including conspiracy against the United States, conspiracy to obstruct justice, and various financial crimes.

The memo states that Manafort repeatedly and knowingly violated the law, including laws such as the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA), which he was intimately familiar with. The prosecutors describe Manafort's criminal actions as showing a "hardened adherence to committing crimes," with some of these actions being committed while he was under scrutiny due to his work as campaign chairman and later while on bail.

Manafort had initially pleaded guilty to the charges, but the plea deal was revoked after Judge Jackson ruled that he intentionally lied to Mueller's office, the FBI, and the grand jury. The ruling means that prosecutors are no longer bound by the plea deal.

In the Washington, D.C. case, Manafort faces a maximum sentence of 10 years. In a separate case in Virginia, he was found guilty on eight counts and faces up to 24 years in prison and tens of millions of dollars in fines. Prosecutors have urged Judge Jackson to consider stacking his sentence in D.C. on top of his punishment in Virginia. Manafort's sentencing in the Virginia case is also scheduled for March.

Separately, authorities in New York are preparing charges against Manafort for violating state tax laws and other financial crimes, according to reports by Bloomberg News and The New York Times.

Title: Trump Denies Asking Comey to Stop Investigating Flynn, Calls It "Fake News"

Article:

President Donald Trump tweeted on Sunday that he never asked former FBI Director James Comey to stop investigating former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, calling it "fake news" and another "Comey lie." Trump's statement comes after Comey testified before Congress in June that Trump pressured him during an Oval Office meeting in February to end the investigation into Flynn.

Trump's tweet reads: "I never asked Comey to stop investigating Flynn. Just more Fake News covering another Comey lie!" This is in response to Comey's testimony, which stated that Trump asked him to drop the investigation into Flynn.

Flynn pleaded guilty on Friday to lying to federal investigators about his conversations with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. regarding sanctions related to the Kremlin's election interference. He became the first person to hold a position in the Trump administration to be charged by the special counsel.

In a tweet on Saturday, Trump said he had to fire Flynn as national security adviser because the retired Army general lied to Vice President Mike Pence and the FBI. "I had to fire General Flynn because he lied to the Vice President and the FBI. He has pled guilty to those lies," Trump said.

However, two sources familiar with the tweet told The Washington Post that Trump's personal lawyer, John Dowd, crafted the tweet. This has led some legal experts to speculate that Trump may have known Flynn had lied to the FBI and asked Comey to drop the investigation, which could amount to obstruction of justice.

Susan Hennessey, a national security fellow at the Brookings Institution, tweeted that Trump's statement is a "pretty substantial confession to essential knowledge elements of an obstruction of justice charge."

Trump has previously stated that he fired Flynn because of what he said to Vice President Pence, but some have questioned the accuracy of this claim. The White House initially attributed Comey's firing to his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server, but Trump himself told NBC News in May that he was thinking of "this Russia thing" when he decided to fire Comey.

Comey himself offered a cryptic message on Saturday shortly after Trump's tweet about Flynn's firing.

Title: Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates Amid Economic Uncertainty Amidst Coronavirus Outbreak

The Federal Reserve announced a 50-basis-point cut in interest rates on Tuesday, aiming to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. President Donald Trump responded by demanding further rate cuts, stating that the Fed must "come into line with other countries/competitors" and "LEAD." Trump tweeted that the current rate is not competitive and that the U.S. should have the lowest rate.

The Fed's decision to cut interest rates was made in response to slower economic growth due to the outbreak. Fed Chairman Jay Powell emphasized that the move was aimed at providing some support to the economy, but noted that the situation remains fluid and uncertain. Powell stressed that the fundamentals of the economy remain strong.

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin praised the Fed's decision, while Trump reiterated his disappointment, stating that the Fed is "following, not leading." The current Fed benchmark rate stands in a range of 1% to 1.25%.

The market reacted to the rate cut by fluctuating, dipping into and out of negative territory, amid fears of a virus-related global slowdown. The 10-year treasury yield dropped below 1% for the first time in history. The market turned solidly red in afternoon trading, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling over 1,200 points.

The G-7 announced that it would commit unspecified tools to help the global economy deal with the threat of the coronavirus outbreak, the same morning the Fed made its decision. The market had previously experienced its worst performance since the financial crisis last week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling over 12%.

Title: Remembering 9/11: Lessons Learned and Progress Made

The eleventh anniversary of the September 11 attacks has passed, and the United States has made significant strides in improving its foreign and domestic security policies since then. The country has not suffered another attack on its soil, and the lessons of that fateful day have not been forgotten.

In the days following the attacks, President George W. Bush addressed a joint session of Congress, emphasizing the importance of vigilance, tolerance, and thoughtfulness. He outlined the demands made on the Taliban, including the delivery of al-Qaeda leaders, the release of foreign nationals, and the closure of terrorist training camps in Afghanistan.

Since then, the United States has taken steps to improve air safety, expand air marshals on domestic flights, and strengthen intelligence capabilities to track down terrorists. The country has also worked to promote stability and keep its airlines flying, with direct assistance during emergencies.

In recent years, Ground Zero in New York City has faced its share of challenges, but the memorial site has finally been gaining traction. Most of the memorial site opened last year, but there is still work to be done.

Both presidential campaigns will pause their usual activities to commemorate the fallen, with President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney freezing their television ads for the day. President Obama will join a moment of silence at the White House, attend a memorial service at the Pentagon, and visit wounded warriors at Walter Reed medical center. Mitt Romney will speak to the National Guard Association Convention in Nevada.

The anniversary of the 9/11 attacks serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance and cooperation in the fight against terrorism. The United States has made significant progress since then, but there is still work to be done to ensure the safety and security of its citizens.

Title: FBI Allegedly Misled by Christopher Steele in Obtaining Trump Campaign Wiretap

The FBI obtained a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant on October 21, 2016, to spy on Carter Page, a Trump campaign volunteer, based on the infamous Trump-Russia dossier authored by Christopher Steele. However, a Senate document released on Tuesday evening reveals that Steele misled the FBI into making false assertions to a judge, which has further tarnished the FBI's reputation.

According to the Senate Judiciary Committee's criminal referral, the FBI believed it had corroboration for Steele's dossier when it did not. The referral, signed by Senators Charles E. Grassley and Lindsey Graham, states that the FBI relied on Steele's reputation as a credible source, despite not verifying the dossier's claims. The referral also notes that the FBI cited a September 23, 2016, Yahoo News story as corroboration, which was actually sourced from Steele himself.

The FBI's FISA application stated that the information contained in the Yahoo News article matched the information in Steele's dossier, but this was later found to be false. The FBI continued to seek 90-day wiretap renewals based on Steele's reputation, even after he misled agents.

The referral also reveals that Steele received anti-Trump information from Clinton associates funneled through the State Department, which he documented in a memo on October 19. The FBI's investigation into the roles of Clinton operators Sid Blumenthal and Cody Shearer is ongoing.

The FBI's handling of the Steele dossier has been under scrutiny, with some Republicans accusing the agency of hiding the fact that the dossier was financed by Hillary Clinton and the Democratic Party. The FBI's application for the FISA warrant included a footnote referencing possible political backing, but did not disclose the full extent of the dossier's Democratic financing.

The controversy surrounding the Steele dossier and the FBI's handling of the FISA warrant has sparked a renewed call for a criminal investigation into Steele's actions.

Title: Surgeon General Vivek Murthy Confirmed After 17-Month Vacancy

The United States has a new Surgeon General, with Vivek Murthy being confirmed to the position on Monday. The confirmation comes after a 17-month vacancy, with Rear Admiral Boris D. Lushniak serving as the interim Surgeon General since Regina M. Benjamin's departure in 2013.

Murthy, an MD and MBA, is a practicing physician and educator at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School. He is also the co-founder of a clinical trials company, an HIV education organization, and Doctors for America, a group that advocates for stricter gun control laws.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) expressed concerns about Murthy's nomination, citing his tweets criticizing guns and the NRA. However, Murthy has stated that he plans to focus on obesity, not guns, if confirmed. His colleagues, including Dr. Chris Lillis, have defended him, saying his views align with those of major medical organizations.

Murthy's confirmation was also delayed due to concerns from some Democrats who were hesitant to support him, particularly during the run-up to the midterm elections. However, with Congress now in a lame-duck session, Murthy received more support from Democrats and was confirmed with a 51-43 vote.

President Obama praised the confirmation, stating, "I applaud the Senate for confirming Vivek Murthy to be our country's next Surgeon General. As 'America's Doctor,' Vivek will hit the ground running to make sure every American has the information they need to keep themselves and their families safe."

Title: Americans Overwhelmingly Disapprove of Senate GOP's Health Care Bill

The latest NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll reveals that a significant majority of Americans disapprove of the Senate Republican's health care bill, also known as the Better Care Reconciliation Act. Only 17% of those surveyed approve of the plan, while 55% disapprove, and 28% remain undecided or uninformed.

The poll also found that Republicans are divided on the issue, with 21% opposing the bill and 35% supporting it. Independents are even more skeptical, with 68% opposing the proposed legislation.

The Congressional Budget Office analysis released earlier this week highlighted concerns about the bill's impact on healthcare coverage, estimating that 22 million fewer people would have health insurance over the next decade due to the bill's rollback of Medicaid expansion.

The poll also asked Americans about their opinions on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. While some want to see changes to the law, a plurality (46%) believe it should do more, rather than less. Only 7% want to see it do less.

The survey also explored blame if Congress fails to repeal and replace the ACA. Among Americans, 37% would blame Republicans in Congress, 23% would blame Democrats, and 15% would blame President Trump. Among Republicans, Trump would not bear the brunt of the blame, with only 6% blaming him, while 50% would blame congressional Democrats.

The poll surveyed 1,205 adults from June 21-25, 2017, with a ±2.8 percentage points margin of error. A sub-sample of 995 registered voters was also surveyed, with a ±3.1 percentage points margin of error.

Title: Liberals and Technocrats Explore Options to Confront Populist Challenge

The recent rise of populist movements in Western politics has sparked a heated debate about the best approach to address the growing divide between technocratic liberalism and populist nationalism. In a recent article, an author argues that liberals and technocrats have four options to confront the populist challenge: passive resistance, triangulation, brinksmanship, and assimilation.

Passive resistance involves waiting for populist movements to collapse under their own weight, as they often attract marginal and incompetent individuals. However, this approach may not be effective, as populist movements can still achieve success and inflict damage before their inevitable downfall.

Triangulation involves taking some of the populist movement's issues on board, while still preserving the core values of liberalism. This approach acknowledges that populist demands, such as trade barriers or immigration restrictions, may have some merit, but can be implemented in a way that balances the need for economic growth with the need for social cohesion.

Brinksmanship, on the other hand, involves assimilating the worst features of populism in order to defeat it. This approach recognizes that populist movements can be a threat to democracy and freedom, and that liberals may need to adopt some of their tactics to counter their influence.

Finally, assimilation involves embracing the populist movement's ideology and using it to further one's own political agenda. This approach is seen as a risk, as it may lead to the erosion of democratic values and the rise of authoritarianism.

The article concludes that each of these strategies has its risks and limitations, and that the best approach may be a combination of triangulation and brinksmanship. The author notes that the rise of populist movements is a complex issue, and that there is no easy solution.

Title: Trump's VP Pick, Mike Pence, Holds Contrasting Views on Trade, Russia, Iraq, and Muslims

Washington (CNN) - Donald Trump's vice presidential pick, Mike Pence, has held vastly different views on trade, Russia, Iraq, and Muslims compared to the billionaire businessman. Throughout his 16-year political career, Pence, the 57-year-old Indiana governor, has adhered to traditionally muscular Republican policies on foreign affairs. Trump, on the other hand, has taken a more isolationist approach and placed less emphasis on foreign issues.

The issues that Trump has put at the center of his campaign are largely the ones he and his running mate disagree on. Trump made his opposition to the Iraq intervention a major theme, criticizing Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton for her 2002 vote backing the war when she was in the Senate. Pence, near the beginning of his 12-year tenure in the U.S. House, voted for the resolution authorizing the 2003 Iraq invasion.

Pence has also taken a harder line on Russia than Trump, whose authoritarian president, Vladimir Putin, the presumptive GOP presidential nominee has praised. Trump asked an audience at a California rally in May, "Wouldn't it be nice if we could get along with Russia? Wouldn't that be nice?" Pence has opted for stronger rhetoric, telling the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2015 that "A new Iron Curtain is descending down the spine of Europe as modern Russia seeks to redraw the map of Europe by force."

Pence has previously taken issue with some of Trump's national security proposals, calling his proposal to ban Muslim foreigners from entering the U.S. "offensive and unconstitutional" in a December tweet. Trump has since refined the proposal, saying it would only apply to citizens from countries with connections to terrorism.

Perhaps more than any other international issue, Trump has made global trade a defining aspect of his campaign - yet Pence has taken a diametrically opposed position. The real estate mogul has frequently called NAFTA, which regulates trade between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico, "a disaster." During a Republican primary debate in February, he declared, "We are killing ourselves with trade pacts that are no good for us and no good for our workers." Pence, in contrast, praised the role of global trade and slammed protectionism in a 2010 speech to the Detroit Economic Club.

Pence also backed free trade deals with Panama, Colombia, and South Korea while in Congress. Potentially most problematic for Trump, Pence has been a strong proponent of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a regional trade deal involving 12 countries pushed by the Obama administration. Trump has criticized the deal, saying it is a "terrible deal" and a "rape of our country." Pence, however, gave the deal a ringing endorsement and called for its "swift adoption" in a September 2014 tweet.

Despite their differences, Pence and Trump have found common ground on some national security issues - especially when it comes to criticizing President Barack Obama. Like Trump, Pence has slammed Obama for reductions in the size of the American military. Pence has also echoed Trump's critique of the President's preferred terminology for terrorist groups, saying "Lecturing the American people about the crusades while refusing to call Islamic extremism by name is an abdication of leadership."

Title: Romney's Transition Team Plans Modest Accomplishments, Focus on Economic Growth

The transition team of potential President Mitt Romney, dubbed the "Readiness Project," is preparing a series of modest but swift accomplishments if he wins the election. The team is planning to demonstrate quick action to improve the economy while avoiding over-promising, given the narrow margins Republicans will enjoy in Congress, even if they take back the Senate.

According to Romney's advisers, the focus will be on economic growth, with a "200-day plan" rather than the traditional 100-day plan, due to the current political climate. The team is working on government-issued emails and office space on C Street Southwest, with aides and advisers insisting on confidentiality to avoid seeming presumptuous.

Romney's team does not plan to pursue an ideological crusade, but rather wants to be seen as a problem solver, primarily on the economic side. They aim to provide certainty to businesses on taxes and regulation, recognizing that until this is done, sweeping changes cannot be made.

Conservatives expect Romney to make a few changes by executive decree in the first 48 hours if he is elected, including re-implementing the "Mexico City policy" and issuing waivers to states that do not want to participate in elements of the Affordable Care Act.

One of the biggest concerns for a Romney administration will be keeping conservative lawmakers happy while dealing with the nation's fiscal emergency. This may prove challenging, as the loud and powerful wing of House Republicans is resistant to raising revenues, even though it is a mathematical necessity.

Title: Republican Presidential Hopeful Jeb Bush's SuperPAC Aims to Raise $100 Million

The article reports on the fundraising efforts of Republican presidential hopeful Jeb Bush's superPAC, Right to Rise SuperPAC, which aims to raise $100 million by June 1. The superPAC is designed to help Bush win the White House, and much of the money has been raised by Bush himself through private dinners with millionaires and billionaires. The article highlights the significant difference between the rules governing campaign finance and the reality of the situation, with some experts arguing that the rules have been rendered meaningless.

The article notes that Bush has not declared himself a presidential candidate, which allows him to raise unlimited funds for his superPAC. As an official candidate, he would be limited to soliciting contributions of $2,700 per donor. The article also mentions the potential for superPACs to coordinate messages with the candidate's campaign committee, which is currently not allowed.

Experts weigh in on the implications of these developments, with some arguing that the role of superPACs is being exaggerated and that the rules will be strictly respected. Others, however, believe that the relationship between donors and candidates will eventually lead to situations where candidates extract and extort large amounts of money.

The article concludes by noting that this is not the first time presidential candidates have been able to solicit unlimited campaign cash, citing three previous eras: the 1890s and 1900s, the early 1970s, and the "soft money" period of the 1990s. Each of these eras ended with the enactment of new laws regulating political money.

Title: House Votes to Keep Government Open, But Only If Funding is Stripped from ObamaCare

The House of Representatives voted on Friday to keep the government open through mid-December, but only if funding is stripped from the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare. The current funding for the government is set to expire at the end of the month, and lawmakers must approve a stopgap bill to keep Washington open.

The GOP-backed measure would fund the government through December 15 at current funding levels. Republicans argue that the Affordable Care Act is an unpopular law that intrudes on Americans' privacy and their right to be left alone. House Speaker John Boehner stated that the House vote reflects the popularity of the Affordable Care Act, citing businesses that are not hiring or reducing hours due to the law.

The House measure would replace ObamaCare with a plan that expands tax breaks for Americans who buy their own insurance. This sets the stage for a showdown with Senate Democrats, who have vowed to oppose the bill and risk a government shutdown if it passes.

Over 140 congressional Republicans signed on to the bill, which would delay the health care law. Democrats have warned that this strategy risks a government shutdown, with funding set to expire on October 1. The plan would allow Americans who purchase coverage through state-run exchanges to claim a $7,500 deduction against their income and payroll taxes, regardless of the cost of the insurance. Families could deduct $20,000.

The proposal also increases government funding for high-risk pools. Senator Ted Cruz, a vocal supporter of the "defund ObamaCare" push, has vowed to do "everything and anything possible" to defund the law, including a possible filibuster of legislation to prevent a partial government shutdown.

Internal divisions have plagued Republicans this year as they struggle to produce alternatives to the Obama plan. Legislation backed by House Majority Leader Eric Cantor to increase funding for high-risk pools was pulled without a vote after some conservatives objected to improving ObamaCare at a time when they want to repeal it.

Title: Facebook Introduces Policy to Regulate Deepfakes, But Critics Question Effectiveness

Facebook has announced a new policy aimed at regulating so-called "deepfakes" – videos altered to appear as though people are doing or saying something they did not actually do or say. The policy, which comes with caveats, prohibits videos edited through artificial intelligence or machine learning in ways that are not apparent to an average person and would likely mislead viewers. However, it does not apply to parody or satire, or videos edited solely to omit or change the order of words.

Facebook's moderators will remove videos that meet the new criteria, but critics argue that the policy is too narrow and will not effectively address the spread of disinformation. The policy has been met with criticism, with some arguing that it will not have barred the most well-known recent example of an altered video to go viral – a video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi edited to make it seem as though she were slurring her words while speaking at a public event.

Jason Kint, CEO of Digital Content Next, a trade group that represents digital publishers, expressed concerns about the timing of the announcement, noting that Facebook's algorithm and recommendations are responsible for the spread of such videos. "We're entirely at risk here in letting Facebook turn this into a censorship debate while ignoring the fact these videos only receive their velocity and reach due to Facebook's algorithm and recommendations not because they're simply allowed to exist," Kint said.

Saniat Sohrawardi, a researcher at the Rochester Institute of Technology, echoed Kint's concerns, stating that it is a process that cannot yet be effectively automated, meaning it is up to humans to identify suspicious videos from among the millions posted to Facebook. Sohrawardi also noted that even when technology is created to detect deepfakes, the fight against them will have only just begun, as attackers will adapt and create better fakes using machine learning.

The effectiveness of Facebook's new policy remains to be seen, as critics argue that it will not address the root issue of disinformation and that the company's algorithm and recommendations are responsible for the spread of such videos.

Title: Can the Government Quarantine People Against Their Will?

The debate surrounding the government's ability to quarantine individuals against their will, ostensibly for their own health and the health of those around them, requires a dual analysis of the powers of the federal government and the states. The Constitution serves as the foundation for this examination, with the language of the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights emphasizing the importance of individual rights and freedoms.

The Constitution recognizes that freedom is the default position, with government's primary purpose being to protect these rights. The courts have interpreted the Constitution to possess exceptions, but the framers and ratifiers arguably accepted the non-aggression principle, which declares that all aggression against persons and property, even by government, is immoral.

The federal government's powers are limited and delegated, with the states forming the federal government. The courts recognize the concept of personal liberty in a free society, and the Constitution requires due process if any government seeks to impair the life, liberty, or property of an individual.

In the context of a public health crisis, the Constitution does not provide emergency provisions or triggers, but Congress has given itself the power to regulate public health and safety under various pretexts. The Supreme Court has ruled that both the federal government and the states can confine a person who has not committed a crime or has served their sentence, but only to protect society from their intentional or uncontrollable harmful tendencies.

In the case of quarantine, the Constitution requires procedural due process, and a government-ordered quarantine of all persons in a city block or a postal zip code would be an egregious violation of due process. Substantively, no government has the lawful power to curtail natural rights by decree, and procedurally, the states and feds may only quarantine those who are actively contagious and will infect others imminently, with evidence of both presented at a trial.

In conclusion, while the government can quarantine individuals against their will in certain circumstances, it must follow due process and present evidence of both the impairment of liberty and the necessity of the quarantine. The Constitution was not written to give the government the power to right every wrong, but rather to protect individual rights and freedoms.

Title: CFPB Student Loan Ombudsman Resigns, Criticizes Leadership for Serving Financial Companies Over Consumers

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's (CFPB) student loan ombudsman, Seth Frotman, has resigned, citing the agency's leadership for prioritizing the interests of financial companies over those of consumers. In his official resignation letter, Frotman expressed disappointment and frustration with the CFPB's shift in focus, stating that the agency has "abandoned the very consumers it is tasked by Congress with protecting."

Frotman, who served as the student loan ombudsman for the past three years, led the agency's Office for Students and Young Consumers, where he evaluated thousands of complaints from student borrowers and reviewed questionable practices from private lenders, loan services, and debt collectors. During his tenure, the CFPB reviewed over 60,000 student loan complaints and returned more than $750 million to aggrieved borrowers since 2011.
