However, under the Trump administration, the CFPB's leadership has changed, and the agency has faced criticism for its handling of student loan issues. In August 2017, the Department of Education announced it would no longer share information with the CFPB regarding its review of federal student loans. Frotman's resignation letter accused the agency's leadership of "folding to political pressure" and failing borrowers who depend on independent oversight to halt bad practices.

The resignation comes as the Department of Education continues to propose changes regarding aid meant for defrauded students. In December 2017, the Department of Education announced new rules for providing aid to students who said they were defrauded by their colleges, limiting some student loan refunds tied to their income. The New York Times reported in May that the Education Department had largely dismantled a team charged with investigating abuses by for-profit colleges.

Senator Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) tweeted that the administration has "forced another cop from the beat" when it comes to protecting students from predatory colleges, loan servicers, and repayment scams.

**Early Voting Shifts Election Dynamics in Iowa and Beyond**

The 2012 presidential election is taking on a new shape as millions of Americans are casting their ballots ahead of the November 6th election day. In Iowa, a state known for its early voting trend, a surge of voters arrived at election offices to cast their ballots, with some 30 other states also seeing a wave of absentee ballots being sent in. President Barack Obama has been emphasizing the importance of early voting in his campaign strategy, recognizing its potential to increase voter turnout and potentially swing the election in his favor.

The rise of early voting has changed the dynamics of the election, with Election Day becoming Election Month for as much as 40% of the electorate. This shift has led to a new front in efforts to maximize turnout and find voters through micro-targeting. While some argue that making voting more convenient may not necessarily lead to increased participation, others believe it will help engage more people in the democratic process.

In Iowa, the Obama campaign has been actively promoting early voting, with the president himself imploring voters to start casting their ballots six days from now. The campaign has also set up temporary voting sites, including one at a Mexican restaurant and a church, to make it easier for supporters to vote. The Republican Party has also been actively promoting early voting, with the Republican National Committee's political director, Rick Wiley, stating that they will "close the gap" in Iowa.

The trend of early voting is not limited to Iowa, with many battleground states seeing a significant increase in absentee ballots. In Florida, North Carolina, Colorado, and Nevada, as many as 70% of ballots are expected to be cast before November 6th. In Ohio, Wisconsin, and Iowa, the campaigns estimate at least 30% of people will vote early.

While some Republicans acknowledge that the Obama campaign may have an initial advantage in early voting due to Democrats' familiarity with the process, they are working to level the playing field. The Republican Party in Ohio, for example, sent absentee ballot requests to every registered voter in the state.

As the election approaches, both campaigns are deploying resources to "chase ballots" and encourage voters to cast their ballots early. The Obama campaign is sending hundreds of field organizers and volunteers to return envelopes to county election offices, while the Republican Party is sending a mailing to its voters urging them to request an absentee ballot and vote before Election Day.

The outcome of the election remains uncertain, with some voters like Nancy Bobo, 60, expressing confidence in the Obama campaign, while others like Gert Kooi, 76, are firmly behind Mitt Romney. As the election season unfolds, it is clear that early voting is playing a significant role in shaping the outcome.

Title: Trump Receives Endorsement from New Jersey Governor Chris Christie

Article:

In a surprise move, real estate mogul Donald Trump announced on Friday that he had received the endorsement of New Jersey Governor Chris Christie. The endorsement came just a day after Trump's main competitor, Senator Marco Rubio, had a strong performance in the Republican presidential debate. Trump and Christie held a joint press conference in Texas, where Trump praised Christie as an "outstanding man with an outstanding family."

Christie, who has been criticized for his role in the Atlantic City casino industry's decline, has a complicated history with Trump. The two have had public disagreements in the past, with Christie criticizing Trump's temperament and experience in an interview with Greta Van Susteren in August. Trump, on the other hand, has mocked Christie's Bridgegate scandal and suggested that the people of New Jersey want to see him removed from office.

Despite their past differences, Christie said that he and his family decided to support Trump because they believe he is the best candidate to lead the country and prevent Hillary Clinton from becoming president. Christie also emphasized the importance of loyalty, stating that his family has been friends with the Trumps for many years.

It is worth noting that Christie had previously sold his list of donor emails and supporters to Rubio just two weeks ago, and had referred to Rubio as a "robot" during the debate. However, Christie's endorsement of Trump suggests that he may be looking to shift his support to a more viable candidate.

Title: Study Reveals Leftist Dominance in Elite Liberal Arts Colleges

Article:

A recent study by Brooklyn College professor Mitchell Langbert has shed light on the political affiliations of faculty members at top-ranked liberal arts colleges in the United States. The study, titled "Homogeneous: The Political Affiliations of Elite Liberal Arts College Faculty," examines the political leanings of Ph.D.-holding faculty members at 51 of the 66 top-ranked liberal arts colleges according to U.S. News & World Report.

The study found that 39 percent of the colleges in the sample have no registered Republicans on their faculties, and 78 percent of academic departments have no Republican members or so few as to make no significant difference. The Democrat-to-Republican faculty ratio varies widely across departments, with engineering departments having 1.6 Democrats for every Republican, and chemistry and economics departments having about 5.5 Democrats for every Republican.

The study also highlights the stark contrast between the political leanings of college faculty and those of the general American population. According to Pew Research Center surveys, most Americans identify as conservative, yet the majority of college faculty members lean left. This disparity raises concerns about the potential for biased research and academic policy, as well as the potential for students to be indoctrinated with leftist ideologies.

The study's findings are not limited to individual colleges, but also extend to the broader academic culture. Langbert notes that he could not find a single Republican with an exclusive appointment to fields like gender studies, Africana studies, and peace studies. The Democrat-to-Republican faculty ratio is particularly high in anthropology departments, where it is 133-to-1, and in communications departments, where it is 108-to-zero.

The study's results are not surprising, given the political leanings of many college students and faculty members. However, the findings do raise concerns about the potential for biased research and academic policy, as well as the potential for students to be indoctrinated with leftist ideologies.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Health Care Law's Individual Mandate a Tax, Providing Obama with a Political Victory

The Supreme Court's decision to define the individual mandate in the Affordable Care Act as a tax has handed President Obama a significant political victory, allowing him to engage in a four-month-long victory lap as he campaigns for re-election. The ruling validates the president's decision to devote time and energy to getting the legislation passed in 2009, a move that contributed to the Democrats' loss of House control in 2010.

The decision also provides Republicans with a sharper campaign issue, as it highlights the law's tax increases and potential impact on middle-class families. According to the House Ways and Means Committee, the law includes 21 tax increases costing more than $675 billion over the next 10 years, with 12 of those affecting families earning less than $250,000 per year.

President Obama and his rival, presumptive GOP nominee Mitt Romney, engaged in dueling news conferences within two hours of the high court's decision. Romney pledged to repeal the law if elected, while Obama emphasized the law's benefits and downplayed the political benefits of the decision.

The ruling has left some Democrats feeling emboldened, with Democratic strategists arguing that the Supreme Court's decision has aided Obama's agenda and weakened the GOP's opposition. The Obama campaign reported raising funds in the hours following the decision, with Romney's campaign also seeing a surge in donations.

The Supreme Court's decision has provided a significant boost to Obama's re-election campaign, allowing him to tout the law's benefits and defend his decision to devote time and energy to getting it passed. However, the ruling has also provided Republicans with a sharper campaign issue, highlighting the law's tax increases and potential impact on middle-class families.

Title: Federal Debt Projected to Double by 2037, Congressional Budget Office Warns

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released its latest analysis, warning that the federal debt is expected to double by the middle of the next decade and reach more than twice the size of the entire U.S. economy by 2037 unless Congress changes its course on taxes and spending. The CBO's report highlights the country's worst fiscal picture since World War II, with the federal government recording the largest budget deficits since 1945.

The CBO attributes the growing debt to an aging population that requires higher spending on healthcare and higher interest payments on the debt. Public debt is expected to be equal to 70% of gross domestic product at the end of this fiscal year, up from 40% in 2008, and will continue to rise to more than 200% of GDP by 2037. At this level, fiscal catastrophes are more likely, and the government's ability to respond becomes far more constrained.

The CBO notes that the debt does not have to continue growing, as major tax increases and deep spending cuts are already built into the law. However, these measures have repeatedly been met with resistance from both sides of the aisle, with the GOP fighting to permanently extend lower tax rates and Democrats defending existing spending programs and proposing new ones.

The CBO's analysis also provides some interesting snapshots about how the budget and economy will change. The agency predicts that the U.S. population will reach 389 million in 2037 and top 500 million in 2087, with the population skewing ever older. Older workers tend to work fewer hours, meaning that by 2087, the average number of hours worked per employee in the workforce will be about 2% less than in 2022.

The CBO also predicts that the growth in the labor force will slow, keeping economic growth to an average of 2.2% over the long term. The agency also notes that the interest rate on debt will be higher, at an average of 2.7%, a reversal from recent years when economic growth and interest rates were about the same.

The CBO's report highlights the urgent need for Congress to address the country's fiscal challenges and find a balanced solution that includes both spending cuts and revenue increases. The agency's analysis provides a stark warning about the consequences of inaction, with the debt projected to continue growing and the government's ability to respond becoming increasingly constrained.

Title: The Political Implications of Obamacare: A New Chapter in the Debate

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of debate in the United States since its signing into law in 2010. While the economic implications of the act have been widely discussed, the political implications are only now beginning to rise to the surface.

The Democratic Party has long supported health care reform, with President Obama's plan being a key component of his administration's agenda. The plan aimed to increase accessibility and affordability of health care for all Americans, with a focus on protecting Medicare and Medicaid, and reducing inequalities in the system.

However, the Republican Party has been strongly opposed to the plan, citing concerns about its cost and the increased government influence over the health care industry. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the plan is expected to cost taxpayers $1 trillion and will result in the loss of an estimated 80,000 jobs.

Despite the opposition, the plan is set to become a reality, with the phase-in period between 2014 and 2020 expected to cause confusion and uncertainty. Republican governors in red states have taken a different approach, choosing not to set up their own exchanges and instead allowing the federal government to take control.

This new chapter in the debate has sparked concerns about the political implications of Obamacare. Some Republican leaders are using the tactic of blaming the White House for forcing the issue, while others are appealing to voters to keep them in office to watch over the health care system.

The article concludes that the economic cost of implementing Obamacare will be huge, but the economic and political costs of sitting back and doing nothing could be immense. The author argues that red- and blue-state Republicans must continue to oppose the plan vigorously and point out the costs to taxpayers and long-lasting economic damage at every turn.

Overall, the debate surrounding Obamacare is far from over, with both sides presenting their arguments and counterarguments. The political implications of the plan will continue to be a topic of discussion in the coming years.

Title: Uninsured Population in the US Remains Substantial Despite Progress

The uninsured population in the United States has decreased since 2013, but still stands at nearly 30 million people, or 11.9% of the population. This is according to a new book by journalist Elisabeth Rosenthal, who argues that the healthcare system has transformed into a multitrillion-dollar business, perpetuating perverse incentives and exacerbating health inequalities.

A recent series in The Lancet highlights the demographics of the uninsured population, revealing that most individuals without insurance have incomes near or below the poverty line. In 2015, 7.6% of non-poor adults were uninsured, compared to 25.2% of the poor and 24.1% of the near-poor. This means that the poor and near-poor were more than three times more likely to be uninsured than their higher-income counterparts.

The Lancet also notes that racial and ethnic disparities persist, with Hispanics and non-Hispanic blacks having higher uninsurance rates than non-Hispanic whites. The disparities in access to care are wider in the US than in other developed countries, with 39% of Americans with below-average income reporting not seeing a doctor for a medical problem due to cost, compared to 7% of low-income Canadians and 1% of those in the UK.

The Lancet researchers argue that market-based reforms will not address the problem and may even exacerbate inequality. Instead, they advocate for a single-payer, Medicare-for-all reform, as championed by Senator Bernie Sanders. Elisabeth Rosenthal, on the other hand, believes that incremental changes are necessary to unravel the perverse incentives that have built up over time.

The uninsured population in the US has decreased since 2013, but still remains substantial. The data shows that poorer Americans are much more likely to be uninsured than their wealthier counterparts, and racial and ethnic disparities persist.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Adviser George Papadopoulos Sentenced to 14 Days in Prison for Lying to the FBI

George Papadopoulos, a former foreign policy adviser to the Trump campaign, was sentenced to 14 days in federal prison for making false statements to the FBI during the early days of the Justice Department's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in October to lying to the FBI about his meetings in London with a Maltese professor, Joseph Mifsud.

In an interview with ABC's "This Week," Papadopoulos claimed that he felt "pinned" during his FBI interview in January 2017, and that he lied to investigators in an attempt to protect President Donald Trump. He stated that he was unaware of the extent of the investigation into Russian interference in the election at the time of his interview.

Papadopoulos also claimed that he did not incriminate Trump in his 2017 talks with law enforcement, and that he believed he was not made aware of the hacks on Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, or the Democratic National Committee. He testified that he did not tell any Trump campaign officials about his conversation with Mifsud regarding Clinton's emails.

Senator Mark Warner of Virginia, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, expressed skepticism about Papadopoulos' claims, stating that it is unlikely that Papadopoulos did not share his knowledge with other members of the Trump campaign.

Papadopoulos' sentencing comes as part of the special counsel's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. The investigation has led to charges against 12 Russian intelligence officers and several Trump associates, including former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

Title: Trump's Campaign Faces Challenges as Cruz Gains Momentum in Delegate Selection Process

The Trump campaign is facing mounting challenges as the Republican presidential candidate struggles to keep up with the delegate selection process, allowing his rival, Ted Cruz, to gain momentum. Trump has been vocal about his concerns over the process, claiming it is "rigged" against him, but his team has missed crucial deadlines in several states, giving Cruz an advantage.

According to The Washington Post, Cruz could pick up at least 130 additional delegate votes on a second ballot at an open convention, making it harder for Trump to secure the nomination. Trump's campaign has insisted they can still win the nomination outright, but their lack of engagement in the delegate selection process has put them at a disadvantage.

In several states, including Virginia and Arizona, the deadline to apply to be a delegate has passed, and Trump's team is only now starting to engage in the process. In Indiana, for example, the deadline to become a national convention delegate was in mid-March, and 27 of the state's 57 delegates have already been selected.

Trump's campaign is focusing on rallying popular support, which has kept him ahead in the Republican field, but Cruz is banking on his delegate allies to surge over to his side on a second ballot. The Cruz campaign has been more successful in getting supporters elected as delegates, including gaining all 34 delegates in Colorado's state convention.

The dispute over the process has led to a heated exchange between Trump and Cruz, with Trump accusing the Republican National Committee of being "dirty tricksters" and Cruz calling Trump's tactics "union thug" behavior. The tension is building as the race heads into the final stretch, with Indiana's primary on May 3 and the California primary on June 7.

Title: Former US First Lady Laura Bush Condemns Family Separation Policy at Mexican Border

The former US First Lady Laura Bush has publicly condemned the controversial policy of separating children from their parents who illegally enter the country at the Mexican border. In an op-ed published in the Washington Post, Mrs. Bush described the policy as "cruel," "immoral," and "heart-breaking." Her comments come amid growing controversy over President Donald Trump's "zero-tolerance" immigration policy.

According to reports, the policy, introduced by Attorney General Jeff Sessions, separates adults who try to cross the border outside of official entry points from their children, who are then housed in detention centers, including warehouses and converted supermarkets. This has resulted in hundreds of children and babies being kept away from their parents.

Mrs. Bush, wife of former Republican President George W. Bush and a Texas resident, expressed her concerns about the policy, stating that it is reminiscent of the Japanese American internment camps during World War II, which are now considered one of the most shameful episodes in US history. She urged both sides of the aisle to work together to achieve successful immigration reform.

The policy has faced criticism from human rights groups, including the United Nations, which has called it "unconscionable." Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen has defended the agency's role at the border, stating that they do not have a policy of separating families, but rather remove children if the parent they are traveling with has broken the law.

The policy has also been met with resistance from lawmakers, with Democratic lawmakers visiting shelters and processing facilities in New Jersey and Texas, demanding to see detainees. The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a federal lawsuit challenging the policy.

The number of families trying to enter the US overland without documentation is on the rise, with 658 minors, including many babies and toddlers, being separated from their adults in the first two weeks of the new policy. While some families have been reunited after the parent was released from detention, there are reports of people being kept apart for weeks and even months.

Title: House Republicans Demand Release of Trump-Russia Probe Transcripts, Accusing Chairman Schiff of Blocking Transparency

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff has faced criticism from over two dozen House Republicans who are demanding the release of 53 witness interviews from the Trump-Russia probe. The Republicans claim that Schiff is blocking the release of the transcripts, which they believe would provide transparency into the investigation.

In a letter, Representative Jim Jordan, the ranking member on the House Oversight Committee, and 27 other Republican lawmakers stated that the American people deserve to know the truth about the allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. They pointed out that Schiff had previously called for transparency in the investigation, but now seems to be blocking the release of the transcripts.

The House Intelligence Committee voted to release the interviews in September 2018, and a spokesperson for the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) had previously stated that the review process would be completed "very soon." However, the transcripts have yet to be made public. The ODNI has declassified 43 of the 53 interviews, but the remaining 10 transcripts are still being reviewed by the White House as part of the declassification process.

The Republicans are seeking access to the material for their ongoing oversight of the Department of Justice and Federal Bureau of Investigation. On Monday, Representatives Jordan and Mike Johnson asked FBI Director Christopher Wray to turn over all documents and communications related to the FBI's "Crossfire Razor" investigation of former Trump national security adviser Michael Flynn. The request comes after the release of FBI notes that Republicans have argued prove Flynn was ensnared in a "perjury trap."

Title: US Confirms Direct Communication with North Korea Over Missile and Nuclear Programs

The Trump administration has confirmed that it is in direct communication with North Korea over its government's escalating missile and nuclear programs. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson acknowledged the communication channels during his trip to China's capital, Beijing. "We have lines of communication to Pyongyang. We're not in a dark situation, a blackout. We can talk to them. We do talk to them," Tillerson said.

The top US diplomat also stated that the administration has "three channels" open with the regime of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Tillerson emphasized that broad sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear program are beginning to have an effect, citing observations and information from the Chinese government.

However, US Department of State spokesperson Heather Nauert issued a statement saying that while there are "several open channels" for communication with the North Korean government, officials in Pyongyang have shown no indication that they are interested in or ready for talks regarding denuclearization.

Tillerson's comments come after North Korea's foreign minister accused the US of declaring war, in response to President Donald Trump's threat to "totally destroy" North Korea if the US has to defend itself or its allies from the regime. The US has reiterated its willingness to take military action against North Korea, with Trump stating that the US is "totally prepared" for a military option.

The US has been clear that a nuclear-armed North Korea will never be acceptable, and it will be challenging to convince North Korea's leaders to change their stance. The US has estimated that North Korea controls as many as 60 nuclear weapons, although some experts believe the number is smaller. The value of negotiating directly with North Korea remains a topic of debate among US officials and allies, with some expressing skepticism about the effectiveness of such talks.

Title: Republicans and Democrats Clash Over Debt Ceiling, Spending Cuts

The debate over the debt ceiling and spending cuts has intensified, with Republicans and Democrats refusing to budge. President Obama has called Republican threats to hold the line on the nation's borrowing "irresponsible," while Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, believes the debt-limit debate is the perfect opportunity to force Democrats to address the deficit.

The president has warned that Republican threats to default on the nation's debts are "absurd" and would send stock markets tumbling and derail any hope of a serious economic recovery this year. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, Virginia Republican, has pushed back, saying the American people deserve better from Washington and that the country cannot deliver meaningful change and necessary reforms without addressing out-of-control spending.

The White House has not complied with a February 4 deadline to send its budget to Congress, which has been criticized by Rep. Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican and vice presidential nominee last year. The Tea Party Patriots have also weighed in, saying President Obama has spent four years driving up the deficit and stalling on spending cuts, forcing Republicans to take drastic action.

The debate has also sparked discussions about the possibility of shutting down the government to force spending cuts. Some Republicans are embracing the idea, while the White House has said there will be no negotiations over raising the debt ceiling. The Treasury has informed the president and Congress that it will run out of short-term fixes within weeks, and the Bipartisan Policy Center says the Treasury will run out of options on meeting the government's bills between February 15 and March 1.

The debate is ongoing, with both sides refusing to budge.

Title: Former Wrestler Accuses Rep. Jim Jordan of Ignoring Sexual Abuse Allegations During His Tenure at Ohio State University

Article:

A seventh former wrestler at Ohio State University has come forward, accusing Representative Jim Jordan (R-OH) of being aware of the sexual abuse allegations against team doctor Richard Strauss during his time as an assistant coach in the 1980s and 1990s. The allegations have been corroborated by four other former teammates, who claim that Jordan had to have known about the abuse but did nothing to stop it.

David Range, who wrestled for Ohio State in the late 1980s, stated that Jordan was aware of the abuse, saying, "Jordan definitely knew that these things were happening – yes, most definitely. It was there. He knew about it because it was an everyday occurrence."

While no one has accused Jordan of engaging in any abusive behavior himself, several former athletes have expressed resentment towards him for denying knowledge of the abuse. Jordan has maintained that he was unaware of the allegations, but his denial has been met with skepticism by some.

In a recent interview on Fox News, Jordan acknowledged that the culture on the wrestling team during his time as an assistant coach was "pretty common knowledge" that something was amiss. However, he has not apologized for his role in the scandal and has even threatened at least one victim of sexual assault with the Capitol Police.

The controversy has raised questions about Jordan's leadership abilities and his potential to hold a leadership position in the Republican caucus.

Title: Climate Activist Greta Thunberg Criticized for Being Used as a Pawn by Adults

Article:

Greta Thunberg, the 16-year-old climate activist, addressed the United Nations Climate Action Summit in September 2019, delivering a stern rebuke to world leaders. She accused them of stealing her dreams and childhood, saying "You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words." However, some critics argue that Thunberg is being used as a pawn by adults seeking to advance their own interests.

The article suggests that Thunberg's activism is part of a larger youth movement against climate change, which is being promoted and celebrated by adults who find it useful for their own purposes. The author argues that kids are powerful pawns, and that adults are using them to further their own agendas.

The article also criticizes the idea that young people have a unique perspective on complex issues like climate change. The author notes that children often repeat back what they've been told by adults, with less nuance and maturity. The article cites statistics showing that many of the improvements in social and economic well-being for children over the past few decades, such as a decrease in poverty and an increase in life expectancy, have been achieved by adults.

The author argues that the apocalyptic warnings about climate change being spread by adults are causing anxiety and depression in some young people, and that this is a result of adults not providing a balanced view of the issue. The article concludes that children will be all right, and that they will grow up even in a warming world.

Title: US and China Agree to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions Over Next Two Decades

The United States and China, the world's two largest economies and greenhouse gas emitters, have announced a historic agreement to curb their carbon emissions over the next two decades. Under the agreement, the US will reduce its 2005 level of carbon emissions by 26-28% by 2025, while China will peak its carbon emissions by 2030 and aim to generate 20% of its energy from zero-carbon emission sources by the same year.

The agreement marks the first time China has agreed to peak its carbon emissions, according to the White House. US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced the deal during a joint news conference in Beijing, stating that the two countries have a special responsibility to lead the global effort against climate change.

The agreement is seen as a significant step towards addressing the global issue of climate change, with the Center for Climate and Energy Solutions calling it an "extremely hopeful sign" that will help get other countries on board. The deal could also put climate change back on the G20 agenda, said researcher David Holmes of Monash University in Australia.

While some experts have expressed skepticism about the ambitiousness of the goals, others have praised the agreement as a major milestone. The World Wildlife Fund's CEO, Lo Sze Ping, noted that the agreement is important because both countries are taking responsibility to act and work together to resolve the problem, rather than the numbers or targets themselves.

The Obama administration hopes to sell the plan back home by touting the anticipated savings on energy costs, with initiatives and incentives to develop more solar and wind power in both countries. However, some Republicans have expressed concerns that the plan will hurt the US economy and increase utility rates.

The agreement also includes China's commitment to provide 800-1,000 gigawatts of nuclear, wind, solar, and other zero-emission generation capacity by 2030, exceeding the current capacity of all coal-fired power plants in China and close to the total current electricity generation capacity in the US.

During Obama's visit to Beijing, the Chinese government closed factories and gave employees time off to reduce car traffic and emissions in Beijing, resulting in a noticeable reduction of smog and blue skies throughout the APEC summit. The agreement also covers other areas, including denuclearizing the Korean peninsula, cybersecurity, strengthening military relations, and increasing trade.

The agreement is seen as a significant step towards addressing the global issue of climate change, and its success will depend on the cooperation and commitment of both countries to achieve their goals.

Title: Thousands of Migrants from Central America Abandoned in US Cities, Sparking Concerns Over Humanitarian Crisis

The US authorities have been apprehending scores of illegal immigrants attempting to cross the border from the Rio Grande Valley, with many being flown, bused, and then abandoned in cities like Arizona, New York, and Maryland. However, unlike immigrants from Mexico, those from Central American countries like El Salvador and Guatemala are not being easily returned to their countries of origin due to the complexity and cost of the process.

The surge in apprehensions in the Rio Grande Valley has led to a significant increase in the number of immigrants being transported to other states, with Arizona being a major destination. According to Border Patrol agents, the Rio Grande Valley sector apprehended 154,453 immigrants last year, a significant jump from the previous year.

The situation has sparked concerns over a humanitarian crisis, with reports of horrific stories of violence and abuse faced by children and families on their journey to the US-Mexico border. Some have reported being raped and murdered on their way to the border.

One such family, Floridalma Bineda Portillo and her two young boys, were part of a group of about 400 Central Americans who were flown from Texas to Tucson and then shuttled to Phoenix. When they arrived, a volunteer nurse found Bineda Portillo's five-year-old son, Hugo David, wheezing and struggling to breathe due to his asthma, and his three-year-old brother developed a cold after sitting on the floor for hours in the detention center.

The US Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has stated that it does not want to lock up minors in detention centers or split up families, and instead plans to release them under supervision and require them to report to a local ICE office near their destination address within 15 days.

Volunteers from the Phoenix Restoration Project, a humanitarian group, have been providing food, clothing, diapers, and other supplies to the migrants at the Greyhound station in Phoenix. The group has reported seeing many women who are scared, vulnerable, and struggling to communicate due to language barriers.

The situation has sparked concerns over the treatment of migrants and the effectiveness of the US immigration system. Senator Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., has called it a "humanitarian crisis" and urged a humanitarian response.

Title: MSNBC's Nicolle Wallace Criticizes President Trump for Sharing Altered Video of Speaker Pelosi

Article: MSNBC's Nicolle Wallace, a former White House communications director and GOP campaign aide, criticized President Donald Trump on her show "Deadline: White House" for sharing an altered video of Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.). The video, which was slowed down to make it seem like Pelosi was stuttering, was shared by Trump on Twitter, reaching his 60.5 million followers.

Wallace noted that while the video itself was not doctored, the slowed-down version had the effect of making anyone appear to be having a hard time speaking. She also pointed out that Trump has been a victim of doctored videos himself, playing a clip that showed a campaign speech that had been altered.

Wallace decided not to air the original clip shared by Trump, instead opting to show her own slowed-down video to demonstrate the effect. She stated that her show believes transparency is the best way to combat dirty politics, and therefore, broke down the president's actions to smear the Speaker of the House.

In response, Trump denied knowledge of the altered videos and praised his ability to work with Pelosi before accusing her of "not helping the country." The president's actions have sparked controversy, with many criticizing him for spreading misinformation and engaging in political smear tactics.

Title: Clinton Campaign Warns Against Complacency as Trump's Campaign Seeks to Make Up Ground

The Hillary Clinton campaign is cautioning against complacency as new poll numbers suggest Donald Trump may be gaining momentum in the final days of the election. The Clinton campaign is focusing on states in once safely Republican territory, pouring resources into television advertising and local organizing efforts. This strategy could help the Democratic candidate surpass the 270 electoral college votes needed to win the White House and potentially flip control of Congress.

Meanwhile, Trump's campaign is relying on raucous swing state rallies and a message of anti-establishment fervor to appeal to undecided voters. Trump's campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, acknowledged that the candidate is behind, but believes the electoral map has shifted in their favor. Conway pointed to Trump's ability to connect directly with voters and his continued support from a base of enthusiastic supporters.

Some Republicans, however, are skeptical that Trump can overcome his deficit in the remaining two weeks. Karl Rove, a veteran strategist, expressed doubt that Trump can win over enough voters to make a difference.

The Clinton campaign is also targeting Republicans who have stood by Trump despite his controversial comments and actions. The campaign is seeking to hold them accountable for their support and is trying to appeal to reasonable Republicans and independents who may be willing to defect across party lines.

In a statement, Trump's son Eric said his father would "100% accept the results of the election if it's fair." The Clinton campaign is warning against complacency, but Trump's campaign is seeking to make up ground in the final stretch of the election.

**Moderna's COVID-19 Vaccine Candidate Shows Promise in Early Trial**

A candidate vaccine against COVID-19 developed by the federal government and Moderna has shown promise in an early phase trial, with data indicating it is safe and triggers an immune response. The vaccine, mRNA-1273, is being developed using a new technology that uses genetic material to trick the body into producing critical antibodies before infection.

The trial, led by the Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health, involved 45 participants divided into three groups, each receiving a different dose of the vaccine. All participants showed evidence of an immune reaction, which is the goal of immunization. The most common side effects were mild, with more than half of participants experiencing fatigue, chills, headache, or muscle pain.

While the results are promising, it is unclear whether the vaccine will provide sufficient protection against the coronavirus. Experts note that the levels of protective antibodies produced by the trial participants were similar to those found in patients who had recovered from COVID-19, suggesting the vaccine may provide similar protection. However, more research is needed to determine the vaccine's effectiveness.

A larger Phase 3 trial with 30,000 participants is set to begin in July, and the company aims to have a vaccine ready in limited batches by January or next summer. The development process is accelerated, with the first volunteer receiving the vaccine on March 16, just two months after the genetic sequence of the virus was revealed.

Moderna's chief medical officer, Tal Zaks, expressed optimism about the results, stating that all indications are that the vaccine will be safe and effective. However, experts caution that it is too early to know whether the vaccine will be protective, and more research is needed to determine its effectiveness.

Title: Obama Administration Takes Gun Legislation Efforts Outside of Washington

The Obama administration is taking its push for gun legislation outside of the nation's capital, a move that may be a nod to the challenges any gun control bills will face in Washington. Vice President Joe Biden held a round-table discussion in Richmond, Virginia, speaking with individuals who worked on gun safety after the 2007 Virginia Tech shooting.

Biden, who became the administration's point person on guns following the Sandy Hook school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut, released recommendations last week that include renewing the assault weapons ban, limiting the size of ammunition magazines, and universal background checks. However, the effort does not stop there, as Biden emphasized the need to continue gathering insights from experts and stakeholders across the country.

The discussion in Richmond was joined by Democratic Senator Tim Kaine, who was governor of Virginia at the time of the Virginia Tech shooting. Kaine emphasized the importance of working together to reduce gun violence, citing an improved background records check system implemented in Virginia after the shooting.

Biden also spoke about the devastating impact of gun violence, particularly in the wake of the Sandy Hook shooting, which claimed the lives of 20 children and six adults. "What happened up in Newtown – beautiful little babies, 6 and 7 years old, riddled, riddled with bullet holes. Twenty of them dead. I've met with most of their parents. It is a national tragedy," he said.

Meanwhile, Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat from California, introduced a new assault weapons ban, but acknowledged the uphill battle ahead. "This is really an uphill road," she said. "If anyone asks today: Can you win this? The answer is we don't know. It's so uphill."

The National Rifle Association (NRA) quickly responded, stating that Senator Feinstein has been trying to ban guns from law-abiding citizens for decades. "The American people know gun bans do not work and we are confident Congress will reject Senator Feinstein's wrong-headed approach," the NRA said.

Philadelphia Police Commissioner Charles Ramsey spoke at Senator Feinstein's press conference, expressing frustration that the cycle of mass shootings often leads to inaction. "And then it's business as usual as lobbyists begin to quietly go about trying to influence the outcome of any legislation that's passed," he said.

Senator Feinstein emphasized that if her bill and others are to have any chance of passing, the push will need to come from outside of Washington. "If America rises up, if people care enough to call every member of the House and every member of the Senate and say, 'We have had enough,'" she said.

The Obama administration is encouraging supporters to take action and has set up a website for reporting conversations with lawmakers. A Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday will provide an early indication of the mood in Congress, with Wayne LaPierre of the NRA and Mark Kelly, the husband of former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, set to testify.

Title: Bombshell Revelation Sparks Speculation Over Mysterious Death of Ex-KGB Agent

A recent testimony from attorney Joshua Levy, representing Fusion GPS founder Glenn Simpson, has sparked a guessing game about the identity of someone killed as a result of the publication of an unverified and salacious dossier about Donald Trump. The transcript, released by Senator Dianne Feinstein, reveals that Levy stated, "Somebody's already been killed as a result of the publication of this dossier and no harm should come to anybody related to this honest work."

The cryptic reference has led to speculation about who the unlucky person might be. One of the most popular theories is that it refers to Oleg Erovinkin, a former KGB general found dead in his car in Moscow in December 2016. According to a January 2017 report by The Telegraph, Erovinkin was a top aide to Igor Sechin, a former deputy prime minister mentioned repeatedly in the dossier. The KGB chief was also suspected of helping former MI6 spy Christopher Steele compile information on Trump for the dossier.

Erovinkin's death was initially reported as a heart attack, but local media suggested foul play might have been involved. The book "Collusion: Secret Meetings, Dirty Money, and How Russia Helped Donald Trump Win" by British journalist Luke Harding details the circumstances of his death, stating that his body was found in a desolate street with no cafes or businesses, making it an ideal spot for an assassination.

Theories about Erovinkin's involvement in the dossier have been circulating since his death. Christo Grozev of Risk Management Lab, a think-tank based in Bulgaria, claimed in a January 2017 Haaretz article that Erovinkin was the main source of information for the dossier. Grozev stated that Erovinkin was known as "Sechin's treasurer" and "the go-between between Putin and Sechin," and that he was Sechin's closest associate.

Grozev also suggested that Russian President Vladimir Putin would have had a motive to seek and find the mole responsible for the dossier, given his close ties to Erovinkin and Sechin. However, Levy did not immediately respond to requests for information about who he was referring to in his testimony.

Title: North Korea Threatens to Counter US Military Exercises with "Own Mode of Counteraction"

SEOUL (Yonhap) - North Korea has threatened to take countermeasures against the United States if it proceeds with joint military exercises with South Korea, scheduled to begin in early April. The North Korean government stated that it will not beg for talks with Washington and will not evade the military option claimed by the US.

According to the official KCNA news agency, North Korea views the joint exercises as a threat to reconciliation efforts on the peninsula. The agency quoted a North Korean foreign ministry spokesman as saying, "We will neither beg for dialogue nor evade the military option claimed by the U.S." The spokesman added that the fate of the Korean peninsula depends entirely on the attitude of the US.

The US has imposed its largest package of sanctions on North Korea in February, aimed at pressuring the country to give up its nuclear and missile programs. North Korea has slammed the sanctions, but has expressed willingness to talk to the US. However, it has emphasized that any talks must be unconditional.

The White House has stated that any talks with North Korea must lead to an end of its nuclear program. South Korea plans to send a special envoy to North Korea in response to an invitation from leader Kim Jong Un, as announced by President Moon Jae-in during a phone call with US President Donald Trump.

The recent Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang brought a boost to engagement between the two Koreas, following a period of sharply rising tensions over North Korea's missile program.

**Hyde-Smith Wins Mississippi Senate Runoff, Secures Republican Seat**

In a decisive victory, Cindy Hyde-Smith emerged as the winner of the Mississippi Senate runoff election, defeating Democrat Mike Espy by almost 8 percentage points. With 97% of the vote counted, Hyde-Smith secured 53.9% of the vote, while Espy garnered 46.1%.

The outcome was in line with most pre-runoff public polls. Hyde-Smith, a Republican, thanked God, her family, and President Trump, who made rally stops in Tupelo and Biloxi on Monday, just hours before polls opened. In her speech, she emphasized her commitment to representing every Mississippian, regardless of their political affiliation.

Espy, 64, trailed Hyde-Smith by just a point on Election Day but failed to break the 50% threshold, leading to the runoff. He addressed a dejected crowd in Jackson, acknowledging Hyde-Smith's victory and expressing his support for her as she heads to Washington.

The runoff election garnered significant attention, with many expecting a closer outcome. However, Hyde-Smith's victory cemented the Republican majority in the Senate at 53-47.

The campaign was marked by controversy, with both candidates facing scrutiny over past comments and actions. Hyde-Smith faced criticism for her comments about a "public hanging" in a state with a dark history of lynchings, while Espy's checkered past, including indictments and lucrative lobbying work, were highlighted by the Hyde-Smith campaign. Despite these challenges, neither candidate's momentum was significantly impacted, and the election ultimately came down to voter turnout and persuasion.

Hyde-Smith's victory makes her the first woman to be elected U.S. senator in Mississippi, while Espy would have become the first black person elected to the office since Reconstruction.

Title: Senate to Consider Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, Exposing Democrats' Commitment to Unlimited Legal Abortion

The Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act, reintroduced by Senator Ben Sasse (R., Neb.) in January 2019, aims to require doctors to provide ordinary medical care to infants who are born alive after an attempted abortion. The legislation has sparked controversy, with Democrats voting to block it and claiming that "born-alive" infants do not exist. However, evidence suggests that infants do survive late-term abortion procedures with some regularity.

The bill's opponents argue that laws already exist to prevent infanticide, but this is not entirely accurate. While some states have laws in place, there is no federal law requiring doctors to provide life-saving care to infants who survive abortions. Only 33 states have such laws, and New York repealed its born-alive protections last year.

The bill's opponents also claim that it would place government between women and doctors, limiting healthcare options. However, the bill does not regulate when or whether healthcare or abortion may be made available to women; it simply requires doctors to treat newborns who survive abortion the way they would treat any other newborn infant.

The debate surrounding the bill highlights the crucial question of whether the right to abortion includes the right to deny medical care to a newborn infant who was targeted for abortion. While some lawmakers may support the bill, others will likely continue to oppose it, maintaining that the right to abortion includes the right to let an infant die of neglect if they were planned to have been killed a second before.

Title: US Special Forces Rescue Operation Foiled as Al-Qaeda Affiliate Kills American Journalist and South African Teacher

Article:

A US special forces operation aimed at rescuing American journalist Luke Somers and South African teacher Pierre Korkie from al-Qaeda affiliate Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) in Yemen ended in tragedy on Friday night. The operation, which involved US special forces and Yemeni soldiers, was launched in response to AQAP's threat to kill the hostages if the US did not pay a ransom. Unfortunately, the terrorists mortally wounded the hostages before the special forces could reach them, and both Somers and Korkie died during the rescue attempt.

According to Pentagon officials, the US special forces were just moments away from the village where the hostages were being held when they were attacked. The terrorists had attempted to murder the hostages, and by the time the special forces arrived, both Somers and Korkie had suffered serious injuries. The hostages were then evacuated to a nearby US Navy ship, where Somers died en route and Korkie died shortly after arrival.

The US policy of not paying ransoms to terrorists is a controversial topic, with many countries opting to pay ransoms to secure the release of their citizens. However, the US believes that paying ransoms would only encourage more kidnappings and instead uses its military to rescue its citizens. This policy has been criticized for putting American hostages at greater risk.

The recent increase in terrorist groups taking and murdering American hostages, including the deaths of several journalists and aid workers, can be seen as a conflict between jihadists and the US over its ransom-paying policy. While it is unclear who will prevail, the US government has insisted it will not bend, but public pressure could change that. In the meantime, American journalists and aid workers abroad will continue to be targeted as pawns in this conflict.

Title: Trump Campaign Adviser's Drunken Conversation with Australian Diplomat Sparked Counterintelligence Investigation

A recent report by The New York Times reveals that a drunken conversation between a Trump campaign adviser, George Papadopoulos, and an Australian diplomat, Alexander Downer, in May 2016 was one of the catalysts for the counterintelligence investigation into the Trump campaign. According to the report, Papadopoulos told Downer that the Russian government had dirt on Hillary Clinton.

Papadopoulos, a 30-year-old energy consultant, claimed to have been told by a London-based associate, Joseph Mifsud, that Russian government officials had obtained Clinton emails. It is unclear whether Papadopoulos shared this information with anyone in the Trump campaign.

Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in October to lying to the FBI about his encounters with Mifsud and at least two Russian nationals. As part of his plea deal, Papadopoulos agreed to cooperate with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

The FBI became aware of Papadopoulos' claims more than two months after the London meeting with Downer. The Australian government decided to share the information with U.S. investigators after emails stolen from Democrats began to be released by WikiLeaks.

According to current and former law enforcement officials, the Papadopoulos lead, and not the infamous Steele dossier, was what sparked the counterintelligence investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Kremlin operatives.

The article also provides new details about Papadopoulos' interactions with an alleged source for the dossier, Sergei Millian, the chairman of the Russian-American Chamber of Commerce. Millian has been identified as a source for some of the more salacious allegations about blackmail material on Trump and about collusion between the Trump campaign and Kremlin.

Title: Attorney General Barr Vows to Release Redacted Mueller Report Within a Week

Attorney General William Barr testified before a congressional panel on Capitol Hill, pushing back against Democratic criticism over his handling of the initial summary of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia report. Barr stated that his office is working diligently to prepare the report's release, with a goal of making it available to the public within a week.

Barr identified four areas of the report that he believes should be redacted, including grand jury material, information that could reveal intelligence sources and methods, material that could interfere with ongoing prosecutions, and information that could implicate the privacy or reputational interests of "peripheral players." The Justice Department plans to "color code the decisions from the report and provide explanatory notes describing the basis for each redaction."

Despite the criticism from Democrats, Barr maintained that he is working to make as much information as possible available to Congress. However, lawmakers from both parties expressed concerns over the redactions and the four-page summary of the report, which concluded that there was no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election.

House Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Nita Lowey, D-N.Y., accused Barr of "cherry-picking" from the report to draw the most favorable conclusion possible for the president. Other Democrats echoed her concerns, with Subcommittee Chairman José Serrano, D-N.Y., stating that the American people have been left with many unanswered questions and that it is a blow to the system and democracy if the report is not seen.

The Justice Department defended Barr's rollout of Mueller's conclusions, stating that every page of the report was marked as potentially containing grand jury material and therefore could not be immediately released.

Title: UN Report Warns of Al Qaeda's Resurgence as ISIS Fades Away

The United Nations has released a report warning that Al Qaeda, led by the son of Osama bin Laden, could become the next major terror threat in the region. The report, delivered to the Security Council and released this week, highlights the ongoing threat posed by both ISIS and Al Qaeda.

According to the report, ISIS has rallied in early 2018 and still has approximately 20,000-30,000 members in Iraq and Syria. Although the U.S.-led coalition has made significant military gains against the group, ISIS is adapting and evolving into a covert network that continues to threaten other countries. The report notes that the group's leadership remains intact under Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi.

Meanwhile, Al Qaeda has been gaining strength, particularly in Somalia, Yemen, and South Asia. The report states that Al Qaeda's leadership demonstrates strategic patience and its regional affiliates exercise good tactical judgment, embedding themselves in local issues and becoming players. Hamza bin Laden, Osama bin Laden's son, has emerged as a leadership figure in Al Qaeda.

The report also highlights the growing prominence of Al Qaeda's leadership in Iran and notes that improved leadership and enhanced communication will likely increase the threat over time. The report comes amid growing international concern about the civil war in Yemen between the Saudi-led coalition and the Iran-backed Houthis. Al Qaeda in the Arab Peninsula (AQAP) has gained a foothold in the south of the war-torn country amid the chaos.

The report's findings are a reminder that the global fight against terrorism is far from over. As the international community continues to grapple with the challenges posed by ISIS and Al Qaeda, it is essential to remain vigilant and adapt to the evolving nature of these threats.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Flock to South Carolina Fish Fry, Testing Support Among Black Voters

The fish fry in Columbia, South Carolina, hosted by U.S. Representative Jim Clyburn, drew the largest crowd of Democratic presidential candidates yet, giving them a chance to gauge support among black voters, a crucial bloc in the early primary state next year. Twenty-one of the 24 major candidates seeking the party's 2020 nomination attended the event, which acts as an unofficial kickoff to the Democratic primary race in South Carolina.

The event allowed contenders to hobnob with Clyburn's political network while attendees enjoyed an estimated 4,400 pounds of fried fish and 6,400 slices of bread. South Carolina holds the fourth nominating contest early next year, with about 60% of the Democratic electorate being black.

Political strategists say the state is any candidate's to win, with contenders like U.S. Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker investing heavily in South Carolina and viewing it as critical to their path to the nomination. However, the candidates, who are both black and frequently discuss race during their campaigns, have not seen a corresponding bump in polls.

A recent Post and Courier-Change Research Poll showed former Vice President Joe Biden leading with 37% support among likely primary voters, followed by Senator Elizabeth Warren and Mayor Pete Buttigieg. Harris and Booker trailed behind, with 9% and 5% support, respectively.

The poll also showed Biden maintaining a dominant lead among black voters at 52%. Seawright, a Democratic strategist, cautioned that at this point in the race, polls nationwide and in South Carolina mainly reflect familiarity with the candidates, with Biden enjoying widespread name recognition due to serving eight years as vice president for Barack Obama.

Many South Carolina primary voters live in rural areas without high-speed broadband internet, requiring outreach to be done on the ground. "You can't just do the new wave of campaigning where you run digital ads and get on TV," Seawright said. "You have to have a real grassroots activated program, knocking on doors, visiting synagogues and places of worship, showing up at community events, going to the fish fries, going to family reunions."

Harris has stepped up her outreach to historically black colleges and universities by adding a section to her campaign website dedicated to organizing student groups, particularly fraternities and sororities. South Carolina has eight historically black colleges and universities (HBCU), and Harris attended another, Howard University, in Washington.

The candidates attending the fish fry echoed the sentiment that once the primary is over, the party should unite behind its nominee. "When the primary is over we become a united force," Booker said.

Title: Puerto Rico Governor Requests Investigation into Whitefish Energy Contract

The Puerto Rico Governor, Ricardo Rossello, has sent a letter to the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general's office requesting an investigation into the $300 million contract awarded to Whitefish Energy, a small Montana-based company, to restore power on the island. The contract has raised questions about the company's lack of experience and its connection to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke's hometown.

The governor's request comes as San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz, a frequent opponent of President Donald Trump, got into a Twitter feud with Whitefish Energy. Cruz accused the company of admitting political motivations, while Whitefish responded by asking if it should send its workers home or continue working in the city.

Whitefish later apologized for its comments, stating that it wished to make good progress and help everyone in Puerto Rico. The company has mobilized a team of nearly 300 subcontractors to help restore the island's electrical infrastructure in the wake of Hurricane Maria.

Many lawmakers on Capitol Hill have also called for an investigation into the contract, questioning why the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority chose to work with Whitefish instead of reaching out to the American Public Power Association, which normally matches states hit by disasters with nearby public power utilities who have offered up crews and equipment.

Founded in 2015, Whitefish says it has called Puerto Rico before Maria hit to pitch its own services. The company has mobilized a team of nearly 300 subcontractors in Puerto Rico, with more on the way, to help restore the island's electrical infrastructure.

Senator Marco Rubio, R-Fla., stated that Whitefish "showed up at the right place at the right time and that's how they got the contract." He emphasized the importance of restoring power to the island, as every day without power is a day the economy is not functioning and people are suffering.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) had questions about how the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority awarded the contract to Whitefish Energy, but stated that it appeared to comply 100 percent with FEMA regulations. Only 25 percent of the island has power 35 days after Maria hit the island.

Title: Trump Administration to Expand Pro-Life Mexico City Policy, Allocating $8.8 Billion in Global Health Assistance Funds

The Trump administration is set to announce a new policy, "Protecting Life in Global Health Assistance," which will significantly expand the scope of the Mexico City Policy. The policy, reinstated by President Trump in January, requires non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to agree not to perform or promote abortion as a method of family planning in other nations.

The new policy will allocate $8.8 billion in global health assistance funds to various federal agencies and departments, including the Department of State, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and the Department of Defense. This is a significant increase from the previous policy, which only applied to family-planning assistance provided by USAID and the Department of State, with a budget of around $600 million.

The policy will apply to global health assistance funding for international health programs, including those for HIV/AIDS, maternal and child health, malaria, global health security, and family planning and reproductive health. However, it will not apply to humanitarian assistance, such as migration and refugee-assistance activities, USAID disaster and humanitarian-relief activities, and U.S. Department of Defense disaster and humanitarian relief.

NGOs that refuse to agree to the pro-life guidelines will lose out on the funding, but funds will be given to other organizations that comply. A White House official emphasized that foreign NGOs that agree not to perform or promote abortion as a method of family planning will remain eligible for global health assistance funding.

The policy is seen as a winning issue for the Trump administration, with a January Marist Poll showing 83% of Americans oppose federal funding of overseas abortions. The poll also found that nearly 40% of people who supported Clinton in the 2016 election supported the ban on federal funding of overseas abortions.

Title: At Least 25 Women Have Accused President Trump of Sexual Misconduct Since the 1970s

The #MeToo movement has brought renewed attention to allegations of sexual misconduct against President Donald Trump, with at least 25 women accusing him of inappropriate behavior since the 1970s. Trump has repeatedly denied the allegations, calling his accusers "liars."

The allegations against Trump include claims of ogling, harassment, groping, and rape, with some women coming forward in the months leading up to the 2016 presidential election and others doing so after the election. Trump has dismissed the allegations as "fabricated" and "politically motivated," promising to sue his accusers during the election.

In June 2019, columnist E. Jean Carroll accused Trump of sexually assaulting her in a Bergdorf Goodman dressing room in the mid-1990s. Trump has denied the allegations, saying that Carroll's story is "false" and "politically motivated."

The allegations against Trump have been made by women from various backgrounds, including former Miss USA pageant contestants, business associates, and acquaintances. Some of the accusers have spoken publicly about their experiences, while others have remained anonymous.

Despite Trump's denials, a Quinnipiac poll in December 2017 found that 50% of voters believed the allegations against him were disqualifying, with 59% of women and 41% of men surveyed agreeing that he should resign as a result of the allegations.

The #MeToo movement has given some women the courage to come forward and share their stories, with some saying they are trying to "try round two" and show America who Trump really is and how he views women.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Arguments on Same-Sex Marriage Ban

The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Proposition 8, a ban on same-sex marriage in California. The court will hear from lawyers representing both sides of the issue, with proponents arguing that preserving the traditional definition of marriage is a rational reason to uphold the ban, while opponents claim that it violates equal protection principles.

Lawyers for the proponents, led by Charles J. Cooper, will have 30 minutes to present their case, likely focusing on the reasons offered to support the ban and the standing of their clients. Opponents, led by David Boies, will have 20 minutes to argue why the issue should be withdrawn from public debate and the fast-moving political process. Solicitor General Donald Verrilli will have 10 minutes to discuss shifts in the Obama administration's positions.

The court will consider whether the ban violates the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment, which prohibits states from denying any person the equal protection of the laws. Gay rights advocates are hoping the court will adopt a more robust standard of review, known as "heightened scrutiny," which requires a showing that the challenged law is "substantially related to an important government objective."

Proponents of the ban argue that preserving the traditional definition of marriage is a rational reason to uphold the ban, citing the importance of responsible procreation and child-rearing. They claim that allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry would undermine these societal interests and that courts must respect societal judgments made through the democratic process.

Opponents argue that the ban is unconstitutional and that courts must protect the fundamental rights of disfavored minorities. They claim that allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry would not make it more likely that straight couples would act irresponsibly.

The court's decision is difficult to predict, with Justice Anthony Kennedy likely holding the decisive vote. He has been the author of two leading gay rights cases, but his views on the issue are hard to read. Chief Justice John Roberts may be intrigued by the standing question, which could suggest whether he might find dismissal on that ground an attractive offramp.

The court's options include upholding the ban, striking it down, or adopting a rationale that would apply only to California. The Obama administration has suggested an "eight-state solution" that would allow same-sex marriage in certain states, while the court could also dismiss the case for lack of standing, effectively allowing same-sex marriages in California.

Title: Cybersecurity Firm Claims 17-Year-Old Russian Teen Authored Malware Behind Target Data Breach, Blogger Disputes Report

A California-based cybersecurity firm, IntelCrawler, has made a claim that a 17-year-old Russian teenager authored the malware behind the massive Target data breach that affected up to 110 million customers. However, the claim was disputed by Brian Krebs, a widely followed Internet security blogger and former Washington Post reporter.

According to IntelCrawler, the teenager allegedly sold the malware, known as BlackPOS, for about $2,000 to dozens of cybercriminals in Eastern Europe and other countries. The firm's president, Dan Clements, stated that IntelCrawler's CEO had previously reported on the malware earlier last year, identifying the teenager as the author and a well-known programmer of malicious code in the underground world.

Target, the nation's second-largest retailer, has apologized for the security breach, which occurred during the holiday season. The same malware may have been involved in a similar but smaller attack on luxury retailer Neiman Marcus around the same time. The retailers have declined to comment on the incidents.

The malware allegedly enabled thieves to remotely hack into Target's computer systems and obtain customer credit card numbers and other information, which was then sent back to a computer controlled by cyber thieves. State and federal officials, including the Secret Service, have launched an extensive investigation into the breaches.

Title: Federal Regulator Approves Powdered Alcoholic Beverage, Palcohol, Despite Controversy

The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has given the greenlight to Palcohol, a powdered alcohol product intended to be mixed with water to create a drink. This decision comes after the TTB initially approved the product last year, only to later retract the approval due to labeling issues. However, the agency has since resolved these concerns and approved four varieties of Palcohol.

The product, developed by Mark Phillips, comes in a pouch and requires the addition of water to create an equivalent of an alcoholic drink. The four approved flavors include cosmopolitan, margarita, vodka, and rum, with another product, Lemon Drop, expected to be approved shortly.

While Palcohol's approval is a step forward for the company, several states have already moved to ban the product, citing concerns about abuse by minors, the potential for snorting the powder, and the ease of sneaking it into public events or spiking drinks. Lawmakers in Colorado have even advanced legislation to temporarily halt the sale of Palcohol.

The TTB's approval process involves reviewing the product's labeling to ensure it accurately reflects what's inside. According to TTB spokesman Tom Hogue, the agency regularly consults with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to determine whether a product might be considered "adulterated." If the FDA clears the product, the TTB evaluates the labeling to ensure it meets regulatory standards.

Hogue noted that the potential for abuse is not grounds for denying a label, and the agency's primary concern is ensuring accurate labeling. Palcohol's founder, Mark Phillips, hopes to have the product available for sale this summer, although pricing has not yet been determined.

Title: Republicans Face Long-Term Challenge to Revamp Party Infrastructure and Demographic Appeal

Article:

The Republican Party is facing a significant challenge to revamp its political infrastructure and demographic appeal after a decisive defeat in the 2012 presidential election. The party's leaders acknowledge that it will take national leadership and a broad overhaul to address the structural problems that led to the electoral blowout.

GOP leaders agree that the party needs to reach out to Americans beyond its predominantly white, male base and update its voter turnout machine, which is woefully out of date. Florida Senator Marco Rubio's name was mentioned repeatedly as a potential national leader who could help the party begin the process of bouncing back.

The party's leaders recognize that it will take a revived national party, currently a fractured institution with power divided between traditional organizations, Congress, and outside groups, to address the structural problems that doomed Republicans on election night. Ohio Senator Rob Portman described the defeat as a "wake-up call," while West Virginia Representative Shelley Moore Capito emphasized the need for the party to confront the reality that it is not diversified like the country and risks losing women and minority voters in future elections.

Capito noted that the party's candidates often reflect the predominant members of the party, and that if it wants to be a party of a "big tent," it cannot keep leaving people out. She cited her 27-year-old daughter as an example, saying that women of that age do not accept any limitations on their choices.

Virginia Lieutenant Governor Bill Bolling, Mitt Romney's state chairman in Virginia and a candidate for governor in 2013, acknowledged that the party's voter identification and mobilization efforts did not produce the expected results. He emphasized the need for the party to do a better job reaching out to women, Latinos, and young voters, or risk having a hard time winning elections on a national level.

As the full impact of the election results became clear, the party's leaders are left to ponder the way forward and how to revamp their party's infrastructure and demographic appeal.

Title: Justice Department Continues Search for Alternative Way to Ask Citizenship Question on 2020 Census

The United States Census Bureau has begun printing forms for the 2020 census, but the Justice Department has been instructed to find an alternative way to ask respondents about their citizenship status. The Trump administration had previously sought to include a question about citizenship on the census form, but the Supreme Court blocked the move, citing a lack of a legitimate reason for the question.

According to Hansi Lo Wang, an expert on the census, the Justice Department has been told to continue searching for a way to ask the citizenship question, despite the Supreme Court's ruling. This decision was prompted by a tweet from President Trump, who claimed that the Commerce Department had not given up on the question.

The Supreme Court had previously ruled that the administration's justification for the question, which was to better enforce the Voting Rights Act and protect the voting rights of racial minorities, was not legitimate. The court stated that the Commerce Department has the authority to add the question, but it must have a legitimate reason to do so.

The Justice Department has said it will continue to look for a new justification for the question, which would require figuring out a new reason for asking about citizenship. The outcome of this effort is uncertain, as it will depend on whether the courts accept the new justification.

The 2020 census is scheduled to begin in January, and the printing of forms is a crucial step in the process. The census is a count of every person living in the United States, and the forms must be finalized and distributed in a timely manner.

Title: Rep. Maxine Waters Warns Potential Threats to "Shoot Straight"

Article:

Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, made a statement during a rally in Los Angeles on Saturday, urging those who might consider harming her to "shoot straight." The comment was made amidst a backdrop of death threats and cancellations of speaking events in Alabama and Texas, which she attributed to her criticism of President Donald Trump's immigration policies.

Waters had previously called on opponents of Trump's policies to confront and harass Cabinet members, specifically mentioning Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, who was confronted by protesters at a Washington, D.C. restaurant last week. Additionally, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was asked to leave a Virginia restaurant due to her association with Trump.

In response to Waters' comments, Trump warned her to "be careful what you wish for" on Monday, calling her an "extraordinarily low IQ person" and stating that she had called for harm to supporters of the Make America Great Again movement. This is not the first time Waters has made a statement about potential threats, as she previously told a crowd at a town hall meeting in Inglewood last year that if someone were to shoot at her, they should "shoot straight."
