It is worth noting that the exact circumstances and motivations behind the death threats and cancellations of speaking events are unclear, as this information is unavailable.

Title: Superdelegates' Influence Sparks Debate in Presidential Primaries

The role of superdelegates in the United States presidential primaries has become a topic of discussion among supporters of both Democratic and Republican candidates. For Bernie Sanders' supporters, the issue is about the perceived unfairness of the system, where their votes are being nullified by the influence of superdelegates. Jordan Float, a 25-year-old nursing assistant and Sanders volunteer, stated, "Our presidents, our congressmen, anyone in Washington, should not be decided by anyone but the public."

While Sanders has criticized the "rigged political system," he has not been as vocal about the influence of superdelegates, recognizing the need to win their support to win the nomination. Some of his supporters have also toned down their criticism, with the "Superdelegate Hit List" no longer using the term "Hit" and replacing it with telephone cords.

On the Republican side, anxiety is higher due to Donald Trump's potential to fall short of the 50 percent-plus-one delegate threshold set by the Republican National Committee to clinch the nomination before the convention. Trump and his supporters have been vocal in criticizing the process, fearing that their delegates will be "stolen" at the convention. Roger Stone, a longtime associate of Trump, has urged massive protests at the national convention in Cleveland in July, stating, "Don't let the Big Steal go forward without massive protests." He has also threatened to post hotel room numbers of delegates who switch their votes against Trump.

It is worth noting that some superdelegates, like Minnesota's Mr. Morillo, who supports Hillary Clinton, have expressed concerns about the fairness of the system and have stated they would withhold their vote if the race came down to party leaders like themselves.

Title: Twitter's Evolution: From Iranian Protests to Global Conversations

Twitter, a social media platform, has undergone significant changes since its inception in 2009. Initially, it was a small startup with a few employees, but it has since grown to become a global phenomenon with millions of users. Twitter's utility has evolved from a simple status update service to a platform for global conversations, including political discussions.

In 2009, Twitter's co-founders, Biz Stone and Jason Goldman, drafted a blog post about Iranian politics, which was a topic beyond their comprehension at the time. The platform had become a means for Iranians to communicate and organize protests against President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. Twitter's utility had changed, and it had become a political tool.

Fast-forward to today, Twitter is still grappling with the complexities of global conversations. The platform has become a hub for debates, skirmishes, and discussions on various topics, including politics, climate change, and more. The platform's centrality in these conversations is a double-edged sword, as it can facilitate global discussions but also amplify misinformation and hate speech.

Twitter's founders did not intend to become the arbiter of what is right and wrong, but the platform's growth and influence have made it a reality. The company's leadership has struggled to navigate these complexities, with some employees advocating for stricter regulations and others pushing for free speech.

In recent years, Twitter has faced criticism for its handling of controversial conversations, including those involving world leaders like Donald Trump. The company has taken a stance against banning world leaders, citing the importance of preserving free speech and allowing users to engage with their words and actions.

Twitter's evolution has been marked by leadership changes, with the company growing from a small startup to a global platform with 4,000 employees and $2.5 billion in revenue. Despite its growth, Twitter remains in a complicated spot, struggling to balance the need for free speech with the need to prevent harm and misinformation. The company's decisions on how to manage volatile conversations continue to perplex users and the media, leaving many wondering how Twitter will navigate its role as a global conversation hub.

Title: Trump Criticizes Republican Losses, Blames Fellow Republicans for Not Embracing Him

Article:

President Donald Trump held a press conference at the White House on Wednesday, where he delivered a post-mortem assessment of the Republican Party's performance in the midterm elections. Trump criticized several Republican candidates who did not sufficiently support him, including Representative Mia Love, who lost her re-election bid. Love's race was still not officially called as of Wednesday night, with Trump trailing Democratic challenger Ben McAdams by about 5,000 votes.

Trump's remarks were notable for their candor, but lacked humility, as he listed off candidates who won after he campaigned on their behalf and mocked those who did not want his endorsement. Trump stated that he is "not sure if I should be happy or sad" about the losses suffered by Republican candidates who distanced themselves from him, but ultimately felt "just fine" about it.

The president's comments have been met with criticism from some Republicans, including Representative Ryan Costello, who called Trump's performance "disgusting" and expressed anger towards the president's behavior towards Republican candidates who lost due to their association with him. Costello believes that many moderate Republicans made the right decision to distance themselves from Trump, who is deeply unpopular in some parts of the country.

Trump's remarks also highlighted the transformation of the Republican Party, which is now more Trumpian than ever before. The elimination of moderate and Trump-critical members has led to a more unified party that is more supportive of Trump's agenda. The outcome of the midterm elections has also boosted Trump by widening the Senate's Republican majority, giving him more leverage to push his agenda.

The article notes that Trump's comments were deliberate and not impromptu, as he read from a card and laid out what it means to "embrace" Trumpism. The White House was conveying a specific message to Republicans: Trump is now the center of conservatism.

Title: Balancing Liberty and Security in Times of Crisis

In the face of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, the delicate balance between individual liberties and government restrictions has come under scrutiny. As the pandemic spreads, governments around the world are implementing measures to contain its spread, often at the expense of individual freedoms. This raises questions about the limits of government power and the trade-offs between security and liberty.

The concept of habeas corpus, a fundamental right enshrined in the US Constitution, has been at the center of this debate. During the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln suspended habeas corpus, allowing the government to detain individuals deemed a threat to national security. This move was justified by Lincoln as necessary to preserve the government and protect the country from external threats.

However, the suspension of habeas corpus has been criticized as an overreach of executive power. The Supreme Court's Chief Justice Roger Taney ruled that only Congress had the authority to suspend habeas corpus, not the president. This decision was later upheld by Congress, which endorsed Lincoln's suspension.

The debate surrounding habeas corpus highlights the tension between individual liberties and government restrictions. While it is essential to protect individual rights, it is also crucial to ensure the government's ability to respond to emergencies. The Constitution explicitly provides for the restriction of certain rights in times of crisis, recognizing that the survival of the country is at stake.

As the world grapples with the coronavirus pandemic, it is essential to strike a balance between individual liberties and government restrictions. While it is natural to prioritize security over liberty in times of crisis, it is crucial to remember that restrictions should be no more extensive than the threat reasonably demands. The history of the United States has shown that abuses of power are eventually addressed by courts and legislatures, but only after the emergency has subsided.

In conclusion, the debate surrounding habeas corpus serves as a reminder of the delicate balance between individual liberties and government restrictions. As we navigate the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic, it is essential to strike a balance between security and liberty, ensuring that individual rights are protected while also allowing the government to respond effectively to the crisis.

Title: President's Address Fails to Address Security Concerns, Blames Opponents Instead

The recent terrorist attack in San Bernardino has left many Americans questioning the effectiveness of the current administration's policies in keeping the country safe. In his Oval Office address on Sunday night, President Obama had the opportunity to address the nation and provide a plan to rectify the problem, but instead, he chose to blame others for his administration's lapses and do the minimum to appear to be reacting to the threat.

The President could have explained why a low-tech, soft-target terrorism had occurred and what he would do to prevent it in the future. He could have apologized for giving a U.S. visa to a jihadist from Pakistan and agreed to stop his plan to bring more Syrian refugees to the country. Instead, he called for Congress to ban those on the no-fly list from buying guns, a measure that would not have stopped the attack in San Bernardino.

The President's address also failed to address the root cause of the problem, radical Islam, and instead, he blamed his domestic opponents for the failure to keep America safe. His proposal to ban gun ownership for those on the no-fly list is an attempt to shift the blame for the administration's failures, rather than taking responsibility for them.

The President's words fell flat, as his reassurances about the fight against ISIS were not convincing. The terrorist group has been able to expand its influence around the globe, despite the U.S.-led war against it. The President's call for Congress to approve his anti-ISIS campaign was seen as another attempt to shift blame for the failure to keep America safe.

The President's address was criticized for its lack of concrete solutions and its failure to address the root cause of the problem. The office of the President awaits a new leader who can confidently explain how to defeat ISIS and defend the American people, rather than simply blaming opponents and doing the minimum to appear to be reacting to the threat.

Title: White House to Issue Regulation Allowing Government to Contribute to Congressional Health Care Premiums

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is expected to issue a ruling as early as Friday, according to sources, that will allow the government to continue making contributions to the health care premiums of members of Congress and their aides. This decision comes after heavy pressure from Capitol Hill and a personal involvement from President Barack Obama.

The issue arose from the original text of the Affordable Care Act, which stated that members of Congress and their aides must be covered by plans "created" by the law or "offered through an exchange." The Office of Personnel Management had not previously clarified whether the Federal Employee Health Benefits Program could contribute premium payments toward plans on the exchange. If payments stopped, lawmakers and aides would have faced thousands of dollars in additional premium payments each year.

The proposed regulation will ensure that the government can continue to contribute nearly 75 percent of premium payments, alleviating concerns about a "brain drain" among aides. The issue had sparked serious griping from both sides of the aisle, with some Republicans privately expressing concerns about the potential for spiking health premiums.

White House officials acknowledged the need for a fix, but knew that addressing it through a regulation would lead to criticism from some Republicans. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi praised the Affordable Care Act and the efforts of Democrats to educate consumers about its benefits. Senate Minority Whip John Cornyn expressed outrage over the "outrageous exemption for Congress."

The proposed regulation is expected to be issued next week, providing relief to lawmakers and aides who were facing significant increases in their health care premiums.

Title: Unemployment Claims Reach 41-Year Low, But Experts Warn of Potential Bubble

The seasonally-adjusted initial unemployment claims in the week ended July 18 have reached a 41-year low, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. However, some experts are sounding the alarm, warning that the jobless claim data may be stronger than it appears.

Editor of The Wall Street Examiner newsletter, Lee Adler, notes that the actual, not seasonally-adjusted number has been at a record low relative to total employment since September 2013. While the seasonally-adjusted number is indeed remarkable, Adler points out that it is not the only metric to consider. The actual number of jobless claims has been at a record low since 2013, and the workforce was much smaller 41 years ago.

Adler warns that the current numbers are well beyond the bubble record lows of 1999-2000 and 2006-07, and that employers in some sectors are hoarding workers, a behavior associated with bubbles that has led to massive retrenchment in the past. He notes that this time may be different, but history suggests that bubbles often burst, and the consequences can be severe.

Meanwhile, MarketWatch columnist John Coumarianos notes that while U.S. stocks are at historically high valuations, foreign markets are offering compelling investment bargains. According to Research Affiliates, 24 markets trade cheaper than the United States, including the United Kingdom, Japan, Germany, Hong Kong, and India. Coumarianos is particularly enthusiastic about British stocks, citing the country's current cyclically-adjusted price-earnings ratio (CAPE) of 12.4, which is low compared to other countries and regions.

Investors may want to consider the potential risks and rewards of investing in foreign markets, particularly in the United Kingdom, where the CAPE is below its own median of 14.6 using data going back to 1969.

Title: Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez's Controversial Rhetoric Sparks Debate

Article:

Tom Perez, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has been making headlines with his recent speeches and public appearances, which have been characterized by some as "grotesque" and "scatological." Perez's rhetoric has been criticized for being overly aggressive and divisive, with some accusing him of using anger and profanity to garner support for the Democratic Party.

Perez's latest speech, in which he claimed that Republicans "don't give a sh-t" about voters, has sparked controversy and criticism from both sides of the political aisle. The Democratic Party's official store is now selling a T-shirt with the slogan "Democrats give a sh-t about People," which has been seen as a response to Perez's comments.

The article goes on to criticize Perez's approach, stating that it is a "descent into septic depths" and that it is "difficult to find an adjective that describes this descent." The author argues that governance has devolved into a primitive notion that whoever can pound the table the loudest has the most moral authority, and that civility is no longer seen as a desirable trait.

The article also touches on the idea that the rise of social media and the internet has created a culture where the most vile of human behaviors can become electromagnetic waves crossing borders at nearly the speed of light. The author suggests that this has led to a culture of emotional incontinence, where individuals are no longer held accountable for their actions.

The article concludes by referencing the philosophical ideas of Søren Kierkegaard and Jean-Paul Sartre, which emphasize the importance of subjective human judgment and the idea that truth is whatever the individual perceives it to be. The author argues that this philosophy has led to a culture of moral relativism, where all behaviors are equal and OK, and that this has contributed to the decline of civility and the rise of scatology.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of Tom Perez's rhetoric and the Democratic Party's approach, arguing that it is a descent into a primitive and divisive culture.

Title: National School Walk-Out Planned to Protest Congress' Lack of Action on Gun Reform

A national school walk-out is scheduled to take place on March 14 at 10 a.m. to protest Congress' lack of action on gun reform following recent mass shootings. The event, titled "Women's March Youth EMPOWER," is organized by the Women's March and invites students, teachers, and parents to participate.

The 17-minute walk-out is a call to action, demanding Congress pass legislation to keep students and communities safe from gun violence. The event's website states, "Students and staff have the right to teach and learn in an environment free from the worry of being gunned down in their classrooms or on their way home from school. Parents have the right to send their kids to school in the mornings and see them home alive at the end of the day."

The walk-out follows the recent mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida, which left 17 people dead. According to law enforcement sources, the 19-year-old suspect, Nikolas Cruz, claimed "demon" voices told him to carry out the violence.

The event has already gained momentum, with over two dozen walk-outs planned across the country. The Women's March website provides information for localities wishing to participate and join the movement. The hashtag #NationalSchoolWalkout is being used to spread awareness and encourage participation.

Title: Ukraine's Separatist Regions Declare Independence, but Legitimacy of Referendum Questioned

The self-proclaimed separatist regions of Lugansk and Donetsk in eastern Ukraine have declared independence from Kiev, citing overwhelming support from voters. According to the results released by the separatist electoral commissions, 96.2% of voters in Lugansk and 89.07% in Donetsk favored self-rule. However, the legitimacy of the referendum has been called into question due to numerous irregularities and anomalies observed by journalists.

The results are impossible to independently confirm, as no election monitors were allowed to observe the voting process. Many Western news outlets reported instances of voter fraud, ballot stuffing, and voters' lack of understanding of what they were voting for. CNN filmed several voters casting multiple ballots, while BBC reporters found multiple irregularities in the city of Mariupol, including voters being able to cast ballots in any polling station by simply writing their name on a piece of paper.

Interim President Oleksandr Turchynov condemned the referendum, calling it a "farce" with no legal consequences for its organizers. The European Union also criticized the vote, calling it illegal. Russia, on the other hand, stated that it respects the expression of will of the population in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions and will proceed with implementing the results in a "civilized way."

Recent independent polling in eastern Ukraine sharply conflicts with the referendum results. A Pew Research poll found that 70% of respondents in the east and 58% of Russian-speaking eastern respondents wanted Ukraine to remain whole, while only 18% of easterners and 27% of eastern Russian-speakers supported secession. An April poll by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology (KIIS) also found high dissatisfaction with Kiev's governance but little appetite for outright independence.

The referendum only took place in the two easternmost regions of Ukraine, while the earlier polls considered attitudes in a much larger portion of eastern Ukraine. For the referendum results to square with the earlier polls, support for secession would have to be minimal outside of the Lugansk and Donetsk regions. The BBC noted that even among those who did vote, there appeared to be confusion over what they were voting for, with some believing they were casting their ballot to join Russia or simply to gain more power in eastern Ukraine.

Title: Guards at New York City Jail Facility Where Epstein Was Housed Suspected of Falsifying Log Entries

Article:

Guards at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City, where Jeffrey Epstein was being held, are under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying log entries to show they were checking on the disgraced financier and other inmates more frequently than they actually did. According to a report, surveillance video reviewed after Epstein's death shows that guards did not make some of the checks they claimed to have made, with some guards reportedly falling asleep at some point and not checking on Epstein for up to three hours.

The Justice Department has placed two guards assigned to watch Epstein on administrative leave. The guards had claimed they were checking on inmates in Epstein's unit every half hour, but investigators now believe this was not the case.

Epstein's death, which occurred on August 10, has sparked widespread conspiracy theories and outrage, with many questioning how he was able to commit suicide in his cell. Attorney General William Barr has described the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death as "serious irregularities" and has demanded a thorough investigation.

The investigation into Epstein's death and his alleged sex trafficking ring continues, with Geoffrey Berman, the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, vowing to continue the investigation. Several of Epstein's accusers have pointed to Ghislaine Maxwell, his alleged "recruiter," as playing a pivotal role in enlisting his victims. Maxwell has denied all allegations of misconduct and has not released any public statements since Epstein's arrest.

The investigation into Epstein's death and his alleged crimes is ongoing, with many questions still unanswered.

Title: Militants Seize Airport in Southern Yemen as Country Remains in Turmoil

Militants from al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) have taken control of an airport in the southern Yemen city of Mukalla, Hadramawt province, according to officials. The troops guarding the site have fled, leaving the airport in the hands of the extremist group.

The seizure comes as Yemen remains embroiled in a complex conflict, with various factions vying for power. The country has been plagued by chaos since the Houthi rebels, a Shia group, overran the capital Sanaa in September 2014. The rebels, backed by Iran, have since expanded their control across the country.

The Saudi-led coalition, comprising nine mostly Sunni Arab states, has been conducting airstrikes against the Houthi rebels, who are seeking to replace the government of President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi. The coalition claims to be defending the legitimate government of Hadi, while the Houthi rebels accuse him of being corrupt.

AQAP, a rival of both the Houthi rebels and President Hadi, has taken advantage of the chaos to expand its presence in the country. The group has reportedly seized a sea port and an oil terminal in southern Yemen, further complicating the situation.

Yemeni Vice-President Khaled Bahah has expressed concerns about the possibility of a Saudi-led ground offensive, stating that the country does not want to expand the war. The UN's special envoy to Yemen, Jamal Benomar, has stepped down from his post, with the organization announcing that it will name a successor "in due course."

The conflict in Yemen has led to widespread humanitarian suffering, with millions displaced and thousands killed. The international community is working to relaunch peace talks, but progress has been slow.

Title: Congress Scrambles to Prevent Russian Election Interference Amid Growing Concerns

Congress is racing against time to prevent Russia from hacking state election systems and spreading disinformation on social media ahead of the 2018 midterm elections. The challenge is daunting, with lawmakers struggling to regulate private tech companies and states' reluctance to accept federal control over their elections.

Recent revelations about Russia's extensive efforts to spread disinformation on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media sites have underscored the magnitude of the problem. Federal officials have warned that hackers possibly connected to Russia targeted election systems in 21 states last year, and leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee expect Russia to try again in the 2018 congressional elections, the 2020 presidential election, and possibly even this year in the Virginia governor's race.

The biggest risk, analysts say, is not that Russia will help one party's candidates defeat the other's but that they will succeed in causing Americans to doubt the legitimacy of election results. "I don't think the Russians have a favorite political party," said Jack Pitney, a politics professor at Claremont McKenna College in California. "They do have a preference for chaos and division."

Facebook has turned over more than 3,000 suspicious ads to the House Intelligence Committee, which were purchased by an organization connected to Russian intelligence services during the 2016 election. The ads helped demonstrate how Russia employed sophisticated measures to push disinformation and propaganda to millions of Americans online during the election, sowing discord and chaos.

Lawmakers are planning public hearings in the next few weeks with Facebook and other social media companies to examine how Russia exploited social media. "If you see an ad on a social media site, Americans should know whether the source of that ad was a foreign entity," said Rep. Adam Schiff of California, the committee's senior Democrat.

Sen. James Lankford, R-Okla., a member of both the Senate Intelligence and Homeland Security committees, said that Russians have been weighing in on Twitter on both sides of the recent dispute between President Trump and the NFL over whether players should be fired for refusing to stand during the national anthem. "We watched... the Russians and their troll farms and their Internet folks start hashtagging out 'take a knee' and also hashtagging out 'boycott NFL,'" Lankford said.

There is little Congress can do to control what happens on social media other than push tech companies to better police themselves and identify who is buying ads or pushing out false information on their sites. "It's a classic case of congressional pressure as a way of increasing self-regulation by the companies," said Henry Farrell, a professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University. "But it's probably impossible to stop this entirely."

Lawmakers have been pressing the Department of Homeland Security about what federal officials are doing to prevent Russia or other foreign governments from hacking state election systems next year. Acting Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke told the Senate Homeland Security Committee that her agency has the resources it needs to do on-site assessments of election security for all the states that request it before the 2018 election.

Title: President Obama Announces New Fuel-Efficiency Standards for Trucks, Amid Criticism Over His Own Actions

Article:

President Barack Obama visited a Safeway distribution center in suburban Maryland on Tuesday to announce new fuel-efficiency standards for trucks, which aim to reduce carbon pollution and lower fuel costs for consumers. The new standards, set to take effect by 2025, require the trucking industry to reduce fuel consumption by an unspecified amount, building upon the current 10-20% reduction by 2018.

The announcement was met with criticism from some quarters, who pointed out that the president's words do not always align with his actions. The president's recent golfing trip to California, which included playing at some of the state's most water-intensive courses, was seen as hypocritical given his previous statements on the need to conserve water resources.

The White House did not respond to requests for comment on the president's trip to Maryland, which involved a 15-vehicle caravan and an hour-long round trip to deliver a 17-minute speech. The trip was seen as an example of the president's tendency to prioritize flashiness over efficiency.

The criticism extends beyond the president's personal actions to his administration's policies. Republican lawmakers and critics have accused the Obama administration of hypocrisy for using executive actions to change mandates and deadlines under Obamacare and other areas, despite the president's previous criticism of his predecessor's use of executive authority.

The president's press secretary, Jay Carney, defended the administration's use of executive actions, pointing out that Mr. Obama has issued fewer executive orders than former presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton did at this point in their presidency. However, critics argue that it is not the number of actions that matters, but rather the type and scope, and that the president's use of executive authority has been excessive.

The new fuel-efficiency standards for trucks are part of the president's "year of action" in 2014, in which he plans to work without Congress wherever possible. The standards are intended to reduce carbon pollution and lower fuel costs for consumers, and are scheduled to be finalized in March 2016.

Title: McDonald's Raises Wages for Some Workers, But Franchisees May Not Follow Suit

Article:

McDonald's recently announced a wage hike for tens of thousands of its workers, but the move only applies to a small percentage of its stores. The company-owned stores will see an increase in wages, but the majority of its franchisees will not be affected. According to McDonald's, the wage hike is a company-specific decision and does not set a precedent for its franchisees.

The distinction between company-owned and franchisee-owned stores is crucial in the context of a legal battle currently underway at the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB). The NLRB is deciding whether McDonald's is a "joint employer" with its franchisees, which could have significant implications for the company's relationship with its workers and the broader labor market.

The NLRB's general counsel, Richard Griffin, has argued that McDonald's has enough control over its restaurants to be considered a joint employer, citing its rules governing day-to-day operations, such as scheduling software and bag folding. This could mean that McDonald's would be liable for labor law violations committed by its franchisees.

The question of who is a joint employer is not limited to McDonald's and its franchisees. The issue is part of a broader trend in the US labor market, where businesses are increasingly distancing themselves from workers through subcontractors and temp agencies. This has led to lower wages, worse benefits, and growing inequality.

The NLRB has yet to rule on another high-stakes case involving waste management firm Browning Ferris, which could also have significant implications for the labor market. The outcome of these cases could "upset these business relationships" and have "enormous implications for business relationships," according to attorney Michael Lotito.

In conclusion, McDonald's wage hike for some of its workers highlights the complex relationship between the company and its franchisees. The NLRB's decision on whether McDonald's is a joint employer will have far-reaching implications for the labor market and the relationship between businesses and their workers.

Title: A Father's Frustration with the System: A Story of Exploitation and Inequality

The article tells the story of a father's frustration with the system, which is not directed at specific groups such as race or immigration, but rather at the exploitation of labor and the government's treatment of the working poor. The father, who has worked nearly every day of his life and has no savings beyond Social Security, is angry at the bosses who exploit labor and the government that punishes those who are struggling to make ends meet.

The article highlights the father's personal struggles, including having to sell his own plasma for gas money during the Great Recession and having to cash in his retirement to make ends meet after being laid off. He is not angry at his co-workers, including a Filipino immigrant and a Hispanic crew member, but rather at the system that allows corporations to exploit labor and governments to punish the working poor.

The article also touches on the manipulation of white workers' negative energy by a conservative trifecta of media, private interest, and celebrity, which can be seen as a reference to Fox News, the Koch brothers, and Donald Trump.

Title: US Takes Liberal Approach to Counting COVID-19 Deaths, Says Dr. Deborah Birx

The White House Wuhan coronavirus task force briefing on Tuesday evening saw Dr. Deborah Birx clarify the approach the United States takes in classifying deaths from the virus. According to Dr. Birx, the country has taken a "liberal approach" in counting deaths from COVID-19. This means that anyone who dies with COVID-19, regardless of any underlying conditions, is recorded as a COVID-19 death.

Dr. Birx emphasized that the intent is to count anyone who dies with COVID-19 as a COVID-19 death, even if other factors contributed to their demise. This approach differs from some other countries, which may only record COVID-19 as the cause of death if it was the primary cause.

The distinction between dying from and dying with COVID-19 is crucial, as it affects the overall mortality rate and the driving force behind the countrywide economic shutdown. According to the latest numbers compiled by Johns Hopkins University, there are 398,185 positive diagnoses, 21,849 recoveries, and 12,844 deaths in the United States.

Dr. Birx's statement has sparked concerns among some, including Fox News host Tucker Carlson, who suggested that doctors may be classifying conventional pneumonia deaths as COVID-19 deaths, potentially inflating the death toll. However, Dr. Birx's clarification provides a clear understanding of the approach taken by the US in counting COVID-19 deaths.

Title: America's Vision for a Better World: Harmony, Stability, and Progress

The article highlights America's commitment to creating a more peaceful, just, and free world. The country is willing to forge new partnerships and alliances with nations that share similar interests, aiming to achieve harmony and stability. The author notes that America has a history of forming friendships with former enemies, demonstrating the possibility of overcoming past conflicts.

The article also reflects on America's past, specifically its 100th anniversary in 1876, where innovators showcased their creations, such as the telephone, typewriter, and early electric light. The author envisions a future where America's people are free to pursue their dreams, leading to breakthroughs in medicine, space exploration, and economic growth.

The article emphasizes the importance of unity, stating that Americans "bleed the same blood" and "salute the same great American flag." It concludes that achieving this vision requires collective effort, as the country strives to become "greater than ever before" for all Americans.

Title: Google Sued by Former Employee Over Allegations of Discrimination Against Conservative, White Men

Article:

A former Google employee, James Damore, has filed a lawsuit against the tech giant, alleging that the company discriminates against conservative, white men. Damore, who was fired in August for circulating a memo that argued Google's gender pay gap was the result of genetic differences, claims that he was ostracized, belittled, and punished for his heterodox political views.

According to the lawsuit, Damore and another former Google engineer, David Gudeman, are seeking class-action status for anyone who identifies as conservative, Caucasian, or male. The men are being represented by Harmeet K. Dhillon, the Republican National Committee's committeewoman for California.

The lawsuit alleges that Google's management encourages hiring managers to consider protected categories such as race and/or gender as determinative hiring factors, to the detriment of Caucasian and male employees and potential employees. It also claims that the company employs illegal hiring quotas to fill its desired percentages of women and favored minority candidates, and openly shames managers of business units who fail to meet their quotas.

Damore's lawsuit is the latest legal challenge for Google, which also faces a suit for unequal pay. The company has faced criticism for its handling of diversity and inclusion issues, including allegations of gender and racial discrimination.

In his lawsuit, Damore frames himself as a model Google employee who received eight performance bonuses and $150,000 per year in stock bonuses since he started working at the company in 2013. He claims that he was terminated from his job after voicing his complaints about diversity practices and publishing his 10-page memo, titled "Google's Ideological Echo Chamber."

Damore also alleges that he was forced to attend and participate in diversity training events and that he was threatened and insulted by his coworkers following the publishing of his memo. He included an email from another Google employee who promised to "hound" him until one of them was fired.

The lawsuit also alleges that the company maintains separate lists of conservative personalities, including right-wing blogger Curtis Yarvin and InfoWars founder and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, to prevent them from stepping foot on Google's campus.

Damore has remained unemployed since he was terminated from Google, noting that management did not identify any Google policy or procedure that he had violated. He has made a slew of media appearances, started a Twitter account, and met with conservative media and political figures, including Peter Thiel.

A Google spokesperson said the company will defend against the lawsuit in court.

**China Warns US Farmers of Permanent Loss of Market Share Amid Trade War**

China's Vice Agriculture Minister, Han Jun, has warned that American farmers could permanently lose their share of the Chinese market as a result of the ongoing trade war. In an interview with Xinhua news agency, Han stated that many countries have the willingness and capacity to take over the market share the US is enjoying in China, making it difficult for the US to regain the market.

According to Han, Beijing has imposed duties on 90% of agricultural goods it imports from the US since the trade war began, with limited impact on China. The tariffs have caused a significant decrease in US agricultural product exports to China, but the impact on China is minimal due to its diversified import sources.

China is the world's largest importer of soybeans, which it uses to make cooking oil, biodiesel, and animal feed. Han said that Chinese companies have "basically stopped" importing soybeans from US farmers since July 6 and will deal with the impact by finding alternative ingredients for animal feeds. China is expected to import fewer soybeans from the US this year, and preparations have already been made to handle the shortfall.

The country has been buying more soybeans from other countries and promoting alternatives to soybeans for animal feed. Before the trade war, China was on track to import 300 million tons of soybeans from the US this year.

The US was the third-largest market for Chinese fruit and fifth-largest for vegetables last year, with exports valued at a combined $1.84 billion. Han acknowledged that Washington's tariffs would impact China's fruit, vegetable, and seafood producers, but said Beijing would help exporters find alternative markets and boost domestic consumption to minimize the impact.

The European Union is not expected to be able to make up the losses for US soybean producers, as it would only buy 13-14 million tons of soybeans per year over the next decade, compared to the over 30 million tons China bought from the US last year.

Title: California's Approach to Poverty Reduction: A Mixed Bag of Progress and Challenges

California, known for its progressive policies and generous social welfare programs, is on the verge of eliminating childhood deep poverty, according to the American Prospect. To achieve this goal, the state legislature needs to pass a series of multibillion-dollar proposals, including expanding Medi-Cal, funding universal preschool, and investing in affordable housing. However, some experts argue that the state's approach to poverty reduction is misguided and may not be effective in addressing the root causes of poverty.

One such example is the privately-funded pilot program in Stockton, which provides a Universal Basic Income (UBI) to poor residents. While this program has received favorable media attention, some critics argue that it is a "surrender to a grim Dickensian view of the future" that robs people of the dignity of work.

California's labor officials have also been criticized for not addressing the root causes of poverty. The state imposes onerous occupational-licensing rules, which can make it difficult for low-income individuals to pursue dignified and lucrative careers. For instance, the average cost of a license is $500, but the training rules are the main problem. Last year, a bill was introduced to eliminate the 1,500 hours of schooling required to shampoo and curl people's hair for pay, but it died in the Assembly.

Conservative-leaning Arizona, on the other hand, is reforming its laws to recognize new residents' licenses from other states, recognizing that there is dignity in all work. Republican Governor Doug Ducey signed a measure that allows new residents to use their existing licenses, saying, "There's dignity in all work, and we know that whether you make your living as a plumber, a barber, a nurse or anything else, you don't lose your skills simply because you moved here."

California has tried to address the licensing issue in a perverse way, with Attorney General Xavier Becerra sponsoring a bill to help law enforcement arrest people who buy or sell services in the "underground economy." Fortunately, Governor Jerry Brown vetoed the bill. Instead, the state has announced sting operations to catch laborers who have exceeded the meager $500 cap on providing unlicensed contracting.

While California's approach to poverty reduction is well-intentioned, it may not be addressing the root causes of poverty. Instead of reforming its rules, the state is focusing on fining and jailing people who engage in the "underground economy." Perhaps someday lawmakers will realize that the best way to eliminate poverty is to make it easier for people to legally pursue dignified work.

Title: Trump Campaign Counts on "Undercover Voters" to Win in November

The Trump campaign is relying on what they call "undercover voters" to help them win in November, according to an interview with campaign manager Kellyanne Conway. Conway believes that Trump's support is not reflected in polls due to the perceived social stigma of supporting the Republican nominee. She claims that some voters are hesitant to publicly declare their support for Trump, fearing social repercussions.

Conway attributes this phenomenon to the "Bradley effect," a concept that describes the willingness of some voters to tell pollsters they are voting for a different candidate than they actually do. This effect is named after former Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley, who was favored in polls in California's 1982 gubernatorial election but ultimately lost.

Conway believes that a similar phenomenon is occurring in the 2016 US presidential election, with some voters choosing not to publicly declare their support for Trump due to social pressure. She claims that her campaign has developed a "proprietary" method to reach these undercover voters, which involves going to them where they live and engaging with them in a way that makes them feel comfortable expressing their support.

Conway's statements echo the UK's experience in the EU referendum vote, where polling suggested the UK would remain in the European Union, but ultimately voted to leave. Conway believes that some voters are too afraid to express their true opinions in polls, and that her campaign's approach can reach these voters and encourage them to come out and support Trump.

The article also notes that Trump has recently started using teleprompters in his rallies, a departure from his previous unscripted style. However, Trump still managed to stray off script during a rally in Akron, Ohio, making controversial statements about inner cities being more dangerous than war zones.

Overall, Conway's strategy relies on the idea that there are many voters who are hesitant to publicly support Trump due to social pressure, and that her campaign's approach can reach these voters and encourage them to come out and support the Republican nominee.

**Texas Shooting: ISIS Claims Responsibility, Warns of Future Attacks**

In the aftermath of the shooting outside a Prophet Mohammed cartoon contest in Garland, Texas, ISIS has claimed responsibility for the attack, warning of more attacks to come. The group said two Al Khilafa soldiers, Elton Simpson and Nadir Soofi, opened fire outside the event, wounding a security guard before being killed by police.

While ISIS claimed responsibility two days after the attack, there is no immediate indication that the terror group in Iraq and Syria had direct contact with Simpson or Soofi, who both lived in Phoenix, Arizona. Authorities are still investigating any potential links to international terrorism.

The FBI searched the apartment shared by Simpson and Soofi and found it to be relatively barren, with only a hard drive retrieved and being analyzed. Investigators are trying to determine whether the two gunmen had any associates in Phoenix or across the United States who share their ideology.

The shooting occurred outside the Curtis Culwell Center in Garland, where the American Freedom Defense Initiative was hosting a cartoon contest featuring depictions of the Prophet Mohammed, which many Muslims consider sacrilege. The two assailants drove up to the center, started shooting, and struck a security guard in the ankle. However, Garland police returned fire, killing the gunmen before they were able to enter the building.

The attack has stirred memories of other attacks this year in France and Denmark, including the Charlie Hebdo shooting in January and the free speech forum attack in Copenhagen in February.

Title: Former Bolton Aide Won't Testify in Impeachment Inquiry Until Court Rules on Lawsuit

Article:

A top aide to former White House national security adviser John Bolton, Charles Kupperman, will not testify before Congress on Monday as part of the ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Trump. Kupperman's lawyer, Charles Cooper, delivered a letter to Democratic investigators stating that his client will not comply with the subpoena until a court rules on a lawsuit surrounding his appearance.

Kupperman, the former deputy to Bolton, has been caught in a legal tug of war between the White House and Democrats. The White House is trying to block his testimony, citing executive privilege, while Democrats have subpoenaed Kupperman to appear before the House Intelligence, Oversight, and Foreign Affairs committees.

Kupperman filed a lawsuit, asking the courts to rule on which side has the more compelling legal argument. Democrats have warned that Kupperman, now a private citizen, has a legal obligation to appear before Congress. Failure to do so could lead to charges of contempt of Congress.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, House Oversight and Reform Committee Acting Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney, and House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel sent a letter to Kupperman, stating that the subpoena remains in full force and that Kupperman is legally obligated to appear for the deposition on Monday. They warned that if Kupperman defies the subpoena, his absence will constitute evidence that may be used against him in a contempt proceeding.

Cooper, in his letter to Democratic attorney Daniel Noble, said that it is not Kupperman who contests the Democrats' legal claim, but rather President Trump and every President before him for at least the last half century, who have asserted testimonial immunity for their closest confidential advisors.

The White House successfully blocked former White House counsel Don McGahn from appearing before Congress earlier this year by asserting he is immune from compelled testimony. The concept of "immunity" of top presidential advisers from congressional testimony has been invoked by both Republican and Democratic administrations, but there is little case law on the subject.

Kupperman was reportedly on the July 25 call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that is at the center of the impeachment investigation into allegations that Trump solicited foreign leaders to help his reelection in 2020. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff said that Bolton is also a "very important" witness and House Democrats want him to testify. However, he is already anticipating another standoff with the White House.

**Iraq's Political Crisis: Prime Minister Vows to Fight Successor's Nomination**

Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has vowed to fight the nomination of his successor, Haider al-Abadi, the deputy speaker of Parliament, who is working to form a government. The United States has backed al-Abadi and has stepped up aid to support the new government. The militant group Islamic State has made significant gains in Iraq's north, prompting concerns about the country's political stability.

According to senior U.S. officials, al-Maliki is likely to try to obstruct the political process to prevent al-Abadi from taking office. However, they believe he lacks the support to do so, as a large portion of the Shia bloc, including most of his own party, backs al-Abadi. The U.S. has promised additional financial and military support to help al-Abadi's government combat Islamic State, which has claimed large areas of territory in northern Iraq.

The U.S. has also increased military aid to the Iraqi government over the past year to combat Islamic State, but has sought to separate this support from its stance on al-Maliki's leadership. The administration has expressed support for al-Abadi's nomination, with President Barack Obama calling it a "promising step forward." Secretary of State John Kerry has stated that the U.S. is "prepared to consider additional political, economic, and security options" to support the new government.

The U.S. has been encouraged by the unprecedented cooperation between the Iraqi military and Kurdish forces in fighting Islamic State, which has given them hope that Iraq's long-divided ethnic groups are finally uniting in the face of the threat. However, the U.S. risks fueling Iraq's sectarian divide by supporting a Shia-led government, which could push the Sunni population towards Islamic State.

The outcome of this political crisis remains uncertain, with al-Maliki's vow to fight al-Abadi's nomination and the U.S. backing for the new government. If al-Maliki is successful in obstructing the political process, the U.S. may be forced to choose between supporting his caretaker government or waiting for a new prime minister to be designated.

Title: Trump Accuses Elizabeth Warren of Destroying Bernie Sanders' Campaign, Claims She Should Have Dropped Out Before Super Tuesday

Article:

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Monday to accuse Senator Elizabeth Warren of single-handedly destroying Senator Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign. Trump claimed that if Warren had dropped out of the race ahead of Super Tuesday, Sanders could have swept the contests. According to Trump, Sanders lost states he would have won if Warren had dropped out three days earlier.

However, the facts suggest a more complex picture. Sanders had built strong momentum before Super Tuesday, having won most of the early contests. He tied the Iowa Caucuses with Pete Buttigieg and won the races in New Hampshire and Nevada. Biden, on the other hand, had a lackluster start to the calendar but gained momentum after winning the South Carolina primary, which gave him a much-needed boost ahead of Super Tuesday.

Warren did drop out of the presidential race last week, but only after the delegate-rich Super Tuesday primaries. She has not yet endorsed either Biden or Sanders. Sanders, known for his fiery rhetoric, has directed his ire towards the party establishment, currently targeting former Vice President Joe Biden and the powerbrokers backing him.

Warren's departure from the race has left her supporters without a clear choice, and it remains unclear whether she will endorse one candidate or the other. Biden has received endorsements from Senators Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, while Sanders has not yet received an endorsement from Warren.

Title: Trump Blocks Release of Democratic Memo on Russia Investigation, Citing National Security Concerns

The White House has blocked the release of a 10-page memo written by Democratic members of the House Intelligence Committee, which aimed to rebut a Republican document that President Donald Trump allowed to be made public last week. The Republican memo claimed that the FBI and Justice Department were biased against Trump in the federal probe of Russia's interference in the 2016 US election.

The decision has infuriated Democrats, with Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer saying, "Millions of Americans are asking one simple question: what is he hiding?" White House Counsel Don McGahn stated that the Justice Department had identified portions of the memo that "would create especially significant concerns for the national security and law enforcement interests" of the country.

The White House also released a letter from FBI Director Christopher Wray and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, expressing concerns about the memo's release in relation to protecting US intelligence sources and methods. The letter stated that the release of the memo could compromise sensitive information and potentially harm national security.

The controversy surrounding the memo is the latest in a series of disputes between Trump and the Justice Department over the Russia investigation. Trump had previously allowed the release of a memo written by Republican members of the House Intelligence Committee, which took aim at senior law enforcement officials. The Democratic memo, on the other hand, is said to contain facts that the public needs to know, including that the FBI acted properly in seeking permission from a special court for surveillance of Carter Page, a Trump campaign adviser with ties to Russia.

The Intelligence Committee voted unanimously on Monday to release the document drafted by the panel's Democrats, contingent on the Republican president agreeing to reclassify it. However, Trump has blocked the release, citing national security concerns. The White House has also released a letter from McGahn, stating that the president would be willing to reconsider the release of the memo if the committee decides to revise it "to mitigate the risks" identified by the Justice Department.

The controversy has sparked reactions from both sides, with Democratic Representative Ted Lieu calling Trump's action "outrageous" and stating that he believes Trump is intentionally hiding relevant information from the American people. Republican Chairman Devin Nunes has defended the president's decision, stating that the memo "totally vindicates" Trump in the Russia investigation.

The Russia investigation, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, is ongoing, with Trump facing scrutiny over potential collusion with Russia during the 2016 election.

Title: United States Surpasses China as Hardest-Hit Country by Coronavirus Pandemic

The United States has officially become the country with the most confirmed coronavirus cases, surpassing China, where the virus originated. According to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University and Worldometer, the U.S. has recorded over 82,285 cases. This milestone is a testament to the country's extensive testing efforts, with over 552,000 tests conducted to date, a 14.9% rate of positives.

The U.S. death toll stands at 1,177, the sixth-highest in the world, indicating that the country's healthcare system is helping to keep Americans alive at a higher rate than European countries. The confirmed-case death rate in the U.S. is 1.4%, compared to 4% in China, 10.2% in Italy, 7.4% in Spain, 0.6% in Germany, 7.6% in Iran, 5.8% in France, 1.6% in Switzerland, and 5.0% in the United Kingdom.

The U.S. has identified Chicago and Detroit areas as potential new hotspots for the virus, with officials concerned about rapid increases in cases in Cook County, Illinois, and Wayne County, Michigan. The Seattle area remains a hot spot, and New Orleans has seen a rapid growth rate of virus cases, with the metro area accounting for 70% of the roughly 1,800 cases in Louisiana.

The U.S. Army is sending two field hospitals to New York City, which will begin treating patients at the Javits Center on Monday. The hospitals will include up to 700 personnel and almost 300 beds, and will help staff additional beds and medical equipment brought in by state and local authorities. An Army combat hospital from Fort Carson, Colorado, will also be heading to Seattle.

These developments highlight the ongoing efforts to combat the spread of the coronavirus and provide support to affected areas.

Title: Bipartisan Efforts Continue on Immigration Reform, with Progress on Visa Program and Pathway to Citizenship

The ongoing debate on immigration reform in the United States has seen significant progress on two key issues: the visa program for low-skilled, year-round, temporary workers and the pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the AFL-CIO have reached a compromise on the visa program, acknowledging the need for a system that meets business demands while protecting American workers. However, the two groups remain divided on the number of visas to be offered, with the Chamber advocating for 400,000 and the AFL-CIO proposing a number in the "very, very low five figures."

Meanwhile, a bipartisan group of eight senators is working to improve the E-Verify system, which employers use to check the immigration status of their workers. The group is considering an enhanced system that would allow employers to use photographs to identify job applicants and require workers to answer security questions to prove their legal work status.

Despite the remaining differences, the senators are making steady progress toward an overall deal, according to sources familiar with the talks. President Obama has expressed satisfaction with the current pace of negotiations, and White House officials have indicated that he is willing to work with Congress to pass an immigration overhaul.

However, the road ahead remains challenging, particularly in the Republican-controlled House. A group of House Republicans has announced that they are close to releasing a set of principles to guide their own legislation, which would likely differ from the Senate's approach. House Republicans prefer to tackle immigration reform in smaller bills rather than a single comprehensive bill, and many want to offer illegal immigrants a legal status that falls short of a pathway to citizenship.

Despite these challenges, the momentum appears to be building on the pathway to citizenship issue, with senators making progress on this contentious topic. The debate on immigration reform is complex and multifaceted, but the ongoing efforts of lawmakers and stakeholders aim to find a solution that balances the needs of businesses, workers, and the economy.

Title: Trump Kicks Off Presidential Re-Election Bid with Rally in Orlando

Donald Trump officially launched his re-election bid on Tuesday night in Orlando, Florida, a crucial battleground state in the 2020 presidential election. The event was more about showcasing his campaign strategy and rhetoric than a surprise announcement, as he had filed his paperwork for re-election in January 2017.

The rally, held at a 20,000-seat arena, was a trial run of his pitch to the American people, with Trump trying out lines to gauge his supporters' reactions. The crowd's response offered clues about what could be in store for his re-election campaign. Trump boasted about the state of the American economy, regulation-cutting, boosts in military spending, trade negotiations, tax reform, border security, and judicial appointments, all of which received a warm reception from the audience.

The Trump phenomenon has always been about more than policies, with his success attributed to his ability to connect with his supporters and make them feel part of his movement. The rally in Orlando was no exception, with attendees praising his authenticity and ability to speak to them directly.

The event also saw Trump air his grievances against his critics in the "fake news" media, the Democratic Party, and the nation's elite, framing his re-election campaign as a bid for vindication. He warned his supporters that Democrats are trying to erase his legacy and destroy the country if they defeat him in 2020.

Outside the arena, a small group of anti-Trump protesters waved "Baby Trump" balloons and held handmade signs, while a Democratic state legislator from Orlando expected the president to throw "red meat" to his base. The 2020 election may come down to a battle of turnout and passion, fueled by equal parts dedication to the cause and antipathy toward the opposition.

Trump's rally in Orlando showed that he can still draw a massive crowd eager for the political battles to come, with his base enthusiastic about his rhetoric and pugilistic attitude. The enthusiasm may be greater due to pessimistic polls, as Trump and his supporters are motivated to fight against the Democrats, the media, and the world.

Title: Trump Announces Increased Tariffs on Chinese Imports, Stresses Need for Changed Behavior

The United States has announced an increase in tariffs on $200 billion worth of imports from China, effective this Friday. The move comes as a response to China's alleged failure to comply with previous agreements and its continued economic aggression. The tariffs will increase from 10% to 25% on the affected goods, which account for 46% of the $540 billion in goods imported from China in 2018.

The decision was made by President Trump, who stated that the days of negotiating with weak counterparts are over. He emphasized the need for China to recognize that time is short to avoid prolonged pain for its economic aggression and malfeasance. The move is seen as a way to put pressure on China to change its behavior and comply with international norms.

China's ability to retaliate is limited, as the trade relationship is heavily skewed in its favor. The US exported only $120 billion in goods to China last year, less than a quarter of what it imported from the country.

The decision has been met with criticism from some quarters, including former Vice President Joe Biden, who has been accused of being too soft on China. However, President Trump has refused to cave in and has held firm in negotiations on issues such as cyber intrusions, market-distorting subsidies, and the forced transfer of US business technology.

The US has also been frustrated by China's repeated violations of agreements, including its failure to respect the freedom and autonomy of Hong Kong and its militarization of the South China Sea. The US has insisted that tariffs remain on Chinese goods until China demonstrates changed behavior, rather than just promising to change.

The move is seen as a significant shift in the US approach to trade negotiations, as it prioritizes the need for China to change its behavior rather than just making concessions. The US Treasury Secretary has stated that the trade team will either recommend a deal or recommend against one, given China's intransigence and duplicity.

The increased tariffs are expected to have a significant impact on the US economy, but some experts believe that the move will ultimately benefit the country in the long run by promoting fairer trade practices and protecting American industries.

Title: Income Inequality Reaches Historic High in the United States

The past year saw a significant increase in income for Americans, but the benefits were not evenly distributed. According to a recent analysis by economist Emmanuel Saez, the bottom 99% of the country's income distribution saw a 3.9% increase in take-home pay, adjusted for inflation, the best growth in 17 years. However, the top 1% of earners outpaced this growth, with their income increasing by 7.7% last year, reaching a new high.

The past two years have seen a moderate increase in income growth for the majority of Americans, but they have not fully recovered from the recession. The bottom 99% of earners saw their incomes fall 11.6% during the height of the recession from 2007 to 2009, and they have only recovered about 60% of what they lost since then. In contrast, the top 1% of earners saw their incomes grow 37% between 2009 and 2015, capturing more than half of all income growth in the country over that period.

The top 10% of earners took home more than half of all income last year, the highest share ever recorded except for 2012. Income inequality is now at its highest level in the country's history, according to economists Peter Lindert and Jeffrey Williamson, who analyzed tax records, directories, and historical accounts to go back further than most data. They found that in the country's earliest post-colonial history, inequality was quite low and much lower than countries across the Atlantic.

Many factors have contributed to growing income inequality, including the rich getting more and more of their money from returns on investments, which are taxed at a lower rate. Overall, taxes and public programs are doing much less than they used to to mitigate the growth of income inequality, as taxes have been lowered on the rich while lawmakers have withered the social safety net.

Title: US Job Market Rebounds in March, Adding 196,000 Jobs Amid Economic Uncertainty

The US labor market showed a strong rebound in March, with employers adding 196,000 jobs, easing concerns about a slowdown in payroll growth. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.8%, according to the Labor Department's report released on Friday. Economists had estimated 175,000 jobs would be added last month.

The job gains for January and February were revised upward by 14,000, indicating a return to normalcy after severe weather-related disruptions earlier this year. Payroll growth was weak in February, with only 33,000 additions, largely attributed to weather conditions. Construction and leisure and hospitality industries were particularly affected.

The March report showed job gains in health care and social assistance, professional and business services, leisure and hospitality, and construction, with manufacturing cutting 6,000 jobs, a second consecutive anemic showing. Retail shed 12,000 jobs, following a 20,000 decline in February.

The labor force participation rate fell to 63% from 63.2%, indicating a possible resumption of its longer-term decline as baby boomers retire. However, this could also be a one-off drop. The share of American adults working or looking for jobs fell to 63% from 63.2%.

Average hourly earnings rose 4 cents to $27.70, lowering the annual gain from 3.4% to 3.2%. Wage growth has picked up as employers compete for a dwindling supply of available workers, but it has not yet prompted most companies to pass their rising labor costs onto consumers through higher prices, keeping inflation subdued.

The report offers no reason for the Federal Reserve to consider cutting interest rates, as President Trump has urged. However, the report does not suggest a strong enough economy to prompt a rate hike, keeping the Fed in a wait-and-see mode. The Dow Jones industrial average was up about 20 points, or less than 0.1%, in mid-day trading.

Title: House Tax-Code Writer Defends Overhaul Plan Against Criticism of Middle-Class Tax Increases

The House's top tax-code writer, Representative Kevin Brady, defended the chamber's overhaul plan against criticism that many middle-class Americans will pay more and turn voters against the Republican Party. Brady, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, argued that the plan provides tax relief for all Americans, regardless of their income level.

Brady disputed analyses, including one in The New York Times, which concluded that one-third of middle-class families will receive a tax increase. He claimed that these critics are describing an America where the economy never grows and paychecks stay stagnant, which he strongly disagrees with.

Senate Democrats, however, have panned the GOP plan, warning that congressional Republicans representing suburban districts will face voter backlash for their support. Maryland Senator Chris Van Hollen, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, stated that many middle-class families will end up paying more and that those in the suburbs will be particularly affected.

The House and Senate have introduced separate plans, which must pass in each chamber before leaders can craft a compromise bill that gets passed by the entire Congress and put on President Trump's desk before the end of the year. The major differences between the two plans are the delay of a corporate tax cut and the elimination of state and local tax deductions.

Brady emphasized that while there are differences between the plans, there is more common ground than differences. He also expressed optimism about the House plan keeping some state and local deductions and predicted that the committee will vote on the plan in the coming days, with final passage before the self-imposed Thanksgiving deadline.

Title: Professor Warns of Constitutional Concerns Over President's Executive Order on Immigration

Article: A recent appearance on The Kelly File by George Washington University Law School professor Jonathan Turley has sparked concerns about President Obama's planned executive order legalizing five million illegal immigrants. Turley, who describes himself as a liberal, expressed his concerns about the President's decision to bypass Congress and take unilateral action.

Turley warned that the country is at a tipping point, citing his earlier congressional testimony, and expressed his hope that the President will not get away with violating the separation of powers. He emphasized that no president can take on the power of all three branches, and that the President's actions seem to be taking on legislative authority.

Turley also cautioned the President against ignoring the results of the 2014 midterm elections, which saw a clear message from the American people that they want Congress to take a more active role in governance. He noted that the President's decision to defy Congress on this issue is a "very sad moment" and a "particularly dangerous moment" if the President continues to disregard the will of Congress.

Turley highlighted the importance of the separation of powers, which is designed to protect liberty by preventing any one branch from assuming too much control. He warned that the President's actions are creating a "uber presidency" that could lead to a loss of liberty and undermine the Constitution.

In his remarks, Turley urged his fellow Democrats to consider the long-term consequences of their actions and the potential dangers of creating a president who can operate unchecked. He emphasized that the framers of the Constitution sought to avoid this very scenario, and that the current situation is a "very dangerous" one.

Title: Supreme Court Overturns Defense of Marriage Act, But Challenges Remain for Same-Sex Couples

The Supreme Court's 5-4 decision to overturn the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a significant victory for advocates of same-sex marriage. The 1996 federal law, which defined marriage as between one man and one woman, has been deemed unconstitutional. However, the ruling does not establish a national constitutional right to same-sex marriage, but rather makes married gay couples living in states where their unions are legal eligible for federal benefits already enjoyed by married heterosexual Americans.

The decision will benefit legally married same-sex couples living in states that recognize their unions, allowing them to access federal benefits such as public employee benefits, bankruptcy, estate taxes, and immigration. However, the situation becomes more complex for legally married couples living in states that do not recognize same-sex marriage.

Twelve states and the District of Columbia have legalized same-sex marriage, while a majority of states have enacted constitutional bans on gay marriage. The Supreme Court's decision has created a patchwork of marriage laws across the country, with different federal agencies having different standards for recognizing marriage.

The Obama administration will play a crucial role in implementing the court's decision, and same-sex marriage advocates are urging the administration to take executive action to apply a uniform, federal agency-wide marriage definition. A working group at the Justice Department's office of legal counsel has been working quietly for months in preparation for this day.

While some definitions are set by regulation, others are set by federal law, further complicating the DOMA rollback. Same-sex marriage advocates predict that congressional action to resolve marriage definition disparities baked into law is unlikely, given the Republican-dominated House.

The Supreme Court's decision is a significant step forward for same-sex marriage advocates, but it also highlights the complexity and challenges that remain. The Obama administration's role in implementing the decision and applying a uniform marriage definition will be crucial in the coming months.

Title: Trump's Military Support: A Mixed Bag of Ex-Pentagon Brass with Checkered Past

The recent letter signed by 88 retired generals and admirals in support of Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been met with skepticism by the media and some military veterans. The letter, which touts Trump as a commander-in-chief capable of dealing with "enemies of this country" and restoring law and order domestically, has been scrutinized for its signatories' backgrounds.

One notable example is retired Lt. Gen. William G. "Jerry" Boykin, who was reprimanded for disclosing classified information in a 2008 memoir. Boykin, a co-founder and former commander of the elite Delta Force, has a history of controversial statements, including his 2003 remark that "I knew that my God was a real God, and his was an idol" during a speech about his hunt for a Somali warlord.

The Daily Beast searched the list of signatories and found that four were present during a 1991 scandal involving sexual assaults at the 35th Annual Tailhook Association Symposium in Las Vegas. None of the signatories were charged, although one later served as a Navy lawyer in the case.

The Washington Post and CNN have also raised questions about the credentials of some of the signatories, noting that three of the four-star generals supporting Trump retired more than 20 years ago and that some of the signatories did not serve in the same conflicts as Trump.

Retired Army Lt. Gen. Mark Hertling, who was interviewed by CNN, dismissed the names on Trump's list, stating that he did not recognize many of them as being part of the fight against Al Qaeda or other forces.

The media's skepticism has been echoed by Hillary Clinton, Trump's opponent in the November presidential race, who noted that Trump's military support is weaker than that of recent Republicans, such as Mitt Romney and John McCain.

Trump has thanked the military brass for their support, stating that he is honored by their confidence in him to serve as commander-in-chief.

Title: Chinese Hackers Suspected of Stealing Identifying Information of 4 Million Federal Workers

The United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has announced that hackers, believed to be based in China, have breached the computer networks of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and the Interior Department, compromising the identifying information of at least 4 million federal workers. The FBI is currently investigating the incident to determine how and why it occurred.

The stolen data includes information from the OPM, which is responsible for conducting background checks for security clearances, and the Interior Department, which shares its data center with other federal agencies. The breach is believed to have affected every federal agency, with concerns that intelligence agency employee information and former government employees may have also been stolen.

The stolen information could potentially be used to impersonate or blackmail federal employees with access to sensitive information. The OPM is offering credit monitoring and identity theft insurance for 18 months to individuals affected by the breach.

The incident is the latest in a series of cyberattacks on federal agencies, with a former DHS contractor disclosing another breach in November that compromised the private files of over 25,000 DHS workers and thousands of other federal employees. The DHS's intrusion detection system, known as EINSTEIN, identified the hack of OPM's systems and the Interior Department's data center, but it is unclear why it did not detect the breach until after so many records had been copied and removed.

Federal agencies are working to implement two-factor authentication with smart cards to make it harder for intruders to access networks, but implementing this technology takes time. Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr has called for the government to overhaul its cybersecurity defenses, stating that "our response to these attacks can no longer simply be notifying people after their personal information has been stolen. We must start to prevent these breaches in the first place."

Title: South Carolina Congressman Jim Clyburn's Endorsement of Biden: A Look at the Reality of Government Programs

The article discusses South Carolina Congressman Jim Clyburn's endorsement of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and the implications of government programs on the economy and society.
