According to exit polls, 61% of voters said Clyburn's endorsement was an important factor in their decision, and 27% said it was the most important factor.

Clyburn explained that Biden is his friend and has been a reliable vote for government programs that benefit African Americans. He also argued that with Biden on the ticket, reelection prospects for congressmen and congresswomen running for election down the ballot would be better.

The article highlights the similarities between Biden and Bernie Sanders' policies, stating that despite their differences, the realities of their proposals are barely distinguishable. The country is already well down the path to socialism, and without major reforms, it will only become more so.

The article references a Wall Street Journal opinion column by former Senate Banking Committee chairman Phil Gramm and former Bureau of Labor Statistics assistant commissioner John Early, which states that more than 80% of taxes are paid by households with incomes in the top 40% and more than 70% of government transfer payments go to households with incomes in the bottom 40%. The article also notes that the average household income in the bottom 20% is $4,908, and that household receives $45,389 in government transfers.

The article concludes that a President Biden or Sanders would not introduce reforms to bring more market forces into the picture, and that the country is already well on the path to socialism. The article also highlights the difference between socialism and charity, stating that socialism is an institutionalized system that pretends to solve human challenges through politics, whereas charity is voluntary, individualized, and motivated by personal caring.

Title: South Korea's Swift Response to COVID-19: Lessons Learned

The Republic of Korea's swift and decisive response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been widely praised for its effectiveness in slowing the spread of the virus and limiting deaths. In contrast to many other countries, South Korea has seen a relatively low number of confirmed cases and deaths, with fewer than 10,000 cases and 169 deaths reported on April 2. This article examines the key factors that contributed to South Korea's success and what lessons can be learned from its response.

One of the key factors was the country's early preparation and planning. In early January, South Korea began developing and stockpiling test kits, even before a single Korean had been infected. This proactive approach allowed the country to quickly scale up testing and track the spread of the virus.

Another crucial factor was the country's experience with the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak in 2015. This experience led to the establishment of new rules for health crises, empowering the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) to take full authority in directing local responses. Social norms established during the MERS outbreak also made the population more willing to adopt mask-wearing in public.

When the first case of COVID-19 was reported in South Korea, the KCDC quickly sprang into action, setting up a response team to study the virus and tracking the health of over 3,000 people who had traveled to Wuhan, China. The country also established a vast public-private network to produce and administer tests, including drive-through centers, and set up labs to process them.

The country's "super-spreader" identification in Daegu, the third-biggest city, led to a surge in cases, but South Korea quickly responded by increasing testing to over 20,000 people a day and taking more extreme measures. President Moon Jae-in allowed the use of invasive surveillance tactics to track worshippers at Shincheonji churches across the country, and authorities were able to follow the movements of infected people and identify those they had interacted with over the past 14 days.

The country's phone companies have each user's national ID number, allowing authorities to track movements and identify contacts. Those contacts were then told to self-isolate and report their temperatures daily. Anyone who tested positive was sent to one of the quarantine centers set up in hotels and company dorms.

Other Asian countries, such as Singapore, Vietnam, and Taiwan, have also been praised for their effective responses to the pandemic. These countries were previously hit by the 2003 epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which had a 10% fatality rate. As a result, they adopted new health policies involving mask-wearing, testing, and tracking, which helped them respond quickly and effectively to the COVID-19 outbreak.

In contrast, the Trump administration's failure to test and impose distancing rules for two months allowed the virus to gain a foothold, leading to the current exponential increase in cases. However, it's not too late for the U.S. to implement wider testing, with South Korea having tested 1 in every 119 of its people, compared to fewer than 1 in 500 Americans.

The article concludes that the U.S. culture of individualism and states' rights makes it unsuited to extensive contact tracing, surveillance of infected people, and other extreme measures. Governors in eight states were still resisting pleas this week by federal health officials to issue mandatory stay-at-home orders, citing fears of infringing on "personal liberty."

Title: Pelosi Open to Impeachment Proceedings Against Trump, Depending on Mueller's Findings

Article:

House Representative Nancy Pelosi, set to become the new House speaker, has left the door open to impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump, pending the findings of the special counsel investigating Russia's meddling in the 2016 election. In an interview with NBC's "Today" show, Pelosi stated that the decision to impeach would depend on the outcome of Robert Mueller's probe into contacts between Trump's presidential campaign and Russia.

Pelosi, who is expected to take the reins of the House on Thursday, previously expressed reservations about impeachment, citing concerns it could be a "divisive activity." However, she has since taken a more nuanced stance, emphasizing that impeachment should not be undertaken for political reasons.

The Constitution requires impeachment proceedings to begin in the House, where Democrats are now expected to hold a majority. Pelosi noted that it is unclear whether a sitting president can be indicted, citing Justice Department guidelines that suggest it is unlikely. However, she believes that a president can be indicted after leaving office.

Trump has denied any wrongdoing in the campaign or with his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, who pleaded guilty to federal campaign finance violations. Pelosi also discussed Trump's insistence on funding for his promised U.S.-Mexico border wall, stating that it is "hard to pin the president down on the facts" and that he "resists science, evidence, data, truth."

Pelosi also responded to criticism from Trump about her trip to Hawaii over the holidays, while he canceled his planned visit to Florida due to the government shutdown. She emphasized that Hawaii is part of the United States and that she was available on 24 hours' notice.

Title: Justice Department Signals Trump-Russia Inquiry May Be Nearing Completion

The special counsel's Russia investigation is "close to being completed," according to Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, marking the first official indication that the inquiry may be wrapping up. Whitaker made the comment during an unrelated news conference in Washington, stating he had been "fully briefed" on the investigation.

The investigation, which has shadowed President Donald Trump's presidency, has charged 34 individuals, including several close to the president. However, no one close to the Trump campaign has been accused of conspiring with the Kremlin to aid Trump's election.

Whitaker, a Trump ally, took over the Justice Department and oversight of the Mueller probe after former Attorney General Jeff Sessions resigned at Trump's request in November. He has faced criticism for not recusing himself from the Russia investigation, despite publicly criticizing it in the past.

According to Justice Department regulations, Special Counsel Robert Mueller will provide a report to the attorney general at the conclusion of his investigation, outlining his prosecution decisions. However, it remains unclear what form the report will take or whether it will be released publicly. The report may not even go to Whitaker, as Trump has nominated William Barr to serve as the next attorney general, pending a Senate vote.

Barr has expressed a desire to release as much information as possible about Mueller's findings, but has hedged on specifics. Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia, calling the investigation a "witch-hunt."

The evidence so far suggests that a broad range of Trump associates had Russia-related contacts during the 2016 presidential campaign and transition period, with several lying about the communication. Those contacts occurred while the Russian government was actively working to influence the election and sway it in Trump's favor.

Roger Stone, a longtime Trump confidant, became the sixth Trump associate to be charged by Mueller, facing charges of lying to lawmakers, witness tampering, and obstructing a congressional investigation. Stone is expected to plead not guilty at his Tuesday morning arraignment.

Title: Stagnant Wages Remain a Challenge for American Workers Despite Economic Growth

Despite the United States' recovering job market, many Americans are still struggling to see significant raises in their paychecks. According to data, since 1979, average wages have barely kept pace with inflation. This stagnation is not limited to individuals; it also has a broader impact on the economy.

Experts point to sluggish productivity growth as one of the main causes of wage stagnation. In the decades following World War II, American productivity grew steadily, nearly 3% each year. However, in the mid-1970s, this growth slowed to less than 2%. This slowdown has led to a disconnect between productivity and wages, where workers produce more but do not necessarily see the benefits.

Another factor contributing to wage stagnation is the growing wealth gap. Virtually all of the gains made over the past three decades have gone to those at the top of the income scale. This has led to a situation where policymakers are often focused on redistributing wealth through the tax code, rather than addressing the root causes of the problem.

Elevator operator Michael Hall and self-employed truck driver John Pallaoro are just two examples of individuals who have seen their paychecks stagnate over the years. Hall, who has been working at the Space Needle in Seattle for seven years, has not received a raise in four years, while Pallaoro's pay has not increased in decades.

Experts suggest that policymakers need to focus on shaping the rules of the economic game to help average workers command higher pretax wages. Some potential solutions include increasing the minimum wage, making it easier for unions to organize, and implementing immigration policies that limit the growth of the shadow workforce.

The late 1990s offer a glimmer of hope for struggling workers. During this period, the economy was growing rapidly, and the gains were widely shared, allowing workers on every rung of the economic ladder to climb together. Unemployment was below 5% during this time, giving workers leverage to demand higher wages.

As the next president takes office, a central challenge will be ensuring that more American families are not stuck on the bottom floor. The debate over the next year and a half will likely focus on policies that can boost workers' bargaining power and address the root causes of wage stagnation.

Title: Trump Administration Faces Uncertainty as Russia Investigation Enters New Phase

The news of a potential indictment in the Russia investigation has sent shockwaves throughout the Trump administration and the nation's capital. The development marks a significant step forward for the investigation, which has been ongoing since May 2017, when Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Robert Mueller as special counsel to oversee the Justice Department's inquiry.

The investigation has been shrouded in controversy, with Trump-aligned media figures and the President himself questioning the legitimacy of the probe. Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia, and has instead pointed to alleged collusion between the Clinton campaign and Russia.

The news comes after a week of intense criticism from conservative media outlets and Trump's Twitter account, which claimed that the Clinton campaign was behind the creation of the Steele dossier, an intelligence document detailing Trump's Russian ties. The FBI's inquiry predates the dossier, and officials have reportedly said it played no role in the intelligence assessment of Russia's interference in the 2016 election.

The investigation has been marked by controversy and intrigue, including the firing of former FBI Director James Comey and the release of contemporaneous memos written by Comey detailing his interactions with Trump. The memos depicted a President who had little regard for the traditional firewall between the White House's political operations and the Justice Department's criminal investigations.

The investigation has been ongoing for over a year, with no clear end in sight. The potential indictment of anyone connected to the Trump campaign or the White House would be a major development, sending shockwaves throughout the administration and the nation's capital.

Title: Elizabeth Warren's Native American Ancestry Claims Under Scrutiny

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren has been under scrutiny for her claims of Native American ancestry, which she has maintained for years. In a recent video, she shared a story about her parents' elopement, citing her mother's Native American heritage as the reason for their families' initial disapproval. However, a DNA study conducted by Professor Carlos Bustamante of Stanford University revealed that Warren's Native American ancestor may have existed in her family tree "in the range of 6-10 generations ago," making her 1/64th to 1/1024th Native American.

Warren's decision to release the DNA results was seen as an attempt to counter President Trump's criticism of her Native American claims. However, the move backfired, with the Cherokee Nation releasing a statement criticizing Warren's pretensions to Native American group membership. The media's initial support for Warren's claims also began to wane as the story unfolded.

The controversy surrounding Warren's Native American ancestry claims has raised questions about her motivations. Some argue that she claimed Native American status to add diversity to her résumé and enhance her political credentials. Warren's claims of Native American ancestry have been listed in various directories and reports, including those from the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School.

Warren's supporters argue that her claims of Native American ancestry are a way to connect with a historically disadvantaged minority and demonstrate her commitment to social justice. However, critics argue that her claims are based on a "one-drop rule" that suggests a single Native American ancestor makes someone Native American. The controversy highlights the complexities of identity politics and the challenges of navigating issues of race, ethnicity, and ancestry.

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius Takes Responsibility for Obamacare Website Issues

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius testified before a House panel on Wednesday, taking responsibility for the botched rollout of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) and vowing to fix the issues with the HealthCare.gov website. Sebelius acknowledged that the law's messy rollout has hurt the administration's credibility, but assured the public that the website should be running smoothly for most users by November 30.

Sebelius emphasized her accountability for the problems, saying, "You deserve better. I apologize. I'm accountable to you for fixing these problems and I'm committed to earning your confidence back by fixing the site." She also stated that the administration will not release signup numbers until mid-November or allow contractors to speak about them until the information is confirmed and reliable.

The Health and Human Services Secretary also acknowledged that insurers are not receiving accurate and complete data about their new customers due to the website's issues. "They [insurers] are not getting reliable data all the way through the systems," she said. "The system isn't functioning so we're not getting that reliable data. Insurers who I met with said that's the case."

Despite calls for her resignation from some Republicans, Sebelius did not face demands to step down during the hearing. However, some lawmakers criticized her for the administration's handling of the rollout, with Rep. Fred Upton (R-Mich.) stating, "Over the months leading up to the Oct. 1 launch, the secretary and her colleagues at HHS repeatedly looked us in the eye and testified that everything was on track. But something happened along the way – either those officials did not know how bad the situation was, or they did not disclose it."

On the other hand, some Democrats, such as Rep. Henry Waxman (D-Calif.), expressed confidence in Sebelius and urged lawmakers to stop "hyperventilating" about the website's problems. "The problems with HealthCare.gov are unfortunate and we should investigate them, but they will be fixed," he said.

The hearing came as HealthCare.gov experienced technical issues, with an outage at a data center hosted by Verizon Terremark causing problems for users. Despite the challenges, Sebelius remains committed to fixing the website and restoring public confidence in the Affordable Care Act.

Title: Senator Manchin Seeks Bipartisan Support for Gun Control Measures

Article:

Senator Joe Manchin, a lifelong member of the National Rifle Association (NRA), is working to craft bipartisan legislation to expand background checks on firearm purchases. Manchin, a Democrat from West Virginia, has been in close contact with the NRA and is leading a group of lawmakers in an effort to pass a bill that would require background checks for all gun sales, including those between private sellers and unlicensed dealers.

Manchin's efforts come as the Senate prepares to take up gun control measures as early as next month. The Senate Judiciary Committee has already approved a sweeping assault weapons ban and a prohibition on high-capacity ammunition magazines, but those proposals face an uphill battle in the full Senate.

Manchin is trying to persuade at least one pro-NRA Republican to join him in his efforts, which would help to build momentum for the bill. He has been in talks with Senator Mark Begich, a Democrat from Alaska, to combine Begich's proposal to modify gun restrictions for the mentally ill with a new background check plan.

However, Begich has emphasized that Manchin needs to win over more Republican senators than just moderate Senator Mark Kirk, who has an "F" rating from the NRA. Begich believes that Manchin needs to bring on board at least one "A-rated" NRA Republican to have a chance at passing the bill.

The central sticking point in the negotiations is whether records of gun sales or purchases should be retained by retailers. Manchin is working to build a bipartisan coalition and is confident that pro-gun senators will vote for the bill, even if they decline to sign on as sponsors.

It remains to be seen whether Manchin's efforts will be successful, but his willingness to work with the NRA and his reputation as an "eternal optimist" suggest that he is committed to finding a solution that can pass in the divided Senate.

Title: Alabama Republican Party Chairman Expresses Disappointment, Respects Voting Process After Senate Election

The Alabama Republican Party Chairman, Terry Lathan, released a statement late Tuesday, acknowledging the end of the state's Senate race. In the statement, Lathan expressed disappointment over the close race, in which Democrat Doug Jones defeated GOP candidate Roy Moore. Lathan noted that the party is "deeply disappointed" in the outcome, but respects the voting process established by the Founding Fathers.

Lathan also highlighted Jones' campaign promises to work across the aisle with Republicans, stating that "while these issues weren't discussed and no other Democratic Senator has worked with the Republicans, all eyes will be on his votes." She emphasized that Alabamians are conservative and have no intention of moving towards the policies of the Democratic Party. If Jones aligns himself with liberal Democrats in Washington, Alabama voters will remember his choices in the 2020 U.S. Senate election.

Meanwhile, Moore's campaign refused to concede the election, with his campaign chairman, Bill Armistead, stating that "when the vote is this close, it is not over." Alabama state law requires an automatic recount when election results are within 0.5 percentage points. As of reporting, Jones holds 49.9% of the vote, compared to Moore's 48.4%, a 1.5-point gap.

In his victory speech, Jones emphasized the importance of finding common ground and unity, stating that Alabamians led by example in showing the rest of the country how to be united. Jones' win marks the first time a member of his party has won a Senate seat in the state since 1992.

Title: Lawmakers' Delay on Sequestration Cuts May Hinder Hiring and Economic Growth

The uncertainty surrounding the sequestration of automatic spending cuts, set to take effect next year, is causing concern among federal agencies and government contractors. The sequestration, which would total around $110 billion next year, is expected to be decided during the lame-duck session of Congress after Election Day, possibly not until early 2013. This prolonged uncertainty is likely to cause hiring slowdowns and possible layoffs, experts and businesses warn.

Businesses and agencies need to plan for the year ahead, but they cannot do so without knowing how many contracts will be funded and which programs will be cut back on. The uncertainty is already having a chilling effect on the defense industry, with companies like Booz Allen Hamilton and Lockheed Martin taking a more conservative approach to hiring and investing.

The sequestration would cut $55 billion from defense spending and $55 billion from non-defense domestic programs. While lawmakers say they want to help create jobs and economic growth, the uncertainty surrounding the sequestration is likely to have the opposite effect. Experts predict a dramatic slowdown in hiring this fall, with federal agencies and private contractors reluctant to enter into new commitments or make long-term plans.

The WARN Act, which requires businesses with over 100 employees to notify workers at least 60 days in advance of a mass layoff or plant closing, may also come into play. Layoff notices could be issued as early as November, just before the election.

Government contracts expert Dan Gordon expects a "dramatic slowdown in hiring" this fall, while Joseph Minarik, senior vice president of the Committee for Economic Development, believes hiring freezes are the greatest risk on the jobs front. The Committee for Economic Development's Minarik also notes that the time spent planning for this situation is "pure economic waste."

The uncertainty surrounding the sequestration is a real threat to the economy, according to Senator Carl Levin, who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee. "We must do it in time to avoid a severe weakening to this economy," he said.

Title: Democratic Establishment Rallies Around Biden, But Sanders Remains a Strong Contender

The Democratic primary has taken a dramatic turn as the establishment has rallied around Joe Biden, citing concerns about electability and the need to unite the party. However, this sudden surge of support is not necessarily a reflection of Biden's strengths as a candidate, but rather a desperate reaction to Bernie Sanders' momentum.

Biden's campaign was on the verge of collapse before the establishment's intervention, with little money or campaign organization, and polling far behind Sanders in most Super Tuesday states. However, with the endorsement of House Majority Whip Jim Clyburn, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, and other Democratic officials, Biden has suddenly become a strong contender.

The argument from the establishment is that Biden is the best candidate to take on Donald Trump, citing his moderate stance and ability to appeal to a broad range of voters. However, this argument is not without its flaws. Sanders has consistently polled well against Trump, and his strong fundraising abilities and dedicated activist base make him a formidable opponent.

Moreover, Biden's record is at odds with the modern Democratic Party's branding, with a history of supporting policies that have harmed many Americans, including the Iraq War, bankruptcy bill, and financial deregulation. His campaign has also been marked by controversy, including allegations of creepiness towards women and concerns about his cognitive decline.

The Democratic establishment's support for Biden may be a desperate attempt to prevent a Sanders nomination, which could deflate the activist energy that has built up around his campaign. However, this strategy may ultimately backfire, as younger voters who are drawn to Sanders' progressive policies may decide not to vote in November if they feel the fix is in.

Ultimately, the Democratic primary is far from over, with approximately two-thirds of delegates yet to be awarded. The contest is likely to be a grueling one, with both Biden and Sanders vying for the nomination.

Title: The Federal Reserve's Dual Mandate: A Recipe for Economic Instability

The Federal Reserve, led by Chairman Jerome Powell, has been under fire from President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly criticized the institution's handling of interest rates. Trump has called for a full percentage point cut in interest rates, citing the European Central Bank's recent rate cuts. However, libertarians and free market conservatives have come to the Fed's defense, arguing that the institution's dual mandate is flawed and has contributed to past economic crises.

The Fed's dual mandate, established in 1977, aims to achieve both price stability and maximum sustainable employment. However, critics argue that this goal is unrealistic and has led to poor monetary policy decisions. Research suggests that the Fed's failure to contain inflation and create stability in the financial system has contributed to severe banking crises, including those in the 1920s, 1930s, 1980s, and 2000s.

The Fed's control over the money supply is also seen as a flawed concept, as determining the correct supply of money is best left to competitive markets. Economists such as F.A. Hayek, Larry White, and George Selgin have argued that the knowledge necessary to determine the appropriate supply of money is discovered and revealed only through the competitive market process.

The Fed's second mandate of boosting employment is also seen as unrealistic, as it reflects politicians' belief that the government can create, control, and maximize the number of jobs. The Fed's own experience has shown that its policies of quantitative easing and super-low interest rates have prolonged the recession and reduced the return on savings for retirees and others living on fixed incomes.

Experts are unsure of the Fed's impact on growth since 2017, and some argue that the institution's policies have discouraged saving and investment, leading to reduced capital expenditures and slowing the growth of labor productivity and real output. The politicization of the Fed has also led it to pursue policies that go against the objective of price stabilization and financial stability.

In conclusion, the Federal Reserve's dual mandate is a recipe for economic instability, and it is essential to reevaluate its role in the economy. As Milton Friedman once said, "money is much too serious a matter to be left to the central bankers."

Title: Trump Calls Getting Rid of FBI Officials Involved in Trump-Russia Probe One of His Greatest Achievements

Article:

President Donald Trump stated on Tuesday that he considers getting rid of FBI officials involved in the Trump-Russia probe to be one of his greatest achievements in office. Trump made the comment while on Christmas vacation at Mar-a-Lago, in response to a question about whether he is considering a pardon for Roger Stone, a longtime GOP operative who was indicted in the special counsel's investigation.

Trump did not specify which FBI officials he is referring to, but he has previously fired several high-ranking officials, including former FBI Director James Comey, former Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, and former Deputy Chief of Counterintelligence Peter Strzok. Strzok was fired in August 2018 over anti-Trump text messages he exchanged with FBI lawyer Lisa Page. Page resigned from the bureau in May 2018.

The Justice Department's inspector general found that the FBI made "significant inaccuracies" in applications for surveillance warrants against Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The FBI relied heavily on the Steele dossier to obtain the warrants, despite having evidence that undermined the credibility of dossier author Christopher Steele.

Trump stated that he has not yet considered a pardon for Stone, but believes he was treated "very unfair" in the special counsel's case. He also claimed that his campaign was spied on and that the investigation was a "big hoax."

Title: Married Women's Political Views Shift Away from Trump, Toward Democrats

The article explores the shift in political views among married women, who have traditionally been more conservative than unmarried women. According to recent polling, 57% of married women disapprove of President Trump's job performance, a significant increase from 40% in March 2017. This shift is attributed to various factors, including social networks, spousal influence, and economics.

The article highlights the experiences of Christine Garcia, a 37-year-old stay-at-home mom who considers herself a fiscal conservative but a social liberal. She would not disclose her 2016 vote, but expresses disapproval of President Trump and would not vote for him in 2020. Garcia's views are echoed by other married women, who cite concerns about the economy, social issues, and the president's behavior.

The article also explores the experiences of Republican women, who consistently tout the health of the economy. However, younger women, regardless of marital status, tend to be more liberal and Democratic. The article notes that fewer than 50% of American women are married, and the voting gap among women is not solely due to single women, but also tied to age.

The article concludes by highlighting the experiences of married women who have shifted their political views, citing concerns about the president's policies and behavior. These women, such as Louri Jouppi and Sonia Patel, are now volunteering for Democratic candidates and willing to pay more taxes if it means upholding their moral values.

Title: American Electorate Divided: Parties Drift Apart on Demographic Lines

The upcoming presidential election is set to take place amidst a backdrop of increasing polarization in the United States. A recent Pew Research Center study reveals that the two major parties, the Republicans and Democrats, have become less alike than at any time in the past quarter-century. The study highlights fundamental demographic changes in the country, including an aging population, growing racial and ethnic diversity, and rising levels of education, which have reshaped both party coalitions.

The report notes that the Republican Party is becoming whiter, older, and more religious, while the Democratic Party is becoming more diverse, younger, and less religious. The racial makeup of the parties is also becoming increasingly dissimilar, with racial minorities disproportionately favoring the Democratic Party.

In 2008, whites made up 88% of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters, but by 2016, that number had dropped to 86%. Meanwhile, whites made up 64% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners in 2008, but that number has decreased to 57% over the past eight years.

The same trend holds for age, education, and religion. Republicans are becoming relatively older, while college-educated voters are declining as a percentage of the GOP and increasing as a percentage of the Democratic vote. The Democratic coalition now includes 29% of voters who identify as atheist, agnostic, or nothing in particular, compared to 12% of the GOP.

These demographic changes have real-world implications, as different groups have different outlooks and interests. Minorities are more likely to support affirmative action, while college-educated voters are more likely to support increased federal aid for education. Religious voters are more likely to oppose abortion.

The report concludes that the Democratic coalition is more comfortable with diversity, believes the present is better than the past, and looks forward to the future with optimism. In contrast, the Republican coalition sees increasing diversity as a threat, prefers past decades over today, and looks ahead with foreboding.

The winner of the 2016 presidential election will face the challenge of bridging these differences, according to William A. Galston, a senior fellow in governance studies at the Brookings Institution. He notes that these are differences of kind, not degree, and will require an agenda of national reconciliation starting on Day 1 of the transition.

Title: Former CIA Director Warns Iran to "Be Very Careful" Amid Escalating Tensions

Former CIA Director David Petraeus has cautioned Iran to be cautious as tensions between the Middle Eastern nation and the United States continue to escalate. Petraeus warned that Iran will need to "tighten their belt" and prepare for further "screws tightening" in the "maximum pressure campaign" to achieve their desired outcome by November 2020.

Petraeus emphasized the importance of Iran not overplaying its hand and avoiding a punitive response. The warning comes as the Trump administration has sent an aircraft carrier and other military resources to the Persian Gulf region and withdrawn non-essential personnel from Iraq, sparking concerns about the possibility of a confrontation with Iran.

The tensions between Tehran and Washington stem from reports of bombings and attacks across the region linked to Iranian-backed terror groups and the US withdrawal from the nuclear accord with Iran over a year ago. The Trump administration reimposed crippling economic sanctions on Iran, which retaliated by threatening to enrich its uranium stockpile closer to weapons-grade levels if world powers fail to negotiate new terms for its 2015 nuclear deal. Iran has stopped its sale of excess uranium and heavy water as a first step, which was required under the deal.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal to Headline Republican Fundraiser in New Hampshire, Fueling Speculation About 2016 Presidential Bid

Governor Bobby Jindal of Louisiana will deliver the keynote address at a Republican fundraiser in Manchester, New Hampshire, on Friday, sparking speculation about his potential 2016 presidential bid. The event, hosted by the GOP state Senate Political Action Committee, is expected to attract a high price tag, with tickets ranging from $1,000 to $5,000.

Steven Duprey, a Republican National Committee member from New Hampshire, believes the Granite State is an ideal location for candidates to lay the groundwork for a presidential run. "For candidates who might not have as much money as some others, or who aren't yet nationally known, this is a great time to come to New Hampshire to start to introduce themselves and to listen to what New Hampshire voters are concerned about," Duprey said.

Duprey, who served as Senator John McCain's campaign manager during his 2008 presidential bid, emphasized the importance of interacting with voters in a more intimate setting. "John McCain set the standard. Follow his playbook," he said.

The University of Virginia's Center for Politics has handicapped the field of potential 2016 candidates, placing Governor Bobby Jindal in the second tier of candidates for the GOP nomination. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie are considered the frontrunners, with Jindal and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky nipping at their heels.

The event comes as the 2016 presidential election cycle is gaining momentum, with several high-profile politicians already announcing their bids. The New Hampshire primary, which typically takes place in February, is a crucial contest in the nomination process, with many candidates viewing it as a key testing ground for their campaigns.

Title: Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Suspended Amid Controversy Over Same-Sex Marriage Licenses

Alabama's Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy Moore was suspended on Friday, facing possible removal from office for allegedly violating state judicial ethics laws. The Alabama Judicial Inquiry Commission charged Moore with violating the state's judicial ethics laws by ordering state probate judges not to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples, despite contrary rulings by a federal court and the U.S. Supreme Court.

The controversy surrounds Moore's January administrative order to probate judges, instructing them not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples. The order was issued despite the U.S. Supreme Court's June ruling that the U.S. Constitution provides same-sex couples the right to marry, and a federal court ruling making gay marriage legal in Alabama.

The complaint against Moore alleges that he "flagrantly disregarded and abused his authority" by ordering probate judges to commit violations, potentially subjecting them to prosecution and removal from office. Moore has denied the allegations, stating that the commission has no authority over administrative orders or the court's ability to prohibit probate judges from issuing same-sex marriage licenses.

The controversy has resulted in confusion and uncertainty among probate judges, with some issuing marriage licenses to gay couples and others refusing to do so. The Alabama Supreme Court has yet to decide the matter, with Moore stating that until then, probate judges have a "ministerial duty not to issue any marriage license."

Moore, a Republican, has been a vocal opponent of same-sex marriage and has been involved in previous controversies, including being removed from office in 2003 for refusing to remove a Ten Commandments monument. He was re-elected as chief justice in 2012, vowing not to create further friction with the federal courts.

Title: U.S. Investigators Sought Warrants to Read Michael Cohen's Emails in 2017, Documents Reveal

Article:

U.S. investigators sought warrants to read Michael Cohen's emails in July 2017, nine months before the FBI raided the home and office of President Donald Trump's former personal lawyer, according to documents made public on Tuesday. The requests were made six months into Trump's presidency and were sought by Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office as well as the FBI, dating back as far as June 2015.

The nearly 900 pages of documents released by a federal judge in New York provide more detailed accounts of Cohen's financial relationships than previously known. Cohen had been Trump's personal lawyer and self-described fixer for over a decade, but began cooperating with federal investigators soon after the April 2018 raids on his home, office, and hotel room.

The documents reveal that Cohen was in default by December 2017 on more than $20 million in loans backed by New York taxicab medallions he owned. The FBI believed Cohen misrepresented his finances to banks he owed money to. The documents also show that Cohen concealed fees being paid to Essential Consultants, a firm he controlled, for political consulting, including from international clients with issues pending before the Trump administration.

The FBI made extensive use of its access to Cohen's Apple iCloud account, which allowed him to coordinate his work across devices such as an iPhone, iPad Mini, and laptop. Agents said they located a hotel room in New York's Loews Regency Hotel where Cohen was staying by using a device known as a Triggerfish that mimics cell phone towers to find a specific device.

Cohen pleaded guilty in separate prosecutions to lying to Congress, bank fraud, and campaign finance violations. The latter included paying hush money to silence two women who said they had sexual encounters with Trump. Trump has denied having had sexual relationships with the two women, Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal.

The documents were released after U.S. District Judge William Pauley ordered prosecutors to make redacted versions public, in response to requests by news media organizations. Lanny Davis, a lawyer for Cohen, said in a statement that the document release "only furthers his interest in continuing to cooperate and providing information and the truth about Donald Trump and the Trump organization to law enforcement and Congress."

Title: Obama Urges Congress to Act on Comprehensive Immigration Reform

President Barack Obama has called on Congress to move forward on a comprehensive bill to overhaul the nation's immigration system, emphasizing the need for a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the United States. In a speech in Las Vegas, Nevada, Obama laid out key markers he believes must be part of immigration reform, including a pathway to citizenship, increased border security, and a crackdown on businesses that employ undocumented immigrants.

The president's speech comes as a bipartisan group of senators, known as the "Gang of Eight," unveiled their own outline for comprehensive reform, which includes a pathway to citizenship, increased border security, and a crackdown on businesses that employ undocumented immigrants. Obama praised the senators' efforts, stating that their framework is "very much in line with the principles I've proposed and campaigned on for the last few years."

However, Republicans have reacted cautiously to Obama's speech, with some expressing concerns over the president's stance on border security and enforcement. Senator John McCain (R-Ariz.), a member of the Gang of Eight, noted that there are "some differences" between him and the president.

The passage of a comprehensive immigration reform bill in the House of Representatives may prove more challenging, as House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) did not rule out taking up a bill based on Obama's comments. However, Boehner's spokesman Brendan Buck stated that any solution should be a bipartisan one and that the House and Senate must work together to find common ground.

Obama's speech also touched on the need for a pathway to citizenship, which would include going through a background check, paying fines and back taxes, learning English, and going to the back of the line. The president emphasized that this process would not be quick, but it would be fair.

While some Republicans, such as Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), have expressed concerns over the president's stance on border security and enforcement, Obama's speech was met with enthusiasm from the crowd at Del Sol High School, with chants of "sí se puede!" (Yes, we can!) echoing throughout the gymnasium.

The changing political landscape has sparked momentum for comprehensive immigration reform, with seven in 10 Latino voters backing Obama in last November's election. However, Obama emphasized that immigration reform is about more than politics, stating that it is about people and their desire to earn their way into the American story.

Title: Former ICE Director Thomas Homan's Congressional Hearing Erupts in Controversy

Article:

Former acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Thomas Homan, testified before Congress on Thursday, sparking controversy and outrage. Homan, who led the agency from January 2017 to June 2018, was questioned about ICE's conduct and policies during his tenure. The hearing focused on ICE detention centers, which have been criticized for human rights abuses.

During the hearing, Homan faced criticism from Democratic Rep. Pramila Jayapal, who chairs the House Subcommittee on Immigration and Citizenship. Jayapal is the sponsor of the Dignity for Detained Immigrants Act of 2019, which aims to address the problems in ICE facilities. The bill has 130 co-sponsors in the House of Representatives, all Democrats.

Witnesses included Selene Saavedra Roman, a Dreamer wrongfully detained by ICE for six weeks; Denis Davydov, a gay HIV-positive immigrant wrongfully detained by ICE while seeking asylum from Russia; and Blanche Engochan, a Cameroon refugee subjected to horrific mistreatment in ICE detention. These survivors shared their stories of trauma and abuse at the hands of ICE officers.

Homan, however, refused to acknowledge the agency's wrongdoing, instead lashing out at congressional Democrats and accusing them of making "inaccurate and disgusting" attacks on his agency. He praised ICE detention facilities, claiming they have the "highest standards in the industry" and the "best facilities in the world." He also suggested that the U.S. spends too much money on ICE detainees, stating, "I think a lot of taxpayers would be insulted on the amount of money we spend on such a high standards."

Homan's outburst was met with criticism from lawmakers and advocates, who called his behavior unprofessional and unacceptable. His refusal to acknowledge the agency's wrongdoing and his condescending attitude towards lawmakers, particularly women of color, were seen as a symbol of the culture of disrespect and disregard for human rights that has been perpetuated by ICE under his leadership.

The controversy surrounding Homan's testimony highlights the need for accountability and reform within ICE. The agency's detention centers have been criticized for being filthy, brutal, and dangerous, with immigrants being denied access to medical care, forced to live in filthy conditions, and subjected to illegal strip searches. At least 24 immigrants have died in ICE detention under the Trump administration.

The hearing also highlighted the need for Congress to take action to address the problems in ICE facilities. The Dignity for Detained Immigrants Act of 2019, sponsored by Rep. Jayapal, aims to increase standards for ICE facilities, increase inspections, grant more robust rights to detainees, and phase out ICE's use of private prisons. The bill has bipartisan support and is a step towards holding ICE accountable for its actions.

Title: Russian President Vladimir Putin Reappears After 11-Day Absence, Jokes About Rumors

Article: Russian President Vladimir Putin made a public appearance on Monday, putting to rest speculation about his whereabouts over the past 11 days. Putin, 62, met with Kyrgyzstan President Almazbek Atambaev at the Constantine Palace in St. Petersburg. The Russian leader's last public appearance was on March 5, when he was with Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.

During his meeting with reporters, Putin jokingly addressed the rumors surrounding his absence, saying, "It would be boring without gossip." The Kremlin had released undated photo and video footage of Putin, which only fueled speculation about his health, potential loss of control of the government, and even his personal life. However, images published on social media did not indicate any unusual signs about his appearance.

Independent Russian TV channel Dozhd reported that Putin may have been absent due to the flu, while Kurier, an Austrian newspaper, suggested he was being treated in Moscow for back problems. The Kremlin has not commented on the matter.

Alexei Makarkin, vice president of the Moscow-based Center for Political Technologies, stated that discussing Putin's health is equivalent to aiding the enemy, citing the secrecy surrounding the former Soviet Union. The unscheduled inspection of Russia's Northern Fleet, which includes 38,000 military personnel and 3,360 pieces of military hardware, was confirmed by Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, according to the Interfax news service.

Adding to the speculation, a planned visit by Putin to Kazakhstan was postponed to March 20. Moscow has expressed concerns about an increase in NATO exercises near the Russian border. One year ago, Russian forces took over the Black Sea Peninsula, annexing the Ukrainian territory of Crimea.

Title: Trump Arrives at UN General Assembly with Aggressive Agenda

President Donald Trump arrived at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, marking his first appearance at the international gathering as the leader of the United States. According to officials, Trump's mission is to cultivate friendships and call out enemies, with a plan to aggressively put his "America First" agenda into action on the world stage.

Trump's packed schedule includes meetings with senior UN leadership, leaders of over 120 nations, and discussions on reforms to the UN and rethinking America's massive contributions. He will also address the assembly on Tuesday, emphasizing the need for states to promote peace and prosperity while upholding sovereignty and accountability as indispensable foundations of international order.

The president's visit has unnerved many world leaders, who were more comfortable with his predecessor, Barack Obama. Trump's willingness to use American military and economic power has left many wondering what's next. "The world is still trying to take the measure of this president," said Jon Alterman, senior vice president of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

Trump's schedule includes meetings with leaders of France and Israel to discuss how to confront Iran's destabilizing actions across the Middle East, as well as a working dinner with presidents of Peru, Colombia, and Brazil to discuss the crisis in Venezuela. He will also meet with African leaders to strengthen security and economic relationships.

The president's visit comes as the UN faces criticism over its handling of the North Korea crisis, with the US ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, stating that the UN Security Council has run out of options on containing North Korea's nuclear program and the US may have to turn over the matter to the Pentagon.

Trump's visit also comes as he faces criticism over his sharp criticism of the Iran nuclear deal, with administration officials hinting strongly that he will seek to end or renegotiate the deal.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey's Book Excerpts Spark Controversy Over Petty Remarks

Article:

Excerpts from James Comey's new book have sparked controversy over his descriptions of Donald Trump's appearance. The former FBI director's comments about Trump's "orange" face, "small" hands, and "soft white pouches" under his eyes have been criticized as petty and juvenile. While Comey's book is meant to be a serious account of his time as FBI director, these passages have been seen as a departure from that tone.

Critics argue that Comey's focus on Trump's appearance is unnecessary and detracts from the more serious allegations he makes in the book. Instead of building credibility as a witness, Comey's petty remarks make him look like a disgruntled former employee seeking revenge. The comments have also been deemed hackneyed and unoriginal, as they are similar to jokes that have been made about Trump before.

It is unclear why Comey chose to include these remarks in his book, but some speculate that he was trying to get a rise out of Trump. Regardless, the controversy surrounding Comey's book has sparked a larger discussion about the importance of acting adult in public discourse.

Title: Third-Party Candidates Face Uphill Battle to Qualify for Presidential Debate Stage

Third-party candidates Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party nominee, and Jill Stein, the Green Party nominee, are racing against the clock to meet the 15 percent national polling threshold to qualify for the first presidential debate on September 26 at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. The candidates have about a month to boost their polling numbers, but reaching the required threshold remains a steep climb for the underfunded and little-known candidates.

Gary Johnson, the former Republican governor of New Mexico, has approached the 15 percent mark in several surveys, reaching as high as 12 percent in a recent Fox News poll. Johnson's campaign has relied heavily on pushing digital content over social media and media coverage to get his message out. He and his running mate, Bill Weld, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts, have participated in two prime-time town hall events on CNN.

Jill Stein, the liberal Green Party candidate, has topped out at 6 percent in the polls and is only at 4 percent in the RealClearPolitics average. She has made a concerted push to attract supporters of former Democratic contender Bernie Sanders and has grabbed headlines for being fiercely critical of both major party candidates.

Despite the challenges, the third-party candidates have a unique opportunity this year, with both major party presidential candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, having high disapproval ratings. According to GOP pollster David Winston, "You have two historically unappealing candidates in Clinton and Trump that a majority view unfavorably, so a lot of voters are looking for alternatives."

The Johnson-Weld campaign is looking beyond social media to more traditional campaign activities, including rallies, a national radio ad, and a national TV ad in the works. The campaign has raised over $1 million in commitments in one day, with small-dollar fundraising picking up. The campaign has more than 40 paid staffers and nearly as many full-time volunteers.

While pollsters are doubtful either candidate will make the debate stage, the third-party candidates are not giving up. "We think we're moving up right now," said campaign manager Ron Nielson. "We see a lot of support. We feel good. We think we can get above 15 percent."

Title: Florida Reports Record-Breaking 15,000 New Coronavirus Cases, Sparking Concerns and Criticism

Florida has reported a record-breaking 15,000 new coronavirus cases, surpassing the daily record set by any single state. The alarming figure has put the state under intense scrutiny, with public health experts expressing concern about the positivity rate of 11.25%, which is still above the 10% threshold.

The Florida Department of Health received 135,992 test results, with 15,299 coming back positive for COVID-19. While the positivity rate has decreased slightly since the state's record high of 18% reported on Wednesday, it remains a cause for concern.

Governor Ron DeSantis' administration has been criticized for its messaging strategy, which has been seen as downplaying the severity of the situation. The administration has pointed to the decreasing median age of those contracting the disease, with an average age of 38 years old, as a positive sign. However, public health experts argue that the spread in younger populations increases the likelihood of people in at-risk populations, such as seniors, getting sick.

The state's hospitalization numbers have also been a concern, with 6,974 patients hospitalized with coronavirus as their primary diagnosis, a number that jumped to 7,507 on Sunday. The administration had previously refused to disclose hospitalization numbers, but relented after continued pressure from media outlets.

The increased daily case counts and continued double-digit positivity rate come as the issue of reopening Florida's schools becomes the newest politicized coronavirus battlefield. Education Commissioner Richard Corcoran, a DeSantis appointee, has issued an order requiring school districts to open classrooms for five days a week beginning next month. The demand to reopen schools coincides with President Donald Trump's push to get the nation's schools back open, with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos stating that "there has to be a posture of doing something, of action, of getting things going."

The situation in Florida has sparked criticism and concern, with some calling the governor's office's response "heartless" and "disturbing" for using nearly 100 dead Floridians as positive messaging. The increased daily case counts and continued positivity rate highlight the need for continued vigilance and action to combat the spread of the virus.

Title: Romney Launches Scathing Attack on Trump, Calls Him a "Phony" and "Fraud"

Article:

Former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney launched a broadside against Donald Trump's campaign on Thursday, calling the businessman a "phony" and a "fraud" who is playing Americans for "suckers." Romney delivered a scathing speech at the University of Utah, in which he warned that Trump's policies would lead to recession and make America and the world less safe.

Romney also mocked Trump's business record, rattling off some of his lesser-known ventures like Trump Mortgage and saying he would be bad for American workers. He called Trump's promises "as worthless as a degree from Trump University" and said he is playing the American public for suckers.

Trump responded to Romney's criticism, calling him a "failed candidate" who begged him for his endorsement four years ago. Trump also took to Twitter to claim he is the "only one who can beat Hillary Clinton" and recalled Romney's record in the presidential elections so far.

Romney's speech was a stark warning about the consequences of Trump's presidency, saying it would lead to recession and make America and the world less safe. He also called Trump's "brand of anger" a threat to the character of the nation and said he lacks the temperament to be president.

Other Republican leaders, including Sen. John McCain and Ohio Gov. John Kasich, expressed concerns about Trump's candidacy, with McCain urging voters to "think long and hard about who they want to be our next Commander-in-Chief and leader of the free world."

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Sends Emails to Republican Leaders, Sparking Speculation About His Political Ambitions

Article: House Speaker Paul Ryan has been sending emails to select Republican leaders, sparking speculation about his political ambitions. The emails, which have been described as "self-advertisements" by some recipients, ask the leaders to take a "personalized Leadership Priority Survey" to guide the Republican agenda in the upcoming election year.

According to sources, Ryan has sent multiple emails to some recipients, including a prominent RNC member who noted receiving over 10 emails since last week. The emails are seen as unusual, as Ryan has not been as active in sending emails to the same extent in the past.

The emails have sparked debate among Republican leaders attending the RNC meeting, with some interpreting them as a sign of Ryan's interest in becoming the "white knight" candidate if neither Ted Cruz nor Donald Trump wins the nomination. Others believe the emails are simply self-promotional efforts by Ryan to maintain his position as Speaker.

The timing of the emails is significant, as the RNC meeting is set to debate rules that would make it harder for a "white knight" candidate to enter the nomination process. Ryan has previously sworn he would not be interested in the speakership, but he changed his mind and has been serving as Speaker since October.

The emails themselves focus on the importance of the Republican House majority fighting for conservative values, regardless of the outcome of the presidential election. They also ask recipients to take the Leadership Priority Survey to guide the party's agenda in the election year.

While the true intentions behind Ryan's emails remain unclear, they have certainly sparked intrigue and speculation among Republican leaders.

Title: Koch Brothers Launch Multi-Million Dollar Campaign Against Trump's Trade Tariffs

The Koch brothers, Charles and David, are funding a multi-million dollar campaign against President Donald Trump's trade tariffs. The campaign, backed by their company Koch Industries, aims to promote the benefits of free trade through advertising, lobbying, and grassroots efforts. The move comes after Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the EU, Canada, and Mexico.

The Koch-backed groups, Freedom Partners Chamber of Commerce, Americans for Prosperity, and the LIBRE Initiative, are urging the president to lift the recent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports, as well as proposed tariffs on imports from China. Americans for Prosperity President Tim Phillips stated that the tariffs would "hamstring our full economic potential" and that there are better ways to negotiate trade deals than by punishing American consumers and businesses with higher costs.

The campaign indicates the level of concern among business groups, typically Republican supporters, about the impact of the tariffs. Leaders from the EU, Canada, and Mexico have criticized the move and threatened retaliation, sparking fears of a trade war. Mexico has already imposed new tariffs on US goods, including steel, pork, and bourbon.

The Koch brothers, who run one of the world's largest privately owned firms, have a history of political activism, having donated millions to conservative causes and supported candidates. However, they have also made large donations to the American Civil Liberties Union and pushed for criminal justice reform.

The campaign is not an attack on Trump, but rather an attempt to provide "friendly advice" on the benefits of free trade. However, the stakes are high, as congressional efforts to curtail the president's ability to enact new tariffs could escalate the situation. The Koch brothers' company, Koch Industries, has interests ranging from pipelines to paper towels and employs over 120,000 people worldwide.

Title: Congressional Budget Office Estimates Obama's Executive Amnesty to Cost Taxpayers $10.2 Billion Over Ten Years

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released a letter to Senator Thad Cochran (R-MS) estimating that President Obama's executive amnesty programs will cost taxpayers $10.2 billion over the next ten years. The estimate is based on the House of Representatives' Department of Homeland Security funding bill, which would undo both the 2012 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival (DACA) and the 2014 Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA) programs.

According to the CBO letter, the bill would decrease on-budget deficits by $8.8 billion over ten years, primarily due to billions in tax credit spending cuts. The letter explains that the earned income tax credit and child tax credit are refundable tax credits, which reduce a taxpayer's overall income tax liability. If the credits exceed the liability, the excess may be refunded to the taxpayer, classified as outlays in the federal budget.

The CBO estimates that the bulk of the decrease in outlays for refundable credits projected for the 2015-2025 period would be attributable to decreases in earned income tax credits. The bill would decrease the amount of earned income tax credits by decreasing the number of people with Social Security numbers, which are required for taxpayers and dependents to qualify for earned income tax credits. Since Obama's amnesty gives millions of illegal immigrants Social Security numbers, it will cost American taxpayers billions in new spending on those same illegal immigrants.

The CBO letter also estimates that amnestied immigrants will pay $22 billion in Social Security payroll taxes over the next ten years. However, like all Social Security recipients, unless they are deported, amnestied immigrants will eventually be a net drain on the Social Security system, taking out more in benefits than they paid in.

Title: Tea Party Groups Shift Focus to Winning Senate Seats Over Ideological Purity

The Tea Party Patriots and Tea Party Express have announced a shift in their strategy, prioritizing the election of moderate Republicans over ideological purity. This change in approach comes as the groups recognize that winning Senate seats is more important than electing hardcore conservatives. The Tea Party Patriots are backing moderate candidates such as Senator Pat Roberts and Governor Mike Rounds, as reported by The Hill.

According to FreedomWorks Executive Vice President Adam Brandon, this "hold their nose and vote" attitude is a growing trend among Tea Party members. The sentiment is echoed by Tea Party Patriots President Jenny Beth Martin, who stated that her organization's members prioritize having a Republican-controlled Senate and defeating Majority Leader Harry Reid.

This shift in strategy marks a significant departure from the Tea Party's 2010 mantra, which emphasized sticking to principles even if it meant electoral losses. The change comes after the Tea Party groups failed to win key battles in the latest primary elections.

Tea Party Express founder Sal Russo explained that while the group's initial goal was to challenge the establishment, the time has come to focus on taking back the Senate. This concession comes as several Republican Party fixtures, including Karl Rove and Senator Mitch McConnell, have publicly criticized the Tea Party's influence as harmful to the GOP.

However, not all Tea Party groups are on board with this shift. Senate Conservatives Fund President Ken Cuccinelli stated that there is no evidence the establishment has buried the hatchet with the Tea Party, and the grassroots remains aware of the rift within the party.

Title: Pentagon to Audit $400 Million Border Wall Contract Awarded to Firm with Ties to Fox News

The Defense Department's internal watchdog has announced an investigation into a $400 million border wall contract awarded to Fisher Sand and Gravel Co., a North Dakota-based firm with ties to Fox News. The contract, worth $13 million per mile, was awarded to the company in December to build 31 miles of wall in Arizona.

The investigation was prompted by concerns raised by House Homeland Committee Chairman Bennie Thompson, who questioned whether the proposals did not meet operational requirements and prototypes came in late and over budget. The Pentagon's inspector general sent a letter to Thompson, stating that the contract would be audited.

Fisher Sand and Gravel Co.'s head, Tommy Fisher, has denied any wrongdoing, stating that the company was told it was the lowest bidder and best value. However, critics have raised concerns about the company's lack of experience in construction and its previous proposal being rejected.

The border wall is one of President Trump's top priorities, with him promising to build a "big beautiful wall" between the U.S. and Mexico during his 2016 presidential campaign. However, Mexico is not paying for the wall, and as of November 1, Trump had built 78 miles of the wall.

The Trump administration has faced resistance and lawsuits over its efforts to push through funding for the wall, with a federal judge blocking the administration from spending some Defense Department money on the project. The contract awarded to Fisher Sand and Gravel Co. is part of a series of contracts aimed at increasing the mileage of the border wall.

The Pentagon's inspector general has stated that the audit will assess how to complete the review and will formally announce it soon. The investigation comes as concerns about the influence of politics on the contracting process continue to grow.

Title: Campaign Surrogates Make Final Push as Election Day Approaches

As the last Sunday before the 2012 presidential election, Republican and Democrat campaign surrogates engaged in a heated debate about the outcome of the election. White House adviser David Plouffe, who managed Barack Obama's 2008 campaign, expressed confidence in the president's re-election, stating, "I'm very confident that, two days out from Election Day, the president's going to be re-elected on Tuesday night."

On the other hand, Mitt Romney's campaign manager, Rich Beeson, predicted a big win for his candidate, claiming Romney would secure 300 electoral votes, far more than the 270 necessary to take the White House. Obama senior adviser David Axelrod dismissed GOP claims of competitiveness in Pennsylvania, stating, "They understand that they're in deep trouble. They understand that the traditional, or the battleground, states that we've been focusing are not working out for them."

In the crucial battleground state of Ohio, the Real Clear Politics polling average shows Obama ahead by nearly three percentage points. However, US Senator Rob Portman (R) of Ohio, a prominent Romney campaign surrogate, expressed confidence in the GOP candidate's chances, stating, "All the polls are going in the right direction, so I'm very happy about the polling. I feel very good about Ohio."

Recent polls show a tight race, with Obama leading Romney by a nose in a Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, and the two tied in a Politico/George Washington University poll. The Real Clear Politics national polling average has Obama ahead by a tiny fraction.

As the candidates make their final push, they are focusing on turning out their supporters in the 10 or so competitive states. Obama's schedule includes stops in New Hampshire, Florida, Ohio, and Colorado, while Romney's schedule includes Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. Hurricane Sandy, which has had a significant impact on the campaign, has helped Obama, with nearly 70% of those polled approving of his handling of the storm.

Some Republicans have criticized Romney's campaign for not doing more to address the storm's aftermath, while others have praised Obama's response. Obama himself stated that at this point in the campaign, he is largely "a prop" and the race is in the voters' hands.

Title: Trump Blames "Fake News Media" for "Great Anger" in the Country

President Donald Trump has taken to Twitter to express his frustration with what he calls "fake news" and "the true Enemy of the People," blaming the media for the "great anger" in the country. This comes after a violent week that saw a spate of mail bombs and a shooting that killed 11 people at a Pittsburgh synagogue.

In a pair of tweets, Trump stated that the media's inaccurate and fraudulent reporting of the news is causing anger and outrage, and that the media must stop the "open & obvious hostility" and report the news accurately and fairly. He believes that this would help to put out the flame of anger and bring all sides together in peace and harmony.

The tweets were among several messages Trump sent on Monday, in which he also called Florida gubernatorial candidate Andrew Gillum a "thief" and referred to a caravan of immigrants headed through Mexico to the U.S. border as an "invasion."

The president's comments have been met with criticism from Democrats and his political opponents, who argue that his rhetoric has further inflamed the country's divisions and contributed to the recent violent incidents.

Title: US Intelligence Chief Warns of Russian Interference in Midterm Elections, Trump Administration Fails to Impose Sanctions

The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director Mike Pompeo has expressed concerns that Russia will attempt to interfere in the upcoming midterm elections, stating that "I have every expectation" that Russian intelligence agencies will try to spread misinformation and undermine the democratic process. This warning comes as the Trump administration has failed to impose new sanctions on Russian defense and intelligence bodies, despite the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA) being passed by Congress last year.

CAATSA requires the administration to impose sanctions on foreign companies doing business with blacklisted Russian defense and intelligence bodies. However, the Trump administration has not taken any new action, citing the existence of the legislation as a deterrent to such dealings. The administration did release a list of 114 politicians and 196 oligarchs with ties to the Kremlin, but declined to impose sanctions on anyone on the list.

Critics have expressed frustration with the administration's lack of action, with Representative Eliot Engel stating, "I'm fed up waiting for this administration to protect our country and our elections. They chose instead to let Russia off the hook yet again." The State Department cited the estimated $7 billion in Russian defense acquisitions that have been abandoned or postponed as a reason for not imposing new sanctions.

Senator Bob Corker, who helped write CAATSA, expressed confidence that additional sanctions may still be imposed, stating, "This is when sanctions season begins, and so they'll be rolling them out. We feel pretty good about the process." The Trump administration's decision not to impose new sanctions has been met with criticism and concern from lawmakers and experts, who worry that it will embolden Russian aggression and undermine the integrity of the democratic process.

Title: Republicans Eye ObamaCare as Key Issue in 2014 Elections

As the 2014 election approaches, Republicans have a favorable environment, a competitive lineup of candidates, and a map that suggests they could expand their House majority and take the Senate. However, they are still deciding whether to bet big on ObamaCare, a tantalizing target that has been a major focus of their campaign.

The conservative Americans for Prosperity has spent around $27 million on ads this cycle, nearly every penny of which has targeted Democratic incumbents' support for the Affordable Care Act. A special House election in Florida has seen one ad after another targeting the Democratic nominee's support for the health care law. For conservatives, taking aim at ObamaCare is an irresistible match of exposing a political vulnerability while satisfying an ideological gripe.

President Obama's health care law is a tempting target and should be part of any GOP candidate's campaign. However, some in the party's political class are also warning candidates to do more than just harp on the Affordable Care Act. Experts advise that the party needs to turn its criticism of ObamaCare into a broader critique of Democrats, one that includes other issues and makes a broader point about the failures of big-government liberalism.

Some House Republicans are already trying, publicly discussing their own proposals on immigration and health care. These amount to baby steps – they're more guidelines than actual legislation – but are part of a concerted effort from GOP leadership to define what the party stands for. "It is incumbent upon us, as an alternative party, not just an opposition party, to have ideas that we put forward that are grounded in market principles that will work," said Greg Walden, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.

Other GOP campaigns have already broadened their messages. Mitch McConnell, for instance, criticizes his Democratic foe Alison Lundergan Grimes for her position on coal – an issue of particular resonance in Kentucky's race. Attacks on ObamaCare can offer GOP candidates an opening to make a broader point about their opponent. Officials at the National Republican Senatorial Committee argue that Democratic senators who promised all their constituents would be able to keep their health care plans now have a credibility problem. The GOP nominee in the Florida special election said in an ad that his opponent's support for the law proves she's just another tax-and-spend liberal.

Not every Republican is worried that the party risks focusing too much on the law. The issue cuts into so many concerns for voters – their own health care, the country's debt, and the economy – that it's inherently a broad-spectrum attack. That case was bolstered this week when the Congressional Budget Office predicted the economy will lose the equivalent of 2.5 million workers by 2024 because fewer people will opt to work due to the health law.

"If James Carville were a Republican, there'd be a sign hanging in his office that said, 'It's ObamaCare, stupid,'" said Glen Bolger, a GOP pollster. He argued that Republicans shouldn't be worried about dwelling too much on ObamaCare; they should be worried about not talking about it enough. "Yes, we do need more than just ObamaCare," he said. "But we don't need a lot more."

Title: The Inconsistencies in the Rhetoric Against China's Steel Industry

The article highlights the inconsistencies in the rhetoric against China's steel industry, particularly the claims that China overproduces steel, steals intellectual property, and has a plan to dominate the world by 2025. The author argues that these claims are misleading and that the real issue is not China's overproduction, but rather the fact that the Chinese government's subsidization of steel production diverts resources from other areas of the Chinese economy.

The article also questions the logic of imposing tariffs on Chinese steel imports, citing the fact that the US steel industry has been declining for decades due to labor-saving innovations and automation, rather than Chinese imports. The author suggests that the best way to protect American intellectual property rights is not to impose tariffs, but to challenge China's actions through international organizations and form alliances with like-minded allies.

The article concludes by noting that while there are valid concerns about China's human rights record and lack of free market economic policies, the current trade and investment restrictions will not make China more like the US, but rather make the US more like China.

Title: Stock Market Volatility: A Reality Check for President Trump's Boastful Claims

The recent fluctuations in the stock market have led to a stark contrast between President Donald Trump's boasts about the market's performance and the current reality. While the president has taken credit for the market's growth, the recent downturn serves as a reminder that market trends are not solely within his control.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted by 1,500 points earlier today, only to recover some of those losses later in the day. Despite this, the market remains down by around 1,000 points at the close of the market. This volatility is likely to continue, as investors react to recent news from Washington.

The president's claims about the market's performance are not new. During his State of the Union address, he touted the market's growth, stating that it has "smashed one record after another, gaining $8 trillion in value." However, when the market falls, his tone shifts, with unnamed spokesmen attributing the decline to concerns about the economy's fundamentals.
