The current market fluctuations are likely linked to two significant pieces of news from Washington: the new debt figures, fueled by the recent tax cuts, and the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate adjustments in response to signs of a growing economy. The new wage data, set to be released on Friday, may also contribute to investor jitters.

It is essential to note that presidents do not control the market, and market trends are influenced by various factors. While politics can impact the market, it is crucial to acknowledge that both the ups and downs are part of the market's natural fluctuations. President Trump's tendency to take credit for the market's growth without acknowledging the potential downsides is a concerning trend.

Additionally, the recent spike in black unemployment, which had previously been touted as a success story, serves as a reminder that the president's claims of responsibility are not always accurate. It is essential to separate fact from fiction and recognize that market trends are complex and influenced by various factors, rather than solely the president's actions.

Title: EPA Eases Enforcement of Environmental Regulations to Help Industries Cope with COVID-19 Impacts

The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has announced a decision to ease enforcement of environmental regulations covering polluting industries to help them cope with the impacts of the coronavirus outbreak. The move follows requests from the oil lobby and other industry groups for regulatory relief as governments around the world scramble to contain the spread of the virus.

According to a memo signed by EPA Assistant Administrator Susan Bodine, the agency will not fine polluting industries for violating certain monitoring and reporting requirements during the outbreak. The EPA will instead focus its resources on situations that may create an acute risk or imminent threat to public health or the environment.

The memo, which is retroactive to March 13, states that the EPA does not expect to seek penalties for violations of routine compliance monitoring, integrity testing, sampling, laboratory analysis, training, and reporting or certification obligations in situations where the EPA agrees that COVID-19 was the cause.

The decision was met with criticism from over a dozen environmental groups, who argue that easing enforcement of air and water protections will put the public at risk. The groups, including the Environmental Integrity Project and Wild Earth Guardians, claim that the move will exacerbate asthma, breathing difficulty, and cardiovascular problems.

The EPA's decision comes after the American Petroleum Institute asked the Trump administration for temporary relief from regulatory requirements on the oil and gas industry to ensure steady fuel supplies during the coronavirus outbreak. The industry is concerned that the virus will leave it with limited numbers of healthy staff to run critical operations, making it harder to comply with federal environmental and safety requirements.

The EPA's memo did not address the oil industry's request for waivers allowing the sale of winter-grade gasoline deep into spring and summer to deal with a supply glut.

Title: Walmart Urged to Release Surveillance Video of Fatal Shooting of John Crawford III

Article:

The fatal shooting of John Crawford III, a 22-year-old black man, by a white police officer in a Walmart store in Beavercreek, Ohio, has sparked calls for the release of surveillance video footage. Crawford's family and thousands of others have signed a petition to Color of Change, urging Walmart to make the tape public. The incident has raised questions about racial bias and the role of implicit bias in the shooting.

According to reports, Crawford and his girlfriend went to the Walmart to buy ingredients for a family cookout. He picked up an unpackaged BB gun from a shelf and continued shopping. A man named Ronald Ritchie called 911, reporting that a black man was walking around with a gun in the store, pointing it at people. Minutes later, Crawford was dead, shot by police. The gun was later found to be a toy, unloaded, and Crawford's last words were "It's not real."

The incident has sparked debate about whether the police were more likely to shoot Crawford because of his race. While some argue that the shooting was a tragic accident, others believe that implicit bias played a role. Research has shown that people are more likely to perceive darker-skinned individuals as threats, even when they are unarmed.

Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine has refused to release the video, citing concerns that it could bias the jury in any potential trial. However, some argue that the video should be made public to help the public understand what happened and to promote transparency.

Walmart, as the largest employer of black people in the country, has an obligation to ensure that its customers feel safe in its stores. The company has not commented on the incident or the request to release the video.

The shooting of John Crawford III is just one of many cases in which racial bias has been suspected or proven to have played a role. The incident serves as a reminder that racism is not a thing of the past and that implicit bias can be a powerful force in shaping our perceptions and actions.

Title: Clinton's Remarks on Job Creation Spark Controversy, Receive Limited Coverage

The recent remarks made by Hillary Clinton at a campaign event for Massachusetts Democratic gubernatorial candidate Martha Coakley have sparked controversy, with the major English and Spanish broadcast networks blacking out any mention of the comments. Clinton stated that "businesses and corporations do not create jobs," citing the concept of "trickle-down economics" as having been tried and failed.

Since then, English-language networks ABC, CBS, and NBC, as well as Spanish-language networks Telemundo and Univision, have ignored the story in their morning and evening newscasts. This is a stark contrast to how the networks would typically cover similar comments made by a Republican figure or future presidential hopeful.

On the Fox News Channel's evening news program, Special Report with Bret Baier, senior political analyst Brit Hume devoted his commentary segment to the subject, discussing Clinton's original remarks and her subsequent "walk back" of her comments. Hume noted that Clinton's defenders have rushed to her aid, claiming that her statement was taken out of context and that she was simply criticizing outdated Republican tax policies.

However, Hume pointed out that Clinton's original remarks and subsequent clarification did not contradict her initial statement that businesses and corporations do not create jobs. He also noted that an unnamed Clinton aide claimed that the former Secretary of State meant to say that tax breaks for businesses do not create jobs, but this would be a logical conclusion only if one believes that businesses do not create jobs in the first place.

The controversy surrounding Clinton's remarks has sparked debate about whether she believes that businesses and corporations are responsible for job creation. While some have defended her comments, others have criticized her for what they see as a fundamental misunderstanding of the economy. The full transcript of the segment that aired on FNC's Special Report with Bret Baier can be found below.

Title: Capitol Hill Republicans Vow to Block Funding for Global Climate Deal

Article:

Capitol Hill Republicans are preparing to block funding for the global climate deal set to be discussed at the upcoming United Nations conference in Paris, warning that they will not provide vital funding if President Obama attempts to circumvent Congress. The two-week conference, starting on Monday, is expected to bring together world leaders to discuss climate change and its effects on the global community.

President Obama has emphasized the importance of the summit, stating that it will be a "powerful rebuke to the terrorists" and a demonstration of global solidarity. However, lawmakers are concerned that the president may try to bypass Congress and secure funding for the United Nations' Green Climate Fund without their approval.

The fund, which aims to help developing nations deal with climate change, is set to receive $3 billion, with $500 million allocated in the near-term. Critics, including Senators John Barrasso and Jim Inhofe, have warned that any agreement with legally binding requirements must come before the Senate for a vote. They have sent a letter to President Obama, signed by over 30 senators, urging him to relay to developing nations that Congress will not provide funding for the Green Climate Fund without a Senate vote.

Republicans argue that any deal with legally binding elements should be handled like a treaty and subject to Senate ratification. The Obama administration has given varying statements on how it views the potential pact, with Secretary of State John Kerry stating that it will not be a treaty. However, the State Department clarified that the U.S. wants binding and non-binding components.

House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith has expressed concerns that the Clean Power Plan, regulations on power plant emissions, will "represent massive costs without significant benefits." The House is set to vote on measures to repeal these regulations, which are currently the subject of a federal court case brought by mostly Republican-led states.

Despite the resistance, the administration remains optimistic about the summit, with Christiana Figueres, executive secretary of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, stating that a historic deal will be reached. The summit is expected to bring together world leaders, including President Obama, Chinese President Xi Jinping, and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, to discuss climate change and its effects on the global community.

Title: Reagan's Tax Reform Victory: A Lesson for Obama?

Article:

In a stunning turn of events, President Ronald Reagan's own party dealt him a defeat in the House of Representatives on a top priority of his second term. Despite this setback, Reagan managed to switch enough votes to pass the tax reform bill, which became law in 1986. The story serves as a lesson for President Barack Obama, who is facing a similar challenge on trade.

Reagan's experience was marked by a sense of disconnection between the White House and Capitol Hill. House Republicans felt excluded from the process and believed the administration was giving too much to the opposing party. This led to a plan to defeat the procedural rule for considering the bill, which ultimately worked. However, Reagan made an unusual trip to Capitol Hill, asking his partisans to reconsider, and followed up with a letter pledging to work for changes in the Senate and veto any final bill that fell short of his objectives. The measure soon passed the House and became law.

In contrast, Obama's situation differs from Reagan's in several ways that do not work to his advantage. Reagan was still popular, with a 63% approval rating in December 1985, while Obama's approval rating has been about 20 points lower. Additionally, Republicans had a stronger presence in Congress during Reagan's time, with a majority in the Senate and a significant number of seats in the House. Under Obama, Democrats have lost their majorities in both chambers.

Obama's recent meeting with House Democrats took a different tack, with him suggesting that opponents of the bill were not playing straight. This message backfired and cost him votes. With time running out, Obama can still pull off a legislative miracle by emulating Reagan's approach, but it remains to be seen if he can achieve the same success.

Title: Political Polarization in the United States Reaches 20-Year High, According to Pew Research Center Survey

The Pew Research Center has released a survey that reveals a significant increase in political polarization in the United States over the past 20 years. The study, which aimed to understand the nature and scope of political polarization, found that the percentage of Americans holding consistently conservative or liberal positions on major issues has doubled over the past decade, now accounting for 20% of the population.

The survey, which polled 10,013 people, found that the most ideologically oriented and politically active individuals have become increasingly entrenched in their positions, with 92% of Republicans and 94% of Democrats holding views that are significantly to the right and left of the median, respectively. This represents a significant increase from 1994, when 64% of Republicans and 70% of Democrats held such views.

The study also found that political views have become more polarized, with most intense partisans believing that the opposing party's policies threaten the nation's well-being. The survey revealed that political views have spilled over into various areas of life, including where people prefer to live and with whom they associate. For example, 63% of consistent conservatives and 49% of consistent liberals reported that most of their close friends share their political views.

The survey also found that those who hold mixed ideological views, accounting for 39% of the population, are relatively distant and disengaged from the political process. The most ideologically oriented and politically active individuals, on the other hand, are more likely to participate in every stage of the political process, including primary voting, writing letters to officials, volunteering for or donating to a campaign, and amplifying the voices of like-minded individuals.

The Pew Research Center's study provides a comprehensive understanding of the current state of political polarization in the United States, highlighting the growing divide between liberals and conservatives. The findings suggest that political views have become increasingly entrenched, with many individuals holding strong beliefs that are resistant to change.

Title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Defends Free Expression Amid Backlash

Article:

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified at a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, D.C. on October 23, 2019, reiterating his commitment to free expression. Despite this stance, he has faced criticism and boycotts from major American companies and left-wing activists. Zuckerberg's defense of free speech has been met with vitriol, with some labeling him a "hate-speech machine."

In a speech at Georgetown University, Zuckerberg emphasized the importance of protecting the right to express one's views and be heard, even if it means getting the outcomes one wants. He also highlighted the role of free speech in the fight for democracy and praised Supreme Court jurisprudence that has strengthened First Amendment protections.

However, Zuckerberg's stance has been met with opposition from activists who argue that Facebook's platform has been used to spread hate speech and misinformation. They have pressured companies to stop advertising with Facebook, and some have complied. The activists have also sought to associate Facebook with racism and hate, claiming that the company profits from posts by neo-Nazis.

Facebook's decision to keep up a post by President Donald Trump that some deemed inflammatory has been a flashpoint in the controversy. Zuckerberg has maintained that the post was not an incitement to violence and that it was important to allow users to draw their own conclusions.

The stakes are high in this debate, as Facebook is a major institution that plays a significant role in shaping online discourse. If Zuckerberg can be pressured into abandoning his support for free speech, it could have far-reaching implications for the future of online expression.

Title: Berkeley's Handling of Conservative Speakers Sparks Controversy, Trump Weighs In

Article:

The University of California at Berkeley's handling of conservative speakers has sparked a federal lawsuit and a rebuke from President Trump. The Berkeley College Republicans (BCR) and Young America's Foundation (YAF) argue that the university's policy regarding "high-profile speakers" unconstitutionally discriminates against unpopular viewpoints. This policy was adopted after violent protests prompted the university to shut down a February 1 appearance by former Breitbart News editor Milo Yiannopoulos.

The BCR and YAF claim that Berkeley's restrictions on public safety have not been applied equally to left-leaning speakers and amount to an "unlawful heckler's veto" that marginalizes conservative voices. The groups argue that the university's actions are a result of a vague, unwritten policy that has led to the cancellation of conservative speakers, including a planned April 12 talk by conservative journalist David Horowitz.

In response to the controversy, President Trump tweeted that Berkeley risks losing federal funds if it does not allow free speech. However, critics argue that Trump's administration has also been accused of suppressing opposing views. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) recently demanded that Twitter reveal the identity of a DHS gadfly, and the Justice Department is considering criminal charges against individuals who share classified information leaked by others.

The controversy surrounding Berkeley's handling of conservative speakers is not the only example of the suppression of opposing views. Last month, a special agent in charge at Customs and Border Protection (CBP), a division of DHS, issued a summons to Twitter seeking records that would unmask the person or persons behind @ALT_USCIS, an account that regularly criticizes the Trump administration's immigration policies. The summons was later dropped after Twitter filed a lawsuit arguing that it threatened the First Amendment right to engage in pseudonymous political speech.

The investigation into the CBP summons has raised concerns about the government's attempts to intimidate critics and suppress free speech. The Justice Department is also considering criminal charges against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for sharing classified documents with the public. The Obama administration previously abandoned a similar prosecution due to concerns about the precedent it would set.

The controversy surrounding Berkeley's handling of conservative speakers highlights the ongoing debate about the balance between free speech and public safety. While some argue that the university's actions are necessary to protect students and the community, others believe that the restrictions on public speech are an unconstitutional infringement on free speech.

Title: Chris Rock's Insightful Comments on Inequality and the American Dream

Article:

Comedian Chris Rock's recent interview with Frank Rich sparked a lot of attention, with many focusing on his comments about racism. However, a recent study by Gregory Clark, a researcher at the University of California, Davis, has shed new light on Rock's most thought-provoking statement about inequality. During the interview, Rock said, "If poor people knew how rich rich people are, there would be riots in the streets." At first glance, this might seem like a comment about the politics of envy or the scale of inequality. However, Rock was actually discussing the perception of American society and how it influences politics.

Rock expanded his statement to include the "average person," saying they too would be outraged and bewildered by the lifestyle of the 1%. He noted that if the average person could see the Virgin Airlines first-class lounge, they would be shocked by the luxuries available. This assertion is backed by multiple studies that have shown Americans seriously underestimate the degree of inequality in the U.S. economy. According to a study by Slate's Jordan Weissman, subjects estimated that the top 20% of U.S. households owned about 59% of the country's net worth, when in reality the number is closer to 84%.

The gap between perception and reality is not unique to Americans, as people from other developed economies also have ideal distributions that differ from their countries' actual status quo. What sets the U.S. apart is its faith in the American Dream, which has been around for over 100 years. However, a recent study by Gregory Clark found that the American Dream is no longer operational today. Clark's research suggests that social mobility in the U.S. is no better than in medieval England or pre-industrial Sweden.

The American Dream's promise of upward mobility through hard work and perseverance is a powerful force that keeps the gap between perception and reality papered over. However, if more Americans realize that the American Dream is an empty promise, the 1% and those in power will face significant challenges.

Title: Obama and Romney Meet for Lunch, Discuss Leadership and Future Cooperation

In a rare meeting between the two presidential rivals, President Barack Obama and former Republican nominee Mitt Romney met for lunch at the White House on [date]. The meeting was their most extensive private conversation to date, lasting around an hour. According to the White House, the discussion focused on America's leadership in the world and the importance of maintaining that position.

Romney congratulated Obama on his successful campaign and wished him well in the coming four years. The lunch menu included white turkey chili and Southwestern grilled chicken salad. Romney left the White House after the meeting, which was seen as a gesture of goodwill and a sign of respect for the democratic process.

The meeting was a departure from the brief exchanges and debates between the two during the 2012 election campaign. The conversation was seen as a chance for Obama and Romney to put aside their differences and discuss the future of American leadership.

The meeting comes as the country faces economic challenges, including the expiration of tax cuts first enacted during the George W. Bush administration. Obama and Romney had differing views on what to do with the cuts during the campaign, with Romney pushing for them to be extended for all income earners and Obama running on a pledge to let them expire for families making more than $250,000 a year. The White House sees Obama's victory as a signal that Americans support his tax proposals.

Romney has been largely absent from politics since his election loss, spending time with his family and making a few low-key appearances.

Title: Boko Haram Releases Video of Kidnapped Christian Schoolgirls, Demands Prisoner Exchange

A new video obtained by the Associated Press shows over 100 kidnapped Christian schoolgirls, aged 15 to 18, praying to Allah and reciting the Koran in Arabic. The video features Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau, who claims the girls have converted to Islam. The majority of the abducted girls are believed to be Christians, although some are also Muslim.

In the video, three girls are shown speaking, with two stating they were Christian and have converted to Islam, while the third says she is Muslim. Shekau announces that the girls have been "liberated" and will be held until imprisoned militants are freed.

The video is the first sighting of the abducted girls since more than 300 were taken from their school in the northern town of Chibok on April 14. Although over 50 girls escaped their captors and are now safe, at least 276 remain missing.

The United States has offered a $7 million bounty on Shekau's head, and the U.S. State Department has stated that it will not pay ransoms or concessions to kidnappers. The Nigerian government has also denied any plans to pay a ransom to secure the girls' release.

The video emerged as the Nigerian government reportedly made indirect contact with the terrorist group. The Nigerian government has been criticized for its handling of the search for the missing girls, with Amnesty International claiming that security forces were aware of the impending kidnapping but did nothing to stop it.

The search for the missing girls has been ongoing, with Nigerian troops aided by advisers from the U.S., Britain, and France. The U.S. has more than 50 military personnel and advisors based at the Nigerian Embassy to help advise and assist in the search.

Title: Pro-Life Movement Shifts Focus Amid Shift in House Majority

The recent election results have brought significant changes to the US Congress, with the House of Representatives transforming into a pro-choice majority. This shift has left pro-life voters feeling concerned, as the House, once a stronghold for pro-life lawmakers, is now led by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a self-proclaimed abortion rights advocate. According to Mallory Quigley, with the Susan B. Anthony List (SBA), this development is a significant loss for the pro-life movement.

However, Quigley emphasizes that the pro-life movement will continue to focus on keeping tax dollars out of the hands of Planned Parenthood, a key goal for the organization. SBA teams began knocking on doors in July and successfully convinced enough voters to make the Senate reliably pro-life. The organization's efforts were aimed at securing a pro-life Senate, which is crucial for confirming Supreme Court justices.

With President Donald Trump still in office, the pro-life movement remains optimistic. Trump has been a strong supporter of pro-life policies, and his administration has taken steps to protect life, including sending a letter to pro-life voters outlining his plans to protect life if elected. The Department of Health and Human Services is set to finalize its "Protect Life Rule," which will cut off $60 million in funding for Planned Parenthood, their second-largest stream of funding.

Despite the loss of a pro-life majority in the House, Quigley remains optimistic, stating that it's a "very encouraging time to be pro-life." SBA teams will soon begin knocking on doors again to rally the pro-life vote in 2020.

Title: House Judiciary Committee to Conduct Fake Impeachment Inquiry, Despite Lack of Support from Democrats and Voters

The House Judiciary Committee, led by Chairman Jerrold Nadler, has announced plans to conduct a fake impeachment inquiry against President Trump. This move comes despite the fact that the Democrats lack the necessary votes to complete the first step towards removing the President from office. The committee will vote on a resolution outlining the procedures for the investigation, which is expected to occur on Wednesday.

The move has been met with opposition from many Democrats, including Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination. Gabbard stated that she does not support impeachment, citing the potential for further division and polarization in the country. She emphasized the importance of focusing on what is best for the country and the American people.

The article also notes that many moderate Democrats, who are likely to pay the price for Nadler's plan, do not support impeachment. Virtually none of the 31 Democrats who won their seats in districts that Trump won in 2016 favor impeachment. They know that the National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) has targeted their seats, and that Nadler's "inquiry" may doom their re-election bids.

The article also highlights the lack of public support for impeachment. According to a recent Monmouth University poll, only 35% of Americans believe that Trump should be impeached and removed from office, while 59% disagree. Additionally, 41% of Americans believe that the House Judiciary Committee's investigation is a good idea, while 51% believe it is a bad idea.

The article concludes by questioning Nadler's motivations for pursuing this course of action. Some speculate that he may be driven by his personal animosity towards President Trump, while others believe that he may be trying to defend his own congressional seat from a potential primary challenge from the Left.

Title: Trump Defends Sharing Intelligence with Russia, Denies Disclosing Sensitive Information

Article:

President Donald Trump defended his decision to share information with Russian officials during a White House meeting last week, stating that he had the "absolute right" to do so for "humanitarian reasons." In a series of tweets, Trump claimed that he shared "facts" about terrorism and airline flight safety with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Sergey Kislyak.

According to Trump, the meeting was an "openly scheduled W.H. meeting" and he had the right to share information with Russia. He stated that he wanted to discuss humanitarian issues, including the fight against ISIS and terrorism, and that he believes Russia should "greatly step up their fight against ISIS & terrorism."

However, Trump's national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, denied that the president disclosed "intelligence sources or methods," which is what the Washington Post story alleged. McMaster stated that the president and the foreign minister reviewed common threats to their countries, including threats to civil aviation, but at no point did they discuss intelligence sources or methods.

Dina Powell, the deputy national security adviser for strategy, also denied the story, saying that the president only discussed common threats that both countries faced.

The Washington Post reported that Trump "went off script and began describing details about an Islamic State terrorist threat related to the use of laptop computers on aircraft" during the meeting. According to officials, the information Trump relayed had been provided by a U.S. partner through an intelligence-sharing arrangement considered so sensitive that details have been withheld from allies and tightly restricted even within the U.S. government.

Title: Christie Accuses Obama of Lying, Obama's Aide Disputes Claim

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie accused President Barack Obama of lying during an interview on "This Week," citing an advertisement released by the Obama campaign that attacks Mitt Romney's economic plan. The ad claims that Romney wants to cut taxes for the wealthy, which Christie disputes.

Christie stated that Romney's plan would not result in more tax cuts for the wealthy, but rather would maintain the current tax burden on the wealthy. He also criticized the Obama campaign for not providing a clear plan for reducing the national debt.

In response, White House senior adviser David Plouffe disputed Christie's claims, stating that Romney's plan would indeed benefit the wealthy. Plouffe pointed out that individuals making over $3 million a year would receive a tax cut of over $250,000 if Romney's plan were implemented. He also emphasized that the plan would not benefit the middle class, as it would not reduce the deficit or create jobs.

The debate between Christie and Plouffe highlights the ongoing disagreement between the two campaigns on economic policy. The first presidential debate is set to take place on Wednesday, and both sides are preparing to make their cases to the American public.

Title: Mueller Investigation: Trump Not a "Criminal Target," But Still Under Investigation

The special counsel's office has reportedly informed President Trump's legal team that he is not a "criminal target" of the Russia investigation, but rather a "subject" of the probe. This distinction may provide some relief for Trump, but legal experts emphasize that being a "subject" does not necessarily mean he is out of the woods.

A "target" in a criminal investigation typically refers to an individual whom investigators believe has committed a crime and are likely to bring charges against. On the other hand, a "subject" is someone whose conduct is being investigated for potential criminal activity, but no charges are imminent. According to legal experts, Mueller's designation of Trump as a "subject" means he is still investigating the president's conduct for evidence of a crime, but has not determined whether he has committed a specific federal crime.

While this may seem like a distinction without a difference, it is crucial to consider the context of the "criminal target" comments. The comments came during discussions about a potential interview between Trump and Mueller's team, with Mueller's staff seeking information about Trump's firing of FBI Director James Comey and his knowledge of contacts between his team and Russian officials.

Trump himself reportedly wants to sit down with Mueller's staff, but his legal team is divided on whether it's a good idea. Saying Trump is not a target does not hinder Mueller's investigation into his conduct and may even increase the likelihood of Trump agreeing to an interview.

Legal experts emphasize that the distinction between "target" and "subject" is fluid, and a subject can quickly become a target, and vice versa. It's also possible that Mueller sees Trump as a subject because he believes he cannot indict the president while he is in office.

Mueller reportedly needs to interview Trump before he can finish his investigation, but Trump's lawyers have hesitated to allow him to testify, partly due to Trump's history of exaggerations and lies. Trump has previously been caught lying under oath, including during a 2007 deposition in a lawsuit against journalist Timothy O'Brien. This history may make it difficult for Trump to avoid exaggerations or lies during testimony for the Russia investigation.

In conclusion, while being a "subject" may provide some relief for Trump, it does not mean he is out of the woods. The Russia investigation is ongoing, and Mueller's investigation into Trump's conduct will continue.

Title: Congress Debates Renewal of USA Patriot Act Provisions

The USA Patriot Act, passed in 2001, is set to expire at the end of 2015, and lawmakers are debating whether to renew its provisions. Representative F. James Sensenbrenner, the Wisconsin Republican who authored the act, stated that the House will not renew the provisions that allow the government to collect Americans' phone records, effectively ending the government's surveillance program. This decision comes after the program was revealed by former National Security Agency employee Edward Snowden last month.

The Obama administration has declassified more information about the program, which collects metadata from all phone calls, and President Obama has asked for public and congressional support. However, lawmakers from both parties have expressed concerns about the program, citing the lack of transparency and the potential for abuse.

Administration officials testified before Congress, acknowledging that they have the technology to track ATM transactions and cellphone locations, but emphasized that they only gather data when there is a suspected terrorist or criminal activity. They also stated that they involve all three branches of government in the process, regularly briefing congressional committees and seeking approval from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court every 90 days.

However, lawmakers have expressed concerns about the program's scope and the lack of oversight. Representative J. Randy Forbes, Virginia Republican, stated that the administration should have sought permission for the existing program and accused them of trying to hide it. Representative Judy Chu, California Democrat, questioned why 22 employees at the NSA have the power to make decisions that should be made by the FISA courts.

The debate highlights the ongoing concerns about government surveillance and the need for transparency and oversight. The fate of the USA Patriot Act provisions remains uncertain, with the House unlikely to renew them without significant changes.

Title: Senators Raise Concerns Over Marijuana Legalization and International Treaties

Article:

Two members of the Senate, Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein of California and Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa, have expressed concerns that the legalization of marijuana in Oregon, Alaska, and the District of Columbia may put the United States at odds with international law. In a letter to Secretary of State John Kerry and Attorney General Eric Holder, they argued that the Obama administration's decision to permit these states to legalize recreational marijuana violates federal law and the United States' obligations under the United Nations Convention on Narcotics.

The senators noted that the Department of Justice's decision to allow these state laws to take effect has put the United States in a difficult position, as it must now defend its compliance with the treaties. They also expressed concern that the nation's position as a global leader against drugs has been weakened by the decision.

In a press release, Grassley stated that the nation's position as an international leader on drug control issues has been weakened by the decision, and that the country's standing may be undermined by the international treaties the United States and other countries have signed.

The senators have set a deadline of February 1 for Kerry to clarify the State Department's interpretation of the treaties. United Nations officials have also expressed concerns about the compatibility of the new laws with existing conventions. Yury Fedotov, executive director of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, stated that he did not see how the new laws could be compatible with existing conventions.

Tom Angell, executive director of the Marijuana Majority, agrees with the senators that there is an inconsistency between the legalization of marijuana and international treaties. He also agrees with the senators' request for the Justice Department to compile information on the impact of legalization, disaggregated by state and comparable over time, so that data before and after the legalization of marijuana can be compared.

The senators' concerns are not limited to the legalization of marijuana. They have worked together before on anti-drug efforts and released a report in December outlining recommendations on ways to counter illicit activities and corruption surrounding the Afghan drug trade.

Title: Al Qaeda's Resurgence: Experts Warn Against Premature Decline of Terrorist Organization

The recent extension of US embassy and consulate closures across the Middle East and Africa, as well as the increased focus on Al Qaeda's affiliate in Yemen, has led many terrorism experts to caution against claims of the terrorist organization's retreat and demise. Despite the lack of attacks on US soil since 9/11, experts argue that Al Qaeda's threat remains very much alive.

According to Bill Roggio, editor of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies' Long War Journal, those who claim Al Qaeda has been defeated or is on its deathbed either have bad analysis or have been dishonest with the American people. Roggio points to the regions where Al Qaeda has active affiliates, which are expanding in size and reach, and argues that it is impossible to say the group is being defeated.

Bruce Riedel, a leading terrorism analyst and director of the Brookings Institution's Intelligence Project, agrees that while the "old" Al Qaeda with its core leadership in Pakistan may have been depleted, the group has thrived on the chaos engendered by the Arab Spring. Riedel notes that Al Qaeda affiliates are now operating in countries like Syria, Iraq, Libya, Yemen, and Egypt, where they were previously unable to operate due to authoritarian regimes.

Roggio and Riedel both point to recent events, such as the large jailbreaks by Al Qaeda prisoners in Iraq, Pakistan, and Libya, and the spike in Al Qaeda-originating violence in Iraq and successes in Syria, as evidence of the group's resurgence. They also highlight the fact that Al Qaeda's leadership and affiliates have consistently stated their goal of establishing strict Islamist states in various regions and their desire to strike at Western powers.

Some experts argue that the new Al Qaeda affiliates are focused on local insurgencies and local goals, but Riedel and Roggio caution against drawing this conclusion. They note that Al Qaeda's leadership and affiliates have consistently stated their global agenda and have shown a willingness to target Western interests.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of not underestimating Al Qaeda's capabilities and the potential for the group to adapt and evolve in response to changing circumstances.

Title: Bipartisan Support for CARES Act Reveals Limited Differences Between Republicans and Democrats

The recent passage of the $2 trillion CARES Act, the largest spending bill in U.S. history, has highlighted the limited differences between Republicans and Democrats. The bill, aimed at addressing the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, received 96 yes votes and zero no votes in the Senate, with four senators unable to attend the vote. The House passed the bill on a voice vote, with top Democrat Nancy Pelosi and top Republican Kevin McCarthy joining forces to avoid individual members having to explain their votes in the fall's election.

One notable dissenter was Rep. Justin Amash, a Michigan independent who left the Republican Party last summer due to his libertarian philosophy. Amash officially submitted a no vote, criticizing the bill for prioritizing corporate and special interest groups over individuals. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) and National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC) responded with tweets, with the DCCC calling Amash's vote "out-of-touch" and the NRCC accusing him of working against President Trump.

Amash responded with a tweet of his own, saying there is little independent thinking in Congress. The episode highlights the bipartisan support for the CARES Act, which has seen both parties come together to pass major spending bills in the past, including after the 9/11 attacks, the 2008 financial crisis, and now the COVID-19 pandemic.

According to data, since 2000, there have been only three years with a decline in federal spending, and since Donald Trump's election in 2016, real spending has increased by $1,441 per person. The 2020 budget was a record-high $4.8 trillion, and it is likely to increase further before the end of the fiscal year on September 30.

The episode underscores the limited differences between Republicans and Democrats on fundamental issues, with both parties agreeing on the need for increased spending to address national crises.

Title: U.S. Senate Confirms William Barr as Attorney General, Amid Concerns Over Mueller Probe Transparency

The U.S. Senate confirmed William Barr as the new Attorney General on Thursday, with a vote of 54 to 45, largely along party lines. Barr, a seasoned lawyer with decades of Washington experience, will oversee the Justice Department and the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller into whether President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign colluded with Russia.

Barr's confirmation was met with opposition from many Democrats, who expressed concerns that he might not make Mueller's findings fully public. However, with the Senate controlled by Trump's fellow Republicans, Barr's confirmation was virtually assured.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham praised Barr, stating, "He is a steady hand at a time of turmoil and he will bring much-needed reform to the Department of Justice." Barr previously served as Attorney General from 1991 to 1993 under President George H.W. Bush and has won praise from lawmakers in both parties for his expertise and understanding of the Justice Department.

As Attorney General, Barr will be responsible for overseeing Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and whether Moscow colluded with Trump's campaign to influence the outcome. Barr has expressed his commitment to protecting the integrity of the investigation and making public as many of its findings as possible. However, he has also stated that he may not be able to reveal the identities of individuals who escape prosecution, which has raised concerns among Democrats.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, expressed concerns about Barr's independence, stating, "The Justice Department needs a leader who will be independent of the White House and who is able to stand up to President Trump. Bill Barr hasn't demonstrated that he would be that independent leader."

Despite the opposition, many were eager to have Barr installed quickly to replace Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, whose tenure has been marked by controversy. Barr is expected to back many of Trump's tough immigration policies and will be under scrutiny for how he implements a new law easing prison sentences for non-violent criminals, which he had previously advocated against.

Title: Tulsa Police Officers Shot in the Head, One Dies, and Networks' Coverage Raises Questions

A shooting incident in Tulsa, Oklahoma, has left a 15-year veteran police sergeant, Craig Johnson, dead and a six-week rookie officer, Aurash Zarkeshan, in critical condition. The incident occurred during a traffic stop, where a suspect refused to comply with officers' commands and pulled out a gun, firing several shots at close range, striking both officers in the head.

According to Tulsa Police Chief Wendell Franklin, the officers were taken to the hospital in critical condition. Johnson died on Tuesday afternoon, leaving behind a wife and two young sons. Zarkeshan remains in critical condition.

The incident was initially reported by CBS Evening News, but neither ABC nor NBC mentioned it in their broadcasts. ABC did publish an online report, which provided a detailed account of the events leading up to the shooting. The report stated that the suspect refused to comply with officers' commands, and a struggle ensued, resulting in the suspect pulling out a gun and firing several shots at close range.

The incident was also discussed on Fox and Friends, where retired Dallas police officer C'Mone Wingo expressed concerns about the demonization of police officers. She stated that many officers feel unappreciated and undervalued for their work, which can make it difficult for them to want to continue serving as police officers.

The networks' coverage of the incident has raised questions about their priorities and the importance of reporting on police-related incidents. The incident was sponsored by Downy, and their contact information is available for those interested.

Title: Jared Kushner Fined for Failing to Disclose Financial Transactions on Time

The U.S. Office of Government Ethics has ordered Jared Kushner, a senior advisor to President Trump and son-in-law, to pay a $200 fine for failing to disclose recent financial transactions on time as required by federal law. The transactions, valued between $100,000 and $250,000, occurred in February and were related to JCK Cadre LLC, a holding company owned by Kushner.

According to data collected by a Democratic opposition research firm, American Bridge 21st Century, at least 18 members of the Trump administration filed late financial disclosure statements this year, including Kushner. The report also noted that Trump's former chief of staff, Reince Priebus, was four days late with his filing, while Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was 23 days behind, and Chief Strategist Steve Bannon was more than a month tardy.

Individuals required to file financial disclosure statements with the government are typically subject to fines if they are 30 days late in doing so. However, Kushner failed to fall within the 45-day window reserved for similar disclosures called periodic transaction reports. The federal government assessed fees on just 3.6 percent of the 12,000 staffers who filed late periodic transaction reports last year, making Kushner's penalty a rare occurrence.

The White House declined to comment on the record, but a Trump administration official familiar with the matter confirmed that Kushner will pay the fine. Kushner, 36, is married to Ivanka Trump, the president's eldest daughter, and the couple disclosed assets valued between $206 million and $760 million in separate disclosures filed with the OGE last month.

Title: Obama Administration Provided Bergdahl Family with Insider Access to Military's Search Efforts

The Obama administration granted the parents of Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl extraordinary access to the military's search efforts for their son, allowing them to participate in secure video conferences with senior commanders, White House, and State Department officials. The Bergdahls, from Hailey, Idaho, were connected to the National Guard headquarters in Boise, where they received updates on the search efforts and were kept informed about developments.

According to Air Force Col. Timothy Marsano, Idaho's National Guard spokesman, the Bergdahls participated in quarterly video conferences, or up to 20, over the five-year search. The National Guard also offered to help the Bergdahls with media relations, which they accepted.

The Pentagon confirmed that the Bergdahls were regularly informed about the search efforts through various means, including video teleconferencing with military and government agencies. Navy Cmdr. Elissa Smith, a Pentagon spokeswoman, stated that the Bergdahls were kept informed on the efforts to recover Sgt. Bergdahl and the close coordination between U.S. Central Command, the Department of Defense, and other U.S. government agencies.

Robert Bergdahl, Sgt. Bergdahl's father, has expressed sympathy for prisoners at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and has advocated for their release. He has also expressed concern for prisoners worldwide, including those held at Guantanamo.

Larry Johnson, a former government official who worked on American hostage issues, questioned the decision to involve the Bergdahls in top-level discussions about the search efforts, citing concerns that sensitive information could be leaked. However, Col. Marsano denied any breach of sensitive information and emphasized the importance of keeping the Bergdahls informed throughout the search.

Sgt. Bergdahl is currently undergoing the military's reintegration process, which includes debriefings on his captivity. His former Army colleagues accuse him of desertion, claiming he walked off their forward operating base in Paktia province and into the hands of the enemy.

Title: Senate Republicans Engage in Budget Battle, with Ted Cruz Leading the Charge Against Debt Limit Increase

Article:

A rift has emerged within the Senate Republican ranks over the budget, with Senator Ted Cruz and a handful of conservative colleagues refusing to consent to budget negotiations with the House. The disagreement has led to public sniping between Cruz and more senior Republicans, such as Senator John McCain, who are perplexed by the hardball tactics employed by the Texas Republican.

Cruz and his allies, including Senators Marco Rubio, Mike Lee, and Rand Paul, are opposed to adding a debt limit increase to the budget talks, citing concerns about the country's fiscal problems. They argue that the increase would be a step towards further debt accumulation, rather than a genuine effort to address the nation's financial issues.

The unusual public disagreement has put Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell in an awkward position, as he must balance the demands of conservative firebrands who could potentially run for president in 2016 with the need to end the internal feud and maintain party unity.

The situation is reminiscent of the tea party versus establishment fights that have shaken Senate primaries in recent years, but this time the battles are playing out on the Senate floor. GOP leaders are uncertain about how the situation will resolve itself, with some Republicans favoring heading to conference talks and others opposing it.

Senator John Cornyn, the No. 2 Republican and Cruz's Texas colleague, has expressed uncertainty about the outcome, stating, "I'm just watching." Cruz has taken the fight to his own party, stating that he does not trust Republicans to resolve the country's fiscal problems or avoid including an increase to the debt ceiling.

The controversy began after Senate Democrats passed a budget in March, their first such plan in four years. Democrats wanted to begin conference negotiations with House Republicans, who passed their own budget by Representative Paul Ryan. However, Senate conservatives objected to Majority Leader Harry Reid's attempt to begin the proceedings, citing concerns about tax hikes and a debt limit increase.

Title: Obama Urges House to Pass Comprehensive Immigration Reform, Departing from Previous Stance

The article reports that President Obama and top Democrats on Capitol Hill are shifting their focus towards passing comprehensive immigration reform in the Republican-controlled House, rather than a step-by-step process. This change in approach comes as lawmakers prepare to leave Washington for the Christmas holiday break.

In a year-end press conference, Obama emphasized the importance of passing the comprehensive immigration bill passed by the Senate this summer, which he believes would boost the economy and attract high-skilled workers. He urged the House to "get that done."

However, this stance appears to depart from Obama's previous comments, where he expressed willingness to accept a piecemeal approach. In November, he told The Wall Street Journal's CEO Council that he had no problem with House leaders breaking the bill into smaller pieces, as long as all the necessary components were addressed.

Meanwhile, House Speaker John Boehner has repeatedly stated that he will not schedule a vote on the Senate bill or negotiate with Senate Democrats on their legislation. Instead, the House is focused on securing the U.S.-Mexico border and excluding a path to citizenship for some of the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the United States.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, believes that Boehner will eventually negotiate on comprehensive reform, possibly after the congressional primaries this spring and summer. Reid also suggested that some House members facing reelection in Democratic-leaning or middle-of-the-road districts may need to vote for immigration reform.

While some conservative Republicans, such as Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions and Reps. Steve King and Trey Gowdy, are likely to oppose any bill perceived as too lenient on legalization, Florida GOP Sen. Marco Rubio's spokesman has expressed support for a piecemeal approach.

The article provides a neutral and factual account of the current state of immigration reform discussions in the United States, highlighting the differing views and priorities of various lawmakers and stakeholders.

Title: Democrats Eye State-Level Wins to Rebuild and Rebrand

The 2018 midterm elections may not be the most exciting for Democrats, with few Republican Senate seats up for grabs and most House seats considered safe for one party or the other. However, experts suggest that focusing on state-level races could be a game-changer for the party. Thirty-eight governorships are up for election in the next two years, providing an opportunity for new Democratic faces and ideas to emerge.

Governors can operate independently of Washington and pursue innovative policies that can spread quickly across the country, making them a key way to rebrand the Democratic Party. Many recent presidents, including Jimmy Carter and George W. Bush, served as governors before taking office.

The Democratic Governors Association (DGA) believes that winning a slew of governorships could bring a new generation of party leaders into the spotlight and help rebrand the party. Governors can quickly become the stars of their party and pursue fresh policies that spread quickly around the country.

Republicans have successfully rebuilt their party by electing new governors who pushed policies and had a story to tell. Ohio Governor John Kasich, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker are examples of governors who made a name for themselves in their first term and went on to become prominent figures in the conservative field.

Governorships are the perfect means to audition a new party message, says Connecticut Governor Dannel Malloy, who chairs the DGA. This could be especially helpful in the Midwest, where many Democrats worry the Republican Party has found a new stronghold with the white working class.

The Democratic Party needs some stars, says John Weingart, director of Rutgers University's Center on the American Governor in New Jersey, some younger faces to advance their issues and to be potential national candidates in 2020 and beyond. During President Obama's tenure, Democrats lost 12 governorships and over 950 state legislative seats to Republicans, the largest net loss for either party since World War II.

The number of Democratic governors and state legislators over the next few years may be more important than ever. When the next census is held in 2020, state legislatures – and to some extent governors – will lead the subsequent redrawing of congressional districts. Success for Democrats at the state level is "essential," adds Weingart.

For Democrats to reap the rewards of state-level wins at the national level, party donors and voters need to invest in the 2018 midterm elections.

Title: Trump's Economic Legacy: A Divided Opinion on the State of the Union

The United States is currently experiencing its longest economic expansion in American history, with unemployment at a 50-year low and the stock market reaching record highs. President Trump has touted this growth as a testament to his economic policies, stating that the economy is the "best it has ever been." However, opinions on the matter are sharply divided.

Trump's supporters credit his trillion-dollar tax cut and trade battles with China, Mexico, and others for boosting investment and creating jobs in the U.S. They argue that his policies have sparked a historic economic renaissance, with millions of Americans better off today due to his efforts.

On the other hand, Trump's detractors argue that the gains made in the past three years are merely an extension of the progress made during the Obama administration. They claim that Obama prevented another depression and built a solid foundation on which the current economic expansion has grown. Others argue that Trump's policies have weakened the country's long-term prospects by cutting taxes and increasing spending to create a short burst of growth that will ultimately destabilize the economy.

Some critics also point out that most of the gains have been experienced by the wealthy, while the working class has fallen further behind. The rate of economic growth slowed last year to the lowest levels in the Trump presidency, leaving economists uncertain about whether this is a sign the economic upswing is reaching its peak.

Experts and politicians from both sides of the aisle have weighed in on the issue. Andy Puzder, a Washington Post contributor, stated that the Trump administration's policies have finally produced the economic benefits that American workers should have experienced coming out of the recession. Adriana Cohen, a Fox News contributor, credited Trump's policies with sparking the greatest economic renaissance America has seen in decades.

However, others have taken a more critical stance. Tiana Lowe, a Washington Examiner contributor, argued that Trump inherited an economy theoretically overdue for a recession and already returned to what economists considered full employment. Harry Cheadle, a Vox contributor, suggested that the economic metrics Trump touts are continuations of trends that started during the Obama administration, implying that the country has been climbing out of a recession for many years, not that Trump's policies were necessarily transformative.

Sasha Abramskyy, a writer for The Nation, pointed out that poverty rates are falling not because of GOP tax cuts and the resulting ballooning of both inequality and the federal deficit, but rather because of Democratic-controlled cities and states raising the minimum wage and increasing access to health insurance.

Ultimately, the debate surrounding Trump's economic legacy is far from settled, with opinions divided on the impact of his policies on the economy.

Title: Teacher Michael Landsberry Killed in Sparks Middle School Shooting, Authorities Investigate

Authorities are still investigating the circumstances surrounding the shooting at Sparks Middle School in Nevada, which left a beloved teacher, Michael Landsberry, dead and two students injured. The 45-year-old math teacher was a former Marine and Army National Guard member who had been teaching at the school since 2006. He was known for his dedication to his students and his coaching of the school's basketball and volleyball teams.

According to Chief Michael Mieras of the Washoe County School District, Landsberry's actions likely prevented more students from being injured or killed. The chief described Landsberry as "very respected by his peers" and "by students at Sparks Middle School." He calmly approached the shooter, put his hands up in a motion to stop the shooter's actions, and gave students time to escape the scene.

The shooter, who has not been named, took his own life after shooting Landsberry and the two students. One student was shot in the shoulder, and the other was struck in the abdomen. Law enforcement officials did not fire any shots during the incident.

A motive for the shooting has not been determined, and authorities are working to determine why the shooting occurred. A Facebook page, Remembering Mr. Michael Landsberry, has been created to honor the slain teacher, with many parents and students expressing their gratitude for his bravery and selflessness.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Tweets on Brett Kavanaugh: A Case Study in Provoking Controversy

Article:

In a media landscape where attention is scarce, politicians and public figures often resort to provocative tactics to get noticed. Hillary Clinton's tweets about Brett Kavanaugh's views on birth-control pills are a recent example of this phenomenon. Clinton claimed that Kavanaugh referred to birth-control pills as "abortion-inducing drugs," which was widely debunked by fact-checkers and media outlets.

The Washington Post's fact-checker, Glenn Kessler, gave Clinton's claim four Pinocchios, the worst rating, and PolitiFact ruled that the characterization was dishonest. Despite this, Clinton's tweets sparked a significant reaction, with many Democrats rallying to her cause.

The phenomenon of provoking controversy to gain attention is not unique to Clinton or Kavanaugh. In a media environment where every news outlet is a niche product, appealing to a specific audience, the best way to get attention is often to be attacked by the other side. This is the broader context for the lucrative vocation of "trolling," where individuals or groups say or do something provocative to get the other side to attack them, and their own side will rush to their support.

Nebraska Senator Ben Sasse, who has spoken about this phenomenon on his podcast, The Remnant, notes that cable-news producers and magazine editors have told him that there is no chance of getting a 70% audience anymore, but rather a deep and sticky 1% audience. The most effective way to achieve this is by getting attacked, as it draws visibility to oneself.

Sasse points to The New Yorker's "exposé" of Chick-fil-A's "creepy infiltration" of New York City as an example of this phenomenon. He believes that the motive is to get attacked from the other side, wear the victim badge of honor, and then rally others who are part of one's base.

While it is unclear what motivated Clinton's tweets about Kavanaugh, Sasse's observations highlight the broader phenomenon of provoking controversy to gain attention. As the media landscape continues to evolve, it is essential to understand this dynamic and its implications for our understanding of facts and reality.

Title: House Republicans Unveil Spending Bill to Avoid Government Shutdown

The House Republicans have introduced a government spending bill that aims to keep federal agencies funded through the end of September and avoid a potential government shutdown. The bill, drafted by House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal Rogers, R-Kentucky, does not replace the sequester, but rather lessens the impact on the Pentagon and the Department of Veterans Affairs.

The proposal shifts funds around to prioritize specific programs, with the Defense Department's "operations and maintenance" account receiving a boost to ensure funding for military readiness and training programs. The bill also protects some agencies from the across-the-board budget cuts that took effect on Friday, keeping FBI and border security staffing at current levels and increasing funding for embassy security by $2 billion.

The bill keeps federal agencies funded at last year's spending levels, established in the 2011 Budget Control Act, and factors in reductions from the sequester, resulting in actual federal spending dropping below $1 trillion to $982 billion. Rogers stated that the legislation will avoid a government shutdown, prioritize DoD and Veterans programs, and allow the Pentagon some flexibility to manage its funding.

Democrats are expected to try to amend the bill to soften the impact of the spending cuts on domestic programs, with priorities including housing, education, healthcare, and transportation. However, a top Republican aide warned that if Democrats move beyond non-controversial items, they could risk disrupting the swift passage of the government funding bill.

The bill's passage is uncertain, with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi stating that it will be "curious" if Republicans can produce the votes to pass it. The White House has declined to comment on the bill, stating that it wants to see something "practical and non-political" and consistent with the levels established in the Budget Control Act.

The House is expected to begin debate on the spending bill on Wednesday and vote on it on Thursday.

Title: The "Tax the Rich" Movement: A Misguided Approach to Public Finance

The "Tax the Rich" movement, led by groups like Patriotic Millionaires, has gained momentum in recent years, with proponents arguing that the wealthy should pay their "fair share" of taxes. However, a closer examination of the data reveals that the rich are already paying a significant portion of the federal revenue. According to the Tax Foundation, the top 1% of earners accounted for 37.3% of all income-tax revenue in 2016, while the top half of taxpayers paid 97% of income taxes.

The Tax Policy Center estimates that 44% of Americans won't pay any federal income taxes in 2018, but this doesn't mean they don't pay any taxes at all. Payroll taxes, which are often overlooked, account for a significant portion of many Americans' paychecks.

The income tax is also remarkably progressive, with Americans in the top 20% paying an estimated 87% of income taxes in 2018. This is up from 84% in 2017, making the "Trump tax cuts" more progressive.

Proponents of the "Tax the Rich" movement argue that the wealthy should pay their fair share, but this is a debatable claim. It's not unreasonable to argue that the rich should pay a few percentage points more in income tax in the name of fairness. However, it's also not unreasonable to say that when the top 1% of earners provide more than a third of income-tax revenue, they're already paying their fair share.

The idea that the rich should be taxed more to address income inequality is also problematic. According to the Manhattan Institute's Brian Riedl, doubling the top tax brackets would only close one-fifth of the long-term Social Security and Medicare shortfall. Even seizing all annual income earned over $500,000 would not come close to paying for Medicare for All, which has a price tag of $32 trillion.

The "Tax the Rich" movement is based on the assumption that the problems of ordinary Americans are the result of a tiny group of people selfishly refusing to do their part. This is a simplistic and inaccurate view of the issue. It's a form of scapegoating that ignores the complexity of the problem and the many factors that contribute to income inequality.

In conclusion, the "Tax the Rich" movement is a misguided approach to public finance that oversimplifies the issue of income inequality and ignores the many factors that contribute to it. It's time to have a more nuanced and informed discussion about how to address the challenges facing our country.

Title: The Rise of the Imperial Presidency: A Threat to American Democracy

The article discusses the author's perception of President Barack Obama's presidency, specifically his approach to governance and his relationship with Congress. The author argues that Obama's actions have led to a decline in the balance of powers between the legislative and executive branches, and that he has shown a willingness to disregard the Constitution and the will of the American people.

The article highlights several instances where Obama has taken actions that have been seen as an overreach of executive power, including his decision to cease enforcing certain immigration policies, his refusal to defend the Defense of Marriage Act, and his decision to engage in military action in Libya without congressional approval. The author also criticizes Obama's use of recess appointments and his willingness to redefine the term to circumvent the Senate's review process.

The article also touches on Obama's handling of international relations, specifically his exchange with Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, where he asked for "space" on missile defense until after the November election. The author sees this as a display of presidential duplicity and a willingness to put his own political interests ahead of the country's security.

The article concludes by calling for an end to the "era of the imperial presidency" and urging Americans to put aside partisan differences to defend limited government and executive restraint.

Title: Special Counsel Questions Witnesses About Flynn-Rohrabacher Meeting in 2016

The special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election is questioning witnesses about a meeting between former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn and Republican Representative Dana Rohrabacher in September 2016. The meeting took place in Washington, D.C., and involved Flynn's business associates from the Flynn Intel Group, a private security firm.

According to NBC News, Flynn and Rohrabacher met on September 20, 2016, with several of Flynn's associates from the Flynn Intel Group. Rohrabacher is a veteran Republican congressman who has advocated for friendlier ties with Russia. The special counsel is also reviewing emails exchanged between Flynn's associates and Rohrabacher's staff.

It is unclear why the special counsel is scrutinizing the meeting, but Rohrabacher has had longstanding ties to the Kremlin and WikiLeaks, which U.S. defense officials have described as a hostile intelligence agency. He has also had contact with Rinat Akhmetshin, one of the Russia-aligned lobbyists present at Donald Trump Jr.'s June 2016 meeting with Russian political operatives at Trump Tower in New York.

Rohrabacher has also been involved in a recent attempt to broker a deal between WikiLeaks and the Department of Justice, under which WikiLeaks would surrender data exonerating Russia of involvement in the 2016 hack of the Democratic National Committee. Rohrabacher met with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange at the Ecuadorian embassy in London in August.

Federal prosecutors have not indicted Assange for any crimes, but the Justice Department has long sought to bring a case against him for his role in facilitating the release of hundreds of thousands of sensitive intelligence documents via Chelsea Manning.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California has jokingly referred to Rohrabacher's frequent apologies for Putin as creating the impression that the congressman is on Putin's payroll. "There's two people I think Putin pays — Rohrabacher and Trump. Swear to God," he said.

Flynn served as President Donald Trump's national security advisor for less than a month before he resigned in disgrace for lying to administration officials about the nature of his communications with the Russian government during the transition. His extensive and undisclosed ties to the Erdogan government in Turkey are expected to prompt an indictment in the coming weeks.

Rohrabacher's office did not respond to a request for comment by press time.

Title: The Future of Grocery Shopping: A Shift Towards Online and Smaller-Scale Services

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about significant changes in the way people shop for groceries. With lockdowns and social distancing measures in place, consumers are turning to online shopping and delivery services to get the essentials. According to Bryan Leach, CEO of Ibotta, online grocery shopping is expected to rise from 3% to the double digits as a result of the pandemic. This shift could lead to a new attitude towards supermarkets, with consumers doing things differently but still valuing the experience of shopping in physical stores.

One of the main concerns is the added cost of pickup or delivery, which can be a significant premium. Additionally, returns can be difficult and require scheduling online shopping at a time when customers can be home to put perishable items away. Supermarkets may need to adapt to these changes to remain relevant.

However, Leach believes that online grocery shopping will not lead to the demise of the American grocery store. Instead, it could encourage companies to better compensate grocery workers for their skills and persuade Americans to support smaller, local supermarkets. The shift towards smaller-scale, more attentive grocery services is already underway, with shops like Trader Joe's and Whole Foods catering to specific markets. The pandemic may accelerate this trend, as consumers seek more personalized and convenient shopping experiences.

The rise of online grocery shopping could also benefit Main Street-style local shopping, as consumers may opt for online services that supply the basics, such as paper towels and crackers, and visit local shops for more specialized items. As the pandemic persists, it is likely that grocery shopping habits will continue to evolve, with consumers seeking a balance between convenience, quality, and community.

Title: Mark Sanford Wins House Seat in South Carolina, Overcoming Past Scandals

Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina, has won the special election for the 1st Congressional District, defeating Democratic opponent Elizabeth Colbert Busch. Sanford's victory marks a stunning comeback for the politician, who was previously embroiled in scandals involving an extramarital affair and ethics violations.

Sanford's campaign focused on his personal redemption and his experience as a veteran campaigner. He was open about his past mistakes and made them the subject of his first TV ad. Despite his political baggage, Sanford's campaign was able to connect with voters, particularly in the conservative counties of Berkeley and Dorchester, where he won around 60% of the vote.

Colbert Busch's campaign, on the other hand, highlighted Sanford's affair and ethics violations, and received support from national Democratic groups. However, Sanford's campaign was able to overcome these challenges and win over voters.

The election saw a high turnout, with around 140,000 votes cast, and Sanford's campaign was able to capitalize on this by holding numerous events in the closing days of the campaign. The candidate's ability to connect with voters one-on-one was seen as a key factor in his victory.

Sanford's win is a significant upset, as the 1st Congressional District has been held by the GOP for over 30 years. The district is considered a Republican stronghold, and Mitt Romney carried it by 18 percentage points in the 2012 presidential election.

Sanford's victory is also seen as a testament to his ability to connect with voters and overcome his personal scandals. In his victory speech, he acknowledged his mistakes and thanked voters for giving him a second chance. "I am one imperfect man saved by God's grace," he said.

The election results are a significant blow to the Democratic Party, which had high hopes of defeating Sanford and gaining a foothold in the district. The loss is also a setback for House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, who was a target of Sanford's campaign ads.

Title: White House Debates Timing of Immigration Announcement Amid Political Concerns

The White House is engaged in a heated debate over the timing of an announcement regarding immigration policy, with some advisors urging President Obama to delay action, while others push for him to stick to his promised schedule. The debate comes as immigration lawyers at the Homeland Security Department work to develop legally defensible policy options for the president.

Chris Newman, the legal director for the National Day Laborer Organizing Network, expressed hope that the president's conscience would prevail, while Representative Luis V. Gutiérrez, a Democrat from Illinois, emphasized the importance of prioritizing families and security over short-term political considerations. Gutiérrez noted that the delay in action comes at a tremendous cost, with families being split up and children placed in foster care.

Some of Obama's advisors are concerned about the potential political ramifications of a broad action to protect millions of immigrants in the country illegally and provide them with official work papers. They fear that such a move could spark a fierce fight with Republicans and harm Democratic Senate candidates in key states. Control of the Senate is at stake in the upcoming elections, with several close races in states where Obama is not popular, particularly in Southern states where opposition to an immigration overhaul is high.

Democratic senators have reached out to top White House officials, including Chief of Staff Denis McDonough, to argue that the recent crisis with unaccompanied minors crossing the border into the United States justifies a delay. Several Democratic officials on Capitol Hill believe that the angry reaction to the border crisis has eroded public support for changing immigration policy and turned the issue into a negative one for Democrats.

On the other hand, some White House officials are pushing the president to stick to his promised schedule, regardless of the immediate political consequences. They argue that Republicans will criticize the president and attack Democratic candidates even if Obama delays parts of his announcement until after the election.

Title: Ferguson Officer Darren Wilson's Legal Troubles Not Over Despite Grand Jury Decision

The grand jury's decision not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown does not necessarily mean the end of his legal troubles. Wilson could still face civil rights charges brought by the Department of Justice or a civil wrongful death lawsuit filed by Brown's parents.

The FBI defines "justifiable homicide" by law enforcement as the killing of a felon by a law enforcement officer in the line of duty.
