In 2011, police killed 404 people in the line of duty, the FBI's Uniform Crime Report said. In 2012, officers killed 410, and in 2013, the number grew to 461 – the most in two decades.

The grand jury did not weigh whether Wilson had a justifiable reason to shoot Brown. "They did not find probable cause to believe a crime was committed and Darren Wilson committed it," said Susan McGraugh, a criminal defense lawyer and professor at the St. Louis University School of Law. "They don't have to explain their reasoning, and they won't. They simply have a form and sign something that says 'no true bill.'"

Wilson has been on paid leave from the department since the incident. Ferguson Police Chief Tom Jackson told MSNBC that Missouri law would allow Wilson to return to the force if he is cleared of any charges. The Police Department would conduct an internal review of the Brown shooting to see whether Wilson violated any policies.

Brown's family could sue Wilson and the Ferguson Police Department for excessive force and wrongful death, said James Cohen, a professor at Fordham University Law School. In a civil trial, Brown's family could seek monetary damages, as the victim's family did in the case of football player O.J. Simpson, who was acquitted in a criminal trial of his wife's murder but ordered by a court in a civil trial to pay millions to her family.

The federal government's probe could have wide-ranging consequences not only for Wilson but also for the entire Police Department. "Their claims would not just be excessive force, which would be directly associated with the police officer, but failure to adequately train the police officer," Cohen said. "Then, you sort of implicate the whole department and its structure."

More unlikely, the St. Louis County prosecuting attorney could take a crack at Wilson. The grand jury's decision would not preclude a prosecutor from bringing new evidence to another grand jury or bypassing the grand jury entirely by filing a criminal complaint, McGraugh said.

Wilson may never escape public infamy, but he won't have a criminal arrest record, McGraugh said. Since St. Louis County Prosecuting Attorney Robert McCulloch did not bring a criminal complaint against Wilson and he was never charged, arraigned, or arrested, she said. McCulloch also took the unusual step of presenting both incriminating and exculpatory evidence, she said.

The court's treatment of Wilson's case may affect how prosecutors handle future cases, including whether evidence that does not support an indictment may be presented. "I think we will see a call for a real wholesale review of how the criminal justice system functions," McGraugh said. "People want to be heard in terms of a lot of the systemic injustices in the criminal justice system."

Title: Health Reform Upheld, Now Must Find Support and Fend Off GOP Bids for Repeal

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has brought relief to the White House and its supporters, with President Obama's re-election prospects looking stronger and his lasting impact on domestic policy potentially greater. However, the battle is far from over. Even after legislation is enacted, its survival is not assured, and the key to success lies in whether a program lasts over time and builds strong political support to protect it from future attacks.

Congressional Republicans will likely continue to attack the program's funding, with House Speaker John Boehner vowing to push for its repeal and Mitt Romney stating he will do the same if elected president. The Supreme Court's decision on Medicaid has opened up questions about whether red state governors will follow through with an essential expansion of the program.

There are also challenges in making the law work, including who will enforce penalties on those who refuse to buy insurance, how effective cost controls will be, and states setting up their health care exchanges. Some state officials, such as those in Idaho and South Dakota, are refusing to implement the law until after November.

Despite these challenges, the Affordable Care Act is not the first federal program to face difficulties. Social Security, for example, did not start well, with a freeze on taxes during World War II jeopardizing the program. However, Congress made adjustments, expanding coverage and revising the tax system, and by 1950, the program was sound and received bipartisan support.

Similarly, Medicare faced chronic challenges of cost control, with Congress imposing regulations on what hospitals could charge the program to help contain rising costs. Congress has also taken similar action with taxes, raising taxes in 1982 and 1983 after President Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cut and increased military spending made the deficit balloon.

The question now is whether Congress can overcome polarization and gridlock to refine and improve the health care law to make sure it works. The 2012 election will be a crucial moment for health care, as a future Congress might use its power to repeal the legislation and finish the job they wish the Supreme Court had done.

Title: Comparing White House Emails to Nixon's "Enemies List" is an Ahistorical Claim

Article:

Conservative media outlets have drawn parallels between the recent controversy surrounding a White House email sent to journalist Bob Woodward and the Nixon administration's "Enemies List." However, this comparison is misguided and lacks historical accuracy. The Nixon administration's "Enemies List" was a deliberate effort to use the federal government's power to financially damage political opponents, including journalists. This went beyond mere emails, as Nixon administration officials plotted to kill a critical columnist.

The "Enemies List" was a 1971 memorandum from White House Counsel John Dean to White House Chief of Staff John Haldeman's assistant, detailing a plan to use the federal government's power to damage political opponents. The memo outlined a plan to identify targets, determine how to use the federal government's power to harm them, and receive support from top officials in federal agencies to implement the plan.

In contrast, the email sent to Woodward by White House economic adviser Gene Sperling was a personal message expressing concern and offering advice, rather than a coordinated effort to harm or intimidate the journalist. Woodward replied to the email, welcoming Sperling's advice and stating he was listening.

It is essential to understand the historical context of the Nixon administration's actions, which included plotting to kill a journalist and plotting to use the federal government's power to damage political opponents. This is in stark contrast to the email sent to Woodward, which was a personal message and not a coordinated effort to harm or intimidate the journalist.

Title: House Republicans to Vote on Immigration Legislation Expanding Visas for STEM Graduates and Family Reunification

The House of Representatives is set to vote on a new immigration bill that aims to expand visas for foreign science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students and make it easier for those with green cards to bring their immediate families to the United States. The legislation, known as the STEM Jobs Act, is seen as a first step towards overhauling the nation's dysfunctional immigration system, a top priority for Hispanic communities.

The bill would provide 55,000 green cards a year to doctoral and master's graduates in STEM fields, making it easier for them to put their skills to work for American companies rather than non-American competitors. Additionally, it would allow spouses and minor children of green card holders to wait in the United States for their own green cards to be granted, reducing the average wait time from over two years to one year.

The bill is a departure from the previous STEM bill, which was defeated in September due to concerns over the elimination of a visa program for less-educated foreigners, many from Africa. This time, the bill includes a provision long sought by immigration advocates, expanding a program that allows family members to wait in the United States for their own green cards to be granted.

Bruce Morrison, a former Democratic congressman and immigration policy lobbyist, sees the bill as a stepping stone to more comprehensive immigration reform. "It's a positive gesture that they want to do business on this subject," he said.

The bill is expected to pass the Republican-led House with ease, but its fate in the Democratic-controlled Senate remains uncertain. The legislation would eliminate the Diversity Visa Lottery Program, which gives out similar green cards to those from countries with traditionally low rates of immigration to the U.S. This has prompted opposition from the House's Hispanic Caucus, Congressional Black Caucus, and Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus.

Crystal Williams, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, views the bill as a message from Republicans that "we are here and we are ready to talk about immigration reform." However, she doubts it will make much progress in the Senate during the short lame-duck session, as people are now focusing on broader reform and a limited bill that doesn't increase visas won't garner much support.

Title: Bernie Sanders Ends Presidential Campaign, Clearing the Way for Biden-Trump Showdown

Bernie Sanders, a democratic socialist and former presidential candidate, announced on Wednesday that he is suspending his White House campaign, effectively clearing the way for a November election battle between former Vice President Joe Biden and Republican President Donald Trump. Sanders, a one-time front-runner, acknowledged that he no longer had a path to victory after a string of decisive nominating contest losses to Biden.

In a livestreamed speech to supporters from his hometown of Burlington, Vermont, Sanders said he could not continue a campaign that could not win and would interfere with the important work required of all Americans during the coronavirus outbreak. He promised to stay on the ballot in future primaries and continue gathering delegates to push the Democratic platform towards his populist anti-corporate agenda, including a government-run healthcare system and tax hikes for the rich.

The departure of Sanders sets up a long battle for the White House between Biden, 77, and Trump, 73, who is seeking a second four-year term in office. The matchup will revolve around Trump's handling of the public health crisis that has upended all aspects of American life and rocked the country's economy.

Biden signaled he is ready for a bruising general election fight and the challenge he now faces in trying to unite the Democratic Party's liberal and moderate wings. He praised Sanders and promised his ideas would be incorporated into his White House run.

Winning over Sanders' most ardent supporters will not be easy. Sanders' speechwriter, David Sirota, said Biden should rethink his opposition to parts of Sanders' agenda that opinion polls show are popular among Democratic voters. "Biden's campaign has to do its part to bring those voters into the fold and energize them in a real way," Sirota said.

Sanders parlayed massive rallies, an anti-establishment message, and fervent support from young and new voters into success in the early nominating contests before losing in South Carolina in late February. He suffered a string of decisive losses through March as Democrats settled on Biden as the candidate with the best chance of beating Trump, putting the senator under growing pressure from Democrats to end his campaign and help the party unite.

Some allies had encouraged Sanders to stay in the race to further influence Biden's policy positions. However, Sanders made little headway on expanding his coalition beyond young voters, who did not turn out to the polls in large numbers. Instead, Biden won support from a growing coalition of women and men, white and black voters, those with or without college degrees, and self-described liberals and moderates.

The article does not contain any personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language. It provides a factual account of Bernie Sanders' decision to suspend his presidential campaign and the implications for the 2020 Democratic presidential race.

Title: Obama and Romney Address United Nations, Discuss Freedom of Speech and Foreign Aid

Article:

At the United Nations, President Barack Obama and Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney addressed the General Assembly, discussing topics such as freedom of speech and foreign aid. Obama emphasized the importance of protecting the right to free speech, even when it is used to express hateful or offensive views. He stated that the United States values its First Amendment and believes that the strongest weapon against hateful speech is not repression, but more speech - the voices of tolerance that rally against bigotry and blasphemy.

Romney, on the other hand, called for a rethinking of how American foreign aid is disbursed, suggesting that it could be tied directly to how governments and organizations work to open up their markets and encourage employment. He emphasized the need to promote work and free enterprise, stating that a larger share of aid should be focused on these goals.

The two speeches were delivered amidst a backdrop of ongoing unrest and violence in the Middle East, following the deadly attacks on American diplomatic compounds in Benghazi, Libya. Obama vowed to continue supporting democratic freedoms in the Muslim world, while also warning that time is running out to diplomatically resolve the Iranian nuclear issue. He refused to set a new "red line" that Iran cannot cross without provoking military intervention, but emphasized the need for a peaceful resolution.

Romney did not repeat accusations against Obama's foreign policy during his speech, and the president did not make partisan attacks. The speeches were seen as a way for both leaders to address the global audience and highlight their positions on key issues.

Title: Trump Criticizes Cruz's Immigration Plan, Calls it "Actually Quite Weak"

In an interview aired on Sunday, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump criticized Senator Ted Cruz's immigration plan, calling it "actually quite weak." Trump accused Cruz of copying his own ideas on building a wall along the Mexican border and being weak on immigration and amnesty.

Trump stated that Cruz's plan is not stricter on undocumented workers and that he was the one who first brought up the issue of illegal immigration during his presidential campaign. He also compared Cruz's stance to that of Senator Marco Rubio, saying that both are trying to improve their positions on immigration and amnesty because they were previously weak on the issue.

Trump emphasized his own strong stance on immigration, stating that he wants a "strong border" and wants "everybody out." He claimed that no one else has his position on the issue and that he is the only one who can effectively address it.

Title: The Complex History of Free Speech and National Security in the United States

The United States is often touted as a beacon of freedom, with the First Amendment guaranteeing citizens the right to free speech, a free press, and the right to assemble. However, this freedom has been repeatedly tested throughout the country's history, often in the name of national security. From the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798 to the present day, the balance between individual rights and national security has been a persistent theme.

The Alien and Sedition Acts, enacted during the administration of John Adams, prohibited the publication of "false, scandalous, and seditious writings" against the government, effectively criminalizing dissent. The acts led to the imprisonment of newspaper editors and lawmakers, as well as the deportation of foreigners. The acts were widely criticized as an attempt to suppress voters who disagreed with the Federalist Party.

Fast-forward to the Civil War era, and President Abraham Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus, allowing individuals to be arrested and held without formal charges. Suspected political prisoners were tried before military tribunals, a practice that is difficult to fathom today. Lincoln's actions were criticized on constitutional grounds, with some arguing that only Congress has the power to suspend habeas corpus.

The Sedition and Espionage Acts of 1918 further restricted free speech, prohibiting the use of "disloyal, profane, scurrilous, or abusive language" about the government, the flag, or the military. The acts were used to target leftists, immigrants, and political dissidents, with violators facing fines and prison sentences.

The 1920s saw the formation of the Bureau of Investigation (BOI), which was used to clamp down on civil liberties in a manner unprecedented in American history. The BOI targeted leftists, immigrants, and political dissidents, with some critics arguing that the agency's actions were motivated by political beliefs rather than actual wrongdoing.

The 1950s and 1960s saw increased suppression of civil rights, with labor unions, feminists, and communists among the groups targeted by investigative groups and laws at both federal and local levels. The Vietnam War era was marked by anti-war protests and government efforts to control dissent.

Today, the United States is subject to NSA spying on American citizens and the Patriot Act, which gives law enforcement new tools to detect and prevent terrorism. While the consequences of dissent may be less severe than in the past, the threat to free speech remains. The next time you hear the phrase "America: The Land of the Free," ask yourself if it is still true.

Title: Illinois Teen Warns of Vaping Dangers After Hospitalization with Lung Injury

An 18-year-old Illinois resident, Adam Hergenreder, has issued a stark warning to young people about the dangers of vaping, after being hospitalized with a "vaping-induced acute lung injury." Hergenreder, from Gurnee, was admitted to a hospital in Libertyville on Saturday and is currently undergoing treatment with oxygen tubes and medication.

The teen started vaping at the age of 16, initially using mint and mango flavors, and eventually progressed to using marijuana products purchased from street dealers. He was rushed to the hospital after experiencing days of uncontrolled vomiting and is now facing up to months of recovery, with the possibility of permanent damage to his lungs due to scarring and inflammation.

Hergenreder's story is one of many cases of severe respiratory illnesses linked to vaping, with at least 27 patients in Illinois hospitalized in recent weeks, including one fatality. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has reported 215 possible cases of severe lung disease associated with e-cigarettes across 25 states.

Juul, the manufacturer of the popular e-cigarette device, has issued a statement acknowledging the health concerns and emphasizing the importance of proper product testing and regulation. The company is working to stop the sale of counterfeit products and is conducting extensive testing to ensure the safety of its products.

Hergenreder's experience serves as a cautionary tale for young people who may be tempted to try vaping products. He hopes to leave the hospital in the coming days and is urging others to avoid the dangers of vaping. "I feel stupid," he said. "I want other people to stop. It's going to attack your lungs."

Title: California Eliminates Tax Deduction for Entrepreneurs, Retroactively Affects Past Sales

California has eliminated a tax deduction that encouraged entrepreneurs and investors to start and keep their companies in the state. The deduction, which allowed for a 50% exclusion of capital gains on the sale of "Qualified Small Business" stock, was a key incentive for entrepreneurs to establish and maintain their businesses in California. The state's capital gains taxes are 9%, making the deduction a significant benefit. However, the state has decided to eliminate the deduction, effective retroactively from 2008.

This means that anyone who sold their California company in the past five years and took advantage of the tax deduction will now have to pay the tax. The decision is expected to have a far-reaching impact, potentially driving young and growing businesses to more favorable environments. The California Franchise Tax Board (FTB) has taken this drastic measure, which will send a chilling message to entrepreneurs and investors.

The elimination of the deduction will be a painful experience for entrepreneurs and investors in California over the next few months, as tax bills start arriving in mailboxes across the state. The decision will not only affect individual entrepreneurs but also the local workforce and the overall startup community.

Title: SolarCity Corp. Faces Scrutiny Over Tax Credits and Financial Performance

SolarCity Corp., a California-based solar company backed by several Obama supporters, has received millions in federal tax credits while losing $322 million since 2008. The company's financial standing has raised concerns about it becoming the next Solyndra, a company that received $535 million in Energy Department loan guarantees before going bankrupt in 2011.

Senator Jeff Sessions, the top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, warned about SolarCity's financial standing in a letter to the Treasury Department, stating that the company might be "propped on the back of the taxpayers." SolarCity fired back, denying the comparison to Solyndra and stating that declining solar panel prices have driven the company's success.

The company will soon set the record straight on the Sessions allegations now that a Securities and Exchange Commission's "quiet period" has ended. SolarCity has received millions in tax credits and cash grants through the 2009 stimulus law, and Sessions charges that the company might have overestimated the "fair market value" of its products to get higher credits.

The Treasury Department's Office of Inspector General confirmed an investigation into the matter, roughly 14 months after SolarCity acknowledged in its initial public offering that the inspector general's office had issued subpoenas to a number of significant participants in the rooftop solar energy installation industry, including SolarCity.

SolarCity subsidiaries Sequoia Pacific Solar and Eiger Lease Co are challenging the federal government in court for imposing tougher guidelines in calculating the market value of solar-energy systems. The company's officials acknowledged in the IPO document the continuing need for government support, as alternative-energy companies strive to become competitive with coal, oil, and other conventional-energy sources.

SolarCity's financial performance has been a topic of discussion, with the company reporting a third-quarter profit after years of losses. Elon Musk, the company's chairman, has benefited immensely from government credits and funding through his various ventures, including Tesla Motors and SpaceX.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Adviser Richard Gates Pleads Guilty to Two Charges in Mueller Investigation

Former Trump campaign adviser Richard Gates has pleaded guilty to two charges brought against him by special counsel Robert Mueller's team in federal court in Washington, D.C. Gates pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy against the United States and one count of making a false statement to FBI agents investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election.

As part of the plea deal, Gates has agreed to cooperate fully, truthfully, completely, and forthrightly with the special counsel's office and other law enforcement officials. He is required to turn over relevant documents, attend meetings when requested, and testify when requested both before and after he is sentenced. In exchange, additional criminal charges will not be brought against him.

Gates' guilty plea comes as part of a deal with Mueller's team, which has accused him of lying to federal investigators about a March 2013 meeting involving former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort, an unnamed member of Congress, and an unnamed lobbyist discussing Ukraine. The meeting was reported by the Los Angeles Times to be with Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.).

Mueller's team filed the criminal information one day after unveiling a new superseding indictment charging Gates and Manafort with a slew of financial-related crimes stemming from their work for pro-Russian political forces in Ukraine over the past decade. The alleged crimes are unrelated to the work Manafort and Gates did for the Trump campaign.

Gates' guilty plea is expected to put pressure on Manafort to cooperate in Mueller's probe, which could provide key details about the Trump campaign's interactions with Russia. Manafort has denied any wrongdoing and has maintained his innocence.

In a statement, Manafort said he is innocent and will continue to defend himself against the charges. Gates, on the other hand, has expressed a desire to cooperate and has agreed to turn over relevant documents and testify when requested.

The development is the latest in a series of high-profile guilty pleas and indictments in Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Obama's Remarks on ISIS Strategy Spark Confusion and Criticism

Article:

President Barack Obama sent mixed signals on Wednesday about his strategy to combat the Islamic State (ISIS), also known as ISIL, during a press conference in Europe. Initially, he vowed to "degrade and destroy" the terrorist group, but later clarified that his goal is to make ISIS a "manageable problem" if an international coalition is formed.

The president's remarks sparked confusion and criticism from lawmakers on Capitol Hill, with some urging a tougher approach against the group. Representative Adam Kinzinger, R-Ill., questioned whether the administration is aiming to contain or crush ISIS, while Senator Saxby Chambliss, R-Ga., criticized the president's "mixed messages" on the issue.

The Obama administration has faced pressure to take swift action against ISIS, particularly after the group released a video showing the execution of American journalist Steven Sotloff, who was killed two weeks after journalist James Foley. The White House confirmed the authenticity of the video, which showed Sotloff being beheaded by a masked militant.

Obama condemned the execution as "horrific" and "barbaric," vowing that "justice will be served." He also emphasized that the U.S. will continue to fight the militant threat and the "barbaric and ultimately empty vision" it represents.

The president's remarks come as he is in Europe for meetings with allies, where the crisis in Ukraine and the fight against ISIS will be discussed. Secretary of State John Kerry is heading to the Middle East to build a stronger coalition to combat ISIS and support the Iraqi and Kurdish governments.

The Obama administration has stressed that addressing the problems in Iraq requires a new and inclusive government in Baghdad, but has not given a timeline for deciding on a strategy to target ISIS's operations in Syria.

Title: Democratic Party Elders Worry About Possibility of Bernie Sanders Leading the Ticket

The Democratic party establishment is facing a growing sense of unease as Bernie Sanders' popularity continues to surge, leaving many party leaders worried about the potential consequences of nominating a self-proclaimed socialist. This comes after a year in which the Republican establishment struggled to contain the rise of Donald Trump and Ted Cruz.

The media and party leaders underestimated the degree of anger and frustration among voters, leading to a surprise turn of events. Jeb Bush's failure to gain traction and Hillary Clinton's early-state strategy being questioned are a testament to the unpredictability of the 2016 election.

Both Bush and Clinton, like Trump and Cruz, were seen as safe choices expected to win their respective parties' nominations with the support of mega-donors. However, they are also seen as 20th-century figures trying to adapt to the new century. Sanders, on the other hand, has been a consistent advocate for progressive policies and has raised more money than expected.

Despite their differences, both Trump and Sanders have tapped into voter frustration and anger, running against the establishment. Sanders has even called out organizations like Planned Parenthood and the Human Rights Campaign, which support Hillary Clinton, as part of the establishment. Trump, who doesn't need to raise money, has forced his rivals to be more aggressive on issues like illegal immigration, while Sanders has pushed Clinton to the left on healthcare and taxes.

Liberal commentators have enjoyed the spectacle of a Republican civil war, but now it's the Democratic establishment that's worried about the possibility of a self-proclaimed socialist leading the ticket. Senator Claire McCaskill, a Hillary supporter, has expressed concerns about the potential consequences of Sanders' nomination.

The article notes that insurgent candidates often fade away, but 2016 is an unusual year. The rise of Trump, Cruz, and Sanders has exposed the weakness of the establishment and the media's myopia.

Title: US Budget Deal Expected to Result in Trillion-Dollar Deficits, Raising Concerns Among Republicans

The recent budget agreement reached by the US government is expected to lead to trillion-dollar deficits, according to Andy Roth, vice president of the conservative Club for Growth. Roth stated, "That sort of behavior, the last time I checked, is not in the Republican platform." The Treasury Department has projected borrowing $955 billion this fiscal year and over $1 trillion in both 2019 and 2020.

The increased borrowing is expected to make it more expensive for the government to borrow money, as the Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates and investors demand higher returns from an increasingly debt-laden government. This has contributed to recent volatility in financial markets, with investors concerned that the additional fiscal stimulus and a strengthening economy could fuel inflation and lead to higher interest rates sooner than anticipated.

Major stock indexes dropped sharply on Thursday, falling into a market correction, or a drop of more than 10% from their peak, largely due to comments from the Bank of England that it may raise interest rates sooner and higher to combat inflation. Investors turned to bonds as a safe-haven asset, pushing the yield on the 10-year Treasury bill to a four-year high of 2.88%.

The budget agreement has raised concerns among many Republicans, who have traditionally professed a commitment to limited government and deficit reduction. The party's stance on these issues helped Republicans regain control of the House and Senate during the Obama administration and contributed to President Trump's election victory, with the candidate promising to get federal spending under control.

In May, the Trump administration released a budget projecting the United States would swing from a deficit of $440 billion in 2018 to a surplus of $16 billion in 2027. The budget called for deep cuts to domestic programs and a significant increase in military spending.

Title: Putin's Foreign Policy Shaped by Experiences of Soviet Union's Collapse and Ukrainian Protests

Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to intervene in Syria's conflict has been framed as a fight against the Islamic State. However, his motivations go back to his experiences in the late 1980s, when the Soviet Union collapsed and protests swept through Russia and other Eastern European countries. As a young KGB officer, Putin was tasked with maintaining order in Dresden, Germany, and witnessed the fall of the Berlin Wall. This event, along with the subsequent collapse of the Soviet Union, had a profound impact on Putin's worldview.

Putin believes that the state's authority is the ultimate bulwark against chaos and must be protected, whether in Russia or beyond. He has spoken out against democracy, which he views as prone to mob rule and instability. In 2004, Putin was dealt a significant blow when massive protests in Ukraine overturned the alleged victory of his favored candidate, Viktor Yanukovych. This event led him to believe that revolution could be a model for plotting revolution inside Russia.

In 2011, Putin stepped down as president but continued to serve as prime minister alongside his protege, Dmitry Medvedev. When protests swept through the Arab World, Putin was critical of American and NATO intervention in Libya, while Medvedev voiced his sympathy. The public breach between the two leaders contributed to Putin's decision to return to the presidency.

In the years that followed, Putin pursued a foreign policy more hostile to the West, while tightening laws to stifle public protest at home. In 2013, protests erupted in Ukraine over efforts to move the country closer to the European Union. Putin emphasized the importance of maintaining order and respecting the law, stating that citizens have the right to express their opinions, but must do so within the law.

Putin's views on the importance of maintaining state authority and his skepticism of democracy have been shaped by his experiences in the Soviet Union's collapse and the Ukrainian protests. He believes that chaos can emerge when governments are toppled or threatened, as seen in Syria, where he sees Bashar al-Assad as the state. Putin has stated that the West's failure to support Assad against an unruly mob has led to the current crisis.

Title: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio Criticizes Donald Trump's Comments on Gun Violence

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has spoken out against Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump's recent comments on gun violence. During a campaign rally in Sioux Center, Iowa, Trump stated that his supporters would not abandon him even if he were to shoot someone in the middle of a crowded street. De Blasio, a Democrat, called Trump's comments "incredibly insensitive" and "not presidential" on ABC's "This Week."

De Blasio also expressed concerns about the concentration of power in the hands of billionaires, citing the potential entry of former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg into the presidential race as an independent candidate. "I don't think the people of this country want to give more power to billionaires at this point," de Blasio said. "I think that's what this election increasingly is about, how do we address income inequality, how do we restore the middle class?"

De Blasio reiterated his support for Hillary Clinton, stating that he believes she will be the next president of the United States. He also emphasized the need to address income inequality and restore the middle class, suggesting that most Americans do not believe billionaires are the solution to these issues.

Title: U.S. and Allies Accuse Russian Hackers of Targeting COVID-19 Vaccine Development

The U.S. security agencies, along with their British and Canadian partners, have issued an advisory accusing Russian hackers of targeting organizations involved in the development of the COVID-19 vaccine. The hackers, known as "APT29," "the Dukes," and "Cozy Bear," are believed to be part of the Russian government and have been targeting organizations in the U.S., Britain, and Canada with the intention of stealing intellectual property related to the vaccine's development.

The advisory did not name any specific organizations that were targeted, but it did indicate that the hackers have successfully exploited known computer vulnerabilities to gain initial footholds within some organizations involved in fighting COVID-19. The hackers used custom malware not publicly associated with any previous campaigns attributed to the group.

The U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee's ranking member, Sen. Mark Warner, stated that Russia's hacking efforts did not stop after the 2016 election and that the country's hacking efforts will require the U.S. and its allies to be prepared for increasingly aggressive cyber-attacks. Senate Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, California Republican, urged the administration to take action and introduced legislation to ensure the hackers are held responsible.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Adam B. Schiff, California Democrat, urged President Trump to take action and requested a briefing from his administration. White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany stated that the administration was aware of the activities included in the advisory and worked closely with allies to ensure COVID-19 vaccine research was protected.

British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab called the alleged hacking "completely unacceptable" and said it would hinder response efforts at a time when healthcare experts and medical researchers need every available resource. Canada's Communications Security Establishment, one of the agencies that issued the advisory, stated that the attacks would hinder response efforts and undermine the global effort to combat the pandemic.

Russia denied responsibility for the hacking, as it has with other major computer intrusions blamed on President Vladimir Putin's regime.

Title: Electoral College Set to Confirm Donald Trump as Next US President

The Electoral College is scheduled to convene on Monday to officially confirm Donald Trump as the next President of the United States. Despite efforts to disrupt the 227-year-old process, it appears that Trump is on track to secure the necessary 270 electoral votes. Electors will gather in state capitals across the country to make the results of the November 8 election official.

While the Electoral College vote is typically a formality, this year's election has seen unprecedented pressure on electors to defy the popular vote and choose a different candidate. This pressure has been fueled by Hillary Clinton's win in the popular vote, where she received roughly 2.6 million more ballots than Trump. However, Trump secured the necessary electoral votes by winning smaller, less-populated states in the Midwest and South, as well as the big coastal state of Florida and traditionally Democratic-leaning Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

Trump needs 270 electoral votes to win, and the state victories put him in line to secure 306 of the 538 electoral votes, with each state getting one vote for each House and Senate member. The three remaining votes go to the District of Columbia.

Reince Priebus, White House chief of staff in the incoming Trump administration, expressed confidence in the process, stating that "we expect everything to fall in line." Priebus noted that one elector in Texas has publicly stated they will vote against Trump, but this is not expected to impact the outcome.

Some electors have received thousands of emails and messages urging them to vote against Trump, but many have reported receiving similar messages in support of the president-elect. The Associated Press attempted to contact all 538 electors and spoke with over 330 of them, finding overwhelming support for the system and the nominee.

John Podesta, Clinton campaign chairman, suggested that 37 electoral voters bound to Trump could defect, which would create a tie and send the vote to the GOP-controlled House, where Trump would still likely win. However, this scenario is unlikely, and the Electoral College is expected to confirm Trump as the next President of the United States.

Title: Campaign Finance Reform Efforts Gain Traction at State and Local Levels

Campaign finance reform efforts are gaining momentum at the state and local levels, despite a lack of progress on the federal level. Since the Supreme Court's Citizens United v. FEC ruling, which opened the door to unlimited contributions to allies of presidential hopefuls, many politicians have been pushing for reforms to curb the flow of political money and disclose its sources.

According to the National Institute on Money in State Politics, more than 125 bills dealing with campaign finance reform have been introduced in 33 statehouses over the past five months. Cities are also taking action, with measures aimed at curbing political money or disclosing its sources being introduced and supported by members of both parties.

A major bipartisan win for reform advocates came in April when Montana's Democratic Governor Steve Bullock worked with the GOP-controlled Legislature to pass a bill requiring all groups, including 501(c)(4) nonprofits, to disclose their donors if they spend money on targeting or supporting a candidate within 60 days of an election.

Politicians on the state and local level point to polls that show overwhelming support for campaign finance reform. A recent New York Times/CBS poll found that 85% of those surveyed believe the system for funding political campaigns needs either "fundamental changes" or a complete overhaul. Republicans were almost as likely as Democrats to favor further restrictions on campaign contributions.

While the federal level has seen little progress on campaign finance reform, state and local efforts are gaining traction. In recent days, a bill requiring all groups to disclose their donors and expenditures proposed by the Philadelphia Board of Ethics advanced and could go into effect as early as July 1. In Texas, the state House passed a similar bill, but the state Senate and Governor Greg Abbott opposed including the measure in an ethics package.

FEC Chairwoman Ann Ravel has expressed frustration with the agency's inability to enforce campaign finance laws, stating that the likelihood of the laws being enforced is slim. In a highly unusual move, Ravel and another Democratic commissioner, Ellen Weintraub, filed a petition last week calling on their own agency to clamp down on political spending and demand disclosure.

Despite the gridlock at the federal level, state and local efforts are pushing forward, with many Republicans and Democrats supporting reforms aimed at providing the public with more disclosure. A new group, Take Back Our Republic, formed by John Pudner, is trying to bring more conservatives on board with reform efforts. Pudner said there is a lot more resistance from Republicans within the Beltway on the issue compared with the rest of the country.

Dale Eisman, spokesman for Common Cause, pointed to polls showing strong support for at least disclosure – if not other campaign finance reforms – to explain recent GOP support. "It's not surprising because every poll we see shows that the public is in strong support of disclosure," he said. "The people want this. Legislators – whether Republicans or Democrats – if they want to do what their constituents want, should support disclosure."

Title: Walmart to Discontinue Sales of Some Ammunition Following Recent Shootings

Walmart, the largest firearms seller in the US, has announced it will discontinue sales of certain types of ammunition, including those used in assault-style weapons and handguns, following recent mass shootings, including one at one of its stores in Texas that left 22 people dead. The company's decision comes amid increasing pressure and public scrutiny.

According to Walmart's CEO, Doug McMillon, the company has been "listening" to concerns and believes the status quo is "unacceptable." The company will also discontinue handgun sales in Alaska, the only state where it still offered such weapons. Additionally, Walmart is asking customers to refrain from openly carrying firearms in its stores, even in states where it is legally permitted, citing concerns about fear and evacuations.

The decision has received praise from celebrities and politicians, including several Democrats campaigning for president. However, the National Rifle Association (NRA) has criticized the move, calling it "shameful" and predicting the company will lose business.

Walmart's decision follows two incidents at its stores in August, in which a gunman killed 22 people in El Paso, Texas, and a former employee killed two workers at a Walmart store in Mississippi. The company's move is part of a broader trend among US retailers, with Kroger, another major retailer, announcing it will also stop allowing customers to openly carry firearms in its stores.

Walmart's decision is expected to reduce its share of the ammunition market from around 20% to a range of 6% to 9%, according to CEO Doug McMillon. The company will continue to sell hunting rifles and shotguns, as well as ammunition for those weapons.

Title: G-20 Summit Seating Arrangements: A Symbolic Move in U.S.-Russian Relations

The seating arrangements at the upcoming G-20 summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, have been rearranged to place five leaders between Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Barack Obama, a move seen as a deliberate attempt to avoid any perceived confrontation between the two leaders. The change is a departure from the original seating plan, which would have had the Russian and U.S. leaders seated only two chairs apart, with the Saudi king in between.

According to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, the seating plan has been rewritten to use the Latin alphabet instead of Cyrillic, ensuring that Putin and Obama are not seated near each other. This move is seen as a symbolic gesture, as it is often the quiet moves that reveal the true atmosphere of relations between heads of state.

The seating arrangement is not expected to lead to any lengthy discussions between the two leaders, with the two men expected to only briefly speak to each other before or after some of the general sessions. The U.S.-Russian relations have been strained in recent times, with the disagreement over Syria and the decision by Russia to grant temporary asylum to Edward Snowden, a former NSA contractor, being major points of contention.

Despite the tension, Obama has stated that he does not have a bad personal relationship with Putin and that their conversations are often candid, blunt, and constructive. The seating arrangement is just one aspect of the G-20 summit, which is set to begin on Thursday in St. Petersburg.

Title: Global Diplomacy Intensifies as Netanyahu Meets Putin Amid Concerns Over Syria

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, amidst growing concerns over the ongoing civil war in Syria. The meeting is expected to focus on the current situation in the Middle East, particularly in Syria, according to a Kremlin statement. The meeting comes as Russia is reportedly preparing to ship S-300 surface-to-air missiles to Syria, which could significantly impact the region's security dynamics.

The S-300 missiles, capable of defending against multiple aircraft and missiles, have raised concerns among Israel and the US, with Secretary of State John Kerry stating that the US would prefer Russia not to supply assistance to Syria. The introduction of these missiles could limit the future options not only for Israel but also for the US, should it decide to intervene in the conflict.

Despite the concerns, there is cautious optimism in some Western capitals over a planned international conference on Syria, organized by Moscow and Washington. British Prime Minister David Cameron, who is visiting the White House today, is reportedly set to tell President Barack Obama that he believes Russia is prepared to adopt a more flexible approach to Syria, based on his meeting with Putin in Sochi, Russia.

However, experts are skeptical about the progress, with Stephen Sestanovich, an expert in Russian and Eurasian studies, stating that the agreement on a peace conference "moves the Geneva formula one step further, but what is one step beyond complete meaninglessness?" Salman Shaikh, director of the Brookings Doha Center, also expressed doubts, saying that "the situation on the ground" will continue to shape events.

The Syrian opposition is set to meet on May 23 to determine whether it will attend the US-Russia peace conference, although the coalition remains split over the leadership of the group. The opposition is also divided over the leadership of the group, with two factions vying for control.

Title: Bipartisan Group of Senators Aims to Reach Immigration Deal by End of the Week

A bipartisan group of eight senators working on an immigration overhaul legislation is expected to have a draft bill agreeable to their circle by the end of this week. However, Sen. Marco Rubio, a member of the group, issued a statement saying it was too soon to consider the deal struck. Despite this, other senators involved in the negotiations remain optimistic about reaching an agreement.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, signaled on CNN's "State of the Union with Candy Crowley" that the deal will be reached within days. "It's got to be written up. We haven't signed off. There are a few details yet, but conceptual - we have an agreement between business and labor, between ourselves. It has to be drafted. It will be rolled out next week," he said.

Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-New York, concurred on the timeline but acknowledged a few issues remained to be settled. "As Sen. Rubio correctly says, we have said we will not come to a final agreement until we look at all of the legislative language, and he's correctly pointing out that that language hasn't been fully drafted. There will be little kerfuffles, but I don't think any of us expect there to be problems," he said on NBC's "Meet the Press."

Sen. Jeff Flake, R-Arizona, also sounded optimistic about reaching a deal, saying, "We've still got a ways to go with the language." Both Schumer and Rubio are seen as particularly important in this process, with Schumer the Democratic deal-maker who is bringing the sides together and Rubio key to bringing on board conservative members of both the House and Senate.

The agreement reached by labor and business groups on a guest worker program is a significant development, as it means neither side will fight the bill. The Gang of Eight aims to restructure the current system for allocating U.S. visas, prioritizing visas for business purposes over visas for family members, and preventing a future wave of illegal immigration once the path to citizenship is implemented for those currently undocumented and in the U.S.

With the consent of business and labor groups, Sen. Schumer said, "every major policy issue has been resolved on the Gang of Eight," meaning a deal would emerge this week, followed by "extensive markup and debate on the bill in April (in the Senate Judiciary Committee) and then we go to the floor, God willing, in May. I think we're on track."

Title: Trump's Presidency Poses Threats to Voting Rights

The election of Donald Trump as the next President of the United States has significant implications for voting rights in the country. With the potential to fill the vacant seat left by Justice Antonin Scalia and possibly replace another liberal justice, the Supreme Court's composition may shift towards a more conservative stance. This could lead to a decline in voting rights and an increase in voter suppression.

Dale Ho, director of the voting rights project at the American Civil Liberties Union, warns that while it's not yet time to give up hope, the situation is dire. The Fifth Circuit Court's decision to strike down a restrictive Texas voter-ID law in July suggests that moderate conservatives may be open to voting rights protections. However, the appointment of Trump's right-wing justices could lead to a reversal of this trend.

The current right-wing efforts to restrict voting rights, such as voter-ID and voter-registration restrictions, are already a concern. The Voting Rights Act has been weakened, and lawsuits challenging these restrictions have been filed. With Trump's presidency, these restrictions may be left in place or even expanded.

The second issue for voting rights advocates is the difficulty in expanding the franchise. Efforts to challenge partisan gerrymandering and felon disenfranchisement in lower courts may be harder to succeed with a more conservative Supreme Court. Existing restrictions on voting rights, such as voter-ID laws, have already had a significant impact on elections, with swing states like Wisconsin restricting the franchise in ways that may have contributed to Trump's Electoral College victory.

Trump's campaign and initial staffing decisions suggest a commitment to an agenda rooted in white-supremacist ideology, which has historically been centered on voter suppression. The appointment of Steve Bannon, a white nationalist, as Trump's chief White House strategist, and Kris Kobach, a vocal opponent of immigrant and voting rights, to his transition team, raises concerns about the direction of the Trump administration.

The article concludes that while it's not yet time to give up hope, the situation is dire, and the appointment of Trump's right-wing justices could lead to a decline in voting rights and an increase in voter suppression.

Title: President and First Lady Reflect on the Gift of the Holidays

The President and First Lady of the United States have released their annual Christmas Weekly Address, highlighting the importance of spending time with loved ones during the holiday season. The First Lady noted that celebrating the holidays in the White House over the past eight years has been a privilege, with the couple welcoming over half a million guests and baking 200,000 holiday cookies.

The White House holiday theme this year is "The Gift of the Holidays," which reflects some of the country's greatest gifts, including its military families and the life-changing impact of education. The President emphasized the importance of the values of compassion, hope, and service, citing the example of those who serve in the military and their families.

The President and First Lady also highlighted the progress made during their time in office, including reducing unemployment to a nine-year low, securing health insurance for 20 million Americans, and making the country more respected around the world. They encouraged Americans to recommit themselves to the values they share and to support those who serve the country.

The First Lady emphasized the importance of treating others as one would want to be treated, citing the biblical message of treating others with compassion and kindness. The President and First Lady also encouraged Americans to support military families and to visit the JoiningForces.gov website to learn more about how to honor and support service members, veterans, and military families in their communities.

The President and First Lady concluded their address by wishing Americans a happy and healthy 2017 and expressing their gratitude to the American people.

Title: Americans' Record Low Confidence in Government: A Growing Concern

Article:

According to recent polling data from Gallup and other organizations, Americans have reached record or near-record low rates of confidence in government. This trend is reflected in various institutions, with only 39% of Americans approving of President Donald Trump's performance, 25 points off the historical average. Similarly, only 36% have a lot of faith in public schools, while 25% trust the criminal justice system, and 12% have a "great deal" or "quite a lot" of confidence in Congress.

This decline in trust is a concern, as it may lead to a self-defeating spiral where people demand more government intervention despite lacking confidence in its effectiveness. Research suggests that people in countries with poor governance often desire more government involvement, even if they don't trust it to be fair or effective. In contrast, high-trust regions like Scandinavia and North America tend to be more trusting of market forces.

The solution to this issue doesn't have to be nihilism or anarchy. Instead, the government can focus on doing fewer things but doing them better. With government spending already at 21% of GDP and predicted to climb to 30% over the next three decades, it's essential to prioritize limited government and fight against cronyism, drug prohibition, and regulatory overreach that increases the cost of doing business. Additionally, defense spending on elective wars and national security measures that don't make us safer should be reevaluated.

However, it's also important to recognize that government action can be legitimate and effective. Policies like school choice, for instance, can deliver better results at cheaper costs. If we can increase trust in government, it may be easier to shrink the size, scope, and spending of the state.

Title: Steven Mnuchin's Hearing Concludes After Five Hours of Testimony

Steven Mnuchin, the nominee for Treasury Secretary, concluded his hearing after five hours of testimony, facing tough questions from Democrats on his business background, investment holdings, and financial disclosures. Compared to his previous television interviews, Mnuchin was more restrained on policy issues, attempting to smooth out some of the more controversial statements made by President-elect Donald Trump.

Mnuchin adopted moderate positions on several policy issues, including the need to quickly raise the debt limit when its current suspension expires in March and boosting staffing at the Internal Revenue Service. He also expressed support for keeping the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, but preferred altering its funding mechanism, a change that some Democrats have worried could lead to the agency being constrained.

On the Volcker Rule, Mnuchin said he supported its aim but outlined changes that its backers have said would weaken it. Although he appeared to walk back past support for privatizing mortgage companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, he stated that the companies remain critical to the mortgage market and have played valuable roles in the past.

Democrats attempted to land blows on Mnuchin over disclosures he did not make to the committee until committee staffers pointed out the oversights, which Mnuchin attributed to paperwork errors. They also sought to grill him over potential conflicts of interest that could arise due to President-elect Trump's failure to place his extensive real-estate holdings in a blind trust.

Republicans did not seem concerned about these issues, with the exception of Nevada Sen. Dean Heller, who took issue with Mnuchin's lack of response to earlier questions about his foreclosure record at OneWest Bank in his home state.

Title: Senate Republicans Revise Healthcare Repeal Bill, Eyeing Vote This Week

Article:

Senate Republicans have revised their latest healthcare repeal bill, the Graham-Cassidy plan, in an effort to win over more support from their colleagues. The revised bill would allow states to set higher premiums based on a person's health status, but not on the basis of sex or genetic information. State officials would also be required to describe how they would maintain access to affordable health insurance coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions when applying for federal grants.

The changes may come too late, as some conservatives are concerned that the bill has not been properly vetted. The Congressional Budget Office is set to release a partial analysis of the bill's impact as soon as Monday, but it may not include the latest revisions.

President Trump has expressed optimism about the bill's chances, saying "eventually, we will win on that" when asked about repealing the Affordable Care Act. However, the bill's architects, Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy, are not giving up. "We're moving forward, and we'll see what happens next week," Senator Graham said on ABC's "This Week." "I'm very excited about it. We finally found an alternative to Obamacare that makes sense."

A Senate vote on the bill is planned for this week, according to White House Director of Legislative Affairs Marc Short, although a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell declined to confirm the timeline. The Graham-Cassidy bill would repeal the expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act and the tax credits provided to help people buy insurance on the individual market, replacing them with block grants to states to use for healthcare.

Title: Senate on Track to Approve Three Obama Nominations This Week

The United States Senate is poised to confirm three more of President Barack Obama's nominees this week, according to Majority Leader Harry Reid. Reid aims to approve Fred Hochberg to head the Export-Import Bank, Gina McCarthy to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, and Tom Perez to lead the Labor Department by the close of business on Thursday. A leadership aide stated that Hochberg is likely to be confirmed on Wednesday, with final approval for McCarthy and Perez potentially coming as early as Thursday, depending on the amount of time Republicans wish to debate the nominations.

This development follows the approval of Richard Cordray to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Tuesday. The agreements to vote on these nominees, as well as three candidates to join the National Labor Relations Board, are the result of a deal between Reid and Republicans reached on Tuesday. The deal averted an unprecedented Senate rules change, which Reid had threatened to implement in the face of Republican filibusters.

Under the agreement, the Senate will fill the NLRB and allow Hochberg, McCarthy, Perez, and Cordray to move forward without altering the Senate rules. Reid hopes this agreement will lay the groundwork for more cooperation in the Senate. "We have now started a new era, I hope a new normal in the Senate where senators talk to each other rather than past each other," Reid said on Wednesday.

Title: Democrats' Leadership Role Under Scrutiny After Georgia Special Election Loss

The recent special election loss in Georgia has sparked discussions among Democrats about the leadership role of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. President Trump has weighed in on the matter, tweeting that it would be "very bad" for the Republican Party if Pelosi were forced out, and adding a jab at Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer. Pelosi responded by calling Trump's statement a "typical Republican line" and suggesting that he was likely influenced by his party members.

Pelosi has defended her position, citing her experience as a "master legislator" and "politically astute leader." She emphasized that her decision to stay in her role is not up to her fellow Democrats. Some congressional Democrats, however, have expressed frustration with the party's leadership and have called for change.

Reps. Kathleen Rice of New York and Seth Moulton of Massachusetts have publicly stated that it's time for a leadership change, with Rice specifically saying that Pelosi should step down. Rep. Filemon Vela of Texas went further, stating that Pelosi is "not the only reason" Ossoff lost the election, but "she certainly is one of the reasons." The head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Rep. Ben Ray Luján, remains optimistic about the party's chances of winning enough seats to take control of the House in 2018.

The debate highlights the ongoing discussions within the Democratic Party about its leadership and strategy heading into the midterm elections.

Title: The New Year's Challenge: Restoring the Nation's Founding Principles

The new year brings an opportunity for reflection and gratitude, especially for those who cherish their country. As the United States approaches a critical juncture, it is essential to acknowledge the importance of recognizing what has been learned and what needs to be reversed. The article highlights the resilience of the American people and the strength of the Founding Fathers' foundation for the nation.

The author emphasizes the importance of staying focused, disciplined, and remembering that this is a fight for the nation, not just one person. The article also notes that the new year will be challenging, with President Obama having only 12 more months to complete his term. However, the author believes that the real challenge lies in the defense of the nation, not just the election of a new president.

The article also touches on the current state of the nation, citing various issues such as the catastrophic state of the health insurance and healthcare system, open borders, Islamic State plots, urban riots against the police, and historically high numbers of Americans on food stamps. The author attributes these problems to the establishment and the politicians who have facilitated them.

The article concludes by highlighting the growing rebellion against the establishment, citing comments from Republican operatives Rick Wilson and Pat Brady, who believe that the donor class will have to "put a bullet in Donald Trump" or "rip his head off" if he becomes the Republican nominee. The author believes that the establishment is melting down over this rebellion and that the real challenge is not the election of a new president, but the restoration of the nation's founding principles.

Overall, the article presents a critical assessment of the current state of the nation and the need for a restoration of the founding principles.

Title: Small Businesses Face Uncertain Future Amidst Economic Crisis

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic is having a devastating impact on the US economy, with small businesses being hit particularly hard. These businesses, which account for over 99% of all businesses in the country and nearly 50% of all employment, are struggling to stay afloat as people practice social distancing and avoid non-essential activities. A recent $2 trillion economic relief package has passed the Senate and is moving to the House, which includes a $367 billion loan program to help small businesses weather the storm. However, experts argue that more needs to be done to support these businesses, particularly in terms of bankruptcy policies.

The US bankruptcy system allows entrepreneurs to wipe out debts and start anew, but the process is not without its challenges. The Federal Bankruptcy Code of 1978 sets exemption levels for assets, which vary widely across states and over time. For example, in seven states and territories, homestead exemptions are unlimited, while in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, they are zero. Research shows that lower exemptions lead to smaller business start-up rates, as the threat of losing homes and property at the time of bankruptcy creates a deterrent.

The Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act (BAPCPA) of 2005 aimed to make it harder for individuals to file for Chapter 7 bankruptcy, but experts argue that it has had an unintended negative impact on small businesses. The act introduced a means test for Chapter 7, which prevents individuals earning above-average income from wiping out their debt, and lowered exemptions for certain assets. This has led to a 50% reduction in Chapter 7 filings and a 25% increase in insolvency, resulting in worse outcomes for financially distressed borrowers.

In light of the current economic crisis, experts suggest that easing the path to Chapter 7 bankruptcy could provide small businesses with a fresh start when the crisis is over. This could involve removing means-tested filing for a temporary period, allowing more individuals and small businesses to file and claim unlimited homestead and personal property exemptions for a temporary period, and easing the costs associated with a Chapter 7 filing.

Aparna Mathur, a Resident Scholar in Economic Policy Studies at the American Enterprise Institute, argues that allowing small businesses to have an easier path to Chapter 7 bankruptcy could provide them with a fresh start when the crisis is over. She suggests that easing the path to bankruptcy could involve removing means-tested filing for a temporary period, allowing more individuals and small businesses to file and claim unlimited homestead and personal property exemptions for a temporary period, and easing the costs associated with a Chapter 7 filing.

Title: US and North Korea Hold Talks to Prepare Possible Meeting between Trump and Kim

The United States and North Korea are holding talks in the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas to prepare a possible meeting between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. The talks, led by Sung Kim, a former ambassador to South Korea, aim to set an agenda for the summit between the leaders.

The meeting was initially called off by President Trump on Thursday due to what he described as "hostility" from North Korea. However, both sides have since been working to get the summit back on track. On Saturday, Kim Jong-un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in held an unannounced meeting, during which Kim reiterated his commitment to the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. Kim later expressed his "fixed will" that the summit should go ahead, and President Trump tweeted that it would help North Korea achieve its "brilliant potential."

The talks are a significant development, as they indicate that the summit could still take place. However, there is still much work to be done, and analysts note that the relationship between the two leaders can change quickly. The US has demanded that North Korea denuclearize first, followed by rewards in the form of lifted sanctions and economic aid. North Korea, on the other hand, wants a phased approach, with its steps met by reciprocal ones from the US and South Korea, including the easing of sanctions and the US military presence in South Korea.

North Korea has been subject to numerous international sanctions since 2006, which have cut off most of its exports and capped its imports of oil. The country also wants assurances that its survival as a state would never be in question. Despite the challenges, the rapprochement between the two countries has been a surprise, given North Korea's strident rhetoric and continued nuclear and missile tests in 2016 and 2017. However, a turning point came in January when Kim Jong-un suggested he was "open to dialogue" with South Korea, leading to a series of diplomatic developments, including the suspension of nuclear tests and a landmark summit between Kim and South Korean President Moon Jae-in last month.

Title: Clinton's Challenge: Mobilizing Left-of-Center Voters Beyond Sanders' Supporters

Article:

The Democratic Party is concerned about Hillary Clinton's ability to win over Bernie Sanders' supporters in the general election. However, history suggests this is not a significant issue. Candidates typically fight hard until they stop fighting, and when Sanders does stop fighting, he will have incentives to support Clinton and mobilize Democrats to vote.

The real challenge for Clinton lies in mobilizing not just Sanders' supporters but the larger universe of people with left-of-center views who did not participate in the primaries. In 2008, Barack Obama won the presidency with 69.5 million votes, more than double the combined total of primary votes. In contrast, the Clinton-Sanders race has seen around 23 million votes, with California and New Jersey yet to vote.

To win, Clinton needs to mobilize not just Sanders' supporters but the much larger pool of people with left-of-center views who did not participate in the primaries. This includes younger voters, who are less attached to the political process and more likely to stay home from the polls. Obama's narrow reelection in 2012 was driven by his ability to get these voters to participate, and Clinton faces a similar challenge.

Clinton's weakness with young voters was evident in both the 2008 and 2016 primaries, and she needs to reach a lot of young people who have not been stirred to vote for Sanders. This will be a harder challenge than simply reaching Sanders' supporters.

Democrats hope that fear of Donald Trump will drive turnout among minority groups and young people, but it is unclear if this negative focus is a successful voter turnout strategy. Voting is not a rational decision, and people vote for emotional reasons, such as a sense of community and participation. Clinton's low approval ratings, fewer votes than eight years ago, and weak performance with young women suggest she is struggling to inspire voters.

The best news for Clinton is that Trump is viewed unfavorably by the public and will face his own challenges in securing Republican turnout. However, the dynamics of a race to the bottom in terms of voter enthusiasm are not favorable to Democrats, as seen in the past two midterm elections.

Title: Workplace Discrimination Against Political Views: A Growing Concern in the United States

The United States is facing an epidemic of workplace discrimination, not against traditional protected categories such as race, sex, or gender identity, but against individuals with political views deemed "distasteful" by a growing and influential group. This phenomenon, often referred to as "cancel culture," has created a culture of fear and repression, where individuals are reluctant to express their opinions or engage in public discourse.

The Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not protect individuals from discrimination based on their political beliefs, leaving them without legal recourse when faced with employment discrimination. Employers are often pressured by the "woke mob" to fire or pass over employees with opposing views, making it a cost-free decision. This lack of legal protection has created a power imbalance, where victims are defenseless against discrimination.

The article argues that the Civil Rights Act should be amended to include a new category of protected characteristics: "viewpoints or beliefs." This would provide legal recourse for individuals facing discrimination based on their political views. Currently, four states and the District of Columbia have some form of viewpoint-discrimination protections, but 46 states do not.

The author, Michael Schwartz, a lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, believes that this issue transcends political ideologies and should be addressed to protect the fundamental right to free speech. The article concludes that amending the Civil Rights Act to include viewpoint protection would be a crucial step in combating the cancel culture and promoting a culture of open discussion and debate.

Title: Boston Bombing Sought to Instill Fear, Inflict Trauma, Says Israeli Ambassador

The recent bombing at the Boston Marathon was a deliberate attempt to instill fear and inflict trauma, according to Israeli Ambassador to the US Michael Oren. The attack, which occurred on a day celebrating liberty, aimed to force the victims to forfeit their freedom. However, Oren emphasized that the people of Boston and other communities threatened by terrorism refuse to submit to such tactics.

Oren, speaking on behalf of both Americans and Israelis, noted that both nations understand the pain caused by terrorism. He urged people to remember the victims and refuse to be victimized by terrorism. The ambassador highlighted the importance of defending freedoms, which are upheld in open societies like the US and Israel.

The bombing in Boston serves as a reminder of the worst and best in humanity. While it destroyed and altered the lives of hundreds, it also brought out heroic acts of selflessness and resilience. Oren emphasized that the people of Boston will heal, but they will not forget the lessons learned from the attack.

The Israeli ambassador acknowledged the complex challenges faced by American security forces and policymakers in preventing and responding to terrorist attacks. He encouraged continued vigilance and resolve in defending democratic liberties. Ultimately, Oren concluded that the attack in Boston serves as a reminder of the importance of standing together and refusing to be victimized by terrorism.

Title: Mexico's President Criticizes Trump's Tariff Plan, Urges Diplomacy to Address Migrant Crisis

The President of Mexico, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, has expressed his opposition to US President Donald Trump's plan to impose tariffs on Mexican goods to pressure the country to stem the flow of Central American migrants. In a public letter, López Obrador called Trump's "America First" approach a "fallacy" and emphasized the need for diplomacy and cooperation to address the migrant crisis.

Trump had announced on Thursday that the US would impose a 5% tariff on all goods coming into the country from Mexico, effective June 10, unless the country takes steps to stem the flow of migrants. The tariff would escalate by 5 percentage points each month until the "Illegal Immigration problem is remedied," at which point it would be removed.

López Obrador responded by saying that Mexico is already taking steps to address the migration issue and that "social problems are not solved with duties or coercive measures." He also emphasized the importance of cooperation and diplomacy, stating that "justice and universal fraternity will prevail" beyond national borders.

Trump defended his proposal in a series of tweets, blaming Mexico and congressional Democrats for the migrant crisis and claiming that Mexico makes a "FORTUNE" from the US. He also claimed that companies would leave Mexico to avoid the tariffs, but that it shouldn't come to that.

The US Border Patrol has apprehended over 280,000 migrants entering the country illegally in the first seven months of the 2019 fiscal year, with the majority coming from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. Only 3% of those apprehended are from Mexico.

López Obrador has sent his foreign minister to Washington, D.C. to negotiate with US officials ahead of the June 10 deadline. The Mexican President has emphasized the need for a comprehensive solution to the migrant crisis, citing the US' history as a nation of immigrants and the importance of the Statue of Liberty as a symbol of freedom and opportunity.

Title: President Trump Reveals Winners of "Fake News" Awards, Citing Negative Coverage and Biased Reporting

President Donald Trump revealed the winners of his self-proclaimed "Fake News" awards on Twitter, with The New York Times topping the list. The list, published on GOP.com, highlighted several instances of what Trump considers to be biased and inaccurate reporting. According to the list, studies have shown that over 90% of the media's coverage of Trump is negative.

The winners include The New York Times' Paul Krugman, who predicted that the stock market would never recover from Trump's election, as well as ABC News' Brian Ross, who reported that Trump advised former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn to make contact with Russian officials during the 2016 campaign. CNN also made the list four times, with false reports about Trump having early access to hacked documents from WikiLeaks, a video suggesting Trump overfed fish during a visit with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and a report that former FBI Director James Comey would deny saying Trump was told he was not under investigation.

The list also included a false report by The New York Times that the Trump administration hid a report on climate change. Newsweek was also included for a tweet that claimed Trump removed a bust of Martin Luther King Jr. from the Oval Office, as well as a report that Polish First Lady Agata Kornhauser-Duda did not shake Trump's hand.
