The Office of Special Counsel wrote to President Obama in September about continued problems at the Phoenix VA Medical Center, including the lack of training for emergency room nurses and substandard care at other facilities.

Despite these challenges, the VA has proposed disciplinary action against 27 employees and one senior executive for manipulating scheduling, although only three have been fired. The agency has also faced criticism for its handling of employee whistleblowers, with some facing retaliation for reporting wrongdoing.

Funding for the VA has increased 73% since 2009, but examples of waste and mismanagement persist, including a $1 billion overrun on a hospital construction project in Denver and an investigation revealing a VA executive received almost $300,000 in relocation expenses.

Title: Public Opinion Divided on Supreme Court's Constitutional Interpretation

A recent survey has shed light on the deep-seated divisions in the United States over how the Supreme Court should interpret the Constitution. The survey, conducted in October, found that about half of the public (46%) believes the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's original meaning, while an identical share thinks it should base its decisions on what the Constitution means in current times.

The survey also revealed significant differences in opinions based on political affiliation, age, race, ethnicity, education, and religious affiliation. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents were more likely to believe the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's original meaning, with 74% expressing this view. In contrast, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents were more likely to believe the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's current meaning, with 23% expressing this view.

The survey also found that younger adults (63% to 31%) were more likely to believe the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's current meaning, while those aged 30-49 were more divided (44% original meaning, 45% current meaning). Adults aged 50 and older were more likely to believe the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's original meaning (54%).

The survey also highlighted differences based on race and ethnicity, with Blacks more likely to believe the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's current meaning (63%) compared to whites (41%). Adults with at least a college degree, particularly those with postgraduate degrees, were more likely to express this view.

Finally, the survey found that white evangelical Protestants overwhelmingly believed the court should base its decisions on its understanding of the Constitution's original meaning (79%), while the religiously unaffiliated were more likely to believe the court's decisions should be based on the Constitution's current meaning (64%).

**Trump's Transition and Presidency: Americans' Mixed Views**

A new CNN/ORC poll has shed light on Americans' opinions about President-elect Donald Trump's transition and presidency. Two weeks after Election Day, most Americans believe Trump will do a good job as president, with 53% saying he will do a very or fairly good job. However, fewer approve of his handling of the transition, with 46% expressing approval and 45% disapproval.

The poll also found that majorities think Trump will achieve several of his campaign promises, including repealing and replacing Obamacare, renegotiating NAFTA, and creating good-paying jobs in economically challenged areas. However, opinions are more divided on other issues, such as "draining the swamp" and reducing corruption in Washington, defeating ISIS, and building a wall along the US-Mexico border.

The poll suggests that Trump's presidency will bring change to the country, with 66% saying so. However, only 43% believe this change will be for the better, a 20-point drop from the 63% who thought Barack Obama's presidency would bring change for the better in 2008.

Trump's favorability has risen to 47%, with 50% viewing him unfavorably. His transition has received mixed reviews, with 46% approving and 45% disapproving.

The poll also highlights demographic divides, with women, non-whites, and urban residents expressing less confidence in Trump's abilities than men, whites, and rural residents. The share of Americans who think things are going well in the country has dipped, with 47% saying so, down from 54% in late October.

Overall, the poll suggests that Trump's presidency will be marked by a polarized public opinion, with many Americans having strong feelings about his abilities and policies.

Title: Trump Defends Criticism of Clinton's Campaign, Dismisses Foreign Policy Concerns

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump defended his criticism that Hillary Clinton's campaign success is largely due to her being a female candidate, stating that "the only card she has is the woman's card." Trump made these comments on Sunday, following his sweep in five Northeast primary contests. He also dismissed concerns about his foreign policy stance, saying that the United States needs to focus on domestic spending and scale back its involvement in the Middle East.

In his foreign policy speech last week, Trump suggested that the United States should reduce its military presence in the Middle East and focus on domestic spending. He argued that every move the US has made in the region has been wrong and that other countries should pay more to protect the world. Trump also stated that more taxpayer money should go towards U.S. infrastructure.

Trump's comments were met with criticism from his GOP primary rival, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who called his policy speech "weak and naive." Trump, however, argued that his attacks on Clinton are no worse than those of her primary challenger, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who has questioned Clinton's qualifications.

While Trump's favorability ratings among women are low, he believes that his numbers will improve if and when he faces Clinton in the general election. "Once I start on Hillary, the numbers will change," he said. "Watch what happens with Hillary. Watch what happens with her numbers."

Title: House Democrats Introduce Resolution to Block Trump's National Emergency Declaration

House Democrats have introduced a resolution to block President Trump's declaration of a national emergency along the U.S.-Mexico border, setting the stage for a potential fight that could lead to the president's first veto. The resolution, introduced by Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), has gained overwhelming support from fellow majority Democrats in the House, with 222 cosponsors as of Friday morning.

The resolution aims to terminate Trump's emergency proclamation, which was declared last Friday in connection with the signing of a government spending package that included $1.4 billion for border barrier construction. Trump aims to use the emergency declaration and other tools to free up billions more for border security, but Democrats argue that the move is an overreach of executive power.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) called Trump's decision "dishonoring the office in which he serves," while Rep. Castro dubbed it the "FakeTrumpEmergency." The level of support for the resolution ensures it will likely pass the House, but its fate in the Republican-controlled Senate is uncertain.

Several Republican senators, including Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine), have expressed concerns about the declaration, raising the possibility that the measure could clear the chamber. If it does, it would expose a fracture in the party and likely prompt Trump to issue his first veto.

The resolution is a response to Trump's decision to declare an emergency, which he claims is necessary to protect the country from illegal immigration, crime, and drugs. Trump has highlighted construction already underway and pledged to press forward with more, but Democrats argue that the move is an unconstitutional overreach of executive power.

The brief resolution filed Friday simply states that Trump's emergency proclamation "is hereby terminated." A staff aide introduced the measure during a short pro forma session of the House, and Pelosi has promised that the House will "move swiftly" to pass the measure, predicting it will be referred to the Senate and then sent to the president's desk.

Title: Former US President Barack Obama Endorses Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for Re-election

Former US President Barack Obama has endorsed Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for re-election, stating that Trudeau is a "hard-working, effective leader who takes on big issues like climate change." Obama's endorsement comes as Trudeau faces criticism over recent revelations that he wore blackface at least three times as a younger man.

Trudeau is seeking to remain prime minister after next week's elections, but his campaign was rocked by the release of photos and videos showing him with his face painted black or brown for various costumes. Trudeau apologized for his actions, but could not confirm whether they were the only instances of him engaging in such behavior.

Obama and Trudeau have been friends since Trudeau was elected in 2015, and their friendship has continued even after Obama left office in 2017. Obama's endorsement of Trudeau highlights a contrast with his handling of the US presidential primary, in which he has not publicly endorsed any candidate.

Some Canadians have expressed discomfort with Obama's endorsement, citing concerns about foreign election interference. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Obama's endorsement has influenced the election in any way. Elections Canada has stated that any expenses incurred as a result of the endorsement would need to be disclosed and would be subject to review.

Obama has endorsed foreign leaders in the past, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel. His endorsement of Trudeau is seen as a nod to the Canadian leader's progressive policies and his commitment to addressing global issues like climate change.

Title: Senate Approves Amended Immigration Framework, Heads to House for Consideration

The United States Senate has officially approved the amended "Gang of Eight" immigration framework, with a vote of 68-32 in favor. The bill will now move to the House of Representatives for consideration. The rare scene saw Senators voting one by one, with Vice President Biden presiding over the chamber. Before the result was announced, Biden admonished the gallery against overt expressions of approval or disapproval.

The bill's supporters had expressed confidence that they would hit the 70-vote threshold, which they viewed as symbolically significant. However, the final vote fell short of that mark. The legislation needed 51 votes to pass, and it significantly outperformed that minimum. Fourteen members of the GOP conference crossed the aisle to join Democratic support, while every "no" vote was cast by a Republican.

The bill's supporters included Senators Marco Rubio and Jeff Sessions, who delivered dueling closing floor arguments advocating and opposing passage, respectively. The discussion now shifts to the House of Representatives, where Speaker John Boehner has already vowed to ignore the Senate-passed bill. Marco Rubio has signaled support for the creation and passage of a distinct House bill.

The Republican senators who voted in favor of the bill were: Alexander (TN), Ayotte (NH), Chiesa (NJ), Collins (ME), Corker (TN), Flake (AZ), Graham (SC), Hatch (UT), Heller (NV), Hoeven (ND), Kirk (IL), McCain (AZ), Rubio (FL), and Murkowski (AK).

Title: Congress Approves Tax Breaks for Various Industries, Including Hollywood and Puerto Rico Rum Producers

The recently passed fiscal crisis package, aimed at sparing the middle class from tax hikes, has been criticized for containing a host of special-interest favors. The package, worth approximately $76 billion, extends over 50 temporary tax breaks for various industries, including Hollywood, Puerto Rico rum producers, and the alternative energy industry.

Lawmakers, including those who approved the package, are now expressing disappointment and frustration with the inclusion of these tax breaks. Senator John McCain, R-Ariz., described the move as "larding up must-pass emergency legislation with giveaways to special interests and campaign contributors." Senator Bob Corker, R-Tenn., who voted in favor of the bill, called it a "terrible vote to have to take" and emphasized the need for tax reform to eliminate loopholes.

The tax breaks, which were already in the law, were extended for another year by Tuesday's vote. These breaks, worth billions of dollars, include:

* A rule allowing TV and film producers to write off the first $15 million in production costs inside the U.S., valued at $248 million.
* A provision allowing motorsport race tracks to more quickly write off improvement costs, valued at $78 million.
* A 50% tax credit for expenses related to railroad track maintenance through 2013, worth $331 million.
* Increased tax rebates to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands from a tax on rum imported into the United States, worth $222 million.
* A tax credit of up to $2,500 for buying electric-powered vehicles, expanded to include electric-powered motorcycles, at a cost of $7 million.
* A tax credit for the production of wind, solar, and other renewable energy, at a cost of $12.2 billion.

While each industry defends their tax treatment as vital, Senator McCain expressed concern that the inclusion of these tax breaks in the package feeds "cynicism" among the American people. He stated that the tax breaks were "crammed into the bill literally in the middle of the night" and that the American people deserve better.

Title: Trump Says Memo Vindicates Him in Russia Probe, But Democrats Dispute Its Findings

The White House released a previously classified memo on Friday, alleging abuse by the FBI and Department of Justice in the Russia investigation. President Donald Trump tweeted that the memo "totally vindicates" him, stating that there was no collusion and no obstruction. However, Democrats have disputed the memo's findings, calling it "deeply misleading and factually inaccurate."

The memo, released by House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes, alleges that officials at the FBI and DOJ used bias against Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, leading to the appointment of special counsel Robert Mueller to investigate charges of collusion between Trump's aides and Russian officials. Trump approved the memo's release and called its revelations a "disgrace," saying that "a lot of people should be ashamed of themselves."

Reaction among lawmakers was swift. Rep. Pete King, a member of the House Intelligence Committee, called for public hearings about the FBI and Justice Department actions that led to FISA warrants allowing the surveillance of former Trump adviser Carter Page. However, Sen. John McCain of Arizona blasted the memo's release, saying it served "no American interests" to make the information public.

Democrats were largely united in their condemnation of the memo, with House Intelligence Committee Vice Chairman Adam Schiff calling it "deeply misleading and factually inaccurate." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi also criticized the memo, calling it a "desperate attempt to distract the American people from the truth about the Trump-Russia scandal."

Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee are pushing to release their own memo, which they say provides "vital context" missing from the Nunes memo. Trump said he would be inclined to allow a Democratic rebuttal if it passes a "security and legal review."

Jerrold Nadler, the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, said Trump's decision to release the memo was "part of a coordinated propaganda effort to discredit, disable, and defeat the Russia investigation." On Saturday, Nadler circulated a memo to House Democrats disputing the conclusions of the Nunes memo and arguing that Page was a lawful target of surveillance.

The memo's release has sparked a heated debate, with both sides accusing the other of political gamesmanship. The controversy is likely to continue as the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and potential collusion with Trump's campaign continues.

Title: Government Shutdown Continues as Talks Remain Unlikely

The federal government has shut down for the first time in 17 years, with no clear indication of when it will reopen. The impasse is due to a disagreement between the House and Senate over funding and the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The House passed a bill that would continue government funding, but the Senate rejected it, citing concerns over Republican attempts to tie funding to changes to the healthcare law.

Senate Democrats, led by Majority Leader Harry Reid, have refused to negotiate with the House until they pass a "clean" spending bill, free from any provisions related to Obamacare. Reid stated that the Senate will not "re-litigate" the healthcare issue, which has been a contentious topic in the past.

The House Speaker, John Boehner, has not provided a clear path forward, stating that the government has "big problems" and that a solution will require an amicable agreement. The shutdown is expected to last at least a week, according to Stan Collender, a former Capitol Hill aide.

The shutdown has created uncertainty and has sparked concerns about its impact on the economy and the public. Some Republicans have expressed doubts about the House GOP strategy, with Reps. Peter King, Charlie Dent, and John McCain questioning the approach. Democrats, on the other hand, appear to have a unified front, with President Barack Obama supporting their stance.

A recent Quinnipiac poll found that 72% of Americans oppose a government shutdown over Obamacare, while 22% support it. The shutdown has also highlighted the challenges Republicans face in blaming Democrats for the shutdown, given their decades-long anti-government rhetoric.

As the impasse continues, it remains unclear when the government will reopen, but one thing is certain: the shutdown will have significant consequences for the country and its citizens.

Title: Biden's Lead Tested as Democratic Primary Enters New Phase

As the summer comes to a close, the 2020 Democratic presidential primary is shifting into high gear, with former Vice President Joe Biden's position at the top of the pack facing increased scrutiny. Biden, 76, has consistently maintained a comfortable lead, but his campaign has been plagued by doubts over his age, fitness for office, and whether he can be a standard-bearer for a party that has grown increasingly liberal.

The next few weeks will likely magnify these questions as Labor Day serves as the traditional marker for the White House race to intensify, with five months to go until the first nominating contest in Iowa. Democrats are lacking a true consensus candidate, one who can unite a party fractured along ideological and generational lines.

While Biden enjoys widespread name recognition due to his eight years as Barack Obama's vice president and a long Senate career before that, he stands to suffer as voters begin to focus on other candidates, according to strategists. This may open the door wider for his closest competitors, U.S. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, or another rival, to seize momentum.

The Democratic field has shrunk slightly in the past month, with U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand dropping out last week. However, 20 contenders continue to vie for the nomination. Ten Democrats will square off on September 12 at a debate in Houston.

Democratic strategist Delacey Skinner said, "Most people don't even know who most of the candidates are." Jeff Link, a longtime Democratic strategist in Iowa, likened the primary-season campaign to an American football game and said Labor Day marks the start of the second half. "The only thing that matters is the fourth quarter," Link said.

Biden has weathered fierce attacks from his rivals and his own penchant for misstatements to remain in front. Yet his string of gaffes and episodes of faulty memory have sparked concern over his age and his capacity to battle President Donald Trump next year if he is the party's nominee.

Beyond Biden, the story of the contest's first few months was the rise of Warren, whose relentless campaign schedule and formidable state-level organization have made her a serious threat to win the nomination. She has particularly emerged as a rival to Biden in Iowa, a state he desperately needs to win to reinforce his argument that he is the candidate best equipped to take down Trump.

Questions persist about Warren's ambitious liberal agenda and whether she can attract moderate and black voters, as Biden does. However, Skinner said Warren can expand her appeal beyond siphoning liberal voters from Sanders and other candidates on the left. "She actually is starting to draw moderates. She doesn't feel like a Bernie. She doesn't feel like she's out to blow things up," Skinner said. "I see her as someone who can draw supporters from Bernie and from Biden."

All of the top-tier contenders have faced questions about whether they can bring together a deeply divided party and ultimately defeat Trump. Sanders is a self-described "Democratic socialist" who employs the rhetoric of a revolutionary and has seen his support slide as compared to his 2016 presidential bid when he gave Hillary Clinton a tough fight for the party's nomination. U.S. Senator Kamala Harris had what appeared to be a breakout moment in the first Democratic debate in June but has since fallen back in the polls. At times, she has struggled to articulate consistent policy stances.

Pete Buttigieg, mayor of South Bend, Indiana, drew a flurry of press attention early in his campaign, but concerns persist about his lack of national experience. He, too, has had trouble drawing support from African-American voters amid criticism over his handling of race relations and policing in his city.

Joe Zepecki, a Democratic strategist in the general election battleground state of Wisconsin that Trump narrowly won in 2016, said flawed candidates are the norm for this stage of the campaign and eventually the party will coalesce behind a nominee. "They all have flaws because the process of running for president forces those flaws to the fore," said Zepecki, who worked for Obama's 2012 re-election campaign. "That's how we do this."

While that may be true, the enduring questions surrounding Biden's age and fitness for office may mean Democrats will lack the "safe" choice they have had in the past, whether the candidate has been former Vice President Al Gore in 2000, former U.S. Senator John Kerry in 2004, or Clinton, the former U.S. senator and secretary of state, in 2008 and 2016.

Iowa's Link said the 2020 race remains fluid, and even a lower-tier contender such as U.S. Senator Cory Booker or former U.S. Representative Beto O'Rourke could still make a charge. The objective for candidates right now, Link said, is to "organize, organize, organize - and get hot at the end."

Title: The Weekly Standard Closes Its Doors: A Tragic Loss for Conservative Journalism

The news of The Weekly Standard's closure has been met with widespread sadness and regret. Founded in the mid-1990s, the magazine was known for its unique blend of cultural criticism, political commentary, and literary analysis. Under the leadership of editor-in-chief Bill Kristol, the publication became a hub for intelligent and thought-provoking writing, featuring a diverse range of voices and perspectives.

The magazine's strength lay in its ability to attract and nurture talented writers, many of whom went on to become prominent figures in their fields. The Standard's stable of writers included David Brooks, Matt Continetti, Mark Hemingway, John McCormack, Michael Warren, and many others, each bringing their unique voice and expertise to the table.

The magazine's cultural section, in particular, was a treasure trove of long-form essays on books, ideas, and culture, showcasing the publication's commitment to exploring the intersection of politics and culture. This section has been a staple of the magazine, offering readers in-depth analysis and commentary on the issues that matter most.

The Weekly Standard's closure is a significant loss for conservative journalism, as it was a platform that allowed writers to explore complex ideas and themes without fear of reprisal or censorship. The magazine's demise is a blow to the literary world, as it was a haven for writers who valued intellectual curiosity and critical thinking.

While the news of the magazine's closure is sad, it is also a testament to the power of The Weekly Standard's influence and the impact it had on the literary landscape. The magazine's archives remain a treasure trove of intelligent and thought-provoking writing, and its legacy will continue to inspire and inform readers for years to come.

Title: States Rush to Protect Abortion Rights Amidst Uncertainty Over Roe v. Wade

In the 47th year since the landmark Roe v. Wade decision, states across the United States are scrambling to protect women's reproductive rights amid concerns that the historic court decision may be overturned. The Supreme Court's conservative shift, following the confirmation of Justices Brett Kavanaugh and Neil Gorsuch, has sparked a surge in state-level legislation aimed at safeguarding abortion access.

Exactly one year ago, New York became the first state to codify the right to abortion in its state law, effectively enshrining Roe v. Wade. Since then, Illinois, Rhode Island, and Vermont have followed suit, while Michigan, New Jersey, and the District of Columbia are considering similar measures. In 2019, statehouses passed more legislation protecting or expanding abortion access than in the entire previous decade.

However, in response to the Supreme Court's conservative shift, red states have been taking a different approach. In 2019, four states – Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri, and Tennessee – passed trigger laws, which would ban abortion if the Supreme Court overturned Roe. Twelve states passed abortion bans, and eight states now have trigger laws on the books, with 20 having laws that could restrict abortion access if Roe were overturned.

According to Planned Parenthood, approximately 25 million women of reproductive age live in a state where abortion could be banned if Roe is overturned. Millions more are already forced to navigate hurdles to access abortions, including 72-hour waiting periods, mandatory counseling, and invasive ultrasound procedures.

The Supreme Court will hear its first abortion case since the confirmation of Justices Kavanaugh and Gorsuch in March, concerning a 2014 Louisiana law requiring abortion providers to have admitting privileges at local hospitals. While the justices are not expected to overturn Roe outright in this case, legal experts argue that if they rule in favor of the law, access to abortion in states like Louisiana could exist in name only.

Title: Former President Obama Criticizes Justice Department's Decision to Drop Flynn Case

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has expressed concerns about the Justice Department's decision to drop the case against Michael Flynn, his former national security adviser. In a private conversation with ex-members of his administration, Obama stated that the move raises concerns about the rule of law and institutional norms. He noted that there is no precedent for someone charged with false statements getting off scot-free, and that this development can accelerate quickly, as seen in other places.

Obama's comments were leaked to Yahoo News and reported on Saturday morning. He emphasized the urgency of the situation, urging those listening to feel the same sense of urgency as he does. The former president also cited the Flynn case as a reason to vote for his former Vice President, Joe Biden, in the November election against President Trump.

It is worth noting that Obama misstated the charges against Flynn, who was accused of making false statements to the FBI, not perjury. Flynn pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his conversations with the then-Russian ambassador but later sought to withdraw his guilty plea.

The Justice Department dropped the case against Flynn, citing that the FBI's 2017 interview with Flynn was not conducted with a legitimate investigative basis. The FBI had initially sought to close the probe three weeks earlier, stating it had not uncovered any wrongdoing. Anti-Trump former FBI agent Peter Strzok pushed to keep the case open, according to recent court documents.

President Trump has repeatedly criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Flynn prosecution, calling it corrupt and treasonous.

Title: State Department Admits Delay in Releasing Hillary Clinton's Emails Due to Classification Review

The United States Department of State has revealed that it is behind schedule in releasing former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton's emails, citing the need to review and redact potentially classified information. According to John F. Hackett, the department's top open records officer, the government only recently realized the extent of the potentially classified information in Mrs. Clinton's communications, prompting the need to have intelligence officers review her emails to ensure they do not contain secrets.

As a result, the department has released less than 12 percent of Mrs. Clinton's emails, falling short of the 15 percent goal set by Judge Rudolph Contreras earlier this year. Mrs. Clinton had previously claimed that she did not conduct any classified business on her personal email account, which she used during her tenure as secretary of state. However, an inspector general's report found that some information in her emails should have been classified at the time she sent them.

The State Department is currently reviewing and redacting the emails to ensure they do not contain classified information. Mrs. Clinton's unique arrangement, which involved using a private server at her home in New York instead of an official secure State Department account, meant that her emails were not part of the official record for six years. The department was only able to retrieve her emails in December 2014, nearly two years after she left office, and she has since turned over 55,000 pages of emails, or about 30,000 messages.

Mrs. Clinton has refused to turn over her server, stating that it would be pointless since she has wiped the emails clean. The department plans to release 6,106 pages of emails in August and 7,156 in September, which will still leave more than 60 percent of the messages to be released by the deadline set by Judge Contreras.

Title: Former Trump Lawyer Michael Cohen Accused of Rigging Online Polls in 2015

Former President Donald Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, is back in the headlines for a 2015 meeting at Trump Tower, where he allegedly paid a technology expert to rig online polls in Trump's favor. According to The Wall Street Journal, Cohen offered John Gauger, the owner of Red Finch Solutions and chief information officer at Liberty University, $50,000 to manipulate two news sites' polls. Gauger said Cohen handed him a Walmart bag containing $12,000 in cash during the meeting, but never paid the remaining $38,000.

Cohen did not deny the report in a tweet, stating that what he did was "at the direction of and for the sole benefit of" Trump. However, he denied giving Gauger cash, claiming that all payments were made by check.

Gauger reportedly had limited success in moving the needle in the polls he was paid to manipulate. In January 2014, Cohen asked Gauger to sway a CNBC online poll on the top American business leaders with a program that could vote for Trump repeatedly, but Trump did not break into the top 100. In February 2015, Cohen asked Gauger to boost Trump in a Drudge Report poll on potential 2016 Republican presidential candidates, but Trump ended up coming in fifth with 5% of the vote.

Cohen also asked Gauger to create a Twitter account, @WomenForCohen, which was run by a female friend of Gauger's to portray Cohen as a "sex symbol" and hype his statements in favor of Trump's presidential campaign. The account remains active with 527 followers as of Thursday morning.

Gauger said the last time he spoke to Cohen was in April 2018, after the lawyer's office, home, and hotel room were raided by the FBI. Cohen was sentenced to three years in federal prison last month after pleading guilty to crimes related to tax evasion, campaign finance violations, and lying to Congress.

The Journal reported that Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, said if Cohen requested a $50,000 reimbursement but only paid Gauger $12,000 to $13,000, it shows Cohen is a "thief." Cohen is expected to testify before the House Oversight Committee on February 7, where he will likely face questions about his "dirty deeds."

Title: Tillerson Says "All Options Are On The Table" In Dealing With North Korea

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has stated that the United States does not want to take military action against North Korea, but "all options are on the table" if a serious threat arises. Tillerson made these remarks during a visit to South Korea on Friday, a day after saying that diplomatic efforts have failed to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.

Tillerson's Asia tour began in Japan and will conclude in China. The top American diplomat is traveling without a press contingent. He emphasized that while the U.S. would prefer to avoid an armed conflict, "if they elevate the threat of their weapons program to a level that we believe requires action, then that option's on the table."

Joseph DeTrani, former special envoy for six-party talks with North Korea, believes that Tillerson is being straightforward with China and regional allies in the Asia region, stating that the U.S. is looking at negotiations all the way to preemption. If there is an imminent strike against the United States, all options must be considered.

North Korea's recent missile tests have raised concerns, with Japan conducting a missile evacuation drill on its coast. The U.S. is also seeking to engage with China to address the issue, as part of Tillerson's trip. The State Department has stated that an important part of Tillerson's agenda in China will be to push Beijing to push North Korea to abandon its nuclear and missile programs.

Tillerson will also plan for a visit by President Xi Jinping to meet with President Trump at his private club in Mar-a-Lago, Florida, next month, although this has not been formally announced yet. China wants ties with the U.S. to remain stable, so as not to distract from a leadership reshuffle this fall.

Title: Supreme Court to Tackle Controversial Issues Amid Presidential Election

The Supreme Court is set to begin its next term on Monday, with a docket that includes several contentious issues that neither President Barack Obama nor Mitt Romney has been eager to discuss during the presidential campaign. The justices will take up the question of affirmative action, with the University of Texas's affirmative action program being challenged by Abigail Fisher, a white undergraduate applicant who was denied admission. The Obama administration has backed the university's right to run its affirmative action program, but has a history of being skittish about getting publicly involved in debates over race and education-related affirmative action.

The court may also announce its decision on same-sex marriage around the same time, which could stir up controversy. Additionally, the justices will hear their first case relating to the federal government's terrorist surveillance program, which allows tapping phones and email communications as part of the war on terror.

None of these issues have been prominent on the campaign trail this year, and it's unlikely that the justices will rule on any of them before the election. However, the court's decisions could still have an impact on the presidential race, particularly given the historic 5-4 decision last term upholding the Affordable Care Act.

The case on the University of Texas's affirmative action program is set to be argued on October 10, just one week before the first presidential debate on domestic issues. The vice presidential debate is scheduled for October 11. While neither candidate is likely to want to discuss these issues, Richard Taylor, a business diversity advocate and former Massachusetts transportation secretary under Romney, believes that they should be on the checklist for debate preparation.

The Obama administration has backed the University of Texas's affirmative action program, but has a history of being skittish about getting publicly involved in debates over race and education-related affirmative action. The federal government's policy statement on the use of race in education languished in protracted interagency debates until last December, with some critics accusing the administration of having a reluctance to take on race and equality issues.

Title: President Obama Signs Bipartisan Budget Bill, Easing Spending Cuts and Defense Authorization Act

President Barack Obama signed a bipartisan budget bill on Thursday, marking a significant step towards easing mandatory spending cuts over the next two years. The bill, which was approved by the Senate last week and the House earlier this month, reduces across-the-board cuts by about $63 billion and includes projected savings of $85 billion.

The bill signing comes as Obama's presidency nears its end, following a tumultuous year marked by a partial government shutdown, a near-default by the Treasury, a troubled health care rollout, and congressional gridlock. The deal prevents another government shutdown for nearly two years and marks one of Obama's last official acts as president.

The bill also includes appropriations for Department of Defense programs and related spending at other agencies. The National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal 2014 sets out a Pentagon base budget of $526.8 billion for the 2014 fiscal year.

However, the defense authorization act does not go as far as the president would like in closing the Guantanamo Bay detention center. As in past years, Obama attached a signing statement expressing concerns about "unwarranted and burdensome restrictions" on transferring detainees out of the prison. While the law eases some restrictions, making it easier to transfer detainees to foreign countries, Congress still refuses to allow the transfer of detainees to U.S. soil, making it nearly impossible to close the prison.

In his signing statement, Obama described the restrictions as "unwise" and emphasized that the executive branch must have the authority to determine when and where to prosecute Guantanamo detainees.

Title: Obama and Romney Make Final Push in Tight Election Race

In the final 24 hours of campaigning, President Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney are focusing on a narrow cross-section of voters in six key states, each employing their own unique strategies to sway undecided voters. The candidates are using rock superstars to help deliver their messages, with Bruce Springsteen joining Obama's campaign and The Marshall Tucker Band and Kid Rock backing Romney.

On Monday, Obama and Romney held rallies in various states, with the president urging voters to help him "finish what we started" and Romney emphasizing the need to "unleash the power of America's entrepreneurs." Obama accused Romney of trying to "repackage the same old, bad ideas" and touted the Clinton administration's economic record of the 1990s as evidence that Democratic ideas "work." Romney, meanwhile, claimed his campaign has "gathered strength" in recent weeks and become a "movement."

The race remains extremely close, with both candidates neck and neck in the polls. According to the RealClearPolitics electoral map, Obama has a slight advantage in the electoral vote count, with 201 electoral votes likely to vote for him and 191 for Romney. The toss-up states include Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Wisconsin.

Ohio is considered a crucial swing state, with both candidates campaigning there on Monday. Romney is also making a late push for Pennsylvania, which could provide a firewall if he loses Ohio. A recent poll showed the race in Pennsylvania tied at 47 percent, with Obama's team calling Romney's move a "Hail Mary" and a sign he still lacks a clear pathway to reaching the required electoral votes.

In their final appeals, both candidates emphasized the need for bipartisanship and cooperation. Obama pledged to work with anyone, regardless of party, to move the country forward, while Romney emphasized the importance of "working together" to address the country's challenges.

Title: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Reverse Order Requiring Release of Tax Returns

Article:

President Donald Trump has appealed to the Supreme Court, seeking to reverse a court order requiring his accountants to hand over eight years of tax returns. The request comes after a federal appeals court in New York ruled that Manhattan prosecutors could enforce a subpoena against Trump's accounting firm, Mazars USA, for his personal and corporate financial records from 2011 to 2018.

In their petition to the Supreme Court, Trump's personal lawyers argued that the subpoena is "politically motivated" and that the president should be immune from state criminal process. They claimed that the Constitution gives the president immunity from criminal proceedings, and that the subpoena is a "perfect illustration" of why a sitting president should be categorically immune.

The petition also stated that the Second Circuit decision is "wrong" and should be reversed, with Trump's lawyer, Jay Sekulow, saying that the subpoena violates the U.S. Constitution and is therefore unenforceable.

A three-judge panel of the Second Circuit had previously ruled that Manhattan prosecutors could obtain Trump's financial records as part of a grand jury investigation, over Trump's claims of presidential immunity. The district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr., agreed not to enforce the subpoena while Trump's lawyers appealed to the Supreme Court.

The investigation is focused on payments allegedly made to silence two women who allege they had affairs with Trump. Trump's lawyers have argued that the president has blanket immunity from criminal prosecution, with Trump's personal lawyer, William Consovoy, stating that the president could not be prosecuted even if he shot someone on Fifth Avenue in New York City.

The three judges on the circuit court panel, all Democratic appointees, ruled that any immunity Trump had did not cover a subpoena to his accounting firm. Trump has faced criticism for breaking with a decades-long tradition of presidents voluntarily releasing their tax returns, and this petition represents a last-ditch effort to keep the documents hidden.

This is not the only legal battle over subpoenas for Trump's financial records. A separate case in Washington, D.C. has cleared the way for House Democrats on the Oversight Committee to pursue Trump's financial records from Mazars, with Trump's lawyers indicating they will also appeal that decision to the Supreme Court.

Title: SpaceX's Falcon 9 Rocket Successfully Launches with Two American Astronauts, Marking a New Era in Commercial Space Travel

Article:

SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket thundered away from Earth on Saturday, carrying two American astronauts, Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken, into orbit. This historic launch marks a new era in commercial space travel, with the United States returning to launching astronauts into orbit from its own soil for the first time in nearly a decade.

The mission unfolded amid the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic and racial unrest in the United States. NASA officials and others hoped the flight would serve as a morale-booster for the nation. "Maybe there's an opportunity here for America to maybe pause and look up and see a bright, shining moment of hope at what the future looks like, that the United States of America can do extraordinary things even in difficult times," NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine said before the launch.

With the successful liftoff, SpaceX, founded by Elon Musk, became the first private company to launch people into orbit, a feat previously achieved only by three governments: the United States, Russia, and China. The flight also ended a nine-year launch drought for NASA, the longest such hiatus in its history.

The mission is the latest milestone for NASA's commercial crew program, a partnership between the agency, SpaceX, and Boeing. The program aims to develop and operate a new generation of spacecraft and launch systems capable of carrying crews to low-Earth orbit and the International Space Station.

The flight is expected to be a significant milestone for the space industry, with analysts predicting that space exploration and adjacent businesses, such as space tourism and long-haul travel on Earth, will grow into a more than $800 billion industry in the next decade. NASA has also announced partnerships with private companies, including SpaceX and Blue Origin, to work on the landing systems for its Artemis program, which aims to land the first woman and next man on the moon by 2024.

The successful launch of the Falcon 9 rocket marks a major achievement for SpaceX and NASA, and sets the stage for future commercial space travel and exploration.

Title: Mitt Romney's Mormonism in the Spotlight: A Look into the Controversial White Horse Prophecy

Article:

Mitt Romney's Mormon faith has been a topic of interest and scrutiny in the 2012 presidential election. As the Republican nominee, Romney's religious beliefs have been under the microscope, with some questioning the role of his faith in his political views. One aspect of his Mormonism that has garnered significant attention is the White Horse prophecy, a concept that has been both praised and criticized.

The prophecy, attributed to Joseph Smith, the founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS), predicts that when the Constitution is near collapse, a "White Horse" will rise and lead America back to greatness. While the church has largely discredited the prophecy, it remains a topic of interest among some Mormons and non-Mormons alike.

Romney, a former Mormon bishop, has not publicly addressed the prophecy in great detail, instead opting to focus on his economic and political policies. However, his father, George Romney, mentioned the special role Mormons have to play in preserving the Constitution during his own presidential run.

The White Horse prophecy has been interpreted by some as a call to action for Mormons to save the country when it is in crisis. According to LDS beliefs, the Garden of Eden was located in Missouri, and Joseph Smith found the Book of Mormon in upstate New York. The prophecy has been seen as a way for Mormons to fulfill their role in preserving the Constitution and the nation as a whole.

While some have criticized the prophecy as being too apocalyptic and divisive, others see it as a reminder of the importance of preserving the Constitution and the country's founding principles. Romney's views on the Constitution, which he has mentioned on the campaign trail, have sparked debate among some, with some seeing it as a sign of his commitment to preserving the document.

As the election approaches, Romney's Mormonism will likely continue to be a topic of discussion and scrutiny. While the White Horse prophecy may not be a central issue in the campaign, it remains an important aspect of Romney's faith and a topic of interest for many Americans.

Title: Democrat Doug Jones Wins Alabama Senate Seat, Reflecting Broader Election Trends

The special election in Alabama's Senate seat, held on Tuesday, saw Democrat Doug Jones emerge victorious over Republican Roy Moore, with a margin of 1.5 percentage points. Jones' win marks the first time a Democrat has won a statewide office in Alabama since 2008. The election had several unique characteristics, including the controversial nature of Moore's candidacy and the fact that Jones outspent his opponent by a significant margin.

Despite these factors, the Alabama election also reflects broader trends seen in recent elections, including the Virginia gubernatorial race earlier this year. These trends suggest that Democrats may be gaining momentum heading into the 2018 mid-term elections, which will determine control of the House of Representatives and the Senate.

One key factor contributing to the Democratic advantage is increased support from non-white voters. Additionally, party turnout in metropolitan areas and stronger performance in well-educated suburban communities have been notable. In contrast, Republican turnout in white rural counties, which played a significant role in Donald Trump's 2016 presidential victory, has lagged in recent elections, including the Virginia gubernatorial race and the Alabama Senate election.

The outcome of the Alabama election serves as a reminder that the 2018 mid-term elections will be highly competitive and closely watched. With control of the House and Senate on the line, both parties will be vying for every vote. The results of this special election may provide a glimpse into the broader trends that will shape the outcome of these elections.

Title: WIRED Magazine Concedes Right-Wing Criticism of WHO May Contain Valid Points

Article:

A recent tweet from WIRED magazine sparked controversy when it acknowledged that a "right-wing stunt" criticizing the World Health Organization (WHO) may have contained a valid point. The tweet linked to an article written by a journalist who initially expressed surprise at finding common ground with conservative views on the WHO. The author, a self-proclaimed advocate for global governance, initially defended the WHO against right-wing attacks, but later conceded that the organization may have made mistakes in its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The article references a now-notorious WHO tweet from January 2020, which stated that there was no evidence of human-to-human transmission of COVID-19 in China, despite evidence to the contrary. The tweet was widely criticized, and the author of the WIRED article suggests that the WHO may have been slow to respond to the crisis and potentially misled the public.

The article also notes that the right-wing criticism of the WHO is not entirely unfounded, as many people have lost faith in the organization due to its perceived closeness to the Chinese Communist Party. The author concludes that while the right-wing criticism may be motivated by political ideology, there is some reason to suspect that the WHO may have made mistakes in its handling of the pandemic.

The tweet and article have sparked a lively debate on social media, with some users accusing the author of engaging in "mental gymnastics" to justify the right-wing criticism. Others have praised the author for acknowledging the complexity of the issue and the need for a nuanced discussion.

Title: The "Literally-Serious" Conundrum: Understanding Trump's Communication Style

The concept of taking Donald Trump's statements "seriously but not literally" has gained traction in recent months, with some arguing that this approach is a key to understanding the president-elect's communication style. The idea, coined by reporter Salena Zito, suggests that Trump's supporters take his words seriously, but not as literal truths. This distinction has been credited to Trump's team, with Corey Lewandowski, his first campaign manager, stating that the media took Trump's statements too literally.

Peter Thiel, a major Trump backer, also made the point at the National Press Club in October, saying that the media always takes Trump literally but not seriously. Trump himself has hinted that he buys into this interpretation, admitting that his statement about not letting Carrier leave was a euphemism.

The "literally-serious" approach has been applied to other politicians, including Vice President Joe Biden, who has made some outlandish statements over the years. However, Trump's lack of experience in public office and his claims of being an outsider and a "disrupter" make his words take on greater importance.

While the "literally-serious" distinction may be an interesting analytical insight into Trump's communication style, it is unclear how it would apply in real-world situations. For example, when Trump claims millions of people voted illegally, should the media take that claim seriously but not literally? Or should they assume that some number of people voted illegally, but not millions?

Perhaps the "literally-serious" distinction is a way of saying that Trump should get a free pass whenever his words get him in trouble. Trump has said he has the best words and could be more presidential than anyone, except maybe Abraham Lincoln. He would be well-advised to take his own words seriously, if not literally.

What a president says matters, and credibility is a finite resource that can be easily depleted when you think you'll never be held accountable for what you blurt out.

Title: Former Vice President Dick Cheney Criticizes Senate Report on CIA Interrogation Techniques

Former Vice President Dick Cheney has spoken out against the recently released Senate report on CIA interrogation techniques, calling it "full of crap" and a "terrible piece of work" that is "deeply flawed." Cheney made his comments on Fox News' "Special Report with Bret Baier," stating that some of the controversial techniques used on militants had been previously tested and produced results.

Cheney acknowledged that he had not read the entire 500-page report summary, but strongly defended the tactics, including waterboarding and rectal hydration. He asked, "What are you prepared to do to get the truth against future attacks against the United States?"

Cheney also refuted claims that President George W. Bush was kept in the dark about the interrogations, stating, "I think he knew everything he wanted to know and needed to know."

The report, from the Senate intelligence committee, claimed that the interrogation techniques used were "brutal and far worse" than the CIA represented to lawmakers. The report also claimed that the tactics were not effective and the spy agency gave "inaccurate" information about it to Congress and the White House.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, the head of the intelligence panel, alleged on the Senate floor that the CIA techniques in some cases amounted to "torture." She stated, "History will judge us by our commitment to a just society governed by law and the willingness to face an ugly truth and say 'never again.' There may never be the right time to release this report... But this report is too important to shelve indefinitely."

The White House and President Obama backed the decision to release the report, despite warnings from lawmakers and some inside the administration that it could lead to a backlash against Americans.

Title: Trump's Legal Battles May Test His Faith in the Supreme Court

The legal disputes targeting President Donald Trump's personal and professional dealings may soon be decided by the Supreme Court, which has given him victories on some pivotal policies. However, the court's conservative majority, including two justices appointed by Trump, may not be as sympathetic to his personal interests.

Legal experts predict that the court may uphold lower court decisions finding proper legislative purpose in recent inquiries regarding tax and financial fraud subpoenas. This could be a blow to Trump's defiance of congressional subpoenas, which he has challenged in lower courts.

The Supreme Court has already given Trump victories on some policies, including upholding his travel ban targeting people from several Muslim-majority countries. However, the court's stance on his personal and professional dealings may be different. Conservative legal scholar J.W. Verret, an expert in corporate and securities law, believes that the court will support strong separation of powers, as outlined in the U.S. Constitution.

Trump has defied a series of subpoenas from the Democratic-led House of Representatives, seeking testimony from current and former administration officials and documents covering matters such as his tax returns, banking records, family business interests, and Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 election and Trump's actions to impede the inquiry.

The president and his lawyers have challenged the oversight authority of Congress, a stance that Democrats have framed as an attack on the separation of powers. Trump has sued to block enforcement of certain subpoenas, losing thus far in lower courts. House Democrats appear poised to press the matter by bringing their own court actions to try to enforce their subpoenas.

Other lawsuits, including one brought by congressional Democrats, accuse Trump of violating an anti-corruption provision in the Constitution, called the emoluments clause, by continuing to accept payments from foreign governments through his businesses, including a downtown Washington hotel.

Some of Trump's losses in lower courts are already on appeal, and potentially could come before the Supreme Court with decisions issued during the heat of the election season. The court's first taste of the fight between Trump and congressional Democrats could come in two fast-moving cases, involving subpoenas for financial records from his accounting firm, Mazars LLP, and two banks with which he has done business: Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp.

The emoluments issue also could be heading toward the justices. The Supreme Court will likely have the final say concerning potential conflicts of interest tied to Trump's Washington hotel and other business interests, as courts have never had to deal with this in 200-plus years, said Ciara Torres-Spelliscy, a law professor at Stetson University College of Law in Florida.

Title: French Magazine Charlie Hebdo Attacked, 12 Dead in Paris Shooting

Article:

A deadly attack on the Paris office of the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo has left 12 people dead, including the editor and a cartoonist, and several others injured. The attack, which occurred on Wednesday, is being described as France's deadliest terror attack in at least two decades.

The masked gunmen, who shouted "Allahu akbar" ("God is great" in Arabic), stormed the Charlie Hebdo office, killing 12 people and injuring several others. The attackers then escaped, with police launching a manhunt to track them down.

French President Francois Hollande condemned the attack, calling it a "terrorist attack without a doubt." He also announced that several other attacks have been thwarted in France in recent weeks.

The attack occurred just minutes after Charlie Hebdo tweeted a satirical cartoon of the leader of the Islamic State group, and another cartoon featuring a caricature of an extremist fighter saying "Just wait – we have until the end of January to present our New Year's wishes."

The 12 dead included two men who went by the pen names Charb and Cabu, both of whom were well-known cartoonists. Two police officers were also among the dead, including one who was assigned as Charb's bodyguard after receiving death threats.

The attack has sent shockwaves across the world, with world leaders condemning the violence. However, some supporters of the Islamic State group have celebrated the attack as "well-deserved revenge" against France.

The attack has also sparked concerns about the safety of journalists and the importance of protecting freedom of speech. Charlie Hebdo has been repeatedly threatened for its caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad and other controversial sketches.

The French government has raised its security alert to the highest level and reinforced protective measures at houses of worship, stores, media offices, and transportation hubs. Schools across the French capital have also closed their doors.

The investigation is ongoing, with police working to track down the attackers and determine their motives.

Title: Senate Votes to Give Congress a Role in Trump's Tariff Strategy

The United States Senate voted 88-11 to instruct lawmakers negotiating a government funding bill to include language providing a role for Congress on tariffs implemented for national security reasons, known as Section 232 of the trade laws. The vote is non-binding, meaning lawmakers do not have to add trade language into the funding bill, but the vote margin, with more senators supporting it than the amount needed to override a veto, underscores the depth of concern on Capitol Hill.

The president used Section 232 to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, including slapping financial penalties on key trading allies like the European Union, Canada, and Mexico. However, Republicans have been wary of using legislation to push back against Trump's tariff strategy, with some arguing it would undercut the president's negotiating ability.

Senate Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) tried to attach legislation requiring congressional approval for tariffs applied for national security reasons to both a defense policy bill and the farm bill, but was blocked both times. Corker said after the vote that he would continue to push for the Senate to pass stand-alone legislation on Trump's tariff authority.

Some GOP senators, including Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), argued that Congress has to rein in the abuse of presidential authority and restore congressional authority in this regard. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) has said he will bring up tariff legislation in the committee, with some GOP senators on the panel voicing support for narrowing Section 232 of the trade law.

Eleven Republican senators voted against the measure, including Sen. David Perdue (R-Ga.), who said senators were tying Trump's hands. "I just don't understand why this body continues to try to tie the hands of this president at every turn," he said. "This president is committed to creating a more level playing field for our workers and our companies here at home to compete."

Title: Obama's Credibility at Stake in Syria Crisis, Influenced by Iraq War Experience

The Obama administration's response to the increasing evidence of chemical weapons use in Syria is being shaped by the lessons learned from the Iraq War, according to former officials and analysts close to the administration. The ghosts of the Iraq War weigh heavily on President Barack Obama and his top advisers, who are cautious about getting it wrong and don't want to repeat the mistakes of the past.

The administration's recent statement that there is some evidence that President Bashar Assad did use sarin gas has left them balancing their concerns against Obama's repeated vows that the use of nerve agents or poison gas by Assad's regime would be a "red line" and a "game changer" that would force the U.S. to have a stronger reaction to the ongoing conflict.

Former officials and analysts agree that the Iraq War experience is a significant factor in the administration's decision-making. "It has to be a factor," said Greg Craig, who served as a foreign policy adviser on Obama's 2008 campaign and as his first White House counsel. "He does not want to jump to conclusions or shoot from the hip."

The administration is also mindful of the CIA's 2003 statement that it was a "slam dunk" to conclude that Iraq had nuclear weapons, which turned out to be incorrect. Similarly, the CIA reported that Saddam Hussein had an active chemical and biological weapons program, which was also off the mark.

Experts agree that the administration is being cautious and careful, given the lessons learned from Iraq. "I think they're right to be careful and cautious on this because the intel can be wrong, as we've learned in Iraq," said Sandy Berger, a former Clinton national security adviser.

The White House official who briefed reporters on the Syria issue emphasized the importance of establishing the facts with certainty and presenting information that is "airtight" and "credible" to underpin all decision-making. The official noted that the U.S. has a history of intelligence assessments being wrong, including those related to weapons of mass destruction.

The challenges that U.S. troops faced in Iraq are also a key factor in Obama's wariness about getting more deeply involved in Syria. After some predicted American troops would be greeted with roses, the conflict turned out to be a quagmire that took the U.S. five years to extract itself from, and played a central role in delivering Obama to the Oval Office.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Challenges Common Core Education Curriculum in Latest GOP Presidential Hopeful Move

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has become the latest Republican presidential hopeful to adjust his stance on the Common Core education curriculum, joining a growing list of potential 2016 candidates recalibrating their positions to appeal to conservative voters. Jindal, who initially supported the Common Core in 2010, now views it as an example of an overbearing federal government. This shift follows similar moves by Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who have reversed their positions on immigration reform and foreign assistance to Israel, respectively.

Analysts suggest that these changes are designed to bring the candidates in line with an increasingly conservative litmus test for Republican primary voters. "They are adapting to new GOP winds and trying to put themselves in the strongest possible position," said Darrell M. West, vice president and director of governance studies at the Brookings Institute. "This means getting tough on the Common Core, which conservatives hate. It also means becoming more negative on comprehensive immigration reform and making sure they are supportive of Israel."

Strategically, Mark McKinnon, a GOP strategist, believes that the summer is a good time for candidates to adjust their positions. "If you're going to flip-flop in politics, best to do it early and off-Broadway," he said. Candidates of all stripes have done the pre-primary flip-flop, and often on major heartfelt stances.

Jindal's lawsuit, filed on Wednesday, accuses the Obama administration of using federal grants and waivers to illegally coerce states into adopting the Common Core standards, which 44 states and the District of Columbia have adopted. "Common Core is the latest effort by big government disciples to strip away state rights and put Washington, D.C., in control of everything," Jindal said. "What started out as an innovative idea to create a set of baseline standards that could be 'voluntarily' used by the states has turned into a scheme by the federal government to nationalize curriculum."

The announcement came a day after Rubio made his boldest stance yet on immigration, sending President Obama a letter saying there is "no realistic path forward on comprehensive [immigration] reform for the foreseeable future" – essentially declaring his own legislation dead. Instead, he said that Congress should take a piecemeal approach to the problem, starting with stemming the flow of illegal immigrants into the country. Only then, Rubio said, will there be the political will to deal with the millions of illegal immigrants already living here.

Meanwhile, in the wake of the war in Gaza, which has fueled a strong response from the party's deep pool of pro-Israel voices, Paul has tried to reassure voters that he has never supported cutting aid to Israel, despite previous statements to the contrary.

While opponents use flip-flops to attack candidates, Michael McKenna, a GOP consultant, said they also show the political process is working. "These shifts are part of what makes popular sovereignty so great – those who want to get elected have to (ultimately) express the will of the majority of the electorate, or they don't get elected," McKenna said in an email. "And usually people like to do it when not too many folks are watching the evolution. Because it can get misconstrued as being indecisive or, worse, pandering."

Title: The Polarization of Public Discourse: A Study in Uncertainty and Bigotry

The recent hearings surrounding the Supreme Court nomination of Brett Kavanaugh have sparked a heated debate, with many commentators and individuals taking sides without fully considering the uncertainty surrounding the allegations. The lack of concrete evidence and contradictory testimonies have led to a proliferation of assumptions and stereotypes, ultimately perpetuating bigotry and polarization.

The case at hand is shrouded in mystery, with no concrete evidence to support or refute the allegations. Despite this uncertainty, many have taken sides, often relying on preconceived notions and biases. The original evidence has been largely ignored, and instead, new reasons have been conjured to confirm existing positions. This has led to a toxic environment where persuasion is no longer a valuable tool in public discourse, replaced by mobilization and the creation of stereotypes.

The phenomenon of bigotry has been on full display, as individuals have created and applied stereotypes to groups and individuals without knowing the facts. This is a dangerous trend, as it can lead to the conviction of innocent people, as seen in the cases of Alfred Dreyfus and the Central Park Five. The Duke lacrosse scandal is another example of how bigotry can lead to false accusations and the destruction of reputations.

In the context of the Kavanaugh hearings, thousands of people have made assumptions about his behavior based on their perceptions of "privileged" individuals, while others have rallied behind him, convinced that the "Left" is out to get them. This kind of thinking perpetuates a culture of fear, mistrust, and division.

The takeaway from this episode is that public discourse has become increasingly polarized, with individuals more focused on mobilizing their base than engaging in constructive dialogue. The lack of intellectual humility and the willingness to consider uncertainty have given way to a culture of bigotry and stereotype-making. As a society, it is essential to recognize the dangers of this trend and strive for a more nuanced and informed public discourse.

Title: Ferguson Protests Continue, Despite Tension and Violence

Ferguson, Missouri, has seen another day of protests and demonstrations, with some turning violent, but many residents remain determined to continue their fight for justice. Despite the chaos and looting that erupted on Monday night, many protesters are refusing to back down, saying they are not afraid to stand up against what they see as systemic injustice.

The day began with a tense atmosphere, with National Guardsmen in full riot gear standing in a line outside the Ferguson Police Department, facing a crowd of hundreds of protesters. The crowd chanted slogans, including "We are not your enemy, we just want justice." Despite the building tension, many protesters remained resolute, saying they will not be deterred by the violence and looting that occurred on Monday.

Some residents, like Shannon White, 20, expressed frustration and anger at the system, saying people are tired of being treated unfairly. Veronica Wintersheidt, 29, and her husband braved the cold temperatures to show their solidarity, saying they understand the struggle is not easy, but it is necessary.

Throughout the day, authorities scrambled to prevent a repeat of the violence, with Missouri Governor Jay Nixon ordering additional National Guardsmen to the area, boosting their numbers from 700 to 2,200. The governor emphasized the need to "do better" and prevent a repeat of the lawlessness.

The protests are a response to the grand jury's decision not to indict Darren Wilson, the white police officer who shot and killed 18-year-old Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, on August 9. The decision sparked widespread outrage and protests across the country, with many calling for justice and accountability.

While some protests turned violent, with buildings being burned and stores being looted, many others remained peaceful, with protesters calling for calm and unity. The vast majority of protests in the weeks after Brown's death have been peaceful, and authorities hope to keep it that way.

The investigation into the shooting of Michael Brown is ongoing, and authorities are still seeking answers. The case has sparked a national conversation about race, police brutality, and systemic inequality, with many calling for change and reform.

Title: Open Borders Activists Endorse Warren and Sanders in 2020 Democrat Presidential Primary

The 2020 Democrat presidential primary field is seeing endorsements from open borders organizations, with Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Bernie Sanders (I-VT) receiving support from United We Dream Action (UWDA) and other groups. UWDA, which includes illegal aliens as part of its membership, praised Warren and Sanders for their support of ending all deportations of illegal aliens.

In a video endorsement, UWDA stated that "after four years of Trump, there's absolutely no question that detention camps need to be closed, deportations need to be stopped, and the enforcement machine needs to be taken apart brick by brick." The organization highlighted the candidates' support for key provisions of the "Free to move, free to stay" platform, including shutting down for-profit detention camps, shrinking ICE and CBP budgets, and providing a pathway to citizenship without provisions that harm immigrants.

The endorsement is significant for Warren and Sanders in California, which has the largest illegal alien population and foreign-born population in the country. By election day in November, one-in-five California voters will have been born outside the U.S. In North Carolina, Sanders is receiving support from the open borders lobbying organization Mijente and the Hispanic American Democrats of Mecklenburg County, with members knocking doors for Sanders.

Nationwide, activists are reporting enthusiasm for Bernie among Latino voters, with some calling him "Tío Bernie." In prior primaries, like the Iowa Democrat Caucus, illegal aliens and noncitizens have organized for Sanders. Both Warren and Sanders have endorsed a platform that decriminalizes U.S.-Mexico border crossings, provides amnesty for the majority of the 11 to 22 million illegal alien population, and offers taxpayer-funded healthcare for all illegal aliens, noncitizens, and foreign nationals.

Title: Senior Aides to Joe Biden Ask TV Networks to Limit Rudy Giuliani's Airtime

Article:

Senior advisors to Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden have written to television news channels, requesting that they limit the airtime given to Rudy Giuliani, President Donald Trump's personal lawyer. The letter, obtained by the Daily Beast, argues that Giuliani is spreading "false, debunked conspiracy theories" and "lies" on behalf of Trump.

Giuliani has been a frequent guest on network and cable news shows since the Ukraine scandal broke, with some pundits describing his comments as "unhinged" and "desperate." The letter's authors, Anita Dunn, a former acting White House communications director under Barack Obama, and Kate Bedingfield, Biden's deputy campaign manager, claim that Giuliani is using his airtime to introduce "increasingly unhinged, unfounded, and desperate lies" into the national conversation.

The letter also notes that Giuliani is not a public official and does not hold any public office that would entitle him to opine on the nation's airwaves. The authors demand that if Giuliani does appear on TV, an equivalent amount of time should be given to a surrogate for the Biden campaign.

Giuliani has been accused of spreading conspiracy theories and misinformation about Biden, including claims that the former vice president pressured Ukraine to fire its chief prosecutor in 2016 to protect his son, Hunter Biden. However, top officials in the Ukraine government have denied any evidence of corruption relating to either Biden.

The letter is an attempt by the Biden campaign to limit Giuliani's influence and prevent him from using his airtime to spread misinformation and propaganda. The move is seen as a response to Giuliani's increasing prominence in the media and his role in the Ukraine scandal.

Title: Supreme Court Struggles to Reach Consensus on Key Cases

The United States Supreme Court is facing an unusual delay in issuing decisions on several key cases, with some justices appearing to be struggling to find common ground. The court's ideological divide, with five conservative and four liberal justices, is making it challenging to produce rulings at their usual pace.

During a recent oral argument in a case involving the redrawing of electoral districts, Justice Stephen Breyer suggested that the court might put off a decision altogether. This remark highlighted the difficulty the justices are having in resolving cases, particularly those involving partisan gerrymandering.

The court has issued only 18 rulings in cases already argued this term, lagging behind its normal pace. Several major cases remain unresolved, including ones on Wisconsin and Maryland electoral boundaries, as well as a case involving a Christian baker who refused to make a wedding cake for a gay couple.

Experts expect the justices to issue a larger-than-normal number of 5-4 rulings in the coming months, which could increase the chances of conservative Justice Anthony Kennedy casting the deciding votes. The court's most contentious rulings often come in June, and the presence of Justice Neil Gorsuch, who has shown a willingness to question his colleagues, may be contributing to the delay.

The impasse over partisan gerrymandering was first seen in a challenge by Democratic voters to Republican-drawn state legislative districts in Wisconsin, and the justices appeared no closer to resolving the matter after hearing the similar Maryland dispute. The court also seemed divided in the worker class-action case, with the justices having to decide whether workers can be forced to sign agreements waiving their right to bring class-action claims against their employer.

The slow pace of rulings may be due to scheduling, with the court having had hard and divisive cases earlier in the term, said Kannon Shanmugam, a regular Supreme Court lawyer. The court usually takes less time to issue a ruling when the justices are unanimous, and it has issued 11 unanimous rulings and seven with dissenting votes this term.

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Comments on Trump's Knowledge of Stormy Daniels Payment

Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and current lawyer for President Donald Trump, released a three-point clarification on Friday regarding his comments about the hush-money payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels.
