The clarification comes hours after Trump said Giuliani would "get his facts straight."

Giuliani's statement aimed to clarify his views on the payment, which was made to Daniels in the weeks leading up to the 2016 election. The payment was reportedly made to resolve a personal and false allegation about an alleged sexual encounter between Trump and Daniels in 2006. Giuliani did not walk back the statement that Trump reimbursed his personal attorney, Michael Cohen, for the $130,000 payment.

In his clarification, Giuliani emphasized that the payment was made to resolve a personal and false allegation, and that it would have been done regardless of whether Trump was a candidate or not. He also clarified his previous comments about the timing of the payment, stating that his references to timing were not describing his understanding of Trump's knowledge, but rather his understanding of the matter.

Giuliani also clarified a comment he made about the firing of former FBI Director James Comey. He stated that Trump's dismissal of Comey was clearly within his Article II powers and was in the best interests of the nation. This clarification comes after Giuliani suggested that Trump fired Comey because he would not say that Trump was not a target of the Russia investigation.

Trump defended Giuliani, calling him a "great guy" who "just started days ago" and will "get his facts straight."

Title: NSA's Metadata Collection and Data Storage Efforts: A Growing Concern

The National Security Agency (NSA) has been collecting and storing vast amounts of metadata, including telephone call logs and email traffic, since the 9/11 attacks. Initially, the agency relied on major carriers to provide this data, but as concerns grew among phone and internet companies about customer backlash, the NSA began storing the data itself. This led to the construction of a massive data storage center in Utah, leveraging declining storage costs and advanced search software.

Industry experts describe these vast databases as "bit buckets," collections of electronic data waiting to be sifted through. However, many of these records remain untouched, with some experts estimating that most of the data is never examined. The NSA's ability to process and analyze the data has been a concern, with the agency seeking permission from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to hold onto the information for up to five years.

In 2009, the Obama administration wrote secret rules for collecting internet data, which were approved by the court. The rules allowed the government to retain electronic communications for up to five years, citing the limitation on the NSA's ability to filter communications. A private expert who advises the NSA on technology described this exception as "holding onto the ocean until you figure it out."

Title: The Iran Nuclear Deal: A Cautious Step Towards Peace or a Recipe for Disaster?

The recent nuclear agreement between six world powers and Iran has sparked intense debate about its implications for regional security and the Middle East. Critics have accused President Obama of "selling out" Israel, drawing parallels with Neville Chamberlain's appeasement of Hitler in the 1930s. However, a closer examination of the deal reveals a more nuanced picture.

Under the agreement, Iran has agreed to dismantle its nuclear program, including the destruction of 68% of its centrifuges and the reduction of its low-enriched uranium stockpile by 97%. The country has also agreed to not enrich uranium beyond 3.67% purity for 15 years and to redesign and rebuild its heavy water reactor at Arak to prevent the production of weapons-grade plutonium.

While some critics argue that Iran's history of deception and support for terrorism makes it impossible to trust the country to adhere to the agreement, others point out that the deal includes intrusive inspections and monitoring measures to ensure compliance. The United States and its allies have demanded regular and intrusive access to Iran's nuclear facilities, as well as its supply chains, and have imposed sanctions that will remain in place until the country meets its obligations.

The comparison to Neville Chamberlain's appeasement of Hitler is not entirely accurate. Chamberlain's deal with Hitler did not include intrusive inspections or sanctions, and it failed to address the root of the problem. In contrast, the Iran deal includes a robust inspection and verification mechanism to ensure that Iran is adhering to its commitments.

Moreover, the deal is not a "sell-out" of Israel. The United States has increased its military aid to Israel and has provided it with advanced missile defense systems, including Iron Dome. The deal also includes provisions for the United States to maintain its military presence in the region and to continue its support for Israel's security.

In conclusion, while the Iran nuclear deal is not perfect, it represents a cautious step towards peace and a reduction in the risk of war. It is a complex and nuanced agreement that includes intrusive inspections and monitoring measures to ensure compliance, and it is not a "sell-out" of Israel.

Title: Trump's Attempt to Clarify Helsinki Comments Met with Skepticism and Criticism

The media has largely dismissed President Trump's attempt to clarify his comments in Helsinki, with many labeling his explanation as unconvincing and even mocking it. Trump's statement, which acknowledged that Russia interfered in the 2016 election, was met with skepticism due to his explanation that he misspoke and meant to say "wouldn't" instead of "would." His demeanor during the press conference was also criticized, with some describing it as unenthusiastic.

Some media outlets, such as CNN and Slate, have been particularly critical of Trump's comments, with CNN's Erin Burnett calling his excuse a "dog ate my homework" alibi and Slate describing his walkback as "only a little less disgraceful" than his initial comments in Helsinki. The Washington Post offered a more nuanced analysis, noting that Trump's statement was a "dual message" that attempted to appease both those who want him to respect the nation's intelligence agencies and those who want him to challenge the status quo.

The article also highlights the differing reactions to Trump's comments, with some commentators accusing him of being a traitor and others viewing his actions as a minor mistake. The New York Times posed the question of whether Trump had reached a turning point or simply endured another episode that will fade away. The article concludes by noting that the media's criticism of Trump's comments has created a chasm between those who view him as a traitor and those who see him as a flawed but not treasonous individual.

Title: Scott Walker's Position on Ending Birthright Citizenship Remains Unclear

Article: Scott Walker, a former governor of Wisconsin and a presidential candidate, has been criticized for his unclear stance on ending birthright citizenship for children of undocumented immigrants. The issue has been a hot topic in recent weeks, with Donald Trump advocating for its repeal through constitutional amendment or court challenges.

Walker's initial response to the question was ambiguous, with him acknowledging that the issue is important but not taking a clear stance. In an interview with NBC's Kasie Hunt, he said, "I think that's something we should, yeah, absolutely, going forward... It's about enforcing the laws in this country." When pressed further, he emphasized the importance of enforcing laws and using E-Verify to stop job magnetism.

Walker's campaign later clarified his statement, saying that he believes in enforcing laws, keeping people from coming to the country, and addressing root problems to end birthright citizenship. However, many have criticized his response as unclear and evasive.

In a separate interview with CNBC's John Harwood, Walker said he was not taking a position on the issue, stating that it was important to secure the country's borders before addressing birthright citizenship. This lack of clarity has led to criticism, with some comparing his approach to Jeb Bush's reluctance to take a stance on the Iraq war.

Walker's campaign had previously announced a "reset" of his campaign, aiming to take on the Republican establishment and show that he, like Donald Trump, strongly opposes the status quo. However, his handling of the birthright citizenship issue has not provided a clear answer on his stance.

Title: TSA's Inefficiencies and the Case for Privatization

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) recently concluded a month-long contest aimed at improving the efficiency of airport security procedures, offering $15,000 in prize money to the best ideas. However, some critics argue that the agency's very existence is the problem, and that privatization could be a more effective solution.

Air travel has become a cumbersome experience since the 2001 attacks, with passengers required to present identification, undergo searches, and limit their carry-on luggage. Many consider the TSA's policies an invasion of privacy, while others see them as necessary for security. However, a report from the RAND Corporation reveals that air travel is incredibly safe, with more people dying in incidents related to mechanical failures than in security-related scenarios.

The TSA's performance in detecting explosives is also questionable. An internal agency report found that agents at two of the nation's busiest airports failed to detect fake bombs 60-75% of the time. In comparison, private screeners missed fake explosives only 40% of the time in 1990, when security technology was less advanced.

The TSA's poor performance can be attributed to its bureaucratic structure, which lacks the incentives to adapt, innovate, and cut costs. Unlike private firms, the TSA does not face the pressure of profit and loss, which drives innovation and efficiency. Instead, it seeks to expand its budget and demonstrate its importance to the government.

The TSA's recent contest may be an attempt to improve its public image, but it is unlikely to fundamentally change the agency's incentives. If the TSA were to rapidly improve speed and efficiency, it would likely lead to budget cuts and personnel reductions, which would undermine its own existence.

In conclusion, the TSA's inefficiencies and lack of incentives make it an ineffective solution for airport security. Privatization could be a more effective approach, as private firms face the pressure of profit and loss, driving innovation and efficiency.

Title: Obama's Hiroshima Visit: A Complex Journey Through History and Politics

The upcoming visit of President Obama to Hiroshima, Japan, has sparked controversy and raised questions about the historical context and potential implications of his trip. In 2009, President Obama expressed his vision for a world free of nuclear weapons, but since then, North Korea has continued to develop its nuclear arsenal. The visit is seen as an opportunity for the President to highlight the devastating effects of nuclear weapons, but critics argue that it may also perpetuate a one-sided narrative and undermine efforts towards Japanese-South Korean reconciliation.

According to Deputy National Security Adviser Ben Rhodes, the President's trip will focus on the loss of innocent lives, including those killed in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, as well as the overall toll of war on innocent people. However, some critics argue that the visit lacks historical context, omitting the 2,403 lives lost at Pearl Harbor and the millions of casualties spared by the rapid conclusion of World War II.

The visit may also be seen as an endorsement of Japan's view that the United States has chosen Tokyo over Seoul and accepts revisionist history depicting Japan as the victim. This could undermine efforts towards Japanese-South Korean reconciliation and perpetuate a narrative that ignores the historical context of World War II.

Instead of focusing solely on the end of nuclear weapons, some argue that President Obama should use his visit to emphasize the importance of standing together against totalitarian regimes that seek to impose their will on weaker neighbors. The visit presents an opportunity to reflect on the tragedy of Hiroshima not just as a result of a weapon of war, but also as a consequence of aggressive regimes and the wars they impose.

The visit is set to take place amidst a complex web of historical and political tensions, and its implications will be closely watched by observers around the world.

Title: Trump Signs Bill Striking Down Auto Lending Rule Aimed at Reducing Discrimination

The Trump administration has signed a bill repealing a rule aimed at reducing discrimination in auto lending, allowing dealerships to once again mark up interest rates on loans to sell cars. The rule, adopted by the Obama administration in 2013, prohibited dealerships from charging higher interest rates to minority borrowers. Critics argued that this practice was discriminatory, as black and Hispanic car buyers were paying higher interest rates than white buyers.

The rule was not a traditional regulation, but rather a guidance document explaining how the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would enforce the anti-discrimination provisions of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. The guidance was not subject to the normal regulatory process, and car dealers, lenders, and other interested groups did not have the opportunity to provide comments.

The Congressional Review Act allows Congress to review and repeal regulations, and the House and Senate voted largely along party lines to repeal the rule. The House voted 234-175 in favor of repeal, while the Senate voted 51-47. Democrats voted to keep the rule in place.

The repeal of the rule does not prevent the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau from issuing similar guidance in the future, but it would require specific authority from Congress. The move is the 16th time President Trump has signed a bill striking down a regulation under the Congressional Review Act.

Title: Tesla CEO Elon Musk Criticizes Media, Floats Idea of Website to Rate Journalists

Article:

Tesla CEO Elon Musk has expressed frustration with the media, taking to Twitter to criticize what he perceives as "holier-than-thou hypocrisy" among big media companies. Musk claimed that journalists are under pressure to generate clicks and advertising revenue, leading to a lack of credibility. He also floated the idea of creating a website, possibly called Pravda, where the public can rate the truthfulness of articles and track the credibility of journalists and news outlets.

Musk's comments come as Tesla faces scrutiny over recent crashes involving its vehicles. In one incident, a driver reported that the autopilot feature was engaged when the vehicle crashed into a truck at 60 mph. Musk responded by pointing out that the media gives more attention to a single Tesla crash than the thousands of accidents involving traditional vehicles.

Musk also responded to individual reporters, including one who compared him to President Trump. Musk argued that anyone who criticizes the media is labeled as "just like Trump," and that the media has lost its credibility. He encouraged journalists to focus on being truthful and earning the public's trust.

The idea of a website to rate journalists and news outlets is not new, but Musk's proposal has sparked debate. Some see it as a way to increase transparency and accountability, while others worry it could lead to censorship and a chilling effect on free speech. Tesla did not respond to a request for comment on Musk's remarks.

Title: White House Officials Confirm Vice President Pence's Presence Despite COVID-19 Concerns

The White House has confirmed that Vice President Mike Pence will be present at the White House today, despite earlier reports suggesting he would be working from home and self-isolating after an aide tested positive for COVID-19 last week. According to administration officials, Pence is voluntarily keeping his distance from other people, having repeatedly tested negative for the virus since his exposure.

The vice president's press secretary, Katie Miller, and President Trump's personal valet have both tested positive for COVID-19, with President Trump having had contact with both individuals in the past week. In response, the White House has implemented new guidelines, including testing anyone who sees the president, asking more staff members to work from home, increasing the use of masks, and beginning more rigorous screening of anyone who enters the White House grounds.

Senior White House Adviser Kevin Hassett acknowledged the risks of working in the White House, stating, "It's a small, crowded place. It's a little bit risky. But you have to do it because you have to serve your country." Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, however, assured that enough is being done to protect the president, saying, "I can tell you, this is probably the safest place that you can come to."

The White House has already instituted daily COVID-19 tests for the president and vice president, as well as those closest to Trump. Despite the concerns, President Trump expressed confidence, stating he is "not worried" about the virus spreading in the White House.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order Withdrawing US from Trans-Pacific Partnership, Focuses on Economic Growth and Jobs

President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday, formally withdrawing the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade deal. The move was a key campaign promise, with Trump describing the agreement as a "bad deal" and a "death blow for American workers." The withdrawal was made possible because Congress had not ratified the accord, despite strong support from business groups and former President Barack Obama.

The move is seen as a significant shift in the US's trade policy, with Trump emphasizing the need for better deals on a one-on-one basis. The president met with union leaders at the White House, receiving applause from ironworkers and sheet metal workers, and vowed to stop "ridiculous trade deals" that have taken jobs and companies out of the country.

Trump also signed executive orders freezing non-military federal hiring and reinstating the Mexico City Policy, which limits federal funding for abortions abroad. The move was met with opposition from liberal and pro-choice groups, who see it as a step backward for women's rights.

The president's focus on the economy and jobs continued with a breakfast meeting with business leaders, where he outlined a plan for massive reductions in taxes and federal regulations to spur economic growth. Trump emphasized the need to "make our products here again" and reduce the federal regulatory burden by 75%. He also plans to cut income taxes for middle-class families.

The withdrawal from the TPP has been met with mixed reactions from lawmakers. Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer, a Democrat, dismissed the move as meaningless, while Senator John McCain, a Republican, called it a "serious mistake" that will have lasting consequences for the US economy and its position in the Asia-Pacific region. Senator Bernie Sanders, an independent, welcomed the move, saying it was a step in the right direction for American workers.

The president is expected to sign an executive order in the coming days to begin renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, which he blames for the massive exodus of manufacturing jobs from the US since its implementation in 1994.

Title: Obama's Potential Pick for Secretary of State Faces Opposition from John McCain

Article:

President Barack Obama has not publicly announced his choice to replace Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State, but his recent defense of Susan Rice's integrity has sent a clear signal that she may be his top contender for the position. If that's the case, it would create a high-profile showdown between Obama and Senator John McCain, who has emerged as the loudest critic of Rice's potential nomination.

McCain has pledged to block Rice's nomination, citing her role as the public face of the White House's response to the 2012 Benghazi attack. He believes she either showed incompetence or was involved in a cover-up, as she initially stated that the attack was a spontaneous demonstration. However, CIA Director David Petraeus has testified that he immediately concluded it was a coordinated terrorist strike.

The Republican Party has 45 votes in the new Senate, enough to uphold a filibuster, but it's unclear if they will unite behind McCain's efforts to block Rice's nomination. Senator Lindsey Graham, McCain's closest ally, has expressed skepticism about blocking Rice, stating that he will listen to her record and context before making a decision.

Other Republican senators, such as Marco Rubio, have also declined to "pre-judge" Rice's potential nomination. Joe Lieberman, a senator who is leaving office in January, has also expressed support for Rice, stating that her statements on television were consistent with the intelligence community's information.

While McCain has been vocal in his opposition, it appears that the rest of the Republican Party is not yet united behind him. As a result, a Susan Rice nomination is likely to face opposition, but not necessarily a filibuster.

Title: Judge Rules Trump's Twitter Blocking of Critics Violates First Amendment

A federal judge in New York has ruled that President Donald Trump's practice of blocking Twitter users who criticize him violates the First Amendment. The decision was made in response to a lawsuit filed in July 2017 by the Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University, along with seven individual Twitter users.

U.S. District Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald ruled that Trump's actions, which have blocked several Twitter users who have been critical of him, are unconstitutional. The judge wrote that the "interactive space" where Twitter users can engage with the President's tweets is a designated public forum and that blocking users based on their political views constitutes viewpoint discrimination that violates the First Amendment.

The ruling states that the blocking of plaintiffs based on their political speech is a violation of the First Amendment, and rejects the White House's contention that the President's personal First Amendment interests supersede those of the plaintiffs. The decision does not address the White House's claim that Trump's tweets are official statements.

The lawsuit was filed after Trump blocked several Twitter users who had criticized him. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the ruling.

Title: Fox News' Election Coverage Criticized for Misinformation and Failure to Move the Needle

Article:

The 2012 presidential election has left some Republicans vowing to break their addiction to Fox News, which was touted as a sure thing for Mitt Romney's victory. Strategists believe it's crucial for the party to address its "choir-preaching problem" and venture beyond the comforts of the Fox News bubble. However, there is little indication that enough Republicans will have the courage or desire to break free from Fox's grip on branding the party.

Fox News' formula of slash-and-burn tactics worked wonders in catering to a hardcore, hard-right audience of several million viewers, with the network poised to post $1 billion in profits this year. However, in terms of supporting a national campaign and hosting a nationwide conversation about the country's future, Fox's work was a marked failure. This failure helped sink any hopes the GOP had of winning the White House.

The Republican primary, sponsored by Fox News, was underwhelming, and the general election campaign saw Romney damaged by embracing Fox News rhetoric. Romney's missteps, such as botching facts surrounding the Benghazi raid and parroting the "47 percent" talking point, were often accompanied by Fox misinformation. Romney's embrace of reality TV host-turned-Fox News pontificator Donald Trump also damaged his chances.

Fox viewers were also misled, fed a year's worth of misinformation about candidates and completely misinformed about the state of the race. Fox faithful were left crushed on Election Night when Romney's fictitious landslide failed to materialize.

The coverage of the campaign has been widely panned as an editorial and political fiasco. The coverage failed to move the needle in the direction of its favored Republican candidate and remained detached from campaign reality for months at a time. Republican strategist Mike Murphy urged Republicans to embrace a view of America that's not lifted from "Rush Limbaugh's dream journal." San Francisco Chronicle columnist Jon Carroll wondered if Romney's defeat marked the end of a Fox News era.

Conservatives should have thought twice about the long-term implications of having irresponsible media outlets like Fox supersede leadership within the Republican Party. However, as Fox News became the driving electoral force, candidates had to bow down to Fox in search of votes and coveted free airtime. The Republican Establishment is Rush Limbaugh, Roger Ailes, Karl Rove, and their ilk, who rule on talk radio airwaves and on the GOP's own "news" channel, Fox.

There is a reason New York magazine labeled Ailes "the head of the Republican Party." A GOP source told the magazine, "You can't run for the Republican nomination without talking to Roger. Every single candidate has consulted with Roger." This meant campaigns were forced to become part of the channel's culture of personal destruction and blanket themselves in Fox's signature self-pity.

Title: US and Mexico to Hold Talks Amid Threat of Tariffs and Border Crisis

The United States and Mexico are set to hold talks on Monday to address the threat of tariffs on Mexican imports and the ongoing border crisis. The discussions come after President Donald Trump announced his intention to impose a 5% tariff on Mexican imports starting June 3, citing the need to pressure the Mexican government to stem the flow of migrants crossing the border.

The tariff threat has sparked concerns among top officials, with Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney warning that the president is "deadly serious" about imposing the tariffs. However, it remains unclear what specific actions Mexico needs to take to satisfy the administration's demands.

Mexican Economy Minister Graciela Marquez will meet with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Monday, followed by delegations led by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Foreign Relations Secretary Marcelo Ebrard on Wednesday. The talks aim to address the border crisis and the potential tariffs, which could have significant economic implications for both countries.

The tariff threat has been met with skepticism by some, with Republicans on Capitol Hill and business leaders expressing concerns that it could harm the US economy and disrupt trade relations with Mexico. Senator John Kennedy of Louisiana called the tariffs a "mistake" and said it was unlikely Trump would impose them.

The US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which updates the North American Free Trade Agreement, is also at risk of being derailed by the tariff threat. Top Republicans have warned that the tariffs could harm the economy and undermine the agreement.

The border crisis has been a long-standing issue, with Trump repeatedly threatening to seal the border with Mexico. However, it remains unclear what specific actions Mexico needs to take to satisfy the administration's demands. The US Department of Homeland Security has suggested that Mexico could take steps to decrease the record numbers of migrants at the border, such as sealing its southern border with Guatemala and cracking down on domestic terrorist organizations.

Economists and business groups have warned that the tariffs could increase the costs of many Mexican goods that Americans rely on, but Mulvaney has played down those fears, saying he doubts businesses will pass on the costs to consumers. The tariff threat has also raised concerns about the potential impact on the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which is still awaiting approval in Congress.

Title: Iran Fires Missile at US Drone, Misses Target Amid Tensions Over Oil Tanker Attacks

Article:

The United States has reported that Iran fired a missile at a US drone on Thursday, but the attack missed its target. The incident occurred shortly after the MV Altair tanker sent out a distress signal amid the attacks the US says were perpetrated by Iran. The US military stated that the missile was a modified SA-7 fired from Iran's mainland.

According to a senior US official, the unmanned MQ9 Reaper drone arrived at the scene at 6:20 am local time, and the missile was fired at 6:45 am. The US military said that the drone was on station to assist the Norwegian-owned crude oil tanker.

Additionally, officials revealed that a US MQ9 drone was shot down in Yemen by Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in recent days.

The news comes amid heightened tensions in the region following the attack on oil tankers that put the US and Iran on the brink of a direct conflict. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has blamed Iran for the "blatant assault" on oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman, citing intelligence, weapons used, and recent similar Iranian attacks on shipping.

Pompeo stated that Iran is working to disrupt the flow of oil through the Strait of Hormuz and that this is a deliberate part of a campaign to escalate tension. He emphasized that the US would defend its forces and interests in the region.

President Trump also weighed in on the situation, stating that the attack had "Iran written all over it." He pointed to a video showing the Iranians removing an unexploded mine from one of the vessels, saying, "Iran did do it and you know they did it because you saw the boat."

The US military released a video and still photos showing the limpet mine on the Japanese-owned Kokuka Courageous, before a Revolutionary Guard patrol boat removed the mine. The incident has sparked concerns about the potential for further escalation in the region.

Title: Texas Representative Vicente Gonzalez Switches Support to Biden, Joins Growing List of Hispanic Lawmakers Backing the Former Vice President

Article:

Texas Representative Vicente Gonzalez has switched his support from Castro to Biden, joining a growing list of Hispanic lawmakers backing the former Vice President. Gonzalez's decision is seen as a significant blow to Castro's campaign, as it signals that not all Castro supporters will automatically follow him to the Warren campaign. Since Castro endorsed Warren, Biden's campaign has announced endorsements from a slate of former Castro supporters in Texas, including state Representatives Rafael Anchia, Ryan Guillen, Eddie Lucio III, Oscar Longoria, and Armando Martinez.

Biden's campaign has also received support from other prominent Texas politicians, including former San Antonio Mayor Phil Hardberger, state Senator Jose Menendez, state Representatives Rhetta Bowers and Garnet Coleman, and Dallas County Clerk John Warren. Additionally, he has received endorsements from Representatives Eddie Bernice Johnson, Marc Veasey, and Filemon Vela.

Biden is expected to campaign in Texas this week, with fundraisers scheduled in Dallas and Houston. He has consistently led in public polls in the state, even when two home-state candidates, Castro and former Representative Beto O'Rourke, were running. In CNN's December poll, Biden garnered 35% support, 20 points ahead of his nearest competitor.

Representative Gonzalez believes Biden has an undeniable appeal in Texas, citing his ability to bring people together around ideas that can be delivered. He expects Biden to win delegates in every congressional district and believes his brand of politics, which emphasizes unity and bipartisanship, resonates with Texans.

Gonzalez is the latest congressional Democrat from a battleground district to support Biden, following endorsements from Representatives Conor Lamb and Chrissy Houlahan of Pennsylvania, Elaine Luria of Virginia, and Abby Finkenauer of Iowa. The growing list of moderate Democrats backing Biden has been reported to be a result of fears that a more liberal nominee could cost them their seats in the 2020 election.

Title: The Founding Fathers Warned Us About Runaway Partisan Outrage, But We Didn't Listen

The Founding Fathers of the United States understood the dangers of political parties and factions, which they called "aggregations of selfish and greedy'self-interests'." They warned that these factions would "agitate the community with ill-founded jealousies and false alarms, kindle the animosity of one party against another." Unfortunately, their warnings have been ignored, and the consequences are now evident.

The article highlights the tendency for voters to prioritize loyalty to their party or faction over the country's interests. This can lead to a lack of cooperation and a focus on short-term gains rather than the common good. The author notes that the original American ideology emphasized the subordination of individual interests to the greater good, but this has been lost in the current political landscape.

The article also touches on the idea that voters often choose candidates based on superficial characteristics, such as race, gender, or accent, rather than considering their qualifications and policies. This can lead to disappointing results, as seen in the cases of Jimmy Carter and Barack Obama.

The author concludes that human nature is to blame for the current state of politics, as people tend to prioritize their own interests over the common good. The Founding Fathers' philosophy of politics as a collaborative process has been corrupted by lawyers and judges who prioritize their own interests over the greater good.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of the current state of American politics, highlighting the dangers of partisan outrage and the importance of prioritizing the common good.

Title: ObamaCare Signups Begin with Improved Experience, but Challenges Remain

The second round of ObamaCare signups has started, with the administration aiming to enroll 3 million Americans and re-enroll the roughly 7 million people who signed up in the fall of 2013. The Affordable Care Act (ACA) is facing new challenges from Capitol Hill and the federal court, but President Obama is urging consumers to review their options and potentially save money or find a better plan.

The enrollment period, which closes on February 15, has seen 77 new health insurance providers participating for 2015, indicating a business opportunity. The administration has set a goal of enrolling 9.1 million people in 2015, a 28% increase from the previous year.

The federal website, HealthCare.gov, has been revamped to handle last season's peak loads and beyond, with a simplified online application process and easier navigation. However, premiums for 2015 are a wild card, with prices varying dramatically from state to state.

The administration is seeking to lower expectations, with Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia M. Burwell stating that the sign-up season will be successful, even if it's only half as long as last year's. The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a legal challenge on the law's tax credits, which make premiums affordable for millions.

Despite the challenges, Americans don't seem to be giving up on the ACA. A recent survey found that 61% of respondents expect the law to be implemented in its current form or something near that. The administration is confident that the sign-up season will be successful, with Burwell stating that the tax credits will continue, at least for the time being.

The pool of potential customers is estimated to be 23-27 million people who don't have access to affordable coverage on the job. For those already signed up, coverage will renew automatically if they do nothing, but that may not produce the best result. Returning customers could miss out on lower-premium options and get stuck with outdated and possibly incorrect subsidies.

The sign-up period will be the first time that renewal has been tried for current customers, and it overlaps with tax-filing season. Current customers who got tax credits this year will have to file new tax forms to prove they got the right amount. Too much subsidy and their tax refunds will be reduced; too little, and the government will pay them.

Community-based counselors helping uninsured people say interest remains strong, but they worry about this year's abbreviated sign-up season. Nathalie Milias, who works with Haitian groups in Miami, said she has been feeling the demand since the summer as uninsured people approached her. "They see me in the store, they call," said Milias. "The locations I go to are already calling and saying, 'How many appointments do you want for Monday?'"

The sign-up period will be a crucial test for the ACA, as the administration seeks to improve the shopping experience and increase enrollment. Despite the challenges, the law remains a vital part of the healthcare landscape, and its future will be closely watched in the coming months.

Title: Dick Cheney Warns of "Deep Doo" in North Korean Crisis

The recent developments in and around North Korea have raised concerns among lawmakers and experts, with even former Vice President Dick Cheney expressing his concerns about the situation. According to sources, Cheney met with GOP lawmakers and described the crisis as "we're in deep doo." The situation has become so worrisome that even the mention of North Korea's unpredictable leader, Kim Jong Un, seems to have frightened even the most seasoned politicians.

The crisis has been escalating, with the Obama administration warning that North Korea may test-fire mobile ballistic missiles at any time. U.S. satellites are monitoring the Korean peninsula, and officials believe that the missiles have received their liquid fuel and are ready for launch. Japan has deployed missile defense systems around Tokyo, and some Chinese tour groups have canceled visits to North Korea.

Adm. Samuel J. Locklear, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, characterized the crisis as "a clear and direct threat to U.S. national security and regional peace and stability." The situation has left many wondering what North Korea's next move will be, with some experts suggesting that Kim Jong Un may not have left himself an exit door.

The U.S. government is preparing for any eventuality, with President Obama and his security team ready to respond forcefully in the event of a missile launch. The response would need to be clear and unequivocal, leaving no doubt that the administration means business.

Title: The Decline of the Civil Rights Movement: A Shift from Confronting Injustices to Extorting Contributions

The 50th anniversary of the March on Washington has sparked a reflection on the progress made in the fight for civil rights. While the original movement was a glorious triumph, the contemporary movement has become an intellectually exhausted and self-serving endeavor. The difference between the two is stark: the original movement confronted grave injustices, while the current movement is focused on imagined slights and manufactured controversies.

The original movement, led by figures like Martin Luther King Jr., was marked by great courage and moral authority. King's philosophy was rooted in his engagement with biblical prophets and Reinhold Niebuhr, and he believed that "unearned suffering is redemptive." He was a skilled orator and a practiced Baptist preacher who wedded the cadences of the Bible to the nation's founding ideals under the unbearable pressure of historic events.

In contrast, figures like Al Sharpton have built their careers on a catalog of the ridiculous and outrageous, seeking newspaper clips and cable TV appearances. Sharpton has been accused of defaming individuals and making inflammatory statements, including his infamous call to "pin their yarmulkes back and come over to my house" during anti-Jewish riots.

The contemporary civil rights movement has become a "fund-raising juggernaut," with organizations like the Congressional Black Caucus relying heavily on corporate donations. This shift from a movement focused on social justice to one focused on self-interest is a farce compared to the original movement's noble goals.

President Barack Obama's speech at the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington attempted to reach rhetorical heights by citing individuals serving the community, but ultimately fell flat. The real issue is that cultural breakdown has more to do with the struggles of blacks than any officially sanctioned discrimination. The left is reluctant to acknowledge this reality, and instead uses charges of racism to deflect uncomfortable conversations.

In conclusion, the contemporary civil rights movement has lost its way, prioritizing self-interest and manufactured controversies over the original movement's noble goals. The decline of the movement is a testament to its degeneration, rather than its continued relevance.

Title: Kerry Emerges as Front-Runner for Secretary of State Position

Article:

The United States is likely to see a familiar face take the reins as Secretary of State, with Senator John Kerry emerging as the top contender for the position. A senior State Department official confirmed that Kerry's appointment is the "working presumption," although White House officials emphasized that the deal is not yet finalized.

Kerry's potential appointment would mark a significant milestone, as he would be the first white man to hold the position since Warren Christopher left in 1997. His predecessors, Madeleine Albright, Colin Powell, Condoleezza Rice, and Hillary Clinton, have all been women.

Kerry's colleagues in the Senate have expressed confidence in his ability to navigate the confirmation process, with Senator John McCain already jokingly referring to him as "Mr. Secretary." Both men are Vietnam War veterans and worked together to secure diplomatic recognition for Vietnam.

The composition of President Obama's national security team has been a topic of discussion, particularly since the withdrawal of Susan Rice from consideration for the position. Rice is likely to remain as ambassador to the United Nations and may also succeed Tom Donilon as national security adviser. Donilon, however, does not intend to leave his post for at least a year or two, unless he is named White House chief of staff.

Other contenders for key positions include former Senator Chuck Hagel, who is likely to head the Defense Department, and acting CIA Director Michael Morell, who may be named to the position permanently. Michèle A. Flournoy, a former undersecretary of defense for policy, remains a candidate for the Defense Department, but Hagel's experience and reputation may give him an edge in winning votes from his former colleagues.

The article also highlights Kerry's diplomatic efforts, including his work with Hamid Karzai, the president of Afghanistan, and his visits to Pakistan to ease tensions. Kerry's ability to navigate complex diplomatic situations and build relationships with world leaders has impressed President Obama and his national security team.

Title: Clinton Campaign's Internal Documents Reveal Strategies for Influencing Media Coverage

The Clinton campaign's internal strategy documents and emails, obtained by a source identifying himself as Guccifer 2.0, have shed light on the campaign's efforts to shape media coverage to their advantage. The documents, which include emails and memos, reveal a deliberate strategy to cultivate relationships with journalists and influencers to promote favorable coverage.

The documents show that the Clinton campaign identified journalists they considered "friendly" and "reliable surrogates" to promote their message. These individuals included Maggie Haberman, then of Politico, now covering the election for the New York Times, and Hilary Rosen, a CNN contributor. The campaign also maintained a list of "progressive helpers" and "media figures" who could be targeted with messaging.

The documents also reveal that the campaign would often internally draft stories they wanted published and specify what should be quoted "on background" and what should be described as "on the record." In one instance, a January 2015 strategy document outlined a plan to induce Haberman to write a story on Clinton's decision-making process, which was later published in the New York Times.

The documents also highlight the campaign's use of off-the-record gatherings and intimate parties to build relationships with journalists and influencers. One such event, described in an April 2015 memo, was a cocktail party hosted by Clinton strategist Joel Benenson, which was designed to impart the campaign's messaging to leading news figures.

A separate email chain, not provided by Guccifer 2.0 but appearing on the DCLeaks.com site, contains plans for another off-the-record media get-together in May, where food and drinks were provided by the campaign on the condition that nothing said would be reported to the public.

The documents also reveal that the campaign employed tactics to shape coverage to their liking, including providing a constant stream of stories to journalists assigned to cover Clinton. As campaign manager Robby Mook noted in a March 2015 memo, a key strategy was to "give reporters who must cover daily HRC news something to cover other than the unhelpful stories about the foundation, emails, etc."

The authenticity of these documents has not been disputed, and the Clinton campaign has not responded to requests for comment.

Title: Pence Straddles Delicate Line as Trump's "Law and Order" Positioning Collides with Calls for Police Reform

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence has found himself navigating a delicate balancing act as the Trump administration responds to the growing movement to defund police departments. While President Trump has used the issue as a rallying cry against Democratic nominee Joe Biden, Pence has taken a more conciliatory approach, acknowledging the need for police reform and expressing empathy for those affected by systemic racism.

In a recent meeting with state attorneys general, police union representatives, and local sheriffs, Pence emphasized the importance of finding a balance between supporting law enforcement and addressing the concerns of those who feel marginalized and oppressed. The meeting underscored the challenge Pence faces in straddling the line between Trump's "law and order" positioning and the need for police reform.

Pence's approach has been shaped by his experience as Indiana governor, where he worked closely with African American pastors and business owners to address issues of racial injustice. One pastor who worked with Pence during his time as governor praised his willingness to engage in frank discussions about race relations and acknowledged that the economy alone cannot deliver racial justice.

However, Pence's past stance on police brutality has been criticized by some, who see his support for the "Blue Lives Matter" movement as a nod to Trump's tough-on-crime platform. Pence's absence from Trump's visit to St. John's Episcopal Church, where the president held up a Bible, also raised eyebrows among some White House officials and outside allies.

Despite these differences, Pence's allies argue that his ability to adapt to the times and modify his posture as needed could benefit the administration in this historic moment of social unrest. As the country grapples with the aftermath of George Floyd's death and the ongoing protests, Pence's willingness to listen and engage with affected communities may be a crucial factor in the administration's response.

Title: Nursing Homes Remain Most Vulnerable to COVID-19, Data Reveals

Nursing homes and long-term care facilities have been disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with at least 22 states reporting more than half of their reported COVID-19 fatalities occurring in these settings. According to data aggregated by the Foundation for Research on Equal Opportunity (FREOPP), a free market think tank, 42% of COVID-19 deaths across 39 states that report the location of deaths have occurred in nursing and residential care facilities. This figure may even be undercounting, as some states exclude deaths that occurred in hospitals but originated in assisted living facilities.

The data highlights the vulnerability of nursing home residents, who are often elderly or infirm, with many suffering from long-term ailments or weakened immune systems. The close living quarters and shared common spaces in these facilities also facilitate the spread of the virus. In addition, some states' early policy decisions, such as allowing nursing homes to accept patients with active COVID-19 infections, may have contributed to the spread of the disease.

In contrast, states like Florida have taken a more proactive approach, locking down nursing homes and prioritizing personal protective equipment (PPE) shipments to these facilities, which may have helped reduce the number of deaths. As states begin to reopen their economies, policymakers must adapt to the growing body of evidence about COVID-19 vulnerabilities and prioritize protecting the most vulnerable populations.

The concentration of deaths in nursing homes should give younger, healthier Americans more confidence about returning to normal life and inform public policy decisions about slowing the disease's spread. According to Avik Roy, president of FREOPP, the fact that nearly half of all COVID-19 deaths have occurred in long-term care facilities means that the 99.4% of the country that doesn't live in these places is roughly half as likely to die of the disease. This data has implications for policy-making as states look to safely reopen their economies.

Title: Media Matters Targets Sean Hannity's Advertisers Over Allegations Against Roy Moore

Article:

Media Matters, a left-wing activist group, has launched a campaign to pressure advertisers into pulling their ads from Fox News host Sean Hannity's show. The group is using allegations surrounding Alabama GOP Senate candidate Roy Moore's past behavior as a new weapon in their campaign. Moore is accused of making sexual contact with a 14-year-old girl while he was a 32-year-old attorney, as well as pursuing romantic relationships with other teenage girls around the same time.

Media Matters operatives are smearing Hannity to his sponsors, accusing him of defending child sex abuse. Hannity has explicitly stated that anyone guilty of what Moore is accused of doing has no place in politics.

As a result, several advertisers have pulled their ads from Hannity's show. Coffee company Keurig announced it would no longer run ads during the show, while Realtor.com said it would not be running ads on Hannity in the future. Another sponsor, 23andMe, stated it was not currently running TV ads on Hannity and would not be doing so in the future.

Media Matters has been targeting Hannity's advertisers for months, launching a "Stop Sean Hannity" campaign in August. The group published a list of Hannity's sponsors and urged left-wingers to let advertisers know that they "will get burned if they continue to associate with Hannity."

This campaign comes after Media Matters and other left-wing activists successfully pressured Fox News into firing Bill O'Reilly following sexual harassment allegations against the host.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Dismisses Democratic Demands for Live Testimony in Impeachment Trial

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has rejected demands from Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, for live testimony during the impending impeachment trial against President Trump. McConnell stated that Democrats in the Senate want to "clean up the House's mess" and are seeking to add to the "sloppy work" of the House Intelligence Committee Chairman, Rep. Adam Schiff.

According to McConnell, the House failed to pursue "useful witnesses" and did not want to wait for due process. He claimed that Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her colleagues threatened to impeach the president if they had to go to court to obtain evidence. The House's articles of impeachment, as they stand now, appear "inadequate to prove what they want to allege."

McConnell's remarks come after Schumer published a letter to the majority leader and held a press conference earlier this week, demanding live testimony from four key witnesses: White House acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, senior adviser Robert Blair, former National Security Adviser John R. Bolton, and associate deputy director Michael Duffey. Schumer stated that these witnesses have direct knowledge about President Trump's decision-making regarding the withholding of aid to Ukraine.

Schumer argued that conducting a trial without the facts is equivalent to saying that they are afraid and have something to hide. The two leaders are expected to meet soon to agree on rules and procedures for the trial, which is expected to begin next month.

Title: Kanye West Distances Himself from "Blexit" Campaign, Focusing on Creativity

Kanye West, the American rapper and fashion designer, has publicly distanced himself from the "Blexit" campaign, which aimed to encourage African Americans to leave the Democratic Party. In a series of tweets on October 30, 2018, West clarified that he was not involved with the campaign and had not intended to associate himself with it.

According to West, he was approached by Candace Owens, a black conservative who is a prominent advocate for the "Blexit" movement, to design a logo for the campaign. However, the designer who created the logo declined to be credited, and Owens used West's name instead. West emphasized that he had no involvement with the campaign and its goals.

The rapper's decision to distance himself from the "Blexit" campaign appears to have led to a broader shift in his stance on politics. In subsequent tweets, West expressed a desire to focus on his creative pursuits and emphasized that he is no longer involved in politics. He wrote, "My eyes are now wide open and now realize I've been used to spread messages I don't believe in. I am distancing myself from politics and completely focusing on being creative!"

West had previously outlined a political platform, which included supporting job creation, prison reform, common-sense gun laws, and holding those in power accountable. He also expressed support for those who risk their lives to serve and protect others, as well as those seeking asylum and parents fighting to protect their children from violence and war.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Names Members for Benghazi Committee

Article:

House Speaker John A. Boehner has appointed seven Republican members to the select committee on Benghazi, tasked with investigating the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic post in Libya that killed four Americans. The committee's chairman, Trey Gowdy, is a former prosecutor known for his tough questioning of former Internal Revenue Service official Lois G. Lerner. Gowdy has pledged to conduct a serious and fact-based investigation, stating, "This is a serious investigation. I don't want theater; I don't want a sideshow. I want the members of this committee to find the facts for the four families who lost their loved ones, and the facts for the American people."

The committee will explore security lapses leading up to the attack, the U.S. response to the attack, the Obama administration's initial effort to portray the attack as a mob uprising spawned by an anti-Islam video, and efforts to pursue the attackers. Some rank-and-file Democrats have praised Gowdy's selection, with Rep. Xavier Becerra, California Democrat and caucus chairman, calling him a "great prosecutor."

The committee's membership includes a mix of Republicans with different backgrounds and experiences. The two women appointed are Rep. Martha Roby, a second-term congresswoman from Alabama and a former lawyer, and Rep. Susan W. Brooks of Indiana, a former U.S. attorney who sits on the Homeland Security Committee. Other members include Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, a member of the oversight panel and a former chairman of the Republican Study Committee, and Rep. Peter J. Roskam, a member of the Ways and Means Committee.

Despite assurances from Boehner and Gowdy that the investigation will be fair and non-partisan, some Democrats have accused Republicans of using the tragedy as a political tool and to raise campaign money ahead of the midterm elections. Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Florida Democrat and chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, stated, "The bottom line here is that the Republicans have clearly lost the ability...to drive their turnout, because we've had such a precipitous drop among Republicans, even in their fervor for repealing the Affordable Care Act, that they are clearly doing this to drive their turnout."

Gowdy has reiterated his pledge not to use Benghazi to raise money and asked his colleagues not to do so either. However, he also pointed out that Democrats have raised money by using the bloody wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and the deadly aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

Title: Chicago Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson Requests Internal Investigation After Being Found Lying Down in Car

Chicago Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson has asked the department to conduct an internal investigation into his own actions after being found lying down in a car on October 17, 2019. A passerby discovered Johnson early in the morning and called 911, prompting police officers to check on his well-being. According to police department spokesman Anthony Guglielmi, officers did not observe any signs of impairment, and Johnson drove himself home.

Guglielmi stated that Johnson requested the investigation because he believes officers and the superintendent should be held to the highest standard. The investigation will involve interviewing officers and reviewing available evidence to ensure that the incident occurred as described.

Johnson, 59, underwent kidney transplant surgery in August 2017, and his son was the donor. He has since been hospitalized for a small blood clot in his lung and has been experiencing fatigue and blood pressure issues. The investigation comes as Johnson continues to recover from his medical issues and navigate his role as superintendent of the Chicago Police Department.

**Pope Francis Named Time Magazine's Person of the Year**

Time magazine has named Pope Francis its Person of the Year, citing his efforts to shift the message of the Catholic Church and capture the imagination of millions of people who had become disillusioned with the Vatican. This is the third time a pope has received this honor, with Pope John Paul II and Pope John XXIII being the previous recipients.

Pope Francis, the first non-European pope in 1,300 years, was chosen from a list of finalists that included former U.S. National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden and gay rights activist Edith Windsor. The selection was made by Time's editors, who considered suggestions from the magazine's over 2 million Twitter followers.

The magazine credited Pope Francis with elevating the healing mission of the church, focusing on serving and comforting those in need, rather than emphasizing doctrine. The pontiff's style is characterized by his frugality, having chosen to live in a small suite in a Vatican guest house instead of the spacious papal apartment.

Pope Francis has also been praised for his willingness to challenge traditional Catholic teachings, including his comments on homosexuality and his support for greater justice and peace. In a recent interview, he said the Vatican must shake off its obsession with teachings on abortion, contraception, and homosexuality and become more merciful.

However, some critics argue that more action is needed to address the Catholic Church's sex abuse scandals. Barbara Blaine, president of the Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests, said that while Pope Francis has announced a panel to consider ways to improve the screening of priests, more needs to be done to protect minors and help victims.

The cover of Time magazine's Person of the Year issue features Pope Francis, with a caption highlighting his ability to capture the imaginations of millions who had given up on the church.

Title: National Parks' Closure Due to Shutdown Affects Local Businesses in Texas and Beyond

The ongoing federal government shutdown has caused significant disruptions to national parks across the United States, resulting in economic losses for local businesses that rely heavily on tourism. In Terlingua, Texas, a small community near Big Bend National Park, the effects of the shutdown are already being felt.

The Big Bend Natural History Association estimates it will lose around $35,000 per week in sales from its bookstores in closed park buildings. The Far Flung Outdoor Center has reported six cancellations at its dozen cabins, while the owner, Greg Henington, worries that the uncertainty surrounding the shutdown will deter visitors from coming to the area.

The National Parks Conservation Association estimates that at this time of year, there are usually around 500,000 visitors to the nation's 400 parks, generating around $18 million daily for nearby communities. However, with the shutdown, many of these visitors are staying away, causing a significant impact on local businesses.

In Macon, Georgia, the Ocmulgee National Monument Native American site, which usually attracts around 157,000 visitors annually, has been closed, resulting in an estimated $9 million loss for the local economy. Similarly, the Hurricane Ridge Ski and Snowboard Area in Washington has remained closed due to a lack of staff to plow the road, resulting in a loss of around $5,000 per day in revenue and the furlough of 16 part-time workers.

The National Park Service has not commented on the situation, while the Small Business Administration did not respond to a request for comment. The National Parks Conservation Association estimates that the shutdown will continue to affect local businesses until a resolution is reached.

In the meantime, small business owners like Kathryn Petralia, co-founder of Kabbage, an online small business lender, are stepping in to provide loans to affected businesses. "They need every dollar that comes in the door," she said.

The shutdown has also caused a buildup of uncollected garbage and sewage in some national parks, with the National Park Service following a contingency plan to close areas if issues arise. The uncertainty surrounding the shutdown has left many business owners worried about the long-term impact on their operations.

Title: Cruz's Wisconsin Win Raises Concerns About GOP Unity and Trump's Prospects

Article:

Senator Ted Cruz's decisive victory in the Wisconsin Republican primary has sent shockwaves through the party, with the Texas senator consolidating his role as the "anti-Trump" in the presidential nomination race. Cruz won 48% of the vote, beating Donald Trump by 13 points, and secured most of the state's delegates. However, this win does not necessarily mean Cruz is uniting the Republican Party, as many of his supporters were motivated by anti-Trump sentiment rather than enthusiasm for his own candidacy.

The results show that more than half of Cruz's supporters and two-thirds of Ohio Governor John Kasich's supporters were "scared" of what Trump would do in the White House, highlighting the deep divisions within the party. Only a quarter of Cruz's own voters were excited about his presidency, suggesting that his support is largely driven by opposition to Trump.

The Wisconsin primary also revealed concerns about the Republican Party's ability to come together behind a single candidate. If Trump is the party's nominee against Hillary Clinton, only 61% of GOP primary voters said they would vote for him, while 19% would vote for a third-party candidate, 10% would vote for Clinton, and 8% would not vote at all. If Cruz were the nominee, 66% of Wisconsin Republicans would back him, 18% would vote third-party, 6% would vote for Clinton, and 6% would not vote.

The results also highlight the deep divisions within the party, with Trump inspiring rock-solid loyalty among a third of the GOP electorate, while many others are motivated by opposition to him. If Trump is not the nominee, many of his supporters say they will abandon the party altogether.

The next test for the party comes in two weeks with the New York primary, where Trump and Clinton will face off against each other. If either candidate underperforms, it will be clear that Wisconsin was a turning point, and both will be damaged but still on track to head to their respective conventions with the most delegates. The math is almost impossible to overcome at this stage in the race.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Appoints Special Counsel to Oversee Investigation into Trump-Russia Allegations

The Department of Justice has announced the appointment of former FBI Director Robert Mueller as the Special Counsel to oversee the investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump 2016 presidential campaign and the Russian government. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein made the announcement in a press release on Wednesday.

According to Rosenstein, his decision to appoint a Special Counsel was made in the public interest, as it is essential to ensure the integrity and independence of the investigation. He emphasized that his decision does not imply that crimes have been committed or that prosecution is warranted, stating that he has made no such determination.

Rosenstein emphasized that the appointment of a Special Counsel is a rare occurrence, as the Department of Justice typically handles tens of thousands of criminal investigations and other matters annually without partisan political considerations. However, he believes that the unique circumstances of this case require a Special Counsel to ensure the public's confidence in the outcome.

Special Counsel Mueller will have access to all necessary resources to conduct a thorough and complete investigation, and Rosenstein is confident that he will follow the facts, apply the law, and reach a just result. The appointment of Mueller is intended to ensure that the investigation is conducted fairly and without bias, upholding the principles of the rule of law and the public's trust in the government.

Title: YouTube Bans Gavin McInnes, Founder of Proud Boys, for Copyright Infringement

YouTube has removed the channel of Gavin McInnes, the founder of the Proud Boys, citing copyright infringement. McInnes had gained nearly a quarter-million subscribers on the platform. The move comes after McInnes had already been banned from various social media platforms, including Twitter and Facebook.

McInnes' social media presence has been controversial, with some criticizing his content as promoting white nationalism and extremism. In the past, he has been involved in high-profile incidents, such as a speech at a New York Republican club that ended in a brawl between his followers and left-wing activists.

The Proud Boys have been labeled as an extremist group by some, including the Washington state sheriff's office, which reported that the FBI considers them to be an extremist group with ties to white nationalism. However, the FBI has since clarified that they do not designate groups as extremist, but rather investigate individual threats of violence.

The controversy surrounding McInnes and the Proud Boys has led to him being dropped by The Blaze, a conservative media outlet, just days after it was announced he would be hosting a show.

Title: Theresa May Announces June 7 as Her Last Day as UK Prime Minister

Article:

Theresa May has announced that she will step down as the Conservative Party leader on June 7, bringing an end to her three-year premiership. The decision comes after intense pressure from her own party, particularly the 1922 Committee, which threatened to trigger a second vote of no confidence in her leadership if she did not resign.

May spoke in Downing Street, expressing her gratitude for the opportunity to serve the country and listing her government's achievements, including tackling the deficit, reducing unemployment, and boosting funding for mental health. However, she acknowledged that her failure to deliver Brexit remains a matter of deep regret.

The prime minister's announcement came after a meeting with Graham Brady, the chair of the 1922 Committee, and followed her recent speech outlining a new Brexit deal, which was met with criticism from Tory backbenchers and many of her own cabinet members. The leader of the House of Commons, Andrea Leadsom, resigned on Wednesday, and several cabinet ministers expressed concerns about May's plan to give MPs a vote on a second referendum.

The 1922 Committee will set out the terms of a leadership contest, which is expected to begin on June 10 and last around six weeks. The Conservative Party will elect a new leader, with the frontrunner being Boris Johnson, although more than a dozen senior Tory figures are considering throwing their hats into the ring.

May's departure comes after three years of wrangling with Brexiters on her own backbenches about what future relationship with the European Union they would be prepared to accept. Her failure to deliver Brexit has led to her resignation, with the deadline for the UK's departure from the EU looming on October 31.

The Conservative Party will now begin the process of electing a new leader, with the first round of voting expected to take place on June 13. The winner will be chosen by a combination of MP votes and a postal ballot of the party's 140,000 members.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Scandal Echoes Nixon's Watergate Scandal

The recent controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's email practices has drawn parallels to the Watergate scandal that brought down President Richard Nixon's administration 40 years ago. Bob Woodward, the journalist who broke the Watergate story, notes that the similarities between the two scandals are striking. Both involved the mishandling of classified documents, with Nixon's administration accused of covering up a break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters, and Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State.

Like Nixon, Clinton was once considered a shoo-in for her party's nomination, but her candidacy is now facing significant challenges. The controversy surrounding her email practices has led to open speculation that she could be held criminally liable for mishandling classified documents, a crime that has sent lesser-known individuals to jail.

Woodward, who was a young staffer in the Nixon White House during the Watergate scandal, notes that the parallels between the two scandals are eerie. Both involved the misuse of power and the cover-up of wrongdoing. In Nixon's case, the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters was followed by a cover-up that involved high-ranking officials in the administration. Similarly, Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State has raised questions about her handling of classified information.

The investigation into Clinton's email practices is ongoing, with the FBI and several congressional committees looking into the matter. While it is unclear what will ultimately be found, the parallels between the two scandals are striking. As Woodward notes, the digital age has made it easier for investigators to track down deleted emails and other digital evidence, making it more difficult for individuals to cover their tracks.

In the end, the outcome of the investigation will depend on what is ultimately found. However, the parallels between the two scandals serve as a reminder of the importance of transparency and accountability in government.

Title: Orange County's Shift from Republican Stronghold to Democratic Majority

The article discusses the significant shift in Orange County, California, from being the most Republican county in the United States to a Democratic majority. The author recounts their personal experiences and observations of the county's political landscape, noting that even in the 1990s, the county was still predominantly Republican. However, changes began to appear, and by the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton received more votes than Donald Trump.

The article highlights the county's demographics and economy, stating that the defense-based economy and demographics have changed, leading to a shift in politics. The author notes that Republicans struggled to overcome the liberal Democratic mayor in Irvine, but eventually succeeded a few years ago. However, the county government's latest voter-registration figures show that Democrats now have a slight registration advantage over Republicans.

The article also touches on the implications of this shift for the state as a whole, noting that California Republicans relied heavily on Orange County's Republican vote totals to balance out their disadvantage in other parts of the state. Without Orange County's strong Republican vote, Republicans are no longer competitive in statewide races.

The author concludes that the recriminations over the shift are pointless and that the GOP needs to face reality and come up with new strategies to stay relevant. The article notes that there are still issues that Republicans can tap into, such as road congestion, housing, and poverty, but the party's poor leadership and outdated thinking have gotten it nowhere.

Title: Florida Governor Rick Scott's Shift on Medicaid Expansion: A Nuanced Decision

Florida Governor Rick Scott, a vocal critic of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), has faced criticism from conservatives for his decision to accept federal funds to expand the state's Medicaid program. However, as Charles Krauthammer explained on "Special Report," the situation is more complex than it initially seems.

Governor Scott's decision to accept the Medicaid expansion funds is seen as a pragmatic move, as it would provide affordable health insurance to his constituents, particularly the elderly, who are a significant voting bloc in the state. This decision is in contrast to his previous stance, when he led the charge to repeal Obamacare in state and federal court.

While some conservatives are upset by Governor Scott's reversal, others argue that it is a necessary step to ensure access to healthcare for those who need it. The decision is also seen as a pragmatic one, as the federal government will foot the bill for the program 100%.

It is worth noting that Governor Scott is not alone in his decision. Several other states with conservative chief executives, such as Louisiana, Texas, and Wisconsin, have refused to participate in the Medicaid expansion program. However, Governor Scott's decision is seen as a significant departure from his previous stance, and some are questioning whether his change of heart is driven by his upcoming re-election bid.

Regardless of the motivations behind Governor Scott's decision, the fact remains that the Affordable Care Act is now the law of the land, and it is up to elected officials to navigate the complexities of implementing it.

Title: Trump's Plan to Shape Global Perceptions: A Shift in Media Strategy

Article:

In recent years, President Donald Trump has been vocal about his dissatisfaction with the media's coverage of his presidency. This sentiment is not surprising, given the numerous controversies and scandals that have surrounded his administration. To address this issue, Trump has taken steps to restrict his media consumption to sources that align with his views, such as Fox News. However, this approach has limitations, as it only reaches a specific audience and does not address the broader perception of his administration among the general public.

In an effort to shape global perceptions of his presidency, Trump has turned to the Voice of America (VOA), a federally funded news organization with an annual budget of $218.5 million. VOA broadcasts to 236.6 million people worldwide and plays a significant role in shaping impressions of the United States and its leaders in foreign countries. Prior to 2013, VOA exclusively served foreign audiences, but it became available domestically in 2013.

It is unclear whether Trump is aware of VOA's existence or if he chose to disregard it as an ineffective vehicle for disseminating propaganda about his work in Washington. However, it is clear that he is seeking a more direct means of shaping global perceptions. In January 2017, VOA's director, Amanda Bennett, stated that her team would "absolutely" not be "manipulated by the Trump administration." Despite this, Trump appears to be looking for a more controlled approach to media coverage, similar to those employed by Russia and North Korea.

It remains to be seen whether Trump's efforts to shape global perceptions will be successful. However, it is clear that his administration is taking a more proactive approach to media coverage, seeking to influence public opinion and shape the narrative around his presidency.

Title: Clinton Campaign Staff Received Heads-Up on Senate Investigation into Uranium One Deal

The email traffic between top staffers for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign and the Clinton Foundation has shed light on the routine and intimate interaction between the two entities. The emails, part of the hacked emails belonging to John Podesta, the chairman of Clinton's presidential campaign, were posted on the WikiLeaks website.

The email thread demonstrates the close communication between the campaign staff and the Clinton Foundation, with Maura Pally, the foundation's communications director, sending an email to Podesta on June 30, 2015, alerting him to a letter from Sen. Charles Grassley (R-IA) to Attorney General Loretta Lynch, dated June 30, 2015, asking questions about contributions to the Clinton Foundation and the Uranium One deal.

The letter from Grassley pointed out that nearly 25% of the country's uranium deposits were approved for sale to a Russian company, Rosatom, in a transaction that raised national security concerns. The transaction was approved quickly, with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) conducting a review, which included the Secretary of State and the Treasury Department.

The email thread also highlights the close ties between the Clinton Foundation and the Obama Administration, with the Clinton Foundation and the Obama Administration entering into a memorandum of understanding that required donations to be disclosed. However, millions of dollars in donations to the Clinton Foundation from executives with an interest in the Uranium One/ARMZ transaction were not disclosed, breaching the agreement.

The email exchange also raises questions about the role of the Department of Justice in the Uranium One/ARMZ transaction and whether Secretary Clinton's relationship with the Clinton Foundation required her to recuse herself from the CFIUS review.

Title: Trump Pardons Conservative Commentator, Considers Pardons for Martha Stewart and Rod Blagojevich
