The history of police misconduct investigations and reforms in the United States is a long and complex one, with various commissions and task forces convened over the years to address concerns about police brutality and violence. The Lexow Committee, established in 1894, was the first major investigation into police misconduct in New York City, with complaints primarily centered around "clubbing" - the use of nightsticks or blackjacks to bludgeon citizens.

The Wickersham Commission, convened in 1931, examined the criminal justice system and the problem of Prohibition enforcement, and found a lack of professionalism among police officers. The Kerner Commission, established in 1967, investigated the urban uprisings and found that police actions were a "final incident" before the outbreak of violence in 12 of the 24 surveyed disorders. The commission's report included recommendations such as building community support for law enforcement and reviewing police operations in the ghetto to ensure proper conduct.

Despite these commissions and reports, police violence and misconduct continued, with calls for reform following the brutal police beating of Rodney King in 1991 and the killings of Michael Brown and Eric Garner. The Obama administration's President's Task Force on 21st Century Policing resulted in procedural tweaks such as implicit-bias training, police-community listening sessions, and slight alterations to use-of-force policies and systems to identify potentially problematic officers early on.

However, even some members of the task force have questioned the effectiveness of these reforms, with Tracey Meares stating in 2017 that "policing as we know it must be abolished before it can be transformed." The philosophy behind these reforms is that more rules will mean less violence, but police officers continue to break rules, as seen in recent incidents where officers have been caught on camera slashing tires, shoving elderly men, and arresting and injuring journalists and protesters.

Title: Democrats Unveil Ambitious Plan to Decarbonize US Energy Sector

The Democratic Party has unveiled a comprehensive plan to decarbonize the US energy sector, aiming to achieve 100% zero-carbon power with escalating requirements starting immediately. The plan includes new requirements for states to submit plans showing how they will meet net-zero emissions targets, as well as increased financial support for low-carbon buildings codes and infrastructure.

The plan also includes stronger vehicle emissions rules, support for electric vehicle infrastructure, and a "buy clean" program to spur decarbonization of energy-intensive manufacturing. Additionally, the oil-and-gas industry will be mandated to deeply cut methane emissions.

Energy and Commerce Chairman Frank Pallone expressed skepticism about Republican support for the plan, stating that most GOP lawmakers are climate deniers. However, he emphasized that the plan is designed to be achievable without carbon pricing, although it does include provisions for power companies to buy and trade clean energy credits.

The plan also notes that states that do not submit or receive approval for their net-zero plans will be subject to a backstop carbon fee. Some environmental groups, such as the Sunrise Movement and Friends of the Earth, have expressed disappointment with the plan, citing a lack of ambition and a failure to address the scale and scope of the climate crisis.

The plan is seen as a step in the right direction by some, but it remains to be seen whether it will be enough to address the urgent need for climate action.

Title: Education Department Under Trump Closes Title IX Complaints Faster Than Under Obama

The Education Department under President Donald Trump has been resolving Title IX gender-discrimination complaints against universities and colleges at a significantly faster pace than during the Obama administration, according to federal data released under the Freedom of Information Act. The data shows that the average length of an open complaint under Trump was 88 days, compared to 150 days under Obama.

The Trump administration's desire to quickly wrap up these investigations, which often involve alleged sexual assaults on campus, reflects years of protest from universities and some conservative groups that the Obama administration was using individual assault cases to open broad, years-long investigations into university practices. Under Obama, Title IX complaints that closed between 2010 and 2016 had remained open an average of 150 days. In 2017, when Trump took office, the average length of an open complaint was 88 days. Cases opened in the first four months of this year were resolved after an average of 39 days.

The Education Department under Secretary Betsy DeVos opted to end an Obama-administration practice of broadening individual student complaints to look for systemic issues in how schools were handling sexual assault and harassment. Schools often complained that the inquiries were excessive or unfair. Peter McDonough, general counsel of the American Council on Education, which represents university presidents, said the policy under Obama created a "perception that investigators had to find something...And on campuses, it became seen as a 'gotcha' game."

Civil-rights advocates disagreed, saying Obama's more expansive approach drilled to the root of discrimination. Catherine Lhamon, who headed the Education Department's civil rights office in Obama's second term, said the only times the department opened broader cases were for high-profile investigations involving Michigan State University and the University of Southern California. Both cases featured much-publicized medical faculty members accused of assaulting numerous patients.

The data, released to The Wall Street Journal, contain all Title IX complaints against colleges and universities between 2010 and early May of this year. Under Trump's administration, the percentage of investigations ending in resolution agreements, which lay out policy changes for the institution and include a monitoring period, also fell. Nearly one in 12 cases ended in resolution agreements during Obama's tenure, compared with closer to one in 50 under Trump.

Most complaints that didn't reach resolution agreements were dismissed, though the Trump administration has also dismissed a higher number of cases, the Journal found. More than 90% of the cases since 2017 have been dismissed, while in the six years prior, that figure was closer to 67%. The Education Department can dismiss a case because the department determines it lacks jurisdiction or if it finds the allegation fails to state a violation, lacks sufficient detail, or is speculative or incoherent. The Journal's data don't indicate the justification for individual case dismissals.

Liz Hill, an Education Department spokeswoman, said resolving complaints without long delays is a priority for the Office for Civil Rights. "Part of what makes OCR's mission meaningful is that OCR weighs in on crucial civil-rights issues in a timely way...Without an effort at timely resolution, a student complaining of civil-rights violations in, say, middle school might not get an answer from OCR until he or she has graduated from high school."

The administration has more broadly been looking to change the department's approach to enforcement of Title IX, the 1970s-era law prohibiting gender discrimination in educational settings. In September, Mrs. DeVos rescinded a controversial Obama-era policy that directed schools to use a standard of evidence that was less rigorous than some schools had been employing. The administration hopes to release its own set of rules as early as September, and Education Department officials may mandate a higher standard of evidence, according to people familiar with their conversations.

Title: Hillary Clinton Names Policy Team, Including Maya Harris, to Focus on Women of Color

Article:

Hillary Clinton has announced a trio of policy leaders to help shape her 2016 presidential campaign. Two of the team members, Jake Sullivan and Ann O'Leary, were expected choices, given their previous roles as top aides to Clinton during her time at the State Department and in her Senate office. The third member, Maya Harris, is a lesser-known figure, but her expertise in policy and her research on women of color may prove crucial to Clinton's efforts to build a coalition.

Harris, a law professor and senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, has written a paper titled "Women of Color: A Growing Force in the American Electorate." In it, she argues that politicians and strategists often overlook the concerns of women of color, treating them as a subset of broader groups, such as women or youth. Harris contends that women of color are a rapidly growing voting bloc and that any politician seeking to win their support must prioritize their interests on the policy agenda.

The paper also highlights the significance of women of color in future elections. Harris notes that women are the largest voting bloc in the country, and women of color represent 74% of the growth in eligible women voters since 2000. Moreover, women of color are not only eligible to vote but also tend to vote at higher rates than men, with African-American women voting at higher rates than anyone.

While Harris's paper does not delve into specific policy proposals to win over women of color, her basic political theory suggests that Clinton's campaign may focus on giving women of color reasons to turn out and vote. This approach could differ from Obama's 2008 campaign, which aimed to appeal to a broader coalition. Clinton's campaign may prioritize policies that directly address the concerns of women, including women of color.

The hiring of Harris as a policy adviser sends a signal that Clinton intends to prioritize the interests of women of color in her campaign. With a majority of the electorate being female and a majority of voters of color being female, Clinton can work to make policy appealing directly to women in a way Obama could not.

Title: Oprah Winfrey's Potential Presidential Run Gains Momentum After Golden Globes Appearance

Oprah Winfrey's longtime boyfriend, Stedman Graham, has fueled speculation about her potential presidential run in 2020, stating that if called upon, she would serve as president. Graham's comment comes after Winfrey's powerful speech at the Golden Globes, where she referenced the #MeToo movement and civil rights, sparking widespread speculation about her political aspirations.

During her acceptance speech for the Cecil B. DeMille Award, Winfrey spoke about the importance of women's voices being heard and believed, saying "their time is up." The speech was met with applause from A-list celebrities and sparked a flurry of tweets from liberal commentators and celebrities, with many calling for her to run for president in 2020.

NBC network and celebrities have dubbed Winfrey "our future president" following her appearance, and even host Seth Meyers joked about her running for office during the Golden Globes ceremony. Meyers' joke was met with a tweet from NBC, which was later deleted, stating "nothing but respect for OUR future president."

Winfrey's speech and appearance at the Golden Globes have sparked widespread speculation about her political ambitions, with many believing she would be a strong candidate. While no official announcement has been made, Graham's comment suggests that Winfrey would be willing to consider a presidential bid if called upon.

Title: Huawei's Chief Financial Officer Detained in Canada, Faces Extradition to the US

The chief financial officer of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei, Meng Wanzhou, has been detained in Canada, sparking concerns about the potential implications for the US-China trade war and the global technology industry. Meng, the daughter of Huawei's founder, was arrested on December 1, but the news was not made public until recently, at her request.

The charges against Meng remain unknown, but the US has been investigating Huawei over possible violations of sanctions against Iran. Huawei has denied any wrongdoing, stating that it has complied with all applicable laws and regulations where it operates.

The arrest has sent shockwaves through the global markets, with European shares hitting a two-year low and Asian indexes dropping sharply. The incident has also revived concerns about the US-China trade war, with some analysts warning that it could escalate tensions between the two nations.

Beijing has condemned the detention, calling it a violation of human rights and demanding that Canada and the US clarify the reasons for the arrest and release Meng. The Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson stated that the detention "violates a person's human rights" and that Beijing has made "solemn representations" to both countries.

The arrest comes as Huawei faces increased scrutiny over its ties to the Chinese government and concerns that its technology could be used for spying. The US has blocked the use of Huawei's equipment in infrastructure for new 5G mobile networks, citing national security concerns.

A bail hearing for Meng has been set for Friday, and her extradition to the US is possible. The incident has significant implications for the global technology industry, with Huawei being one of the largest telecommunications equipment and services providers in the world.

The arrest has also sparked a heated debate on social media, with some users criticizing the US and Canada for what they call "bullying" tactics, while others have expressed concerns about the potential risks of Huawei's technology.

Title: Trump's "America First" Doctrine Sparks Concerns of Isolationism Abroad

The recent inaugural address of US President Donald Trump has sparked concerns among world leaders and experts about a potential shift towards American isolationism. Trump's emphasis on "America First" has been interpreted as a rejection of the country's traditional role as a global leader and a champion of international cooperation.

In his inaugural address, Trump outlined a vision of a world where foreign relations are reduced to a zero-sum game, where gains for one country come at the expense of another. He stated that the wealth of the American middle class has been "ripped from their homes and then redistributed all across the world." This rhetoric has been seen as a departure from the country's historical commitment to supporting friends and opposing foes, as enshrined in John F. Kennedy's inaugural address.

The phrase "America First" has a historical connotation, dating back to the 1930s when it was used by Charles Lindbergh to advocate for American neutrality during World War II. While Trump may not have been aware of this reference, it has been noted by world leaders and experts, who are concerned about the implications of this doctrine.

Some have argued that Trump's "America First" stance is simply a negotiating tactic to secure better trade deals or alliances. However, experts point out that this is not a one-off statement, but rather a deliberate and carefully crafted part of Trump's philosophy. The inaugural address was three weeks in the making, and Trump prefaced his "America First" proclamation with a statement that a new vision will govern the country.

The article highlights the historical context of American foreign policy, citing the Marshall Plan and the country's role in stabilizing Western Europe during the Cold War. It argues that Trump's vision misunderstands the logic behind this policy, which was not simply altruistic, but rather an exercise in enlightened self-interest.

The article concludes that Trump's "America First" doctrine is a departure from the country's historical commitment to global leadership and cooperation. The withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership is seen as the first fruit of this doctrine, and experts warn that it will have far-reaching consequences for the country's relationships with other nations and the global economy.

Title: Rubio's Political Future in Jeopardy Amidst Controversy Over Immigration Reform

Article:

Marco Rubio's political future is facing scrutiny after a series of headlines and criticisms from prominent conservative media outlets and thought leaders have raised questions about his involvement in the Gang of Eight immigration reform bill. The senator's association with the bill has led to accusations of undermining the conservative cause and lying like Democrats.

The bulk of the criticism comes from prominent conservative media outlets such as Breitbart.com, RedState.com, The Daily Caller, and the Washington Examiner, as well as thought leaders in the conservative movement. They have accused Rubio and his staff of "doing something the Democrats are salivating over," "undermining the cause," and "lying like Democrats."

In a recent piece for National Review, Rich Lowry portrayed Rubio as a "rank amateur" used as a "conservative Hispanic human shield" by Democrat mastermind Chuck Schumer. This criticism is not limited to conservative media outlets, as Rubio's staff has also faced backlash for their handling of the issue.

Rubio's spokesman, Alex Conant, recently sparked controversy by comparing the plight of those who voluntarily broke the law by coming to the United States to those who were forcibly brought here against their will via slavery in the 18th and 19th centuries. Conant's remarks were widely criticized on the Right, with many viewing them as an attempt to label those who believe in enforcing immigration laws as racists.

The controversy has led some to question whether Rubio has the political acumen to become a viable presidential candidate in the future. With his staff's handling of the issue only making things worse, Rubio's political future is now in jeopardy.

Title: Iowa Republican Convention Marred by Rancor and Division

The Iowa Republican State Convention, held on Saturday, was marked by tension and disagreement among party activists, with supporters of Texas Rep. Ron Paul dominating the proceedings. The event saw 21 of the 25 delegates up for a vote pledging their support to Paul, leaving many concerned about the party's image and the state's first-in-the-nation caucus status.

The convention was characterized by heated debates and calls for unity, with some speakers urging attendees to deliver the swing state to Mitt Romney. Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley and State Party Chairman A.J. Spiker both called for unity, but Spiker failed to mention Romney's name during his speech.

Prominent blogger Craig Robinson, who was undecided during the caucus season, expressed concerns about the division within the party, stating that it does not seem like the Iowa GOP is acting like a majority party. However, Jeff Taylor, a Paul supporter and newly chosen national delegate, believes that internal disagreements can be beneficial for the party.

The outcome of the convention does not necessarily reflect the results of the Iowa caucuses, where Paul came in third place. The unbound delegates, who can vote for any candidate at the national convention, will make up all but a handful of Iowa's 28 delegates going to Tampa. The situation may lead to a contentious national convention in Florida this summer.

Title: Canadian Parliament Unanimously Rebukes President Trump for Disparaging Remarks Against Prime Minister Trudeau

The Canadian House of Commons has passed a motion unanimously rejecting "disparaging ad hominem statements by U.S. officials," specifically targeting President Trump and his advisors for their criticism of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau following the G-7 summit in Montreal. The motion, proposed by MP Tracey Ramsey, condemned the "deliberately divisive actions" of the U.S. president and emphasized the importance of maintaining a united front against the tariffs imposed by the U.S. on Canadian steel and aluminum products.

The motion was passed on Monday, following President Trump's criticism of Prime Minister Trudeau over the weekend. Trudeau had vowed to retaliate against the tariffs, stating that Canadians are "polite, reasonable, but we also will not be pushed around." Trump responded by calling Trudeau "dishonest" and "weak" on Twitter, and his surrogates amplified the attack during media appearances.

The Canadian Parliament's measure also expressed opposition to the "illegitimate tariffs imposed by the U.S. government against Canadian steel and aluminum workers" and solidarity with the Government of Canada's decision to impose retaliatory tariffs. MP Ramsey emphasized the importance of unity during this difficult moment in Canada-U.S. relations, stating, "At this difficult moment in our history with our U.S. neighbors, Canadians need to know that all sides of this House stand united as one."

Title: FBI's Top Agent on Trump-Russia Investigation Suggests No Evidence of Collusion in Text Message

The FBI's top agent on the Trump-Russia investigation, Peter Strzok, sent a text message in May 2017 that suggests he had no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. The message was revealed by Wisconsin Sen. Ron Johnson, the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, during a radio interview on Tuesday.

In the text, Strzok wrote: "You and I both know the odds are nothing. If I thought it was likely, I'd be there no question. I hesitate in part because of my gut sense and concern that there's no big there there." Johnson described the message as "jaw-dropping" and said it referred to the Mueller investigation, which had just begun two days earlier.

Strzok was removed from the investigation in July 2017 after the Justice Department's inspector general discovered his anti-Trump text exchanges with FBI lawyer Lisa Page, his mistress. Strzok was the FBI's deputy counterintelligence chief and was picked in July 2016 to oversee the investigation into possible Trump campaign collusion with the Russian government.

Johnson said that the text message is significant because it shows that Strzok, who was a top investigator on the Clinton email inquiry, had doubts about the investigation and did not believe there was any significant evidence of collusion. The text was included in 400 pages of messages exchanged between Strzok and Page, which lawmakers are reviewing for evidence of anti-Trump and pro-Clinton bias.

The FBI has acknowledged that it failed to preserve five months' worth of text messages exchanged between Strzok and Page, citing a "misconfiguration" issue with their mobile devices. The agency does not have text messages for the period between December 14, 2016, and May 17, 2017, the day Mueller was appointed.

Johnson said that Congress needs to see the missing text messages because Strzok and Page were "completely unguarded in their communication" and may implicate others in corruption.

Title: House Republicans Issue Subpoenas to Treasury Department and State Department

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, chaired by Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.), has issued subpoenas to the Treasury Department and State Department for documents related to the IRS's targeting of conservative groups and the 2012 Benghazi attack. The subpoenas were issued on Friday and give the departments until August 16 to respond.

The Treasury Department is being asked to provide hundreds of thousands of pages of documents related to the IRS's targeting of conservative groups, including any communications between the White House and IRS or Treasury Department on the effort. The State Department is being asked to provide information related to the September 11, 2012, attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador to Libya J. Christopher Stevens.

Rep. Lamar Smith (R-Texas), chairman of the Science, Space and Technology Committee, also issued a subpoena to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as part of its probe into the "secret science" behind the agency's Clean Air Act regulations. The subpoena demands that the EPA turn over unreleased public health studies conducted by Harvard University and the American Cancer Society, which were used to develop regulations on particulate matter and ozone.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has been investigating the IRS's targeting of conservative groups since May, and has received only a fraction of the over 600,000 pages of documents initially identified as related to the scandal. The committee has also been investigating the Benghazi attack since 2012, and has received access to 25,000 pages of documents from the State Department. However, congressional investigators are not allowed to retain the documents, which are carted in and out of the Capitol each day.

The committee's chairman, Rep. Darrell Issa, has accused the Treasury Department of engaging in a "systematic effort to delay, frustrate, impede, and obstruct the Committee's investigation." The Treasury Department has responded that it has made 70,000 pages of documents available to the committee, with more than 70 IRS lawyers working on processing the information requests by Congress.

The Science Committee's subpoena to the EPA is the first in over two decades, and is part of its probe into the "secret science" behind the agency's Clean Air Act regulations. The committee has been seeking information from the EPA since September 2011, but has been unsuccessful in getting the information it needs.

Title: Trump's Shift to Good Cop: A New Era in Foreign Policy?

Article:

President Donald Trump has been known for his bombastic and confrontational approach to foreign policy during his first 15 months in office. However, with the appointment of his new team of foreign-policy hardliners, including Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, National Security Adviser John Bolton, and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, Trump may be poised to adopt a more diplomatic and conciliatory approach.

Trump's past behavior has been characterized by his "bad cop" persona, where he would often make bold and aggressive statements, such as his criticism of NATO members' contributions and his labeling of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un as "short and fat" and "rocket man." However, his appointees, including former national-security adviser H.R. McMaster and former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, played the role of "good cop," working to soften the edges of Trump's rhetoric and find common ground with international partners.

The new team's tough reputations may allow Trump to shift his approach and become the "good cop," emphasizing his deal-making skills and willingness to find compromises. This could be beneficial for several reasons. Firstly, it would align with his campaign promises to avoid entangling overseas interventions, which resonated with his swing-state, blue-collar supporters. Secondly, it would allow him to use his "art-of-the-deal" style to find common ground between adversaries, such as the Chinese, North Koreans, and Iranians. Finally, it would enable him to join forces with Defense Secretary James Mattis, who has been seen as a voice of caution and moderation, to pose as a unified voice of caution seeking agreements rather than confrontations.

While it is unclear whether Trump will indeed adopt this new approach, his past behavior suggests that he may be willing to adapt and change his tactics. With his new team in place, Trump may be able to outsource his hawkishness to Bolton and Pompeo, reminding enemies that his compromising nature is their last chance at an agreement.

Title: Obama Defends TPP Deal, Urges China to Adopt Similar Standards

Article:

In his weekly address to the nation, U.S. President Barack Obama defended the newly concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade deal, which excludes China. The 12-country accord, concluded after five years of negotiations, features the strongest labor and environmental standards in history, according to Obama. The deal aims to level the playing field in international trade and could be the largest regional trade pact ever once approved by all signatories.

Obama emphasized that the TPP will encourage investment and press China to shape its behavior in commerce, investment, and business regulation to TPP standards. The deal spans about two-fifths of the global economy and marks one of Obama's key diplomatic and economic achievements.

The TPP aims to set the rules for 21st-century trade and eliminate tariffs on a wide range of goods, including beef, dairy products, wine, sugar, rice, horticulture, and seafood, as well as manufactured products, resources, and energy. The countries involved in the deal are the US, Canada, Japan, Australia, Brunei, Chile, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, and Vietnam.

However, the deal has faced opposition from activists, who argue it favors big business over consumers and governments. US congressional leaders have also expressed reservations, and Hillary Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner in the 2016 presidential election, has come out against the deal. Clinton stated that, given what she knows about the deal, it falls short of her "high bar" for creating American jobs, raising wages, and advancing US national security.

Title: Students' Lives Altered by Reality of School Shootings

In the aftermath of the recent mass shooting at a Texas high school, students at Mount Pleasant Community High School in Iowa are reevaluating their safety in the cafeteria. Calysta Wilson and Courtney Fletcher, both juniors, are particularly concerned about their usual seating arrangement, which is closest to the doors. They believe that if a gunman were to enter the room, they would be among the first targets.

This heightened awareness of school violence is a new reality for many high school students. The frequency of mass shootings across the country, including the recent incidents in Florida and Texas, has led to a shift in students' conversations from "this could never happen here" to "what do we do when this happens?"

Students who have grown up with the persistence of mass shootings and have participated in active shooter drills are now constantly thinking about the possibility of a shooting in their schools. They consider the safety of their classrooms, calculating escape routes and hiding spots in wide-open rooms. Some students even run scenarios in their heads about how likely they are to get shot.

Since the Sandy Hook Elementary School mass shooting in 2012, there have been over 200 school shootings nationwide, including the recent rampage in Parkland, Florida, which inspired a youth-led movement to reform gun laws. As a result, students are discussing the location of doors and windows in their classrooms as risk factors and calculating escape routes.

For some students, like Emily Rubinstein, a sophomore at a New York high school, the reality of school violence has become a constant concern. She considers her English classroom the safest, with only one door and a difficult-to-find hallway. However, she is more exposed in math class, sitting in the second desk of the second row, in a direct diagonal path from the door.

Despite these concerns, Emily and many other students have not let their fears affect their schoolwork, friendships, or extracurricular activities. They have learned to adapt to the new reality of school violence and are taking steps to prepare for the worst-case scenario.

Many schools have taken proactive measures to prepare for an active shooter situation. A 2016 report from the United States Government Accountability Office found that two-thirds of school districts conduct exercises to prepare for an active shooter. Some schools, like Bartlesville High School in Oklahoma, have held regular safety drills and lockdowns since 2012, while others, like Spring Mills High School in West Virginia, have conducted "code red" lockdowns to test staff preparedness.

Title: Biden's Strong Showing in Midterm Primaries Suggests He's the Likely Democratic Nominee

Article: The recent primaries in six states across the Midwest, South, and Northwest have solidified former Vice President Joe Biden's position as the likely Democratic nominee to take on President Donald Trump in the November election. While Biden did not win every contest, his victories in Michigan, Illinois, Ohio, and Arizona, along with his expected wins in upcoming states, will likely give him an insurmountable delegate lead over Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders.

The results on Tuesday night confirm what has been clear since Super Tuesday: Biden is doing better than Hillary Clinton did in 2016, while Sanders is performing worse. The Mississippi results, in particular, showed a similar pattern to the 2016 election, with the more centrist candidate winning with around 80% of the vote, while the insurgent democratic socialist finished in the mid-teens.

Sanders' weakness has been evident since the 2016 election, and it has been exacerbated by his lack of support among ideologically moderate black voters in the South. Additionally, his campaign is struggling to regain momentum, with losses in key states like Michigan and Missouri, and a narrow lead in Idaho and Washington.

With no other viable opponents, the Biden campaign has become virtually unstoppable in its march to the Democratic nomination. While it remains to be seen whether Biden can beat Trump in the general election, the recent results give Democrats reason to suspect that he might.

Title: Obama to Announce New Executive Action on Gun Restrictions

The White House has announced that President Barack Obama will meet with Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Monday to discuss options for tougher gun restrictions. The meeting is expected to lead to a new executive action aimed at expanding background checks on gun sales. The exact timing and content of the action are still unclear, but gun control advocates are anticipating the announcement to be made in the coming days, ahead of Obama's annual State of the Union address on January 12.

The White House has not commented directly on the exact timing or content of the executive orders, but White House spokesman Eric Schultz stated that the President expected a set of recommendations on unilateral action to arrive at the beginning of the year. The meeting with Lynch is seen as a key step in fulfilling Obama's promise to take further unilateral steps to curb gun deaths.

Gun control advocates are pushing for the administration to address the so-called "gun show loophole," which allows certain sellers of guns to avoid conducting background checks before making sales. The loophole is seen as a major weakness in the current system, as it allows many gun sales to go unregulated. The administration is also expected to announce new funding for government agencies to better enforce existing gun laws.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has expressed opposition to the proposed executive action, stating that it would make it harder for law-abiding citizens to exercise their right to self-defense. The NRA has previously argued that Obama's "gun control agenda" was rejected by Congress and that his actions are a "defiance of the will of the people."

The exact details of the new executive action are still unclear, but it is expected to include measures to expand background checks and improve the reporting of lost and stolen guns. The administration is also considering setting an annual sales threshold of 25 guns for a seller to be defined as "engaged in the business" of selling guns, and requiring them to obtain a license and conduct background checks.

Title: Mississippi Elementary School Renamed After Barack Obama, Ditching Confederate Leader Jefferson Davis

The Davis International Baccalaureate (IB) Elementary School in Jackson, Mississippi, will be renamed in honor of Barack Obama at the start of the 2018-2019 school year. The decision was made after a vote by school stakeholders on October 5, announced by PTA President Janelle Jefferson at a district board of trustees meeting.

The school, which serves a predominantly black student body, aimed to rename the campus to reflect a person who embodies values and public stances consistent with what they want their children to believe about themselves. Discussions began in August to rebrand the magnet school, previously named after Confederate President Jefferson Davis.

More than 95% of the school's students are black. PTA President Jefferson noted that Jefferson Davis, infamous for his role in the Confederacy, would likely not be pleased about a diverse school promoting the education of the very individuals he fought to enslave, bearing his name.

The renaming process involved a three-week suggestion period, during which staff and students offered potential names, followed by a vote. Board President Camille Simms and School Board Member Jed Oppenheim praised the school's initiative, with Oppenheim describing the decision as a "powerful narrative."

The school will conduct "aggressive fundraising campaigns" to cover the costs of new signs and stationery bearing Obama's name. The renaming is set to take effect at the start of the 2018-2019 school year.

Title: Supreme Court's Healthcare Ruling Divides Americans, Changes Perceptions of the High Court

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the national healthcare law has not significantly shifted public opinion on the measure itself, but it has changed Americans' views of the high court. According to a CNN/ORC International survey released Monday, 50% of Americans agree with the decision, while 49% disagree. The poll found a clear partisan divide, with more than eight in ten Democrats agreeing with the decision and more than eight in ten Republicans disagreeing.

The survey also revealed that only about one in five Americans, and only 35% of Republican rank-and-file, say they are angry about the decision. Similarly, only one in six Americans, and only one in three Democrats nationwide, say they feel enthusiastic about the court's ruling.

The poll found that perceptions of the high court have changed, with the court's approval rating among Democrats jumping by 23 points to 73%, while among Republicans, it fell by 21 points to 31%. Among independents, approval of the Supreme Court edged up five points to 53%.

Opinions on Chief Justice John Roberts are also divided along partisan lines, with a majority of Democrats holding a favorable view of him compared to only three in ten Republicans. However, more than a third of all Americans are unsure how they view Roberts, likely due to the low profile he and his colleagues have kept for many years.

The survey also found that three in ten Americans believe the high court is too liberal, while 22% believe it is too conservative, and 46% believe it is about right. The Republican-led House of Representatives has scheduled a July 11th vote to attempt to repeal the healthcare law, with 51% of Americans saying Congress should repeal all provisions of the measure and 47% saying no.

Regarding the individual mandate, 48% of Americans favor it, while 51% oppose it. However, six in ten Americans believe the mandate is a tax, as ruled by the Supreme Court. The survey found that the number of Americans who favor all or most of the provisions in the bill has gone up a bit since last year, and despite roughly half looking to repeal all the provisions in the law, only one in eight say they oppose everything in the bill.

The CNN poll was conducted by ORC International from July 28 to July 1, with 1,517 adult Americans questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.5 percentage points.

Title: Saudi Arabia's Interest in Nuclear Power Plants: A Security Arrangement or Economic Gain?

The proposed construction of nuclear power plants in Saudi Arabia would require a significant investment of over a trillion dollars, far exceeding the potential revenue generated from selling power. So, what drives the interest of the Saudi Arabian government and other Arab states in this project? According to Thomas Cochran, a prominent scientist and nuclear nonproliferation proponent, it's not about energy; it's about security.

Under the ACU plan, the Saudi Arabian government and other Arab states would be buying into a security arrangement involving the United States, Russia, France, and the United Kingdom. This plan was initially proposed by Michael Flynn, a former national security advisor, as a cash infusion for the Russian government, the US nuclear industry, and related companies.

The plan aimed to generate power, but not electrical power. Instead, it would provide a financial boost to the Russian government, which would use the income to purchase Russian military hardware, compensating for lost military sales to Iran. In return, Russia would decrease its support for Iran, and the US would benefit from increased arms sales.

The nuclear industry, Russia, and Iran would all benefit from this deal, but the Middle East would become client states to a joint US-Russia protection scheme, with control over their power, weapons, and finances. However, the plan never came to fruition due to several reasons, including the Obama administration's sanctions on Russia, the Iran nuclear treaty, and the lack of interest from the key stakeholders.

Michael Flynn's failure to disclose his extensive dealings with the Turkish government, Russian ambassador Sergei Kislyak, and Russian state media, as well as his receipt of payments from a Russian cybersecurity firm, have raised concerns. While Flynn's connections were known, the Trump administration ignored them, but the Special Counsel and Senate Intelligence Committee later investigated these ties, making them a significant issue.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Supports Bill to Ban Abortions After 20 Weeks Gestation

Article:

Texas Senator Ted Cruz has publicly endorsed Senate Bill 1, a legislation that aims to ban abortions after 20 weeks gestation and raise standards of care at abortion clinics by requiring them to meet the same standards as ambulatory surgical centers. In his testimony, Senator Cruz emphasized the importance of protecting the unborn and the need for action in the face of recent revelations about the Gosnell case.

Senator Cruz stated that the bill is not intended to harm women, but rather to protect the unborn from agony and death. He also referenced the concept of natural rights, citing the Declaration of Independence and the idea that life comes first. The senator believes that the Founding Fathers would find legalized infanticide abhorrent and unconscionable.

The bill in question would prohibit abortions after 20 weeks gestation, a move that Senator Cruz believes is necessary to protect the unborn from pain and death. He also noted that many Americans understand this, but too many do not. The senator's stance on this issue is clear: liberty and late-term abortion cannot coexist.

It is worth noting that Senator Cruz's testimony will be read at the Stand for Life Rally at the Texas State Capitol, where thousands of Texans are expected to gather to express their support for the bill.

Title: US Considers Targeting Specific Militant Leaders as Lawful Acts of War or Self-Defense

The United States has a long-standing policy of considering targeted strikes against specific militant leaders as lawful acts of war or self-defense, particularly when it is not feasible to attempt to capture them. This approach was evident during the US air campaign against the Islamic State (IS) in 2014, which was declared by the Obama administration as part of the existing armed conflict authorized by Congress against Al Qaeda after the 9/11 attacks.

The Islamic State, which was once a component or affiliate of Al Qaeda, split away due to internal disagreements. One notable figure associated with the group is Jihadi John, whose real name is believed to be Mohammed Emwazi. Emwazi gained prominence in August 2014 when IS released a video featuring him, a British-accented man, alongside journalist James Foley. Foley was later beheaded off-camera, and Emwazi threatened to kill another journalist, Steven J. Sotloff, if his demands were not met. Two weeks later, IS released a video showing Emwazi beheading Sotloff.

The Washington Post revealed Emwazi's identity in February, reporting that he grew up in a well-off family that moved to Britain when he was a child and studied computer science at the University of Westminster. The revelation sparked intense examination of the causes of radicalization among Muslim immigrants in Europe.

Emwazi was part of a group of friends, known as the "North London Boys," who prayed at the same mosque and became captivated by an Egyptian-born cleric, Hani al-Sibai. Sibai is thought to have close links to the Tunisian branch of Ansar al-Shariah, a Salafist group linked to a deadly attack in June on tourists in Tunisia. The leader of this network, Bilal al-Berjawi, was stripped of his British citizenship in 2011 after he joined the Islamist group Shabab in Somalia and was killed by an American drone strike the following year. Another friend, Mohamed Sakr, was also killed by a drone strike in Somalia in the same year.

Title: The Impact of Protests on the Presidential Race: A Complex Picture

The ongoing protests against police violence have sparked a heated debate about their potential impact on the upcoming presidential election. While some believe the unrest will benefit former Vice President Joe Biden, others argue it's too early to predict the outcome. The situation is complex, with both candidates having made missteps and neither fully addressing the issue.

President Donald Trump has faced criticism for his handling of the protests, including his walk across Lafayette Square to St. John's Church after his Rose Garden remarks. However, some Democrats who initially criticized the move later engaged in similar actions, such as kneeling for nine minutes while partially attired in traditional African garb.

The data suggests that more whites are killed by police than blacks each year, and the number of officer-involved shootings is down across the board. Despite this, the discussion often focuses on the disproportionate impact of police violence on minority communities.

Former Vice President Joe Biden has made some statements and ventured out a few times, but he has not taken a more prominent role in addressing the issue. Some critics argue that he has a checkered past on criminal justice reform, having played a key role in the 1994 Crime Bill, which contributed to mass incarceration. The bill's sentencing provisions were criticized by former President Bill Clinton, who said Biden was responsible for the legislation.

In contrast, President Trump has championed efforts to reform the criminal justice system, including the First Step Act, which has helped balance the books and given people of color a second chance. The nation's views on race and crime are changing, and Trump's actions have helped some individuals incarcerated under laws passed with Biden's support get a fresh start.

The article concludes by challenging Biden to demonstrate his ability to bring people together and address the issue of police violence, rather than simply making statements.

Title: Obama Administration's Unilateral Actions Raise Concerns Over Executive Power

The Obama Administration has faced criticism for its decision to not enforce certain laws, rather than working with Congress to reform them. This approach has been seen as a departure from the traditional way of governance, where the President works with lawmakers to achieve policy goals. Instead, the Administration has chosen to use executive power to achieve its objectives, often bypassing Congress altogether.

The Administration has taken this approach on several issues, including the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), the DREAM Act, and No Child Left Behind. In each case, the President has chosen not to defend or enforce the laws, rather than working with Congress to reform them.

This shift towards unilateral action has raised concerns among some legal experts and scholars. Jonathan Turley, a constitutional scholar, has noted that President Obama has fulfilled the dream of an imperial presidency that Richard Nixon strived for. He has also stated that the President is now functioning as a super-legislator.

Progressives, who have historically been critical of executive power, have been silent on this issue. They have cheered on the President's unilateral actions, including drone strikes that kill American citizens and recess appointments done without a recess. However, they should be careful what they wish for, as these powers could be used by any President, regardless of party affiliation.

Imagine a scenario where a Republican President simply announces that the Environmental Protection Agency is halting enforcement of pollution regulations or that the IRS is not enforcing the Obamacare mandate. The consequences of such actions would be severe and far-reaching.

The Obama Administration's approach has also been compared to that of former President George W. Bush, who was criticized for his expansion of executive power. However, President Obama has not only kept every executive power claimed by Bush but has also expanded it further.

The debate over executive power is an ongoing one, and the Obama Administration's actions have raised important questions about the balance of power between the legislative and executive branches.

Title: Americans Divided on Supreme Court's Decision on 2010 Health Care Law

A recent poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News has revealed that more than two-thirds of Americans hope the Supreme Court will overturn some or all of the 2010 health care law. Only 24% of respondents expressed a desire to keep the entire law in place. The Supreme Court is expected to make a decision on the law by the end of the month.

The poll found that 41% of those surveyed believe the court should strike down the entire law, while 27% think the justices should overturn only the individual mandate, which requires most Americans to obtain health insurance or pay a penalty. These numbers have remained relatively consistent over recent months and were not significantly affected by the six hours of arguments presented in the Supreme Court in March.

The poll also showed a significant divide along party lines, with two-thirds of Republicans wanting the entire law overturned and 43% of Democrats wanting it upheld. Independent voters were more likely to want to see some or all of the law struck down, with 22% hoping the entire law would survive.

Education also played a role in respondents' opinions, with nearly a third of those with a college education wanting the law upheld, compared to about 20% of those without a college degree.

Legal scholars and political scientists are divided on whether the Supreme Court takes public opinion into account when making its decisions. A 2010 study published in The Georgetown Law Journal found that justices are more concerned with the views of academics, journalists, and other elites than with public opinion. The nationwide poll, conducted from May 31 to June 3, surveyed 976 adults and had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

**Supreme Court Blocks Enforcement of Louisiana Abortion Law, Raising Questions About Nationwide Implications**

The Supreme Court has issued a stay, temporarily blocking the enforcement of a Louisiana abortion law that requires abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a local hospital. The law, passed in 2014, has been challenged by abortion rights advocates, who argue that it is medically unnecessary and an effort to shut down abortion clinics.

The case, June Medical Services v. Gee, has implications for abortion rights nationwide, as it could potentially affect the future of abortion laws across the country. The Supreme Court's decision to block enforcement of the law is a victory for abortion rights advocates, but the story is far from over.

The Louisiana law is similar to a Texas law that was struck down by the Supreme Court in 2016, Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt. The Center for Reproductive Rights challenged the Louisiana law on behalf of abortion providers, and the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals allowed it to stand, breaking with Supreme Court precedent.

The Supreme Court's decision to block enforcement of the law was a 5-4 vote, with Chief Justice John Roberts joining the four more liberal justices. Justices Alito, Kavanaugh, Thomas, and Gorsuch voted to allow the law to go into effect.

Abortion rights advocates welcomed the decision, with Nancy Northup, president and CEO of the Center for Reproductive Rights, stating, "The Supreme Court has stepped in under the wire to protect the rights of Louisiana women. The three clinics left in Louisiana can stay open while we ask the Supreme Court to hear our case."

Laws requiring admitting privileges have proliferated around the country in recent years, with abortion opponents arguing that they are necessary to protect women's health. However, courts have generally failed to find evidence for this, and abortion providers do not need admitting privileges for their patients to visit a hospital.

The Supreme Court's decision to block enforcement of the Louisiana law is a temporary reprieve, and the case will now go back to the Court for further consideration. If the Court decides to hear the case, it could potentially revisit and possibly overturn Roe v. Wade, which has protected abortion rights for nearly 50 years.

Title: Trump's Legal Troubles Have Not Boosted Democratic Prospects, Despite Media Focus

The media's intense focus on President Trump's legal entanglements has not translated into a boost for the Democratic Party's prospects, despite the sensationalist coverage of his legal woes. The Democratic Party has been fixated on the investigations led by special counsel Robert Mueller and the Southern District of New York, which has led to a "bifurcated view" of Trump's presidency, separating his policies from his personal character.

However, this focus has not had a significant impact on Trump's approval ratings, which have actually increased to 44% in the Real Clear Politics average, his highest rating in a year. The Democratic Party's advantage on the congressional generic ballot has also been cut in half, from plus 13 points to plus 6.5 points.

The article suggests that Trump's economic policies, particularly his desire to combat offshoring and deindustrialization, have been a key factor in his rising popularity. The tax bill passed in December, which was seen as a signature conservative policy achievement, has also contributed to his increased approval ratings.

The article also notes that the Democratic Party's focus on Trump's legal troubles has relieved them of the responsibility to develop a substantive message, allowing them to ignore the issues that engage voters, such as the economy and healthcare. The article concludes that the party needs to adjust its strategy to appeal to Rust Belt voters who abandoned Hillary Clinton for Trump in the 2016 election.

Title: Representative Charlie Rangel Criticizes Tea Party, Calls it a "Cult"

Article:

Representative Charlie Rangel (D-NY) recently expressed his concerns about the conservative wing of the Republican Party, specifically targeting the Tea Party. In an interview, he described the Tea Party as a "cult" that suffers from an "illness." Rangel, who has been in office since 1971, stated that the Tea Party's ability to influence the repeal of a law passed by the House, Senate, and declared constitutional by the courts is "past Civics 101" and an example of "illness."

Rangel's comments have sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that his remarks are an attempt to discredit the Tea Party and its supporters. The Tea Party, a coalition of individuals who share similar political beliefs, has been a significant force in American politics in recent years.

In response to Rangel's comments, some have pointed out that the Tea Party is not a cult, but rather a group of like-minded individuals who have banded together for political clout. Others have noted that Rangel's own actions, such as allocating millions of taxpayer dollars to a New York library named in his honor, may be seen as self-serving and cult-like.

The debate surrounding the Tea Party and its influence on American politics continues to be a topic of discussion and controversy.

Title: Zoom's Dark Side: FBI Warns of "Zoombombing" and Privacy Concerns

The video conferencing platform Zoom has become a staple for many during the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 200 million daily users in March. However, its rapid growth has also brought new concerns about security and privacy. The FBI has issued a warning about "Zoombombing," a phenomenon where intruders hijack video calls and post hate speech and offensive images.

Dennis Johnson, a recent doctoral graduate, fell victim to Zoombombing during his dissertation defense. He was in the middle of presenting when someone started drawing male genitalia on the screen and scrawled a racial slur. The incident left him shaken and ruined what should have been a triumphant celebration.

The FBI has received multiple reports of conferences being disrupted by pornographic and/or hate images and threatening language. The agency is warning schools, in particular, to be cautious. Zoom has published a guide on how users can protect meetings and changed settings for accounts used by schools and universities to make their meetings more private by default.

However, security researchers have found flaws in Zoom's software that could allow hackers to spy through a computer's webcam or microphone. Zoom has released fixes for these issues, but concerns about data sharing and privacy remain. The company has stopped sharing data with Facebook, but is now facing a class-action lawsuit.

Zoom CEO Eric Yuan has acknowledged the company's shortcomings and is prioritizing privacy and security fixes. The company is freezing work on new features to address these concerns. As Zoom's popularity continues to grow, users are left wondering if the convenience of the platform is worth the potential risks to their privacy and security.

**North and South Korea Agree to Reopen Joint Industrial Complex**

In a significant step towards cooperation, North and South Korea have agreed to hold talks on reopening the Kaesong industrial complex, which was shuttered in April. This marks the first step towards cooperation since the complex was closed, following a series of steps in the opposite direction.

The agreement comes after Pyongyang had previously rejected all previous offers to discuss reopening the complex. Observers speculate that North Korea's acquiescence may be a sign that it is feeling isolated from China, a vital ally that has expressed frustration with North Korea's intransigence and warmed up to US-led efforts to isolate Pyongyang.

According to Daniel Pinkston, a senior analyst for the International Crisis Group covering Northeast Asia, North Korea's decision to agree to talks may indicate that the cost of keeping the complex closed is greater than anticipated. The complex, launched during the "sunshine" era of North-South engagement, provides inexpensive labor for South Korean companies and critical foreign currency for isolated North Korea.

The agreement may also be a bid to soothe Beijing, which has taken a tougher stance on North Korea, supporting tighter UN sanctions and stepped-up border inspections. China has shut accounts of North Korea's Foreign Trade Bank, its main foreign exchange institution, and a leading Chinese state bank has shut accounts of the North Korean bank.

The talks, if they happen, will be the first direct meeting between officials from the two countries since February 2011. The North has preferred private talks through nongovernmental channels, but the South has been insistent on government-to-government talks. All outstanding issues that have strained cross-border relations, including the disconnecting of the hotline between the North and South, will be on the table.

The closure of the complex came after tightened UN sanctions following North Korea's third nuclear test in February and the holding of regular US-South Korea military drills. The North pulled its 50,000 workers from the complex and blocked deliveries, and South Korean workers eventually departed as well.

Title: Senior Officials in Trump Administration Reportedly Worked to Counter President's Agenda

Article: A senior official in the Trump administration has written an anonymous opinion piece in The New York Times, stating that many officials have been working to frustrate parts of the president's agenda to protect the country from his worst impulses. The official described "early whispers" among Cabinet members to remove Trump from office, but they decided against it to avoid a constitutional crisis. The author wrote that the root of the problem is Trump's lack of moral compass and lack of guiding principles in his decision-making.

The official stated that while they want the administration to succeed, they believe it is their duty to prioritize the country's well-being over Trump's actions, which they deem detrimental to the republic. The article has sparked a guessing game in Washington about who wrote the piece and whether it came from within the White House or another government agency.

The article has also fueled accusations that Trump is unstable and unfit for the presidency, and may resurrect talk among some Democrats about potentially impeaching him if they take control of the U.S. House of Representatives in November elections. Trump responded by calling the article a "gutless editorial" and bashing The New York Times as "failing." He also tweeted that the author should be turned over to the government for national security reasons.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo denied being the author of the piece, stating that if he were not able to execute the president's intent, he would leave his position. The article's publication has also led to further controversy, with Defense Secretary James Mattis rejecting a book by Bob Woodward describing chaos in the White House, and Trump calling it "total fiction."

Title: Lawmakers Debate Whether to Arm Syrian Rebel Forces Amid Escalating Conflict

The ongoing conflict in Syria has sparked a heated debate among lawmakers in the United States about whether to arm the rebel forces fighting against the government. The discussion comes after Syria accused Israel, a close U.S. ally, of launching rockets into the country.

Some lawmakers, like Senator John McCain, argue that the U.S. should have intervened militarily in Syria a long time ago. McCain stated that the Obama administration's reluctance to take action is a "tragedy" and that the U.S. should establish a "safe zone" in Syria, take out the government's air assets, and supply the rebel forces with weapons.

On the other hand, Representative Peter King expressed concerns that arming the rebels could be "counterproductive" and might end up in the wrong hands, potentially strengthening al-Qaeda. King emphasized the need to ensure that any arms provided to the rebels do not fall into the possession of al-Qaeda supporters.

Senator Pat Leahy agreed that some rebel groups include radical elements, but believes that the U.S. has already shown support in the conflict by providing refugee aid and anti-aircraft equipment to Turkey. Leahy suggested that supplying weapons to the rebels could be the next step, as long as the right groups are targeted.

Representatives Tom Cotton and Mike Rogers also weighed in on the issue. Cotton advocated for arming the rebels and imposing a no-fly zone to prevent further civilian casualties. Rogers emphasized the need for the U.S. to play a role in bringing down the Assad government, but not by sending troops on the ground.

In contrast, Representative Dutch Ruppersberger stood by President Obama's decision to wait until the U.S. has all the facts before taking action. Ruppersberger believes that any further efforts should be made with other countries, rather than the U.S. taking on the role of "sheriff for the whole world."

White House deputy press secretary Josh Earnest stated that the president understands Israel's concerns about the threat posed by Hezbollah obtaining advanced weapon systems and believes that Israel has the right to take actions to protect its people.

The debate highlights the complexities and challenges of the situation in Syria, with lawmakers weighing the potential risks and benefits of intervention.

Title: Hundreds Arrested in Mississippi Immigration Raids

A coordinated operation by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's Homeland Security Investigations led to the arrest of approximately 680 individuals believed to be working in the United States without authorization. The raids took place on Wednesday at seven agricultural processing plants across Mississippi, with over 600 ICE agents involved in the operation.

The targeted plants, owned by five companies, were located near Jackson and Canton, Mississippi. One of the plants, owned by Koch Foods Inc., is one of the largest poultry processors in the U.S., with over 13,000 employees and an estimated $3.2 billion in annual revenue. Another plant, owned by Peco Foods Inc., is the eighth-largest poultry producer in the U.S.

The arrested workers were taken to a local Mississippi National Guard hangar, where they were interviewed about their immigration status, including whether they had any deportation orders. No representatives from the companies involved responded to requests for comment.

The raids have sparked criticism from the Southern Poverty Law Center, with attorney Julia Solórzano stating that the operation is part of a "war against immigrant families and the communities in which they live." The organization also noted that the raids come just days after a gunman targeted immigrants in El Paso, Texas.

The size of the raid operation is reminiscent of a 2008 operation in Iowa, where over 400 unauthorized workers were arrested in a meatpacking facility.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister's Congressional Address Sparks Partisan Fallout

Article:

The controversy surrounding Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's upcoming address to Congress has highlighted the potential benefits of partisanship in upending the status quo. The White House has taken a public stance against Netanyahu's decision to accept an invitation from House Speaker John Boehner, which has led to a breakdown in the traditional bipartisan consensus on U.S. policy towards Iran.

Netanyahu's decision to reject an invitation from Democratic Senators Dick Durbin and Dianne Feinstein to meet privately with Democrats has been criticized by some as a missed opportunity to build bridges and reduce partisanship. However, Netanyahu's supporters argue that the meeting would have been seen as a concession to the Obama administration's efforts to undermine Israel's interests.

The controversy has significant implications for the Obama administration's efforts to reach a deal with Iran on its nuclear program. The deal, which has been years in the making, is seen as a major achievement for the administration. However, it faces opposition from both Republicans and some Democrats who are skeptical of the deal's terms.

The Obama administration has taken a strong stance against Netanyahu's decision, with National Security Advisor Susan Rice calling his speech "destructive" to U.S.-Israeli relations. Secretary of State John Kerry has also weighed in, reminding lawmakers that Netanyahu supported the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003, a move that has been widely criticized.

The fallout from Netanyahu's decision has made it unlikely that Congress will pass new sanctions on Iran, which would have scuttled the deal. Instead, the deal is expected to go ahead, with the Obama administration's efforts to build international support and pressure Iran to comply with the agreement.

The controversy has also highlighted the deep divisions within the U.S. political system, with some lawmakers and experts arguing that partisanship is a necessary evil in achieving progress on key issues. Others see it as a major obstacle to cooperation and progress.

Title: Congressional Representatives Plan to Boycott Trump's Inauguration, Citing Concerns Over Policy and Tone

Article:

A number of members of Congress have announced that they will not attend President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, citing concerns over his Twitter posts and policy stances. Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the dean of the House of Representatives, stated that he will "do everything in my power to ensure that accountability is brought to bear on the administration and that the Constitution and our nation's laws are adhered to, as no one is above the law."

Representative Barbara Lee of California expressed concerns over Trump's treatment of the African-American community, stating that "he has demeaned and insulted the African-American community, and we are going to have to really raise our voices and resist this if these views are going to be reflected in his policies." Other representatives skipping the event include Representatives Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona, Maxine Waters of California, Luis V. Gutiérrez of Illinois, Katherine M. Clark of Massachusetts, William Lacy Clay of Missouri, Nydia M. Velázquez, Jerrold Nadler, and José E. Serrano of New York, Marcia L. Fudge of Ohio, Earl Blumenauer and Kurt Schrader of Oregon, and Mark Pocan of Wisconsin.

The decision to boycott the inauguration comes as Trump's approval ratings among African-Americans remain low, with only about 8% of black voters supporting him in the November election. The appointment of Stephen K. Bannon, former head of Breitbart News, as Trump's White House chief strategist has also raised concerns among some that nationalist and racist views will be brought to the West Wing.

The Rev. Al Sharpton, who led a march on Saturday in Washington, stated that Trump's Twitter posts drove more people to brave the cold to demonstrate.

Title: Trump Visits Philadelphia Suburbs to Pitch Child Care Plan, Targeting Suburban Women Voters

Article:

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, visited the Philadelphia suburbs on Tuesday to promote his "Child Care Affordability Plan", which aims to address the concerns of suburban women voters. The plan includes allowing parents to deduct child care expenses from their income taxes, guaranteeing six weeks of paid maternity leave, and creating new "Dependent Care Savings Accounts" to help finance items ranging from childhood development to elderly care.

Trump emphasized that his plan is "pro-family, pro-child, and pro-worker", stating that it is essential to take care of the people who are the backbone of the country. His daughter, Ivanka Trump, introduced him, highlighting the need to create policies that champion all parents.

The Trump campaign has been focusing on the Philadelphia suburbs, which are seen as a key battleground in the election. The area has not backed a Republican presidential candidate since 1988, and current polls give Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton an edge in the state.

The Trump campaign's child care plan includes capping tax deductions for child care expenses, with those making more than $250,000 individually or $500,000 as joint filers not eligible. Lower-income taxpayers would be eligible for rebates through the Earned Income Tax Credit. The Dependent Care Savings Accounts could be financed by tax-deductible contributions and tax-free appreciation, and parents could use them to finance traditional child care, after-school programs, and tuition for private schools, as well as elder care for aged parents.

The Clinton campaign has criticized Trump's plan, calling it "half-baked" and stating that it lacks seriousness, given Trump's history of disrespecting women in the workplace and the lack of evidence he has provided paid family leave or child care to his own employees. The Clinton campaign has also highlighted her lifelong commitment to fighting for children and families, including her plan to make preschool universal for 4-year-olds.

Title: Michael Brown's Parents File Civil Suit Against Ferguson and Former Officer

The parents of Michael Brown, the unarmed 18-year-old man who was fatally shot by Ferguson, Missouri, police officer Darren Wilson in August, have filed a civil lawsuit against the city, former police chief Thomas Jackson, and Wilson. The lawsuit, filed at the St. Louis County Courthouse, alleges that Wilson "unjustifiably shot and killed" Brown, using an "unnecessary and unreasonable" amount of force.

The lawsuit claims that Jackson was responsible for hiring, training, and supervising Wilson, and that the Ferguson Police Department's internal culture contributed to the incident. The family's attorney, Benjamin Crump, stated that the shooting was predictable due to the department's internal culture and that the family has been seeking a "thorough independent review" to challenge Wilson's narrative.

Crump referenced recent high-profile cases of police shootings of unarmed black men, saying that the police narrative often contradicts the objective evidence. The legal team has not specified a specific amount of monetary damages they are seeking.

The lawsuit is expected to rely on evidence presented in state and federal investigations into the shooting, but the legal team believes it will provide a "more accurate picture of what took place that day." The investigations into Brown's death did not result in indictments for Wilson, but a Department of Justice report found a "pattern of unconstitutional policing" within the city's police department.

Title: Schumer's Moment of Truth: A Choice Between Leadership and Extremism

Article:

Chuck Schumer, the Senate Minority Leader from New York, is facing a critical moment of truth. On one hand, he is under pressure from a restless Democratic caucus and a group of radical activists funded by George Soros, who are demanding he block eight Trump nominees. On the other hand, sober voices within the Democratic caucus are warning him to tame the passions, slow the mob, and act responsibly.

The Democratic Party is at a crossroads, having lost 1,042 governing seats under President Obama. If Schumer succumbs to the radical left and continues to block Trump's nominees, the party may soon be wondering what happened. The Whig Party, which ended in the 1850s, is a cautionary tale.

Schumer has a choice to make: he can stop the antics or destroy the Democratic brand. Americans do not subscribe to extremism or radical responses to electoral loss. If Schumer chooses to prioritize his party's interests over the country's, he risks losing the respect of the American people.

Seasoned leadership is not about exacting vengeance or settling scores, but about abiding history, demonstrating patience, respecting institutions, comity, and high office. Schumer has a chance to restore propriety to the role of Minority Leader by turning down the volume on the media madness, defanging his radical left, and respecting the confirmation process.

If Schumer chooses the path of extremism, the consequences will be dire. The Democratic Party will be seen as dysfunctional, irresponsible, and captured by the radical left. The party will lose its centrist identity, and the die will be cast for 2018. On the other hand, if Schumer chooses the path of leadership, he will be remembered as a statesman who put the country's interests above his party's.

Americans are watching, and they want a respectful, fair, and orderly confirmation process. Anything else smacks of extremism. Schumer should take a cue from Robert Frost's poem "The Road Not Taken" and choose the path less traveled, which will make all the difference.

Title: South Koreans Unfazed by North Korean Threats, Focus on Daily Life

Seoul, South Korea - Despite being just 30 miles from the demilitarized zone dividing North and South Korea, the capital city of Seoul seems to be carrying on with life as usual. The city's 25 million residents appear to be unaffected by the constant stream of threats from North Korea, with many viewing them as a normal part of life.

According to local journalists, South Koreans have grown accustomed to the warnings of thermonuclear war, annihilation, and devastation, and have learned to take them in stride. "We are post-war, we don't worry about that," said a journalist specializing in local news. "We take it for granted."

Seoul is a prime target for North Korea's artillery and rockets, and the city's residents are well aware of the threat. However, they seem to have accepted it as a reality and are focused on their daily lives. "We know North Korea doesn't want war," said one resident. "They want money and food," adding that Pyongyang has tried various tactics, including missiles and nuclear threats, to try to blackmail the South.

Former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell visited Seoul this week and urged the city's residents to be optimistic, citing the progress made in democratization and economic growth. He encouraged them to focus on jobs, human dignity, and environmental issues, rather than being burdened by the threats.

In contrast, some residents of the South Korean islands near the demilitarized zone are more aware of the threat, recalling the 2010 attack that killed four South Koreans on Yeonpyeong island. However, even in these areas, the threat of war is seen as a distant possibility, rather than a constant reality.

For those living in Seoul, the thought of war is unthinkable, and the city's residents are focused on their daily lives, with many not even recalling the last civilian air raid drills, which took place 30 years ago.

Title: Kathy Griffin Apologizes for Controversial Trump Impersonation

Kathy Griffin, a comedian and actress, has apologized for a performance art project that featured a bloody, decapitated head designed to resemble President Donald Trump. The stunt, which was widely condemned on social media, has sparked a heated debate about the boundaries of comedy and the impact of political satire.

Griffin's apology came after she faced intense backlash from both sides of the political spectrum, including from her CNN co-host Anderson Cooper, who called the photo "disgusting and completely inappropriate." The Secret Service also responded, stating that threats made against its protectees receive the highest priority of all its investigations.

The photo, which was inspired by a scene from the TV show Game of Thrones, was meant to be a commentary on the "mocker-in-chief," but many saw it as a crossing of a line. Griffin initially defended her actions, saying she was "merely mocking the mocker in chief," but later deleted her tweets and took down the photo from her social media account.

In a rare display of remorse, Griffin acknowledged that she had gone too far and understood how the image might offend people. "I am sorry. I went too far. I was wrong," she tweeted.
