The incident has sparked a wider conversation about the role of comedy in politics and the importance of respecting the boundaries of good taste. While some have defended Griffin's right to free speech, others have condemned her actions as a form of hate speech.

The fallout from the incident has been swift, with CNN announcing that it has terminated its contract with Griffin. Trump himself responded, saying that Griffin should be ashamed of herself and that her actions were "sick." Even some of Griffin's fellow comedians and celebrities, such as Debra Messing and Mitt Romney, have spoken out against her actions.

The incident serves as a reminder that, even in the age of social media, there are still consequences for crossing the line. As the author of the article notes, "Shock artists like Griffin are merely poseurs hiding behind the guise of humor while avoiding the hard work of coming up with real thought-provoking comedic material. Instead, they just continuously blur the boundaries of good taste."

Title: Libya's Political Crisis Escalates as Factions Align Behind Rival Leaders

Libya is facing a deepening political crisis as rival factions align behind two leaders, former Libyan General Khalifa Haftar and Islamist politicians who dominate the country's interim parliament. The crisis has sparked concerns of widening conflict and instability in the oil-rich nation.

Haftar's forces have attacked Islamist militias in Benghazi and claimed credit for an attack on the General National Congress (GNC), the parliament. In response, the GNC has summoned militias from the city of Misrata to Tripoli to resist what it describes as an anti-democratic power-grab by Haftar's camp.

The crisis reflects a rift between Islamist politicians who dominate the GNC and their non-Islamist rivals, but it is also drawing in armed groups who seem to be motivated by regional ties and opportunism. Haftar has won some support from residents in Benghazi who hope he can bring stability to the city, which has seen a pattern of bombings, shootings, and abductions often blamed on hardline Islamist militias.

However, others remain skeptical of Haftar's apparent lack of a long-term agenda for the city and unclear ambitions. The former cabinet member from Libya's first post-Qaddafi government, who spoke on condition of anonymity, questioned whether Haftar is qualified to run a city and whether he believes in elections.

The crisis has also drawn in foreign embassies, which are on alert amid fears of widening conflict. The acting prime minister, Abdullah Al-Thinni, has called on the GNC to vote immediately on a 2014 budget and confirm his successor, the prime minister-elect, before a recess and elections for a new interim legislature. If confirmed, the new premier would be Libya's fifth since the fall of the Qaddafi dictatorship in 2011.

The crisis highlights the challenges facing Libya, which has struggled to establish a stable government since the fall of the Qaddafi regime. The country has been plagued by militia violence, political infighting, and economic instability. The international community is urging the Libyan factions to find a peaceful solution to the crisis and to work towards a more stable and democratic government.

Title: US and China Unveil Ambitious Targets to Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions

The United States and China, the world's two largest carbon dioxide polluters, have unveiled ambitious targets to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions in an effort to foster a global agreement on climate change next year. According to the agreement, the US will reduce its emissions by 26-28% below 2005 levels by 2025, a deeper cut than previously planned. China, on the other hand, has committed to capping its greenhouse gas emissions by around 2030.

US President Barack Obama described the US goals as "ambitious" and emphasized that the accelerated pace of cuts will improve public health and boost jobs. He praised China for agreeing to "slow, peak, and then reverse" its carbon emissions eventually. China has also pledged to get about 20% of its energy from non-fossil fuel sources by 2030.

The new targets for the US are likely to face opposition from congressional Republicans, who have frequently criticized the Obama administration's environmental policies. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican, has denounced the "war on coal" and wants to cut funding to the Environmental Protection Agency. He described the new targets as "unrealistic" and warned that they would increase utility rates and reduce jobs.

Environmental groups, however, praised the deal, saying it would create momentum for a global climate-change pact in Paris next year among nearly 200 nations. The agreement is seen as a significant step forward in the global effort to combat climate change, as it marks the first time China has agreed, at least in principle, to cap its greenhouse gas emissions.

Title: Trump Meets Freed American Prisoners, Hints at Progress in North Korea Relations

Article:

President Donald Trump greeted three American prisoners freed by North Korea on Thursday morning, marking a significant diplomatic milestone between the longtime adversaries. The freed prisoners, Kim Dong-chul, Tony Kim, and Kim Hak-song, were escorted back to the U.S. by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington, D.C., at 2:42 a.m. Thursday.

Trump and First Lady Melania Trump boarded the plane to meet the Americans before accompanying them to the tarmac. The President expressed his gratitude for the release, stating, "I'm very honored to have helped these great folks, but the true honor is going to be if we have a victory in getting rid of nuclear weapons." He also hinted at a planned meeting between the U.S. and North Korea, saying, "We have a meeting scheduled in a very short period of time. We have the location set. We'll see if we can do something that people did not think was going to happen for many, many years."

The release of the prisoners, largely seen as a goodwill gesture by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, could pave the way for a new era of U.S.-North Korea relations after heightened tensions last year saw President Trump and Kim threaten each other with nuclear strikes. The U.S. had long demanded the Korean-American citizens' release, with two of the men taken captive last year and Kim Dong-chul detained since 2015. No other Americans are believed to be imprisoned in North Korea.

The freed prisoners were taken to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for medical examinations after their meeting with the President and Vice President Pence. Trump tweeted that they appeared to be "in good health." However, U.S. officials are likely cautious after the last American to be released from North Korean custody, Otto Warmbier, died shortly upon his return to the U.S.

The release came during Pompeo's second visit to North Korea this year, where he secured the Americans' freedom in exchange for North Korea's promise to desert its nuclear weapons program. Pompeo stated, "For decades, we have been adversaries. Now we are hopeful that we can work together to resolve this conflict, take away threats to the world and make your country have all the opportunities your people so richly deserve."

Vice President Pence said in an interview on ABC's "Good Morning America" that the release of the prisoners signaled a willingness by the North to negotiate in a way that appears "different" from past efforts. "We are seeing hopeful signs from Kim Jong Un that he is prepared to embrace complete denuclearization — that's his words," Pence said.

The meeting between Trump and Kim is expected to take place in late May or early June, although the White House has yet to reveal further details.

Title: Treasury Secretary Geithner's Proposed Tax Plan: A Complex Solution to a Complex Problem

The White House has proposed a plan to temporarily protect taxpayers from middle-class tax hikes by adjusting the withholding tables for tax purposes. According to Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, this plan would allow the White House to ensure that wealthier taxpayers with annual incomes above $250,000 see their taxes rise, while leaving withholding tables unchanged for the middle class. This would mean that middle-class workers would not see a higher cut from their paychecks.

However, experts and lawmakers agree that Geithner has the power to adjust the withholding tables, which employers use to determine how much to deduct from workers' paychecks for taxes. In theory, Geithner could leave the withholding tables the same for lower-income workers, effectively making it seem as if their taxes haven't gone up. But this plan is considered a complex solution to a complex problem.

The plan does not address the underlying issue of tax rates going up, and it is unclear what the eventual tax rate will be and when it will go into effect. If Geithner guesses incorrectly and fails to withhold the correct amount, tens of millions of people could find themselves owing a large sum to the IRS when tax day arrives.

In reality, this plan does not solve the ongoing tax debate, as it does not address the core issue of tax rates going up. The plan is a temporary fix that may not provide a long-term solution to the tax debate.

**French Alps Crash: Search Operation Called Off as Airbus A320 Likely Carries 150 Passengers**

French authorities have called off the search operation for the Airbus A320 aircraft that crashed in the French Alps earlier today, likely killing all 150 people on board. The plane, operated by Germanwings, a low-cost subsidiary of Lufthansa, was traveling from Barcelona, Spain, to Duesseldorf, Germany.

According to Germanwings CEO Thomas Winkelmann, the plane began descending after reaching its regular height and then dropped for eight minutes. The aircraft lost contact with French radar and air traffic control at 10:55 a.m. local time, when it was at an altitude of about 6,000 feet.

Winkelmann stated that the exact reason for the sudden descent is unknown, saying, "We can't say at this point in time why our colleague decided to lower the plane as swiftly as he did. We don't have any information about why he brought the plane down so quickly to a lower height."

The French Civil Aviation Authority's Eric Heraud confirmed that the plane did not send out a distress signal, contrary to earlier reports. The aircraft was delivered to Lufthansa in 1991 and had been operating for Germanwings since 2004. Its last routine check was on Monday, and its last major inspection was in the summer of 2013.

The nationalities of the passengers have not been released, pending notification of kin. However, the Education Ministry in German North Rhine-Westphalia state confirmed that 16 high-schoolers and two teachers from a school in Haltern, Germany, were aboard the flight.

The exact location of the crash is unclear, but the terrain where the plane went down is difficult to access, hampering search efforts. A black box was located at the site of the crash, and will be used to investigate what caused the plane to go down.

Title: Afghan Forces End Siege, Kill Gunmen Who Attacked Sikh Temple in Kabul

Afghan security forces have concluded an hours-long siege, killing the gunmen who attacked a Sikh religious complex in Kabul, the Ministry of Interior has announced. The attack, which began on Wednesday, resulted in the deaths of at least 25 people and left eight others wounded. The Islamic State (ISIL) armed group claimed responsibility for the attack.

According to eyewitness Raju Singh Sonny, a man dressed in a police uniform entered the temple, shot a guard, and began attacking worshippers in the main hall. Several other attackers also entered the building, shooting people as they went from room to room.

The operation by security forces concluded, and all attackers were killed, according to Interior Ministry spokesman Tariq Arian. The area around the temple, located in old Kabul, was cordoned off by security forces.

The attack resulted in the deaths of at least 25 people, including a child whose body was brought to a Kabul hospital. Those injured included a parliamentarian from the minority Sikh community, Narindra Singh Khalsa, who was near the Gurdwara (Sikh place of worship) when the attack occurred.

In an interview with AP News Agency, Mohan Singh, who was in the Gurdwara at the time of the attack, described hearing the sound of gunshots and diving for cover under a table. He later heard the sound of explosions, which he believed were hand grenades. He was injured when parts of the ceiling fell on him.

Photographs shared by the Interior Ministry showed about a dozen children being rushed out of the Gurdwara by Afghan special forces, many of them barefoot and crying. Many people were still inside the building after the attack, according to Khalsa.

The SITE Intelligence Group, which tracks activities by armed groups, confirmed that ISIL had claimed responsibility for the attack on its Aamaq media arm. This is the second attack on a minority group in Kabul this month, following an attack on a gathering of minority Shia Muslims that killed 32 people.

The attack comes amid a political crisis in Afghanistan, with the US announcing a $1 billion cut in aid to the government due to a lack of progress in forming a negotiating team to talk to the Taliban. The US and the Taliban signed a deal last month, but the talks have stalled due to disagreements between the Afghan government and the Taliban.

Title: Education Secretary DeVos Defends Plan to Withhold Federal Funds from Schools That Don't Reopen Amid Pandemic

Article:

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has defended her plan to withhold federal funds from schools that do not reopen in-person classes amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In an interview with Fox News Sunday, DeVos stated that there is no danger in sending children back to school and that other countries have successfully reopened their schools without significant issues.

DeVos pointed to countries like Germany, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden as examples of successful school reopenings, despite having fewer daily cases of COVID-19 than the United States. However, Fox News Sunday host Chris Wallace noted that these countries have far fewer daily cases of COVID-19 than the US, making it difficult to compare the two.

DeVos argued that schools should not be eligible for federal assistance if they do not reopen, citing the need to fulfill the promise of education to students and their families. She also stated that the mental health consequences of missing school outweigh the concern about the virus, as children are infected at a lower rate and tend not to suffer from serious complications.

However, Dr. Tom Inglesby, director of the Center for Health Security at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, disagreed with DeVos' stance, stating that while children are at a lower risk of serious infections, they are not at zero risk and can still spread the virus. Inglesby also noted that there have been deaths in the United States, including a recent case in South Carolina.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized DeVos' comments, calling them "malfeasance and dereliction of duty" and stating that the administration is "messing with the health of our children." Pelosi emphasized the importance of returning to school safely and warned that ignoring science and governance could lead to the spread of the coronavirus.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued guidelines for reopening schools, which DeVos described as "very tough, expensive, and impractical." However, Inglesby noted that the guidelines are meant to be helpful for educators determining how to reopen schools, and that a one-size-fits-all approach may not be suitable for all schools.

Title: President Trump Orders National Guard Withdrawal from Washington D.C. Amid Peaceful Protests

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has ordered the withdrawal of thousands of National Guard troops from Washington D.C. after a weekend of peaceful protests against police brutality. The troops were deployed to the nation's capital last week in response to unrest and property damage in the area. According to Trump, the situation is now "perfectly under control," and the troops will be returning home, but can quickly return if needed.

The decision to withdraw the National Guard comes after a week of protests and demonstrations in Washington D.C., which were largely peaceful and resulted in minimal property damage. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd, a black man who died in police custody in Minneapolis.

The use of the National Guard and active-duty military troops to calm the unrest sparked criticism from some Democrats and even some of Trump's Republican allies. District Mayor Muriel Bowser ordered Utah National Guard members out of a hotel near downtown last week, citing a budget issue. Bowser also made it clear that she did not want military-style police patrolling the streets.

The use of the National Guard and active-duty military troops to calm the unrest also sparked pushback within the Trump administration. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper broke with the commander-in-chief on the issue, saying the protests did not meet the heightened level to call for military intervention. "The option to use active-duty forces in a law enforcement role should only be used as a matter of last resort, and only in the most urgent and dire of situations," Esper said.

About 1,600 active-duty military troops were sent to the nation's capital last week after a church and other buildings near the White House were set ablaze. Monuments were also tagged with graffiti. The troops, however, were not deployed to confront citizens. Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf defended the administration's moves, saying the unrest diminished after the increase in law enforcement presence. "We took the right action," Wolf said. "We have seen governors deploy the National Guard."

Attorney General William Barr said he thought members of the administration were on the same page that troops should be used as a last resort. "They should only be deployed as a last resort and we didn't think we would need them," Barr said. The attorney general also said the president has the authority to send troops into states even if state leaders have not requested help.

Title: Kashmir Tensions Escalate as India and Pakistan Blame Each Other for Continued Conflict

The ongoing tensions between India and Pakistan over the disputed region of Kashmir have led to a surge in violence and a renewed call for a permanent peaceful resolution. The conflict has its roots in the structural violence and political repression in Kashmir, which has led to the radicalization of some young Kashmiris, including Adil Ahmad Dar, who carried out a suicide bombing that brought the region to the brink of war.

Both India and Pakistan share responsibility for the continued tensions, with India's use of air power inside Pakistan representing a major departure from existing norms of engagement between the two sides. Pakistan's unwillingness to challenge the violent sway of underground anti-India groups has also contributed to the ongoing conflict.

The situation has been exacerbated by India's decision to use air power inside Pakistan for the first time since 1971, which has raised concerns about the potential for further escalation. Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has called for calm and returned the Indian pilot captured from an attack plane that Pakistan downed. However, it remains unclear whether Khan or his successors will be able to maintain composure if India continues to encroach on Pakistani sovereignty to hunt down terrorists.

The conflict has been ongoing for years, with both sides blaming each other for the violence and destruction. The situation has led to the displacement of thousands of people and the loss of countless lives. It is time for India and Pakistan to give up their intransigent positions and work towards a peaceful resolution.

In other news, Senator Elizabeth Warren has provided more detail on Medicare financing than her Democratic opponents, including Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg. Her Medicare plan comes closer to paying for itself than various Republican tax cuts, but critics argue that she has not provided a reassuring transition plan for those who may be affected by the changes.

In a separate development, the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump's actions has continued, with some arguing that circumstantial evidence is sufficient to prove wrongdoing. While Trump's defenders may claim that the evidence is circumstantial and lacks an explicit quid pro quo proposal, experts argue that circumstantial evidence can be enough to prove a criminal exchange. The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen whether it will lead to removal from office.

Title: Michelle Obama Named Most Admired Woman for the First Time, Barack Obama Remains Top Man

The annual survey conducted by ██ has revealed that Michelle Obama has been named the most admired woman for the first time, surpassing Hillary Clinton's 17-year reign. Michelle Obama, the former first lady, won by a significant margin, with Oprah Winfrey coming in second and Melania Trump third.

Barack Obama, the 44th President of the United States, has been named the most admired man for the 11th consecutive year, a record that puts him just one first-place finish short of tying Dwight Eisenhower's record.

Queen Elizabeth II finished among the top 10 most admired women for the 50th time, a record that surpasses Oprah Winfrey's 31st appearance and Hillary Clinton's 27th. Other notable finishers include German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, talk show host Ellen DeGeneres, and human rights activist Malala Yousafzai.

The survey, conducted from December 3-12, asked Americans to name the man and woman they admire most, with the results showing a significant shift in the top 10 most admired women. Michelle Obama's win marks a change at the top of the list for the first time in 17 years, with Hillary Clinton falling back after a long career as first lady, U.S. senator, secretary of state, and two-time presidential candidate.

The top 10 most admired men this year includes former President George W. Bush, Pope Francis, Microsoft founder Bill Gates, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, former President Bill Clinton, the Dalai Lama, former Vice President Joe Biden, Tesla CEO Elon Musk, and Vice President Mike Pence.

The survey also showed that Democrats and Republicans had dominant favorites for Most Admired Man, with 35% of Democrats naming Obama and 32% of Republicans naming Trump. Independents were slightly more likely to name Obama (13%) than Trump (10%).

Title: The Electoral College: A Compromise with Complex Implications

The Electoral College, established by the Founding Fathers as a compromise between a popular vote and congressional selection of the President, has been a topic of debate and scrutiny since its inception. The system, which awards Electoral votes to the winner of each state's popular vote, has been criticized for its perceived inefficiencies and unfairness, particularly when the popular vote outcome does not align with the Electoral College outcome, as seen in the 2016 election.

The Electoral College was created as a compromise between those who wanted the President to be elected by popular vote and those who believed Congress should select the President. The system was designed to balance the power between the federal government and the states, as well as to ensure that smaller states have a voice in the election process.

Each state has a designated number of Electors equal to the number of Senators and Representatives it is entitled to in Congress, resulting in a total of 538 Electors. A majority of 270 votes is required to elect the President. In most states, the Electoral votes are awarded on a winner-takes-all basis, meaning that the candidate who wins the popular vote in a state receives all of that state's Electoral votes.

The Electoral College has been the subject of numerous proposals for reform or abolition, with over 700 proposals introduced in Congress since its establishment. However, any changes to the system would require a constitutional amendment, which is a difficult and time-consuming process.

Some states have opted to join the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, which would effectively bypass the Electoral College by awarding Electoral votes to the winner of the national popular vote, regardless of the outcome in individual states. This approach has been criticized for potentially creating a system where candidates focus solely on a few key states, rather than building coalitions across the country.

Supporters of the Electoral College argue that it encourages candidates to build coalitions and pay attention to the entire country, while opponents argue that it discourages candidates from doing so. Ultimately, the debate surrounding the Electoral College highlights the complexities and challenges of ensuring that elections accurately represent the will of the people.

Title: House Republicans Divided on Immigration Reform, Border Security a Priority

Article:

House Republicans emerged from a closed-door meeting on Wednesday with no consensus on granting legal status to the 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the United States. While some lawmakers expressed support for a pathway to citizenship, others remained opposed, citing concerns about border security and the rule of law.

The meeting, which lasted over 2.5 hours, highlighted the deep divisions within the Republican Party on the issue. Representative Steve King estimated that his colleagues were split 50/50 on the matter. The Republican-led House and Democratic-led Senate have been at odds over the issue, with the Senate passing a comprehensive immigration bill that includes a pathway to citizenship.

House Speaker John Boehner has suggested that the House may consider a bill focused on border security as a first step towards a larger agreement. However, this proposal has been met with skepticism by some lawmakers, who argue that it does not address the issue of undocumented immigrants already living in the country.

The Senate bill, which was passed last month, would provide a 13-year path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, as well as $46 billion for border security and visa reform. The bill has been praised by the White House and many Democrats, but has been rejected by House Republicans.

The debate is likely to continue, with some lawmakers predicting that it will take months or even years to reach a resolution. The November presidential election, in which President Barack Obama won over 70% of the Hispanic vote, has put pressure on Republicans to address the issue. However, some House Republicans are hesitant to back a pathway to citizenship, fearing challenges from the conservative Tea Party movement.

The debate has also been fueled by a recent report from the White House, which argues that passing comprehensive immigration reforms would expand the economy by 3.3% by 2023 and reduce the federal deficit by almost $850 billion over 20 years. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has also expressed support for the bill, citing the economic benefits.

The debate is likely to continue, with both sides dug in and unwilling to budge. However, some lawmakers are hopeful that public pressure and the need for a comprehensive solution will eventually lead to a breakthrough.

Title: Senate Approves Chuck Hagel as Defense Secretary, Ending Contentious Battle

The United States Senate has approved Chuck Hagel's nomination as Defense Secretary, bringing an end to a contentious battle that exposed deep divisions over the president's Pentagon pick. The vote was historically close, with 58 senators supporting Hagel and 41 opposing him.

Hagel, a former Republican senator, faced resistance from many senators due to concerns over his record of past statements and votes on various issues, including Israel, Iran, and nuclear weapons. Republicans had earlier blocked the nomination, citing a need for more information from the Obama administration on the September 11 Libya attacks.

During his confirmation hearing, Hagel faced criticism for his use of the term "Jewish lobby" to refer to pro-Israel groups, which he later apologized for. He also faced scrutiny over his past statements and votes, including his opposition to President George W. Bush's decision to send an extra 30,000 troops to Iraq in 2007.

Despite the challenges, Hagel's nomination ultimately received the support of three Republicans, Senators Thad Cochran, Mike Johanns, and Richard Shelby, as well as Senator Rand Paul, who switched to support Hagel in the final vote. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid praised Hagel's "exemplary record of service to his country" and criticized the delaying tactics of his Republican colleagues.

Hagel will succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta and join President Obama's retooled national security team. His nomination was bitterly split the Senate, with Republicans turning on their former party colleague and Democrats standing by Obama's nominee.

Title: President Trump's Job Approval Numbers Surge to Best Figures of His Presidency

Article:

According to a recent RealClearPolitics poll, President Trump's job approval rating has reached its highest point since taking office, sitting at 47 percent. This marks a significant improvement from his previous record of 46 percent, with his disapproval rating dipping to 49.5 percent, its lowest point since February 2017. The poll also shows that Trump's approval rating has improved by a net 6.5 points in just over a week, largely due to his handling of the medical and financial crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

The poll highlights Trump's handling of the pandemic as a key factor in his improved approval ratings. A recent Gallup poll showed that a majority of Americans approve of his handling of the crisis, with 60 percent expressing approval. Trump's early implementation of travel bans, including his January 31 ban, has been praised for its effectiveness in slowing the spread of the virus.

The president's daily press briefings have also been well-received, with millions tuning in to hear his updates on the pandemic. While some media outlets have criticized the briefings, many Americans appreciate the direct communication with the president and the involvement of experts like Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx. The briefings have allowed for a public debate on the best course of action, which has been seen as a healthy and informative approach.

Trump's ability to work with Democrats, including Governors Newsom of California and Cuomo of New York, has also been highlighted as a positive aspect of his leadership during the crisis. The passage of the $2 trillion stimulus package, which was worked out with Democrats in the U.S. Senate, has been seen as a crucial step in addressing the economic impact of the pandemic.

Overall, the poll suggests that President Trump's job approval numbers are surging due to his handling of the coronavirus pandemic, with many Americans appreciating his leadership and willingness to take bold action.

Title: Trump's Budget Proposal Fails to Tame National Debt, Experts Say

The Trump administration's latest budget proposal, released on Monday, promises to bring federal spending and debt under control, but experts argue that it relies on unrealistic economic projections and accounting gimmicks to achieve this goal. The proposed budget would run trillion-dollar deficits in each of the next four years and take 15 years to balance, even with optimistic assumptions about future economic growth.

The budget also fails to eliminate the national debt in eight years, as promised by President Trump during his campaign. Instead, it would add more than $7.9 trillion to the national debt over the next decade, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget (CRFB).

The CRFB, a nonpartisan group that advocates for balanced budgets, says the budget is likely to add about $10 trillion to the national debt by 2029, based on more realistic economic projections. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) also assumes lower levels of future revenue than the Trump budget does, and expects the deficit to reach $1.3 trillion annually by 2029.

The budget proposal also relies on unrealistic spending cuts, such as the $660 billion in savings assumed from repealing and replacing Obamacare, which has been deemed impossible by many experts. The budget also attempts to hide spending increases for the Pentagon by moving new funds into off-the-books accounts originally meant for foreign wars.

Experts argue that the budget fails to address the root causes of the national debt and instead relies on accounting gimmicks and fantasy assumptions. "The nation has never been in such a troubling fiscal situation," writes Chris Edwards, director of tax policy studies at the Cato Institute. "Federal debt is soaring even after a decade of economic growth. Debt is imposing a rising cost that burdens all of us. Politicians have always had incentives to spend, but never before has Washington been so irresponsible."

The budget also calls for the extension of the 2017 tax cuts, which are currently expected to expire in 2025. Experts argue that if annual spending growth was restrained to 1.8 percent, the budget could balance within 10 years, even with lower expected revenues. However, the budget ignores this possibility and instead relies on unrealistic economic projections and accounting gimmicks.

Title: State Legislatures Take Center Stage in Policy Debates, Analysts Say

State legislatures across the United States have been addressing a range of issues this year, including gun control, healthcare, education, and police procedures. According to analysts, these state-level debates may have a more immediate and lasting impact than any decisions made in Washington, D.C., where government is currently divided.

The roots of polarization in state legislatures can be traced back to the 2010 elections, when Republicans made significant gains in statehouses and pushed for policies that restricted labor unions and abortion access, while expanding gun rights. Around the same time, national organizations representing interest groups, such as teachers and gun owners, became more active in state capitals, finding it easier to make progress in state legislatures than in Washington due to gridlock in Congress.

The number of states with either supermajorities of Democrats or Republicans has grown, leading to lawmakers rarely feeling the need to compromise. "If you are a Republican in one state, you are probably going to be pushing the same agenda as a Republican in another state, and the same is true for Democrats," said Sarah F. Anzia, a political scientist at the University of California, Berkeley. "That hasn't always been true, and the result is that now more than ever, state legislatures are key players in these partisan battles over politics."

In Minnesota, the only state with a divided legislature, promises of bipartisanship sometimes devolved into stalemate. During a budget standoff last month, Democratic Governor Tim Walz angrily denounced Republicans for blocking gun control efforts and supporting deep tax cuts, saying those policies "fit better in Mississippi and Alabama than they do in Minnesota."

Title: Trump Fires Navy Secretary Richard Spencer Over Handling of Eddie Gallagher's Case

Article:

President Donald Trump announced the termination of Navy Secretary Richard Spencer, citing his dissatisfaction with the handling of the Eddie Gallagher case and other aspects of his performance as Navy secretary. Trump took to Twitter to express his displeasure, stating that he was "not pleased" with the way Gallagher's trial was handled by the Navy and that he was "treated very badly" despite being "completely exonerated on all major charges."

Gallagher, a Navy SEAL, was acquitted of murdering a wounded prisoner in Iraq but was convicted of posing for a photo with the militant's body. Trump restored Gallagher's rank earlier this month, and Navy officials subsequently convened boards to consider expelling him from the commando unit.

Spencer's termination was reportedly due to his disagreement with Trump over the handling of Gallagher's case. In a letter to Trump, Spencer acknowledged his termination, stating that he could not in good conscience obey an order that he believed violated the sacred oath he took to support and defend the Constitution.

The Pentagon announced Spencer's termination, citing a "loss of confidence" in his ability to execute the duties of the office. Trump has nominated Rear Admiral Kenneth Braithwaite, the ambassador to Norway, to replace Spencer as Navy secretary.

The controversy surrounding Gallagher's case has been ongoing, with Trump's intervention seen as a key factor in the clash that led to Spencer's departure. Former Navy Secretary Ray Mabus, who held the top Navy post in the Obama administration, stated that Trump's actions "undermined good order and discipline" and "dishonored the SEALs" by saying they couldn't hold a review board.

The situation has sparked criticism from some, with a former senior Defense official describing it as "the Trump circus" and stating that everything the president touches turns into a "convoluted process of politics."

Title: Trump Questions Cohen's Recording of Conversation About Payment to Playboy Model

Article:

President Donald Trump questioned his former attorney, Michael Cohen, for recording a conversation they had about paying a woman who alleged she had an affair with Trump. Trump tweeted about the tape, asking "What kind of a lawyer would tape a client?" and expressing surprise that the recording was made.

The recording, which was seized by the government during a raid on Cohen's apartment, office, and hotel room earlier this year, shows Cohen telling Trump that he needs to "open up a company for the transfer of all of that info regarding our friend David," seemingly referring to American Media Inc. head David Pecker. Cohen says "we'll have to pay," and Trump is heard telling him "pay with cash," although it is unclear from the muddled sound whether Trump is suggesting paying or not paying.

The recording is legal, as New York only requires one party to consent to allow a conversation to be recorded. Experts have largely said the tape does not prove any criminal wrongdoing. The contents of the other 11 tapes seized during the raid are not publicly known at this time.

Trump's comments about the recording come after CNN aired the audio on Tuesday night. Trump did not name Cohen or harshly criticize him, instead asking a series of questions about the recording. "What kind of a lawyer would tape a client? So sad! Is this a first, never heard of it before? Why was the tape so abruptly terminated (cut) while I was presumably saying positive things?" Trump tweeted.

"I hear there are other clients and many reporters that are taped - can this be so? Too bad!" he added.

Cohen, who worked for years as Trump's fixer at the Trump Organization, is reportedly under investigation for bank fraud and campaign finance law violations. He has raised speculation he might cooperate with investigators in recent weeks after saying his "first loyalty" is to the country, not Trump.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Spotted at Closed Beach, Defends Use of State Park

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie was spotted at Island Beach State Park, a state-operated beach, on Sunday, despite the state's beaches being closed due to a budget standoff. The governor was photographed lounging in a beach chair, with his family and friends around him. When asked if he got any sun that day, Christie replied, "I didn't get any sun today. I didn't get any sun today."

Christie's spokesman later clarified that the governor was only on the beach for a brief visit to talk to his family, and he wore a baseball hat the entire time. The governor has been criticized for using a state park that is closed to the rest of the state's residents due to the budget impasse.

In a press conference, Christie defended his use of the park, stating that his family does not use any state services while there and that his residence is separate from the park. He also jokingly told state residents that they could run for governor and have a residence at the park.

The incident sparked a flurry of memes and criticism on social media, with many calling for Christie to leave the beach. The Asbury Park Press published a headline reading, "Gov. Christie, get the hell off the beach!"

Christie's approval ratings have been low, with a recent Quinnipiac University poll showing him with a 15% approval rating among New Jersey voters, the worst approval rating for any governor in over 20 years. His lieutenant governor, Kim Guadagno, a Republican, posted her disapproval of Christie's beach visit on Facebook and is now running for governor herself.

Title: House Republicans Demand Answers on Benghazi Attack, Citing Security Requests Denied

Article:

Two House Republican leaders, Darrell E. Issa and Jason Chaffetz, have called for a hearing to investigate the September 11 terrorist attack on the US consulate in Benghazi, Libya, which killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens. The lawmakers claim that the State Department had refused repeated requests from diplomats in Libya for increased security measures before the attack. According to Issa and Chaffetz, the US mission in Libya made 13 security-related requests to Washington, but these were denied.

The State Department has confirmed that the US mission in Libya did make requests for increased security, but officials in Washington denied these requests. The department has pledged to cooperate with the congressional investigation, which will parallel four other probes into the attack.

The hearing, scheduled for October 10, is expected to focus on the events leading up to the attack and the response of the US government. The incident has sparked controversy, with Republicans accusing the administration of downplaying the seriousness of the attack and Democrats pointing to the lack of a reasonable security presence that could have defended the consulate.

The attack occurred amid widespread protests against US facilities throughout the Arab world, sparked by an Internet video denigrating Islam's Prophet Muhammad. The US director of national intelligence has since acknowledged that early analyses of the events were incorrect, and officials have linked the attack to terrorist groups.

The hearing is likely to showcase the deep differences between the parties' views on the best stance to take in the face of popular fury at the United States. The incident has also led to a renewed focus on the State Department's handling of security and diplomacy in the Middle East.

Title: Cream of Wheat Packaging Under Review Amidst Growing Concerns Over Racial Stereotypes

Article:

B&G Foods, the parent company of Cream of Wheat, has announced an immediate review of the brand's packaging, following recent decisions by other companies to overhaul their branding in response to renewed calls for racial equality. The review comes as the company acknowledges concerns regarding the Chef image on its packaging, which has been criticized for perpetuating racial stereotypes.

The Cream of Wheat brand has been criticized for its use of a smiling Black chef on its packaging since the 1890s. The original mascot, known as Rastus, was a racial caricature of a Black man, which is considered derogatory. The image was later replaced in the 1920s with a depiction of a Chicago chef, Frank L. White, who passed away in 1938.

This move follows announcements by other companies, including Quaker Oats, Mars, and Conagra Brands, to retire or rebrand their products due to concerns over racial stereotypes. Quaker Oats announced it would retire the Aunt Jemima brand from its packaging, citing its association with a racial stereotype. Mars, the owner of Uncle Ben's, announced it would "evolve" its brand and visual identity, while Conagra Brands began a review of its Mrs. Butterworth's brand, which features a syrup bottle with an offensive "Mammy" racial caricature of a Black woman.

B&G Foods has stated its commitment to evaluating its packaging and taking proactive steps to ensure its brands do not inadvertently contribute to systemic racism. The company has unequivocally condemned prejudice and injustice of any kind.

Title: Anne Holton, Wife of Tim Kaine, Steps Up as Democratic Surrogate for Hillary Clinton

Anne Holton, the wife of Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine and daughter of a former Republican governor, is increasingly taking on a more prominent role in the Clinton campaign. As Hillary Clinton's popularity numbers take a hit in the polls, Holton is being deployed to help shore up support among women voters and push the Democratic presidential nominee's education platform.

Holton, a former lawyer, judge, and Virginia education secretary, has an accomplished background in politics and education. She resigned from her role as education secretary in July to focus on the campaign. Her unique experience and background make her well-positioned to promote Clinton's education platform and connect with women voters who may be having second thoughts about the Democratic nominee.

According to Matthew Dallek, an associate professor of political science at George Washington University, Holton's involvement is a strategic move to help boost Clinton's favorability and trust numbers. "Because Hillary Clinton's favorability and trust numbers are so low – she needs help... and it's the kind of help Bill Clinton is unable to provide," Dallek said.

Holton has been making appearances on the campaign trail, meeting with students, supporters, and educators in New Hampshire and Virginia. She has also been highlighting Clinton's role as a new grandmother, often receiving "awwws" from audience members. In recent stops, Holton has focused on Clinton's education proposals, including making college tuition free for some students.

While it is unusual for the spouse of a vice presidential nominee to play such a prominent role, Holton is a political factor and public expert in her own right. Her father, A. Linwood Holton Jr., was a moderate Republican who became the first GOP governor to be elected in Virginia in nearly a century. He worked to integrate the schools in response to court-ordered desegregation, even sending a young Anne Holton to attend a public school in Richmond with a black student majority.

The Clinton campaign has signed off on Holton's public appearances, but declined an interview request from FoxNews.com. Meanwhile, Karen Pence, the wife of Republican vice presidential nominee Mike Pence, has been making more appearances on the trail, accompanying her husband on a recent swing through Georgia.

Title: President Obama's Thanksgiving Address Focuses on Gratitude and Unity

In his Thanksgiving Day address, President Obama did not explicitly mention the word "immigration," but he did express gratitude for the contributions of immigrants and the nation's diversity. The president reflected on the country's history, acknowledging the Pilgrims who arrived on American shores and the Native American tribes who welcomed them. He also recognized the generations of immigrants who followed, who came from all over the world and worked to build a better life for themselves and their families.

The president's message was one of unity and gratitude, as he emphasized the importance of counting one's blessings and giving thanks for the freedoms and opportunities available in the United States. He specifically mentioned the men and women in uniform who defend these freedoms and the people who work to make the country a better, more compassionate nation.

In his address, President Obama also encouraged Americans to remember those in need and to take action to help them. He praised those who volunteer at soup kitchens, participate in service projects, and bring joy to those who are lonely or struggling. The president emphasized that this kind of generosity is a fundamental part of American culture and a key aspect of the nation's identity.

Throughout his message, President Obama stressed the importance of unity and the idea that Americans are all part of one family. He concluded by saying, "No matter our differences, we're all part of one American family. We are each other's keeper. We are one nation, under God."

Title: Gun Rights Supporters to March in Fort Smith, Arkansas, to Highlight Disputed Law

A group of gun rights supporters, Arkansas Carry, is planning an invitation-only "open carry" march in Fort Smith, Arkansas, this weekend to highlight a law that they argue allows the open carry of handguns, despite an attorney general's opinion stating otherwise. The new law, which took effect on August 16, defines a "journey" as traveling "beyond the county in which the person lives."

The head of Arkansas Carry, Steve Jones, claims that the attorney general's advisory opinion is incorrect and that the law authorizes open carry. Jones stated that the group coordinated the event with police and prosecutors, although city officials are staying out of the debate over the attorney general's opinion.

Fort Smith Police Chief Kevin Lindsey wrote in an email to officers that there would not be a violation of the law unless an officer could prove that there was an unlawful attempt to employ a handgun, knife, or club as a weapon against a person. A patrol car will be present at the march, and Sgt. Daniel Grubbs, a department spokesman, stated that as long as everyone is lawfully in possession of a handgun, they are legally allowed to carry it under certain situations.

The attorney general's office declined to comment on the event. In his advisory opinion, Attorney General Dustin McDaniel stated that the "journey" exception was meant to allow Arkansans to "protect themselves from the dangers of the open road" and that he does not interpret Act 746 as authorizing "open carry."

The gun rights group is planning to hold similar marches in other cities to highlight the law.

Title: House Minority Leader Pelosi Faces Growing Pressure from Democrats on Impeachment and Leadership

Article:

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi is facing increasing pressure from her fellow Democrats on two fronts: her stance on impeachment and her leadership style. Despite her initial reluctance, a majority of House Democrats voted to introduce articles of impeachment against President Trump on Wednesday, with 58 Democrats voting in favor. This move comes after Pelosi and Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer had urged caution, stating that "now is not the time to consider articles of impeachment."

Pelosi's hesitation on impeachment has put her at odds with left-wing activist groups that have been demanding Trump's impeachment since before his inauguration. Her leadership style has also been questioned by some Democrats, particularly after her handling of the sexual harassment allegations against Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.). Conyers resigned last Friday after sworn affidavits from four former staffers described him as a "serial sexual harasser" who preyed on female staffers and demanded sexual favors.

Pelosi initially defended Conyers, calling him an "icon," and deferred to a House Ethics Committee investigation. However, it took her 10 days to call for Conyers' resignation, which she did only after facing pressure from fellow Democrats who were furious over his remaining in office. The first two Democrats to demand Conyers' resignation were Reps. Kathleen Rice (D-N.Y.) and Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.), who have been critical of Pelosi's leadership.

Other Democrats, such as Reps. Tim Ryan (D-Ohio) and Joseph Crowley (D-N.Y.), have also questioned Pelosi's leadership, demanding a faster investigation and calling for Conyers to resign. Crowley and Rep. Linda Sanchez (D-Calif.), chair and vice-chair of the House Democratic Caucus, respectively, took a more cautious approach, urging restraint and waiting for the ethics committee's investigation to conclude.

In the end, Pelosi and her leadership team caved to pressure and demanded Conyers' resignation. The incident highlights the challenges Pelosi faces in keeping her caucus in line and her leadership style under scrutiny.

Title: President Obama to Propose Major Spending Increases in FY 2016 Budget

Article: President Barack Obama is set to release his fiscal year 2016 budget on Monday, which is expected to include significant spending increases. In his weekly address, Obama emphasized that the federal government has the funds to invest in infrastructure, education, and other priorities due to shrinking deficits. The budget would also undo automatic spending cuts known as sequestration, paving the way for even higher spending in the future.

The president's proposal would increase spending by $74 billion and includes measures such as making two years of community college free for responsible students and expanding access to faster internet and new markets. Obama stated that the government can afford these investments, citing a reduction in deficits since he took office.

Deficits have indeed decreased significantly over the past few years, but the national debt continues to rise, standing at $18 trillion. Republicans, however, are pushing their own measures aimed at helping working families, including a plan to expand 529 college savings accounts.

House GOP leaders have proposed a plan to expand the 529 accounts, which allow families to save for college and withdraw the money tax-free. The White House had previously sought to tax 529s but withdrew the plan after public criticism and private pressure from prominent Democrats.

Representative Lynn Jenkins, a Kansas Republican, urged the president to put his full weight behind the GOP plan to expand and strengthen 529 accounts, stating that it would reward hardworking families and make it easier for them to send their children to college. Jenkins also called on the president to approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which cleared the Senate this week but is expected to be vetoed by Obama.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee to Receive Classified Document Justifying Drone Strikes Against Americans

The Senate Intelligence Committee will receive a classified document on Thursday morning that seeks to justify the administration's policy of targeting Americans overseas via drone attacks. The document, provided by the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC), aims to clarify the legal basis for the use of lethal force in counterterrorism operations.

The announcement comes as confirmation hearings are set to begin for CIA director nominee John Brennan, who has been a key figure in the drone program during his four years as President Barack Obama's principal adviser on terrorism. The development is also a response to criticism from senators, including several Democrats, about the secrecy surrounding the drone policy.

The 16-page white paper, titled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qaida or an Associated Force," is a policy paper rather than an official legal document. The document is intended to provide legal justification for the drone strikes, which have been a contentious issue among lawmakers and human rights groups.

The drone campaign against al Qaeda and its allies has been a significant aspect of Brennan's legacy, with at least 28 of the terrorist organization's leading members killed in drone strikes, including Anwar al-Awlaki, a U.S. citizen who was killed in a drone strike. Human rights groups have expressed concerns about the targeted killing of al-Awlaki and his teenage son, who was also killed in a separate strike.

The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Rep. Mike Rogers, has defended the drone strike that killed al-Awlaki, stating that he had officially joined al Qaeda and declared war on the United States. Rogers believes that once an individual joins a foreign terrorist organization, they no longer receive the same protections as U.S. citizens.

In his 2012 speech at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, Brennan argued that drone strikes are legal under the Authorization for Use of Military Force resolution passed by Congress after the September 11 attacks and because there is no international law that prohibits the use of remotely piloted aircraft for this purpose.

The president has agreed to provide the Intelligence Committee with access to the OLC opinion, stating that the scrutiny and debate are healthy. The move is seen as a step towards greater transparency and accountability in the drone program.

Title: ACLU Asks Judge to Order Mental Health Counseling for Separated Immigrant Children

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has requested a federal judge to order the U.S. government to provide mental health counseling for the approximately 2,000 immigrant children separated from their parents at the U.S.-Mexican border. The request comes after a chaotic week for U.S. immigration officials, who failed to meet a court-ordered deadline on Tuesday for reuniting children under the age of five.

The ACLU argues that the government must establish a fund to pay for professional mental health counseling to treat children who are suffering from severe trauma as a result of their forcible separation from their parents. The cost of the fund will be determined at a future date.

The family separation policy was instituted as part of President Donald Trump's efforts to curtail illegal immigration. The administration ended the practice last month after widespread protests. However, nearly half of the 103 children under five remain separated because of safety concerns, the deportation of their parents, and other issues.

The ACLU also claims that the government failed to communicate with the plaintiffs about when and where immigrants would be released, something it had promised the judge it would do. In one case, the ACLU said immigration officials reunited a mother with her six-month-old daughter, then dropped them alone at a bus stop late at night. The woman finally obtained a bus ticket around midnight Tuesday after her attorney and an advocate got involved.

The government now must reunite all parents and the remaining 2,000 children by July 26. The government's struggle to reunite around 100 children under five has raised questions among immigration advocates about whether it has any coherent plan for reuniting the remaining families. Immigration officials have said the process was slowed by background checks, and in court papers, they said they identified one parent with a warrant for murder in Guatemala and others with suspected human trafficking violations. Other parents were barred from being reunited for less serious violations, such as drunk driving convictions.

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar said in a statement, "Throughout the reunification process our goal has been the well-being of the children and returning them to a safe environment. The reunification process has been chaotic and has unequivocally come at a cost."

Beth Krause, a supervising lawyer at the Legal Aid Society's Immigrant Youth Project, said, "The reunification process has been chaotic and has unequivocally come at a cost."

Title: Rep. Duncan Hunter Resigns from Congress, Will Leave Office on January 13

Rep. Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California, has sent a letter of resignation to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and California Governor Gavin Newsom, and will officially leave his post on January 13. Hunter, 42, pleaded guilty last month to a single count of conspiracy to misuse at least $150,000 in campaign funds for personal expenses. He is facing up to five years in prison and will be sentenced on March 17.

In his letter, Hunter did not mention his guilty plea or innocence, instead focusing on his congressional accomplishments and military service. He highlighted his decision to join the Marines after the 9/11 terror attacks and listed the ways he has helped his constituents improve their lives. Hunter also expressed his pride in giving a voice to men and women in uniform.

According to the indictment, Hunter and his wife spent campaign funds on a birthday party for their daughter at an expensive hotel, as well as social outings with friends at a French bistro in Washington, D.C. Prosecutors also accused Hunter of using the funds for extramarital affairs with lobbyists and congressional aides. His wife, Margaret, was also charged in the case but accepted a plea deal in June, which required her to testify against her husband.

The 50th Congressional District, which Hunter represented, has a Republican registration advantage over Democrats. Former congressman Darrell Issa is considered a front-runner to fill the vacant seat. Governor Newsom has not yet announced whether he will call for a special election, and has the option to leave the seat vacant until November under state law.

Title: Georgia State Representative Erica Thomas Claims Racially Charged Verbal Assault in Publix Aisle

A Georgia state representative, Erica Thomas, has accused a white man of making racist comments and telling her to "go back where you came from" after she had too many items in the express lane at a Publix store. Thomas, a Democrat, shared her experience on Twitter and Facebook, stating that the man called her a "lazy SOB" and told her to leave because she had too many items in the express lane.

According to Thomas, she was shopping with 15 items, which exceeded the 10-item limit for the express lane. She explained that she was nine months pregnant and couldn't stand up for long, making it difficult for her to move to another lane. The man, Eric Sparkes, allegedly approached her and made the comments, which Thomas described as a form of racial profiling.

However, Sparkes, who claims to be a Democrat, has denied the allegations, stating that he was simply trying to point out that Thomas was using the express lane with too many items. He explained that he approached the customer service desk and asked what could be done, as the store policy prohibits customers from using the express lane with more than 10 items. Sparkes claimed that Thomas became aggressive and berated him, and he responded by calling her "selfish."

The dispute has sparked a heated debate on social media, with some supporting Thomas's account and others siding with Sparkes. The incident highlights the ongoing issue of racial profiling and discrimination, as well as the importance of understanding and respecting store policies.

Title: Romney Refuses to Release More Than Two Years of Tax Returns Amid Pressure

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, has maintained his stance of only releasing two years of his tax returns, despite growing pressure from the Obama campaign and some fellow Republicans. Romney has argued that he has complied with the law by releasing his 2010 return and an estimate of his 2011 tax information, with plans to make the full return public once it is finalized.

This position is consistent with Romney's stance during his 2002 campaign for Massachusetts governor, where he also only released two years of tax returns. At the time, his Democratic rival, Shannon O'Brien, released her tax information and called on Romney to do the same. Romney cited privacy concerns, stating that some information is not required for release and is private.

However, Romney has also called for greater tax transparency in the past when it served his political purposes. During his 2002 campaign, he sought to turn Enron into a campaign issue when it was revealed that O'Brien's husband, Emmett Hayes, had lobbying ties to the scandalized energy and commodities firm. Hayes had filed his taxes separately from O'Brien, and Romney's campaign demanded that O'Brien come clean about her husband's financial ties to Enron.

In contrast, Romney's campaign manager, Eric Fehrnstrom, defended the decision not to release Romney's returns, stating that O'Brien was trying to hide important information from voters by declining to reveal her husband's returns, while Romney was simply acting on principle.

The tax return issue also made an appearance in Romney's first political campaign, his 1994 Senate run against Ted Kennedy. In that race, Romney assumed the role of transparency advocate, calling for Kennedy to release his tax returns. However, Kennedy refused, and Romney did not release his own returns as well.

It is worth noting that Romney's stance on tax transparency has been inconsistent, as he has called for greater transparency in the past when it served his political purposes. However, his current refusal to release more than two years of tax returns has drawn criticism from some Republicans and Democrats alike.

Title: Vice President Mike Pence Responds to Criticism from Democratic Presidential Hopeful Pete Buttigieg

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence has responded to recent comments made by Democratic presidential hopeful Pete Buttigieg, who criticized Pence's religious beliefs on marriage during a speech to an LGBT campaign group. Buttigieg, who is openly gay and married, stated that Pence's quarrel is not with him, but with his creator. Buttigieg also mentioned that his gay marriage brought him closer to God.

In response, Pence told CNBC that Buttigieg "knows better" than to make critical comments about his Christian faith and personal beliefs. Pence noted that he has a good working relationship with Buttigieg, who was the mayor of South Bend, Indiana, during his governorship.

Pence's wife, Karen, also responded to Buttigieg's comments, emphasizing the importance of respecting people's religious beliefs. She stated that children should learn that it is okay to have different faiths and that people should not be attacked for their beliefs.

It is worth noting that Pence has been a long-time advocate for traditional marriage, and his views on the issue have not changed.

Title: Ben Carson's Campaign for Vice President May Be Gaining Momentum

Ben Carson, the former neurosurgeon and presidential candidate, may have ended his bid for the presidency, but his campaign for vice president is just beginning. According to sources familiar with the plan, members of Carson's brain trust have scheduled a meeting on March 29 in Palm Beach, Florida, where Carson has a mansion, to discuss his future plans.

The meeting will reportedly include a discussion on what to do with the massive 700,000-person mailing list the campaign has accumulated, the PAC connected with the campaign, and possibly establishing a formalized speaking program for Carson. The main focus of the meeting, however, will be to position Carson to be offered the vice presidential spot by Donald Trump should he become the nominee.

Carson's team has been exploring ways to leverage his massive mailing list and political action committee to support Trump's campaign. The meeting will also likely involve discussing a potential speaking program for Carson, who has been a vocal supporter of Trump.

While Carson has not officially joined the Trump campaign, he has hinted that he would be willing to accept a position in a potential Trump administration. Carson has also announced his involvement with the group My Faith Votes, which aims to mobilize Christian voters in the general election.

The meeting comes after Carson's campaign manager, Ed Brookover, joined the Trump campaign as a delegate selection team leader. Brookover did not comment on the meeting, and other members of Carson's team, including treasurer Logan Delaney and former senior adviser Mike Murray, also declined to comment.

The meeting's agenda will likely include discussing the potential role Carson could play in a Trump administration, as well as exploring ways to utilize his massive mailing list and political action committee to support Trump's campaign.

Title: White House and Congressional Leaders Struggle to Find a Permanent Solution to Budget Crisis

The recent government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis has left many questioning whether President Barack Obama has effectively sidelined Republicans. Despite the White House's claims that they have achieved a victory, many are skeptical that the temporary fixes discussed will bring about lasting change. The next few days will be crucial in determining the government's financial future, with the possibility of default and future deadlines looming.

White House officials have downplayed the idea that their recent discussions with Republicans were a negotiation, instead framing it as a conversation about what would and wouldn't be included in a deal. Congressional leaders have also attempted to explain away the temporary nature of the solutions being discussed, which could bring about another crisis in a few weeks or months.

Despite the White House's confidence in having shocked Republicans and Democrats alike with their commitment to preserving Obamacare and holding the line on major budget basics, many still doubt that the system will fundamentally change. The House GOP has been sidelined from the final stages of negotiations, but some Republicans, such as Senator Ted Cruz, remain committed to using shutdowns and debt limit standoffs as a means to achieve their goals.

Senator Jeff Sessions, the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee, believes that the discussion will not go away and may resurface in the future. The reinvigorated Democrats see this as a sign that their opponents are running out of steam, but the White House argues that they are not negotiating with those who demanded a "ransom" and are instead focusing on finding a more permanent solution.

The White House press secretary, Jay Carney, emphasized that the continued threat of default as a point of leverage in a budget negotiation is putting the American economy at risk in an effort to achieve a partisan advantage. However, the reality is that Republicans have successfully forced the president to choose between risking a global meltdown and eating chunks of their agenda, despite having only a slim majority in one chamber of Congress.

Title: Trump Criticizes Obama's Handling of Syria, Blames Former President for Recent Chemical Attack

Article:

President Trump has criticized the handling of the Syrian crisis by his predecessor, former President Barack Obama, calling the recent chemical attack in Syria "reprehensible" and blaming Obama's "weakness and irresolution" for the situation. Trump's statement did not specify what actions his administration would take in response to the attack or what its posture would be towards the Syrian government.

Trump's criticism of Obama's policy on Syria dates back to 2013, when he was a private citizen. At the time, Trump argued that the US should not get involved in the conflict. In August 2013, after the US concluded that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons, Trump tweeted that the US "should stay the hell out of Syria." He repeated this message as the conflict intensified and the Obama administration considered a military strike.

In 2013, the US and international community concluded that the Syrian government had used chemical weapons, and the Obama administration was considering a military strike to send a message. Trump questioned whether it was worth it, focusing on how the US would look in the eyes of the world. When Obama announced he would seek congressional approval to carry out strikes in Syria, Trump criticized the decision, saying it was a sign of weakness.

The situation ultimately led to a multinational agreement, brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry, in which the Syrian government agreed to give up its chemical weapons. Trump was not pleased with the outcome, concluding that Obama's handling of Syria made America look weak.

Trump's recent statement on the chemical attack in Syria did not provide any new information on what his administration would do in response to the attack or its posture towards the Syrian government. Press Secretary Sean Spicer said that the president's statement "speaks for itself" and that Trump is meeting with his national security team to discuss the situation.

Title: Obama Abandons Plan to Tax College Savings, Republicans Seek to Expand Break

Article:

In a sudden and unexpected move, President Barack Obama has dropped a plan to tax college savings accounts, known as 529 plans, which had been part of his budget proposal. The decision came after a strong lobbying effort from key leaders in his own party, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and House Budget Committee ranking Democrat Chris Van Hollen. The plan had been met with swift opposition from both Republicans and some Democrats, who argued it would disproportionately affect middle-class families.

The 529 plans, which benefit mostly upper-middle-class and wealthier families, were part of a broader proposal to shift taxes to the wealthy and shift benefits to lower-income individuals. However, the plan faced criticism from conservatives and mainstream groups, who argued it would hurt the middle class.

The White House announced the decision to drop the plan, stating that it had become a distraction and would not be included in the budget proposal. Instead, the administration will focus on delivering a larger package of education tax relief with bipartisan support.

House Republicans, however, are seeking to expand the tax break for 529 plans. A legislative aide to one of the authors of a bipartisan bill to expand tax savings for 529s said the plan is expected to be brought to the floor for a vote in late February.

The decision to drop the plan was met with mixed reactions. Some Democrats, such as Rep. Ron Kind, a moderate Wisconsin Democrat, joined with Republican Rep. Lynn Jenkins to propose a bill to expand and strengthen 529s. Others, like former White House economic adviser Jared Bernstein, criticized the decision, suggesting the White House might have been "blindsided" by the criticism and should have tweaked the plan to allow lower-income individuals to keep using the accounts.

Not everyone was pleased with the decision, however. Some left-leaning groups had backed nixing the savings vehicle, citing the perception that it was widely used by the middle class. The Urban Institute's Kim Rueben noted that only 3% of families use 529 plans, and the vast majority make more than $200,000 a year.

Iowa Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley, former chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, praised the decision, stating that the average amount saved in such plans by Iowa families is less than $20,000. "It didn't make sense to attack a program that encourages savings," Grassley said. "The tax code encourages all kinds of behavior, and saving for college is usually something everybody supports. The president's dropping his misguided plan is a victory for common sense."

Title: Trump's Strongest Supporters in Media Lose Faith in Attorney General Jeff Sessions

Article:

In a recent interview with The New York Times, President Trump expressed regret for choosing Jeff Sessions as Attorney General, sparking a wave of criticism from some of his strongest supporters in the media. While the White House maintains that Trump still has confidence in Sessions, some prominent pro-Trump voices have publicly turned against him.

Roger Stone, a longtime Trump adviser, stated that Sessions "does not have the confidence of the President" and should resign. Chuck Johnson, a writer for GotNews, called for Trump to fire Sessions and replace him with Senator Ted Cruz, citing Cruz's supposed pro-Constitutional stance and intelligence. Right-wing blogger Mike Cernovich blasted Sessions as "out of touch" and demanded he step down.

New York Post columnist Michael Goodwin had previously called for Trump to fire Sessions, suggesting that firing the special counsel would be a rallying cry for the left and alienate some Republicans. While Fox News host Sean Hannity and radio host Rush Limbaugh stopped short of calling for Sessions' resignation or firing, they both appear to have soured on the Attorney General.

Hannity criticized Sessions on his radio show for not reopening the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server, stating that "I don't know where Jeff Sessions is, maybe something's happening that we don't know about." Limbaugh similarly sided with Trump over Sessions, suggesting that Trump was blindsided by Sessions' recusal and that he would be "livid" if he were in Trump's shoes.

Title: Florida Senator Marco Rubio Criticizes US-Cuba Policy, Says It Has Benefited the Castro Regime

Article: Florida Senator Marco Rubio, a son of Cuban migrants, criticized the US-Cuba policy during a recent debate in Miami, stating that the reopening of relations with Cuba has allowed more money to flow to the Castro regime, rather than improving the lives of the Cuban people. Rubio emphasized that "nothing will change for the Cuban people" and that things are actually worse now than they were before the opening.

Rubio's comments were met with applause from the audience, as he listed his anti-Castro grievances. In contrast, Donald Trump, who is currently leading in the polls and delegate count, said he wants a "much better deal" with Cuba and believes it's time to make a deal after 50 years. Trump emphasized that the US should not make deals that are not beneficial to the country.

Ted Cruz, another candidate on the stage, was asked if he would break diplomatic relations with Cuba, and he responded that it illustrates a "real difference" between him and his opponents on foreign policy. Cruz stated that Trump and Hillary Clinton, Obama's first secretary of state, have taken the same basic trajectory on policy.

John Kasich, the fourth candidate on stage, was asked if he would encourage US companies to do business with Cuba, and he responded that he would not. Trump reiterated that the US would not make a deal unless it's a "very good deal" for the country.

Title: ABC's George Stephanopoulos Under Fire for Donations to Clinton Foundation

ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos has faced criticism on social media for his donations to the Clinton Foundation, with many calling for his resignation. The controversy surrounds Stephanopoulos' $75,000 donation to the foundation, as well as his listed membership in the Clinton Global Initiative in 2010 and 2011.

According to reports, Stephanopoulos moderated a panel for the foundation during those years, but ABC claimed he did not pay any fees. The Washington Free Beacon contacted ABC about the donations, and the network replied just minutes after Politico broke the news, leading the Washington Post to demand an apology for "shopping around a scoop to a friendlier news outlet."
