On Twitter, users expressed their discontent with Stephanopoulos' ties to the Clinton Foundation, with some calling him a "Clinton hack" and demanding his resignation. Others questioned whether Stephanopoulos' donations were a conflict of interest, given his role as a news anchor.

The controversy has sparked a lively discussion on social media, with some users calling for Stephanopoulos to resign and others defending his right to donate to the foundation. The situation highlights the ongoing debate about the intersection of politics and journalism, and the importance of transparency in reporting.

Title: NFL Owners and Players Meet to Address National Anthem Protests, Trump's Criticism

The National Football League (NFL) held a meeting with team owners, players, and union leaders to discuss the ongoing controversy surrounding players kneeling during the national anthem. The meeting aimed to address the concerns of both sides, with NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell stating that the league is committed to helping players in their political activism.

The meeting came after U.S. President Donald Trump repeatedly denounced the players' actions as unpatriotic, urging fans to boycott games if players continue to kneel. Trump's comments have only made the practice more widespread, with over half of NFL players being black and protesting the killing of unarmed black men and boys by police, as well as racial disparities in the criminal justice system.

Despite Trump's wishes, the NFL did not seek commitments from players to stop kneeling during the national anthem. Instead, the league focused on helping players in their political activism, with Goodell praising players' character and their commitment to addressing social justice issues.

The meeting was attended by about two dozen people who showed their support for the protesting athletes, kneeling on the sidewalk while holding placards that read "Take a knee against police brutality." NFL players, including Malcolm Jenkins of the Philadelphia Eagles, discussed ways to amplify their voices and make long-term changes.

The NFL Players Association and the league itself released a joint statement, saying that everyone involved in the NFL community respects the country, flag, and anthem, and is working together to find common ground and commit to positive change.

The meeting was seen as a step towards finding a solution to the controversy, with the NFL and players' union working together to address the issues.

Title: China Announces Tariffs on US Products Worth $60 Billion in Escalating Trade War

The Chinese government has announced plans to impose tariffs of up to 25% on US products worth $60 billion, in response to the Trump administration's threats to tax $200 billion of Chinese goods. The tariffs, which will affect around 38% of all American exports to China, will target products such as meat, coffee, nuts, and machinery.

According to the Chinese State Council Tariff Commission, the tariffs are aimed at "safeguarding China's own legitimate interests" and will be imposed if the US follows through on its threats to tax Chinese goods. The list of targeted products includes 5,207 US goods, which will be subject to duties of 25%, 20%, 10%, and 5%.

The US and China trade goods and services worth around $650 billion each year, making it the largest trading relationship between two countries. However, China exports more to the US than the other way around, making it more challenging for the country to hit back against US tariffs.

The trade tensions between the US and China have been escalating since April 2017, when President Donald Trump directed the US Commerce Department to investigate whether imports of steel and aluminum from China and other countries threatened national security. The investigation resulted in tariffs on steel and aluminum products from China and many other countries in March. Beijing responded with equal measures, and the US then imposed tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods in July. The most recent threat from the Trump administration came this week, when it warned that it could impose steeper tariffs than originally planned on another batch of imports from China.

The White House has stated that instead of retaliating, China should address the longstanding concerns about its unfair trading practices. The US has also received responses from other major trading partners, including Canada, Mexico, and the European Union, which have imposed retaliatory tariffs in response to US tariffs on steel and aluminum.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Announces Plans to Introduce War Powers Resolution to Limit Trump's Military Actions Against Iran

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Sunday that the House will introduce and vote on a War Powers Resolution to limit President Trump's military actions against Iran. This move comes after Trump's decision to conduct an airstrike in Iraq that killed Iranian General Qassem Soleimani, head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' elite Quds Force. Pelosi and other Democrats have been critical of Trump's decision, claiming he did not properly notify Congress in advance and warning about the risk of escalation in the region.

The War Powers Resolution, which will be introduced by Senator Tim Kaine, D-Va., reasserts Congress's long-established oversight responsibilities by mandating that if no further Congressional action is taken, the Administration's military hostilities with regard to Iran cease within 30 days.

The White House sent Congress formal notification of the drone strike under the War Powers Act on Saturday, a senior administration official told The Associated Press. The notification, required by law within 48 hours of the introduction of American forces into an armed conflict or a situation that could lead to war, had to be signed and sent to Congress. However, the document sent to congressional leadership, the House speaker, and the Senate president pro tempore was entirely classified, according to a senior aide for the Democrats and a congressional aide speaking to the AP.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., and Senator Robert Menendez, D-N.J., also sent a letter to the president on Sunday asking him to fully declassify the notification, claiming that "there appears to be no legitimate justification" for keeping it secret.

Trump tweeted on Sunday that "legal notice is not required" for him to take additional action, but claimed that his online posts provided notification to Congress that he "will quickly & fully strike back, & perhaps in a disproportionate manner" if Iran attacks "any U.S. person or target." Iran has vowed to retaliate and avenge the death of Soleimani, and Iranian officials have announced they will be abandoning the 2015 nuclear deal, signaling threats of further nuclear proliferation.

Trump had also tweeted on Saturday that even Iran's cultural sites were potential targets for U.S. military action. "They're allowed to kill our people. They're allowed to torture and maim our people. They're allowed to use roadside bombs and blow up our people, and we're not allowed to touch their cultural sites? It doesn't work that way," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday.

Earlier that day, Iraqi lawmakers approved a resolution calling to expel U.S. troops from the country, who were sent there more than four years ago to aid in the fight against the Islamic State terror group.

Title: New York City's Jewish Community Reeling After String of Alleged Hate Crimes

The Jewish community in New York City is reeling after a recent string of alleged hate crimes, including vandalism targeting Jewish institutions and a violent attack on a rabbi's home in the suburb of Monsey. The alleged assailant, Grafton Thomas, entered the rabbi's home on the seventh night of Hanukkah and began slashing people with a longsword, leaving several people seriously wounded. Thomas's motivations are unknown, and friends report that he is mentally ill.

The incident has sparked concerns about anti-Semitism, with some attributing the rise in hate crimes to white supremacy, the alt-right, or President Donald Trump's rhetoric. However, Thomas is an African American man, which means his motivations may not fit the typical profile of anti-Semitic attacks.

According to Armin Rose, writing for Tablet, the overwhelming majority of alleged perpetrators in New York City are either black or Hispanic, and casting anti-Semitism as an issue pitting Jews against other minority groups threatens to re-agitate problems that many in the Jewish and surrounding communities hope no longer exist.

While far-right anti-Semitism is often the most familiar type, there is also anti-Semitism on the left and among progressive activists who have associated with known anti-Semites. The Jersey City shooters had a connection to the Black Hebrew Israelites, a black nationalist cult.

It is important to note that murder is often non-ideological, and just a small number of killings each year can be credibly connected to a political agenda. There is little evidence that these attacks are ideologically motivated, at least in terms of the ideologies of hate we are most familiar with, wrote Batya Ungar-Sargon in Forward.

The left and right should not ignore anti-Semitism, regardless of the perpetrator's background or ideology. Everyone should be concerned and angry about attacks and intimidation directed at Jewish people, but it is also important to demand more reporting and accurate reporting about the scale of the problem. Nationally, it is unclear that anti-Semitic violence is rising dramatically, and while anti-Semitic incidents have increased in New York City by 53% from 2018 to 2019, the overwhelming majority of incidents are classified by police as "criminal mischief," typically meaning vandalism and graffiti, with only 13% involving violence.

Title: New York Politicians Arrested in Alleged Plot to Buy GOP Spot in Mayoral Election

A New York State Senator and several local politicians were arrested on Tuesday morning for allegedly attempting to buy their way onto the Republican ticket in the upcoming New York City mayoral election. Senator Malcolm Smith, a Democrat, was taken into custody after being accused of agreeing to pay off Republican county committee leaders in exchange for their support.

According to the complaint, Smith allegedly agreed to pay bribes to obtain certificates authorizing him to run for mayor as a Republican, despite being a registered Democrat. The bribes were to be paid to party chairmen in the state's five boroughs.

City Councilman Daniel Halloran, a Republican, and four other local politicians were also arrested in connection with the alleged plot. Halloran allegedly received $20,500 in exchange for supporting Smith's bid for the GOP nomination, while two other officials were to receive $40,000 in bribes with a promise of an additional $40,000.

Smith's lawyer, Gerald Shargel, has denied the charges, stating that his client is a "dedicated and highly respected public servant." Smith has been a state senator since 2000 and has held various leadership positions, including president pro tempore of the state senate.

The arrests come as the mayoral election approaches, with current Mayor Michael Bloomberg unable to seek a fourth term. City Council Speaker Christine Quinn is considered the leading contender for the Democratic nomination, while Joe Lhota, a former deputy mayor under Rudy Giuliani, is the Republican frontrunner.

**US-China Trade Tensions Escalate as Beijing Threatens Retaliation**

The United States and China have taken a step back from resolving their trade dispute through negotiations, with Beijing vowing to retaliate against the US's plans to impose tariffs on an additional $300 billion in Chinese imports. The US had previously announced plans to impose 10% tariffs on these imports starting September 1 and December 15.

According to the State Council Tariff Committee, China has "no choice but to take necessary measures to retaliate" against the US's actions. However, the committee did not specify what these measures would be.

The US and China have been engaged in a trade war for months, with the US imposing tariffs on Chinese goods and China retaliating with its own tariffs on US goods. The two countries have held several rounds of talks, but have yet to reach a deal.

In a statement, a foreign affairs ministry spokeswoman expressed hope that the US would leave Hong Kong as an internal matter for the Chinese government to deal with. The US has been critical of China's handling of the situation in Hong Kong, where protests have been ongoing for over two months.

US President Donald Trump said he has a call scheduled "very soon" with Chinese President Xi Jinping to discuss the trade dispute. Trump also tweeted that he has "zero doubt" that Xi can "quickly and humanely solve the Hong Kong problem."

China's position on the trade negotiations has been consistent and clear, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The country hopes the US can meet halfway and implement the consensus reached by the two leaders in Osaka, and find mutually acceptable solutions through dialogue and consultation.

The US and China have been engaged in a trade war for months, with the US imposing tariffs on Chinese goods and China retaliating with its own tariffs on US goods. The two countries have held several rounds of talks, but have yet to reach a deal.

Title: Pentagon Warns of Unprepared Military Due to Automatic Budget Cuts

The Pentagon has warned that the automatic budget cuts known as sequestration could leave the US military unprepared for challenging combat missions. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel told Congress in April that the military is "eating its seed corn," meaning it is consuming its own readiness. The cuts will primarily affect maintenance and training, which will further erode the military's readiness and be costly to regain in the future.

The Air Force is particularly affected, with cuts in flying hours meaning pilots cannot practice their skills. At Seymour Johnson Air Force Base in North Carolina, training flights are a daily routine. However, due to budget constraints, pilots are being grounded, and the 336th Fighter Squadron has been shut down. Lieutenant Colonel James Howard, the squadron's commander, notes that the longer pilots remain idle, the longer it will take for them to regain their readiness.

Some critics argue that the military is using these complaints as a way to avoid budget cuts, citing the cancellation of high-profile programs like the Blue Angels and Fleet Week in New York. However, others argue that the military is simply trying to maintain its readiness and flexibility.

The problem is that Washington views sequestration as a temporary issue, with the military and Congress banking on the chance that the budget will return to normal next year. However, the long-term solution is a budget deal, which is not yet visible on the horizon. The Pentagon is seeking limited relief by asking Congress to allow it to shift funds to protect top priorities like flying time.

Title: Senate Reshapes Courts with Rule Change, Allowing for Faster Judicial Confirmations

The United States Senate has undergone a significant transformation in the past nine months, with Majority Leader Harry Reid's decision to change the rules allowing for the faster approval of most of President Barack Obama's judicial nominees. Since the rule change, the Senate has confirmed dozens of new judges, giving the administration a lasting impact on the judiciary.

Prior to the rule change, the Senate confirmed 36 district and circuit court judges over a roughly equivalent period during the 113th Congress. In contrast, the Senate has confirmed 68 judges since the rule change, according to Senate statistics. Republicans have fought against the rule change, using their remaining procedural tools to slow down the approval process.

The rule change has allowed the Obama administration to catch up to the judicial confirmation records of his immediate predecessors and recast the balance of the courts. Democrats argue that the installation of liberal-leaning justices up and down the bench will have a lasting impact.

However, the rule change has also had consequences. Republicans argue that it has "chilled" the lawmaking climate, and the Senate has fallen into a legislative deep freeze. Democrats have faced retribution from the GOP, with Senator Mike Enzi citing the "nuclear option" as a reason for blocking a raft of Obama's ambassadorial choices.

The rule change has also led to a change in the way the Senate operates. Republicans have shown no indication they will relent on their demand for procedural votes on most nominees, which slows the Senate to a crawl. Confirmation rates are up, but nominations still plod toward approval.

The impact of the rule change is difficult to quantify, with Democratic aides and researchers arguing that at least 20 key judicial and executive nominees would have been blocked by the GOP or delayed for months before November. Republicans, on the other hand, highlight changes in the balance of power, arguing that the Senate is far less efficient than a year ago.

The rule change has been met with mixed reactions from both sides. Democrats see it as a necessary step to address judicial emergencies and clear a backlog of judges, while Republicans view it as a power grab by the majority party. The debate is likely to continue as the Senate navigates the complex process of judicial confirmations.

Title: Ben Carson's Support Drops in Republican Presidential Poll Amidst Voter Doubts on Experience and Leadership

A recent national poll conducted by Quinnipiac University has shown a significant decline in support for Dr. Ben Carson, a 2016 presidential candidate, among Republican voters. The poll, released today, indicates that Carson's support has dropped 7 percentage points, from 23% to 16%, trailing Donald Trump by double digits.

According to the poll, Trump garnered 27% support, while Senator Marco Rubio took 17%, and Senator Ted Cruz earned 16%. All other GOP candidates received 5% or less. Carson had been neck-and-neck with Trump in early November, but has since fallen behind.

The poll suggests that voters are increasingly questioning Carson's experience and leadership abilities. Only 42% of Republican voters now believe Carson has the right experience to be president, a significant drop from 64% just four weeks ago. Similarly, only 6 in 10 Republicans say he has strong leadership qualities, down from 76% in early November.

The poll also shows that Carson's support has declined across various areas, including honesty and trustworthiness, and overall favorability. In a hypothetical general election matchup, Carson's 10-point lead over Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton from last month has evaporated, with the two candidates now tied at 46%.

The poll also highlights Clinton's continued strong support among women and liberals, with her leading Carson by 16 points among women and 30 points among liberals. Clinton remains the clear frontrunner in the Democratic nomination race, ahead of Senator Bernie Sanders by 30 points.

The poll was finalized before Carson's recent trip to Jordan to meet with Syrian refugees, a move aimed at bolstering his foreign policy credentials. However, the poll suggests that Carson's support has dropped equally across the board, particularly among evangelical voters, where he dropped 13 points.

Trump, on the other hand, remains steady at the top of the national polls, with less than two months until the Iowa caucuses.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Condemns White Nationalist Robocalls Amidst Voter ID Law Controversy

Article:

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has condemned robocalls from the American National Super PAC and its founder William Johnson, which have been flooding landlines in the state with messages perceived as racist and divisive. The calls, narrated by an elderly woman, assure listeners that Donald Trump will "respect all women and help preserve western civilization." This code phrase is believed to refer to Trump's stance on immigration and social welfare, which some see as a veiled attempt to appeal to white nationalists.

The controversy comes as Wisconsin prepares for its primary election, where a voter-ID law passed by the GOP-controlled legislature and signed by Walker may disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of mostly minority voters. The law has been criticized for its potential to suppress voting rights, particularly among traditionally Democratic constituencies.

Walker's condemnation of the robocalls is seen as ironic, given his own history of promoting policies that have disproportionately affected minority communities. The New Republic reported that Walker has spent his entire career cutting funding for programs benefiting inner-city African-Americans, such as public transportation, and pushing for private-school vouchers that decimate public education.

The article also highlights the racial polarization in Wisconsin, citing the state's segregated cities and suburbs, as well as the prevalence of white resentment politics on local talk radio. The author notes that Walker has been a guest on these shows, which have fueled the rise of white nationalism.

The controversy surrounding the voter-ID law and the white nationalist robocalls serves as a reminder of the broader efforts by Republicans to limit voting rights and suppress the power of traditionally Democratic constituencies. The article concludes that while Walker and his allies may not see themselves as racists, their actions and policies have had racist effects, and their condemnation of the robocalls rings hollow given their own history of promoting divisive rhetoric and policies.

**Stock Market Sees Sharp Decline, But Experts Say Global Recession Not Imminent**

The US stock market experienced a significant decline on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 588 points, or 3.6%, to close at 15,871.35. The Standard & Poor's 500 index also saw a decline of around 4%. The losses were triggered by concerns over China's struggling economy, which saw its benchmark stock index plummet 8.5%. The decline was dubbed "Black Monday" in Shanghai.

However, experts are cautioning against panic, saying that the situation is not as dire as it seems. Many forecasters believe that the risks are not of the global recession kind, and that the US economy is still demonstrating some forward momentum.

The US domestic economy is expected to show a growth rate of around 3% annualized in the latest reading, which is expected to be released this week. Home sales have ticked up positively, and the job market has improved, with unemployment at 5.3% of the labor force.

Some analysts argue that US stocks are not in "bubble" territory, with valuations looking average and relatively cheap compared to alternative investments. Others point out that the recent data from other major economies has been generally good, and that there is little to justify fears of a major global downturn.

The cooling of China's economy is expected to have a ripple effect on emerging-market nations, but experts say it is unlikely to have a significant impact on the US economy. The decline in China's currency has put pressure on other export-oriented economies, but the US is expected to see only small economic effects, with some positive benefits from lower commodity prices.

While the recent decline may seem unsettling, analysts say that sizable downward corrections are a feature of a healthy stock market. Volatility can be a sign that investors are actively engaged and that the market is adjusting to new information.

For long-term investors, dips can be buying opportunities, and some investment strategists see the current decline as a good buying opportunity. However, for those who are just starting to save or are hesitant to invest due to past market downturns, the current situation may be a daunting prospect.

Title: White House Scenes Well Drawn, but Book Fails to Balance Criticism of Media with Critique of Trump

The article discusses Howard Kurtz's book "Media Madness," which aims to provide an explanation and narrative for the ongoing battle between President Trump and the press. The book acknowledges that Trump is "loose with his language" and fails to "vet" his pronouncements, but places the onus on the media for mistakenly taking Trump literally. The article argues that this approach is problematic, as it requires a degree of calibration that is not present in Kurtz's own body of work. The book also portrays the White House as a chaotic, seat-of-the-pants operation, with Trump's behavior often resembling a cross between Lord of the Flies and Goodfellas.

The article highlights several vignettes from the book, including Trump's treatment of his staff, such as his yelling at Sean Spicer and his son-in-law Jared Kushner. The book also recalls Trump's meeting with the New York Times, which was cancelled and then rescheduled with Reince Priebus taking the blame. The article notes that Kurtz's portrayal of the White House is well-drawn, but that the book fails to balance its criticism of the media with a critique of Trump's behavior.

The article concludes that while "Media Madness" succeeds as a window on the dysfunction of Trump's White House, it comes up short as a critique of the media. The book captures the mainstream's visible biases but lets the president off too easily, failing to address Trump's own flaws and biases.

Title: FBI Investigation of Martin Luther King Raises Questions About FBI's Methods and Media Coverage

The FBI investigated Martin Luther King Jr. under the pretext that his aides included people loyal to the Russian government rather than their own. The agency used electronic surveillance to spy on him, reviewing salacious material of a sexual nature. The administration that initially authorized the spying denied, denied, denied.

The parallels between the FBI's actions against King and those against Donald Trump in 2016 are striking. However, the media's response to the two investigations diverges. While the FBI's actions against Trump were widely reported, the media's coverage of the King investigation has been limited.

A recent article published by Standpoint magazine reveals shocking discoveries about King's behind-closed-doors behavior. The article, written by Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer David Garrow, details King's alleged participation in an orgy and his alleged rape of a woman. The FBI bugged hotel rooms where King slept and expected privacy, and law enforcement officers listened to what they characterized as a rape without intervening.

The revelations raise questions about the FBI's methods and the media's coverage of the investigation. The FBI's actions against King, including bugging his hotel rooms and listening to his private conversations, are disturbing. The media's reluctance to report on the allegations, despite the involvement of a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, is also noteworthy.

The article's publication has sparked controversy, with some critics accusing the author of sensationalism and others defending the need for transparency. The FBI's actions against King, while disturbing, are not without precedent. The agency has a history of investigating and surveilling prominent figures, including J. Edgar Hoover and James Comey.

The media's response to the investigation has been mixed. While some outlets have reported on the allegations, others have been reluctant to touch the story. The lack of coverage in the US media is striking, given the significance of the allegations and the involvement of a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian.

The FBI's investigation of Martin Luther King raises important questions about the agency's methods and the media's coverage of the investigation. The controversy surrounding the article's publication highlights the need for transparency and accountability in both the FBI and the media.

Title: Two Minnesota Republicans Reportedly Attacked Over Political Differences

Article:

Two Republican politicians in Minnesota have reported being physically attacked in recent days, allegedly by individuals who were angry about their political views. State Representative Sarah Anderson (R) was attacked on Sunday by an unidentified male who was found kicking down her yard signs. According to Anderson, the police have a tentative identification of the suspect and plan to interview him.

Shane Mekeland, a Republican candidate for Minnesota House District 15b, reported being attacked on Friday during a campaign event at a bar. He suffered a concussion and said his attacker made a statement indicating anger towards politicians who allegedly abandon the middle class. Mekeland described the statement as "typical" and not specifically aligned with either party.

Some Democrats, including Representative Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and former Attorney General Eric Holder, have faced criticism in recent months for calls to protest GOP candidates and lawmakers. Holder, who served under former President Obama, took to Twitter to defend himself, stating that he is not advocating violence and that Republicans are undermining democracy. He emphasized the need for Democrats to be "tough, proud, and stand up for the values we believe in."

It is unclear whether the attacks on Anderson and Mekeland are related to the political tensions and rhetoric surrounding the 2022 midterm elections. The incidents highlight the growing concerns about political violence and intimidation in the United States.

Title: Office of Government Ethics Director Walter Shaub to Resign, Citing Desire to Pursue Ethics Reforms

Article:

Walter Shaub, the Director of the Office of Government Ethics (OGE), announced his resignation on Thursday, effective July 19. Shaub, who was appointed by former President Barack Obama in 2013, has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration's handling of ethics issues. In his resignation letter, Shaub expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to lead the OGE and emphasized the importance of upholding the principle that public service is a public trust.

Shaub's departure comes as no surprise, given his frequent clashes with the Trump administration over issues such as the president's decision to distance himself from his business empire and the administration's disclosure of ethics waivers for former lobbyists serving in the White House. Shaub had previously criticized the White House for not taking adequate steps to distance Trump from his business interests, stating that the president's actions created an appearance that his businesses were profiting from his occupancy of the presidency.

Shaub will join the Campaign Legal Center as senior director of ethics, where he will focus on pushing for changes to federal ethics rules. The OGE's primary goal is to prevent conflicts of interest for government employees, but it has limited means to enforce federal ethics rules, aside from publicly raising questions about possible conflicts.

The White House accepted Shaub's resignation and expressed appreciation for his service. The president plans to nominate a successor "in short order." Shaub's term was set to expire in January, and his departure means that Trump has the power to appoint a new director.

Shaub's departure has been met with praise from some ethics experts, who credit him with being "far more outspoken" than his predecessors about the ethical shortcomings of the Trump administration. Don Fox, who served as the OGE's general counsel from 2008 to 2013 and acting director from 2011 to 2013, stated that Shaub was "far more outspoken" about what he perceived as the ethical shortcomings of this administration.

In his new role, Shaub hopes to bolster federal ethics rules and work towards ethics reforms at all levels of government.

Title: House Republicans to Vote on Full Repeal of Affordable Care Act

The House of Representatives is set to hold a vote on Wednesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, in its entirety. This marks the chamber's second attempt to repeal the law, which was upheld by the Supreme Court as constitutional in June. The vote is unlikely to pass the Democratic-controlled Senate, and President Obama has vowed to veto any such measure if it reaches his desk.

House Republicans have held 29 previous votes to repeal specific parts of the ACA since 2011. The latest measure was debated on the House floor for four and a half hours on Tuesday, with the remaining time set aside for the day of the vote. Democrats accused Republicans of wasting time with a "display of political theater" instead of focusing on helping the economy.

Democrats argued that the Supreme Court's ruling to preserve the law indicates that Republicans should move on to other issues. "It's time for Republicans to move on," said Rep. Donna Edwards, D-Md. Republicans, however, maintained their stance on the issue, contending that the high court only declared the law constitutional, not good policy.

House Republicans promised to repeal the ACA during the 2010 midterm elections, and they are committed to keeping that promise. "House Republicans promised the American people that if granted the majority, we would repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, better known as ObamaCare," said House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich. "Let's face it, ObamaCare is nothing like what was promised."

Representative Lee Terry, R-Neb., stated that he has voted to repeal the law 30 times and will continue to do so until it is repealed. The vote is expected to be a symbolic gesture, as the ACA is unlikely to be repealed in its entirety.

Title: Republicans Remain Silent as Trump Threatens to Fire Special Counsel Mueller

Article:

In the face of President Donald Trump's recent threats to fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller, many Republicans are remaining mum on the issue. Despite some initial reluctance to sign on to legislation preventing Trump from unilaterally firing Mueller, Republicans are now seemingly unwilling to take a stance on the matter.

According to The New York Times, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, as well as Senators John Cornyn, John Thune, Richard Burr, Chuck Grassley, Kevin McCarthy, Devin Nunes, and Bob Goodlatte, have declined to comment on the issue. The article notes that a majority of the Senate Intelligence Committee members have also remained silent.

House Speaker Paul Ryan's office issued a statement saying that Mueller and his team should be allowed to do their job, but stopped short of condemning Trump's potential actions. Senator Marco Rubio expressed confidence in Mueller's ability to conduct a fair and thorough investigation, but did not specify what he would do if Trump were to fire the special counsel.

Senator James Lankford described Trump as "exceptionally frustrated," but did not offer any concrete plans to address the situation. Senator Jeff Flake, one of the few Republicans to speak out, expressed hope that Trump would not fire Mueller, stating that it would be a "massive red line" that could not be crossed. However, he also noted that it would be too late to take action once the deed is done.

The lack of response from Republicans has sparked concerns about their willingness to stand up to Trump and protect the integrity of the investigation. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen whether Republicans will take a stronger stance on the issue.

Title: Hillary Clinton's New Book "What Happened" Hits Bookshelves, Sharing Memorable Anecdotes from Her 2016 Election Loss

Article:

Hillary Clinton's highly anticipated book, "What Happened," has finally hit bookshelves, offering a glimpse into her 2016 presidential election loss. The book chronicles Clinton's experiences during the two most intense years of her life, providing a unique perspective on the election and its aftermath.

In the book, Clinton shares several memorable anecdotes, including her early discussions with President Obama about running for president. She writes that Obama signaled his support for her candidacy, stating that he believed she was the party's best chance to hold the White House and keep their progress going.

Clinton also recounts her decision to attend President Trump's inauguration, seeking advice from an unexpected source: former President George W. Bush. Despite their political differences, Bush advised her to attend the inauguration, citing its importance for the country. Clinton writes that this advice gave her the push she needed to attend.

The book also touches on Clinton's encounters with Republican politicians, including former Rep. Jason Chaffetz, who had been critical of her handling of the Benghazi attack. Clinton reveals that she mistook Chaffetz for Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, and didn't recognize him until he posted a photo of their encounter on Twitter.

Clinton also shares an awkward encounter with Ryan Zinke, Trump's soon-to-be Interior secretary, who had previously called her the "antichrist." She writes that she was surprised he wanted her to meet his wife, considering their past disagreements.

In addition, Clinton discusses the controversy surrounding the FBI's reopening of the investigation into her emails, which some people thought she should have fired her longtime adviser Huma Abedin over. Clinton writes that she stood by Abedin, who had done nothing wrong and was an invaluable member of her team.

The book concludes with a poignant moment of Clinton and her husband, Bill, lying in bed on election night, feeling exhausted and unsure of what the future held.

Title: Taylor Swift Endorses Democratic Candidates in Tennessee Midterm Elections

Taylor Swift, the popular American singer-songwriter, has publicly endorsed two Democratic candidates running in the upcoming midterm elections in Tennessee. In a statement posted on her Instagram account, Swift expressed her support for Phil Bredesen, a Democratic candidate running for the Senate, and Jim Cooper, a Democratic candidate running for the House of Representatives.

Swift, who has previously been reluctant to share her political opinions, stated that she will be voting based on which candidate will protect and fight for human rights. She specifically criticized Marsha Blackburn, a Republican congresswoman running for the Senate, citing her voting record on issues such as equal pay for women, the Violence Against Women Act, and LGBTQ+ rights.

Swift's endorsement could potentially boost turnout among her young fans, many of whom are now of voting age. According to a study by Pew, millennials are among the most liberal generations in the U.S., with the majority supporting Democrats in their districts. However, young voters have historically shown low turnout rates, with only 20% of voters between the ages of 18 and 24 voting in the past four midterm elections.

Swift's statement emphasized the importance of voting and encouraged her fans to educate themselves on the candidates running in their state and vote based on their values. She also urged young voters to exercise their right to vote, stating that "so many intelligent, thoughtful, self-possessed people have turned 18 in the past two years and now have the right and privilege to make their vote count."

The endorsement has sparked reactions from both sides of the political spectrum. Blake Kitterman, vice president of Tennessee Young Democrats, praised Swift's decision, stating that her values align with those of the Democratic party. Andy Cole, vice chairman of the Tennessee Young Republicans, downplayed the impact of Swift's endorsement, saying that young voters are more concerned with issues like jobs and education than celebrity endorsements.

The midterm elections in Tennessee are set to take place on November 6th, with Swift's endorsement potentially influencing the outcome.

Title: US Secretary of State Warns Israeli-Palestinian Peace Deal in Jeopardy

The US Secretary of State, John Kerry, has expressed grave concerns about the prospects of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, citing the Israeli government's continued construction of settlements in occupied territories. Kerry emphasized that the two-state solution is the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and that Israel's current government is moving in the opposite direction.

The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, responded by calling Kerry's speech "obsessively focused" on settlements and accusing him of paying lip service to Palestinian terrorism. The Palestinian Liberation Organization's Hanan Ashrawi stated that the Palestinians have adhered to past agreements and honored their commitments, while Israel has consistently violated its commitments and is now actively working to destroy the two-state solution.

The US abstention from a recent UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements has sparked anger from Israel, with Netanyahu taking diplomatic reprisals against countries that voted in favor of the resolution. The US decision not to veto the resolution was seen as a significant shift in US policy, with some interpreting it as a sign that the US is no longer committed to the two-state solution.

The conflict over Israeli settlements is a major obstacle to peace, with over 500,000 Jews living in about 140 settlements built since Israel's 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The settlements are considered illegal under international law, although Israel disputes this.

The US Secretary of State's warning comes as the international community is gearing up for a French-led peace conference in mid-January, which could potentially set the stage for future diplomacy. However, the incoming US administration has made it clear that it will not pressure Israel into a corner, with President-elect Donald Trump tweeting that the US will not treat Israel with "total disdain and disrespect."

Title: Walker and Foes See Gubernatorial Race as Evenly Divided as Scott Walker Limping Toward 2016

Scott Walker, the Wisconsin governor, is facing another fight for his political survival as he seeks re-election against Mary Burke, a wealthy former Trek Bicycle executive and member of the Madison School Board. Despite his recall election victory in 2012, Walker's popularity has waned, and he is now struggling to assemble a bare majority to keep him in office.

Walker's campaign has focused on defending his record on job creation, an unexpectedly contentious point in his record. He has been criticized for his handling of the economy and his handling of public assistance programs. In recent campaign stops, Walker has been defending his record and asking voters to give him more time to get the economy turned around.

Walker's opponents, including Burke, have been critical of his record and have emphasized their own plans for job creation and economic growth. Obama campaigned for Burke in Milwaukee, hailing her as a "practical person" who knows how to spur economic growth.

The race is seen as evenly divided, with both Walker and Burke receiving support from around 47% of voters. The outcome will depend on "Obama-Walker voters," Wisconsinites who may have voted against Walker's recall in 2012 but for the president's reelection the same year.

Walker's campaign has emphasized his accomplishments, including sending a $322 rebate to Wisconsin taxpayers this year and implementing a drug testing program for public assistance recipients. However, his opponents have criticized his record and have emphasized their own plans for job creation and economic growth. The outcome of the election will be closely watched, as it will determine whether Walker will be able to continue his term as governor or if Burke will take over.

**Las Vegas Mass Shooting Leaves 59 Dead, 527 Injured**

A mass shooting occurred at a country music festival in Las Vegas, Nevada, on Sunday night, leaving at least 59 people dead and 527 injured. The gunman, identified as 64-year-old Stephen Paddock, opened fire from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Hotel towards the open-air music festival, which was attended by 22,000 people. Paddock killed himself as police stormed the room, where 10 guns were found.

The investigation has found no link to international terrorism, despite a claim from the so-called Islamic State. The FBI has confirmed that there is no evidence of a connection to an international terrorist organization.

The attack occurred during the final shows of the three-day Route 91 country music festival, with thousands of concert-goers enjoying a performance by top-billing singer Jason Aldean when the first of several bursts of automatic gunfire rang out. Hundreds of shots were fired, with witnesses describing the scene as chaotic and terrifying.

The victims include Jordan McIldoon, 23, from British Columbia, Canada, and Sonny Melton, a nurse from Big Sandy, Tennessee. An off-duty Las Vegas police officer was also among those who died.

The investigation is ongoing, with authorities searching Paddock's home in Mesquite, Nevada, and a second property. His motives for the attack remain unclear, with some investigators suggesting psychological issues, but there is no confirmation of this.

The attack has sparked a renewed debate on gun control in the United States, with former congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords calling for tougher gun laws. The incident is the deadliest mass shooting in recent US history, and it has left the city of Las Vegas reeling.

Title: Trump Slams Journalist for Fabricated Quote, Calls for Changes to Libel Laws

Article:

President Donald Trump has criticized journalist and New York University professor Ian Bremmer for attributing a quote to him that he claims is "completely ludicrous." The quote in question stated that Trump believed North Korean leader Kim Jong Un would make a better president than Joe Biden.

Trump took to Twitter to express his displeasure, stating that Bremmer had made up the quote and that it was an example of the "age of Fake News." He also called for changes to libel laws to hold the media accountable for spreading false information.

Bremmer initially responded to a Twitter user questioning the validity of the quote by saying it was "plausible," and later admitted that his initial tweet included a "completely ludicrous" statement. He later apologized for the mistake, stating that his tweet was meant in jest and that he should have been clearer.

Many journalists and Trump's traveling press corps quickly noted that the quote was fabricated. The incident has sparked debate about the role of social media in spreading misinformation and the importance of fact-checking in journalism.

Title: Fact-Checking the Debate: Obama and Romney's Claims Under Scrutiny

The second presidential debate between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney took place on Tuesday night, with both candidates facing intense scrutiny over their claims and facts. In this article, we will examine some of the key points made by the candidates and assess their accuracy.

One of the most contentious issues was the Benghazi attack, which occurred on September 11, 2012. Romney accused Obama of saying that the attack was an "act of terror," while Obama maintained that he never made such a statement. However, it is clear that Obama did suggest that the attack was a terrorist strike, although he did not specifically call it an "act of terror." The White House initially described the attack as a "spontaneous" demonstration related to an anti-Muslim video, but later changed its assessment to a pre-planned terrorist attack.

Romney also made claims about Obama's budget plan, stating that it would cost $8 trillion. However, Obama's math overshot by about $1 trillion, according to most estimates. Romney's own tax plan is estimated to cost $5 trillion, with the cost of extending the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans accounting for $1 trillion of that total.

In terms of specifics, Romney has proposed eliminating or scaling back taxpayer credits and deductions to offset the cost of his tax cuts. He has not provided full details on how he would achieve this, but has floated the idea of a $25,000 cap on deductions, which is lower than the $17,000 cap he previously mentioned.

Overall, while both candidates made claims about the facts, it is clear that the truth sometimes got caught in the crossfire during the debate.

Title: Missouri Gun Measure Fails to Override Veto by One Vote

Article:

A controversial gun measure in Missouri failed to override the governor's veto by a single vote in the state Senate. The bill aimed to make Missouri a haven for gun-toting felons and lunatics by nullifying federal gun regulations, including background checks. The measure would have also made it a crime for federal agents to enforce these laws.

The claim that a state can unilaterally decide to nullify federal law is considered absurd by many, including gun advocates who acknowledge its invalidity. Robert Levy, who funded litigation to convince the Supreme Court that the Second Amendment has nothing to do with a well-regulated militia, has recently conceded that the Missouri stunt flouts the very Constitution that its supporters claim to uphold.

Other states, such as Colorado and Iowa, are also pushing for more relaxed gun laws. Iowa recently passed a bill allowing concealed carry permits for blind individuals, while Colorado adopted a universal background check system and a modest restriction on high-capacity magazines. The National Rifle Association (NRA) has launched an effort to punish Colorado legislators who stood up for public safety over gun seller profits, resulting in the recall of two thoughtful legislators.

The NRA's efforts to punish legislators who stand up for public safety over gun seller profits are dangerous, as they undermine democracy and create false and misleading views about the actual content of state and federal laws. This rhetoric can galvanize unstable individuals, as seen in the case of Timothy McVeigh, who was influenced by similar hyperbole after the passage of the federal background check system and the assault weapons ban.

Gun owners must recognize their obligations to prevent the types of tragedies that occur daily in the U.S. when lawfully owned guns are used, intentionally or inadvertently, to kill and maim others. They must also take responsibility by not being duped by NRA deceptions to advance the economic interests of gun merchants and by taking every effort to ensure that their guns do not contribute to the mayhem.

Title: Obama Administration's Decision to Try Osama bin Laden's Son-in-Law in Federal Court Reignites Debate Over Handling of Suspected Terrorists

The Obama administration's decision to try Osama bin Laden's son-in-law, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, in a federal court in New York City has sparked a renewed debate over how to handle suspected terrorists. The move has drawn criticism from Republicans in Congress, who argue that Abu Ghaith should be held in military custody as an enemy combatant.

Abu Ghaith, who pleaded not guilty to conspiring to kill Americans, is accused of possessing information that could prevent harm to the United States and its allies. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., stated that Abu Ghaith is an enemy combatant and should be held in military custody.

The White House, however, claims that there is a "broad consensus" across the federal government to prosecute Abu Ghaith in a civilian court. Principal Deputy White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said that the intelligence community agrees that the best way to protect national security interests is to prosecute Abu Ghaith in an Article III court.

"We're able to question him as part of the regular process in detaining individuals like this, but we're also able to put him through Article III courts to ensure that he's held accountable for his crimes," Earnest said.

Despite the administration's justification, McConnell argued that the decision "makes little sense" and that the intelligence community "deserves the same access to intelligence and methods of defeating the enemy available to the team that found Bin Laden."

Representative Mike Rogers, R-Mich., also expressed opposition to the decision, stating that civilian court is not the appropriate venue and that the administration should treat enemy combatants like the enemy. "Al Qaeda leaders captured on the battlefield should not be brought to the United States to stand trial," Rogers said.

Other Republicans, including Representative Pete King, R-N.Y., also expressed concerns about the decision, citing security concerns and the potential for Abu Ghaith to receive a lighter sentence in a civilian court.

However, not all members of Congress oppose the administration's actions. Representative Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., who represents the congressional district where Ground Zero is located, expressed support for the decision, stating that he is "pleased Sulaiman Abu Ghaith will have to face justice in New York."

"We are a nation committed to the rule of law, and we will demonstrate our values to the world even in the face of the most despicable mass murder in our history," Nadler said.

Title: Rubio's Border Security Proposal Tests Limits of Bipartisan Immigration Reform Coalition

Article:

The Gang of Eight's hopes for a Senate supermajority on immigration reform are facing a major hurdle as the bill's fate hangs in the balance. The key challenge lies in securing enough Republican votes, particularly on border security measures, without alienating the majority of Senate Democrats who support the current bill. Senator Marco Rubio, a key member of the Gang of Eight, is pushing for a proposal that would have Congress, rather than the Department of Homeland Security, write the border control strategy. Rubio argues that Americans do not trust the government to get it right, and wants lawmakers to craft the plan at the outset.

Rubio's proposal has sparked concerns among reform proponents, who worry that the Senate supermajority is an elusive goal that could undermine the bill, particularly on border security. Marshall Fitz, a veteran of previous immigration reform fights, stated, "We are advocating for a strong and tight and effective bill as possible. If that means we are targeting 62 votes, then 62 on a strong bill is better than 75 on a weak bill that looks like a special interest bonanza."

Rubio believes that the current version of the legislation lacks the necessary votes to break a filibuster, let alone the 70-plus votes needed to pass the bill. Republicans view border security as a threshold issue, and many have told him that the requirements must be tightened before they can consider backing the bill. Rubio has stated, "It's very simple. If we can come up with a plan that people have confidence in for the border, I believe we'll have immigration reform. If we can not, we will not, and we should not. I don't think it will pass without those measures in there. I just don't."

Rubio has often gotten his way in the Gang of Eight deliberations, and his continued involvement is critical to the cause of bipartisan immigration reform. The group has made concessions to satisfy his demands, including a cut-off date for recent undocumented immigrants, a conservative media rollout, and an extended debate in the Judiciary Committee. Rubio has also consulted with top Republican targets, border security officials, and House members focused on border issues to gauge their demands for the bill.

Title: US Economy Regains Jobs Lost During Great Recession, but Wages Remain a Concern

The US economy has regained all the jobs lost during the Great Recession, according to a report commissioned by the U.S. Conference of Mayors. The report, prepared by the firm IHS, found that the country has regained all the jobs lost since the end of 2007, but the wages earned by workers in the restored sectors are significantly lower than those in the sectors where jobs were lost. The report highlights a "wage gap" of 23 percent, with annual wages in restored sectors averaging $47,171 compared to $61,637 in sectors where jobs were lost.

The report's findings contradict claims made by President Obama, who stated that the economy is better and that the country is experiencing a six-month streak of at least 200,000 new jobs each month. The report's data suggests that while job growth is occurring, the quality of those jobs is a concern.

Economist Pamela Villareal from the National Center for Policy Analysis noted that the growth in the economy has primarily occurred in retail, food service, and hospitality sectors, which typically pay lower wages. She emphasized the need for growth in higher-paying high-tech jobs, which could be achieved by reducing regulations and taxes.

The report also found that income inequality has grown during the recovery from the Great Recession. The top 20 percent of income-earning households now take home 51 percent of all income, compared to 43.6 percent in 1975. IHS economist Jim Diffley noted that this trend of the rich growing richer and the poor growing poorer extends back decades and is not a result of any specific policies implemented by the current administration.

The report's findings suggest that while the US economy has regained jobs lost during the Great Recession, the quality of those jobs and the growing income inequality remain concerns.

Title: Judge Rules Paul Manafort Breached Plea Deal by Lying to Prosecutors

A US District Court judge has ruled that Paul Manafort, the former election campaign chief of Donald Trump, breached his plea deal with special counsel Robert Mueller by making multiple false statements to the FBI, Mueller's office, and a grand jury. Judge Amy Berman Jackson made the ruling on Wednesday, stating that Manafort lied about three different topics, including his contacts with Konstantin Kilimnik, a Russian political consultant with alleged ties to Russian intelligence.

Manafort, 69, had pleaded guilty to some charges in August, avoiding a separate trial, and was convicted of financial fraud related to his work as a political consultant in Ukraine. He had accepted a plea deal in return for cooperating with Mueller's investigation. However, the judge cleared Manafort of allegations that he lied on two other subjects.

The verdict means that Manafort could now face harsher sentences or have charges against him re-filed. Last year, Mueller stated that Manafort had lied on a variety of subject matters after signing the plea deal. In August, Manafort was convicted on eight counts of fraud, bank fraud, and failing to disclose bank accounts. He pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy against the US and one charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice in a plea bargain with Mueller.

The plea deal, which avoided a second trial on money laundering and other charges, meant Manafort would face up to 10 years in prison and forfeit four of his properties and the contents of several bank accounts. The charges related to Manafort's political consulting work with pro-Russian politicians in Ukraine, largely predating his role with the Trump campaign.

Title: President Obama Addresses Veterans Affairs Scandal, Outlines Steps to Improve Agency

President Barack Obama has spoken out about the ongoing Veterans Affairs (VA) scandal, outlining steps to address the issues plaguing the agency. While stopping short of calling for the resignation of VA Secretary Eric Shinseki, Obama emphasized the need for accountability and improvement.

The President described Shinseki as a "great soldier" who has "put his heart and soul into this thing," but acknowledged that the agency has failed to meet the needs of veterans. Obama brought in White House Deputy Chief of Staff Rob Nabors to oversee a broader review of the VA, dispatching him to Phoenix, where the allegations of patient deaths tied to delayed care first surfaced.

"We've got to do better," Obama said, indicating that he wants to wait for the conclusion of internal probes before addressing whether any more top officials should resign. "When I hear allegations of misconduct... I will not stand for it. None of us should."

The President also highlighted his administration's accomplishments in taking care of veterans and their families, but faced criticism from leading Republicans for his delayed response to the scandal. Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell called for "serious action and accountability," while Sen. John McCain, a veteran and former prisoner of war, deemed Obama's statements "wholly insufficient" in addressing the systemic problems plaguing the veterans' healthcare system.

The controversy has expanded, with the Department of Veterans Affairs Inspector General's Office investigating 26 facilities nationwide over allegations of manipulated waiting times and other issues. The House of Representatives has approved a bill giving the VA secretary greater authority to fire or demote senior executives, while the Senate is considering similar legislation.

The VA's Inspector General's Office has confirmed that 26 facilities are being investigated nationwide over allegations of manipulated waiting times and other issues. The controversy erupted in Phoenix last month after allegations of delayed care that may have led to patient deaths and a cover-up by top administrators.

Title: Supreme Court's New Term to Address Controversial Issues, with Chief Justice Roberts' Voting Record Under Scrutiny

The upcoming Supreme Court term, which begins on Monday, is expected to be a significant one, with cases involving gun control, abortion, L.G.B.T. rights, and immigration on the docket. The term is likely to provide insight into the court's conservative majority's willingness to block the agenda of the next Democratic president and Congress.

Chief Justice John Roberts, known for his emphasis on precedent and concern for the court's legitimacy, has been the subject of speculation about his potential to act as a check on the court's conservative majority. However, an analysis of his voting record suggests that Democrats may have reason to be concerned.

According to our analysis, Chief Justice Roberts has compiled a voting record that is among the most partisan of any justice in the modern era when it comes to cases overturning precedent. He has presided over 21 such cases and voted to overturn precedent in 17, or 81 percent of the time. In 15 cases with partisan implications, he voted for conservative outcomes 14 times, or 93 percent of the time.

Our analysis also shows that Chief Justice Roberts' voting record is as conservative as those of his most extreme current and former colleagues, Justices Thomas, Alito, Kavanaugh, and Scalia. In all 42 split-decision cases involving racial minorities, immigrants, workers, and abortion, he voted for conservative outcomes 100 percent of the time.

The Supreme Court Database, maintained by the law school at Washington University in St. Louis, was used to determine whether a decision was liberal or conservative. The database defines a decision as liberal if at least four liberal justices voted for it, and conservative if at least four conservative justices voted for it.

The analysis by Take Back the Court, an organization that tracks Supreme Court voting records, found that Chief Justice Roberts' voting record is consistent with his statements during his 2005 confirmation hearing, where he emphasized his respect for precedent, even-handedness, and predictability. However, his voting record suggests that he may not be the swing vote that some had hoped for.

As the Supreme Court begins its new term, the nation can expect to see the court's conservative majority take a stance on some of the most contentious issues of the day. While Chief Justice Roberts' voting record may not be as moderate as some had hoped, it is clear that he is a key player in shaping the court's decisions.

Title: California Becomes Second State to Implement Automatic Voter Registration

California Governor Jerry Brown has signed a bill that will automatically register adult citizens to vote, starting in 2016. The new law will register individuals who obtain a driver's license, renew a license, get a state identification card, or fill out a change of address form with the Department of Motor Vehicles, unless they decline to be registered. This move follows Oregon's lead, which became the first state to implement automatic voter registration earlier this year.

The bill was supported by Democrats in the California legislature, while Republicans opposed it, citing concerns about potential voter fraud. However, the law does not register unauthorized immigrants, as they would be required to provide proof of citizenship to obtain a driver's license.

The new law aims to increase voter registration rates, which are currently low in California. According to the Los Angeles Times, about one-fifth of the state's 38 million people are eligible to vote but not registered. The law is seen as a step towards making voting easier and more accessible, rather than more difficult.

Oregon's law, which was implemented earlier this year, registers all adult citizens in the DMV's database, while California's law will be implemented more gradually, as individuals get or renew their licenses or state IDs, or change their addresses. Both laws make it the government's responsibility to ensure that all eligible voters are registered.

The move towards automatic voter registration has been met with support from national Democrats, with Hillary Clinton calling on all states to automatically register citizens to vote when they turn 18, unless they choose to opt out. Fifteen other states have introduced similar bills, with the Brennan Center tracking their progress.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Proposes $20 Trillion in Federal Spending for Universal Healthcare

Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat and presidential candidate, has proposed $20 trillion in federal spending over the next decade to provide healthcare to every American without raising taxes on the middle class. The plan aims to quell criticism that Warren has been vague about how she would pay for her sweeping proposal. Her refusal to say whether she would impose new taxes on the middle class had become untenable and made her a target in recent presidential debates.

The details of Warren's "Medicare for All" plan aim to transfer almost all of the $8.8 trillion she estimates employers would otherwise spend on private insurance for employees to the government. She claims this would generate almost half of what is needed to cover Medicare for All. Companies with fewer than 50 employees that don't already sponsor coverage would be exempt from the proposal.

Warren's plan has been quickly attacked by her moderate rivals, including former Vice President Joe Biden, whose campaign said it amounts to "mathematical gymnastics." Some independent experts have also questioned whether her numbers are realistic. The Urban Institute think tank recently pegged the cost closer to $34 trillion over 10 years, which could mean Warren's predictions about needed tax revenue would come up short.

The plan has also been criticized for its potential to create winners and losers among companies depending on their health care costs. It could lock in inequities based on companies that have an older workforce with better benefits. If the transfers from employers to the government don't raise enough money, Warren said she would make up the difference by imposing a supplemental contribution requirement for big companies with extremely high executive compensation and stock buyback rates.

Warren estimates she could generate $20.5 trillion in revenue through a combination of higher levies on capital gains and other investments, new taxes on the wealthiest 1% of Americans, and eliminating a Pentagon contingency fund used for anti-terrorism operations. However, some lawmakers may be reluctant to side with Warren's call to raise $800 billion over 10 years by eliminating the fund.

The proposal will face scrutiny in the coming months as Warren and other presidential candidates campaign in Iowa, which holds the nation's leadoff presidential caucuses in three months. Health care remains a dominant issue as the first votes of the Democratic contest near.

Title: Schumer Proposes Open Primaries to Weaken Tea Party Movement

Article:

Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, has proposed a plan to weaken the Tea Party movement by introducing nonpartisan "blanket" primaries, where all candidates compete and the top finishers advance regardless of party affiliation. Schumer believes this system would force right-wing candidates to appeal to centrist voters, pushing out the most extreme candidates.

Schumer's plan is already in place in some states, such as California, Louisiana, and Washington, where voters from all parties can participate in the primary. He believes this system would help to move the Tea Party movement away from its extreme positions and towards more moderate views.

Schumer also argued that the Tea Party movement is controlled by a few wealthy donors whose limited-government philosophy does not reflect the ideas of millions of voters who identify as Tea Party supporters but benefit from government programs such as Social Security or public education. He believes that Democrats should go on the offensive by portraying the government as a "force for good," focusing on issues such as raising the minimum wage, making college more affordable, and building bridges, roads, and broadband infrastructure.

However, Sal Russo, chief strategist for the Tea Party Express, predicted that the strategy will not work with Tea Party supporters, who are unlikely to be swayed by the idea of a bigger and more expensive federal government.

The Tea Party movement emerged in 2009 in response to public anger over the government bailout of private banks and the early moves by President Obama to boost government spending. Schumer believes that Fox News and other conservative-leaning news outlets helped spread the "propaganda" to the masses.

Schumer's proposal has been met with skepticism by some, including Dan Holler, communications director for the conservative activist group Heritage Action for America, who believes that the plan is an attempt to divide the Tea Party movement. Holler noted that Schumer's proposal shows that Democrats are starting to see Tea Party lawmakers as serious competition, and that the movement's success has changed how Washington operates.

Title: US Freezes Coronavirus-Related PPE Aid to 13 Countries, Citing Domestic Priorities

The United States has temporarily halted the delivery of coronavirus-related personal protective equipment (PPE) to at least 13 countries, including Vietnam, Bangladesh, Honduras, and the Philippines, due to domestic shortages and priorities. The decision has left American officials scrambling to explain the move to foreign counterparts, who may view it as a snub.

The hold on aid is part of a broader effort to prioritize domestic supplies and address the country's own needs before sending equipment abroad. The decision is seen as a delicate balancing act, as the US relies on international cooperation to combat the pandemic and maintain global supply chains.

The US has already delivered PPE to several countries, including Myanmar, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Laos, with some embassies announcing the donations in press releases. However, the current freeze on aid has raised concerns that the US may be seen as abandoning its global leadership role in the fight against COVID-19.

The US has provided $274 million in funding to 64 countries, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo highlighting the aid in a recent press conference. However, some critics argue that the amount of aid offered internationally has been too slow and too small, risking the continued spread of the virus to Americans and communities in countries with weaker infrastructure.

The US has not yet curtailed exports by American companies, with roughly 280 million masks in warehouses around the US purchased by foreign buyers on Monday alone. FEMA has not actively encouraged or discouraged US companies from exporting overseas, but is asking USAID to send back most of the reserves of protective gear stored in warehouses in Dubai and Miami for use in the US.

The US government is working to address domestic shortages and prioritize its own needs before sending aid abroad. While the hold on aid is not meant to be permanent, officials acknowledge that the delays risk damaging relationships with allies who could help the US with critical supplies down the road.

Title: US Healthcare System Prepared to Contain Ebola Outbreak, Officials Say

The Obama administration is working to reassure the public about the Ebola outbreak in the United States, emphasizing that the healthcare system is well-equipped to prevent an outbreak. Dr. Anthony Fauci, infectious diseases chief at the National Institutes of Health, stated that the US healthcare infrastructure is capable of stopping Ebola in its tracks.

A high-level briefing at the White House reflected the administration's urgency in addressing public concerns. Fauci, along with Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell and Lisa Monaco, President Barack Obama's top homeland security adviser, spoke with reporters to provide updates on the situation.

Monaco emphasized that the US is not considering a travel ban to prevent individuals from West African countries affected by the outbreak from entering the country. Instead, efforts are focused on identifying high-risk individuals before they leave the outbreak zone. Dozens of people have been stopped from boarding flights in the region, she said.

The first person diagnosed with Ebola in the US, who had traveled from Liberia, was initially sent home despite revealing his travel history, before returning to a hospital by ambulance days later. Texas officials are monitoring 50 people, 10 of whom are considered high-risk, who came into contact with the individual. Four have been quarantined, and there have been issues with disposing of infectious waste from the patient's apartment.

Fauci acknowledged that there were initial missteps in Dallas, but emphasized that many things went right and are going right. Health officials have said it's possible that someone who had close contact with the first patient after he became ill might also get sick, but they believe further spread is unlikely due to public health measures in place.

The White House announced that President Obama will meet with his national security advisers on Monday to discuss the Ebola outbreak and the administration's response. The administration has emphasized that the best way to contain Ebola is to attack it at its source. The Pentagon has begun deploying up to 4,000 troops to West Africa, with military leaders arriving and assessing the need.

Navy Rear Admiral John Kirby, the Pentagon's spokesman, stated that the military is building two treatment centers in Liberia and has begun medical testing for Ebola at two new labs. Service members are being trained on how to avoid getting Ebola and will have personal protective equipment if needed. Kirby said he is unaware of any special staffing or changes at military hospitals in the US to prepare for caring for Ebola patients.

As of now, about 230 US troops are deployed for the Ebola mission, with about two dozen in Senegal setting up a transportation center and the rest in Liberia. The Army has announced that up to 3,200 soldiers from various units will be deployed to Liberia, including 1,800 from Fort Campbell, Kentucky, who will arrive late this month.

Title: Hillary Clinton to Reveal Vice Presidential Candidate on Friday

Hillary Clinton is set to announce her vice presidential candidate on Friday, according to people close to the search. The announcement is expected to take place at a campaign rally in Miami, Florida, where Clinton will make her first appearance with her running mate.

Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia has emerged as a leading contender, receiving support from President Barack Obama and former President Bill Clinton. Kaine's ability to speak fluent Spanish is seen as an asset, as Clinton's campaign aims to appeal to Hispanic voters.

Clinton has been conducting a methodical search for her running mate, with Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack and Labor Secretary Tom Perez also being considered. Sen. Cory Booker of New Jersey was also a contender, but his limited experience in national security and government made him less likely to be selected.

The Clinton campaign has been careful to keep the selection process secret, with only a select few knowing the identity of her chosen running mate. The announcement is seen as a way to generate excitement and momentum for the Democratic ticket heading into the party's convention in Philadelphia.

Clinton's selection of a running mate marks a new chapter in her political career, as she has the opportunity to choose her own partner. Her husband, Bill Clinton, has expressed support for Kaine, but ultimately, Hillary Clinton will make the final decision.

The weekend debut of the Democratic ticket is designed to build anticipation for the party's convention, with Clinton and her running mate expected to embark on a bus tour to key campaign battlegrounds.

Title: Erica Garner, Daughter of Eric Garner, Dies at 27 After Suffering Heart Attack

Erica Garner, the 27-year-old daughter of Eric Garner, who died in 2014 after being placed in a chokehold by a New York City police officer, has passed away. She died on Saturday while in a coma following a massive heart attack.

Garner became an activist after her father's death, advocating for justice and police reform. She was a vocal critic of police brutality and was involved in various protests and campaigns. Her father's last words, "I can't breathe," became a rallying cry for activists.

Garner had been in a coma since suffering cardiac arrest on Christmas Eve. Her mother, Esaw Snipes-Garner, said her daughter had suffered her first heart attack shortly after giving birth in August.

The city of New York had agreed to pay a $6 million civil settlement to the Garner family after a grand jury declined to indict the officer involved in the 2014 incident.

Garner was also an outspoken supporter of Senator Bernie Sanders during the 2016 presidential campaign, appearing in a campaign ad on his behalf. She also criticized New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio over policing matters.

In a statement, Senator Sanders said, "My thoughts are with Erica Garner. I have had the privilege of joining with her at a number of events and was deeply impressed with her courage and insights."

Garner's official Twitter account, run by her family and friends, described her as having a heart "bigger than the world" and said she "cared when most people wouldn't have. She was good. She only pursued what was right, no matter what."

Title: Trump's Fourth of July Speech Includes False Claims About Coronavirus and Administration's Response

Article:
