House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi emphasized that most Democrats stand tall in support of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), despite 39 Democrats joining Republicans in voting for a bill that would allow insurers to keep health plans that do not meet federal laws. Pelosi made her comments on NBC's Meet the Press, stating that she and her members have "full confidence" in the law, regardless of their vote.

Pelosi pointed to states with their own health insurance exchanges, such as California and Kentucky, which are reportedly signing up customers and praising the prices. California, for instance, announced that it will soon offer online enrollment for the Small Business Health Options Program for businesses with fewer than 50 employees. As of November 12, around 60,000 people had chosen insurance plans through the state's exchange.

While the bill is unlikely to move forward in the Senate, Pelosi believes that House Democrats can use it to demonstrate their opposition to a law that may be unpopular in their districts. The bill's passage is seen as a way for Democrats to show they are willing to listen to concerns and work with Republicans, even if it means going against the party's stance.

Pelosi did not dwell on the problems with the ACA, such as the broken website and the president's promise to allow insurers to offer customers their old plans. Instead, she focused on the future, highlighting the progress being made in states with their own exchanges.

Title: Michigan Attorney General Files Emergency Motion to Halt Jill Stein's Recount Request

Michigan Attorney General Bill Schuette has filed an emergency motion with the Michigan Supreme Court to bypass the Court of Appeals and ensure a timely process in response to Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein's request for a recount in the 2016 election. Schuette's office stated that Stein's refusal to accept the state-verified results poses an expensive and risky threat to taxpayers and abuses the intent of Michigan law.

Stein had filed a request for a recount in Michigan, citing a razor-thin margin of 0.2 percentage points, or around 10,000 votes out of over 5.5 million cast, which made the state the last to be called in the election. Trump supporters have also tried to stop the recount in Wisconsin, where Stein is also fighting to continue the process.

Stein's campaign plans to intervene and join the Wisconsin Elections Commission in defending the recount, citing the importance of ensuring integrity in the vote. In an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper, Stein defended her decision to request recounts in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania, stating that predictors suggest tampering would be most likely to be discovered in these states.

Stein's attorney, Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, stated that citizens across the country want a recount and deserve to see the process through to ensure the integrity of the vote. Schuette's office, on the other hand, argues that Stein's refusal to accept the results and her request for a recount are a waste of taxpayer money and an abuse of the electoral process.

The Michigan Attorney General's office has filed an emergency motion with the Michigan Supreme Court to halt Stein's recount request, citing the need for a timely process and the potential financial burden on taxpayers. The outcome of the recount is still pending, with both sides presenting their arguments to the court.

Title: Facebook Critic Roger McNamee Warns of Social Media's Dark Side

Roger McNamee, a longtime tech investor and early Facebook advisor, has written a new book, "Zucked: Waking Up to the Facebook Catastrophe," in which he argues that Facebook is a threat to democracy, public health, and user privacy. McNamee, who advised Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg in the early years of the company, believes that Facebook's success in creating a revolutionary social media platform has led to its downfall.

According to McNamee, Facebook and other internet giants like Google have created products that prey on the weakest elements of human psychology, creating habits and addictions. He claims that these companies have not taken sufficient steps to safeguard users from bad actors, making them vulnerable to exploitation. McNamee credits Facebook's success in creating a platform that allows advertisers to target specific audiences as the heart of the problem.

In an interview on "CBS This Morning," McNamee stated that Facebook's ability to target users has allowed advertisers to reach exactly the people they want to reach, just like the Russians did in the Brexit referendum and the 2016 US presidential election. He expressed concern that the next generation of technology will only make the danger greater.

McNamee also highlighted several instances where Facebook has been accused of taking advantage of minors, including a case where it was accused of taking advantage of minors with credit card charges related to games and another case where it spied on users' usage. He also criticized Facebook's response to allegations of discrimination and data privacy issues, citing the Department of Housing and Urban Development's citation of Facebook for advertising tools that allowed discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act.

Facebook responded to McNamee's claims, stating that it has fundamentally changed how it operates to better protect user safety and security over the past two years. However, McNamee disputed this claim, citing instances where Facebook has been called out and did not change.

McNamee's book, "Zucked: Waking Up to the Facebook Catastrophe," is available in hardcover, eBook, and audio formats.

Title: Trump Administration Releases Immigration Demands, Including Border Wall Funding and Crackdown on Central American Children

The Trump administration has released a list of immigration demands, which includes funding for a wall on the Mexico border and a crackdown on the admission of children from Central America. This move is part of the administration's efforts to negotiate a deal to allow young undocumented migrants, known as Dreamers, to stay in the US legally.

The list of principles also calls for withholding federal grants for "sanctuary cities" and limiting legal immigration by issuing fewer family-based green cards to spouses and minor children of US citizens and lawful permanent residents. Additionally, it demands the creation of a points-based system for migrants to gain entry to the US.

Democrats have rejected the list as "immoral" and "far beyond what is reasonable," setting up a likely showdown in Congress. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat from New Mexico and chair of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, stated that if Republicans and the White House refuse to back off, Democrats are prepared to derail legislation.

Dreamers and groups advocating for them have reacted with horror, calling the decision to use them as a "bargaining chip" "shameful." Christian Ramirez, director of the Southern Border Communities Coalition, said the decision to use Dreamers as a bargaining chip was "shameful."

The Trump administration's demands have been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle. While some Republicans have expressed support for the proposals, others have expressed concerns about the potential impact on families and the economy. Democrats have vowed to continue fighting for a pathway to citizenship for Dreamers.

The Trump administration's decision to use Dreamers as a bargaining chip has been met with widespread criticism, with many calling it "immoral" and "cruel." The administration's demands have set up a likely showdown in Congress, with Democrats vowing to continue fighting for a pathway to citizenship for Dreamers.

Title: Conservative Book Club Editor Reveals Top Books and Movies of 2016

The Conservative Book Club, dubbed the "Oprah Winfrey book club for the right," has released its list of top books and movies for 2016. Christopher Malagisi, the energetic editor-in-chief, shared his picks in an exclusive end-of-the-year video interview with ███ News Foundation.

Malagisi believes that The New York Times does not give conservative books a fair shake, which is why his organization provides a one-stop shop for readers. The top 10 conservative books of 2016 include titles from authors such as Ann Coulter, Megyn Kelly, Brad Thor, Phyllis Schlafly, and a graphic novel creator.

The honorable mention list includes additional notable authors. As for movies, Malagisi recommends "13 Hours," "Hell or High Water," "Hacksaw Ridge," "Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party," "Captain America: Civil War," "Risen," and "Silence."

Malagisi believes that American culture has been dominated by the left, and he thinks that students are not being taught why America is exceptional. He views conservatism as conserving the best from 2,500 years of human history, which culminated in the Constitution guaranteeing liberty and rights previously unknown across the planet.

According to Malagisi, American culture has been dominated by the left, and he believes that people should learn more about politics through entertainment, such as books, movies, TV, music, or art. This is why his work is focused on books, movies, and TV at the Conservative Book Club, which has over 850,000 members.

For more information on the Conservative Book Club, readers can visit their user-friendly website or follow them on Facebook or Twitter @ConservBookClub.

Title: US and Russia Explore Diplomatic Solution to Syria Crisis

The US and Russia are exploring a diplomatic solution to the crisis in Syria, with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton calling any move by Syria to surrender its chemical weapons to international control an "important step." The proposal, floated by US Secretary of State John Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, would have Syria turn over its chemical weapons stockpiles to international inspectors within a week, avoiding a US military strike.

Clinton met with President Barack Obama at the White House, where she emphasized the need for swift and comprehensive action to address the chemical weapons threat in Syria. She urged Russia to support the international community's efforts or face accountability. The White House is seeking Congressional approval for a military strike in response to a chemical weapons attack in August, but a new proposal would have Syria surrender its chemical weapons to avoid a strike.

The Obama administration is intensifying its lobbying efforts, with the President planning six television interviews and a visit to the Capitol to make his case to lawmakers. The White House is also considering a proposal by UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to have Syria move its chemical arms stocks to sites where they can be safely stored and destroyed.

Some members of Congress remain skeptical, with Senator Mike Rogers saying the President has "fumbled" the message on Syria and faces a critical moment. Others, like Senator Dianne Feinstein, believe Russia can play a key role in encouraging the Syrian government to stop using chemical weapons and place its stockpiles under UN control.

A survey by USA Today found majorities of both the Senate and House remain uncommitted on whether to back military action, complicating predictions about the outcome. With the hunt on for more votes, lawmakers are exploring alternative resolutions, including a narrower proposal that would focus on deterring future use of chemical weapons.

Title: Giuliani Disputes Claims of Racism in Eric Garner's Death, Blames Black-on-Black Crime

Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani has sparked controversy by stating that racism was not involved in the death of Eric Garner, who died last July after being placed in a chokehold by police officer Daniel Pantaleo during an arrest. Giuliani made his comments on Fox & Friends, citing the presence of a black sergeant at the scene and the fact that any suspect under similar circumstances would have been treated the same.

Giuliani also criticized New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, civil rights activist Al Sharpton, and others who suggested racism was involved in the incident, stating that their comments are "tearing down respect for a criminal justice system that goes back to England in the 11th Century." He argued that it is racist to focus on the "handful" of incidents where blacks are killed by police, rather than the numbers who die from black-on-black crime.

Giuliani also took aim at New York Democrat Rep. Charlie Rangel, who said it was "totally impossible to believe that someone can die, and nobody is indicted." Giuliani called this statement "totally absurd" and accused Rangel of trying to inflame people and give them a "totally ignorant view of the law."

In his comments, Giuliani emphasized that the incidents involving Garner and Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, were not racial incidents, but rather cases of individuals who had committed crimes and resisted arrest. He suggested that activists like Sharpton could accomplish more by focusing on crime in the black community with the same passion as they do in cases where police shoot someone.

Giuliani's comments have sparked a heated debate, with many critics accusing him of downplaying the issue of police brutality and racism.

Title: Obama Distances Himself from Iraq Withdrawal, Blames Predecessor Bush

The White House has recently seen a shift in President Barack Obama's stance on the 2011 withdrawal of U.S. forces from Iraq. Less than 48 hours after authorizing airstrikes against Islamist militants and humanitarian air drops to save trapped Iraqi civilians, Obama blamed his predecessor, George W. Bush, for the absence of American troops in Iraq. The president rejected the assertion that he could have left a small peacekeeping force in the war-torn nation.

This change in narrative comes after three years and a successful re-election campaign, during which the full removal of U.S. forces from Iraq was touted as one of the White House's most significant foreign policy achievements. However, with the terrorist group Islamic State running roughshod through Iraq, capturing key territory, and slaughtering Christians, Obama has begun to adjust his stance.

In a recent press conference, Obama stated that the reason for not having a follow-on force in Iraq was because the Iraqis did not want U.S. troops there, and the Iraqi government could not pass the necessary laws to protect American troops. This explanation is in contrast to his previous claims that he had ended American involvement in Iraq and left no U.S. boots on the ground.

The shift in Obama's stance has been met with criticism from political pundits, who point out the irony of a president moving away from his signature foreign policy achievement. Ron Fournier of the National Journal tweeted that the president is distancing himself from his own record, while James Taranto of The Wall Street Journal editorial board noted that Obama is no longer claiming credit for the removal of American forces.

Analysts agree that the Iraqi government had no interest in allowing U.S. forces to remain in the country, as they refused to guarantee American troops immunity from prosecution in Iraqi courts. However, the shift in Obama's stance has been seen as a sign of the administration's growing unease over the consequences of the withdrawal.

The controversy comes as the White House is facing criticism over its broader foreign policy, with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton questioning the administration's underlying principle of "don't do stupid stuff." Republicans have been even harsher in their critiques, charging that Obama's handling of the Iraq crisis has proven his incompetence.

In conclusion, President Obama's recent shift in stance on the 2011 withdrawal of U.S. forces from Iraq has sparked controversy and criticism from political pundits and analysts. While the president's initial claims of a successful withdrawal have been debunked, the shift in his stance has been seen as a sign of the administration's growing unease over the consequences of the withdrawal.

Title: French President Emmanuel Macron to Meet with President Trump in Washington This Week

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron is set to visit the United States this week, where he will meet with President Donald Trump and participate in a series of high-level meetings and events. Ahead of the trip, Macron sat down for an exclusive interview with Fox News Sunday, where he discussed his relationship with Trump and several key issues on the global agenda.

Macron emphasized the importance of maintaining strong relationships with allies, stating, "You can't make a trade war with your allies. It's too complicated. If you make war against everybody, you make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war against Iran -- come on -- it doesn't work. You need allies." He also expressed optimism that Trump will exempt European countries from the international tariffs he intends to impose on aluminum and steel, saying, "You don't make trade war with your allies. Let's see what he will decide on May 1. I just say, where are your priorities?"

On the topic of Iran, Macron cautioned Trump against withdrawing from the Iran Nuclear Deal, stating, "I'm not satisfied with the situation with Iran" but suggesting that leaving the deal without a "better option" would be a mistake. He also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a regime change in Syria, saying, "It's not automatically U.S. forces, but that's U.S. diplomacy and that's your presence. We will have to build a new Syria after war. And that's why I think the U.S. role is very important to play."

Macron also touched on the issue of terrorism, stating that he and Trump share a commitment to fighting the global threat and that he will ask Congress for its support in this effort. He described the U.S. as "one of the last resorts" for peace and multilateralism, and expressed optimism that Trump's presidency will have a positive impact on the world stage.

The trip will mark the first official state visit since Trump took office last year and will include a state dinner at the White House and a joint address to Congress.

Title: Trump Jr.'s Account of Russia Talks Raises Questions About 2017 Testimony

The recent guilty plea by Michael Cohen, former lawyer to President Donald Trump, has raised questions about Donald Trump Jr.'s testimony to Congress regarding his family's real estate negotiations with powerful Russians. Trump Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee in September 2017 that he was only "peripherally aware" of negotiations that Cohen has admitted to carrying on through June 2016.

Cohen's guilty plea revealed that he had briefed Trump's family members about his talks, although the court documents do not specify who. Trump Jr. also told Senate investigators that he was not aware that Cohen had reached out to the press secretary for Vladimir Putin as part of his talks with Moscow about a putative new Trump Tower project there.

Trump Jr.'s answers allude to a number of prospective projects, and he was asked by Senate investigators about news reports about a Trump Tower Moscow negotiation that took place in 2015 and 2016, which he acknowledged but did not detail. An attorney for Trump Jr. did not immediately respond to a request for comment on this story.

The shift in understanding of the events of 2016 provided by Cohen is important for a few reasons: first, it called into question the Trump family's denials about having business dealings with Russians; second, it confirmed the Trumps had a channel open with powerful Russians at the same time the Russian government was waging a widespread campaign of "active measures" against the United States; and third, it put the Russian government and others in Moscow in the position of being able to know, confidentially, the truth about the Trump family's denials about negotiations over the Moscow real estate deals.

The article does not take a stance on the matter, but rather presents the facts and quotes from various individuals involved.

Title: Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh Testifies Before Senate Judiciary Committee

Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, reiterating his stance on the judiciary's authority to check the power of the White House. He declined to comment on President Donald Trump's criticism of the judiciary or offer praise of the president's character. The second day of the confirmation hearing saw Democrats pressing Kavanaugh on his views on abortion and racial issues, as well as newly released emails highlighting his opinions on these topics.

Kavanaugh emphasized his independence as a judge, stating that his only loyalty is to the Constitution. He refused to comment on whether he would recuse himself if a case involving the Mueller investigation or other issues relating to Trump's conduct came before him. The nominee also declined to answer questions on how a 1974 Supreme Court ruling against President Richard Nixon could be applied to the ongoing investigation by Special Counsel Robert Mueller.

The hearing was repeatedly interrupted by protesters hostile to Kavanaugh, but the nominee remained in good humor and made no gaffes that could derail his confirmation. The committee will hear from outside witnesses on Friday before wrapping up the hearing.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Remains in Position Amid Reports of Resignation or Firing

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has not resigned or been fired, despite reports suggesting otherwise. The White House confirmed that President Donald Trump and Rosenstein had an extended conversation about news stories published last week, which reported that Rosenstein discussed secretly recording Trump or having him removed from office. The two are scheduled to meet on Thursday, after Trump's return from a United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York.

Rosenstein oversees the investigation into Russian election interference and links between the Trump campaign and Moscow. The New York Times reported last week that he discussed secretly recording the president and invoking the 25th Amendment to remove Trump from office. Rosenstein denied the report, calling it "inaccurate."

If Rosenstein were to leave his job, it would raise questions about the oversight of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Under the Department of Justice succession statute, Solicitor General Noel Francisco would take over, but Trump could also appoint a temporary replacement on an "acting" basis for up to 210 days.

Democrats in Congress and former federal prosecutors have called on Republicans to protect the Mueller investigation. "Congress must take immediate steps," said Representative Val Demings of Florida. "Time to protect the Mueller investigation. Now," tweeted Preet Bharara, former US Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

Rosenstein has been overseeing Mueller's work since Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself due to his contacts with Russian officials during the Trump campaign. Trump has repeatedly attacked Sessions for his decision.

The president's relationship with Rosenstein has been tumultuous, with Trump calling him "weak" but also saying their relationship is "fantastic." Frustration has moved in both directions, with Rosenstein reportedly growing "angry" at Trump in May 2017 after Trump used a memo written by Rosenstein to justify the firing of FBI Director James Comey.

Title: Politics and the Olympics: A Complex History of Intrusion

The Olympic Games, intended to be a celebration of sports and goodwill, have often been marred by political tensions and controversies. The decision by President Obama not to attend the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, in February, marks a rare instance where the United States will not be represented by a president, vice president, first lady, or former president since 2000. Instead, athletes such as Billie Jean King and Caitlin Cahow will represent the country.

The Olympic Charter prohibits any form of demonstration or propaganda, yet political protests and international gamesmanship have been a constant feature of the modern games. The Council on Foreign Relations has highlighted controversies over the past century, including the 1972 Munich Olympics, which were marred by the murder of 11 Israeli athletes and coaches by Palestinian terrorists.

The Olympics have also been used as a platform for political statements, with athletes such as Jesse Owens and Tommie Smith using their podium appearances to protest against racism and social injustices. Nations have also used the games as a means to showcase their political ideologies, with the Soviet Union and the United States engaging in a propaganda war during the Cold War.

In recent years, political tensions have continued to intrude on the Olympics. The 2008 Beijing Summer Games saw protests against China's human rights record, while the 2012 London Olympics were criticized for their handling of security and logistics. The upcoming Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are likely to be affected by the country's "homosexual propaganda" law, which has sparked international outrage.

Despite the challenges, the Olympics remain a symbol of international cooperation and athletic achievement. As historian Eric Marcus notes, "It's always been incredibly naive to think somehow you can screen out everything that's going on in the world during a given period of time, particularly in a part of the world that's problematic."

Title: China Reports Record Rise in Imported Coronavirus Cases as Students and Expats Return from Abroad

China has reported a record increase in imported coronavirus cases, with 41 new confirmed cases reported on Friday, all of which were brought in from overseas. This brings the total number of imported cases to 269, with no locally transmitted cases reported for the third consecutive day. The majority of the new cases were students and expats returning from the United States and Europe, where many universities and businesses have shut down due to the rapid spread of the virus.

Beijing and Shanghai were the main entry points for the returnees, with five of the 14 new cases in Beijing being Chinese students returning from abroad, and five of the nine cases in Shanghai being students flying back from Britain, France, and Switzerland. The southern provinces of Guangdong, Fujian, and the eastern provinces of Shandong and Zhejiang, as well as Shaanxi and Sichuan, also reported cases.

While there is no reported transmission of the virus from people arriving from abroad to local communities, authorities across China are tightening public health measures to prevent the import of the virus and a potential rebound in cases. The National Health Commission has emphasized the need to strictly prevent the import of the virus from overseas and to prevent a rebound in cases.

The influx of infections from overseas presents a potential threat to Chinese authorities keen to restart factories and get consumers to spend again. Analysts have slashed forecasts for China's first-quarter gross domestic product to levels not seen since the Cultural Revolution ended in 1976, with all sectors of the economy hammered by the coronavirus outbreak this year.

The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China stood at 81,008 at the end of Friday, with a death toll of 3,255, up by seven. The lack of locally transmitted cases for the third day running underscores a recovery that has prompted officials to relax restrictions, even in the virus epicenter of Wuhan.

Title: Senate Fails to Pass Defense Spending Bill Amid Partisan Divide

The Senate has failed to pass the Defense spending bill, which accounts for half of the country's discretionary budget, due to a partisan divide. The bill, which authorizes money for troops, ships, and aircraft, as well as sets military policy, has been caught in the midst of a contentious debate between Republicans and Democrats.

The Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, refused to allow a vote on the bill last week, citing concerns over government spying and the potential for new sanctions on Iran to be tacked onto the bill. This move was met with resistance from Republicans, who argued that the Democratic-controlled Senate was making a "power grab" and demanded the ability to offer amendments and hold votes on them.

The bill has been delayed for months, with some Republicans accusing Reid of using too much power in running the chamber and arguing that the bill could have been passed earlier. The Senate has traditionally been a bastion of bipartisanship when it comes to the Defense authorization bill, but the current impasse has left lawmakers pessimistic about the road ahead.

The bill is the latest example of the partisan divide in Congress, which has stalled several major pieces of legislation, including the farm bill and immigration reform. The Senate has only a few legislative days left in the year, and if it fails to pass the bill, troops will still receive pay and fighter jets will continue to be built, but major policy changes may be lost.

The impasse has left lawmakers frustrated, with some expressing concerns that the dysfunction in Congress is approaching an all-time low. The Senate's failure to pass the bill is a blow to the tradition of bipartisanship that has characterized the Defense authorization process in the past.

Title: House Democrats Unveil Impeachment Articles, Secure Trade Deal with Canada and Mexico

House Democrats have unveiled two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump, coinciding with the announcement of a pending deal on a new U.S.-Canada-Mexico trade pact. The agreement, known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), was finalized after intense negotiations over the weekend and was announced on Tuesday morning. The signing ceremony took place in Mexico City later that day.

The USMCA is a revised version of the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which has been a priority for the Trump administration. The deal has been endorsed by the AFL-CIO and labor unions, as well as the Trump White House and House Democrats.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been praised for her ability to get things done while pursuing impeachment. The deal is seen as a major legislative win for the Democrats, who can now go home for the holidays and tout their bipartisan accomplishments.

The USMCA has been the subject of intense negotiations between the Trump administration, House Democrats, and labor unions. The deal eliminates some provisions that were opposed by Democrats, including those that would have raised the price of pharmaceuticals across North America by locking in high drug prices and expanding big pharma's monopoly.

The House Judiciary Committee will consider the articles of impeachment at an unusual evening session on Wednesday, with a full House vote likely to take place next week.

Title: Supreme Court's Bostock Decision Casts Doubt on Trump Administration's Anti-LGBTQ Regulation

The Trump administration's regulation permitting health providers to discriminate against LGBTQ patients has been put into serious doubt following the Supreme Court's landmark decision in Bostock v. Clayton County. The ruling, which held that Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which bans discrimination "because of... sex," is broad enough to forbid workplace discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, has implications that extend beyond employment discrimination.

The decision suggests that both educational institutions and healthcare providers may not discriminate against LGBTQ individuals, as both Title VII and the Affordable Care Act prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex. The Affordable Care Act, in particular, prohibits discrimination in healthcare programs or activities receiving federal financial assistance, which applies to nearly all public schools, colleges, universities, and hospitals.

The Trump administration's new healthcare regulation, which permits health providers to discriminate against LGBTQ patients, is likely to be challenged in court. Lawyers challenging anti-LGBTQ discrimination by schools and healthcare providers are already notifying judges of the Court's decision in Bostock, and new lawsuits are being prepared to strike down the regulation.

The Supreme Court's decision in Bostock also has implications for the Trump administration's anti-LGBTQ agenda in education. The administration opposes anti-discrimination protections for transgender students, but the Court's ruling suggests that such discrimination is illegal. The Affordable Care Act and Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, and the Court's decision in Bostock suggests that these provisions apply to discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.

While the Trump administration's ban on transgender service members in the military may survive, much of its anti-LGBTQ agenda is in serious trouble after Bostock. The Court's decision has far-reaching implications, stretching beyond employment discrimination to education and healthcare, and has the potential to establish a clear legal framework for protecting the rights of LGBTQ individuals.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Federal Law Allows Citizenship Revocation for False Statements

The Supreme Court has ruled that federal law authorizes courts to strip immigrants of their U.S. citizenship if they obtained it as a result of making false statements to the federal government. The decision, which was written by Justice Elena Kagan, vacated a lower court's decision and remanded the case back to the trial court for further proceedings.

The case involved Divna Maslenjak, a Serbian woman who sought refugee status in the United States in 1998 and was granted citizenship in 2007. However, she had made false statements on her application, including claiming that her husband had evaded military service in Bosnia. In reality, her husband had served in the Bosnian Serb Army.

The government argued that Maslenjak's false statements violated federal law, specifically 18 U.S.C. § 1015(a), which criminalizes making a false sworn statement during naturalization. The government claimed that her false statements also violated 18 U.S.C. § 1425(a), which makes it a crime to procure naturalization "contrary to law." The lower court agreed, and Maslenjak's citizenship was revoked.

The Supreme Court disagreed, ruling that the government must establish that the illegal act played some role in the defendant's acquisition of citizenship. The Court concluded that the jury instructions given in the case were faulty and that the jury should have been told to decide whether Maslenjak's lying about her husband's military service was part of the cause of her obtaining citizenship.

In a concurring opinion, Justice Neil Gorsuch wrote that the majority's framework was too elaborate and that the Court should send the case back down with a less-elaborate holding, allowing the lower courts to flesh out additional details as necessary over time. Justice Samuel Alito also wrote a separate opinion, concurring in the judgment, and argued that the immigration statute is violated when a person makes a "material" false statement during the naturalization process, but does not necessarily need to be part of the cause of obtaining citizenship.

The Supreme Court's decision highlights the importance of accurate and truthful information in the naturalization process and underscores the need for clear and concise legal guidance for judges and jurors in these cases.

Title: Obama's Budget Proposal Includes Modest Changes to Social Security and Medicare

The White House has announced that President Obama's upcoming budget will tie tax hikes to modest changes in Social Security and other benefit programs. The plan, set to be unveiled on Wednesday, includes a provision to lower cost-of-living adjustments to Social Security, which would curb the growth in benefits. The administration claims to be offering these changes reluctantly, as part of a "cohesive package" to convince Republicans to accept increased revenues.

House Speaker John Boehner has already preemptively rejected the proposal, stating that the president and his party already extracted tax increases on top earners as part of the deal to avert the fiscal crisis at the end of 2012. Boehner argues that the plan would leave the country with a budget that never balances and that the president has moved in the wrong direction.

The proposal also includes a plan to place limits on tax-preferred retirement accounts for top earners, which could generate about $580 billion in revenue over 10 years. The administration claims that the plan aims to reduce the deficit by $1.8 trillion over 10 years.

However, the plan has drawn criticism from liberal members of Congress, including Senator Bernie Sanders, who has expressed concerns that the changes would cut Social Security and benefits for disabled veterans and their survivors. The chained CPI, a revised inflation adjustment that would curb annual increases in government programs, has been met with opposition from labor groups and liberals.

The budget proposal comes after the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-run Senate passed separate and markedly different budget proposals. The Obama administration's plan will replace the sequester with other spending cuts, but will steer clear of major cuts to Medicaid, including tens of billions in reductions to the health care plan for the poor that the administration had proposed only last year.

Title: Walgreens to Close Approximately 200 U.S. Stores as Part of Cost-Cutting Initiative

Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) has announced plans to close around 200 U.S. stores as part of its efforts to reduce costs by $1.5 billion by the end of fiscal 2017. The company aims to achieve this goal through a combination of store closures, reorganization of corporate and field operations, driving operating efficiencies, and streamlining information technology and other functions.

The soon-to-be closed stores represent approximately 2% of Walgreens' 8,232 drugstores in the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The company has not yet disclosed which specific stores will be closed, but has stated that it is not focusing on any specific geographic area. There is also no set timeline for when the closures will take place.

Despite the store closures, Walgreens reported strong earnings in its second quarter, with adjusted net earnings increasing 33.2% to $1.2 billion. Second-quarter sales also increased 35.5% to $26.6 billion. The U.S. retail pharmacy division, which includes Walgreens and Duane Reade stores, posted sales of $21 billion in the second quarter, up 7.4% over the year-ago quarter. Total sales in stores open at least a year were up 6.9% over the same quarter a year ago.

The company's decision to close stores is part of its ongoing efforts to adapt to changing market conditions and improve its financial performance. Walgreens acquired Alliance Boots in December, creating a new company with over 12,800 stores in 11 countries. The combined company, renamed Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc., took on the ticker symbol WBA.

Title: Sarah Palin Criticizes Obama, Bloomberg, and the GOP at Conservative Political Action Conference

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican vice presidential nominee, delivered a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) outside Washington, D.C., on Saturday. In her remarks, she criticized President Barack Obama, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, and the Republican Party, calling for a return to core conservative values.

Palin compared Obama to white-collar criminal Bernie Madoff, saying that just as Madoff was a good salesman, Obama is a good politician, but with a key difference: Obama is using the country's money. She also urged Obama to "step away from the teleprompter and do your job."

Palin's criticism was not limited to Obama, as she also targeted the "permanent political class" and the "permanent campaign mode" that she believes has led to a lack of effective leadership in Washington. She said, "Never before have our challenges been so big and our leaders so small."

The former governor of Alaska also took aim at Mayor Bloomberg's proposed ban on large sodas, holding up a Big Gulp and joking that Bloomberg's efforts are not needed. She also criticized the lack of leadership coming from Washington, saying that instead of leadership, the country is getting "reality television."

Palin's speech was well-received by the audience, with many attendees applauding her remarks. Her comments on gun control, gun ownership, and the need for more transparency in government were also met with applause.

In her speech, Palin also poked fun at some of the current political debates, including the issue of gun control, saying that background checks are a "dandy idea" and that she and her husband, Todd, have a metal rack for their hunting rifles. She also joked about the need for young conservatives to be focused on their goals, rather than getting distracted by beer.

Overall, Palin's speech was a call to action for the Republican Party to return to its core values and principles, and to focus on solving the country's problems rather than engaging in "reality television."

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee to Hold Confirmation Hearing for Rep. John Ratcliffe as Director of National Intelligence

The Senate Intelligence Committee is set to hold a confirmation hearing for Rep. John Ratcliffe, a Republican from Texas, who has been nominated by President Trump to serve as the Director of National Intelligence (DNI). Ratcliffe is a member of the House Intelligence, Judiciary, and Ethics Committees and has been a vocal defender of the President during the Russia investigation and impeachment proceedings.

Ratcliffe was initially considered for the DNI position last year but withdrew his name from consideration due to concerns about a potentially rancorous and partisan confirmation process. However, President Trump nominated him again in February, and the hearing is the first major Senate session since the coronavirus-induced hiatus.

As a former federal prosecutor, Ratcliffe has been known for his aggressive questioning during the Russia probe and its aftermath. He has grilled Special Counsel Robert Mueller over his decision not to exonerate President Trump of obstruction of justice charges. Ratcliffe has also served as Chief of Anti-Terrorism and National Security for the Eastern District of Texas and Mayor of Heath, Texas.

The DNI position was created after the 9/11 terrorist attacks to oversee the U.S. intelligence community and serve as an adviser to the President, National Security Council, and Homeland Security Council on national security-related intelligence issues. The current acting DNI is Richard Grenell, who took over after former DNI Dan Coats' resignation last summer.

Democrats' opposition to Grenell could improve Ratcliffe's chances of being confirmed, as House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Adam Schiff sent Grenell a letter demanding answers regarding organizational changes in his office, including President Trump's recent termination of Intelligence Community Inspector General Michael Atkinson.

Title: Americans Skeptical of Trump's Denials of Russian Collusion

A recent poll conducted by Suffolk University has revealed that most Americans do not believe President Donald Trump's denials of collusion with Russia during the 2016 presidential campaign. The poll found that only 24% of respondents have a lot of trust in Trump's denials, while 59% have little or no trust.

The skepticism towards Trump's denials comes as prosecutors continue to file court documents and plea deals in cases involving some of the president's closest associates, including his former personal lawyer Michael Cohen, who was sentenced to three years in prison. The poll also found that 53% of respondents have a lot or some trust in special counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating whether Trump's team conspired with Russia and if the president tried to obstruct investigations into those accusations.

The poll surveyed 1,000 registered voters and had a margin of error of +/-3 percentage points. The results show that Americans are divided on the issue of Russian interference in the 2016 election, with 50% saying Russians definitely interfered to help Trump, while 27% say they definitely did not.

The poll also found that 46% of respondents believe Trump associates definitely colluded with Russia, while 29% say they definitely did not. The results suggest that Americans are closely following the Russia story, with 50% saying they pay a lot of attention to it.

The poll's findings are consistent with previous surveys that have shown a decline in Trump's approval ratings and a growing skepticism towards his presidency. The results also highlight the deep divisions within the country, with Trump supporters continuing to back the president and his denials, while many others are increasingly skeptical of his claims.

The poll's director, David Paleologos, noted that those who follow the news most closely are the most skeptical, with two-thirds having little or no trust in Trump's denial. He also noted that those who are not following the investigation closely are Trump supporters, who are invested in the president's success and are pained to see his stock declining.

The poll's findings come as Trump's former White House national security adviser, Michael Flynn, was scheduled to be sentenced for lying to the FBI. The president tweeted his support for Flynn, saying he was a "good guy" who was being unfairly targeted. The poll's results suggest that many Americans are watching the Russia story closely and are skeptical of Trump's denials.

Title: US Deploys F-22s to South Korea as Part of Joint Military Exercises Amid Heightened Tensions

The United States has deployed F-22 stealth fighter jets to South Korea as part of joint military exercises, amid heightened tensions with North Korea. The move comes after North Korea declared it had entered a "state of war" with the South and threatened the US mainland.

South Korean President Park Geun-hye warned that any provocative moves by North Korea would be met with a "strong response" and emphasized the need for a strong defense. The US has sought to show its willingness to defend its South Korean ally by highlighting its military strength during the exercises.

The exercises, known as Foal Eagle, are an annual training exercise between the US and South Korea, and this year's iteration has been met with increased rhetoric from North Korea. The North has threatened to attack the US mainland and has labeled the US a "boiled pumpkin," vulnerable to attack.

Despite the heightened tensions, analysts have expressed skepticism about North Korea's ability to follow through on its threats. However, concerns remain that the North could carry out a localized attack on South Korea, as it did in 2010 when it shelled Yeongpyeong Island, killing four people.

The US and South Korea have been trying to strike a balance between acknowledging the North's rhetoric as a cause for concern and downplaying the severity of the threat. The US Defense Department has stated that there are "no indications at this point that it's anything more than warmongering rhetoric."

The situation has prompted North Korea's traditional allies, China and Russia, to urge restraint and caution. China has called for calm and urged all parties to work together to turn around the tense situation in the region. Russia has also expressed its concerns and urged all parties to exercise responsibility and restraint.

The coming weeks are likely to be marked by more saber-rattling, with North Korean delegates currently gathered in Pyongyang for the Supreme People's Assembly and the anniversary of the birth of Kim Il Sung, the nation's founder, on April 15. The US-South Korea military exercises are also set to continue until the end of the month.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar Calls for Conditions-Based Aid to Israel, Denounces Treatment of Colleagues

Article:

Representative Ilhan Omar and fellow Democrat Rashida Tlaib held a press conference on Monday to denounce their treatment by the Israeli government and accuse Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and President Trump of conspiring to prevent them from visiting Israel. The congresswomen were supposed to visit Israel on Monday, but Netanyahu announced last week that they would not be admitted, citing concerns that they were planning to use the trip as a platform to grandstand rather than engage in a fact-finding mission.

Omar and Tlaib denied these claims, stating that they had planned to meet with members of the Knesset and Israeli military veterans who advocate for Palestinian self-determination. They also claimed that their itinerary, obtained by an Israeli public broadcaster, showed meetings with Palestinian activists and international human rights groups, but no lawmakers or officials.

The congresswomen were barred from entering Israel due to their support for the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. Tlaib, who is of Palestinian descent, shared her personal experiences of harassment by Israeli authorities, even as a U.S. citizen. Omar and Tlaib urged their colleagues to consider curtailing U.S. aid to Israel unless Prime Minister Netanyahu improves conditions for Palestinians.

"We must be asking, as Israel's ally, that Netanyahu stop the expansion of settlements on Palestinian land and ensure full rights for Palestinians if we are to give them aid," Omar said.

The congresswomen also suggested that President Trump had reached out to Israel to prevent their visit, citing their ongoing feud. Trump, who strongly supported Israel's decision, called Tlaib "obnoxious" for choosing politics over her grandmother.

Democracy for America, a progressive advocacy group, had called for other members of Congress to refuse to visit Israel in solidarity with Omar and Tlaib. However, Omar urged lawmakers to go to Israel to see the conditions of the Palestinians for themselves. "We can't let Trump and Netanyahu succeed in hiding the cruel reality of the occupation from us," she said.

Title: Amazon Rainforest Fires: Understanding the Immediate and Long-term Impacts on the Global Ecosystem

The Amazon rainforest is experiencing its worst fire season in over a decade, with widespread blazes engulfing the region. Dan Nepstad, president and founder of the Earth Innovation Institute, shared his insights on the immediate and long-term effects of these fires on the global ecosystem.

According to Nepstad, it's challenging to determine the true extent of the fires, as many are not easily detectable by satellites. However, he noted that most of the fires are burning in damaged or cleared areas, making them more visible. This year's fires are particularly concerning due to their persistence and the amount of tree biomass being burned, which can spread smoke across entire regions.

Nepstad emphasized that the biggest threat to the Amazon is the large-scale displacement of scrub vegetation, which dries out the forest floor and makes it more prone to intense fires. This can lead to a long-term scenario where the forest is unrecognizable, with grasses and shrubs replacing the original vegetation.

To mitigate the situation, Nepstad suggests shifting from fire-prone systems, such as extensive cattle ranching, to more intensive forms that prioritize tree-based land use. This would incentivize landholders to invest in fire prevention and reduce the need for fires to manage their land.

When asked about the often-repeated phrase "the Amazon is the lungs of the world," Nepstad clarified that it's a simplification. Instead, he emphasizes the Amazon's role as a cooling system for the planet, as the forest absorbs energy and cools the atmosphere through evapotranspiration. The loss of the Amazon would significantly impact global climate patterns and air circulation.

Nepstad's insights highlight the urgent need for a systemic approach to address the Amazon's vulnerability to fires and promote sustainable land use practices.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Defends Decision to Recuse Himself from Russia Investigation

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has reiterated that he believes he made the right decision to recuse himself from any investigations related to Russia, stating that he "did the right thing" and followed explicit regulations by not participating in the investigation into the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Russia.

In an interview with Maria Bartiromo on "Sunday Morning Futures," Sessions explained that as a participant in the Trump campaign, he was required to step aside from the investigation, which was led by special counsel Robert Mueller. Sessions' decision to recuse himself reportedly infuriated President Trump, who had initially supported Sessions' appointment as Attorney General.

In addition to discussing his recusal, Sessions also touched on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which is set to expire on March 5. Sessions expressed uncertainty about whether Congress will find a permanent legislative solution to the program, which temporarily protects some illegal immigrants. He noted that President Trump has offered a potential path to citizenship for up to 1.8 million illegal immigrants, which is more generous than the original DACA policy.

Sessions also discussed the need for law enforcement officials to improve their ability to identify signs of potential mass shooters, following the FBI's acknowledgment that it was alerted but failed to follow up on a tip about the alleged shooter in the recent Florida high school shooting. Sessions met with a group of sheriffs and believes that receiving and acting on these signs is crucial to preventing such tragedies.

Overall, Sessions' comments provide insight into his thought process and actions regarding the Russia investigation and other pressing issues, including immigration reform and mass shootings.

Title: Senate Approves Sweeping Immigration Overhaul, Sending Bill to House

The United States Senate has approved a comprehensive immigration overhaul, extending legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants while increasing border security. The bill, which passed with a 68-32 vote, sends it to the House of Representatives, where it faces a chilly reception.

The legislation, a product of weeks of bipartisan negotiations, would provide a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants currently living in the country illegally. It also includes measures to prevent future illegal immigration, such as increasing border security, hiring 20,000 new Border Patrol agents, and deploying high-tech devices to secure the border with Mexico.

The bill's passage marks a partial victory for President Obama, who has made immigration reform a cornerstone of his second-term agenda. However, the bill fell short of the 70 votes some backers had hoped for, and some Republicans have already declared it "dead on arrival" in the House.

House Speaker John Boehner declined to comment on how his caucus would proceed, saying they would "go home for the recess next week and listen to our constituents" before discussing the way forward.

Despite the strong majority in favor of the bill, Congress remains divided on the issue. Republican opponents voiced frustration, citing concerns about the bill's potential impact on wages and unemployment. Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala., said the failure to reach 70 votes "ensures the House has plenty of space to chart an opposite course and reject this fatally flawed proposal."

The legislation would be the most significant overhaul of the US immigration system since the 1980s. It would expand legal immigration and increase border security, while providing a pathway to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants.

The bill's passage is a rare example of bipartisan cooperation, with all Democrats and 14 Republicans voting in favor of the legislation. However, the House Judiciary Committee is working on a piecemeal approach, with separate bills addressing issues such as employer verification and high-skilled workers.

The legislation's opponents argue that it prioritizes "amnesty" over security, while supporters see it as a necessary step towards fixing the broken immigration system. The bill's fate now rests with the House, where it faces an uncertain future.

Title: Republicans' Reversal on Repealing the Affordable Care Act: A Shift in Public Opinion

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been a contentious topic in the United States since its introduction. Initially, many Americans opposed the law, but recent developments suggest that public opinion may be shifting. According to polls, about half of those surveyed now express support for the act, with many people willing to fight to keep their subsidies.

This phenomenon is not unique to the Affordable Care Act. In other countries, people have also shown resistance to changes in their benefits and subsidies. For instance, French workers protested against changes to their job protections, including a 35-hour workweek, which was seen as detrimental to the economy. Similarly, Greek day care workers took to the streets when their government proposed increasing their work hours.

The article highlights the challenges of reforming or eliminating government programs, citing examples from the United States and other countries. It notes that even seemingly reasonable changes, such as ending farm subsidies, can lead to severe reactions. The article also touches on the concept of corporate welfare, where special interests and lobbyists can influence policy decisions.

The article concludes by noting that while some politicians have attempted to reform or eliminate certain programs, such as the mohair subsidy, it can be difficult to achieve significant changes. The article also highlights the complexity of entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, which are often seen as essential by many Americans.

Title: Unaccountable Police Culture: A Systemic Issue Beyond Racism

The recent arrest of Minneapolis policeman Derek Chauvin, charged with the murder of George Floyd, has sparked widespread outrage and calls for accountability. However, the issue goes beyond individual misconduct, revealing a systemic problem of unaccountable police culture. Chauvin had 18 complaints filed against him during his 19-year tenure, with only two resulting in discipline. This lack of accountability is not unique to Chauvin, as a Reuters report found that out of 2,600 complaints filed against Minneapolis police since 2012, only 12 resulted in disciplinary action.

The problem is not limited to Minneapolis, as a 2017 Reuters report revealed that police union contracts often make it difficult to discipline officers, even in cases of extreme misconduct. In Columbus, Ohio, an officer accused of brutally beating a black college student was subject to 40 complaints, but was not terminated due to union rules that require prior complaints to be expunged from the record after a few months.

The lack of accountability is not limited to police departments, as a 2016 Government Accountability Office report found that over 99% of federal employees received a "fully successful" rating, indicating a broader problem with accountability throughout government.

The issue is not solely a matter of racism, as some argue, but rather a result of a flawed system that prioritizes due process for police officers over accountability to the public. The confusion between liberty and responsibility has led to a culture of unaccountability, where supervisors are hesitant to discipline officers due to the burden of proof required in legal proceedings.

The consequences of unaccountable police culture are far-reaching, including the erosion of public trust, the breakdown of civil society, and the corrosion of norms. The lack of accountability can also lead to a culture of cynicism and disrespect, as seen in the recent protests and riots.

To address this issue, a new social contract with public employees is needed, prioritizing accountability for the public good. This can be achieved by giving veto power to peer committees and ensuring that supervisors are empowered to make judgments about officer performance. Ultimately, accountability is not just a matter of fairness to individual officers, but a necessary condition for the health of our public culture.

Title: Obama Expresses Hope for Resolution to Budget and Debt Deadlocks

The White House and Congress are working over the weekend to resolve the ongoing budget and debt impasse, with President Obama expressing optimism that a solution can be reached soon. In his weekly address, Obama praised the House Republicans' offer to raise the nation's borrowing limit for six weeks, calling it a "positive development." He emphasized the need to end the government shutdown and work together to address the country's budget deficits.

The administration has warned that the government will run out of authority to pay its bills unless Congress agrees to raise the debt limit by Thursday. The House and Senate are working on differing proposals to raise the debt ceiling and reopen the government, which has been shut down for 12 days. House Republicans have proposed a plan that would set up budget talks, while Senate Democrats are considering a plan to extend the borrowing limit through the 2014 elections.

Senate Republicans, on the other hand, are working on a proposal that would increase the borrowing limit until January, end the government shutdown, and delay the implementation of the Affordable Care Act's medical device tax. Republicans have accused Obama of seeking increased revenue as part of the negotiations, while the president has emphasized the need to cut budget deficits in a "smarter, balanced way" that allows for investment in key areas.

As negotiations continue, House Armed Services Chairman Howard "Buck" McKeon urged the president to sign interim measures approved by the House to reopen some government services, including national parks. McKeon also called on Obama to work with Congress to reopen the entire government and avoid defaulting on the country's debts.

**Tokyo Olympics Postponed Until 2021 Amid Global Coronavirus Spread**

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe have agreed to postpone the Tokyo Olympics until the summer of 2021 at the latest, due to the ongoing global spread of the coronavirus. The decision was announced on Tuesday, with the IOC and Abe stating that the Games will be rescheduled to a date beyond 2020 but not later than summer 2021.

According to a joint statement, the decision was made to "safeguard the health of the athletes, everybody involved in the Olympic Games, and the international community." The statement also emphasized that the Olympic flame will remain in Japan and the Games will retain the name "Olympic and Paralympic Games Tokyo 2020."

Veteran IOC member Dick Pound told USA Today that the postponement has been decided, with parameters going forward still to be determined. Pound also noted that the ramifications of postponing the Games would be "immense."

The IOC has begun discussing scenarios for modifying existing operational plans for the Games, including changes to the start date, with a decision expected within the next four weeks. Canada and Australia have already announced they will not be sending athletes to Tokyo, while USA Swimming has called on U.S. officials to do the same.

In a letter to athletes, IOC President Thomas Bach acknowledged the uncertainty and emotional impact of the decision, stating that the rational approach may not align with athletes' emotions. The IOC has emphasized that cancellation is not on the agenda, and the Games will still take place under the name "Olympic and Paralympic Games Tokyo 2020."

Title: Trump Administration Unfazed by International Criticism, Says No Country Exemptions for Steel and Aluminum Tariffs

The Trump administration has shown no signs of backing down from its decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, despite widespread criticism from both domestic and international quarters. According to White House trade adviser Peter Navarro, there are no plans to exempt any countries from the 25% and 10% duties, respectively.

The tariffs, announced on Thursday, have roiled markets and raised concerns about a potential trade war. While the administration's rhetoric has focused on China, the duties will also affect significant imports from Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Japan, and the European Union.

The Pentagon had recommended targeted tariffs, but Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said that was not the direction the president would take. Ross dismissed threats of retaliation from American allies as "pretty trivial."

The move has sparked a rare moment of unusual alliance, with labor unions and liberal Democrats applauding the administration's approach, while Republicans and business groups warn of dire economic and political consequences.

Trade politics often cut along regional lines, but this debate has opened a rift between the president and his party, leaving him with support mainly from his ideological opposites. Some Democrats, such as Senators Sherrod Brown and Bob Casey, have praised the move, while Republicans like Senators John Thune and Governor Scott Walker have expressed concerns.

The Business Roundtable's Josh Bolten called on the administration to reconsider its stance, saying that sometimes a president needs to recognize that campaign rhetoric may not be right and should be retracted. Tim Phillips, president of Americans for Prosperity, noted that the tariffs could lead to higher prices for individual Americans and hurt the administration politically.

The president himself has taken to Twitter to defend the move, saying "Trade wars are good and easy to win."

Title: Attorney General Barr to Release Redacted Mueller Report on Thursday

Article:

Attorney General William Barr plans to release a redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election and contacts between Moscow and President Donald Trump's campaign on Thursday morning. The Justice Department announced the plan on Monday, stating that the report, which is approximately 400 pages long, will be released to Congress and the public. The report's release comes after Mueller turned over his confidential report to Barr on March 22, ending his 22-month-long inquiry.

The report's release may not be the final step in the process, as Congressional Democrats have demanded the release of the full report with no redactions and have asked for the underlying evidence gathered by Mueller. The Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee has voted to empower its chairman, Jerrold Nadler, to issue subpoenas for the full report and underlying evidence.

Moments after the department announced its plans for releasing the report, President Trump took to Twitter to attack Mueller's team and deride the "Russia Hoax." The Mueller investigation has cast a cloud over the presidency of Trump, who has often called it a politically motivated "witch hunt."

Barr has pledged to be as transparent as possible, but he will redact certain portions of the report for reasons including protecting secret grand jury information, intelligence-gathering sources and methods, information relating to ongoing cases, and the privacy of "peripheral third parties" who were not charged. The redactions will be color-coded by category, according to Barr, explaining the reasons that parts are blacked out.

The attorney general has also said he will testify publicly about the report's conclusions before the Senate and House judiciary committees on May 1 and 2, respectively. The Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee has voted to empower its chairman, Jerrold Nadler, to issue subpoenas for the full report and underlying evidence.

Title: Sheldon Adelson's $10 Million Contribution Makes Him the Most Prolific Campaign Donor in the 2012 Election

Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner, and his wife, Dr. Miriam Adelson, have given $10 million to Restore Our Future, a super PAC backing Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney. This significant contribution makes the Adelsons the most prolific campaign donors in the country, with a total of at least $35 million given to super PACs during the 2012 campaign. The Adelsons' generosity is unmatched, with their closest competitor, billionaire industrialist Harold C. Simmons and his wife, Annette, trailing behind with contributions of at least $15 million.

Sheldon Adelson's net worth of approximately $25 billion allows him to give even more, and he has expressed willingness to spend up to $100 million on the 2012 elections. The Adelsons' contributions have primarily gone to Winning Our Future, a super PAC that supported Newt Gingrich during the Republican primaries. However, after Gingrich dropped out, the Adelsons shifted their support to Romney, with Adelson meeting the candidate for lunch at his Las Vegas hotel, The Venetian, in May.

The Adelsons' ties to Romney's supporters, particularly wealthy Jewish donors, are strong, as they have served on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition together. Additionally, the Adelsons have connections to Restore Our Future, as its political director, Carl Forti, previously worked for Freedom's Watch, an issue advocacy group that spent $17 million during the 2008 election.

**US Declares National Emergency, Restricts Huawei Technology Amid Security Concerns**

The United States has declared a national economic emergency, empowering the government to restrict technology and services from "foreign adversaries" deemed to pose "unacceptable risks" to national security. The move targets Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company, amid concerns that its equipment could be used for cyber-espionage and sabotage.

The executive order, issued by President Donald Trump, does not name specific countries or companies but reflects government concerns that equipment from Chinese suppliers could pose an espionage threat to US internet and telecommunications infrastructure. The order directs the Commerce Department to draw up a plan for enforcement within 150 days.

Huawei has responded to the move, stating that restricting the company would not make the US safer or stronger, but rather would force the country to use inferior and expensive alternative equipment, lagging behind other countries and ultimately harming US companies and consumers.

The company is willing to communicate with the US to ensure product security, echoing reassurances given to the UK. The Commerce Department has added Huawei and 70 affiliates to its "entity list," banning the company from acquiring components and technology from US firms without government approval.

The move is the latest development in the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, with both sides imposing tariffs on each other's goods. The US has previously labeled Huawei a threat and lobbied allies not to use Huawei network equipment in next-generation 5G networks, calling it untrustworthy.

China has emphasized that the concept of national security should not be abused and that it should not be used as a tool for trade protectionism. The country has also pledged to take necessary counter-measures against the US actions, including increased tariffs on US imports and added regulatory hurdles for US companies operating in China.

The US Commerce Secretary, Wilbur Ross, stated that the order is aimed at protecting the supply chain from "foreign adversaries" to the nation's information and communications technology and services supply chain. The move has been met with criticism from China, with a foreign affairs spokesman describing US actions against specific Chinese companies as "disgraceful and unjust."

Title: Supreme Court's Potential Impact on Abortion Rights: Beyond the Simple "Overturn" Scenario

The Supreme Court's potential decisions on abortion rights have sparked widespread concern, with many assuming that the court might simply overturn Roe v. Wade. However, this scenario is not the only, or even the most likely, outcome. The court's decisions can be broken down into four possible categories: nuclear options, overruling Roe v. Wade, chipping away at Roe v. Wade, and incremental changes.

The nuclear options are the most extreme and least likely scenarios. One possibility is that the court could flip Roe v. Wade on its head, declaring that the Constitution prohibits abortion in the interest of protecting fetal life. This would outlaw abortion across the nation, making it illegal for women to access the procedure. Another nuclear option is the court eliminating the right to privacy established in the 1965 Griswold v. Connecticut case, which would effectively do away with the basis for Roe v. Wade and allow states to regulate abortion as they wish.

The second possibility is that the court could overrule Roe v. Wade, which would still allow for a right to privacy but not include a constitutional right to abortion. This would give states the freedom to regulate abortion as they see fit, with some advocacy groups estimating that up to 22 states could make abortion illegal entirely.

The most likely scenario, however, is that the court will chip away at Roe v. Wade by upholding restrictions on abortion. The court has already done so in previous cases, such as upholding bans on performing abortions in public facilities and blocking medication abortion in Arkansas. This could lead to more severe restrictions on abortion rights, making it harder for women to access the procedure.

Chief Justice John Roberts is known for his incremental approach, and it's unlikely that he would choose to overrule Roe v. Wade when there are other ways to achieve similar results. Instead, the court may interpret the "undue burden" standard, which allows states to impose restrictions on abortion, but with a slightly different interpretation. This could lead to a patchwork of laws across the country, making it harder for women, particularly those in red states, to access abortion services.

Title: Hobby Lobby Employee Claims Discrimination After Being Fired During Pregnancy

A recent report by RH Reality Check has shed light on a former employee's experience at Hobby Lobby, a company known for its Christian values and family-friendly work environment. Felicia Allen, who started working as a part-time cashier at Hobby Lobby in 2010, claimed that she was fired after requesting time off to give birth to her child, despite being assured by her supervisor that her job would be waiting for her when she was ready to return.

According to Allen, she was told by her supervisor that she would not lose her job due to her pregnancy, and she felt comfortable taking time off to prepare for the birth. However, when she was ready to return to work three weeks after giving birth, she was not rehired, despite her previous assurances.

Allen also claimed that Hobby Lobby fought her on unemployment benefits, stating that she could have taken personal leave but opted not to. She eventually won her claim, but the experience left her feeling that the company had discriminated against her due to her pregnancy.

The report highlights the company's arbitration policy, which requires employees to sign away their right to sue in court. This policy has been criticized by experts, who argue that it allows companies to keep disputes out of the public eye and avoid accountability.

Hobby Lobby's president, Steve Green, has stated that the company's Christian principles guide its business practices, but it remains unclear how this story of alleged discrimination against a new mother aligns with those principles. The company has not yet responded to a request for comment.

This incident raises questions about the company's treatment of employees, particularly those with family obligations. While Hobby Lobby has been praised for its family-friendly policies, this story suggests that the company may not always live up to its promises.

Title: US District Court Issues Temporary Injunction on Obama's Immigration Policy

The United States District Court for the Southern Division of Texas has issued a temporary injunction, enjoining the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) from implementing the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans or Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) program, which was announced by President Obama on November 20, 2014. The injunction, issued by U.S. District Court Judge Andrew Hanen, preserves the status quo until a more thorough court proceeding can rule on the merits of the case.

The court's decision means that the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services office will not begin accepting new applications for the DAPA program, which was scheduled to start in May. Additionally, the estimated four million illegal immigrants who would have been eligible for work permits, driver's licenses, and Social Security numbers under the program will not receive these benefits.

The court did not rule on the existing Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which was implemented in June 2012. The injunction only affects the expansion of DACA outlined in the November 20 DAPA Memorandum and the larger DAPA program.

The White House has announced that it will appeal the decision to a three-judge panel of the 5th Circuit, which could issue a decision around July or August of this year. If the Obama administration loses the appeal, it could then appeal to the Supreme Court, with the earliest possible hearing in March 2016 and decision in June 2016.

The temporary injunction has sparked debate in Congress, with Speaker John Boehner urging Senate Democrats to allow a vote on a bill to fund the Department of Homeland Security, which would defund Obama's amnesty programs. However, it is possible that a compromise could be reached, where the DHS bill would continue to defund the DAPA program, but Democratic Senators could offer amendments to preserve the DACA program. Moderate Senator Susan Collins has already floated such a compromise.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Cancels Summer Vacation to Focus on Agenda

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has abruptly canceled nearly half of the Senate's summer vacation, citing the need for lawmakers to stay in Washington and make progress on President Trump's agenda. The decision comes as Congress faces a packed schedule, with passing a budget, repealing Obamacare, and beginning work on tax reform at the top of the to-do list.

McConnell stated that the Senate will utilize the first two weeks in August to make progress on these issues, which he believes are crucial to the country's future. He also mentioned that the Senate's backlog of presidential nominations has grown due to Democratic obstruction, and that keeping lawmakers in Washington will help address this issue.
