Rank-and-file Republicans have expressed support for the decision, with Senator Ted Cruz stating that the Senate should not go home until its job is done. However, Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer, a Democrat, has criticized the move, saying that Republicans are trying to mask their own legislative failures.

The decision to cancel summer vacation is a rare move, as Congress usually only abbreviates its recess when facing an immediate spending deadline that could result in a government shutdown. This time, the Senate will spend the next two weeks rewriting and debating the Republican bill to repeal Obamacare, followed by the annual defense policy bill and potentially raising the federal government's borrowing limit.

Analysts note that Congress must accomplish these tasks by October, and that the Senate's schedule is packed with other pressing issues, including passing a new budget to streamline the process for tax reform. While some have expressed concerns about the decision, others believe that adding more time to the schedule will help break Democratic resistance and allow the Senate to make progress on its agenda.

Title: Senate Majority Obama Leaned On the Past Six Years is Gone

The 2014 midterm elections saw the Senate majority that President Barack Obama leaned on for the past six years come to an end. The Democratic Party's inability to capitalize on opportunities and cope with challenges led to their loss of control in the Senate. The election was marked by a series of missteps and missed opportunities, including a bitter feud between Democratic leaders over their candidate in South Dakota, a flawed Democratic candidate in Iowa, and a failure to capitalize on a weak Republican in Georgia.

The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) had suggested Obama do a barrage of robocalls and radio interviews to help turn out black voters, but he was not allowed to visit battleground states. Obama's aides had felt for months that he wasn't being used enough in the closely contested Senate races that would determine control of the chamber and the shape of his last two years in office.

State by state, the Democrats couldn't get it together. They faced the "six-year itch" of Obama's second term, when the president's party traditionally gets pummeled. The Republicans, on the other hand, had a simple message: a vote for them is a vote against Obama. And Democrats were never able to escape it.

The election was also marked by a series of challenges and controversies, including the Affordable Care Act (ACA) website debacle, the rise of ISIL in the Middle East, the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, and the crisis over Russia's actions in Ukraine. These issues kept Obama front and center in the news, exactly where Democrats on Capitol Hill didn't want him.

The White House officials have their own gripes, saying that Senate Democrats blundered time and again by being too frightened to do anything, mishandling their relationship with Obama, while candidates foolishly ran from a president they were going to be tied to anyway.

The article concludes that the Democratic Party's inability to capitalize on opportunities and cope with challenges led to their loss of control in the Senate, and that the election was marked by a series of missteps and missed opportunities.

Title: Trump Administration Plans to Impose Tariffs on $200 Billion in Chinese Goods

The Trump administration is set to impose tariffs on approximately $200 billion worth of Chinese goods as early as Monday, according to a senior administration official. This move is part of a prolonged trade battle between the world's two largest economies. The tariffs, which could be as high as 25%, are intended to punish China for its policies deemed unfair and harmful to American businesses.

The administration has been threatening these tariffs for months, citing intellectual property theft and mandated technology transfers as major concerns. The public comment period on the tariffs ended last week, clearing the way for the president to make good on the threat. However, pressure from American businesses may have led the administration to temper its approach, with some urging consideration of the tariffs' impact on consumers, particularly ahead of the retail holiday season.

The National Retail Federation and 150 other business groups expressed concerns about the tariffs' effects on farmers, families, businesses, and workers in a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer. The president has also threatened to impose tariffs on virtually all $505 billion worth of Chinese imports, with $267 billion ready to go on short notice.

Despite the ongoing trade tensions, the administration and Chinese leaders are planning to resume trade talks later this month. The president has maintained a tough stance on China, stating that the country is under pressure to make a deal with the United States, while the U.S. is not under pressure to make a deal with China. The White House has confirmed that the president intends to move ahead with the tariffs, with a White House spokeswoman stating that the administration will continue to take action to address China's unfair trade practices.

China has threatened to retaliate with tariffs ranging from 5 to 25% on an additional $60 billion in U.S. products as soon as the Chinese tariffs are imposed. The U.S. exports around $130 billion in goods to China, leaving room for China to explore alternative retaliatory measures.

Title: Recent Attacks in Afghanistan Highlight Risks for Foreigners

The recent killings of an award-winning photographer and a doctor in Afghanistan have highlighted the risks faced by foreigners in the country. Anja Niedringhaus, a German citizen and photographer for The Associated Press, was killed by a police officer at a checkpoint in eastern Afghanistan, while Kathy Gannon, a Canadian reporter who had covered Afghanistan and Pakistan for The Associated Press for decades, was wounded in the same attack. A month prior, a Swedish journalist was shot and killed in a heavily guarded area of Kabul.

These incidents are reminiscent of the insider attacks that plagued the international coalition's military training mission in Afghanistan two years ago. However, as international coalition soldiers have largely stuck to their bases and new strategies have been implemented to prevent such attacks, foreign workers in Afghanistan have become the primary targets. While the number of Western civilians targeted is still small compared to military deaths, both are greatly outstripped by Afghan civilian casualties in the war.

The Taliban has been targeting locations popular with expatriates, including a recent assault on a restaurant in central Kabul that left 21 people dead, most of them foreigners, and shootings at the luxury Serena Hotel that killed nine. These events have put the thousands of foreigners living in Kabul on high alert.

The unpredictable nature of the violence has prompted some embassies to redouble their security efforts and has led those living outside secure areas to limit their exposure. Friends and colleagues of Dr. Jerry Umanos, a pediatrician from Chicago who was killed in the attack, described him as a dedicated and skilled doctor who was passionate about working with Afghans and teaching the next generation of doctors.

Title: Trump's D-Day Speech Receives Unlikely Praise from Mainstream Media Critics

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, President Trump's speech on the 75th anniversary of D-Day received praise from two of his biggest mainstream media critics, CNN's Jim Acosta and MSNBC's Joe Scarborough. Acosta, known for his combative approach to reporting on the Trump administration, commended Trump for staying on script and delivering a message that honored the bravery of Allied fighters who "stood in the fires of hell" during the D-Day invasion.

Acosta stated that Trump "hit all the right moments" when paying respect to the D-Day heroes, noting that it was a "beautiful moment" when Trump acknowledged that many of the troops who fought in the war felt that the "heroes were the ones that never came back," but the survivors formed a remarkable generation.

Scarborough, a frequent critic of Trump, echoed Acosta's sentiments, calling Trump's speech "the strongest speech of his presidency." He praised Trump for acknowledging the sacrifices of those who fought in the war, saying it was a "beautiful moment" when Trump recognized that many of the troops who fought in the war felt that the "heroes were the ones that never came back."

It is worth noting that Acosta and Scarborough are not typically known for their praise of Trump, and their comments were likely unexpected by many viewers. However, their remarks highlight the importance of the D-Day anniversary and the significance of honoring the bravery and sacrifices of those who fought in the war.

Title: NSA Allegedly Taps into Unencrypted Data Links of Google and Yahoo Servers

The National Security Agency (NSA) has allegedly tapped into the unencrypted data links of Google and Yahoo servers, according to a recent report by the Washington Post. The report claims that the NSA, in collaboration with its British counterpart GCHQ, has gained access to the data through an unnamed telecommunications provider outside the US. This access allegedly allows the NSA to collect data from hundreds of millions of user accounts, including emails, videos, and audio files, not just metadata, from both foreign citizens and American citizens.

The report states that Google and Yahoo's massive servers are carefully guarded and strictly audited, with Google's buildings housing its servers being guarded around the clock by trained personnel and secured with heat-sensitive cameras, biometric verification, and more. However, the NSA's alleged hack has raised concerns among engineers with close ties to Google, who reportedly expressed outrage upon seeing a drawing of the hack revealed by Edward Snowden.

The White House and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which oversees the NSA, declined to confirm, deny, or explain the agency's alleged actions. NSA Director Gen. Keith Alexander stated that the agency does not access such networks without a court order, according to Politico. The NSA also released a statement saying it only uses attorney general-approved processes in data collection.

Google and Yahoo have also responded to the allegations. Google stated that it is "troubled by allegations of the government intercepting traffic between our data centers" and is not aware of this activity. The company has been extending encryption across more and more Google services and links to protect user data. Yahoo also denied giving access to its data centers to the NSA or any other government agency.

The controversy surrounding the NSA's alleged actions has sparked renewed debate about the agency's surveillance practices and the need for greater transparency and accountability.

Title: US States Begin Lifting Lockdown Orders as Social Distancing Guidelines Remain in Place

As the United States continues to navigate the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, several states have started to lift their lockdown orders, allowing some businesses to reopen and individuals to return to their daily routines. However, public health experts warn that social distancing guidelines will remain necessary throughout the summer to prevent a second wave of infections.

According to Johns Hopkins University, the US has recorded over 994,000 coronavirus cases and more than 56,700 deaths as of Tuesday. Despite the decline in infection rates in some hotspots, including New York, the epicenter of the outbreak, the virus remains a significant threat.

Governors and mayors have issued varying plans for reopening their states and cities, with some allowing businesses to resume operations and others maintaining restrictions. Georgia, Oklahoma, Alaska, and South Carolina have already lifted some restrictions, while Colorado, Tennessee, and Montana have announced plans to relax rules in the coming weeks.

Some city mayors have issued their own separate plans to end local lockdowns, with Colorado's Democratic Governor Jared Polis announcing that kerb-side retail pickup can begin on Monday, and hair salons, barbershops, and tattoo parlors allowed to reopen on Friday. Tennessee will allow restaurants to reopen on Monday, while Mississippi's mandatory lockdown order expires on the same day.

Montana's governor has allowed churches to reopen starting on Sunday, with social distancing measures still required. Restaurants and schools will be allowed to reopen on May 7. Eight states led by Republican governors, including Arkansas, Iowa, Nebraska, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming, never issued mandatory stay-at-home orders.

Michigan's Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer told ABC News that it is too early to lift mandatory orders in the state, stating, "We've got to be nimble and we have to follow the science and be really smart about how we reengage."

Despite some states lifting restrictions, officials in both Ventura and Orange Counties in California reported that most people were adhering to social distancing guidelines, including staying 6 feet apart. However, many beaches remain closed, with the sheriff of LA County warning beach-goers that "enforcement is in full effect."

Texas Governor Greg Abbott said he will not renew the state's stay-at-home order when it expires on April 30, stating that it has "done its job." Republican Governor Mike DeWine of Ohio announced that non-essential surgery that does not require an overnight hospital stay can resume on May 1, with offices allowed to reopen on May 4 and retail businesses on May 12.

Public health experts warn that lifting restrictions too soon could lead to a second wave of infections, and social distancing will remain the norm "through the summer to really ensure that we protect one another as we move through these phases," said Dr. Deborah Birx, White House coronavirus taskforce co-ordinator.

The article concludes with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo suggesting that some parts of his state could begin to reopen after the current stay-at-home order expires on May 15, with transmission rates and death rates dictating how and when the state reopens.

Title: Federal Appeals Court Strikes Down North Carolina's Voting Restrictions, Citing Discriminatory Intent

The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has struck down North Carolina's voting restrictions, some of the strictest in the nation, citing discriminatory intent. The decision comes after the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down Texas's Voter ID laws and a federal district court placed an injunction against Wisconsin's restrictions. The ruling affects over 1.3 million voters in four swing states, mostly by eliminating early voting periods and requiring specific forms of identification.

The court found that North Carolina's 2016 law disproportionately affected African Americans, who were poised to become a major electoral force. The law eliminated early voting periods, same-day registration, and out-of-precinct voting, which disproportionately affected African Americans. The court noted that the state legislature enacted the law after receiving data on the use of voting practices by race, and that the new provisions targeted African Americans with "surgical precision."

The court's opinion condemned the state legislature for acting with discriminatory intent, stating that the law was intended to disadvantage African Americans. The court found that the law was not an accident, but rather a deliberate attempt to disenfranchise African Americans.

The decision is part of a growing trend of judicial opinions striking down voting restrictions, with challenges pending in Ohio, Virginia, and Kansas. The ACLU's Dale Ho, who argued the case, hailed the decision as a "huge victory" and noted that public opinion is shifting as well.

The ruling puts North Carolina's photo ID requirement, changes to early voting, same-day registration, out-of-precinct voting, and preregistration on hold, allowing a million more voters to participate in elections. While the state could appeal, Ho expressed optimism about the court's decision, stating that the state's odds of success are low.

Title: Obama and Romney Neck-and-Neck in Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin, According to Latest Polls

A recent Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times survey has revealed that President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger Mitt Romney are running neck-and-neck in three crucial battleground states: Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin. The poll found that Obama has a slight edge in each of the three states, with margins within the polling error.

In Florida, Obama received 49% of likely voters' support, compared to Romney's 46%. In Ohio, Obama led with 50% of likely voters, while Romney received 44%. In Wisconsin, Obama had 49% support, and Romney had 47%.

The poll also showed that Romney's selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate has had a minimal impact on voter support. In Florida, Romney's support increased by one percentage point since Ryan's announcement, while in Wisconsin, it increased by two points. Ohio's numbers remained unchanged.

The survey also found that voters in these key states view Ryan more favorably than Vice President Joe Biden. In Florida, 29% of voters had an unfavorable impression of Ryan, compared to 44% for Biden. In Ohio, 27% of voters had an unfavorable impression of Ryan, compared to 40% for Biden. In Wisconsin, Ryan's home state, 35% of voters had an unfavorable impression of him, compared to 42% for Biden.

The poll also touched on the issue of Medicare, a key concern in the presidential campaign. The survey found that a majority of voters in all three states believe Medicare should continue operating as it currently does, with the government providing insurance to seniors. Strong majorities also said they believe Medicare is worth the cost to taxpayers.

The Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times poll was conducted by telephone between August 15-21, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percentage points in each state.

Title: Illinois Voter Challenges Ted Cruz's Eligibility to Run for President

Article:

A voter from Illinois, Lawrence Joyce, has filed a lawsuit against Senator Ted Cruz, challenging his eligibility to run for the Republican presidential nomination. Joyce claims that Cruz is not a "natural-born citizen" and therefore cannot be president. This comes after Cruz's rival, Donald Trump, threatened to sue him over a campaign ad.

Joyce's lawsuit will be heard in the Circuit Court of Cook County in Chicago on Friday. He is seeking to have Cruz disqualified from the Illinois primary ballot, which is set to take place next month. Joyce's previous objection to Cruz's candidacy was dismissed by the state's Board of Elections, but he appealed the decision and was granted a hearing.

Cruz has maintained that he is a natural-born citizen, citing his mother's American birth. However, Joyce believes that Cruz's birth in Canada makes him ineligible to run for president. "What I fear is that Ted Cruz becomes the nominee, come September, Congressman Alan Grayson of Florida will go forward with his threats and probably several other Democrats will file suit to prevent Ted Cruz from being on the ballot," Joyce said.

The Trump campaign has not commented on the lawsuit, while Cruz's spokesman, Rick Tyler, declined to comment. A federal lawsuit was filed in Texas last month asking for a determination of Cruz's eligibility to run, and voters in New York have also filed a challenge with the state Board of Elections.

Constitutional law professor Sanford Levinson from the University of Texas School of Law believes that Joyce would need to prove standing – or why Cruz's potential ineligibility affects him specifically – for the judge to proceed with the case. Even if the judge declares Cruz ineligible, the GOP candidate's campaign would likely appeal the decision, potentially tying the case up for months.

It remains to be seen how this lawsuit will play out, but it is clear that the eligibility of presidential candidates is a contentious issue that will continue to be debated in the coming months.

Title: Libertarian Party's Gary Johnson Sees Surge in Support, Could Make Debate Stage

The Libertarian Party's presidential ticket, led by Gary Johnson and William Weld, is experiencing a significant surge in support, with polls showing them reaching nearly 15% of the vote, the threshold needed to participate in the presidential debates. This comes as both major-party candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, face popularity issues and trust gaps with voters.

The RealClearPolitics average has Johnson at 8.4% in a four-way race with Trump, Clinton, and Green Party candidate Jill Stein, up from 4.5% in June. A recent poll released Wednesday put Johnson at 12%, while an NBC poll taken during the Democratic convention put him at 9%.

Party officials believe the unpopularity of the major-party candidates gives the Libertarian Party an "unprecedented opportunity." Johnson's record as a two-term New Mexico governor, re-elected as a Republican in a Democratic state, is being touted as a key factor in his appeal.

While it is unclear whether the support in the polls will translate into support at the ballot box, there are signs that more voters are seeking an alternative candidate. Johnson and Weld generated buzz before the conventions with a slick video ad listing their accomplishments, and Johnson believes his stance on social issues and foreign policy could bring Bernie Sanders supporters on board.

The Libertarian Party is banking on Johnson introducing himself to voters not familiar with his story, especially if he is able to get on the debate stage. However, he has until the middle of September to hit 15% in not just one poll but an average of five recent polls chosen by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

While the record for third-party or independent candidates is not strong, Johnson's potential impact is hard to gauge. The latest poll found Johnson siphoning support about equally from the Democratic and GOP candidates. However, he could get a boost in the coming weeks as some Republicans reportedly consider backing him, including 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush.

Title: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Same-Sex Marriage Cases, Allowing Lower Courts to Continue Ruling in Favor of Marriage Equality

The Supreme Court has declined to take up cases challenging same-sex marriage, effectively allowing lower courts to continue issuing rulings in favor of marriage equality across the country. This decision means that states such as Indiana, Oklahoma, Utah, Virginia, and Wisconsin will be required to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

The Supreme Court's decision not to hear the cases is seen as a greenlight for lower courts to continue striking down traditional marriage laws. The Court has previously established a trend of waiting for a majority of states to adopt same-sex marriage before making a ruling, rather than taking a proactive approach.

In the past, the Court has used this approach to establish a "trend-line" and declare that society has "evolved" on certain issues. For example, the Court waited 17 years to overrule the 1986 decision in Bowers v. Hardwick, which had upheld the criminalization of sodomy. The Court ultimately declared that anal penetration was a constitutional right, stating that "an emerging awareness that liberty gives substantial protection to adult persons in deciding how to conduct their private lives in matters pertaining to sex."

However, Justice Scalia has criticized this approach, arguing that the Court's statement was false and that the state still regulates certain behaviors, such as prostitution, adult incest, and child pornography. Scalia also noted that constitutional entitlements do not spring into existence simply because some states choose to lessen or eliminate criminal sanctions on certain behavior.

The Court's decision not to hear the same-sex marriage cases has given lower courts the tools to create an "emerging consensus" on the issue. Last year, the Court ruled that state attorneys general could refuse to defend state laws in favor of traditional marriage, effectively allowing the executive branch of state government to destroy laws it does not like. The Court also set the predicate for future same-sex marriage rulings in the United States v. Windsor case, in which the Court declared that anyone opposed to same-sex marriage is an enemy of human decency.

Ben Shapiro, Senior Editor-At-Large of and author of the book "The People vs. Barack Obama: The Criminal Case Against The Obama Administration," has criticized the Court's approach, stating that it allows for a top-down evolution of the law, rather than a grassroots movement.

Title: FBI and NCTC Briefings Contradict CIA Director's Account of Benghazi Attack

The FBI and National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC) provided Capitol Hill briefings on September 13, stating that the evidence supported an Al Qaeda or Al Qaeda-affiliated attack on the US diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya. This assessment stands in contrast to CIA Director David Petraeus' briefing on September 14, which described the attack as tied to a demonstration.

According to sources, the FBI and NCTC briefings were based on intercepts of individuals believed to have participated in the attack, who were celebratory, as well as a claim of responsibility. The briefings also mentioned the presence of Al Qaeda training camps in the area, which was described as a hotbed for militant groups Ansar al-Sharia and Al Qaeda in North Africa.

In contrast, Petraeus characterized the attack as a "flash mob" with militants showing up spontaneously with RPGs, downplaying the skill required to fire mortars, which were also used in the attack. Petraeus emphasized that the attack was linked to a demonstration and was spontaneous, rather than pre-meditated.

As lawmakers learned more about the attack, they were "angry, disappointed, and frustrated" that Petraeus had not provided a more complete picture of the available intelligence. A US intelligence official disputed Petraeus' briefing, stating that the first briefing to lawmakers carefully laid out the full range of available information, noting that extremists, including those with possible links to AQIM and Ansar al-Sharia, were involved in attacks that appeared spontaneous.

The current assessment of the Benghazi attack is that while no one is ruling out the idea that militants may have aspired to attack the US, the bulk of available information supports the early assessment that extremists with ties to Al Qaeda and Ansar al-Sharia did not plan the attacks for day or weeks in advance.

Title: Egyptian Security Forces Crack Down on Muslim Brotherhood Protest Camps, Causing Hundreds of Casualties

Egyptian security forces used armored cars, bulldozers, tear gas, and automatic weapons to clear two protest camps in Cairo set up by Muslim Brotherhood supporters of ousted Islamist President Mohammed Morsi, resulting in hundreds of casualties and at least 149 deaths. The government reported that at least 149 people had been killed and over 1,400 injured.

The smaller of the two camps, located at Nahda Square near Cairo University, was cleared within hours, while the larger camp around the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque in the northeastern suburb of Nasr City was still under siege by mid-morning, with protesters battling against far greater numbers of police.

The Egyptian interim government issued a statement expressing sorrow over the bloodshed and blamed the Muslim Brotherhood for any blood spilled. The government urged protesters to refrain from using violence and warned that authorities would not stand for any attempts to attack state buildings and police stations.

The crackdown had been anticipated, with protesters bracing for the assault. Some protesters were reported to be throwing Molotov cocktails and broken paving stones, while military snipers targeted protesters. There were varying reports about casualties, with Western reporters at several morgues and hospitals seeing dozens of dead protesters with gunshot wounds to the head and chest, indicating that authorities were shooting to kill.

The Muslim Brotherhood claimed that hundreds had been killed by indiscriminate fire from soldiers and police, while the authorities reported about a dozen deaths, including two police officers. The Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights, a human rights group, reported that the crackdown had already sparked attacks by Brotherhood supporters against Coptic Christian churches in southern Egypt.

The events are likely to widen the division between supporters of the Brotherhood and secularists and religious minorities who largely supported the military's July 3 ouster of the Brotherhood-supported Morsi, following mass protests against his rule.

Title: Stephen Moore: Trump's Victory Shifts Republican Party's Focus

Article:

Stephen Moore, a senior economic adviser to Donald Trump and a former libertarian and free-trader, believes that the Republican Party has undergone significant changes since Trump's victory. In an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep, Moore stated that the party is now more focused on populist and working-class issues, which may not align with the views of some conservatives.

Moore, who worked for Ronald Reagan's administration, acknowledged that the country's problems and voter concerns have changed since the 1980s. He believes that Trump's presidency will bring about a shift in the Republican Party's priorities, with a focus on reviving U.S. manufacturing jobs, being tough on China in trade negotiations, and addressing the concerns of industrial Midwestern states.

Regarding Trump's plans to renegotiate trade deals with China and Mexico, Moore expressed hope that the president-elect will not impose 35% tariffs, which he opposes. Instead, he believes that Trump will prioritize fair and free trade, as he has stated in some of his speeches.

Moore also discussed Trump's personal business holdings, stating that he believes the president-elect will put his business dealings aside and prioritize the national interest. He emphasized that Americans will demand this from Trump, and that he will need to make tough decisions to ensure the country's success.

In terms of Trump's promise to bring back jobs to industries like steel and coal, Moore believes that while some jobs may not return, the country can still bring factories and jobs back to the United States with a better tax system and regulatory environment. He emphasized that the country has the best-trained workers, low-cost energy, and a competitive public policy system, making it possible to revive industries like coal mining, steel production, and manufacturing.

Overall, Moore's comments highlight the potential changes in the Republican Party's priorities under Trump's presidency and the challenges and opportunities that come with it.

Title: Minnesota Senator Al Franken Announces Resignation Amidst Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Minnesota Democratic Senator Al Franken has announced his resignation from the U.S. Senate, effective January 2, 2018. Franken's decision comes after a wave of sexual misconduct allegations against him, including claims of groping and forcibly trying to kiss women.

Franken, who has denied some of the allegations, stating that some are "simply not true" and that he remembers others "differently," also took a parting shot at President Trump and Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore. Franken's resignation was met with a mix of reactions from his colleagues, with some Democratic senators and staff members in attendance for the announcement.

Franken's resignation will be filled by a temporary appointment by Minnesota Governor Mark Dayton, with Democratic Lt. Gov. Tina Smith being a likely candidate. The successor will serve until a special election is held in 2018 to determine who will fill the final two years of Franken's term.

The allegations against Franken began with a 2006 incident involving radio broadcaster Leeann Tweeden, who claimed Franken kissed and groped her without her consent. Since then, seven additional women have come forward with similar allegations, including claims of groping and forcibly trying to kiss women.

Franken's political career has been in peril since the allegations surfaced, with many Democratic senators and politicians calling for his resignation. The Minneapolis Star Tribune, the largest newspaper in Franken's home state, called for his immediate resignation, stating that he has "lost the confidence of so many colleagues" and cannot effectively serve in the Senate.

Franken's resignation comes amid a broader conversation about sexual misconduct and accountability, with many politicians and celebrities facing allegations of inappropriate behavior.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Kelly Clarifies Deportation Policy and Encourages Undocumented Residents to Report Crimes

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly has clarified the Trump administration's stance on deportation, stating that anyone in the country illegally is subject to deportation, but "Dreamers" shielded by the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program should not worry. Kelly emphasized that the administration is not targeting individuals who have been granted DACA, but rather focusing on those who are undocumented and have not been granted any legal status.

Kelly also emphasized the importance of reporting crimes, even for undocumented residents. He stated that they should report local offenses, and that they can usually do so anonymously. This comes after law enforcement officials expressed concerns that a drop in reported crimes from certain communities was a result of Trump's immigration policies.

Senator Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, has expressed concerns about the administration's approach, stating that targeting sanctuary cities and refusing to provide funding for a border wall could lead to a government shutdown. Durbin also warned that the administration's demand for funding for the border wall is a "poison pill" that could have negative consequences.

In a statement, Kelly said that the administration is focused on securing the Southwest border and deporting those who are in the country illegally. He emphasized that the administration is not targeting "Dreamers" and that those who are undocumented should report crimes and cooperate with law enforcement.

Overall, Kelly's comments aim to clarify the administration's stance on deportation and encourage undocumented residents to report crimes, while Durbin's concerns highlight the potential consequences of the administration's policies.

**Libertarian Gary Johnson and Green Party's Jill Stein Offer Alternative to Trump and Clinton**

The 2016 presidential election is shaping up to be a unique and unpredictable contest, with Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson and Green Party nominee Jill Stein offering voters an alternative to the traditional choices of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. Both Johnson and Stein are campaigning on a platform of small government and individual freedom, with a focus on issues such as marijuana legalization, gun rights, and limited government intervention in personal affairs.

Gary Johnson, a 63-year-old businessman and former Republican governor of New Mexico, is running alongside his running mate, Bill Weld, a former Republican governor of Massachusetts. Johnson has a background in business, having served as the CEO of a legal cannabis company, and has long supported marijuana legalization. He has pledged not to use the drug if elected.

Jill Stein, a 66-year-old Harvard-trained physician and liberal activist, is running alongside her running mate, human rights activist Ajamu Baraka. Stein is selling herself as the "Plan B" for disaffected Bernie Sanders supporters who are dissatisfied with Hillary Clinton's candidacy. She has expressed support for progressive policies such as a $15-per-hour federal minimum wage, a "wartime-scale mobilization" to combat climate change, and the abolition of student debt.

Both Johnson and Stein are polling at around 10% and 3.4%, respectively, and are desperate to make it into the first presidential debate on September 26. However, they face a steep climb, as a candidate needs to hit 15% in five national polls to qualify for the debate stage. The two candidates are suing the debate commission for the right to participate.

The election is shaping up to be a close contest, with many voters expressing dissatisfaction with both Trump and Clinton. Johnson and Stein are hoping to capitalize on this discontent and attract a significant protest vote. While it is unclear whether they will be able to make a significant impact, their presence in the race is likely to shake up the political landscape and give voters an alternative to the traditional choices.

Title: Senate Immigration Bill Faces Criticism Over Border Security and Enforcement Loopholes

The newly released Senate immigration bill has been met with criticism from some quarters over concerns about border security and enforcement loopholes. The bill, touted as a major investment in border security, has been criticized for giving the government "discretion" to choose when to enforce immigration laws.

The National ICE Council, which represents Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, has long complained that the Obama administration has made their job harder by preventing agents from detaining and deporting select illegal immigrants. In a letter to Senator Marco Rubio, a key member of the "Gang of Eight" lawmakers drafting the bill, National ICE Council President Chris Crane expressed disappointment that the bill does not address their concerns.

Crane noted that the bill focuses mostly on exterior security measures and relies on the discretion of the Department of Homeland Security, despite the agency being in federal court for allegedly undermining the constitutional rule of law. He also expressed concern about the administration's "directives" that release "dangerous criminal aliens" back into the community and the abuse of prosecutorial discretion.

Senator Jeff Sessions, a vocal critic of the immigration bill, echoed Crane's concerns, stating that the bill neglects interior enforcement needs and leaves intact the administration's abuse of prosecutorial discretion to prevent the enforcement of federal law.

The bill does contain provisions for border security and fencing, as well as a set of "triggers" that must be met before illegal immigrants currently in the country can apply for a green card. However, critics argue that legalizing millions of illegal immigrants without establishing a strict system of interior enforcement will allow the problem to persist.

The bill is scheduled to come up for its first hearing on Friday, and Senator Marco Rubio has expressed a willingness to consider revisions. The bill has received bipartisan backing, with some Republicans expressing a willingness to consider an immigration overhaul to leverage the immigrant workforce and cut red tape.

Title: James O'Keefe's Latest Attempt to Mislead the Public Exposed

Article:

James O'Keefe, a well-known conservative activist, has been accused of orchestrating a scheme to deceive the public once again. This time, he allegedly hired a woman, Jaime T. Phillips, to fabricate a story about a sexual relationship with Roy Moore, a Republican Senate candidate, in 1992, which led to an abortion when she was 15. The story was presented to The Washington Post as a dramatic account of an alleged sexual assault.

However, the Post discovered that Phillips was actually working for O'Keefe and Project Veritas, a conservative watchdog group. This revelation has sparked widespread criticism, with many accusing O'Keefe of attempting to discredit Moore's accusers and undermine the credibility of those who have come forward with allegations of sexual misconduct.

In a bizarre twist, O'Keefe claimed to have video evidence of a "confrontation" with a Washington Post reporter who allegedly forced his way into the Project Veritas office. However, the Post obtained footage of the encounter, which showed O'Keefe inviting the reporter to the office and declining to answer questions.

The incident highlights the ongoing controversy surrounding O'Keefe's tactics and the blurred lines between fact and fiction in his reporting. Critics argue that his methods are designed to mislead the public and undermine the credibility of legitimate news organizations.

In response to the allegations, supporters of Roy Moore have been encouraged to donate to Doug Jones, the Democratic candidate running against Moore in the Alabama Senate election, in an effort to promote transparency and truth.

Title: Obama Announces Restrictions on Military-Style Equipment for Local Police Departments

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced new guidelines restricting the transfer of military-style equipment to local law enforcement agencies. The move is aimed at easing tensions between police and minority communities, following several high-profile police-involved shootings. The White House has issued a report outlining the new recommendations, which include banning the sale of tracked armored vehicles, weaponized aircraft, and high-caliber weapons and ammunition to local police departments.

Under the new guidelines, local police departments will still be able to purchase this equipment on their own, but they will no longer be able to acquire it from federal agencies or use federal funds to purchase it. The decision is part of a broader effort to promote community policing and improve relations between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

The President's visit to Camden, New Jersey, where he announced the new guidelines, comes as he seeks to increase federal funding for community policing initiatives. Camden has been one of New Jersey's most crime-ridden cities, but reforms over the past two years have led to a decline in crime rates and an increase in police presence in the community.

The White House has also announced several other initiatives aimed at promoting community policing, including the Police Data Initiative, which will help police departments track data on use of force and police stops. The initiative will also provide data scientists to help some police departments develop an early warning system, using data to flag potential problems. Additionally, the White House will release a body-camera tool kit to help police departments plan and implement body-camera programs.

The Department of Justice will also begin accepting applications for grants designed to advance the practice of community policing in law enforcement agencies, providing funding for hiring, training, and technical assistance, as well as the development of innovative community policing strategies, research, and best practices.

Title: Former Sen. Rick Santorum Launches Second Bid for Presidency, Focusing on Protecting American Workers

Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania has announced his second bid for the presidency, vowing to be a warrior for working-class Americans. At a campaign launch event at Penn United Technologies, a manufacturing company near his boyhood home in Pennsylvania, Santorum emphasized his commitment to protecting American workers and their wages from the impact of unskilled foreign labor.

Santorum, who finished as the runner-up to Mitt Romney in the 2012 Republican nomination race, has been open about his interest in taking another shot at the White House. He promised to offer a "bold" conservative vision, starting with abolishing the IRS and replacing the "corrupt" tax code with a "simple, fair, flat tax." He also vowed to cut government spending, revoke executive orders and regulations that harm American jobs, and prioritize education, military, and pro-life legislation.

Santorum criticized the current immigration policy, stating that the influx of unskilled workers has led to stagnant wages and family incomes. He emphasized that his priority is the American worker, as opposed to the priorities of big business and politicians seeking votes.

Political analysts note that Santorum faces a challenging task in standing out in the crowded nomination race, with a strong field of candidates, including Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson. Santorum will need to make a strong impression in the first GOP-sanctioned debate on August 6, hosted by Fox News, to remain a viable candidate.

Santorum's campaign will focus on a "Take America Back Tour" with stops in Iowa and South Carolina this week. He previously represented part of the Pittsburgh suburbs in the US House from 1991 to 1995 and served in the US Senate from 1995 to 2007, where he held Republican leadership positions until he lost his seat to Democrat Bob Casey in the 2006 election.

Title: Republican Presidential Candidates Criticize CNBC's Debate Moderation, Jeb Bush's Campaign Fizzles

Article:

The third Republican presidential debate, hosted by CNBC, was marked by criticism from candidates and viewers alike over the network's moderation and factual errors. The debate, which took place on October 28, 2015, saw candidates Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and Chris Christie stand out for their strong performances, while Jeb Bush's campaign appeared to suffer a significant blow.

Rubio, Cruz, and Christie all took issue with the debate's format and questions, with Rubio and Cruz delivering strong counter-punches to Bush's attempts to criticize their Senate voting records. Rubio's performance was particularly notable, with him landing a strong blow against Bush and earning applause from the audience.

Bush's campaign, which had been struggling in the polls, failed to gain momentum and was criticized for its lack of substance and inability to effectively respond to questions. The former Florida governor's attempts to take shots at Rubio and other opponents were met with strong pushback, and his campaign's overall performance was seen as lackluster.

Other candidates, including Donald Trump and Ben Carson, had some strong moments, with Trump drawing attention and laughs with his responses and Carson delivering a solid answer on his stance on homosexuality and marriage. However, both candidates were also criticized for their responses to questions, with Trump denying statements he had made on his website and Carson facing questions about his involvement with a company accused of unethical practices.

The debate was widely panned by viewers and critics, with many calling it a "trainwreck" and criticizing the network's handling of the event. The debate's poor performance may have marked the beginning of the end for Jeb Bush's campaign, which had been struggling to gain traction in the polls.

Title: Bloomberg's Unorthodox Strategy: A Game-Changer in the Democratic Primary?

Article:

Bernie Sanders' campaign had built a significant operation in California, but billionaire Mike Bloomberg's late entry into the race has changed the dynamics. Within two months, Bloomberg hired 200 employees in California, dwarfing Sanders' 80-strong team in the state. Bloomberg's massive spending on television ads has also given him an edge, with over a quarter-billion dollars spent nationwide since November.

Bloomberg's unorthodox strategy involves skipping Iowa and three other states that vote in February, instead focusing on larger, delegate-rich states that will start voting from March. This approach has been tried before, but none had the financial might of Bloomberg. His spending onslaught has already shown signs of paying off, with him rising to third nationally among Democratic and independent voters in the latest poll.

California is the single biggest prize of the presidential primary, with 10 times as many delegates available as in Iowa. Bloomberg's campaign has 800 staffers in place across 35 states, with hundreds more at his campaign headquarters in New York. In Texas, he has a staff of 150, while Warren has more than two dozen paid staffers.

Bloomberg's spending spree has also inflated the cost of television ads in Texas, making it harder for other candidates to keep up. The other candidates' Super Tuesday operations will soon get an influx of staffers as organizers depart states like Iowa to bolster efforts elsewhere.

Warren's campaign has more than 1,000 staff members and more than 100 field offices in 31 states, with hundreds of organizers in states that vote after Super Tuesday. Sanders is relying on enthusiastic volunteers, with over 560 events held in Texas alone.

Bloomberg's campaign has 800 staffers in place across 35 states, with hundreds more at his campaign headquarters in New York. In an interview, Bloomberg said he was forced to skip the first four voting states because "all the political operatives were taken up" by the time he decided to enter the race. However, he vowed to go everywhere else.

The contrast between Bloomberg's approach and that of his rivals highlights the risks and opportunities of his unorthodox strategy. While some see it as a game-changer, others believe it may not be enough to overcome the challenges he faces. Only time will tell if Bloomberg's spending spree will pay off and give him a strong position heading into the general election.

Title: Bloomberg News Editor-in-Chief Addresses Potential Conflicts of Interest in Coverage of Michael Bloomberg's Presidential Campaign

Bloomberg News Editor-in-Chief John Micklethwait has issued a note to staff addressing the challenges and potential conflicts of interest that come with covering former Mayor Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign. Bloomberg News, a leading news organization, is owned by Michael Bloomberg, the Democratic presidential candidate.

Micklethwait acknowledged that covering the campaign will be a complex task, given the newsroom's reputation for independence and its editorial board's close ties to Bloomberg. He noted that the newsroom will need to balance its coverage of the campaign with the need to maintain its independence and adhere to electoral laws.

To address potential conflicts of interest, Micklethwait announced that the editorial board responsible for Bloomberg Opinion will take a leave of absence to join Bloomberg's campaign. The board will be suspended, and unsigned editorials will not be published during the campaign. Columnists will continue to write and publish their own opinions, and the newsroom will continue to accept op-eds from outside contributors, excluding those on the election.

Bloomberg News will maintain its tradition of not investigating Michael Bloomberg, his family, or his foundation, and will extend this policy to his Democratic primary rivals. However, if other news outlets publish investigative pieces on Bloomberg or his opponents, Bloomberg News will not "hide" them from readers.

Micklethwait also noted that the newsroom will continue to investigate the Trump administration, as it is the current government. If Bloomberg is chosen as the Democratic presidential candidate and Trump emerges as the Republican candidate, the newsroom will reassess its approach to covering the campaign.

The note was obtained by CNN and provides insight into the challenges and considerations that Bloomberg News will face in covering its owner's presidential campaign.

Title: White House Mutes Gun Control Groups in Effort to Present United Front on New Laws

The White House has implemented a strategy to ensure a united front on gun control measures, offering gun control groups access and involvement in discussions in exchange for their silence and support. The implied rules, according to conversations with those involved, include no infighting, no second-guessing in the press, and support for whatever the president and Vice President Joe Biden propose. In return, the groups receive a voice in the discussions, a role in the final agreement, and weekly meetings with Biden's chief of staff, Bruce Reed.

The White House's goal is to present a united front as President Barack Obama pushes for new laws, and to avoid shouldering the blame if and when the negotiations fail. The strategy has forced a major change on some of Washington's noisiest advocates, including the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, Third Way, Mayors Against Illegal Guns, and Americans for Responsible Solutions.

Despite the dimming hopes for any legislation, including the recent end of bipartisan talks on universal background checks, gun control groups are still holding out hope that something might happen. Paul Helmke, former president of the Brady Campaign, stated, "We need the White House." The White House's strategy has brought gun control groups together, providing them with a voice in the discussions and a role in the final agreement, in exchange for their silence and support.

Title: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton Responds to Benghazi Questions, Faces Criticism from Senator Ron Johnson

Article:

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton faced intense questioning on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, with Wisconsin Republican Senator Ron Johnson accusing the Obama administration of initially misleading the nation about the attack on the U.S. mission in Benghazi, Libya, last September. Clinton responded with a strong defense, expressing righteous outrage and frustration with the criticism.

During the exchange, Clinton showed emotion as she addressed Johnson's questions about what the administration knew about the attack and when it knew it. She emphasized the importance of figuring out what happened and preventing similar incidents in the future. The exchange was captured on C-SPAN's video library, with two clips available online.

Clinton is set to step down as Secretary of State soon, with President Obama nominating Senator John Kerry to replace her. The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will hold a confirmation hearing for Kerry today at 10 a.m. ET, with Senator Robert Menendez presiding. It is expected that Kerry will face little opposition in the Senate. Clinton is scheduled to introduce Kerry at the hearing.

Title: White House Press Secretary Encourages Reporters to Watch Controversial Video, Playboy Correspondent Pushes Back

The White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, recently told the press corps to watch a video from conservative provocateur James O'Keefe, stating that it is "whether it's accurate or not." The video in question features a CNN producer, John Bonifield, criticizing the network's handling of the Trump-Russia story. However, the taping of Bonifield without his knowledge has raised ethical concerns.

The sequence of events began when a reporter from Breitbart, a right-wing website, asked Sanders about the recent controversy surrounding CNN's retraction of a story alleging a meeting between a Trump campaign staffer and a Russian investment fund. Sanders used this opportunity to reiterate her complaints about the mainstream media and encouraged reporters to watch the O'Keefe video.

The video shows Bonifield expressing frustration with CNN's coverage of the Trump-Russia story, stating that it was "bad" and "silly." However, it is unclear whether the video is accurate or not, as Bonifield was taped without his knowledge.

In response to Sanders' comments, a Playboy correspondent, Brian J. Karem, interrupted her, saying that the administration's actions are also inflaming the situation. Karem argued that the media is simply trying to do its job and that the audience has the option to turn the channel or not read the news if they disagree.

Sanders responded by stating that the dishonesty in the news media is what is being inflamed, and that the media's actions are causing harm to the country. The exchange highlights the ongoing tensions between the Trump administration and the media, with both sides accusing each other of dishonesty and bias.

Title: A Pattern of Sore Losers: A Historical Analysis of Democratic Presidential Candidates

The article discusses the alleged characteristic of Democratic presidential candidates being sore losers, with the exception of Barack Obama, who is described as a sore winner. The author claims that every Democratic presidential candidate since Jimmy Carter has complained about the election being stolen from them, with Hillary Clinton being the most recent example. The article highlights the losses of Jimmy Carter, Al Gore, John Kerry, and Hillary Clinton, and how they have all continued to express discontent with the results.

The article also mentions Richard Nixon's 1960 loss to John F. Kennedy, which is presented as an example of a Republican candidate accepting the results of the election. The author notes that American historians have a negative view of Nixon, but does not provide any further context or explanation.

The article's tone is critical of Democratic presidential candidates, portraying them as sore losers who are unable to accept the results of the election. The author's language is informal and conversational, with a focus on storytelling and anecdotal evidence rather than rigorous analysis or fact-checking. The article does not provide any concrete evidence or statistics to support its claims, and its tone is more opinion-based than objective.

Title: US Closes Lahore Consulate in Pakistan Due to Specific Threat, Moves Personnel to Islamabad

The United States has closed its consulate in Lahore, Pakistan, and relocated non-essential personnel to the embassy in Islamabad due to a specific threat against the consulate. The decision was made as a precautionary measure, according to US Embassy spokeswoman Meghan Gregonis.

The consulate was already closed for Eid al-Fitr, a festive holiday marking the end of the holy month of Ramadan, but it will not reopen on Monday and no date has been set for its reopening. The move is unrelated to the recent closure of 19 US diplomatic posts in the Middle East and Africa.

Pakistan has been experiencing a spate of extremist attacks against its targets, with various groups linked to Al Qaeda opposing the country's alliance with the US. The Pakistani government has received intelligence that militants plan to attack key locations in the city, including the airport and parliament building.

In recent days, there have been several violent incidents in Pakistan. On Friday, gunmen opened fire on worshipers leaving a mosque in the western city of Quetta, killing 10 people who had come to offer prayers for the Eid al-Fitr festival. On Thursday, a suicide bomber attacked the funeral of a police officer killed by militants, killing at least 30 people, including 21 police personnel.

The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack in Quetta, saying it was revenge for a police raid on an allied group. The violence has "rattled" the government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who has vowed to show the militants an "iron fist" and has announced that his government's counterterrorism policy will be ready next week.

The lack of a national counterterrorism strategy has resulted in confusion and a lack of consensus on how to deal with the terrorists, with opposition politicians urging the government to immediately convene a national conference of all political parties to come to a policy consensus.

Title: House Committee Chairmen Request Special Counsel to Investigate FBI and Justice Department's Handling of Clinton and Trump Probes

Article:

Two House committee chairmen, Trey Gowdy and Bob Goodlatte, have written a six-page letter to Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, requesting a special counsel to evaluate the Justice Department and Federal Bureau of Investigation's handling of probes into Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump during the 2016 election. The letter highlights concerns about the FBI's decision not to prosecute Clinton for her improper use of government email and the agency's handling of the investigation into Trump's campaign and possible collusion with Russians.

The chairmen, who are set to lose power when the Republicans slip into the minority next year, have been investigating the agencies for over a year, reviewing thousands of documents and interviewing key witnesses. They concluded that former FBI Director James Comey acted improperly when he cleared Clinton of wrongdoing, and some witnesses, including FBI General Counsel James Baker, did not back the exoneration.

The letter invites the attention of Whitaker and McConnell to the transcripts of witness testimony and encourages them to continue investigating the matter. The chairmen had previously asked former Attorney General Jeff Sessions to appoint a special counsel to evaluate the matter in March, but he declined and instead appointed U.S. Attorney John Huber with the task. Huber is still conducting the review, according to the lawmakers.

The letter also raises concerns about the FBI's handling of the probe into Trump's campaign and possible collusion with Russians, specifically calling out the bias of federal agents and their different treatment of the candidates during the election. The chairmen are concerned about how derogatory information about Trump was accessed by the FBI, the sourcing of such information, the vetting of such information, and government reliance on it in court pleadings.

The lawmakers' request comes after they questioned former FBI Director James Comey and former Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Capitol Hill earlier this month. Comey criticized the closed-door hearing, saying it harms the integrity of the FBI, and also used the opportunity to criticize the president.

Title: Buzzfeed Secures $50 Million Investment from Andreeson Horowitz to Expand Operations

Buzzfeed, a popular internet media company, has received a $50 million investment from venture capitalists Andreeson Horowitz. The company plans to use the funds to expand its content offerings, increase its video production capabilities, and open new offices worldwide. According to Chris Dixon, a partner at Andreeson Horowitz, Buzzfeed has emerged as a "preeminent media company."

Founded in 2006, Buzzfeed started as an aggregator of light-hearted lists, videos, and quizzes that users could share on social media. Its user-friendly layout and colloquial tone made it a hit among young people and office workers looking for entertainment. Recently, the company has shifted its focus to current affairs, hiring a team of journalists to blend its irreverent style with hard news.

Buzzfeed's audience is growing, with 75% of its hits coming from social media referrals on Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest. The site receives roughly four times more viewers per month than The New York Times and was valued more than three times higher than The Washington Post, which was acquired by Jeff Bezos for $250 million this year.

Andreeson Horowitz partner Chris Dixon explained that the company invested in Buzzfeed because it is "disruptive," changing the landscape of online media. One reason for its success is its understanding of the internet and its users. All of Buzzfeed's content is available on and formatted for mobile devices, targeting people who browse while standing in a queue or commuting to work.

The company plans to use the new funds to invest in Buzzfeed Motion Pictures, its video unit based in Los Angeles. The unit will focus on producing videos ranging from six seconds to one hour documentaries. Buzzfeed's videos are already popular and often get picked up by mainstream media sites. With this investment, the company may even produce a movie version of its popular "23 Ways to Have the Coolest Locker in School" quiz.

Title: Study Reveals Growing Climate Polarization in the US, WSJ Coverage Found to be Lacking in Climate Science

A recent study by sociologists at Oklahoma State University has found that political polarization on climate change is on the rise in the United States. The study, published in the journal Environmental Politics, analyzed data from 2010 to 2019 and found that Republicans are less likely to accept the scientific consensus on climate change than they were a decade ago. Democrats and independents, on the other hand, are slightly more likely to answer questions about climate change correctly.

The study also found that climate change is now more polarizing than issues such as abortion and gay marriage. Republicans have become increasingly anti-environmental, with nearly unanimous opposition to environmental legislation in recent years. This has led to a lack of motivation among Republican policymakers to address the issue, as they prioritize their constituents' concerns over the long-term viability of the planet.

The study notes that public perception and priorities are heavily influenced by media coverage. A 2013 study found that conservative media consumers are more likely to distrust scientific experts and reject climate science realities. A recent report by Media Matters found that the Wall Street Journal's climate coverage is riddled with misinformation, with 33% of opinion pieces published during the study period featuring climate science denial or inaccurate claims about climate change.

The study also highlights the role of the fossil fuel industry in perpetuating climate denial. The industry has created an echo chamber in which they control the climate messaging of conservative media and party leaders, which trickles down to misinform Republican voters and grows the partisan gap on climate change.

The authors of the study see no easy way to break through the "denial countermovement," consisting of fossil fuel corporations, business allies, conservative think tanks, and conservative media. Until the fossil fuel industry's control over conservative policymakers and media loosens, American climate action will be up to the Democratic Party.

The study's findings suggest that there is plenty of blame to go around, with Republican policymakers failing to deliver much-needed leadership on climate change, American conservatives relying too heavily on biased media sources, and conservative media outlets like the Wall Street Journal misinforming their readers.

Title: A Call to Refuse the "Butt Defense" in National Discourse

The start of a new year often brings a sense of renewal and a chance to reflect on personal and national discourse. Unfortunately, the latter has become mired in a cycle of finger-pointing and blame-shifting, rather than constructive conversation. The author of this article suggests that one way to break this cycle is to abandon the "Butt Defense," a tactic often employed in personal and political discussions.

The author, who has implemented this approach with their own children, notes that it is essential to take responsibility for one's actions and reactions. In their household, the "Butt Defense" was a common excuse used by children to deflect accountability, often resulting in further conflict. The author proposes that this same approach can be applied to national discourse, encouraging individuals to focus on their own actions and reactions rather than blaming others.

The author argues that the "Butt Defense" is a major obstacle to constructive dialogue, as it prevents individuals from acknowledging and addressing the root causes of problems. By refusing to defend what is indefensible and calling out hateful or atrocious actions for what they are, individuals can help diminish the impact of extreme elements on all sides.

The author concludes that this approach is not a panacea, but it is a step in the right direction. By taking responsibility for our own actions and reactions, we can begin to move forward and create a more constructive national discourse.

Title: Google Removes 200 Publishers from Ad Network, Cracks Down on Fake News Sites

Google has removed approximately 200 publishers from its AdSense network, a move aimed at combating the proliferation of fake news sites. The ban was part of an update to an existing policy prohibiting sites that mislead users with their content. Google regularly weeds out advertisers for false or misleading claims, but the recent ban focused on impersonating news sites, particularly those with shortened top-level domains that mimic legitimate news organizations.

The removals occurred in November and December, with affected publishers including sites that impersonate real news organizations through shortened top-level domains, such as ".co" domains that appear similar to legitimate news sites ending in ".com." Google declined to provide a list of the banned sites.

The company's annual report on advertising policy violations also revealed that it removed 1.7 billion ads in 2016, a significant increase from the 780 million ads removed in 2015. The rise in ad removals is attributed to a combination of advertiser behavior and improvements in technology to detect offending ads.

Additionally, Google prohibited ads for payday loans, considered predatory, and disabled roughly five million such ads in the latter half of 2016. The company also suspended 1,300 accounts engaged in "tabloid cloaking," where advertisers run links to news headlines that appear legitimate but actually promote products like weight loss supplements.

Google's efforts to combat fake news sites and misleading advertising are part of its ongoing commitment to maintaining a trustworthy and safe online environment for users.

Title: National Parks and Museums Close Amid Government Shutdown, But It's Not the End of the World

The recent government shutdown has led to the closure of several national parks and museums, sparking concerns about the impact on tourists and the environment. However, a closer look reveals that the situation is not as dire as it seems.

The shutdown, which began on December 21, has affected agencies that rely on funding, including the National Park Service. While some parks remained open initially, they were without staff, maintenance workers, and other employees who have been furloughed. As a result, trash has accumulated, and restrooms have become dirty. In response, officials have closed Sequoia, Kings Canyon, and Joshua Tree National Parks in California, as well as parts of Yosemite.

In Washington, D.C., the Smithsonian and the National Gallery of Art remained open using leftover funds, but those funds have since run out, and the Smithsonian announced that its museums and the National Zoo will close. The National Gallery's status is still uncertain.

The closures have caused inconvenience for tourists who had planned trips around these parks and museums. However, there are many privately run institutions that are not affected by the government shutdown. In D.C., for example, the Phillips Collection, the National Building Museum, and the Newseum remain open. Additionally, California has a state park system that offers alternative options for outdoor enthusiasts.

The supposed "trashing" of the parks is also not as severe as reported. The main concerns are litter, dirty bathrooms, and people relieving themselves in the wrong places. While these issues are unpleasant, they can be easily addressed once furloughed employees return to work.

In conclusion, while the government shutdown has caused some inconvenience, it's not the end of the world. The closures are largely a result of the classification of national parks and museums as "non-essential" services, which are not as critical as those deemed "essential" like law enforcement and healthcare. Once the shutdown is resolved, the parks and museums will reopen, and the issues will be addressed.

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Face Recall Efforts After Passing Gun-Control Measures

Article: Colorado state lawmakers who supported the passage of some of the toughest gun-control laws in the country are now facing recall efforts. Two groups, Pueblo Freedom and Rights Group, are targeting state Rep. Mike McLachlan, state Sens. Angela Giron, Evie Hudak, and John Morse. The lawmakers passed bills in March that banned magazines holding more than 15 rounds and required background checks for all gun transfers, which were signed into law by Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper.

The recall efforts will require signatures from 25 percent of the vote in each lawmaker's district to trigger a special election. The signature deadline is May 21, and the Colorado Secretary of State's office has confirmed that it has approved the petition forms.

State Sen. John Morse, the Senate president, had pushed a more far-reaching proposal that would have held owners, sellers, and makers of assault-type weapons liable for the havoc inflicted by their guns. However, he pulled the bill after realizing he didn't have enough votes. Despite this, his efforts have still drawn the ire of the groups organizing the recall efforts.

In addition to the recall efforts, the legislature also passed a bill before adjourning on Friday that prohibits domestic-violence offenders from owning guns. Hickenlooper is expected to sign the legislation.

The recall efforts are not unique to Colorado, as Connecticut, Maryland, and New York have also passed tighter gun-control measures following the December 2012 mass shooting at a Connecticut school that killed 20 first-graders and six adults. However, there are no indications of organized recall efforts in those Democratic-leaning states.

State Sen. Evie Hudak has also faced criticism for a comment she made to a rape victim testifying against a bill that would have banned concealed weapons on college campuses. Hudak suggested that the attacker might have used a gun on the woman had she been carrying a concealed weapon, saying "statistics are not on your side even if you had a gun."

**North Korea's Threats Against South Korea: Mostly Bluffing, Says Expert**

A recent series of "provocations" by North Korea has raised concerns about the country's intentions, but according to expert Stephan Haggard, the threats are mostly bluster and bluffing. Haggard suggests that North Korea's escalating signals of resolve may be driven by domestic politics rather than a genuine desire to attack.

The expert notes that North Korea's pursuit of nuclear and missile capabilities remains a concern, but the country's rhetoric may be more about posturing than actual military action. The "withdrawal" from the armistice agreement between North and South Korea is not a significant change, as the armistice is not a peace treaty, but rather a cease-fire agreement.

North Korea's decision to renege on agreements with South Korea, such as the denuclearization of the peninsula, is unfortunate but not surprising, given its pursuit of nuclear weapons. The country's bluster had little impact on the UN debate, and the recent sanctions resolution was passed unanimously, with China also signing on.

Haggard suggests that North Korea's rhetoric may be driven by domestic politics, as Kim Jong Un's authority is not yet fully consolidated. The expert notes that the country's exercises and threats of retaliation have been successful in deterring attack, even though none was coming, and that the regime can claim a victory in "staring down" American threats.

The expert concludes that North Korea's nuclear and missile programs are a problem that requires concerted action from the five parties in the region, but overheated rhetoric is not the same as an intention to attack. Maintaining a cool head and not over-reacting to hyperbole is the proper course of action, and the leadership should pivot away from nuclear posturing toward economic reform, which is what the people of North Korea really need.

Title: Tunisia Mourns After Deadly Museum Attack, Islamic State Claims Responsibility

The National Bardo Museum in Tunis, the birthplace of the Arab Spring democracy movement, was the site of a deadly attack on Wednesday, leaving 21 people dead, including 17 foreign tourists. The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the attack, but the link to any specific terrorist group remains unclear.

The two gunmen, identified as Yassine Laabidi and Hatem Khachnaoui, were killed by police during a raid. Twelve of the dead were passengers on the MSC Splendida and five from the Costa Fascinosa, who were visiting the museum when the gunmen stormed it. The attack has led to the cancellation of future arrivals scheduled for Tunisia by five major ship companies.

Tunisians took to the streets in solidarity, holding a moment of silence and singing the national anthem outside the museum. Culture Minister Latifa Lakhdar spoke defiantly, stating that the attackers are targeting knowledge, science, reason, history, and memory.

The Islamic State released an online recording claiming responsibility for the attack, praising the "knights of the Islamic State" and calling the museum a "den of infidels and vice." The Tunisian government estimates that over 3,000 Tunisians have joined Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria, with training camps in neighboring Libya providing easy access to the fight for Tunisian Muslims discontent with the fledgling democracy in Tunis.

The attack has sent shockwaves around the world, with the U.S. First Lady Michelle Obama expressing condolences over the "horrific event" in Tunisia. The National Bardo Museum, which attracts art lovers and tourists from around the world, was the site of the attack, with Japanese tourist Noriko Yuki, 35, describing the chaos and horror of the incident.

Title: Obama Apologizes to Americans Who Lost Health Insurance, Despite Previous Assurances

President Barack Obama apologized to Americans who have lost their health insurance, acknowledging that they were misled about being able to keep their plans under the Affordable Care Act (ACA). In an exclusive interview with NBC News at the White House, Obama expressed regret for the situation, stating, "I am sorry that they are finding themselves in this situation based on assurances they got from me."

The apology comes after the administration added a grandfathering caveat to its healthcare pitch, clarifying that individuals who had or have a plan before the ACA's passage can keep it if it hasn't changed since the law's passage. However, millions of Americans are still receiving cancellation notices, with estimates suggesting that 50-75% of the 14 million individuals who buy health insurance individually will receive such notices in the next year.

The Obama administration has been denying claims that the President misled millions of people about keeping their health insurance plans, despite reports from NBC News and other major news outlets that the White House knew for years that cancellation letters would be issued. The administration has known about the cancellations for about three years, according to NBC News.

Democratic Senators on Capitol Hill are working to pass legislation that would allow millions of Americans who received cancellation notices to get their healthcare plans back. It remains unclear whether President Obama is willing to support this effort. Meanwhile, 67% of Americans in the individual health insurance market are expected to lose their current health plans as insurance companies comply with Obamacare requirements under the law.
