A protest organized by Take Back Kentucky, which aimed to "celebrate freedom and fight back against the unconstitutional shutdown over the coronavirus," took place on Sunday outside the Kentucky state capitol. The approximately 100 attendees began by celebrating the Second Amendment, but the rally eventually turned into a call against coronavirus restrictions. Protestors marched to Governor Andy Beshear's house, shouting "Come out Andy," and later returned to the state capitol, where some participants hung an effigy of the governor from a tree. The effigy featured a picture of Beshear's face and a message that read "sic temper tyrannis," a Latin phrase translating to "thus always to tyrants." The effigy was removed shortly after.

The protest's actions sparked swift backlash from both sides of the political aisle. Senate Majority Leader and Republican Senator Mitch McConnell condemned the effigy in a statement, saying that while he supports the First Amendment, the actions went too far. "As a strong defender of the First Amendment, I believe Americans have the right to peacefully protest. However, today's action toward Governor Beshear is unacceptable. There is no place for hate in Kentucky," McConnell stated.

Other politicians, including Republican Secretary of State Michael G. Adams and Democratic Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer, also condemned the effigy hanging. The Kentucky House Democrats issued a lengthy statement calling the act "beyond reprehensible."

Title: Biden's Media Strategy Criticized for Avoiding Tough Questions

Article: Joe Concha, a media reporter for The Hill, has criticized presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's media strategy, stating that the former vice president has been avoiding tough questions by only facing handpicked questions from safe outlets in controlled situations. Concha made these comments on Fox & Friends, citing Biden's recent interview with Charlamagne Tha God on "The Breakfast Club" as an example of how the campaign wants to avoid similar situations.

During the interview, Biden made controversial comments on race relations, saying "I tell you, if you have a problem figuring out whether you're for me or Trump, then you ain't black." He later walked back the remarks, stating "I shouldn't have been so cavalier." Concha believes that Biden's campaign wants to present a "scripted or homogenized" version of the candidate, avoiding any unscripted or impromptu interactions that might lead to controversy.

Biden has not held a press conference in 77 days, and Concha argues that this is a deliberate strategy to avoid difficult questions. The media reporter believes that Biden's campaign is trying to present a version of the candidate that is different from his past self, stating, "We don't want extemporaneous Joe Biden because that's where he always gets in trouble."

Meanwhile, Biden remains ahead in the polls, with majorities of Americans citing racism, unemployment, and the coronavirus as major threats to the country's stability, according to a recent Fox News poll. The poll also found that Biden supporters are more likely to say they are voting against Trump rather than for Biden, while Trump supporters are more likely to say they are voting for him rather than against Biden.

**Facebook Takes Steps to Combat Deepfakes, But Critics Say Policy Falls Short**

In the lead-up to the presidential election, Facebook has announced steps to combat deepfakes, videos manipulated using artificial intelligence to make it appear as though someone has said or done something they haven't. The social media giant will ban videos that are "edited or synthesized" to deceive users, but will allow parody and satire. However, critics argue that the policy is too narrow and fails to address the broader issue of disinformation.

Deepfakes are videos doctored using cutting-edge AI to distort reality. The technology, which analyzes real images to generate fake ones, is a growing form of disinformation and social media platforms have been struggling with how to deal with it. Facebook and other tech companies are sponsoring a "Deepfake Detection Challenge" to encourage AI researchers to develop new ways to automatically detect doctored videos.

The ability to create fake videos or manipulate existing videos has been around for decades, but powerful new technologies are making it cheaper, faster, and easier to produce deepfakes that are "nearly indistinguishable from reality." Experts warn that the proliferation of deepfakes poses a significant threat to democracy, as they can be used to mislead voters and erode trust in institutions.

To detect deepfakes, experts recommend being constantly on the alert for videos, images, and audio that have been altered. Some tell-tale signs include low-resolution or grainy video, single-person talking in the video, and inconsistencies in the background. However, as deepfake technology rapidly improves, AI techniques will be needed to detect what the human eye can't.

While there are non-technical ways to sniff out deepfakes, such as verifying the publisher's credibility and checking for sources, experts agree that detection is an ongoing arms race. As people develop more accurate detection algorithms, fakers will develop even more sophisticated frauds.
